name: Fort Zachary Taylor Historic State Park
description: There are two short trails in the park; the Sand Hog Trail, located near the beach, loops through an area of native trees and vegetation typically found along the coast in the Florida Keys. Several interpretive plaques identify various plants and provide interesting information that you may not know. The other trail, Fort View Trail, takes you through a small section of tropical hammock that overlooks the fort and moat. The native trees provide essential food and habitat needed for many of the migratory bird species that frequent this area. Fort Taylor is the last stop for many of these species that get the rest and re-nourishment needed before continuing their migratory journey. Birds that have never before been seen in the United States, have been spotted at Fort Taylor and usually along the Fort View Trail.

name: Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park
description:
Connect with the Hawaii of days past and enjoy the peace and serenity as you stroll along on the self-guided tour through the Royal Grounds and the Pu'uhonua.For those wanting to explore further, the backcountry trail offers a 2 mile round trip hike along the 1871 trail through the agricultural areas that surround the park.This ancient trail existed long before Europeans arrived in Hawaii and originally connected coastal villages along the South Kona Coast. In the 1800's the trail was expanded to accommodate those traveling in horse-drawn carriages.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Hawai'i Volcanoes
description:
The true character of the park is best discovered on foot. With over 150 miles of trails in the park, exploration by walking and hiking can be a fascinating and enjoyable experience.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Kaloko-Honokohau National Historical Park
description:
Walk along the footpaths used by Hawaiian people years ago. Take the Mamalahoa Trail and imagine what it would be like to lead your donkeys laden with produce on your way to the market. Take a portion of the Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail past heiau and house platforms that remain from long ago. The more recent Ala Hele Ike Trail will lead you from the visitor center to Honokohau Beach, passing native plants and stone walls and a corral that remains from the ranching days of the past as you hike along the trail.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Kekaha Kai (Kona Coast) State Park
description:
Kekaha Kai (Kona Coast) State Park is a diverse area with a sandy beach in one location and the 342-foot high Pu'u Ku'ili cinder cone in another. Swimming, sunbathing and other beach related activities are common here. Amenities include restrooms, picnic tables and trash cans.

The park's 4.5-mile hike offers beautiful views of the coastline, Kua Bay, the summit of Pu'u Ku'ili and various streams and flora.

name: 'Akaka Falls State Park
description: The famous 65-acre 'Akaka Falls State Park is home to the  'Akaka Falls which plunge 442 feet into a beautiful gorge. The park's self-guided walk, the 'Akaka Falls Loop Trail will take you by the scenic vista points that overlook the cascading Kahuna Falls and the 'Akaka Falls. The walk may take up to 30 minutes. The level of difficulty is easy.

name: Hapuna Beach State Recreation Area
description:
The Hapuna Beach State Recreation Area is a 61.8-acre beach area. It is a popular location for swimming, bodysurfing, sunbathing, expert surfing or picnicking. Dangerous rip tides and waves may occur so keep watch on children and inexperienced swimmers. Hikers are also welcome and common here. The park amenities include lifeguard services, restrooms, picnic areas, trash cans and drinking water.

The hiking trail on the property is the Ala Kahakai Trail (Kawaihae-Anaehoomalu). It is a moderately graded difficulty with a 30 foot elevation gain. This is a beautiful coastal hike with scenic views of ancient fishermen's trails, pristine shorelines, anachialine ponds and sea cliffs.

name: Pu'ukohola Heiau National Historic Site
description:
In addition to the Park's loop trail (1/2 mile), many visitors enjoy hiking south from the Park along the Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail. A nice section is from the Park to Mau'umae Beach (about 3/4 mile). For more the adventurous, you can walk further to Hapuna Beach (about 3 miles).<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Kalopa State Recreation Area
description: At 2,000 feet elevation, Kalopa State Recreation Area is a 100 acre site that is a great place for camping, picnicking and an easy family hike. The park features a native 'ohi'a forest. The park includes a 2 mile horse loop and the Kalopa Nature Trail. The nature trail is a 0.7 mile loop of easy difficulty. The trail winds through the native 'ohi'a rainforest. 25 different species of trees, shrubs and vines can be seen along the trail.  Restrooms, picnic tables, camping sites, trash cans and drinking water are located on the property.

name: Polipoli Spring State Recreation Area
description:
Polipoli Spring State Recreation Area is located at about a 6,200 ft elevation. The views of Central and West Maui, Kaho'olawe, Moloka'i and Lana'i are arguably unmatched when the the air is clear, but the park is in the fog belt of the Kula Forest Reserve. The fog is a minor set back though because the various hiking trails and the forest landscapes are incredible. Park managers advise that the visitor wear brightly colored clothing during pig and fowl hunting seasons. The park's amenities include restrooms, lodging and trash cans.

Four hiking trails run through the park: The Haleakala Ridge Trail, The Plum Trail, The Polipoli Trail and the Redwood Trail which when combined make up a 3.5 mile loop.

name: Haleakala National Park
description:
The summit area of Haleakala National Park has over 30 miles (48 km) of hiking trails. Trails range from just 10 minutes to long overnight trips. You might hike in the native shrubland, looking for native forest birds and endemic plants, or in the aeolian cinder desert, exploring the geologic history of the summit.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Wai'anapanapa State Park
description:
The remote Wai'anapanapa State Park is located along the low-cliffed volcanic coastline. Seabird watching is common as are other activities such as picnicking, camping, shore fishing and hiking. The park has several beautiful natural features including the native hala forest, a cave, an ancient religious temple, sea stacks and a small black sand beach. The park amenities include restrooms, camping, outdoor showers, trash cans and drinking water.

The hiking trail on the property is the Ke Ala Loa O Maui/Piilani Trail. The level of difficulty is moderate and the elevation gain is 200 feet. The rugged coastal trails takes you through views of the Hana Coast and Slopes of Haleakala.

name: Diamond Head State Monument
description:
Diamond Head State Monument is home to Diamond Head, the name of a 760-foot extinct volcanic peak, also known as a volcanic tuff cone. This is Hawaii's most recognized landmark and one of the United States' common landmarks. The park offers a hiking trail and beautiful coastal views. Restrooms, vending machines, trashcans, lookouts, interpretive signs, drinking water and picnic areas are all offered for the visitors convenience.

The popular hiking trail on the property is the Diamond Head Summit Trail. It is only 1.6 miles, but the hike takes about 2 hours depending on level of experience. You will gain 560 feet. The trail is marked as moderate difficulty.

name: Wa'ahila Ridge State Recreation Area
description:
Wa'ahila Ridge State Recreation Area is located on a Norfolk Island pine forested ridge. There are beautiful views of the Manoa and Palolo valleys. Picnicking is a popular activity here, as well as family hiking. The park amenities include restrooms, picnic tables, a hiking trail, trash cans and drinking water.

The Wa'ahila Ridge Trail is located at the park and is a beautiful 2.4 mile trek of a moderate to difficult level of experience. The hike offers great views of the native forest and wildlife. The hiker will gain 500 feet of elevation.

name: Ka Iwi State Scenic Shoreline
description: Ka Iwi State Scenic Shoreline has a 1 mile hike that leads the visitor to the historic Makapuu lighthouse. During the hike you will see beautiful panoramic views of the southeastern O'ahu coastline. Whale sightings are common. The state shoreline offers no amenities so be sure to pack supplies.

name: Keaiwa Heiau State Recreation Area
description: Keaiwa Heiau State Recreation Area is a 384-acre park with beautiful Norfolk pine groves and eucalyptus trees. Camping is a very popular activity in the forested setting. Like most parks in this area, the views are nothing short of spectacular. There are a few moderate level hikes offered at the park with a variety of views from streams to B-24 bomber remnants. The 'Aiea Loop Trail is a 4.8 mile trail that will take 2.5 to 3 hours to complete.

name: Manana Trail
description: Manana Trail is a 5 mile hiking trail in Pearl City, Hawaii.

name: Ahupua'a O Kahana State Park
description: Kahana is an unbelievably unspoiled valley of ancient Hawaii. The nearly 5,300-acre park has views from the sea to the mountains. Since the valley is so well-preserved, there are extensive remnants of ancient Hawaiian culture including temples, shrines, homesites. stone walls and irrigation channels. There are a few hiking trails on the property that are fairly easy, but they can be muddy due to the common rain of the valley. Camping is also permitted. The two hiking trails at the park offers stunning views of Kahana Bay, koa trees, tropical rain forest and Kahana Stream.

name: Kaena Point
description: Kaena Point features 8 miles of hiking trails near Waialua, HI.

name: Peacock Flats
description: Peacock Flats features 10 miles of hiking trails near Haleiwa, Oahu, HI.

name: Laie Falls Trail
description: Laie Falls Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Laie, HI.

name: Koke'e State Park
description:
Koke'e State Park is known for its breathtaking views of the Kalalau Valley. Picnicking, tent camping and nature observation are all popular activities here. Many visitors come to the area for the rain forest hiking along the rim of the Walmea Canyon. Trout fishing and pig hunting are also permitted during the appropriate seasons. The park offers several amenities including restrooms, outdoor showers, picnic areas, hiking trails, trash cans, a restaurant and drinking water.

The park has 19 popular hiking trails varying in level of difficulty, but all equally scenic. The parks totaled equal approximately 25 miles, but most likely a larger length.

city: Na Pali Coast State Wilderness Park
name: Na Pali Coast State Wilderness Park
description:
The Na Pali Coast is a beautiful, yet sometimes hazardous park. The cliffs at the park provide a rugged grandeur of narrow valleys ending at the sea. The views are spectacular. Waterfalls and streams are plentiful throughout the deep cuts of the valley cliffs. Camping is an extremely popular activity at this park, but permits are required. The park does not offer drinking water, so bring treatments with you. Several hiking trails are available for visitor use.

The Kalalau Trail is the most popular. It is a moderate to difficult trail with exceptional views of wet gulches to open ridge line. Permits are required.

name: Ha'ena State Park
description: Ha'ena State Park is a scenic area located on Kaua'i's north shore. It is a very popular destination for viewing wet caves, swimming, shore fishing, picnicking or just relaxing on the beach. There is also the 11-mile Kalalau Trail for hikers. It is best to arrive early because parking is limited.

name: Bahia Honda State Park
description: The park has three nature trails. The Silver Palm Trail is located at the southeast end of the island in Sandspur and there is a self-guided brochure available. The other trail is located on the southwest end of the island in the Calusa area and leads you to the top of the Old Bahia Honda Bridge. Along the sides of the trail you may see several butterfly species. The view is spectacular; from the top of the bridge you can see the entire island. You have a bird's-eye view of the water below. You may see large rays or fish jumping. If the water is clear, you can see fish and sea turtles swimming beneath the surface. Or, take a leisurely stroll through the Wings and Waves Butterfly Garden located near the Loggerhead parking lot. This small garden was planted in 1998 after the winds from Hurricane Georges destroyed the vegetation in this area. If you look closely at the foliage, you may see the tiny endangered Miami Blue butterfly.

name: Curry Hammock State Park
description: A 1.5-mile nature trail winds through the hardwood hammock. The tread is uneven and appropriate footware is recommended.

name: Long Key State Park
description: In addition to the Long Key Lakes Canoe Trail, the park offers two land-based nature trails for visitors to explore. The "Golden Orb Trail," named after a native spider, is a leisurely 40-minute walk through several plant communities. The "Layton Trail" is located on the bay side of the park and takes 15 minutes to walk.

name: Indian Key Historic State Park
description: Visitors may explore the island and learn about its unique past by following the re-created street system. This interpretive trail takes you through the historic community of Indian Key, the first county seat of Dade County.

name: Windley Key Fossil Reef Geological State Park
description: The park has approximately 1.5 miles of trails that wind through a tropical hardwood hammock. Along the trails, visitors are able to observe over 40 species of trees and plants that are native to the Florida Keys. With the aid of a guidebook, numbered trail stops, and interpretive markers, it is easy for visitors to learn about the natural and cultural resources of the site. Ranger-guided tours are also available.

name: John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park
description: The park maintains three nature trails in two uniquely different environments. The Mangrove Trail is a loop trail on a boardwalk that allows visitors to peacefully view the mangroves and estuaries they thrive in. An observation tower also allows a larger view of this very important ecosystem. Another loop trail, the Wild Tamarind Trail, winds through the park's beautiful tropical hardwood hammock, allowing visitors to view many of the area's native hardwood species. The Grove Trail also winds through the hardwood hammock, but terminates at the Grove. This cultural resource has been replanted with tropical fruit trees, as originally planted by early pioneers in Key Largo.

name: Florida Keys Overseas Heritage Trail
description: One of the best ways to experience the Keys' colorful communities and beautiful scenery is on foot. The longest, continuous section of paved trail currently located in the Upper Keys between MM 106 at Key Largo and through MM 72 at Islamorada, Village of Islands. Other sections of trail have been completed as noted on the map. Where there is no existing trail, hikers may, with caution, follow the shoulders of the road since the trail generally parallels US Highway 1.

name: Dagny Johnson Key Largo Hammock Botanical State Park
description: A self-guided nature trail winds through the tropical hardwood hammock and includes a native plant butterfly garden. An additional 6 miles of backcountry trails are available to explore simply by completing a backcountry permit at the John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park Ranger Station. Exploring the trails gives visitors a chance to see some of 84 protected and rare species of plants and animals, including wild cotton, mahogany mistletoe, or the Schaus' swallowtail butterfly. The largest tract of West Indian tropical hardwood hammock in the U.S. is contained in this park, and provides a wealth of opportunity for birdwatchers and photographers. The main half-mile trail is paved and accessible to wheelchairs and bicycles.

name: Everglades National Park
description:
In many areas of the park, trails allow you to explore the diversity of habitats within south Florida. While exploring the park, be sure to bring plenty of water and be aware of changing weather conditions.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Pineland Trails
description: Pineland Trails features 5 miles of hiking trails near Homestead, FL.

name: Bill Baggs Cape Florida State Park
description: Nature trails are located on the west side of the park. To the north, is a trail through the mangrove wetlands, beginning 100 feet north of The Boater's Grill parking area. A trail through the coastal strand runs from 100 feet east of The Boater's Grill parking area and travels south ending in Area D.

name: Bird Basin Park
description: Bird Basin Park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Miami, FL.

name: Florida Trail
description: The Florida Trail is one of only 11 designated National Scenic Trails, and it runs for 1,400 miles from the far southern reaches of Florida all the way up through Central Florida, Northern Florida, and through the Panhandle.

name: Big Cypress National Preserve
description:
Hiking within Big Cypress can be along designated trails, or orienteering through unmarked territory. Hikers should be prepared for conditions depending on the season. The dry season provides the most comfortable hiking conditions. The wet season has its unique challenges, and hikers should be prepared for tromping through water that in places can be waist deep. During either season rewards can be many - quietly watching an otter eat a fish, feeling the wind rustling your hair, discovering tropical blooms or happening upon a bear track.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Oleta State Park
description: Oleta State Park features 9 miles of hiking trails near Miami, FL.

name: Fakahatchee Strand Preserve State Park
description: A 2,000-foot long boardwalk at Big Cypress Bend, meandering through the old growth cypress, enables the visitor to experience the beauty of this unusual swamp.

name: Resaca de la Palma State Park
description: The World Birding Center visitors' center is the portal to over 8 miles of trails, four decks that overlook the 4 miles of resaca, and a 2.76-mile tram loop that winds through the park. A tram leaves the visitor center every hour on the half hour. Visitors need to park in the parking lot; private vehicles are not allowed within the park. Resaca's many trails can be accessed by tram, hiking, biking or walking.

name: Collier-Seminole State Park
description: The park has three trails for hiking or biking. A 0.9 mile walking/nature trail is down by the boat basin. There is a 3.5 mile mountain bike or hiking trail, and the 6.5 mile hiking Adventure Trail. During the rainy season, water may cover parts of the trail; call the ranger station for the current conditions.

name: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park
description:
The Park offers a å_ mile trail (1 mile round-trip) to an overlook of the battlefield, where visitors will find interpretive panels and replica cannon. Two additional trails lead out to the U.S. and Mexican battle lines. Those who cannot walk this distance may use an accessible road which will allow them to enter the trail at a point closer to the overlook.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: John U. Lloyd Beach State Park
description: At the south end of the park, we offer a relaxing, 45-minute self-guided nature walk through a native subtropical coastal hammock. Here you can see examples of a seaside hardwood forest unchanged from the impact of development. You may also see wildlife such as squirrels, raccoons and a myriad of birds.

name: East Everglades Levee Trail
description: East Everglades Levee Trail features 68 miles of hiking trails near Southwest Ranches, FL.

name: Live Oak Trail
description: The Live Oak Trail is a 4,843-foot, wood-chipped trail.

name: Seminole Trail
description: The Seminole Trail is a paved trail that includes an interpretive exhibit on the Seminole Indians.

name: Pine Island Ridge
description: The Pine Island Ridge Trail includes a 4,381-foot paved path and a 1,250-foot trail with a 28-foot-high observation tower, Tree Tops Tower, at the entrance to the Live Oak Trail.

name: Picayune Strand State Forest/ Sabal Palm
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. It is a 3.2 mile loop. The forest is made up of a mix of cypress strands, wet prairie, and pine flatwoods in the lowlands, and subtropical hardwood hammocks in the uplands. The majority of this area will be underwater with enough rainfall.

name: Markham Park
description: Markham Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Sunrise, FL.

name: Hugh Taylor Birch State Park
description: The Coastal Hammock Trail provides hikers a 20-minute leisurely walk through a native maritime tropical hardwood hammock ecosystem, some of the last designated within Broward County. Interpretive signs along the trail provide information about the habitat and native flora. The Mid Trail gives a different view of the park by including many plants brought here by Mr. Birch. A self-guided Audio Tour may be taken through your personal cell phone. Please inquire at the Ranger Station for the Mid Trail Audio Tour information. The tour is free at this time, but donations are appreciated for maintaining the program. All donations go to the park's 'Friends' group, Friends of Birch State Park, Inc. Stations are marked with numbers 1-12. This å_-mile walk winds its way through a mix of native vegetation and non-native species and offers the listener an historical and ecological overview of the park.

name: Quiet Waters Park
description: Quiet Waters Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Pompano Beach, FL.

name: Daggerwing Nature Center
description: Two trails.

name: Mound Key Archaeological State Park
description: The park is in development stages.

name: Lovers Key State Park
description: The Black Island Trail is 2.5 miles of hiking or biking adventure through a maritime hammock along the canal banks of Black Island. There are a total of 8 miles of trails within the park including the beach.

name: Koreshan State Historic Site
description: The park features a Hiking Trail along the river and a Running Trail along the park boundary that takes you through a pine flatwoods habitat.

name: Matanzas Pass Preserve
description: The Preserve offers 1.25 miles of trails that wind through the canopies of mangroves and the oak hammock.

name: West Delray Regional Park
description: West Delray Regional Park features 3 miles of hiking trails near Delray Beach, FL.

name: Estero Bay Preserve State Park
description: The Estero River Scrub has four trails with a combined length of about 10 miles. Visitors hiking to the river can stop to rest at one of the benches located along the bank. At Winkler Point, the observation decks along the trail are a good place to view waterfowl and wading birds. Gopher tortoises, warblers, wrens and woodpeckers are commonly seen.

name: Six Mile Cypress Slough Preserve
description: Much effort was needed throughout the 1980s to protect the Six-Mile Cypress watershed from the results of outside development (pollutants, draining off of vital water sources). The Lee County Board of Commissioners and South Florida Water Management District found themselves more than once battling to maintain the integrity of the Preserve's water source. These efforts culminated in 1991 with Lee County Parks and Recreation opening the Preserve's boardwalk and facilities to visitors.

name: Falcon State Park
description: Self-guided nature trail.

name: Okaloacoochee Slough State Forest/ Twin Mills
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. It is a 2.3 mile loop. The forest is home to, threatened, and endangered species such as the Florida panther, Florida black bear, sandhill crane, wood stork, and gopher tortoise.

name: Okeeheelee Nature Center
description: Excellent trails.

name: Lake Trail
description:
Multi-use paved trail<br />
<br />
This trail follows the intracoastal waterway for a majority of the way. It passes the famous White Hall, the winter estate for guiled age railroad tycoon Henry Flagler. after crossing Royal Palm way the trail returns to along the water and proveds spectacular views of West Palm Beach and the estates of Palm Beach.

name: Hickey's Creek Mitigation Park
description: Hickey's Creek Mitigation Park offers three, looped HIKING ONLY trails that total five miles.

name: Cayo Costa State Park
description: Enjoy a leisurely walk on our nature trails, which meander through our beautiful barrier island. Along the way you can see many species of birds, including several rare and endangered, that visit our island in the spring and fall, during their migratory journeys. Some of these species use our island's natural resources for their nesting activities.

name: Butterfly Orchid Trail (Apoxee Urban  Wilderness Trail)
description: Great trail for all ages. ADA accessible paved trail

name: Apoxee Trail (Apoxee Urban Wilderness Park)
description:
Pronounced "Ah-po-ee"<br />
Parking and Trailhead Located Just off of Jog Rd on the west side(Just North of Okeechobee Blvd).

name: Owa-hee Trail (Grassy-Waters & Apoxee Urban Wilderness)
description:
This trail follows hard packed trail on top of the levee system that surrounds both Grassy Waters Preserve and Apoxee Urban Wilderness Park. <br />
Offers great wildlife viewing opportunities, including migratory birds in the winter.

name: Caloosahatchee Regional Park
description: Caloosahatchee Regional Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Alva, FL.

name: Apoxee Urban Wilderness Park
description:
Pronounced "Ah-po-ee"<br />
<br />
This park is home to several different hiking trails.<br />
<br />
Parking and Trailhead Located Just off of Jog Rd on the west side(Just North of Okeechobee Blvd).

name: Gasparilla Island State Park
description: Enjoy a leisurely walk on our nature trails, which meander through our beautiful barrier island. Along the way you can see many species of birds, including several rare and endangered, that visit our island in the spring and fall, during their migratory journeys. Some of these species use our island's natural resources for their nesting activities.

name: Dyer Park
description: Dyer Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near West Palm Beach, FL.

name: Grassy Waters Preserve Boardwalk
description:
Short, easy family hike on a well maintained boardwalk with spectacular views!<br />
<br />
The nature center offers programs and canoe trips.

name: Hog Hammock Trail
description: Short easy hike with great view of cypress swamp and open prairies

name: Richard S. Weinstein Satinleaf Nature Trail
description: This short trail offers you a glimpse of maritime hammock filled with several species of tropical plants.

name: John D. MacArthur Beach State Park
description: The park has three nature trails for visitors to explore.

name: Ranch Trail
description: This trail follows along the northern boarder of the the natural area.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail (Corbett WMA)
description: One of the more remote sections of The Ocean to Lake trail offering amazing vistas. Some sections are underwater most of the year so be prepared to get wet.

name: Western Trail
description: This trail follows the western boundary of the park along a sandy trail that can be under water during the wet season.

name: Loxahatchee Slough Natural Area
description: Loxahatchee Slough Natural Area is home to many animal and plant inhabitants as well as several hiking trails.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail (North Loxahatchee Slough NA)
description: This trail offers great hike through pine flatwoods. Seasonal flooding is common.

name: Don Pedro Island State Park
description: Enjoy a leisurely walk on nature trails that meander through the island's eleven distinct natural communities. Along the way you can see the island's protected plant species, including giant leather fern, spreading air plant and coontie.

name: Stump Pass Beach State Park
description: Take a quiet stroll along the 1.3-mile hiking trail that stretches to the southern end of the park and through the park's five distinct natural communities.  Along this trail you may see a variety of  wildlife such as a ospreys, southern bald eagles, fiddler crabs and wading birds; and plants such as prickly pear cactus, indigo berry, bay cedar, and coontie.

name: River Walk Trail
description: Longest Trail in Riverbend Park and is a great short trip for the family.

name: Pine Walk
description: Another short trail

name: Riverbend Park
description: Great hiking trails.

name: Loxahatchee River Bend Park
description: This 680 park was the location of the Second Seminole Indian War, and is currently home to a small network of trails and other attractions.

name: Reese Blvd Trail
description: great connector trail from Hunt Camp trail to Big Hammock Picnic Area.

name: Battlefield Trail
description: This trail is located on an old battleground during the Seminole Wars.

name: Hunt Camp Trail
description: Connects the main entrance to the Farmstead Loop.

name: Other Trails
description:
All of the trails bellow are less than 0.25miles and offer unique and diffrent views of the park.<br />
<br />
Indian Camp Trail, Pond Trail, Indian Hammock Trail, Cow Pen Loop Trail, Bridge, Overlook Trail, Dark Hammock Trail, and Big Grove Loop Trail.

name: Hunters Loop Trail
description: Nice short loop trail

name: Big Hammock Loop Trail
description: Short walk through giant oak trees.

name: Picnic Island Loop Trail
description: Wonderful loop trail for the family after a great picnic.

name: Wildlife loop Road
description: Paved road great for jogging and bicycling.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail (Riverbend Park)
description:
This is the segment of the Ocean to Lake Trail that passes through Riverbend Park.<br />
<br />
The trail is hard-packed gravel trail 8' trail.

name: Farmstead Loop
description: Short trail with two bathrooms

name: Military Loop Trail
description: This trail follows the original military trail that passed through the park connecting US forts during the first and second Seminole wars.

name: Grove Trail
description: Nice short trail

name: Myakka State Forest North Loop
description: Myakka State Forest is made up primarily of mesic flatwoods with a mixture of longleaf pine and slash pine overstory with a palmetto understory. Numerous depression marshes are scattered throughout the flatwoods, providing many opportunities for viewing wading birds and other wildlife. The forest includes approximately 2.5 miles of frontage on the Myakka River which is designated as an Outstanding Florida Water and a Wild and Scenic River. The Myakkahatchee Creek flows throughout the forest for 1.5 miles and provides an additional water resource.

name: Myakka State Forest South Loop
description: Myakka State Forest is made up primarily of mesic flatwoods with a mixture of longleaf pine and slash pine overstory with a palmetto understory. Numerous depression marshes are scattered throughout the flatwoods, providing many opportunities for viewing wading birds and other wildlife.

name: East Loop Trail
description:
Traversing at least 8 different ecosystems this trail offers you diversity that is sometimes hard to find on South Florida Trails. From the rolling Scrub highland sand ridges (with elevations around 80 feet on some peaks) to the low sawgrass beds and everything in between this trail offers great views and is great for dayhiks or an overnight trip. overnight camping is limited to two sites at Scrub Jay Primitive Campground with a hand water pump (non-potable so bring a filtration system) and an outhouse. <br />
<br />
On the northern most end of this loop is shared with the Ocean to Lake Trail which can be used to link up with the West Loop trail, Kitching Creek Camp or even a thru-hike to Riverbend Park. <br />
<br />
Expect lose sand (sugar sand as we Floridians call it) on the Eastern half of the loop and possible water on the Western half of the trail (dry season tends to be late November-Early March).<br />
<br />
Note: Contact the Ranger Station to ensure you can get a campground as they tend to fill up some weekends.

name: Loop 2
description: A longer version of loop 1 with a primitive campground located on the eastern  segment of the loop.

name: Loop 4
description: The longest loop in Dupuis with a primitive campground on the southern segment of the trail shared with the the Ocean to Lake Trail.

name: Loop 3
description: Great wide vistas of open prairie land, Primitive campground found on the western loop of the leg on loop 2.

name: Loop 1
description: Easy 5 mile loop that offers great vistas of the Northern Everglades.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail (Dupuis WMA)
description: Wonderful trail, with some water during the wet season. Offers wonderful views, and few other humans to be seen or heard.

name: Dupuis Reserve
description: Dupuis Reserve is an expansive wildlife management area that is home to several different hiking trails, including a sizeable section of the Ocean to Lake trail. Click on the individual trail listings for more information.

name: Jonathan Dickinson State Park
description: Jonathan Dickenson State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Hobe Sound, FL.

name: Lake Okeechobee
description: Phipps Martin Area has hiking trails to enjoy.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail (Jonathan Dickinson State Park)
description:
Westbound (to Lake) this segment of the Ocean to Lake Trail starts at the intersection of the East Loop Trail. Continuing 3.2 miles the trail then passes through the Scrub Jay Camp (non-potable water and outhouse available). At mile 6.3 the trail passes through Kitching Creek Camp (non-potable water and outhouse available). These two primitive campgrounds are the only permitted campgrounds within the park. Around mile 8 the trail follows along the edge of an Hobe Groves then crosses Cypress Creek within the next mile. Cypress Creek may not have water during dry season so be sure to carry enough water. The trail then crosses under I-95 and the Florida Turnpike at mile 11.5 along the Loxahatchee River. the Final 2 miles crosses BZ Creek then the Loxahatchee River (at Indiantown Road, SR 706). After crossing the Loxahatchee River the trail follows then passes under Indiantown Road and enters River Bend Park at the Northeastern corner of the park. <br />
<br />
<br />
Blaze Color: Orange. Be careful to follow the the Ocean to Lake trail signs because other trails may also have orange blazes.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail
description:
According to Wikipedia, the "Ocean to Lake Trail is a 63-mile greenway spur off the Florida Trail. It starts at Hobe Sound Beach and endis at Lake Okeechobee in Port Mayaca. The trail is under development as of 2012 and portions are open to the public in Jonathan Dickinson State Park, Corbett Wildlife Management Area, and DuPuis Reserve. The 2012 Ocean To Lake Greenway Celebration included horseback riding, cycling, hiking and trail running." The trail is still under construction, so more sections will be added in the future. If you have new information on the Ocean to Lake Trail, be sure to add it!<br />
Click on the individual trail listings for more detailed information.

name: Ocean to Lake Trail (Hobe Sound Beach Park to Jonathan Dickinson State Park)
description:
This segment of the Ocean to Lake Trail is about 3.4 miles. Starting at Hobe Sound Beach Park this segment ends 1 mile beyond the northern boarder of Johnathan Dickinson State Park at the intersection of the East Loop Trail. This segment follows SE Bridge Road, Old Dixie Highway, and US 1 until it enters Johnathan Dickinson State Park.<br />
<br />
Blaze Color: Orange

name: Jelks Preserve
description: Hiking only along a changing sand, forest floor, and grassland terrain. Picnic Tables and Benches are scattered around the outer loop trail. There are NO restroom facilities, Fresh Water supplies, or Garbage collection. There are many secondary trails running between the outer loop which offer a myriad of switchbacks to choose from, allowing a great variety of hiking distances based upon your trail choices.

name: North Port Mountain Bike Trails
description: North Port Mountain Bike Trails features 9 miles of hiking trails near North Port, FL.

name: Halpatiokee
description: Halpatiokee features 10 miles of hiking trails near Stuart, FL.

name: Hobe Sound Beach Trail
description: NOTE: The only way to enter St. Lucie State Park is by foot or boat. No freshwater is available so bring as much as you need!

name: St. Lucie Inlet Preserve State Park
description: A 3,330-foot boardwalk meanders from the dock to the beach. Along the way, you will traverse two coastal hammocks. The skunk-like aroma is from the white stopper, a tropical tree. Some of the common plants observed along the way are live oak, cabbage palm, paradise tree, wild lime and several species of native fern. Along the beach, you will see gray nicker bean, coin vine and federally-listed plants such as the beach star.

name: Seabranch Preserve State Park
description: Amazing park with several Florida natural communities within a short hike.

name: Oscar Scherer State Park
description: Oscar Scherer State Park features 12 miles of hiking trails near Osprey, FL.

name: Myakka River State Park
description:
Walk through the treetops and then climb a 74-foot tower for an eagle's-eye view of hammocks and wetlands.

Hikers can explore 39 miles of the Florida National Scenic Trail that crosses large expanses of rare Florida dry prairie. This trail is maintained by Florida Trail Association volunteers.

name: Lake June-in-Winter Scrub State Park
description: Nice area for hiking.

name: Grassy Island Trail
description: Grassy Island Trail is a 5 mile hiking trail in Okeechobee, Florida.

name: Savannas Preserve State Park
description: We offer an array of scenic foot travel in the park, from our short nature trail, loop hikes and also hikes that stretch the length of the park. There are over 15 miles of multi-use trails available to park visitors and group tours. The trails are shared by hikers, bicyclists and horseback riders. The nature trails wind throughout the Savannas marsh system, so depending on the season and weather, the trails may be wet. Please plan accordingly! For additional information please contact the Education Center (Thursday through Monday) at (772) 398-2779 or the Park Office at (772) 340-7530.

name: Fort Pierce Mountain Bike Trail
description: Fort Pierce Mountain Bike Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Ft. Pierce, FL.

name: Lake Manatee State Park
description: There are several trails located throughout the park. Stop by our ranger station to obtain the maps of our in-park trails or our multi-use Gopher Trail.

name: Highlands Hammock State Park
description: Highlands Hammock Webster defines hammock as " a fertile area in the southern U.S. and especially Florida, that is usually higher than its surroundings and that is characterized by hardwood vegetation and deep humus-rich soil." True enough. But visitors to Highlands Hammock State Park know exactly what it means -- " Beautiful!." Stroll along the elevated boardwalk over Charlie Bowlegs Creek and search the tea-colored water for alligators. Walk along the boardwalk of the Memorial Trail and view the colorful, scattered leaves. See fall in Florida, and maybe observe a flock of White Ibis feeding. Walk deep into the woods under the expansive tree canopy of the Ancient Hammock Trail. Wonder over the giant oaks and their airplant-laden branches. Lake June in Winter Scrub State Park is located 20 minutes from HHSP, and offers hiking opportunities through rare scrub habitat. Current amenities include a picnic pavilion, composting toilet, and short å_ mile nature walk through scrubby flatwoods and bay communities along a spring-fed creek. This nature trail is a delightful oasis, providing a quiet and shady spot in this predominantly scrub and scrubby flatwoods ecosystem. Another brief walk will offer beautiful views of Lake June in Winter, a 3500-acre lake that lies west of the property. Hikers may enjoy several miles of firelanes that transverse this hot, sunny habitat. From these firelanes, you may see Gopher Tortoises, Florida Scrub Jays, Bald Eagles, Wild Turkeys, Bobcats, Florida Scrub-Lizards and more! Rare, endemic plants of the Florida Scrub can be discovered by those interested in botany. Full sun and deep sands should be expected. Be sure to bring plenty of drinking water, suitable shoes, sunblock and perhaps a cell phone. This park is remote and quiet, affording a very relaxing and peaceful wilderness experience.

name: Fort Pierce Inlet State Park
description: Our Oak Hammock Trail leads visitors through one of the few remaining oak hammocks on a south Florida barrier island. It's a nice, leisurely walk and only 30-minutes long. You can see many native trees including Gumbo Limbo, Redbay and a variety of oaks.

name: De Soto National Memorial
description:
The Nature Trail winds along the shoreline and through several Florida ecosystems, including a mangrove forest like the one that De Soto's men would have encountered when they landed. Trails include interpretive signage and waysides that tell the story of the De Soto Expedition and the natural history of the area. Bicycling is allowed in the parking lot, but not on the sidewalks or trails.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: The Preserve
description: The Preserve features 12 miles of hiking trails near Sebring, FL.

name: Avalon State Park
description: Our coastal hammock, located on the west side of A1A, is open to visitors. You must park outside the gate and walk in because of the low marsh areas. This is an excellent place for bird watching. You can see many native trees including the Gumbo Limbo, Red Bay, Live Oak and Mangrove.

name: Madira Bickel Mound State Archaeological Site
description: The park is in development stages. Nature trails and kiosk with historical information are planned for the future.

name: Egmont Key
description: Walk through the historic ruins of Fort Dade or along the brick paths that remain from the days Fort Dade was an active community with 300 residents. Gopher tortoises can sometimes be seen as you walk the historic paths. Many visitors are treated to the sight of hummingbirds and other seabirds.

name: Paynes Creek Historic State Park
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Little Manatee River State Park
description: A 6.5-mile hiking trail that meanders through a diversity of habitats is available in the park's northern wilderness area.  A primitive camp, located along the trail, is available by reservation only. All hikers must register at the park's ranger station. Little Manatee River State Park's nature trails have been designated as the area's best hiking trails. The Florida National Scenic Trail runs through Little Manatee River State Park and is maintained by Florida Trail Association volunteers.

name: Mustang Island State Park
description: Great area for hiking.

name: Boyd Hill Nature Preserve
description: Boyd Hill Nature Preserve is located along the shores of Lake Maggiore in St. Petersburg. The 245-acre park features trails and boardwalks through 5 ecosystems, a bird of prey aviary, guided hikes, picnic areas, and an education center.

name: Pinellas Trail
description: Paved muli-use trail stretching from St. Petersburg to Tarpon Springs. Former railroad bed offers access to several parks and recreation areas along its length.

name: Balm Boyette Scrub Preserve
description: Balm Boyette Scrub Preserve features 20 miles of hiking trails near Tampa, FL.

name: Alafia River State Park
description: Alafia River State Park features 14 miles of hiking trails near Brandon, FL.

name: War Veteran's Memorial Park Boardwalk & Nature
description: This is a linear trail through the interior of the park.

name: St. Sebastian River Preserve Southeast Blue Trail
description: St. Sebastian River Preserve Southeast Blue Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near Sebastian, FL.

name: Tower Boardwalk
description: This is a short boardwalk trail that loops around. The loop has two spurs. One spur connects the Observation Tower and the other connects a pond with an observation area.

name: Boca Ciega Millennium Park Boardwalk
description: The park and trail is a stop on the Florida Fish & Wildlife Conservation Commission's Great Florida Birding Trail. You can view shore birds, wading birds, birds of prey, upland birds & water fowl.

name: Bay Boardwalk
description: This a boardwalk trail that makes a loop with a spur from Upland Trail. The spur goes to the Bay Observation Platform.

name: Upland
description: This is a short paved trail connecting Lookout Point trail, Bay Boardwalk trail and Tower Boardwalk trail. The Weedon Island Preserve Cultural & Natural History Center is on this trail.

name: Boca Ciega Millennium Park Nature
description: This is a short loop trail that begins and ends at picnic shelter 5.

name: Boca Ciega Millennium Park
description: This waterside park is home to many natural communities, and several trails and observatories from which to view them. It is also a stop on the Florida Fish & Wildlife Conservation Commission's Great Florida Birding Trail.

name: Lookout Point
description: Trail from picnic area 2 to picnic area 3. Connects to Boy Scout Trail.

name: Boca Ciega Millennium Park Multi-Purpose
description: This paved trail begins at the park entrance and parallels the road to picnic shelters 1 & 2.

name: Boy Scout
description: Developed with the assistance of local Boy Scout Troops, this 1-mile loop trail takes hikers through pine flatwoods and maritime and xeric hammocks. There are benches and bridges along the path.

name: Maple
description: A boardwalk trail between Sawgrass Trail and Oak Hammock Trail.

name: Sawgrass
description: Boardwalk trail to an observation tower on Sawgrass Lake.

name: Oak Hammock
description: This dirt trail provides opportunities to see birds, butterflies, plants and animals in their natural settings within the most densely populated county in Florida.

name: Lake Seminole Park Multi-Purpose
description: The park has a 2-mile multi-use trail forjogging, hiking, bicycling, or rollerblading that winds through a pine flatwoods. A 1-mile cut-off is available for those less vigorous. Lake Seminole affords hours of pleasure for boaters, jet skiers, water-skiing, fishing, etc. A softball field and volleyball courts are available. Benches and swings are strategically situated for relaxing views of the several ponds and the lake.

name: Wheedon Island Preserve
description: Wheedon Island Preserve is a beautiful natural area and home to a number of great hiking trails.

name: Red Trail (Micco Scrub Sanctuary)
description: Great 3 mile trail that goes though classic scrubland

name: Walsingham Park
description:
Visitors can enjoy hiking, jogging, or cycling a 6 mile trail with a 10-station fitness area. Visitors can also enjoy bird-watching, observing many plant species, fishing an/or boating. Wildlife includes: snakes, tortoises, turtles, hawks, mottled ducks, herons, wrens, thrashers, warblers; as well as butterflies comprised of swallowtails, sulphurs, gulf fritillary, Carolina satyr, white peacock.<br />
<br />
Five habitat areas have been delineated within the boundaries of Walsingham Park: botanical gardens, pine flatwoods, oak scrub, Walsingham Reservoir with detention ponds, swales and wetlands; and cleared areas.

name: Barrier Island Sanctuary Trail
description: unpaved trail that traverses from the ocean, oak hammock to the mangrove swamps of the Indian river.

name: John S. Taylor Park Multi-Purpose
description: a tree-lined 2 mile multi-purpose shell trail and a small island that is accessible by a bridge and an open playing field. There is a disc golf course here too.

name: Loyce E. Harpe Park (carter Road)
description: Carter Park Trail features 7 miles of hiking trails near Lakeland, FL.

name: Eagle Lake Park Nature
description: Loop with spurs on the south end of the park.

name: Eagle Lake Park
description:
The park is home to numerous wild animals, and features a resorted wetlands area. <br />
<br />
Amenities:<br />
6 picnic shelters - reserve shelters online<br />
3 restrooms<br />
playground<br />
dog park - follow dog park rules<br />
A paved 12-foot wide recreation trail<br />
Numerous shell paths for walking and enjoying nature<br />
2,000 feet of boardwalks over restored wetlands<br />
Catch and release fishing permitted from designated areas only, no bank fishing allowed.<br />
3 vending stations

name: Eagle Lake Park Multi-Purpose
description:
A paved 12-foot wide recreation trail.<br />
Numerous shell spur paths for walking and enjoying nature. Includes 2,000 feet of boardwalks over restored wetlands.

name: Sydney Dover Trails
description: Sydney Dover Trails features 7 miles of hiking trails near Dover, FL.

name: DeSoto Recreational Park
description: This is a public park right on McKay Bay in Downtown Tampa. There is a skatepark, playground, family pool, and paved hiking/biking trail around the perimeter of the park. There's also a pavilion right on the water which makes a great fishing spot.

name: McKay Bay Nature Park
description: This is a 38-acre nature preserve right next to McKay Bay in downtown Tampa. It has status as a national avian sanctuary and is the home to many species of bird. There are some short trails around the park and one 1.25 mile paved trail for hiking or biking.

name: Sand Key
description: This is a nature trail winding its way through the park portion of Sand Key. The trail goes from the near the entrance on the South end to loop in the middle and then North to Clearwater Pass. There is a beautiful view of Clearwater Bridge and the Gulf of Mexico from here.

name: Allen David Broussard Catfish Creek Preserve State Park
description: This State Park offers 6 miles of hiking trails, 7 miles of equestrian and great fishing!

name: Jordan Scrub Sanctuary
description: This Scrub Sanctuary houses many animals, as well as singletrack trails and jeep roads. More trails are planned in the future.

name: White Trail Loop (Jordan Scrub Sanctuary)
description: This trail offers the best cross section of this sanctuary and can be underwater  during the wet season.

name: Red Trail (Jordan Scrub Sanctuary)
description: This trail seasonally floods so keep that in mind before heading out.

name: Blue Trail (Jordan Scrub Sanctuary)
description: Visit this great park that few know about. several lakes  and abundant with wildlife.

name: Caladesi Island State Park
description: This trail is through the interior of the island. Countless birds use this island for all kinds of purposes. Marsh rabbit, gopher tortoise, raccoon, and armadillos reside there too.

name: Philippe Park Shoreline
description: An Indian mound listed in the National Register of Historic Landmarks and majestic shade trees welcome visitors at the oldest park in Pinellas County. Take in the view of Old Tampa Bay while strolling along a one-mile shoreline trail. Guided hikes are scheduled. Check park calendar for dates and times.

name: Coconut Point Sanctuary Trail
description: Step back in time where  Juan Ponce de Leon may have discovered Florida and see Florida the way he did.

name: Boundary Canal Trail
description: paved multi-use trail that follows the canal on the north end of Malabar scrub.

name: Turkey Creek Sanctuary -WEST-
description: This side of Turkey Creek has a jogging/exercise trail, boardwalks, a canoe deck, a few spur trails, Nature Center, and a picnic pavilion. The boardwalks offer a picturesque tour of natural Florida and offer a self guided nature tour. the spur trails offer more views of the creek and also connect sections to make loops. this park is fun for the whole family.

name: Ais Trail Park
description: unpaved and boardwalk nature trail

name: Malabar Scrub Sanctuary
description: Malabar Scrub Sanctuary features 10 miles of hiking trails near Malabar, FL.

name: Mobbly Bayou Preserve
description: Hiking trail through the bayou.

name: Sugarberry Loop Trail
description: Shell nature trail following a waterway then turning back through a wooded area. Less than a mile long.

name: Kettles Trail
description: Shell nature trail through pines and palmettos. Begins at Grant Trail and ends at Gopher Trail. Less than a mile long.

name: Gopher Trail
description: Shell nature trail through pines and palmettos. Begins at Palm Trail and ends at Grant Trail. Less than a mile long.

name: Cline Trail
description: Shell nature trail through an oak hammock. Begins at Skinner Trail and ends at Palm Trail. Less than a mile long.

name: Oak Trail
description: Shell nature trail through an oak hammock. Less than a mile long.

name: Palm Trail
description: Shell nature trail through an oak hammock, bayhead, and sand pines. Begins at Skinner Trail and ends at Gopher trail. Less than a mile long.

name: Harris To Lake Trail
description: Beginner nature trail through a wooded area to Lake Suemar. Less than a mile long.

name: Grant Trail
description: Shell nature trail following the canal opposite Lake Suemar. Less than a mile long.

name: Fern Trail
description: Shell nature trail through a bayhead connecting Skinner Trail and Palm Trail. Less than a mile long.

name: Skinner Trail
description: Shell nature trail following a canal flowing to Cedar creek through a wooded area. Less than a mile long.

name: Hammock Park
description: Hammock Park is a small park in Dunedin, FL that is home to several short hiking trails.

name: Osprey Trail
description: Half boardwalk half shell nature trail. Less than a mile long.

name: Cedar Trail
description: Shell nature trail crossing Cedar Creek and two other waterways. Less than a mile long.

name: Honeymoon Island State Park
description:
According to Wikipedia, "Honeymoon Island State Park is a Florida State Park located on Honeymoon Island, a barrier island across St. Joseph's Sound from Palm Harbor, Ozona, and Crystal Beach. The park is 385 acres (1.6 km2) in land area with 2,400 acres (10 km2) submerged and 4 miles (6 km) of beach. It lies at the western end of Causeway Boulevard, which becomes Curlew Road east of Alternate US 19. The address is 1 Causeway Blvd."
It is also home to many hiking trails. click on the individual trail listings for more detailed information about each one.

name: Dent Smith Trail
description: Walking on this trail you wonder if your still in Florida or if you have been transported to a jungle in south america. Wonderful trail.

name: Lake Corpus Christi State Park
description: Lake Corpus Christi State Park is full of history and beautiful landscapes, making it a wonderful destination for outdoor lovers. Activities here include boating, fishing, swimming, hiking and camping.

name: Honeymoon Island Nature Trail (Florida)
description:
Hours and entrance fees Florida state parks are open between 8 a.m. and sundown every day of the year (including holidays). The park assesses a per vehicle daily or yearly entrance fee, $8 per day in 2012. $2 for Pedestrian or biker. $4.00 for one person in vehicle. The nature trails will give you ample opportunities to run into the inhabitants of the island. While Osprey are the norm, keep an eye out for the gopher tortoise crossing your path, the armadillo foraging for food, or the raccoon scurrying off into the woods. Please remember the essentials when exploring the outdoors - sun protection, hydration, and bug spray. <br />
Mosquitos are quite prevalent in the picnic areas and trails away from the beach, and can quickly inflict dozens of bites on uncovered, unprotected skin

name: Osprey
description: This is a sand path that winds it way through a virgin slash pine flatwood. The tops of old trees are where you can see osprey and their large nests. There are benches along the trail. There are also a few short paths to lagoons and the beach.

name: Lettuce Lake Park
description: More than half of the park's property lies in the natural floodplain of the Hillsborough River, and consists of a hardwood swamp forest. This feature provides a natural storage reservoir for floodwater and improves water quality, acting as a biological filter to remove excess nutrients from the water. The remainder of the park consists of hardwood hammocks and pine flatwoods plant communities.

name: Pelican Cove
description: This sandy path winds its way from the virgin slash pines and through a mangrove forest.

name: Bull Creek Conservation Area
description: Bull Creek Conservation Area  features 9 miles of hiking trails near St. Cloud, FL.

name: Peggy Park
description: This is a loop trail at the south end of the park.

name: Wilderness Trails Park Loop
description: Wilderness Trails Park Loop features 15 miles of hiking trails near Tampa, FL.

name: Boardwalk
description: The elevated boardwalk runs along the boat ramp, leading to an elevated lookout tower for a scenic overview of Lake Tarpon.

name: North
description: The North Trail begins at Shelter #10, running through a cypress swamp to the canoe trail. This is a linear trail.

name: Erna Nixon Park Nature Trail
description: take this short family hike on this boardwalk through giant a oak forest.

name: Wall Springs Park
description: This park is home to several different hiking trails.

name: Wall Springs Park Multi-Purpose
description: This trail is designed to attract cyclists from the bordering Pinellas Trail and is handicapped accessible.

name: Wall Springs Park Nature
description: Short pedestrian only nature trail.

name: Goose Island State Park
description: Guided nature hikes are held year-round. Guided birding tours are held from January through April.

name: A.L. Anderson Park
description: This is a short trail that has been developed along Lake Tarpon. There is a combination of paved walkways and boardwalk.

name: Brooker Creek Preserve/ Pine Needle Path Loop
description: This is a very large preserve in Pinellas County which also features a really nice environmental and education center. It encompasses 8,700 square acres of land. There are several hiking and equestrian trails. The Pine Needle Path Loop Trail is 4 miles long and hikers will trek through pine flatwoods, cypress swamps, forested wetlands, and even cross a channel of Brooker Creek. This trail is quite challenging and should only be tackled by the serious hiker. This trail may be closed during the summer due to flooding.

name: Brooker Creek Preserve
description: This is a very large preserve in Pinellas County which also features a really nice environmental and education center. It encompasses 8,700 square acres of land. There are several hiking and equestrian trails.

name: Brooker Creek Preserve/ Blackwater Cutoff Loop
description: This is a very large preserve in Pinellas County which also features a really nice environmental and education center. It encompasses 8,700 square acres of land. There are several hiking and equestrian trails. The Blackwater Cutoff Loop Trail is 2.8 miles long and consists of both dry pine flatwoods and wet forested wetlands. The northern portion of the trail crosses one of the 13 channels of Brooker Creek. This area may be underwater during the summer months.

name: Brooker Creek Preserve/ Bird Path
description: This is a very large preserve in Pinellas County which also features a really nice environmental and education center. It encompasses 8,700 square acres of land. There are several hiking and equestrian trails. The Bird Path Trail is 0.1 miles long and can be accessed from the main parking lot. It is a short nature trail leading hikers through an oak hammock and ending at a freshwater marsh. Be on the lookout for birds.

name: Brooker Creek Preserve/ Flatwoods Loop
description: This is a very large preserve in Pinellas County which also features a really nice environmental and education center. It encompasses 8,700 square acres of land. There are several hiking and equestrian trails. The Flatwoods Loop Trail is 1.5 miles long and is a mostly sand trail which traverses through pine flatwood communities with low growing saw palmettos, abundant grasses and many flowering shrubs and plants.

name: Brooker Creek Headwaters
description: 1111-acre sanctuary is the headwaters of the Brooker Creek Watershed, which flows westward to Lake Tarpon and into Upper Tampa Bay. The site is managed for threatened plants and animals such as the hooded pitcher plant, Southern pine lily, and gopher tortoise.  Natural plant communities are quite varied within the preserve.  Cypress swamps, pine flatwoods, and oak hammocks are home to deer, turkey,  bobcats, foxes,  and coyotes.  The wooded areas that border either side of Ramblewood Road include oak  scrub, a rare plant community.

name: Hillsborough River State Park- Wetlands Restoration Nature Trail
description: This is a linear trail that takes you through wetlands. Seasonal flooding will prevent you from hiking here. Call ahead for conditions.

name: Hillsborough River State Park
description:
One of the first state parks in Florida, this is an original CCC park and features all sports of activities and amenities, including several different hiking trails.

Other amenities/activities include: Bicycling, campfire circles, camping (full facility), camping (primitive), camping (youth), canoeing & kayaking, concession & restaurant, fishing, nature trail (as well as hiking), interpretive exhibit, meetings and retreats, pets, picnicking, playground, restrooms, showers, swimming, tours, wildlife viewing, and geo-seeking.

name: Florida Trail- Hillsborough River State Park
description: This is a 3.4 mile section of the Florida Trail that follows the Hillsborough River through the northern section of the park. Be prepared to walk through mud and fight mosquitoes.

name: Hillsborough River State Park- River Rapids Nature Trail
description: This loop trail is on the bank of the beautiful Hillsborough River. The trail continues to an area where you can observe a set of class II rapids.

name: Hillsborough River State Park- Baynard
description: This trail loops around the north corner of the park. It follows the Hillsborough River for a short time but mostly it goes through some really swampy areas. Take mosquito repellent because they are  everywhere. Without repellent you won't be able to stop walking or swatting.

name: Fred Howard Park
description: This a short loop trail that crosses a bridge and has a boardwalk. It loops from the picnic shelters to the beach and back. In the middle of the loop is a bayou/pond which is visible all the way around.

name: Suncoast Trail
description: Paved trail parallels the Souncoast Parkway and goes through Hillsborough, Pasco, and Hernando counties.

name: Wickham Trails
description: Wickham Trails features 0 miles of hiking trails near Melbourne, FL.

name: Key Vista Nature Park
description: There is a $2.00 fee to park here. The park has abundant wildlife and peaceful surroundings. There is also a boardwalk, fishing access, restrooms, nature trails, a picnic area, and an observation tower. The trail is 1/4 mile long and takes you to an observation tower overlooking the Gulf of Mexico.

name: Jay B. Starkey Wilderness Park
description: Within this park you can access a 6.7 mile paved trail that connects to the 42 mile Suncoast trail, 27 miles of hiking trails, 10 miles of equestrian trails, fishing, picnicking, camping, and bird watching. The most prominent features within this community are pine flatwoods, cypress domes, freshwater marshes, stream and lake swamps, sandhill and scrub.

name: Cypress Creek Preserve
description: Cypress Creek is a tributary of the Hillsborough River. The creek meanders its way through cypress and hardwood forests. There is also an abundance of slash pines, longleaf pines, and palmettos. There is about 6-8 miles of hiking trails available divided between the two entrances.

name: Orange Trail
description: Comprised mainly of pine flatwoods, cypress domes and open pasture land, this piece of natural Florida wilderness is home to many animal species including the American bald eagle, sherman's fox squirrel, gopher tortoise, white-tailed deer, wild turkey and bobcat. The park offers numerous recreational opportunities including 12 miles of hiking trails, horseback riding (with your own horse), biking, picnicking and nature study. Two picnic areas with a total of four pavilions, two restrooms and a fishing/observation dock are available. Three of the pavilions are available for rental. Freshwater Fishing is also a popular activity. Visitors can fish either from the bank or a small boat such as a canoe, kayak or Jon boat. Gas powered motors are not permitted however electric trolling motors are. For overnight enthusiasts, both a primitive backpack camp and a primitive youth camp are available.

name: Conner Preserve
description: This preserve is filled with steep sandhill ridges, expansive marshes, dense cypress sloughs and lush pine flatwoods. There are a total of 16 miles of hiking-only trails.

name: Starkey Wilderness Preserve/ Serenova Tract
description: The Serenova Tract is part of Jay B. Wilderness Park. There are 18 miles of multiuse trails for hiking, biking, and horseback riding. There is an ADA accessible toilet and an ADA accessible fishing spot. There is also primitive camping available. The trails are a mixture of concrete roads and sandy paths. There is an abundance of native Florida shrubs, trees, and flowers throughout the park.

name: Lori Wilson Park Nature Trail
description: A boardwalk trail through a great oak hammock

name: Werner-Boyce Salt Springs State Park
description: Werner-Boyce Salt Springs State Park contains and protects four miles of coastline along the Gulf of Mexico in western Pasco County. This salt spring is home to many different types of unique wildlife including the gray fox, gopher tortoises, West Indian manatees and alligators. Birdwatching is also a popular pastime here. Picnicking, boating, fishing and hiking are all accepted activities at the Werner-Boyce Salt Springs State Park. There is a simple hiking trail on the property-- it begins at the picnic area. More hiking trails and camping areas are to come in the near future.

name: F. Burton Smith Regional Park Nature Trails
description: Great family hike

name: Shingle Creek Trail
description:
There are several ways to enjoy the property. You can hike the nature trail or paddle* the creek behind Hunter's Creek Middle Creek School. Bicycling is another popular activity on the four miles of power line dirt roads linking the Middle School trail to the Hunter's Vista subdivision. An additional three miles of hiking trails are located within the east and west pine islands. A picnic shelter with tables is located at the east pine island. Finally, you can take a very short hike at the Marriott Trail. At this time, the Marriott Trail provides limited access to the management area and visitors are encouraged to use one of the other access sites.<br />
<br />
Cypress, gum trees, and wet prairies that ring pine islands are evidence the land stays mostly wet. A variety of wildlife such as white-tailed deer, alligators, wild turkey and wading birds thrive in the Shingle Creek corridor. Bring your fishing pole, bicycle, binoculars, or canoe. Either way, you'll get a good look at the initial headwaters of the Everglades ecosystem.

name: Bracco Pond Reservoir Trail
description: This easy multi-use trail wondered through pine uplands forest.

name: Island Pioneer Trail
description: Also known as the George Hamilton Trail this is a multi-use trail offering glimpses into the wetlands that used to cover Merritt Island.

name: Fay Lake Wilderness Area Trail
description: This trail follows the property line around the wilderness area.

name: Weeki Wachee Preserve Trail
description: This is a very nice Florida Preserve. There are man-made lakes created from mining. The water is crystal clear and you can see the bottom until it drops off. There are trails that go around the lakes and a trail that goes into the swamp where there are freshwater and saltwater marshes, and pine-covered sandhills.

name: Econlockhatchee River, The Hal Scott Preserve
description: Econlockhatchee River, The Hal Scott Preserve features 15 miles of hiking trails near Orlando, FL.

name: Kabboord Sanctuary Trail
description: This trail follows an old road and is dry most of the year.

name: Christmas, Tosohatchee State Reserve
description: Christmas, Tosohatchee State Reserve  features 10 miles of hiking trails near Orlando, FL.

name: Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex
description: Kennedy Space Center offers you the opportunity to see the Past, Present and Future of the United States Space Program. with interactive exhibits to actual rockets of the Space race this is truly a great trip with the family!

name: City of Titusville Multi-use Trail
description: This is a paved urban multi-use trail

name: Silver Lake Recreation Complex
description: Trail goes through cypress ponds & a long  Silver Lake & through hardwood hammocks.

name: Low Water Trail
description: Trail goes along the lake & through cypress ponds.

name: High Water Trail
description: Trail goes through oak hammocks.

name: Econlockhatchee Sandhills Conservation Area
description: This property is about 706 acres covering sandy pine flatwoods and floodplains of the Econlockhatchee River. The property protects nearly 1.5 miles of the river, although there are few access points to the river

name: Withlacoochee State Forest/ Croom "A" Loop
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. It is a 7.7 mile loop that starts at the Tucker Hill Trailhead just East of Brooksville. You start out on the A-B Loop Cross Trail and then connect to A Loop which takes you back to your starting point. It is shaded by tall overhead Pines, and Oaks.  There are many rolling hills along the way. There is no water or toilets available.

name: Withlacoochee State Forest - Croom Sec.
description: Great network of hiking trails.

name: Big Pine Tract
description: They have a restroom & a place for a picinic. Nice little trail.

name: Econ River Wilderness Area
description: This small wilderness area (240 acre) offers a wonderful day trip for the family . The main loop trail takes you from pine flatwoods through a bayhead swamp and along the cypress river swamp that follows the Econ river.

name: Fickett Hammock Preserve
description: This preserve is covered with forest and includes hardwood hammock, seasonally flowing streams, and saw palmetto thickets. Interesting tree species include hickory, dogwood, longleaf pine, hophornbeam, ironwood, American holly, and swamp chestnut oak. The trail passes through oak hammocks, hickory groves, sparkleberry thickets, and flatwoods before returning hikers to the parking lot.

name: Annutteliga Hammock
description:
This is an area with lots of sandy ground, karst limerock outcroppings, and lots of sandhills, hardwood forests, and scrub communities. This property links with the Chassahowwitzka Wildlife Management Area, which is a prime black bear habitat.<br />
There are some interior trail that goes through the forest. The other trail follows the property line.<br />
There are no restrooms or water available here.

name: Perry Oldenburg WEA
description: Hiking is most pleasant in the cooler, winter season or early in the day in warmer months. Visitors may hike along the 1.5 mile trail through the sandhills and hardwood hammock, along the powerline right-of-way, or across the 0.5-mile segment of the Florida Trail Association segment.

name: Withlacoochee State Forest/ Croom Tract - Hog Island Trail
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. It is a loop trail near the Withlacoochee River. It is forested and pretty flat with lots of trees, saw palmettos, and flowers.

name: Withlacoochee State Forest/ Croom - River Trail
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. This is a linear that trail runs alongside the Withlacoochee River and is heavily forested. The land is very flat, which makes it an easy trail, except for the long distance.

name: Conservation Center Tract
description: They have an information center & a bird viewing blind. Plus some old settlement history.

name: Chain of Lakes Regional Park Trail
description: Offers great birding opportunities as it wonders through the BCC Titusville Campus.

name: Withlacoochee State Forest/ Headquarters Tract - McKethan Lake Trail
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. It is a loop trail around McKethan Lake. There is a brochure at the trailhead with points of interest coordinating with posted numbers along the trail providing information about the forest.

name: Dade Battlefield Historic State Park
description: Take a leisurely 20 minute walk along the Pine Flatwoods Trail. This trail acquaints visitors with the native pine woods that is home to gopher tortoise, a variety of snakes, woodpeckers and other animals. Review the events of the battle by walking the short battlefield trail. This trail actually follows a stretch of the historic Fort King Military Road. It displays interpretive labels, along with monuments to Dade and his command. There is also a 10K Florida Volkssport Association trail that thoroughly covers the park sites and continues on into the neighboring community.

name: Goliad State Park & Historic Site
description: Great hikes in the area.

name: 2 Mile Tram
description: The trail is a long abandoned logging tram that heads directly west, deep into the heart of Chassahowitzka Swamp.

name: Pull TreeTram
description: Walk down this shady path, an abandoned logging roadway that fingers deep into the swamp. This was one of the many spurs or trams that were built to retrieve the felled cypress trees. Here you'll gain a strong sense of the lost world of the ancient cypress. Huge stumps will give you a sense of the circumference of the mighty trees that once dominated the forest. About 10 minutes down the trail you'll notice an enormous fallen cypress trunk on the right, filled now like a planter with a variety of ferns and palmetto.

name: Cypress Circle
description: The trails takes you around a cypress hammock.

name: Wild Turkey Trace
description: The trail takes you through scrub oak & pine forest.

name: Little Big Econ State Forest
description: Little Big Econ State Forest gets its name from the Little Econlockhatchee River and the larger Econlockhatchee which both flow through it. 9,563 acres in size, this forest is home to a number of different hiking trails.

name: Lake Apopka Restoration Area
description: Lake Apopka Restoration Area features 14 miles of hiking trails near Astatula, FL.

name: Annutteliga Hammock Unit
description: This is a 7,088 acre forest. You can find xeric hammock & a landscape dominated by karst londforms. You can find depressions, sinks & caves. There is two loops, the north loop & the south loop. The north loop is 4 miles & the trail is wide. The south loop is 2 miles & the trail is tighter & more like a trail. Also has a primitive camp site.

name: Barr Street
description: You walk along the river & through hammocks. This is also a Trailwalker trail.

name: Buck Lake Conservation Area Trail
description: Caution during hunting season, Wet during the wet season.

name: Black Hammock Wilderness Area
description:
The Black Hammock Wilderness Area (BHWA) is a 700 acre site located in east<br />
Seminole County near the town of Geneva. This site contains a diverse collection of native plant communities and wildlife and helps protect important recharge areas for<br />
the Geneva Bubble (local aquifer). Additionally, the wetland habitats of this property filter water on its way to Lake Jesup. The trail takes you on a boardwalk over a mixed hardwood swamp, through pine flatwoods & sand pine scrubs.

name: Citrus Loop "D"
description: This trail has many hills & oak hammocks along the way. You will pass by Stage Pond, Brush Sink & Lizzie Hart Sink

name: Geneva Wilderness Loop Trail
description: This wilderness area contains about 5  miles of trail that connect to the Little Big Econ State Forest to the south. There is also the Ed Yarborough Nature Center, although I have never seen it open. The trails wander through several habitats, including scrub, pine flatwoods, marshes and has a small lake system

name: Environmental Center
description: Environmental Center features 5 miles of hiking trails near Orlando, FL.

name: Wekiwa Springs State Park
description: Wekiwa Springs State Park features 9 miles of hiking trails near Apopka, FL.

name: Chassahowitzka River and Coastal Swamps
description: This trail is part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. They call it "Rooks." It is a linear trail and is about 2.5 miles round trip. The trail runs thorough a densely forested wetland area.

name: Citrus Loop "C"
description: Trail runs through small oak thickets, pine trees & can be sandy in some places.

name: Turnbull Hammock Trail
description: This trail is on the Florida birding trail

name: Chassahowitska Salt Marsh Trails / Red Cedar Trail
description: This is a 10 acre salt marsh refuge with an observation tower overlooking the salt marsh, a covered pavilion, several nature trails and a kayak and canoe launch.

name: Chassahowitzka Salt Marsh Trails / Dick Blewett
description: This is a 10 acre salt marsh refuge with an observation tower overlooking the salt marsh, a covered pavilion, several nature trails and a kayak and canoe launch

name: Chassahowitzka Salt Marsh Trails / Lastinger Tower Trail
description: From Crystal River head South on US19 into Homosassa, turn Right onto Yulee Dr, then turn Right onto Mason Creek Rd. The trailhead is on the Right side of the road alittle ways down. From Brooksville head North on US19 to Homosassa, turn Left onto Yulee Dr then Left onto Mason Creek Rd. Trailhead is on the right alittle ways up.

name: Bear Island Trailhead
description: Walking thru a swamp hammock & some oak hammocks.

name: Kettle Island Trailhead
description: Swamp

name: Otter Slough Trailhead
description: Some oak hammocks & saw palmettos.

name: Jumper Creek
description: Mostly swamp with scattered oaks.

name: Rock Springs Reserve
description: Rock Springs Reserve features 12 miles of hiking trails near Sanford, FL.

name: Citrus Loop "B"
description: Most of this trail is hilly & pine hammocks with some old oaks.

name: Withlacoochee State Forest/ Citrus "A" Loop
description: This trail is a part of the Florida Trailwalker Program. It is described as being one of the most rugged trails is Florida. There were quite a few big hills along the way. It takes you through a mix of dense oak and cypress forest and open pine forest. There are no toilets or water available.

name: Withlacoochee State Forest
description: There are a number of different trails in Withlacoochee State Forest, as well as several different tracts of land and different management techniques. Click on the individual trail listings for more detailed trail information.

name: Fort Cooper State Park
description: They have part of the fort wall that was used in the Seminole War. They have restrooms & picnic pavilions.

name: Lake Monroe Conservation Area
