name: Leasburg Dam State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Stoner Park
description: Stoner Park features 12 miles of hiking trails near Shreveport, LA.

name: Buck Creek Trail
description: Buck Creek Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Abilene, TX.

name: Edisto Beach State Park
description:
: A series of short, mostly level trails wind through through Edisto Island's maritime forest of live oak, hanging Spanish moss, and palmetto trees. During your walk you may see white-tailed deer, osprey, or alligators, and may even catch a glimpse of the wary bobcats.

Follow the Spanish Mount trail to the wetland area along Scott's Creek and visit the second oldest Native American pottery site in South Carolina, Spanish Mount, a large shell mound dated to around 2,000 B.C. Remember to stay off the mound and leave the artifacts as you found them.

name: Okatibbee Lake
description: Okatibbee Lake is an 11,000-acre multi-purpose project. The Corps of Engineers maintains one full service campground; four day use parks with three designated swimming areas and four boat ramps. Also, Okatibbee Lake offers excellent hunting opportunities. Presently there are 6,900 acres of land and flooded woodlands leased to the Mississippi Department of Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks for hunting and wildlife viewing.

name: Black Warrior & Tombigbee Lakes
description: Hiking trails at Damsite Lower Pool (Demopolis), Deerlick Creek, and Jennings Ferry Areas.

name: Flat Rock Park
description: Flat Rock Park features 9 miles of hiking trails near Columbus, GA.

name: Border Field State Park
description: The best way to reach Monument Mesa on foot is to park at the entrance gate lot, walk on the road and when the road turns, continue straight on the dirt path to the beach.  When you reach the beach, head south until you reach the border and Monument Mesa (distance = 1.6 miles).  It is advised to stay out of any puddles.

name: Tijuana River Valley Regional Park
description: Great trails.

name: CDT NM06: Burrow Peak Trailhead to Silver City (US Hwy 180)
description:
Section 6 runs 28.6 miles from the Burrow Peak Trailhead to Silver City (US Hwy 180). <br />
The first chunk of this segment is actual trail, but then after that the majority of the 28.6 miles follows roads. <br />
Along the way, this segment passes Burro Peak, Tyrone Rd. (which it follows for a ways), the Burro Mountain Homestead, Hwy 90 (which it follows for a long ways), the town of Tyrone, and finally Silver City and US Hwy 180.

name: Chewacla State Park
description: Chewacla State Park  features 2 miles of hiking trails near Auburn, AL.

name: George L. Smith State Park
description: With natural beauty, lakeside camping and cozy cottages, this secluded park is the perfect south Georgia retreat. It is best known for the refurbished Parrish Mill and Pond, a combination gristmill, saw mill, covered bridge and dam built in 1880.  A group shelter near the bridge is popular for family reunions and parties.  Some campsites sit right on the water's edge, while cottages with gas fireplaces and screened porches are nestled into the woods.

name: Lake Wilmore
description: Lake Wilmore features 3 miles of hiking trails near Auburn, AL.

name: Golden Memorial State Park
description: A nature trail winds through the park memorializes post civil War and a one-room school once located on the site.

name: Brantley Lake State Park
description: Great desert hiking.

name: Lincoln Parish Park
description: Lincoln Parish Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Ruston, LA.

name: City of Rocks State Park
description: City Of Rocks features 8 miles of hiking trails near Silver City  , NM.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California
description: The Pacific Crest Trail runs 2,663.5 miles from the Mexican border to British Columbia, Canada. This is the southernmost section of the Pacific Crest Trail (PCT), and the section descriptions listed here on Tripleblaze will be lettered in a south-to-north fashion, as is done in the official PCT guidebooks. The Google Maps locations given here on the Tripleblaze will be for the southern tip of the section in question, whenever possible.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: A
description:
The Pacific Crest Trail runs 2,663.5 miles from the Mexican border to British Columbia, Canada. This is the southernmost section of the Pacific Crest Trail (PCT), and the section descriptions listed here on Tripleblaze will be lettered in a south-to-north fashion, as is done in the official PCT guidebooks. The Google Maps locations given here on the Tripleblaze will be for the southern tip of the section in question, whenever possible. <br />
<br />
Section A runs 109.6 miles from the southern terminus of the PCT near the Mexican border to the bridge of Highway 79 in Warner Springs, CA. Section A climbs into the Laguna Mountains, and while it is dry and hot and reminiscent of the desert in many places, it stays roughly on the border of the Colorado Desert. Along the way the trail passes Campo, CA; Boulder Oaks Campground; Burnt Rancheria Campground; Mt. Laguna, CA; the Pioneer Mail Trailhead Picnic Area; the San Felipe Valley; Anza-Borrego Desert State Park; Oriflamme Canyon; and Granite Mountain.

name: Otay Valley Regional Park
description: Otay Valley Regional Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Paul M. Grist State Park
description: Tranquility prevails in this beautiful 1,080-acre park as visitors enjoy the relaxing atmosphere around the park's 100-acre lake. Recreational opportunities include swimming, fishing, boating, picnicking, hiking and camping.

name: Oracle State Park: Center for Environmental Education
description: Oracle State Park: Center for Environmental Education offers more than 15 miles of hiking trails. The Arizona Trail also offers the opportunity to extend your trek into the Catalina Mountains to the south and rolling desert hills to the north.

name: Potrero Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Swayback Bridge Trail
description: Swayback Bridge Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Wetumpka, AL.

name: Joe Pool Lake
description: Hiking trails are excellent.

name: Picacho Peak State Park
description: Hiking trails at the park vary in difficulty. Weather can be unpredictable. Please be safe and wear suitable hiking boots. Gloves and water (2 liters per person) are strongly recommended.

name: Big Cedar Wilderness Trails
description: Big Cedar Wilderness Trails features 6 miles of hiking trails near Dallas, TX.

name: Cabrillo National Monument
description:
With plenty of sunshine year round, it's easy to enjoy outdoor activities in San Diego and at Cabrillo National Monument during any time of the year. The Bayside Trail is a scenic 2-mile trail that takes you through a prime example of endangered coastal sage scrub habitat.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Sweetwater Regional Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Sweetwater Regional Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Sweetwater Regional Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lake Morena County Park
description: Lake Morena County Park sits on the beautiful Lake Morena and Morena Reservoir and consists of 3,250 acres of Californian countryside. Recreational activities here include boating, fishing, swimming, canoeing, kayaking, hiking and camping.

name: Betty's Kitchen Interpretive Trail
description: The Betty's Kitchen Interpretive Trail winds through dense riverbottom vegetation past a fishing pier and over a rugged metal bridge. Interpretive panels along the walk familiarize the visitor with the natural and cultural features of "The Kitchen."  Waterfowl, including Spotted Sandpipers, Cinnamon Teal, and American Coots are common in the winter and spring. Other commonly-seen birds include Abert's Towhee, Green Heron, egrets, Harris' Hawk, and a variety of migrating warblers in the spring including Wilson's, Yellow-rumped, Orange-crowned, Black-throated Gray, and Nashville.

name: L.H. Thomson Trails
description: L.h. Thomson Trails features 3 miles of hiking trails near Macon, GA.

name: Bodcau
description: Bodcau features 5 miles of hiking trails near Bellevue, LA.

name: 24 Hour Course
description: 24 Hour Course features 12 miles of hiking trails near Tucson, AZ.

name: Bayou Bodcau Reservoir
description: A series of 3 trails that loop together for a total of 10 miles. These 3 trails offer a unique landscape to the northwest corner of Louisiana. On the trails you will hike on level terrain, and hike in elevation changes of about 100 feet. These trails are perfect for the novice hiker, and can provide good training for the beginer. The trails are used for hiking, jogging and biking, so be on the lookout for other people. The only problem that I encountered with the trails, is that you have to be going in one direction to view the trail markers, as they start off on only one side of the trees. So before you begin make SURE to study the trail map at the trail-head before heading in. There are quite a few "side-loops" that veer off from the main trail, so another reason to study the map first. Wonderful scenery, abundant wildlife and quite hiking prove this trail a great experience.

name: Webb Peak
description: Webb Peak features 4 miles of hiking trails near Safford, AZ.

name: Whispering Pines Bike Trail
description: Whispering Pines Bike Trail is a 5 mile hiking trail in Homer, Louisiana.

name: Lake Claiborne State Park
description:
Lake Claiborne State Park contains a lake with 6,400 acres of surface area making it an incredible location for fishing, swimming, waterskiing or boating. The lake itself is stocked with two types of bass, bluegill, catfish, crappie and white perch among many more. The park's welcoming beach makes for a great place to sunbathe, relax and even picnic. The park's reservable facilities include cabins, campsites and rental boats.

In addition to all these recreational options, the park has six hiking and/or nature trails that measure out to be about 13 miles when combined.

name: James Island County Park
description:
James Island County Park boast 643 acres of beautiful recreation. It is just minutes from downtown Charleston, but it still feels secluded and peaceful. There is a $1 entrance fee per person or you can purchase a yearly pass at a huge discount.<br />
<br />
Not only are there nice walking and running trails, but there is also a huge off-leash dog park, a spray-play fountain area, a small water park, saltwater fishing areas, picnic spots, volleyball courts, horseshoe pits, and a whole lot more. This is a go-to spot for Charleston locals!

name: Oliver Lee Memorial State  Park
description: Set against the dramatic Sacramento Mountains, this park features a historic ranch house, quiet camping in the Chihuahuan Desert, and the unique oasis of pools of water under the cottonwood trees of Dog Canyon. Enjoy a short walk on the Riparian Nature Trail or a challenging hike up the Dog Canyon Trail.

name: Charles Pinckney National Historic Site
description:
Twenty-eight acres of a 715 acre plantation called Snee Farm are preserved in the park. In its open spaces are wayside exhibits along the 1/2-mile walking trail describing the existing house, archeological excavations, agricultural history and how neighboring water and wetlands contributed to the plantation.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Roper Lake State Park
description: The Mariah Mesa Nature Trail is .75 miles and has interruptive signage along the way. The rest of the trails in the park are paths that connect the campgrounds and day-use areas together.

name: Lake O' The Pines State Park
description: Lake O' the Pines State Park is about 27,700 acres with about 18,700 of that being the lake. This park is located in the northeast woods of Texas and has hiking, swimming, camping, boating and fishing.

name: Continental Divide National Scenic Trail
description:
The Continental Divide Trail is 3,100 miles long, stretching from Mexico to Canada and roughly following the continental divide. It is a part of the Triple Crown of long distance hiking trails in the US, along with the Pacific Crest Trail and Appalachian Trail. It is still under construction, so sections of it are constantly changing. The information posted here on Tripleblaze is the most up-to-date available, but these trail descriptions and GPS locations may become obsolete at some point in the future. If you notice any obsolete information, always feel free to post a review with the new info!

Whenever possible, the Google Maps location given for each section of trail will be for the most southern point. All sections are numbered in a south-to-north fashion.

The New Mexico section runs for approximately 650 miles from the Mexican border to the Colorado border, following singletrack trails and roads along the way.

To follow the trail to the north, click on over to the Colorado section.

name: White Sands National Monument
description: Amazing white sand dunes you can hike or drive across. Bring your sunglasses - this stuff is bright and reflective in the bright New Mexico sun. I recommend taking off your shoes and socks to feel the soft, fine sand up close and personal. Since the dunes are constantly shifting due to the wind be sure to remember where you parked - this place can be disorienting!

name: Rodeo Creek Trail
description:
This two and a half mile trail that runs along Rodeo Creek from Mariners Point to Investment Avenue
in Rodeo, with lush planting of indigenous trees, shrubs, grasses and wildflowers is a natural riparian corridor. The periodic placement of benches and picnic tables will create a tranquil respite for those desiring to stop and rest a minute while observing the creek habitat. For pedestrians, bicyclists and the physically challenged the trail will be a link between the neighborhoods and the business/shopping district, as well as, to public transportation transfer stations.

name: CDT NM07: Silver City (US Hwy 180) to NM Hwy 15 (Arrastra Site TH)
description:
Segment 7 of the CDT runs 20.1 miles from Silver City (US Hwy 180) to NM Hwy 15 (Arrastra Site TH). Finally, the CDT begins to leave the dry New Mexico desert and enter the green mountains.<br />
Along the way the trail follows Cottage San Rd., follows Bear Mountain Rd., eventually turns into a real trail, passes Bear Mountain, passes Stewart Peak, rejoins another road, leaves it for a trail, crosses Bear Creek Rd., and finally reaches NM Hwy 15.

name: Lake D'Arbonne State Park
description:
Lake D'Arbonne State Park is the home of forest, hills and a large 15,250-acre lake. This diverse park park is a point of interest to any fisherman, boater, water skier, cyclist, swimmer or camper who hopes to embark on a day of exhilarating fun.

The nature trails at the park provide for a scenic hike or an invigorating wildlife observation experience. Lighted tennis courts are also open for a tennis match in nature's best. The park's reservable facilities include cabins and lodges with basic cookware and appliances, various campsites and rental boats.

The four trails on the property equal out to six miles in length when combined.

name: Cottonwood Campground
description: The Sombrero Peak Trail branches from the Pepperwood Trail. It is a 5 mile hike (one-way) that eventually leads to a rocky peak that overlooks the desert. Trail users should remember to hike safe by bringing appropriate clothing, food, water, and a map.

name: River Legacy
description: River Legacy features 4 miles of hiking trails near Arlington, TX.

name: Lakeside Linkage Preserve
description: Excellent, short trail.

name: Wills Canyon (t5008)
description: Wills Canyon (t5008) features 4 miles of hiking trails near Cloudcroft, NM.

name: Charles Towne Landing State Historic Site
description: Visitors may walk the seven miles of paved and unpaved trails.

name: Pine Mountain Trail
description:
Since 1975, volunteers of all ages have labored to build and maintain the Pine Mountain Trail, a 23-mile footpath. This main trail and connecting loops, that crosses and follows the beautiful Pine Mountain ridge in west central Georgia, is inside the Franklin Delano Roosevelt State Park and near Callaway Gardens. Quiet woods, sparkling streams, misty waterfalls, rock outcroppings, varied forest, scenic overlooks, deer and turkey await your discovery. Just follow the blazes (6" by 2 Ìâå_" rectangles painted on trees). Two-foot-high rock cairns and mileage markers assist the hiker. Wooden location and mileage signs have been placed at each road crossing, trail head, junction, campsite, and at all named parking lots and trailheads. The Pine Mountain Trail offers clear crisp views of distant ridges in winter, with occasional snowfall. In the summer there are lush green ferns and lowland flowers. Wild flowers are abundant and in spring you will find flowering dogwood, native azalea, mountain laurel and rhododendron. Fall brings bright and beautiful leaves of hickory, oak, dogwood and maple, which change from day to day.<br />
<br />
In addition to the 23-mile main trail there are seven loops formed by connecting trails. In 2006, Pine Mountain Trail Association volunteers started and completed the 2.4 mile White Candle Trail section, which combined with the Beaver Pond Trail forms the newest loop, the 3.4 mile East End Loop. Near GA 190, the White Candle Trail passes through a section of old long leaf pines that FDR had planted in 1930. A historical marker nearby tells about the area.<br />
<br />
* Mountain Creek Nature Trail Loop (3.2 miles)<br />
* Overlook Loop (3.4 miles)<br />
* Dowdell Knob Loop (4.3 miles)<br />
* Wolfden Loop (6.7 miles)<br />
* Long Leaf Loop (6.9 miles)<br />
* Big Poplar Loop (7.8 miles)<br />
* East End Loop (3.4 miles) <br />
<br />
Fourteen designated back-country/backpacking campsites are at various places a short distance off the trails. FDR State Park does not charge PMTA members who present their membership card for the required permits to backcountry camp on the trail.<br />
<br />
Info and photos from Pine Mountain Trail Association.

name: Arrowhead Park
description: Arrowhead Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Macon, GA.

name: Lake Warren State Park
description: Yemassee Nature Trail is a short, easy walk, while the interpretive trail is one-mile in length.

name: Cowles Mountain/Pyles Peak
description: Cowles Mountain/Pyles Peak features 9 miles of hiking trails near Santee, CA.

name: Mission Trails Regional Park
description: Mission Trails features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Mission Trails Regional Park
description: Mission Trails features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Mission Trails Regional Park
description: Mission Trails features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Wille White (t113)
description: Wille White (t113) features 5 miles of hiking trails near Cloudcroft, NM.

name: Casa Grande Mountain
description: Casa Grande Mountain features 20 miles of hiking trails near Casa Grande, AZ.

name: East Macon Park
description: East Macon Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Macon, GA.

name: Aravaipa Canyon Trail
description: No pets. Hikers from the east end trailhead should be aware of the parking situation. The wilderness boundary is located 1.5 miles west of the Information Kiosk and restroom (new trailhead). It is recommended that visitors park there and hike through The Nature Conservancy property the remaining distance due to road conditions and possible flooding. Open space at the junction of Turkey Creek and Aravaipa Creek provide additional parking options depending on flood danger.

name: San Pedro Riparian National Conservation Area Trail
description:
view of the gila boxDescription
The 23,000-acre Gila Box Riparian National Conservation Area is truly an oasis in the desert. It has four perennial waterways - the Gila and San Francisco rivers and Bonita and Eagle creeks, which are the lifeline for this remarkable place. The Gila River canyon section, known as the Gila Box, is composed of patchy mesquite woodlands, mature cottonwoods, sandy beaches, and grand buff-colored cliffs. Bonita Creek, popular for birdwatching, hiking, and picnicking, is lined with large cottonwoods, sycamores, and willows. The perennial creek and riparian vegetation make this a cool year-round desert oasis.

name: F.D. Roosevelt State Park
description: The F.D. Roosevelt State Park Georgia's largest state park at 9,049 acres. The park include more than 40 miles of trails making it a fantastic location for any hiker or camper. The 23-mile Pine Mountain Trail is the most popular. It winds through many coniferous and deciduous trees, over creeks and to waterfalls.

name: Lake Mineral Wells State Park & Trailway
description: Great area for hiking.

name: Rose Canyon Open Space Park
description: Rose Canyon Open Space Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Lake Tawakoni State Park
description: Lake Tawakoni State Park contains the 376 acre Lake Tawakoni with plenty of activities to enjoy on it and around it! They include swimming, fishing, boating, mountain biking and hiking.

name: Little Walnut
description: Little Walnut features 20 miles of hiking trails near Silver City, NM.

name: Santee Lakes To Sycamore Canyon
description: Santee Lakes To Sycamore Canyon features 11 miles of hiking trails near Santee, CA.

name: South Alamo Foothills
description: South Alamo Foothills features 6 miles of hiking trails near Alamogordo, NM.

name: Lucas Canyon (t251)
description: Lucas Canyon (t251) features 5 miles of hiking trails near Cloudcroft, NM.

name: Wind Creek State Park
description: At Wind Creek State Park, two hiking trails offer our guests everything from the beauty of wildflowers and blooming dogwood to white-tailed deer. The trails wind over hardwood ridges and through tall pines down the shoreline, offering spectacular views of Lake Martin.

name: Sunset Trail
description: Tail winds through pine forest and meadows.  There are several views of the San Diego area and can see to the Pacific Ocean on a clear day.  The trail connects with Big Laguna Trail and overlaps for a short section.

name: Desert View Trail
description: Interperative Trail with connections to the Pacific Crest Trail.  Trail winds through oak and pine wooded areas and offers views of the Saltan Sea, 4000 ft below.

name: Lb Houston
description: Lb Houston features 6 miles of hiking trails near Las Colinas, TX.

name: Possum Kingdom State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Magnolia Springs State Park
description: Beautiful Magnolia Springs State Park is known for its crystal clear springs flowing 7 million gallons per day.  A boardwalk spans the cool water, allowing visitors to look for alligators, turtles and other wildlife near the springs. A 28-acre lake is available for fishing and boating. Overnight guests can choose from cottages and a small campground.  Magnolia Springs State Park is part of both the Park Paddlers Club and the Muddy Spokes Club. Paddlers who explore the small lake and bikers who finish a 3-mile loop can work toward earning members-only t-shirts.

name: "a" Trail (t119)
description: "a" Trail (t119) features 5 miles of hiking trails near Alamogordo, NM.

name: CDT NM08: NM Hwy 15 to NM Hwy 35
description: Segment 8 of the CDT runs 21.8 miles from NM Hwy 15 to NM Hwy 35. Along the way the trail passes the Twin Sisters mountains and Black Peak. The vast majority of this segment is on real trail, but small portions of it do follow roads.

name: Benbrook Lake
description: Nice hiking trails.

name: Turkey Creek Cliff Dwelling Trail
description:
A short trail leads to a prehistoric cliff dwelling; remnants of 120 years of homesteading and ranching are visible in the canyon. Due to its rich natural and cultural resources, part of Turkey Creek has been identified as an Area of Critical Environmental Concern by BLM.
The Turkey Creek cliff dwelling is one of the most intact structures of its kind in southeastern Arizona. It was probably occupied for a few months each year by prehistoric farmers around 1300 A.D. These people, of the Salado culture, probably collected plants along Turkey Creek, grew corn, and hunted wild animals. Salado farmers disappeared suddenly around 1450 A.D.
No fee or permit is required to visit Turkey Creek or the cliff dwelling. The structure is over 500 years old; treat it with respect by not climbing or writing on its walls. To hike the nearby Aravaipa Canyon Wilderness a permit and daily fee are required. Permits are limited to 20 per day from the east entrance and can be reserved up to three months in advance. Contact the BLM Safford Field Office for reservations.

name: Big Laguna Trail
description: Big Laguna Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Noble Canyon
description: Noble Canyon features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Noble Canyon
description: Noble Canyon features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Noble Canyon
description: Noble Canyon features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Eloise Butler Wildflower Garden and Bird Sanctuary
description: Excellent interpretive trail.

name: Oakoasis Preserve
description: 2.5 miles of loop trail

name: El Capitan Preserve
description: Excellent multi-use trails.

name: Chemin-a-haut State Park
description:
Chemin-a-haut State Park is located on a high bluff overlooking the Bartholomew Bayou in Louisiana. The 503-acre park of well preserved beauty was designed with children in mind. There are two playgrounds and a wading pool for kids. The site also includes a picnic area with 35 family picnic areas and a few group sites and shelters. The park offers lovely high view of the banks of Bayou Bartholomew. There is also the Big Slough Lake on the property for fishing. Cabins are available for renting, complete with appliances and dinnerware.

Chemin-a-haut has three popular trails for hiking. The Bobcat Trail is 1.1 miles, the Boy Scout Trail is .25 miles and the equestrian trails is 8 miles.

name: Lakeside Trail
description: Lakeside Trail features 9 miles of hiking trails near West Point, GA.

name: Rowlett Creek Preserve
description: Rowlett Creek Preserve features 13 miles of hiking trails near Garland, TX.

name: Lake Valley Historic Townsite
description: The mining town of Lake Valley was founded in 1878 after silver was discovered. Almost overnight, the small frontier town blossomed into a major settlement with a population of 4,000 people. Today, silver mining has played out and all that remains is a ghost town. BLM has restored the schoolhouse and chapel. The restored schoolhouse provides a glimpse of what schooling in a rural area was like in the early 20th century. Other buildings in the town site have been stabilized to slow further deterioration. There also is a self-guided, interpretive walking tour.

name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
description: Hikers can follow trails through stands of wind-sculpted pines. A picturesque, pueblo-style structure that served as a restaurant when it was built in 1923 houses the visitor center, featuring interpretive displays. Picnicking and camping are prohibited in the reserve. The reserve's rich plant community features wildflowers in the spring and visitors can see the California quail gathered in coveys in the early mornings of fall and winter.

name: Dry Canyon (t5574)
description: Dry Canyon (t5574) features 5 miles of hiking trails near Alamogordo, NM.

name: Cuyamaca Rancho State Park
description: There are over 100 miles of trails which accommodate hikers, bikers, and equestrians.  The two family camps, Paso Picacho and Green Valley, are open and on the reservation system spring through fall.  Green Valley sits at an elevation of 4,000 feet and has a creek which runs through the middle of the campground.  The day use area offers sets of cascades and shallow pools, great for water play on hot days.

name: Los Penasquitos Canyon Preserve
description: The park features a historic adobe ranch house built in 1823 by the recipients of the first Mexican land grant in San Diego County. The house was enlarged in 1862, and the building and site now comprise a National Historic and Archaeological District. The preserve also offers hiking, biking and equestrian trails and a wedding and reception area.

name: Goodan Ranch Sycamore Canyon Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Rim Trail
description: Rim Trail features 32 miles of hiking trails near Cloudcroft, NM.

name: Table Top Trail
description: The tail begins by crossing several small washes and bajadas (desert outwash plains), and winds northeasterly toward Table Top Mountain through forests of saguaro, cholla, prickly pear, paloverde, and ironwood. At the base of the mountain, the trail begins a series of switchbacks on its steep ascent to the summit. Near the summit the trail is bordered by four-foot-tall walls of loosely piled stones, the origin and purpose form which are unknown. Vegetation on the summit includes an unusual 40-acre island of desert grassland.

name: Squabble Creek
description: Squabble Creek is a 5 mile hiking trail in Rockwall, Texas.

name: Colonial Dorchester State Historic Site
description: A kiosk and interpretive trail offer exhibits and waysides on the history of the village and the process of discovery through archaeological and historical research.

name: Caballo Lake State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Agua Caliente County Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: The Cloud-climbing Rail Trail
description: The Cloud-climbing Rail Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Cloudcroft, NM.

name: High Altitude Racing Loop
description: High Altitude Racing Loop features 10 miles of hiking trails near Cloudcroft, NM.

name: Marrington Trail
description: Marrington Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Goose Creek, SC.

name: North Shore Trail
description: North Shore Trail features 19 miles of hiking trails near Grapevine, TX.

name: Grapevine Lake
description: Centrally located in the heart of the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex just minutes from DFW Airport, Grapevine Lake offers a variety of outdoor recreation opportunities. Nationally recognized trails, full service campgrounds, and beautiful day use areas surround the 7,276 acre lake which hosts over 2,000,000 visitors annually.

name: Picacho State Recreation Area
description: From Park road to Stamp Mill Ruins is 2 miles round trip; through Ice Cream Canyon is 4.5 miles round trip. Stamp Mill Trail makes a modest descent over beavertailcactus- dotted slopes. Enjoy vistas of Picacho Peak and of the Colorado River shore where the town of Piacacho once stood. Ice Cream Canyon Trail explores a colorful canyon tinted with strawberry and spumoni hues. Various cacti-barrel and cholla-dot canyon walls.

name: Luelf Pond Preserve
description: Luelf Pond Preserve offers two miles of trails.

name: Dos Picos Park
description:
Open from 9:30 a.m.-sunset, Dos Picos park is located just Southwest of Ramona. Its name, Spanish for "two peaks," is derived from two prominent mountains nearby. Dos Picos is surrounded by ranchland and steep rocky slopes, which help preserve its secluded atmosphere. The peaceful, shady park is well suited for campers and picnickers.

This park is mainly suited for camping and picnicking, however there is a short nature trail. The trail reaches from the pond to the rest areas for the campsites.

name: Barnett Ranch Preserve
description: Great hiking.

name: Daingerfield State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: San Elijo Lagoon Ecological Reserve
description:
Open from 9 a.m -5 p.m. daily.

Not only is San Elijo Lagoon one of the few remaining coastal wetlands in San Diego County, it is home to an exceptional number of plants and animals.

A walk along the five miles of trails will take you through various plant communities, where you'll encounter many of the 300 species of plants, 16 species of reptiles and amphibians, and 26 species of mammals. The lagoon is especially known for its bird life. At least 300 species have been seen here, 76 of which are classified as sensitive.

name: Simon Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Cedar Ridge
description: Cedar Ridge features 2 miles of hiking trails near Forsyth, GA.

name: CDT NM09: NM Hwy 35 to Rocky Point (FR 150)
description: Section 9 of the CDT runs 13 miles from NM Hwy 35 to Rocky Point (FR 150). Along the way the trail passes Sapillo Creek, several other streams, and the Reeds Peak Trail. This entire section is gorgeous singletrack: No Roads Here!

name: Lusardi Creek Preserve
description: Lusardi Creek features a small multi-use trail system (comprised primarily of utility roads) The preserve is mainly canyons with robust riparian habitat along the creek.

name: Bartram Forest
description: Bartram Forest features 10 miles of hiking trails near Milledgeville, GA.

name: Mt. Gower Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Selma Erwin Nature Trail
description: Selma Erwin Nature Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Milledgeville, GA.

name: Holmes County State Park
description: A system of interpretive nature trails winds through approximately four miles of the park, providing visitors with a close look at native plants, birds, and wildlife. An outdoor amphitheater located along the trail seats approximately 50 people and is available for use at no charge.

name: West Point Lake
description: Great trails throughout the area.

name: Santa Maria Creek/Ramona Grasslands
description:
Located about 30 minutes from San Diego, Ramona Grasslands Preserve is open from 8 a.m. - 5 p.m. (fall and winter), and 8 a.m. - 7 p.m. (summer). The preserve is a total of 3, 521 acres, and there is currently a four-mile loop trail that runs through 480 acres of the western portion of the park.

The loop is shared by bikers and horseback riders, so be on the lookout.

name: Ramona Grasslands Preserve
description: Excellent trails.

name: Palmetto Trail
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. The trail is going to be about 425 miles long when it is finally completed, but currently only about 290 miles of trail are finished and open to the public.<br />
If you are looking for detailed information about the individual segments of the Palmetto Trail, please click on the links to the individual listings below.

name: Swamp Fox Passage
description: Swamp Fox Passage features 42 miles of hiking trails near Charleston, SC.

name: Palmetto Trail - Awendaw Passage
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. When completed, the trail will cover over 425 continuous miles and run through 14 counties.<br />
290 miles are completed and currently available for public use.<br />
<br />
PALMETTO TRAIL - AWENDAW PASSAGE: <br />
7 mile path connecting the coast with the Swamp Fox Passage. Costal and intracoastal waterways, maritime forests. Hiking, backpacking and mountain biking. Easy trail during good conditions.

name: William Heise Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Givhans Ferry State Park
description: The River Bluff Nature Trail is a moderate 1.5 miles. This multi-purpose trail may be used for hiking or biking.

name: Knob Hill Grapevine Lake
description: Knob Hill Grapevine Lake features 10 miles of hiking trails near Grapevine, TX.

name: Arbor Hills
description: Arbor Hills features 2 miles of hiking trails near Plano, TX.

name: Lake Bob Sandlin State Park
description: Great hiking!

name: Colleton State Park
description: Nice little interpertive trail.

name: Lake Hodges
description: Lake Hodges features 14 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Lake Hodges
description: Lake Hodges features 14 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Lake Hodges
description: Lake Hodges features 14 miles of hiking trails near San Diego, CA.

name: Three Rivers Petroglyph Site
description: A rugged half-mile trail begins at the visitor shelter and links many of the most interesting petroglyphs. Another short trail begins on the east side of the picnic area and leads to the remains of a Mogollon village, whose inhabitants were likely responsible for the petroglyphs. Occupied for about 400 years, the site was partially excavated in 1976. On the village site, there are foundations of three types of prehistoric buildings. A small pueblo ruin is nearby and Sierra Blanca towers above to the east. Just up the road is Three Rivers Campground and an entry point into the Lincoln National Forest.

name: Lavon Lake
description: Hiking trails in East Fork Park.

name: Del Dios Highlands Preserve
description: Great views.

name: San Pasqual Trail
description: Trail climbs through a small ravine and then switchbacks up the side of a hill.  Area is mostly grasslands and rocky outcroppings.

name: Rancho La Costa
description: Rancho La Costa features 12 miles of hiking trails near Carlsbad, CA.

name: Rancho La Costa
description: Rancho La Costa features 12 miles of hiking trails near Carlsbad, CA.

name: Rancho La Costa
description: Rancho La Costa features 12 miles of hiking trails near Carlsbad, CA.

name: The Way Up Trail
description: The Way Up trail is the main trail through the Elfin Forest Preserve located in San Marcos, CA. The trail follows the side of the mountain and leads to the Olivehaven Resevoir located at the top of the mountain. a Picnic Area is provided at the top with views of the lake, but not water access is available. Total elevation gain is about 800ft.

name: San Pasqual Battlefield SHP
description:
On December 6, 1846, when the Mexican- American War was in full swing, U.S. Army General Stephen W. KearnyÌÄå¥s force of 160 men attacked Mexican forces at the village of San Pasqual. In spite of heavy American losses, both sides claimed victory.

The Battlefield Monument Trail is a 1 mile loop that walks you through the history of these moments.

The are public restrooms available.

name: Volcan Mountain Wilderness Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Rivers Bridge State Historic Site
description: The Battlefield Interpretive Trail is a self-guided trail about 3/4 of a mile with interpretive wayside panels.

name: Piedmont National Wildlife Refuge
description: Piedmont National Wildlife Refuge features 20 miles of hiking trails near Gray, GA.

name: Safford-Morenci Trail
description: The trail is 18 miles long one way, with an elevation range of 3,700 to 6,200 feet. It winds through the rugged canyons of the Gila Mountains and Turtle Mountain. With the exception of Bonita Creek, streams and springs are scarce along the route. Follow bear and mountain lion country precautions as these creatures are becoming more common along Bonita Creek. The creek's clear, cool water is inviting for a soak, but must be treated before drinking due to human, cattle, and wildlife activity upstream. Carry plenty of drinking water with you. Few people travel this remote route and it remains difficult to follow because it crosses land of mixed ownership. You will need topo maps and a compass to hike this moderate to difficult trail. The best time to hike is fall through the spring months because there is little water and shade. Snow is possible in the high elevations during the winter months.

name: Santa Ysabel Preserves
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Santa Ysabel Preserves
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Double Peak
description: 5 Mile hike round-trip.  Starts at the park near Discovery Lake.  Hike gains elevation until you reach the second highest peak in San Marcos.  Has great views of the surrounding area- from the city to the ocean.

name: Lewisville Lake
description: Excellent hiking trails throughout the area.

name: Anza-Borrego Desert State Park
description: Borrego Palm Canyon is the third-largest palm oasis in California, and was the first site sought for a desert state park back in the 1920s.  It's a beautiful, well-watered oasis, tucked away in a rocky V-shaped gorge. The trail visits the first palm grove and a waterfall.  A longer option takes you exploring farther up-canyon.  In winter, the trail to the falls is one of the most popular in the park. In summer, you'll have the oasis all to yourself. Watch for bighorn sheep, which frequently visit the canyon.

name: Corinth Community Park
description: Corinth Community Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Corinth, TX.

name: Legion State Park
description:
Legion State Park is located in the red hill country of Mississippi. The naturally developed park is a great location for camping, picnicking, hiking, fishing and boating.

A 1.6 mile nature trail that encircles the Lake Toppasha is a great location for a relaxing hike or invigorating trail run.

name: Leroy Percy State Park
description:
For a geologically diverse and beautiful state park, visit one of Mississippi's oldest state park's Leroy Percy State Park. The park is home to artesian springs, cypress trees, ancient oaks, a bayou and a delta hardwood forest. Alligator viewing, hiking, camping, picnicking, playing volleyball, fishing, hunting, boating and disc golfing are all very popular activities here.

There are two nature trails available for hiking that wind through the bayou and hardwood forest.

name: Daley Ranch
description: Daley Ranch features 20 miles of hiking trails near Escondido, CA.

name: San Tan
description: San Tan features 10 miles of hiking trails near Queen Creek, AZ.

name: Sister Grove Park
description: A 75-acre hike/bike trail located between Princeton and Farmersville, adjacent to Lake Lavon. The primitive trail is open for day use only for hiking and off-road bicycling. The trail is closed when wet. Ground fires and hunting are not permitted. Restrooms, pavillion and picnic tables are now available. The park trails are maintained by the Dallas Off Road Bike Association (DORBA). Sister Grove Park is open for day use only from sunrise to sundown.

name: Hampton Plantation State Historic Site
description: This easy, two-mile loop trail begins in the parking area and circles an abandoned rice field directly behind the Hampton Plantation Mansion. You will have an opportunity to explore the rich natural diversity, as well as the history, of the lowcountry, as you pass beneath ancient Magnolia trees that border the trail. You will find a map and information about the trail available on information kiosks at the parking area. Plaques along the way also offer historically significant information as well as information on local plants and animals. Bug repellent is recommended in the warmer seasons as ticks, horseflies, mosquitoes, and the southern "red bugs," or "chiggers," are common.

name: Trinity Trail
description: An Equestrian and hiking trail with trailheads located at Brockdale Park and East Fork Park adjacent to Lake Lavon near the communities of Lucas and Wylie. A restroom facility and picnic areas are available. The 25 mile trail is managed and maintained by volunteers with the Trinity Trail Preservation Association. For trail conditions refer to TTPA's website. View the Trail Map for more details regarding trail mileage and points of interest.

name: Sylaward
description: Sylaward features 15 miles of hiking trails near Sylacauga, AL.

name: Fort Richardson State Park & Historic Site / Lost Creek Reservoir State Trailway
description: Located at Fort Richardson and Jacksboro, this approximately 10-mile hike, bike and equestrian trail runs adjacent to Fort Richardson and along Lost Creek, which is the main watershed for the two city lakes.

name: Noxubee Crest
description: Noxubee Crest features 32 miles of hiking trails near Louisville, MS.

name: Greenbelt Trail
description: The Greenbelt Hike/Bike/Equestrian Trail is located between Lake Ray Roberts and Lake Lewisville. Through a joint project with the Army Corps of Engineers and the Cities of Denton and Dallas, a trail has been established where outdoor enthusiasts will be able to hike and bike the entire length (about nine miles) of the Elm Fork of the Trinity River.

name: Snake Creek Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Hellhole Canyon Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Hellhole Canyon Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Hellhole Canyon Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Kiwanis Fairground
description: Kiwanis Fairground features 1 miles of hiking trails near Griffin, GA.

name: Hamburg State Outdoor Recreation Area
description: Lovely area for hiking.

name: Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument
description:
Hiking in the Gila and Aldo Leopold Wilderness areas is a popular activity. Be sure to call ahead for weather conditions and backcountry water availability.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Dauset Trails Nature Center
description: Dauset Trails Nature Center features 17 miles of hiking trails near Jackson, GA.

name: Guajome County Park
description: Excellent hiking throughout area.

name: Atlanta State Park
description: Atlanta State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Atlanta, TX.

name: Denton Greenbelt
description: Denton Greenbelt features 21 miles of hiking trails near Denton, TX.

name: Lake Tannehill
description: Lake Tannehill is a 11 mile hiking trail in Bessemer, Alabama.

name: Indian Springs State Park
description:
Flovilla is a city in Butts County, Georgia, United States. <br />
Indian Springs State Park is a 528 acre Georgia state park located near Jackson and Flovilla. The park is named for its several springs, which the Creek Indians used for centuries to heal the sick. The oldest park in the nation. Indian Springs State Park became an official "State Forest Park" in 1927<br />
Tent & RV Campsites / Picnic Shelters / Pioneer Site / Group Shelter / Stone Pavilion (contact park for Stone Pavilion reservations 770-504-2277)<br />
ACCOMMODATIONS & FACILITIES:<br />
528 Acres <br />
10 Cottages ($115-$125) -- #2 and #6 are dog friendly ($40 per dog, max 2) <br />
60 Tent, Trailer, RV Campsites ($25-$28) <br />
105-Acre Lake and Swimming Beach (seasonal) <br />
7 Picnic Shelters ($55) <br />
Group Shelter (seats 130, $280) <br />
Stone Pavilion ($300) (Call park for reservations.) <br />
Group Camp and Dining Hall (sleeps 130, $255-$585) <br />
Pioneer Campground ($45) <br />
Museum (seasonal)<br />
Boating - ramp, private boats allowed, 10 HP limit <br />
Fishing Boat Rental<br />
Lake Swimming and Creek Wading <br />
Hiking - 1 mile Hiking Trail <br />
Hiking and Biking - 3.25-mile multi-purpose trail, links to Dauset Trail. <br />
Miniature Golf (fee) <br />
GeoCaching <br />
Playground

name: Erwin Park
description: Erwin Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Mckinney, TX.

name: Palmetto Trail - Lake Moultrie Passage
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. When completed, the trail will cover over 425 continuous miles and run through 14 counties.<br />
290 miles are completed and currently available for public use. <br />
<br />
PALMETTO TRAIL - LAKE MOULTRIE PASSAGE: <br />
<br />
24 mile path connecting the Swamp Fox Passage with the Eutaw Springs Passage. Mostly level, sand and gravel dikes. Plenty of views of Lake Moultrie. Hiking, backpacking and mountain biking. Easy trail during good conditions.

name: Palmetto Trail - Lake Marion Passage
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. When completed, the trail will cover over 425 continuous miles and run through 14 counties.<br />
290 miles are completed and currently available for public use. <br />
<br />
PALMETTO TRAIL - LAKE MARION PASSAGE: <br />
33 mile path connecting the Santee Passage with the High Hills of Santee Passage.<br />
Mostly shoreline travel on Lake Marion. Hiking, backpacking and mountain biking. Moderately difficult trail. Flooding may be encountered during wet periods.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: B
description:
Section B of the PCT runs 101.4 miles from the bridge of two-lane Highway 79 in Warner Springs, CA to Tamarack Road in Cabazon, CA near San Gorgonio Pass. This section of trail passes through the San Jacinto Mountains and includes the first true mountain views of the journey. As you exit the mountains, you'll drop 8,000 vertical feet down to the end of the B section at San Gorgonio Pass.<br />
<br />
Along the way the PCT passes Agua Caliente Creek; Tule Canyon Creek; Kamp-Anza RV Park in Anza, CA; Table Mountain; Highway 74; Anza, CA; Trail 4E04; Fobes Ranch Trail 4E02; Apache Spring Trail; Idyllwild, CA; Wellmans Cienaga Trail; Marion Ridge Trail 3E17; San Jacinto River; and Fuller Ridge.

name: Munny Sokol Park
description: Munny Sokol Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Tuscaloosa, AL.

name: Buckeye Hills Regional Park
description: No formal trails.

name: Boyce Thompson Arboretum State Park
description: Five trails meander through the park offering both easy strolls and rugged climbing desert hiking.

name: Lake Lurleen State Park
description: Lake Lurleen State Park now has approximately 23.47 miles of trails.  The Tashka Trail System is one main trail with five loops off of the main trail.  The fifth loop is now finished and open to hiker and mountain bikers.  The new fifth loop added 4 miles to our beautiful trail system and will be very accommondating to the amateur mountain biker or hiker.

name: Moro Bay State Park
description: A hiking trail offers hikers wildlife viewing opportunities.

name: Bottomless Lakes State Park
description: Good hiking area.

name: White Canyon Trail
description: The White Canyon Trail traverses through the White Canyon Wilderness Area. Along the trail one will see many topographical features, including White Canyon itself and several side canyons, as well as the Rincon, a large escarpment overlooking the Gila River valley to the south. Riparian vegetation, Sonoran desert, and chaparral are the dominant vegetation types in the area. The White Canyon area is enjoyable year-round since each season provides opportunities to enjoy the unique features of the wilderness area's landscape, however fall and spring provide the most comfortable temperatures.

name: Oak Mountain State Park Bump Trail
description: Oak Mountain State Park Bump Trail features 18 miles of hiking trails near Birmingham, AL.

name: Fantasy Island North Singletrack (FINS)
description: Fantasy Island North Singletrack (FINS) features 8 miles of hiking trails near Avondale, AZ.

name: Barnwell State Park
description: The Dogwood Interpretive Trail is a moderately difficult 1.5-mile long trail.

name: CDT NM11: FR 226 to NM Hwy 59
description:
Segment 11 of the CDT runs for 15.1 miles from FR 226 to NM Hwy 59. This section starts out on a little bit of gravel road, but the vast majority is on real trail!<br />
Along the way, this segment passes Lookout Mountain, Franks Mountain West, Franks Mountain East, and Kline Mountain.

name: Wright Patman Dam and Lake
description: Wright Patman Lake is located in the beautiful piney woods of northeast Texas. The lake includes about 30,000 surface acres of water and 50,000 acres of land. Numerous recreational opportunities are available including camping, boating, fishing, swimming, hiking, hunting, and wildlife viewing including wintering bald eagles, pelicans, and various migratory ducks. Local attractions include numerous festivals such as Four State Fair and Rodeo; Quadrangle Street Festival;Jump, Jive and Jam Festival in Texarkana; Forest Festival in Atlanta; and Frontier Days Festival in New Boston. Texarkana also has numerous museums and points of interest including historic buildings and memorials.

name: Palomar Mountain State Park
description: Scott's Cabin Trail runs from Silver Crest Picnic Area to Scott's Cabin; Cedar Grove Campground and Boucher Lookout is a 3.5 mile loop with 800-foot elevation gain.

name: Perk Canyon
description: Perk Canyon features 6 miles of hiking trails near Ruidoso, NM.

name: Doane Pond Nature Trail
description: Short little nature trail around Doane Pond.  Fishing is available at the pond as well as birds and wildlife.  There are trail connections for Scotts Cabin Trail and Fry Creek Trail.

name: Lower Doane Valley Trail
description: Easy hike leaving from the Palomar Mountain State Park Campground.  The hike wonders through meadows as well as patches of oak and pine. Trail offers a connection the Wier Trail and to the Doane nature trail.

name: BSC Trail
description: BSC Trail features 2 miles of hiking trails near Peachtree City, GA.

name: Logoly State Park
description: The park's natural resources provide a living laboratory for students and visitors. Most of Logoly's 368 acres comprise a State Natural Area that includes unique plant species and mineral springs.

name: Rock Hawk
description: Rock Hawk features 15 miles of hiking trails near Eatenton, GA.

name: Cooper Lake State Park
description: Great trails.

name: Palomar Observatory Trail
description: The observatory trail connects the Observatory Campground with the Palomar Observatory. The area is filled with a mixture of Oak and Pine, and offers a variety of wildlife.  Woodpeckers and Blue Jays are easily spotted along the trail.

name: Oak Mountain State Park
description: Oak Mountain State Park has approximately 51 miles of trail that people enjoy on a daily basis.

name: Skidmarks
description: Skidmarks features 3 miles of hiking trails near Roswell, NM.

name: National Trail
description: National Trail features 14 miles of hiking trails near Phoenix, AZ.

name: Desert Classic
description: Desert Classic features 9 miles of hiking trails near Phoenix, AZ.

name: Wilderness Gardens Preserve
description: Great trails.

name: Estrella Mtn Park/ Competitive Loop
description: Estrella Mtn Park/ Competitive Loop features 10 miles of hiking trails near Phoenix, AZ.

name: Lake Chicot State Park
description: The park offers lake tours, levee tours, and other opportunities for you to view a variety of birds and other wildlife.

name: San Onofre SB
description:
San Onofre SB is a rare 3,000 acre coastal-canyon park.
The park is accented by steep bluffs, sandstone cliffs and a canyon by the sea.
There are a half dozen trails here, but the most popular is the Bluffs Beach Trail. It is a beautiful hike, but some areas may be impassable at the highest tide.

name: Stinky Trail
description: Wendy's / Hwy 74 Parallel features 2 miles of hiking trails near Peachtree City, GA.

name: Cloudview
description: Cloudview is a 20 mile hiking trail in Gold Canyon, Arizona.

name: Ray Roberts Lake State Park
description: The Ray Roberts Lake/Lake Lewisville Greenbelt Corridor is a 20-mile multiuse trail system (12 miles for equestrian and 10 miles for hike and bike use) that begins at the Ray Roberts Dam and ends at the headwaters of Lake Lewisville. This unique trail corridor meanders along the heavily wooded banks of the Elm Fork Branch of the Trinity River. Equestrians, hikers, bikers, canoeists, birdwatchers, anglers and other outdoor enthusiasts can access the trail at one of three trailheads, located at FM 455, FM 428 and Highway 380. .

name: Santa Margarita Preserve
description: Santa Margarita County Preserve is 221 acres and is part of the County of San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Program. The property was acquired in 1992 to preserve the resources and picturesque scenery of the Santa Margarita Valley, while providing additional public trails in the community of Fallbrook. In partnership with the Fallbrook Land Conservancy the park was restored after the 2002 Gavilan Fire for public access. The trails are open for multiple use; horse back riding, hiking and mountain biking. To the north the trails connects with the Fallbrook Public Utility Districts trails. To the west the preserve is buffered by Camp Pendleton.

name: Sandy Beach Spur Trail
description:
Sandy Beach Spur Trail is roughly 6 miles using the Spur Trail and the Lake Moultrie Dike. The trail is not heavily marked so the key is to always follow the main dirt road. After traveling about 4 miles on the Spur Trail you will emerge onto the dike. Travel left here for about 2 miles. This will bring you back to Sandy Beach Road. Turn left again and head back to the parking lot.<br />
On the other hand, If you budget plenty of time, there are plenty of diversions. Firebreaks and 2-track roads leave the main road in many places. You will definitely want to check out the primitive camping area on Lake Moultrie. Look for the trail sign with the campground sticker, and proceed 10 minutes to the area. A nice view of Lake Moultrie awaits. You can also see the huge Santee Cooper Cross Station Power Plant across the lake. Also, follow the short trail behind the water hand pump to a small backwater cove. Approach the water quietly and cautiously. This backwater is alligator territory. Another primitive campground is available off the dike.<br />
Overall, this is an easy hike made slightly difficult only during the hottest days of the year. The dirt road and dike are completely exposed. Water is available at both campgrounds, however. Lastly, the Spur Trail is only open from March 1st to November 1st.<br />
You can download a .PDF map at www.palmettoconservation.org.

name: San Clemente SB
description:
San Clemente State Beach is one of California's most popular beaches. It is populated with surfers on the north end of the one-mile beach as well as hikers along the trails on the bluffs. The beach features a bluff top with picnic sites for beautiful views.

Two more well known trails are the Multi-Use trail which is an easy terrain, 1/4 mile trail from Avenita Del Presendente Ave to the campground and the Butterfly trail which is also short, less than 1/4 mile, through a fresh eucalyptus grove.

name: Camp Preston Hunt Boy Scout Trail
description: Camp Preston Hunt Boy Scout Trail is a 6 mile hiking trail in Texarkana, Arkansas.

name: Johnson Branch
description: Johnson Branch features 9 miles of hiking trails near Valley View, TX.

name: Chattahoochee Bend State Park
description: There are about 6 miles of trails at Chattahoochee Bend State Park with plans to add more in the future. The Riverside Trail is fairly flat and sandy and offers great views of the river. The Tower trail from the visitors' center offers more elevation and leads to the observation tower on the Riverside trail. Great place to hike with the family.

name: Lake Lowndes State Park
description:
Lake Lowndes State Park is a wonderful family-oriented park. The park is located on the 150-acre Lowndes Lake. Fishing, camping, softball, tennis, football, mountain biking, hiking, camping, horseback riding and trail running are some of the more popular activities at this diverse park.

A four-mile multi-use trail is available for hiking and mountain biking. There is great hiking here.

name: CDT NM12: NM Hwy 59 to NM Hwy 163
description:
Section 12 of the CDT runs 25.5 miles from NM Hwy 59 to NM Hwy 163. The majority of this segment is legitimate trail, but there are short sections of road interspersed throughout.<br />
Along the way this segment passes Wahoo Peak and Bear Mountain. Towards the end it descends out of the lush mountains into one of New Mexico's high deserts.

name: Red Mountain Park
description: Red Mountan Park features 4 miles of hiking trails near Birmingham, AL.

name: Papago Park Area
description: Papago Park Area features 5 miles of hiking trails near Tempe, AZ.

name: Gila River Canyons Trail
description: This section begins at the Kelvin Bridge as it crosses the Gila River. The trail then follows the Gila River for many miles - sometimes rising several hundred feet above and sometimes near river level. It crosses numerous canyon drainages and occasionally catches a glimpse of The Spine, Walnut Canyon Narrows, Copper Butte, and The Rincon, all to the north.

name: Harquahala Foothills Staging Area
description: The Harquahala Foothills Staging Area serves as the gateway to the 10.5 mile Harquahala Mountain Backcountry Byway and the Harquahala Mountains Wilderness. The byway leads to the 5,600 foot Harquahala Mountain summit which provides dramatic views of the surrounding mountain ranges, most notably the Eagletail Mountains.

name: Brittlebush Trail
description: Brittlebush Trail follows a combination of former vehicle tracks and wide, unmarked desert washes. No trail signage or directional markers are available along the route; therefore, this trail is recommended only for experienced hikers skilled in reading topographic maps. The northern terminus of the Brittlebush Trail intersects the Margie's Cove Trail in the interior of the North Maricopa Mountains Wilderness.

name: Margie's Cove Trail
description: Margie's Cove Trail follows a combination of former vehicle tracks and wide, unmarked desert washes. No trail signage or directional markers are available along the route; therefore, this trail is recommended only for experienced hikers skilled in reading topographic maps. Margie's Cove Trail intersects the northern terminus of the Brittlebush Trail in the interior of the North Maricopa Mountains Wilderness. Margie's Cove Trail is not mapped; however, the route is depicted on the USGS 7.5-minute topographic maps "Butterfield Pass, Ariz." and "Cotton Center SE, Ariz." The remainder of the North Maricopa Mountains Wilderness is depicted on USGS 7.5- minute topographic maps "Margies Peak, Ariz.," and "Mobile NW, Ariz."

name: Lost Dutchman State Park
description: Six trails for hikers. Those planning to use the longer trails should carry a topographic map. Each person should carry at least one gallon of drinking water per day. Remember summer temperatures often exceed 100Ìâå¡F. A trail map is provided with entrance fee.

name: Boyd Pond
description: Boyd Pond features 5 miles of hiking trails near Beech Island, SC.

name: Pass Mountain
description: Usery Mountain Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Mesa, AZ.

name: Hawes Loop
description: Hawes Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Mesa, AZ.

name: Mcintosh Reserve
description: Mcintosh Reserve features 7 miles of hiking trails near Whitesburg, GA.

name: (Doug Ghee) Bald Rock Boardwalk Trail at Cheaha State Park
description: Take an easy stroll down a unique boardwalk trail named after a long-time supporter of Alabama's state parks. Located in Cheaha State Park, the hike ends in a rock outcropping that offers magnificent views of the surrounding valley and mountains. Opened in June 2000, this elevated boardwalk trail was designed to be accessible to everyone regardless of physical ability. Named after former Democratic Senator Doug Ghee, a long-time supporter of Alabama's state parks and primary innovator of Alabama's Forever Wild land acquisition and conservation program, this 1,519-foot trail is short for a "trail" but long for a boardwalk, especially one located in such a remote area. The parking area for this trail is located to the side of the Bald Rock Group Lodge, in front of the trailhead.  One-quarter-mile in length, this interpretive trail terminates in a scenic overlook from where views stretch halfway to Birmingham.

name: Charlie Elliot Wildlife Center
description: Charlie Elliot Wildlife Center features 6 miles of hiking trails near Mansfield, GA.

name: Pulpit Rock Trail at Cheaha State Park
description: The trail leads to a scenic overlook in the Talladega National Forest which is characterized by its many rock outcroppings. This area of the Park is noted for its high concentration of mountain laurel and when in bloom in the spring, makes for a very colorful walk. The trail is one way and does not loop back upon itself. A moderate hike, Pulpit Rock is a quartzite rock facing where many guests come to rappel or just take in the view.

name: North Augusta Greeneway
description: North Augusta Greeneway features 5 miles of hiking trails near North Augusta, SC.

name: Fort Stanton-Snowy River Cave National Conservation Area

Note: These trails were designed and built and are maintained by mountain bikers. As such, this is a very, very popular mountain bike destination and it is filled with riders every day of the week. Just be aware when you go that you will likely encounter significant mountain bike traffic.

name: Panola Mountain State Park
description:
This unusual park near Atlanta was created to protect a 100-acre granite monadnock (mountain) often compared to Stone Mountain and Arabia Mountain. Minimally developed, Panola Mountain shelters rare plants of the Piedmont region. Hikers may explore the park's watershed and granite outcrop on their own, or they may join park staff for guided hikes onto the restricted-access mountain. Children especially enjoy the interpretive center with animal exhibits.

Due to its delicate ecological features, Panola Mountain was designated a National Natural Landmark, and pets are not allowed on most trails. Bicycles are allowed only on the paved PATH trail.

http://gastateparks.org/info/panolamt/

name: Huntington State Beach
description:
Huntington Beach Trail: This hike takes you north along wide sandy Huntington State Beach to Bolsa Chica State Beach and adjacent Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve. You can also make this a one-way jaunt by taking advantage of OCTD Bus #1 which makes several stops along Paciﬁc Coast Highway.

This is an ideal beach trail to bike and hike. A bike path extends the length of Bolsa Chica Beach to the Santa Ana River south of Huntington Beach. You can leave your bike at Bolsa Chica State Beach and hike up to it from Huntington Beach.

name: Valley of Fires Recreation Area
description: The fully accessible Malpais Nature Trail with interpretive displays starts at the group shelter and leads the visitor into the lava flow. The trail is paved and has a guide brochure.

name: Mistletoe State Park
description: Mistletoe State Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Thompson, GA.

name: Keg Creek
description: Keg Creek features 8 miles of hiking trails near Augusta, GA.

name: Tonto National Monument
description:
Tonto National Monument has several trails available for hiking. The paved 1/2-mile Lower Cliff Dwelling trail ascends 350 vertical feet to the dwelling, and is considered moderately strenuous. The 1/4 mile Cactus Patch is an off-shoot of the Lower Cliff Dwelling Trail. The unpaved 1.5-mile Upper Cliff Dwelling trail ascends 600 vertical feet, and is considered strenuous. You must be accompanied by park staff to visit this dwelling.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: CDT NM14: Coyote Stock Tank to FR 3070
description:
Segment 14 of the CDT runs 27.4 miles from the Coyote Stock Tank to FR 3070. While there are 1 or 2 short sections of road in this segment, the vast majority of it is true trail.<br />
Along the way, the trail passes O Bar O Mountain, Salvation Peak, and Pinon Knob.

name: Upper Newport Bay Nature Preserve
description:
Open from 7 a.m.- sunset every day, the Upper Newport Bay Nature Preserve represents about 140 acres out of teh 1,000 acres that is the Ecological Reserve. It's located right out of Costa Mesa and is made up of the bluffs surrounding the Bay. This coastal wetland, one of the largest in southern California, is renowned as one of the finest bird watching sites in North America.

This preserve is also one of the best county facilities for recreation and wildlife viewing. There are plenty of trails that lead over the bluffs and allow you to view the rare wildlife that is found in this park. Be sure to visit the Interpretive Centers that are located in the area!

name: O'Neill Regional Park
description:
Open year round from 7 a.m. to sunset.

Over 23 miles of trails exist in O'Neill, and are perfect for exploring on a hike. Trails will pass through heavily wooded areas with coast live oak and sycamore trees. The hillsides surrounding the park are filled with cactus, wild buckwheat, sagebrush and chaparral of scrub oak, buckthorn and mountain mahogany, so you'll be sure to have a beautiful time!

Trails are shared with bikers and horseback riders.

name: Talbert Regional Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: William R. Mason Regional Park
description: William R. Mason Regional Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Irvine, CA.

name: Hard Labor Creek State Park
description: Weekday hiking on 22-mile horse trail.

name: Bartram Trail (West Dam/Wildwood Park)
description:
The Bartram Trail is a long singletrack trail that runs along the shores of the lack and offers tons of gorgeous views of the blue water! This trail is relatively flat, and as such it is a very easy hike. The trail can be accessed from several different points.

Note: This is a rather popular mountain bike trail.

name: Ben Avery Trailhead
description: The magnificent rocky spires and beauty of the Eagletail Mountains Wilderness Area can be explored along the Ben Avery Trail. Just 70 miles from Phoenix, the Ben Avery Trail makes a perfect day trip. Originally an old jeep route, the trail winds south into a wash and then to the bluffs next to Indian Spring. The trail to Indian Springs and back to your vehicle is approximately 7 miles. For a longer trip, hikers can follow cairns along a faint path into a deep wash, heading northward. A climb up the hillside to the west reveals the dramatic scenery of the Eagletail Mountains, including two natural arches. The best seasons to hike the trail are fall, winter, and spring. There are no permanent sources of water along the trail so plan on packing at least one gallon of water per person, per day.

name: Millwood State Park
description: The park has a self-guided nature trail.

name: Boundary Waters Park

name: McDowell Mountain Park

name: Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve
description:
Arabia Mountain Heritage Area is located within a 20-minute drive east of the City of Atlanta and encompasses land in DeKalb, Rockdale and Henry County. The natural, historical and cultural resources prevalent in this area of Georgia provide an exceptional opportunity for recreation, environmental education and heritage preservation.<br />
<br />
The nucleus of this heritage area is Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve; a DeKalb County Park comprised of 2,000 acres of granite outcrop, wetlands, pine and oak forests, streams, and a lake.<br />
<br />
Trail maps and more information: http://www.arabiaalliance.org

name: Georgia International Horse Park
description:
The Georgia International Horse Park was the site of the cross-country race for the 1996 Olympics. This is still a very popular mountain biking trail, so just be aware when you head out.

The easier side of the trail winds through the woods and is a very moderate trail. The tougher side features some very cool sections of slickrock and some steep climbs and descents. This trail is unlike any other in Georgia!

name: Steeplechase Loop
description:
This is the easier side of the trails at the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/1293/Hiking-Trails/Georgia-International-Horse-Park.html">Georgia International Horse Park.</a>

This trail winds through the woods and is very moderate.

Note: The Georgia International Horse Park was the site of the cross-country race for the 1996 Olympics. This is still a very popular mountain biking trail, so just be aware when you head out.

name: White Oak Lake State Park
description: Watchable wildlife and bird watching opportunities abound here. The park offers regular sightings of great blue heron, egret, osprey, and green heron, and in wintertime, migrating bald eagles. While the lake is drained, many new bird species are being seen due to the habitat change in the lake bed.

name: Harriett M. Wieder Regional Park
description: Unique features include creative challenging play equipment called Galaxy that display attractive, contemporary abstract designs which encourage creative and thought-provoking play for children ages 6-12. Similar to Galaxy, the Elements tot lot area for 2-5 year-olds feature units that promote climbing, sliding, swinging, spinning and tottering fun. Wieder Park has more than 2,200 lineal feet of new trails (just under a å_ mile in the four plus acre area) and an additional 520 feet of soft riding trail spanning the street front portion of the park. The site is further enhanced by 1,700 native plants. Finally its 1,300-foot wire fence protects children from street traffic and serves as a boundary separating adjacent private property.

name: CDT NM13: NM Hwy 163 to the Coyote Stock Tank
description:
Segment 13 runs for 32.4 miles from NM Hwy 163 to the Coyote Stock Tank. Much of this section is spent crossing high New Mexico desert. Roughly half of it is trail, and roughly half is road, although it is not split evenly as the road and trail sections alternate along the entire segment's length.<br />
Along the way this segment passes Pelona Mountain and Coyote Peak. Towards the end the trail starts to get into slightly greener country.<br />
Note: this segment crosses the time zone line.

The trail also goes by the remains of the Mastodon Gold Mine before descending back to the parking lot.

name: Palmetto Trail - High Hills of Santee Passage
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. When completed, the trail will cover over 425 continuous miles and run through 14 counties.<br />
290 miles are completed and currently available for public use. <br />
<br />
PALMETTO TRAIL - HIGH HILLS OF SANTEE PASSAGE: <br />
<br />
9 mile path connecting the Lake Marion Passage with the Wateree Passage. Travels through Manchester State Forest. Red cedar, oaks, and pine. Soft sand. Hiking, backpacking, mountain biking, and equestrian. Moderately difficult trail during good conditions.

name: Sonora Trail

Along the way the trail passes John Kerr Peak and Wagontongue Mountain.

There are several nice vistas that offer good view of the Hemet Valley. The trail is located in a Pine and Oak forest, with plenty of shade and abundant wildlife, particularly squirrels and blue jays.

name: Campbells Pond
description: Campbells Pond features 4 miles of hiking trails near Wedgefield, SC.

description: Trails and picnic area in 9 acre DeKalb county park.

name: Mason Mill Park
description: Paved concrete path with wide wooden bridges lead you to hiking trails running throughout the park. Hike around ruins from the old waterworks, get up close to the creek, and discover granite outcroppings.

name: Quartz Peak Trail
description: Quartz Peak Trail is extremely steep and difficult to follow in places. This is a hike for experienced and well-conditioned hikers only! The trail begins at Quartz Peak Trailhead by following a closed four-wheel-drive track approximately 1/4 mile. Look to the left as you walk up the old road and see a narrow trail ascending the ridge to the north (see map below). The trail is poorly marked in places and does not extend to the summit--the final 1/4 mile to Quartz Peak is a scramble over boulder and talus slopes that requires careful footing. Quartz Peak is a point on the spine of the Sierra Estrella capped with an outcrop of white quartz.

name: Grenada Lake
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Lenora Park
description: Multi-purpose trail.

name: Clyde Shepherd Nature Preserve
description: Lots of trail to explore including boardwalk sections and even a photo blind on the edge of a marshy area. Well signed trails.

name: Forty Oaks Nature Preserve
description: Trails and picnic area in 10 acre DeKalb county park.

name: Morningside Nature Preserve
description: Morningside Nature Preserve features 1 miles of hiking trails near Atlanta, GA.

name: W. D. Thompson
description: About a mile or two of wooded trails. Lots of roots and logs across the trail to scramble over. A small creek with a couple crossings. Hidden gem!

name: Mount San Jacinto State Park
description:
The park offers access to the Pacific Crest Trail, along with many other area trails. From Mountain Station to Round Valley is 4 miles round trip with 600-foot elevation gain; to San Jacinto Peak is 11 miles round trip with 2,300-foot elevation gain.

Also, starting in Chino Canyon near Palm Springs, the Palm Springs Aerial Tramway takes passengers from Valley Station at 2,643 feet elevation to Mountain Station on the edge of the wilderness, elevation 8,516 feet.

name: Eisenhower State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Stone Mountain State Park
description: Many trails to choose from in the park ranging from forested lake trails to the most popular mountain trail that takes you to the summit of Stone Mountain. The mountain trail traverses the exposed granite monolith starting in a thin pine forest and eventually gives way to a completely exposed and sometimes steep ascent. Bring plenty of water on hot days!

name: Montreal Park
description: Hiking trails and picnic area in 9 acre DeKalb county park.

name: Cave Creek Regional Park
description: Located north of Phoenix, this 2,922-acre park sits in the upper Sonoran Desert. Ranging in elevation from 2,000 feet to 3,060, this desert oasis provides any hiker and equestrian majestic views. The Go John Trail loops around a mountain to provide the illusion of being miles away from civilization. In the 1870s, fever stricken gold seekers staked their dreams on the jasper-studded hills. Guided trails to these sites give visitors an opportunity to travel back in time.

name: Cave Creek Park
description: Cave Creek Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Phoenix, AZ.

name: Congaree National Park
description:
Activities at Congaree National Park include hiking, primitive camping, bird watching, picnicing, canoeing & kayaking, Ranger guided interpretive walks and canoe tours, nature study, and environmental education programs.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Bluff Trail, Congaree National Park
description:
1.7 miles of easy and interesting walking through the youngest ecosystem in Congaree National Park. This trail passes through new-growth loblolly pines and mixed hardwoods, providing an opportunity to witness what goes on in the "new" woods, compared to the ancient environs of the rest of the park. Visit http://www.nps.gov/cosw/index.htm for details. <br />
The Bluff Trail can be the start of a longer, and super biodiversified hike using the many combinations of trails available at Congaree. Pick up a free trail map at the visitor center before you start walking. <br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: The Boardwalks Loop, Congaree National Park
description:
2.4 miles of easy and interesting walking on the elevated boardwalk and the low boardwalk through a mixture of bottomland hardwoods and upland pines.
