Visit http://www.nps.gov/cosw/index.htm for details. Call the park directly for current trail conditions before you visit. (803) 776-4396 ext. 0. Every once in a while, the Congaree River floods it's banks, making a hike on the low boardwalk portion impossible. The elevated boardwalk, however, is rarely under water and this is a nice 1.3 mile hike down to Weston Lake. <br />
The boardwalks loop is a self-guided interpretive trail with 21 points of interest. Pick up a free interpretive trail guide at the visitor center before you start walking. <br />
<br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: Sims Trail, Congaree National Park
description:
4.6 miles of interesting walking using the Bluff Trail and Sims Trail as an out-and-back. This is good way to see new-growth forest and old-growth forest in the same hike. The Bluff trail departs the After Hours parking lot and is easy walking to the junction with the Sims Trail. From there, the walking is more like country road travel, all the way down to Cedar Creek. Pick up a free trail map at the Harry Hampton Visitor Center before you start walking. There are many combinations of trails that can be used. You can easily turn the Sims Trail hike into a 'loop' hike by returning on the Weston Lake Loop Trail and Low Boardwalk.<br />
Call the park directly for current trail conditions before you visit. Every once in a while, the Congaree River floods it's banks, making a hike on most of the Sims Trail impossible. (803) 776-4396 ext. 0 <br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: Weston Lake Loop Trail, Congaree National Park
description:
4.4 miles of interesting walking around Weston Lake and through old-growth forest. This trail not only circumnavigates Weston Lake and a large cypress-tupelo slough, it bumps into Cedar Creek a couple times, providing ample opportunities for viewing waterfowl, beavers, and river otters. Feral pigs, raccoons, and whitetail deer can also be seen along the trail. <br />
Visit http://www.nps.gov/cosw/index.htm for details. Call the park directly for current trail conditions before you visit. Every once in a while, the Congaree River floods it's banks, making a hike on most of the Weston Lake Loop Trail impossible. (803) 776-4396 ext. 0.<br />
<br />
Pick up a free park trail guide at the visitor center before you start walking. There are many combinations of trails that can be enjoyed. The Weston Lake Loop Trail is a 'true' loop, using both the high boardwalk and low boardwalk, but using the trail combinations can add-to your Congaree outing.<br />
<br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: Oakridge Trail, Congaree National Park
description:
6.6 miles of interesting walking through old-growth forest and over many streams. Visit http://www.nps.gov/cosw/index.htm for details. Call the park directly for current trail conditions before you visit. Every once in a while, the Congaree River floods it's banks, making a hike on most of the Oakridge Trail impossible. (803) 776-4396 ext. 0 <br />
Pick up a free park trail guide at the visitor center before you start walking. There are many combinations of trails that can be enjoyed. The Oakridge Trail is a 'true' loop trail, but using those combinations can give you a more diversified outing.<br />
<br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: River Trail, Congaree National Park
description:
10 miles of interesting walking that will give you the only access to the Congaree River within the Congaree National Park. Experience the rich biodiversity of hardwood bottomland and witness the long term results of heavy timber cutting that occurred before the park was established and protected.<br />
Visit http://www.nps.gov/cosw/index.htm for details. Call the park directly for current trail conditions before you visit. Every once in a while, the Congaree River floods it's banks, making a hike on most of the River Trail impossible. (803) 776-4396 ext. 0.<br />
<br />
Pick up a free park trail guide at the visitor center before you start walking. There are many combinations of trails that can be enjoyed. The River Trail is both an out-and-back and loop, but using those combinations can give you a more diversified outing.<br />
<br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: Kingsnake Trail, Congaree National Park
description:
11.7 miles of interesting walking through multiple ecosystems and substantial American history. Visit http://www.nps.gov/cosw/index.htm for details. Call the park directly for current trail conditions before you visit. Every once in a while, the Congaree River floods it's banks, making a hike on most of the Kingsnake Trail impossible. (803) 776-4396 ext. 0 <br />
Pick up a free park trail guide at the visitor center before you start walking. There are many combinations of trails that can be enjoyed. The Kingsnake Trail is basically an out-and-back, but using those combinations can give you a more diversified outing.<br />
<br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: Distance Hike, Congaree National Park
description:
This is a 23.2 mile backpacking tour of Congaree that can be completed by experienced hikers, during favorable trail conditions, in two days. The route will take you through every part of the park, allowing you to witness one of the most amazing preservation and conservation efforts in the world.<br />
Free is good. You don't need to buy a guide book. Print this page and bring it with you. Pick up a free trail map at the Harry Hampton Visitor Center. Use both as a guide. Also, register at the visitors center and let the rangers know your intentions. You will need to obtain a free backcountry camping permit. Congaree National Park is a designated wilderness area, and although backcountry camping is allowed, strict regulations apply. Also, the Congaree River floods it's banks every once in a while, making passage on most of this route impossible. It is best to simply call the park directly with questions and concerns, and for current trail conditions. (803) 776-4396.<br />
THE ROUTE:<br />
Starting at the After Hours parking lot - Bluff Trail to the elevated boardwalk.<br />
Left on elevated boardwalk to Weston Lake.<br />
Left on Weston Lake Loop Trail.<br />
Left on Kingsnake Trail.<br />
Travel out-and-back on Kingsnake Trail.<br />
Straight on Oakridge Trail at Bridge I.<br />
CAMP. Bridge G on the Oakridge Trail is exactly the half way mark (11.6 miles). You will want to discuss camping opportunities in this area with the rangers when you obtain your permit.<br />
Left on River Trail.<br />
Complete River Trail loop and return.<br />
Left at River Trail and Oakridge Trail junction.<br />
Right on Weston Lake Loop Trail.<br />
Continue back to Weston Lake.<br />
Left on low boardwalk.<br />
Complete low boardwalk, heading in the direction of the visitors center.<br />
Left on Bluff Trail, departing boardwalk before reaching the visitors center.<br />
End at the After Hours parking lot.<br />
Congratulations! You have walked on every trail in the park except the Sims Trail, which is really a road anyway. No big deal, right?<br />
This route is only a suggestion. Once you see the trail map you will know the variations available. I suggest this route, however, because it is pretty simple to follow and it has a nice flow through the park.<br />
There is one more thing about this route that is interesting. You only have to carry your backpack on 9.7 of the 23.2 miles. You can dump your pack prior to the Kingsnake Trail at bridge I, and then again prior to the River Trail around bridge F. Use caution hiding your pack and inspect it for snakes upon return.<br />
Be sure to ask the rangers about the Friends of Congaree Swamp. This is a non-profit organization that helps protect and promote Congaree National Park and it's unique environment. More info here: http://www.friendsofcongaree.org

name: Heritage Park
description: 1.7 mile soft surface walking trail

name: Silver Comet Rail Trail
description: The Silver Comet Trail features 60 miles of hiking trails near Cobb County, GA.

name: Pat Mayse Lake
description: Pat Mayse Lake features 6 miles of hiking trails near Arthur City, TX.

name: Great River Road State Park
description: Great River Road's Nature Trail gives the visitor a view of the plants and animals of the bottomland, hardwood, forest and swamp. Several trails lead to the sandbar, which at low water form one of the largest beaches in the state. The sandbars are visited by a variety of birds and animals, some of which you may see, others will leave their interesting tracks.  The trail is approximately 1.5-miles long.

name: Dominguez Gap Wetlands
description: Short nature walk on paved, handicap accessible trail.  Relatively flat with lots of birds and wildflowers.

name: Lake Pleasant Regional Park
description: Lake Pleasant Regional Park offers over four miles of trails for pedestrain use only. Park trails range in length from .5 mile to 2 miles and moderate in difficulty.

name: Mountain Park Park
description: 1-mile paved multi-purpose trail

name: Briarwood Recreation Center
description: Trails and picnic area in 18 acre DeKalb county park.

name: Elijah Clark State Park
description: This park is located on one of the largest lakes in the southeast, the 71,100-acre Clarks Hill Lake. It is a great destination for camping as it provides numerous camp sites and picnic areas. Swimming, boating and fishing are also popular activities at this large park. The park is named for a Georgia Revolutionary War hero. Elijah Clark and his wife are buried on the property and a replica of his home and appliance of the era are also there for viewing. Enjoy hiking, mini golfing, archery and canoe rentals all at the Elijah Clark State Park. The nature trail on the property is a 3.75-mile trail with plenty of interesting sights and views.

name: Desert Outdoor Center
description: Guided hikes.

name: Vines Gardens Park
description: 0.5-mile paved trail

name: Brookhaven Park
description: Walking trails and picnic area in 9 acre DeKalb county park.

name: Yorba Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Cottonwood Trail
description: The Cottonwood Trail is a 2.5-mile loop trail that links the Serna Cabin Picnic Area, Bonita Creek Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area, Riverview Campground, Flying W Group Day Use Area, and Kearny Camp Monument. It is an easy trail that includes some gentle slopes and unstable surfaces. Spring and fall offer the most pleasant temperatures for hiking the trail.

name: Dresden Park
description: Trails and picnic area in 24 acre DeKalb county park.

name: Paces Mill
description:
Paces Mill offers running and walking trails along the banks of the Hooch (Chattahoochee River). A rushing waterfall, a trek up Rottenwood Creek to see the ruins of historic Akers Mill (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akers_Mill ), 3.6 miles of paved trail, and even more unpaved trails are a treat for all. <br />
<br />
The paved portion is enjoyed by runners and those who enjoy gentle terrain. Getting off the paved portion allows for great views of the Hooch including Long Island Shoals, Devil Race Course Shoals and a dense urban forest climbing up to a 1000 foot elevation from the 800 foot elevation of the Hooch. <br />
<br />
There is a daily parking fee or the opportunity to purchase an annual pass at an automated machine at the Paces Mill parking area. The annual pass is a great deal as it covers parking at the 16 parking areas along the 48 mile Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area.

name: Lake Perris State Recreation Area
description:
The trail ascends gradually west and occasionally intersects a horse trail. The unsigned path is tentative at ﬁrst but an occasional wooden post helps keep you on the trail, which climbs boulder-strewn slopes.

The coastal scrub community-sage, buckwheat, chamise and toyon predominates. Also much in evidence are weedy-looking non-native species, as well as mustard, prickly pear cactus, morning glory and Russian thistle.

name: Spur Cross Ranch
description: Great hiking trails.

name: Fullerton Loop
description: Fullerton Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Fullerton, CA.

name: Fullerton Loop
description: Fullerton Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Fullerton, CA.

name: Fullerton Loop
description: Fullerton Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Fullerton, CA.

name: Sunset Beach State Recreation Site
description: Sunset Beach State Recreation Site comes with a very famous past. The park marks the west trailhead of the historic Fort-to-Sea Trail - a 6.5 mile route that recreates the experience Lewis and Clark and the Corps of Discovery encountered as they traveled between Fort Clatsop and the Pacific Ocean during the famous winter of 1805-6.

name: Hickory Knob State Park
description: Hickory Knob has several beautiful hiking trails, one or two of which lie right on the shores of Lake Thurmond, offering some gorgeous views of the expansive waters!

name: Silver Comet Mtb Side Trails
description: Silver Comet Mtb Side Trails features 9 miles of hiking trails near Hiram/dallas, GA.

name: Baker Creek
description: Baker Creek features 10 miles of hiking trails near McCormick, SC.

name: Bay Creek Park
description: The 154-acre Bay Creek Park is a day-use only park with great opportunities for baseball, softball, football, skating, tennis, basketball, hiking and it also offers a playground for children and a lighted walking track.

name: Prado Dam
description: Great trails.

name: Hickory Knob State Resort Park
description: The challenging bike/hiking trail which is approximately 12 miles in length, travels through a pine forest, along the lake's edge providing opportunities for many scenic lake views. The trails consist of: Beaver Run Trail (2.5 miles), Lakeview Loop (7.2 miles) and Turkey Ridge Trail (1.7 miles).

name: Ralph B. Clark Regional Park
description:
Open between 7a.m. - 6 p.m., or 7 a.m. - 9 p.m., depending on the time of year, Ralph B. Clark Regional Park is a great little neighborhood getaway. The park is nestles at the foot of the Coyote Hills, and has 105 acres that extends north and south of Rosecrans Avenue. Terrain ranges from large open grass areas, to gently rolling hills of native plants, to sheer sandstone cliffs to the north.

There are nice paved trails that run through this park. There are large shaded picnic areas, hiking and biking trails, and children's playground areas. Don't miss the 2 sand volleyball courts, 3 softball fields, and one baseball field. There is also a 3 acre stocked lake, four tennis courts, and an amphitheater.

name: Ronald Reagan Park
description: .75-mile paved multi-purpose trail

name: Fullerton Dam
description: Managed by Orange County, CA, there are facilities fishing, picnics, nature exhibits, handball and field sports. No permanent pool.

name: Blackburn Park
description: Access to Nancy Creek trail and picnic area in 49 acre park.

name: Graves Park
description: Graves Park is a 70-acre day-use park with two tennis courts, a sand volleyball court, a dog park area, a playground for kids, grills and a 1.25-mile paved multi-use trail.

name: Lake Texoma
description: Great park for hiking.

name: Bethesda Park
description:
Bethesda Park is a 159-acre park with great opportunities for playing softball, baseball, basketball or football. The park also offers a lighted walking track, six soccer fields, playgrounds for kids and a scenic lake.
The park has a 1.5-mile paved trail for hiking plus a walking trail that goes around the lake.

name: Botanical Gardens
description: The Botanical Gardens have a number of beautiful miles of singletrack trails through the woods, as well as trails through their beautifully manicured gardens.

name: Tri-City Regional Park
description: The 40-acre Tri-City Park is located in the City of Placentia, is bordered on two sides by the City of Fullerton, and is within a quarter-mile of the City of Brea's border. It includes a lake and three reservable picnic shelters. A variety of recreational opportunities, including bicycling and walking, model sailboating, fishing and playgrounds are available.

name: Ted Craig Regional Park
description: Walking trails.

name: Tribble Mill Park
description: Tribble Mill has an interesting network of hiking trails that go down by the lake, past several streams, and access some very cool slabs of slickrock.

name: Harbins Park
description: There are 4 or 5 different trail loops here in the park. The forest really isn't all that pretty, and there aren't many great views. Still, if you need to get a hike in, this is a place you can do it.

name: Tequesquite Arroyo
description: Tequesquite Arroyo features 9 miles of hiking trails near Riverside, CA.

name: Cane Creek State Park
description: Hiking, backpacking, mountain biking trails, and a kayak trail, offer outdoor adventure including birding and other wildlife viewing opportunities. The 15.5-mile, multi-use trail goes through rolling terrain, along the lake, and across many bridges including three suspension bridges. There is also a 2.5-mile multi-use trail for smaller adventures. The park's 2.5-mile kayak trail offers a relaxing outdoor aquatic adventure.

name: Wee-chi-ta
description: Wee-chi-ta features 6 miles of hiking trails near Wichita Falls, TX.

name: A.L. Burruss
description: A.L. Burruss features 1.25 miles of hiking trails near Marietta, GA.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: C
description:
Section C of the PCT runs 132.9 miles from San Gorgonio Pass near the town of Cabazon, CA to Interstate 15 near Cajon Pass. This section runs along the entire San Bernardino mountain range, reaching elevations of 8,750 feet.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail crosses the San Andreas Fault and passes Whitewater, CA; Teutang Canyon; Mission Creek; Highway 18; Big Bear City, CA; Big Bear Lake; Bertha Peak; Cougar Crest Trail 1E2; Holcomb Creek; Hawes Ranch trail; Deep Creek; Cedar Glen, CA; Highway 178; Grass Valley Creek; Highway 173; Silverwood Lake State Recreation area; Cleghorn Ridge; Little Horsethief Canyon; and Crowder Canyon.

name: Cholla Cactus Garden
description: Short nature walk through a large patch of Jumping Cholla Cacti.  Brochures available at the start of the trail.

name: Best Friend Park
description: The 43-acre Best Friend Park is a urban area park with two leisure play pools, a tennis center, an indoor badminton courts, basketball courts, a playground, baseball and softball fields and a one mile trail for hiking or jogging.

name: Athens Memorial Park
description: Athens Memorial Park has a few very easy paved trails to walk on, a day use area for picnics, a free zoo, and a couple of miles of scenic singletrack trails. It's so hard to believe that some of these trails are right in the Athens city limits!

name: Chino Hills State Park
description: Hills-for-Everyone Trail follows Ranch Road to McDermont Spring.

name: Lake Herrick
description: These are the closest trails to UGA, and are very popular with walkers, runners, dog walkers, and mountain bikers. The trails spider web all through the woods behind the small Lake Herrick. After spending some time back there, you'll get the hang of the layout. But until then, make sure you keep your wits about you!

name: Sara Babb Park
description: Sara Babb Park features 2 miles of hiking trails near Dallas, GA.

name: CDT NM16: NM Hwy 12 to Pie Town (US Hwy 60)
description:
Section 16 of the CDT runs 40 miles from NM Hwy 12 to Pie Town (US Hwy 60). Unfortunately, this massive 40 mile section follows roads the entire way. While parts of it run through the mountains, it definitely isn't a true wilderness experience. <br />
Along the way this section passes Mangas Mountain, Little Alegres Mountain, and Alegres Mountain.

name: Sweet Water Park
description: 0.5-mile paved multi-purpose trail

name: Sope Creek
description: Sope Creek features 6 miles of hiking trails near Sandy Springs, GA.

name: Mt Tabor Park
description: Mt Tabor Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Dallas, GA.

name: Prado Regional Park
description: Hiking trails; nature trail

name: Lost Horse Mine
description:
This is a 6.2 mile loop that passes by an abandoned but well preserved gold mine. The trail winds around for some impressive vistas and passes an abandoned dwelling with only the chimney remaining.<br />
*Note: This can be done as a 4 mile out and back to just visit the mine.

name: Telegraph Canyon
description: Telegraph Canyon features 25 miles of hiking trails near Brea/chino Hills, CA.

name: Rhodes Jordan Park
description: 1.9-mile paved multi-purpose trail

name: Ben Burton Park
description: There's a couple of miles of trails in the back of Ben Burton park along the Oconee River. If you look around you can find remnants of an old bridge and some other cool stuff.

name: Fort Fisher State Recreation Area
description: Explore Fort Fisher State Recreation Area by foot. The Basin Trail meanders through the marsh allowing hikers a chance to view sound-side flora and fauna. This 1.1 mile, out-and-back trail ends at an observation deck, which is a great location for bird watching.

name: Freeman's Mill Park
description: The small, 12-acre, Freeman's Mill Park is home to the restored historic gristmill. The park is day-use only and has a playground for children, a half-mile paved multi-use trail and restrooms.

name: Pinckneyville Park
description: 2.4-mile paved multipurpose trail

name: East Athens Community Park
description: East Athens Community Park is a 2 mile hiking trail in Athens, Georgia.

name: Fort Yargo State Park
description: Big singletrack loop in Fort Yargo State Park. This was designed, built, and is maintained by mountain bikers, so be aware that there will be significant mountain bike traffic.

name: McDaniel Farm Park
description: 3-miles of paved multi-purpose and soft surface trails

name: Vulture Peak Trail
description: Vulture Peak Trail meanders through classic Sonoran Desert landscapes, including dense stands of saguaro, ocotillo, cholla, and other cactus varieties; crosses wide desert washes; and offers dramatic scenic vistas of rugged desert mountain ranges and valleys in all directions.

name: Holcomb Bridge Park
description: Holcomb Bridge Park is a day-use park in Norcross with two river overlooks for viewing, a wooden amphitheater, restrooms and grills, a picnic pavilion and a .25-mile soft surface for walking or jogging.

name: Shorty Howell Park
description: 1.25-mile paved multi-purpose trial

name: Sunrise Ski Park
description: Sunrise Ski Park features 20 miles of hiking trails near Greer, AZ.

name: Bogart Park
description: Excellent hiking/running trails.

name: J. Strom Thurmond Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout the area.

name: Bobby Brown State Outdoor Recreation Area
description: This pretty Outdoor Recreation Area offers water sport enthusiasts easy access to Clarks Hill Lake, the second-largest man-made lake east of the Mississippi River.  The 71,100-acre reservoir is nestled on the Georgia-South Carolina border, north of Augusta.  A boat ramp is open year-round, and the self-reservation campground is open seasonally.  Park visitors can explore nearly two miles of wooded trails and take a self-guided land navigation/compass course.

name: Pickett's Mill Battlefield Historic Site
description: Pickett's Mill is one of the best preserved Civil War battlefields in the nation. Visitors can travel roads used by Federal and Confederate troops, see earthworks constructed by these men, and walk through the same ravine where hundreds died.  An authentic 1800s pioneer cabin is furnished and open for tours during certain events.

name: Rancho Jurupa Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Arch Rock Trail
description: This is a short nature trail that highlights the geology of the Park. The majority of the trail is flat, though there there are some step and climbs, and the trail is not accessible.  Tail signs point out some interesting information about the local rock formations and how they were created.

name: Oconee River Greenway
description: The Oconee River Greenway runs through several very picturesque areas of Athens, and it is constantly being expanded. It is easily accessible from several different spots in Athens.

name: Ryan Ranch Trail
description: A short, easy hike that allows access to the original site of Ryan Ranch.  This was home and operations center for the Ryan family, who owned the nearby Lost Horse Mine.  The site contains the remains of a bunkhouse, a well, and a windmill.

name: Turnbull Canyon
description: Turnbull Canyon features 29 miles of hiking trails near Whittier, CA.

name: Juniper Flats
description:
Hiking and Sightseeing
Bring your cameras and binoculars! Juniper Flats is a diverse landscape of mountains, canyons and washes. The washes in particular are good hiking trails for experiencingnatural conditions. Wildlife viewing is best in the early morning and evening hours. In the washes, birds tend to gather in thick vegetation.

name: Peter F. Schabarum Regional Park
description: Peter F. Schabarum Regional Park, located in Rowland Heights, is a 575-acre facility with 75 acres developed for walking, hiking, picnics, youth camping, soccer and tennis. Youth tennis lessons are offered year-round and exercise classes are free of charge. There is a new "Life Trail" exercise area, a federally protected blue-line stream and the remaining acres of the park have been left in their natural state and crisscross with hiking, biking and horseback riding trails that connect to the historic Juan Bautista De Anza National Historic Trail.

name: Nike Site # 29 Whittier Hills
description: Nike Site # 29 Whittier Hills  features 8 miles of hiking trails near Whittier, CA.

name: Skull Rock Trail
description: A short hike that travels through the desert and offers a looks at some of the local vegetation and geology.  The trail starts in the Jumbo Rocks Campground.  It travels for about 3/4 of a mile through rocks and brush to Skull Rock, a local, distinctive rock formation.

name: Dacula Park
description: The 76-acre Dacula Park is a spacious area with an activity building for classes and rentals. There is also a large community room. The park offers tennis courts, an outdoor pool, football field, seven youth baseball and softball fields, a playground, picnic pavilion, a volleyball court and a 1.75-mile paved, multi-purpose trail and pond.

name: Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area: Island Ford
description: Approximately 4-5 miles of hiking trails along the Chattahoochee and in the bluffs overlooking the river. Several rock overhangs to explore and opportunities to get up close to the river for fishing.

name: Palmetto Trail - Fort Jackson Passage
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. When completed, the trail will cover over 425 continuous miles and run through 14 counties.<br />
290 miles are completed and currently available for public use. <br />
<br />
PALMETTO TRAIL - FORT JACKSON PASSAGE: <br />
<br />
20 mile path connecting an unfinished section to the east and the Capitol City Passage to the west. Travels through Fort Jackson Military Training Facility. Flat and winding through mostly pines. Soft sand. Hiking, backpacking, and mountain biking. Moderately difficult trail during good conditions. Special regulations apply. Download Fort Jackson brochure - http://www.palmettoconservation.org/maps/FortJacksonBrochure.pdf

name: Leone Hall Price Park
description: Leone Hall Price Park spans 126 acres and is designated a passive park. With natural trails, meadows, beautiful Allatoona Creek running through it and an array of native plant and animal species, it is a great place to hike, take the kids or dog for a walk and enjoy the quiet respite that nature provides.

name: Rabbit Hill Park
description: 2.5-mile paved multi-purpose trail

name: Jones Bridge Park
description:
Jones Bridge's 30 acres include a playground, sand volleyball court, restroom facility three soccer fields and two picnic pavilions. There is a boat launch for canoe's and kayaks. This park of the river is used for tubers as well. Call ahead to check water levels if you are fishing or tubing or kayaking. Before you go, Check the flow - For Chattahoochee River water release information, call 770.945.1466. or tune in to 1610 AM <br />
Do not confuse this park with Jones Bridge in Johns Creek, GA (This park Jones Bridge Park is part of a Gwinnett County Park). Jones Bridge Rec Area is is part of the National Recreation Area and is federally owned<br />
Park hours are from sunrise to sunset.

name: Ryan Mountain
description: Moderately strenuous out and back hike up to the top of Ryan Mountain.  Vistas of Joshua Tree National Park at the top.

name: Skyline Trail
description: Skyline Trail features 11 miles of hiking trails near Los Angeles, CA.

name: The Box Recreation Area
description:
The 640-acre Box Recreation Area is a highly scenic, rugged area which is very popular for technical rock climbing and bouldering. The five cliffs on either side of this box canyon provide popular rock climbing for even highly skilled technical climbers. Challenging climbing opportunities include the Waterfall Wall, Corner Block and the Fillet a Papillon Wall.
Remember, that climbing is a high-risk activity. For safety, climbers should not attempt climbs beyond their abilities. There is a developed parking area with a trailhead, kiosks, and restroom. Drinking water is not available.

name: Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area
description: Workout course & trails.

name: La Brea Loop
description: Moderate loop that climbs to the ridge in Baldwin Hills.  From the summit you can see to the ocean on one side and downtwon on the other.

name: Hidden Valley Trail
description: Short nature hike, but in stark contrast to the surrounding dessert.  The valley walls keep more moisture in the valley, making for a more diverse setting. Popular area with climbers.

name: Allatoona Creek
description: Allatoona Creek features 4 miles of hiking trails near Acworth, GA.

name: Land Corral/St. David Cienega
description: A Cienega ("see-en-e-ga") is a marsh or wetland. Cienegas can form where layers of rock or impervious clay hold water at the surface or through the continuous upwelling of numerous small springs and seeps.  These conditions produce a rare plant community of sedges, grasses, reeds, and cattails because the soil is permanently saturated.  This habitat supports a diversity of interesting plants, birds, insects, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals.

name: Mokaac Trail
description: This historic and scenic trail is open for hiking and horseback use. A cement horseback mounting platform can be found due west of BLM Road 1089 approximately one mile north of the northern end of the trail. The main segment is a moderate two miles each way and ends at Quail Spring.

name: Peachtree Ridge Park
description: 1-mile paved multi-purpose trail

name: Arkansas River - Wilbur D. Mills Pool
description: Excellent trails throughout the area.

name: Autrey Mill Nature Preserve and Heritage Center
description: Over 2 miles of easy trails that navigate through and around Autrey Mill Nature Preserve. There are Native American dwelling replicas as well as native flora and fauna noted with informational plaques. The trail system travels through different habitats and along Sal's creek. Autrey Mill also offers tours of the Heritage Village and an animal exhibit located in the Visitor's Center.

name: Watson Mill Bridge State Park
description: There are a number of wide doubletrack trails here, but they are rather boring. However, there is a fun singletrack nature trail down by the river that runs past some remnants of old buildings and some small waterfalls.

name: Big Creek
description: There are several beautiful singletrack trails spread throughout the park. They are rather rocky and rooty, and these are mostly intended for mountain biking, so expect significant bike traffic.

name: Scout Trail
description: Scout Trail features 2 miles of hiking trails near Acworth, GA.

name: Barker Dam Trail
description: Short, easy hike.  Well used trail follows a short loop, just over a mile.  The trail passes the remains of Barker Dam, once used for watering cattle. Also on the trail is a collection of Petroglyphs.

name: Wall Street Mill Trail
description: This trail follows several washes through the dessert and highlights some of the artifacts left from the mining days of Joshua Tree. The trail leads to a old two stamp mill which was brought to the area for purpose of smashing rocks for mining.  Most of the mill is still there and is easily visible, though protected by fencing.  There is also an old windmill and storage tanks left from the same time period along the hike.  The trail is almost entirely flat, though traveling in the loose sand of the washes can be difficult.

name: Alpharetta Big Creek Greenway (Georgia)
description: Multi-use trail paved and connects to a larger trail system

name: Big Creek Greenway
description: This is a flat, paved trail, but for being right in the city, it's very scenic. Great for taking the kids out for a walk, pushing the baby in a stroller, going for a walk with the significant other, or going for a run without the traffic.

name: Cave Spring Trailhead
description: Cave Spring Trail climbs onto the east slope of the Black Mountains for about 0.8 miles and ends at Cave Spring. The route is steep in places but not hazardous. Cave Spring, as its name implies, is located within a natural cave that provides water for wildlife and wild burros that inhabit the area. To gain access to the cave you will need to duck beneath hackberry trees that guard the entrance. Looking east from the cave entrance treats you to a nice view of the surrounding Sacramento Valley and the Hualapai and Cerbat Mountains beyond. Use of the trail is most comfortable between the months of September and May, although early-morning hiking during the summer can be pleasant as well.

name: Gila Box River Trail
description: Spring and fall are probably the best time for hiking due to pleasant temperatures If you are hiking the trail, remember that the route is not marked and the river may have to be forded several times. To help preserve streamside habitats, please seek a natural open route through or around vegetative thickets.

name: Missouri Spring Trailhead
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Arizona Trail-Buckskin Mountain Passage
description: The 12.5-mile northern trailhead stretch of the Arizona Trail makes its way south through the steep and rugged eastern flank of Buckskin Mountain, where it treats visitors to sweeping views of the Vermilion Cliffs, Coyote Buttes, Kaibab Plateau, and southern Utah. The trail continues to the Grand Canyon and beyond, eventually traversing some 800 miles to Mexico.

name: Black Canyon National Recreation Trail
description: Black Canyon Trail features 62 miles of hiking trails near Phoenix, AZ.

name: Buckskin Gulch Trailhead
description: 47 miles (76 kilometers) to Lee's Ferry Trailhead; 5.7 miles (9.2 kilometers) to Wire Pass Trailhead; 23 miles (37 kilometers) to White House Trailhead

name: Malibu Lagoon State Beach
description: Malibu Lagoon hosts many different kinds of waterfowl, both resident and migratory. The beach is rock cobble on the ocean side of the lagoon. To the landward side of the lagoon stretches the alluvial &#64257;ll &#64258;atland deposited by Malibu Creek. The town of Malibu is situated here.

name: Whittier Narrows Nature Center
description: Bordering the San Gabriel River, this 400-acre sanctuary of riparian woodland, features four lakes, including many plants and animals native to wetland communities. The lakes provide a winter sanctuary for migrating waterfowl and are available by special permit for birding and photography.  Other activities include: hikes, walks, seasonal special events, naturalist docent trainings, Junior Ranger Programs, and nature day camps. School group tours are available by reservation.  Wheelchair and stroller accessible trails are also available. Binoculars are available for loan for guided walks, field trips in Nature activities, and for self-guided walks.

name: Jedi
description: Jedi features 5 miles of hiking trails near Loma Linda, CA.

name: Pinhoti Trail
description: The Pinhoti Trail is a long distance hiking trail that runs from northern Georgia all the way into the heart of Alabama. Most of it is isolated singletrack trails in the high North Georgia mountains, but some sections of the trail follow forest roads and even pavement in places.

name: Rock Springs Park
description: 2-mile paved, multi-purpose trail

name: Leo Carrillo State Park
description: The park also features back-country hiking. Nature walks and campfire programs are offered and a small Visitor Center has interpretive displays. During the summer, children's programs are available.

name: Carolina Beach State Park
description: Six miles of trails wind through a variety of distinct habitats at Carolina Beach State Park. Relatively flat and easy to walk, the trails offer an opportunity to observe the diversity of plant and animal life in the park. Insects may be annoying during the warmer months; repellent is recommended. To avoid becoming lost, stop by the visitor&#65533;s center or marina for a trail map. Pay close attention to trail markers. Bikes and horses are not allowed on the park&#65533;s trails.

name: Big Morongo Canyon Preserve
description: Trails begin from the parking lot kiosk and allow access to the six-mile length of the canyon.

name: Little Mulberry Park
description: 5 miles of paved multi-purpose and soft surface trails for equestrian and hiking

name: Yucaipa Regional Park
description: Yucaipa Regional Park is a grewat place to get away from the city and bring the family for a day of fun in the sun! Activities here include swimming, hiking, horseback riding, canoeing, kayaking, fishing and camping.

name: Hugo Lake State Park
description: The Hiking trails in Hugo Lake State Park are an adventure just waiting. As you walk through the winding trails you'll encounter all species of wildlife. Special interest markers indentify various trees types as well as animal information. You'll even find a primitive rest bench along the path. The Hiking Trails also offer some great views of the lake.

name: Will Rogers State Historic Park
description:
Hiking Trails
Hikers can enjoy a moderate 3-mile loop to Inspiration Point. Adventurous hikers, mountain bikers, and equestrians can tackle the Backbone Trail into the Santa Monica Mountains, which can take you all the way to Point Mugu.

name: Sycamore Canyon/Point Mugu State Park
description: Sycamore Canyon/Point Mugu State Park features 16 miles of hiking trails near Malibu, CA.

name: Sycamore Canyon/Point Mugu State Park
description: Sycamore Canyon/Point Mugu State Park features 16 miles of hiking trails near Malibu, CA.

name: Sycamore Canyon/Point Mugu State Park
description: Sycamore Canyon/Point Mugu State Park features 16 miles of hiking trails near Malibu, CA.

name: Lake Murray State Park & Lodge
description: Lake Murray State Park features 20 miles of hiking trails near Ardmore, OK.

name: Backbone Trail - Kanan Dune To Corral Canyon
description: Backbone Trail - Kanan-dune To Corral Canyon features 13 miles of hiking trails near Agoura Hills, CA.

name: Backbone Trail - Kanan Dune To Corral Canyon
description: Backbone Trail - Kanan-dune To Corral Canyon features 13 miles of hiking trails near Agoura Hills, CA.

name: Backbone Trail - Kanan Dune To Corral Canyon
description: Backbone Trail - Kanan-dune To Corral Canyon features 13 miles of hiking trails near Agoura Hills, CA.

name: Point Mugu State Park
description: On Sycamore Canyon Trail, from Big Sycamore Canyon to Deer Camp Junction is 6.5 miles round trip with a 200-foot elevation gain; return via Overlook Trail is 10 miles round trip with a 700-foot gain.

name: Frank G. Bonelli Regional Park
description: Great trails.

name: Frank G. Bonelli Regional Park
description: Great trails.

name: Frank G. Bonelli Regional Park
description: Great trails.

name: Topanga State Park
description: Many of the park's trails can be accessed from Trippet Ranch. The Musch Trail leads north to Musch Trail Camp by winding in and out of the sun and shade where plant assemblages change with every subtle difference in light and moisture.

name: Harbison State Forest
description: Harbison State Forest features 20 miles of hiking trails near Columbia, SC.

name: Dreher Island State Park
description: From the Community Building, guests can enjoy a relaxing walk along the .25-mile Billy Dreher Nature Trail. From shelter #7 and #8 parking lot, guests can experience a moderate 2.1-mile hike along the Little Gap Trail. In addition to these two hiking trails a .33-mile multi-use trail exits through the middle of State Park Loop. This trail is designated for bike and foot traffic only.

name: La Jolla Canyon Trail
description: Three mile in-and-back over rocky exposed terrain.  Provides access to La Jolla Valley Loop Trail.  Moderately Strenuous.  Water and restrooms at trailhead.

name: Chumash Trail
description: Very strenuous half mile that gains 900 ft and takes you to the crest of the Santa Monica Mountain range from the coast.  This trail dates back 7000 years and was used by the Chumash to travel between the mountains and the ocean.

name: Settles Bridge Park
description: Nice multi-use trails.

name: Long Cane Horse Trail
description: Long Cane Horse Trail features 26 miles of hiking trails near Greenwood, SC.

name: Hastain Trail
description:
Hastain Trail can be accessed from the Southern part of the park nearby the Ranch Amphitheatre. This will begin with a steep climb to the summit overlook and then a gradual decent back towards the middle of the park. After about 3 miles in this direction, the trail meets up with Lake Drive which can be followed back to the trailhead. Alternatively, you can start the trail at this intersection and follow the trail in that direction.<br />
This trail is partially shaded and crosses several slate and granite formations. There are lookouts with views of the park, Beverly Hills and, on a clear day, the ocean.

name: M.A.S.H. Hike
description: This hike mostly along fire road takes you out to the site where the TV show M.A.S.H. was filmed.  There are a few abandoned vehicles and interpretative signs describing the site.

name: Malibu Creek State Park
description: There are 15 miles of streamside trail through oak and sycamore woodlands on chaparral covered slopes.

name: Malibu Creek State Park
description: There are 15 miles of streamside trail through oak and sycamore woodlands on chaparral covered slopes.

name: Malibu Creek State Park
description: There are 15 miles of streamside trail through oak and sycamore woodlands on chaparral covered slopes.

name: San Dimas Canyon Community Regional Park
description: Located in the foothills of San Dimas, Sand Dimas Canyon Community Regional Park is 138 acres of natural area for families in California to get away from the city streets and enjoy! Activities here include camping and hiking.

name: Blinderman Trail
description: Moderate to Strenuous trail that has serveral detours.  It meanders alongside the main road running through the park which makes it difficult to get lost.

name: Ashwood Lake
description:
Ashwood lake is a public fishing lake managed by South Carolina Department of Natural Resources. The 75-acre impoundment boasts a healthy population of bream, largemouth bass, and catfish. 60% of the lake's total shoreline can be fished from the banks. <br />
The long shoreline available to anglers also provides an opportunity for an easy, 2-mile nature walk. Pavilions, located on two sides of the lake, provide shelter and a place for a picnic.

name: Sesquicentennial State Park
description: Sesquicentennial State Park features 6 miles of hiking trails near Columbia, SC.

name: La Jolla Valley Loop
description: This trail loops easily through some of the few remaining native grasslands in the area.  The trail is gently rolling and easy to hike.  There are many spur trails, so take care to keep your bearings.

name: Bogan Park
description: The 83-acre Bogan Park located near Buford is a great place to get away from city life and enjoy the park's indoor aquatic center, double gym, badminton courts and dance studio. The park also offers seven baseball/softball fields, a few volleyball courts and two miles of hiking trails.

name: Calhoun Falls State Park
description: Calhoun Falls State Recreation Area offers a moderately difficult 1.75 mile loop trail, named the Cedar Bluff Nature Trail.

name: Copper Breaks State Park
description: Great hiking here!

name: The Grotto
description: Hike down to a grotto hidden under the boulders.  Trail passes some small cascades and nearby Circle X Ranch.

name: Sandstone Peak via Backbone Trail
description: From the trailhead, Sandstone Peak is about 1 mile in along the Backbone Trail.  At 3111 ft, the summit is the highest in the Santa Monica Moutain Range.

name: Dequeen Lake
description: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers welcomes you to DeQueen Lake and wishes you an enjoyable stay at the project. The project offers the visitor extensive opportunities for a memorable outdoor recreation experience. Food, bait, tackle, etc. are available near the lake. Project personnel are available and will be happy to assist in assuring you a pleasant stay.

name: George P. Cossar State Park
description: A 2.5 mile nature trail begins at the boat ramp overlooking Enid Lake and winds through a mixed pine and hardwood forest, providing a close look at the natural beauty, flora, and fauna found in the park.

name: Joshua Tree National Park
description:
Joshua Tree offers an extensive network of trails of varying length and difficulty. Embracing over 794,000 acres, including 585,000 acres of wilderness, Joshua Tree National Park is a backpacker's dream with its mild winter climate and interesting rock formations, plants, and wildlife. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Point Mugu State Park
description: Point Mugu State Park features 30 miles of hiking trails near Malibu, CA.

name: Taylor Randahl Memorial Mountain Bike Trails At Olde Rope Mill Park
description:
Note: These trails are primarily mountain bike trails, so expect significant mountain bike traffic.

That said, this is a beautiful trail with a couple of cool views and some nice rocky, exposed singletrack.

name: Lario San Gabriel River Trail
description: Looking for a great bike trail that connects the San Gabriel River Bike Trail in Azusa to the "Foothills to the Sea" trail in Seal Beach? Then look no further than the Lario San Gabriel River Trail located in the foothills of Azusa and Irwindale, along the San Gabriel River. This path is great for biking, hiking or strolling. Landscaped with drought tolerant California native plants and a picnic area for ten, makes this a great recreational choice for the entire family!

name: Allatoona Lake
description: Allatoona Dam features 0 miles of hiking trails near Cartersville, GA.

name: New Millennium Loop
description: New Millennium Loop features 14 miles of hiking trails near Calabasas, CA.

name: New Millennium Loop
description: New Millennium Loop features 14 miles of hiking trails near Calabasas, CA.

name: New Millennium Loop
description: New Millennium Loop features 14 miles of hiking trails near Calabasas, CA.

name: Iron Hills Trail (Red Top Mtn. State Park)
description: Iron Hills Trail (Red Top Mtn. State Park) features 3 miles of hiking trails near Cartersville, GA.

name: Pine Creek Lake
description: Excellent hiking in area.

name: Marshal Canyon
description: Marshal Canyon features 14 miles of hiking trails near Claremont, CA.

name: Marshal Canyon
description: Marshal Canyon features 14 miles of hiking trails near Claremont, CA.

name: Marshal Canyon
description: Marshal Canyon features 14 miles of hiking trails near Claremont, CA.

name: Brunswick Nature Park
description:
Brunswick Nature Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Leland, NC. The park has over 900 acres bordering the scenic Town Creek River, and is an excellent place to get outdoors. <br />
Trails here have been designed for mountain bike use as well, so enjoy the surrounding forests, but be responsible as well.

name: Ninety Six National Historic Site
description:
Historic Interpretive Trail: The paved 1 mile walking trail includes wayside signs, the reconstructed siege works and Stockade Fort, original 1781 Star Fort, town site of old Ninety Six, historic roads, and more. The trail begins and ends at the visitor parking lot. Horses, bikes, skateboards, etc are not allowed on the trail. There are 2 small hills (the larger one is located by the Stockade Fort). Ask in the Visitor Center for a map. (approx. 45 mins)<br />
Hiking Trails: The Park has several primitive trails, including the Cherokee Path, Gouedy Trail, and more. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Marshall Canyon Park & Nursery
description: Excellent trails.

name: Datil Well Recreation Area Campground
description: Datil Well Recreation Area Campground includes one of 15 water wells along the old Magdalena Livestock Driveway. The old cattle trail was established in the 1800s and stretched 120 miles from Springerville, Arizona, to Magdalena, New Mexico. The area includes 3 miles of hiking trails in piÌ±on-juniper and ponderosa pine woodlands, with scenic views of the San Augustin Plains. The trail and vistas also offer an occasional glimpse of wildlife in a setting of quiet and solitude. You can close your eyes and almost hear the cattle lowing as they settle in for the night.

name: Big Sycamore Canyon
description: Big Sycamore Canyon features 12 miles of hiking trails near Newbury Park, CA.

name: Big Sycamore Canyon
description: Big Sycamore Canyon features 12 miles of hiking trails near Newbury Park, CA.

name: Big Sycamore Canyon
description: Big Sycamore Canyon features 12 miles of hiking trails near Newbury Park, CA.

name: Red Top Mountain State Park
description: Hiking - 12.5 miles of wooded trails, 3/4-mile paved accessible trail

name: Cheeseboro/Palo Comado Canyon
description: Cheeseboro/Palo Comado Canyon is a 20 mile hiking trail in Agoura Hills, California.

name: Indian Nation Trail
description: Indian Nation Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Hochatown/broken Bow, OK.

name: Dwelling Loop
description: This is a nice singletrack trail that is a part of the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/216/Hiking-Trails/Blankets-Creek-Bicycle-Trail.html">Blankets Creek Trail System.</a> Be aware that Blankets Creek was designed, constructed, and is maintained by mountain bikers and is a very, very, VERY popular urban mountain bike destination.

name: Blankets Creek Bicycle Trail
description: Blankets Creek is a singletrack trail network with 6 trails: South Loop, Dwelling Loop, Van Michael Trail, Mosquito Flats, Mosquito Bite, and Quehl Holler. This trail was designed and built by the Southern Off Road Bicycle Association (Woodstock). As such, it is a very, very VERY popular mountain bike destination. The parking lot is packed out every weekend, and it stays very busy even during the week. Just be aware that if you choose to go here, you will be dealing with a lot of mountain bikers.

name: Van Michael Trail
description:
The Van Michael Trail is a part of the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/216/Hiking-Trails/Blankets-Creek-Bicycle-Trail.html">Blankets Creek Trail System.</a>

The VMT has the most elevation gain of any trail in the trail system. There are several cool views of the lake from the steep, rocky hillside.

Note: This trail was designed and built by the Southern Off Road Bicycle Association (Woodstock). As such, it is a very, very VERY popular mountain bike destination. The parking lot is packed out every weekend, and it stays very busy even during the week. Just be aware that if you choose to go here, you will be dealing with a lot of mountain bikers.

name: Etiwanda Preserve Loop
description: A short loop hike through the North Etiwanda Preserve.  There are several spurs that can be taken to see interesting items and to increase the length of your hik.

name: Cottage Loop Trail
description: Cottage Loop Trail is a 3 mile hiking trail in Elberton, Georgia.

name: Richard B. Russell State Park
description: A nature trail follows the shoreline to one of the oldest steel pin bridges in the area, loops through the adjoining woods and returns to the beach.

name: Parson's Mtn. Recreation Area Trails
description: Parson's Mtn. Recreation Area Trails features 40 miles of hiking trails near Abbeville, SC.

name: Broken Bow Lake
description: The McCurtain County Wilderness Area at the lake's north end retains its primitive, natural beauty.

name: Beavers Bend & Hochatown State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Enid Lake
description: Trails located throughout the area.

name: Lake View Lodge Mountain Bicycle & Hiking Trail
description: Lake View Lodge Mountain Bicycle & Hiking Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Broken Bow/Hochatown, OK.

name: Pine Mountain Recreation Area
description: Pine Mountain Recreation Area features 4 miles of hiking trails in Cartersville, GA.

name: Eaton Canyon Park and Nature Center
description: Great trails.

name: Greeson Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout area.

name: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area
description:
Rocky Oaks offers picnic tables, a small seasonal pond and oak groves which are all accessed via an easy stroll in the heart of the mountains.<br />
<br />
The National Park Service & its partners provide scenic vistas and opportunities for recreation from mountains to ocean.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Lake Greenwood State Park
description: The 0.8-mile nature trail begins at the recreation building located in campground #1.

name: Arroyo Seco
description: Arroyo Seco features 7 miles of hiking trails near Pasadena, CA.

name: Chantry Flats
description: Chantry Flats features 11 miles of hiking trails near Arcadia, CA.

name: DeGray Lake Resort State Park
description: TrailsDeGray Lake Resort State Park has five trails for guests to enjoy alone or on a scheduled, park interpreter guided hike. Each of DeGray's trails takes you into a unique area of the park. In order to preserve the beauty of the park and its trails, bicycles and motorized vehicles are not permitted on the trails. Please protect DeGray's environment by leaving plants, rocks and wildlife alone as well as helping to keep the trails clean of litter.

name: Panorama Trail
description: Panorama Trail features 11 miles of hiking trails near Lakeside, AZ.

name: Glen Helen Regional Park
description: Located at the base of the chaparral covered hills of the Cajon Pass with scenic views of both the San Gabriel and San Bernardino Mountains, Glen Helen Regional Park offers 1,340 acres of recreational activities from the relaxing to the rugged.   Glen Helen offers two lakes for fishing, a swim complex with pool, sandy area, dual water slides, zero depth water play park, large group shelter picnic areas accommodating up to 300 persons - ideal for that company picnic, large family gathering or group event.  There are several picnic areas under shady trees with amazing views throughout the park.  Enjoy wide open spaces for your favorite field games - or bring the kids out to play on the latest playground equipment that will challenge their bodies and their minds!

name: McGrath State Beach
description: This walk takes you on a nature trail through the Santa Clara River Estuary, visits McGrath Lake and travels miles of sandy beach to Channel Islands Harbor.

name: McGrath State Beach
description: This walk takes you on a nature trail through the Santa Clara River Estuary, visits McGrath Lake and travels miles of sandy beach to Channel Islands Harbor.

name: McGrath State Beach
description: This walk takes you on a nature trail through the Santa Clara River Estuary, visits McGrath Lake and travels miles of sandy beach to Channel Islands Harbor.

name: Gillham Lake
description: Hiking trails throughout the area.

name: Echo Mountain Loop
description: Echo Mountain Loop features 7 miles of hiking trails near Altadena, CA.

name: Sunset Trail
description: Sunnyside Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Pasadena, CA.

name: Millard Falls
description: A beautiful, short jaunt following a stream leading to Millard Falls.  The trail criscrosses the stream several times, so take care to keep your feet dry.  Mostly level, out and back.

name: Lake Sidney Lanier
description: Plenty of trails.

name: Crescenta Valley Community Regional Park
description: Crescenta Valley Community Regional Park is nestled in a green, tree-filled valley providing community access to a beautiful natural area of native California flora and fauna. People who frequent the park call it a "hidden jewel" in the Crescenta Valley.

name: Buckskin Mountain
description: Many visitors take advantage of a terrific network of hiking trails.

name: Tombigbee State Park
description: Tombigbee State Park is located six miles from Tupelo. The park offers several outdoor opportunities very close to an urban area. It is the headquarters of the Natchez Trace Parkway. Camping is very popular here, as well as picnicking, hiking, football, baseball, soccer, disc golfing, boating and fishing. The nature trail is a 1.2 mile path for hiking through the woodlands and along the Lake Lee.

name: Badger Springs Trail
description: Badger Springs offers a short trail for non-motorized users within the Agua Fria National Monument. The trail leads down the Badger Springs Wash to the Agua Fria River canyon, an area rich in archaeological resources. The confluence of Badger Springs and the Agua Fria is the location of a fantastic panel of petroglyphs. At the confluence, hikers can travel either upstream or downstream to explore this high desert canyon. Most years the river flows through early summer. Mule deer, white-tail deer, javelina and coyotes roam the area.

name: Snow Summit Mountain Resort
description: Snow Summit Mountain Resort features 10 miles of hiking trails near Big Bear Lake, CA.

name: Gainesville College
description: As jcrunner mentioned, this is a rather popular trail for trail running. It's also rather popular with mountain bikers. While it is pretty flat and the woods aren't really majestic and super impressive, this isn't a bad place for an in-town hike.

name: Daisy State Park Mountain Bike Trail
description: Daisy State Park Mountain Bike Trail features 40 miles of hiking trails near Kirby, AR.

name: Degray Lake
description: Trails located at Arlie Moore.

name: Pine Knot Trail
description: Pine Knot Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Big Bear Lake, CA.

name: Charleston Park
description: Despite RAMBO's announcement back in February that these trails would be opening in 2011, at the time of this writing they are far from complete. However, there are a few miles of singletrack that have been completed that look really great, and this place looks like it will be even better once it is completely finished! There are several great views of Lake Lanier. This will be an excellent addition to Forsyth County!

name: Central Park
description:
There is about a 1-1.5 mile paved walking/running trail up near the baseball fields. It's very flat and easy. <br />
<br />
It should be noted that the 3 mile singletrack trail in the park is only open to mountain bikes: no foot traffic allowed.

name: Channel Islands National Park
description:
Many trails and roads traverse the islands, providing visitors with spectacular hiking opportunities. These trails and roads range from the maintained, relatively flat, signed trails of Anacapa to the unmaintained, rugged, mountainous, unsigned paths of Santa Rosa.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Chicopee Woods
description:
There are a ton of trails here to hike, and it is absolutely beautiful for being right in Oakwood/Gainesville.

This trail was designed and built by the Southern Off Road Bicycle Association (Gainesville), and as such it is intended primarily for mountain biking. It is a very, very popular mountain bike destination, so just be aware. There's a hiking-only nature trail just a tenth of a mile down the road at the Elachee Nature Center.

name: Lakeshore
description: The longest trail in the park, Lake Trail begins at the visitor's center and follows the lakeshore to the Waccamaw River. The trail passes through a variety of ecosystems during its five-mile course. Marked by blue blazes, Lake Trail cuts through a pine forest, past one of the oldest stands of cypress trees in the area, under towering hickory trees, alongside grass beds in the lake that provide cover for a variety of fish species and beside sandy beaches perfect for picnicking or pausing to gaze across the lake.

name: Sand Ridge
description: The Sand Ridge Nature Trail, part of the Lake Waccamaw State Park, is a .75-mile loop that begins and ends near the picnic area. Trail is marked with orange blazes. From the trail, hikers can view reindeer moss, Spanish moss, reindeer lichen, pond pine, longleaf pine, turkey oak, laurel oak and hickory. Trees are marked to help identify the route.

name: Loblolly
description: Marked with red trail blazes, Loblolly Trail is a one-mile loop. Similar to the Pine Woods Trail in content, this loop begins and ends at the visitor's center.

name: Boardwalks
description: Part of the Lake Waccamaw State Park, this is a gravel path from the picnic area parking lot winds through the picnic ground and leads to a 700-foot boardwalk from which hikers can get a closer look at the various plants of the bay forest bordering the lake. The boardwalk ends at a 375-foot pier perfect for fishing. An additional accessible boardwalk that traverses the bay forest is located near the visitor's center and is complete with two sun shelters.

name: Pine Woods
description: A 2.5-mile trail that winds through the park from the picnic area to the visitor's center allows hikers to view the diverse plant life found at Lake Waccamaw State Park. Common plants along this trail include longleaf pines, bay trees and turkey oaks. With a careful eye, hikers can even spot Venus flytraps. Because the flytraps are a rare species, they should not be disturbed.

name: Lake Waccamaw State Park
description:
The cool, tea-colored waters at first appear similar to other lakes in the area, but Lake Waccamaw is one of the most unique bodies of water in the world. You will find here species of animals found nowhere else on the planet, rare plants and endangered animals.<br />
At Lake Waccamaw, you can view one of the greatest geological mysteries of the eastern United States?the phenomenon of Carolina bays. Limestone bluffs along the north shore neutralize Lake Waccamaw's water, making the lake different from any other Carolina Bay. Nearby, you can catch a glimpse of a botanical wonder?the Green Swamp.<br />
From its sandy shorelines to its tree-lined natural areas, Lake Waccamaw offers peaceful surroundings, an intriguing natural history and fun in the sun.<br />
There are 11 miles of beautiful hiking trails to enjoy in this area.

name: Santa Susana Pass SHP
description: This 670-acre historic park in Los Angeles County offers broad views of the rugged natural landscape in contrast to the developed communities nearby. See the narrow ridges, the flowing streams and occasional waterfalls, and the depth of canyons close by and enjoy the fresh air outside of the city. Hikers enjoy aromatic open space with a set of networking trails. The park is also rich in archaeological, historical and cultural significance, so please take care to not disturb the natural beauty and history. The main trail on the property is the Stagecoach Trail. It is a 2.5 mile round trip with a 500- foot elevation gain. It was once used as a road for stagecoach travel between Los Angeles and San Francisco.

name: Oasis State Park
description: Good hiking area.

name: Trace State Park
description: Trace State Park Nature Trail offers a unique landscape of upland pine, hardwoods, and wetland forest. Also of interest, hikers may use our ORV Trails area which features 35 miles of trails that can be utilized by ATV's, motorcycles, horse, mountain bikes as well as the occasional hiker. More indepth information may be view by downloading the below brochure.

name: Devil's Slide
description: Devil's Slide features 3 miles of hiking trails near Simi Valley, CA.

name: Tujunga Ponds Wildlife Sanctuary
description: The 13-acre Tujunga Ponds site in Sunland was acquired by the Department in 1978, following the CalTrans completion of the 210 (Foothill) Freeway through Tujunga wash, requiring CalTrans to create the pond site in mitigation for loss of similar habitat under the freeway.  In agreement with California Fish & Game and CalTrans, the Department accepted the site and its management as a mitigation area, fenced, gated and closed as the area as a wildlife habitat.  It was agreed that the site could be accessed by permit from the Department (Natural Areas) and existing trails around the ponds could be used by visiting groups for nature study, photography and similar passive recreation.  The site contains 2 small lakes (ponds) and surrounding dense willow riparian woodlands and cottonwood riparian woodlands.

name: Gabrielino Trail
description: Gabrielino Trail features 15 miles of hiking trails near Los Angeles, CA.

name: Gabrielino Trail
description: Gabrielino Trail features 15 miles of hiking trails near Los Angeles, CA.

name: Gabrielino Trail
description: Gabrielino Trail features 15 miles of hiking trails near Los Angeles, CA.

name: Fool Hollow Lake Recreation Area
description:
A 1.5 mile walking trail runs along the South and West sides of the lake.
The White Mountain Trail System consists of eleven loop trails offering over 103 miles of hiking. Access points are located within 15 miles of the recreation area in the adjacent Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest.External Link Phone (928) 368-5111.

name: Hansen Dam Recreation Area
description:
This recreation area is centered around the Hansen Flood Control Basin. Although the Army Corps of Engineers owns this land the City of Los Angeles manages the many day-use facilities that are available here. This park boasts many activities including golf and riding stables.

There are some paved trails that run through this park. A playground and picnic area are perfect stops for your walk around the park.

name: Lynches Woods
description: Lynches Woods features 7 miles of hiking trails near Newberry, SC.

name: Ojai Valley Trail
description: The Ojai Valley Trail is a 9 mile trail that parallels Highway 33 from Foster Park on the outskirts of West Ventura, to Fox Street in Ojai. One side of the trail is paved for bicyclists, walkers, joggers and people exercising their pets. Post-and-rail wood fence separates the paved path from a dirt bridle path for horseback riders. Sections wind through wooded areas and past riverbeds.

name: Sulphur Mountain Trail
description: The Sulphur Mountain Trail is 11 miles of dirt road with tight switchbacks and fantastic views of the Ojai Valley and surrounding mountain ranges. Nature lovers will enjoy a variety of wildlife, which includes deer, coyotes, bobcats, foxes, red-tail hawks, rattlesnakes, tarantulas and roadrunners. A small number of private residences are just off the trail. Stay on the trail at all times and obey all "No Trespassing" signs. Motor vehicles are strictly prohibited.

name: Waurika Lake
description: Interpretive trails at Moneka Park.

name: Emma Wood State Beach
description: Ocean's Edge Trail takes you along Emma Wood's mixed rock and sand beach to Seaside Wilderness Park, where pine and palm trees rise above low sand dunes. The nature trail explores wetlands, including a second mouth of the Ventura River, a lagoon and sand bars.

name: Goodale State Park
description: The park has a one-mile self-interpretive nature trail. In addition the park offers a three-mile canoe trail on the park lake and Pine Tree Creek.

name: Silverwood Lake State Recreation Area
description: The Pacific Crest Trail is the jewel in the crown of America's scenic trails, spanning 2,650 miles from Mexico to Canada through three western states.  The trail passes through Silverwood Lake SRA. Additional trails available, including the Miller Canyon Trail to Serrano Beach and Marina.

name: Hurricane Creek
description: Hurricane Creek features 6 miles of hiking trails near Cullman, AL.

name: Viking Trail
description: Viking Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Rome, GA.

name: Chumash
description: Chumash features 3 miles of hiking trails near Simi Valley, CA.

name: Kennesaw Mountain National Park
description: One of the most challenging and one of the most rewarding. Visit it on a weekday and you will most likely see deer up close. Make sure you bring water.

name: Victoria Bryant State Park
description: The trails here at Victoria Bryant go through some relatively pretty areas, but the main trails are wide doubletrack trails that aren't the most attractive. The singletrack "nature trail" down by the river in the center of the park is the most entertaining hike by far.

name: CDT NM17: Pie Town (US Hwy 60) to Jnc. NM Hwy 36 and 117
description: Section 17 of the CDT runs 29.5 miles from Pie Town (US Hwy 60) to the junction of NM Hwy 36 and NM Hwy 117. Unfortunately, this entire section, like segment 16, follows roads the entire way. Hopefully at some point in the future these sections will be rerouted onto real trails. This whole segment passes through some very dry country.

name: Berry College
description: Berry College features 10 miles of hiking trails near Rome, GA.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: D
description:
Section D of the Pacific Crest Trail runs 112.5 miles from I-15 near Cajon Pass near Phelan, CA to Agua Dulce. This section of trail passes through the San Gabriel Mountains and contains the highpoint of the entire Southern California section: 9,399 feet atop Mount Baden-Powell.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes the Acorn Canyon trail; Wrightwood, CA; Guffy Campground; Angeles Crest Highway 2; Grassy Hollow Family Campground; Vincent Gap; Mount Baden-Powell; Windy Gap; Little Jimmy Spring; Little Jimmy Campground; Trail 3N04; Mt. Williamson; Rattlesnake Trail 10W03; Little Rock Creek; Burkhart Trail 10W02; Highway 2; Sulphur Springs Campground; Bare Mountain Canyon; Mill Creek Summit; Mt. Gleason's north ridge; Messenger Flats Campground; Acton, CA; Santa Clara River; Antelope Valley Freeway 14; and the VRCP trail.

name: Burning Sunshine
description: Burning Sunshine  features 8 miles of hiking trails near Tupelo, MS.

name: McGee Creek State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Reinhardt College Trails
description: Reinhardt College Trails features 5 miles of hiking trails near Waleska, GA.

name: Pine Log Creek
description: Pine Log Creek Trail features a 4.5 miles path crossing seven rustic footbridges over Pine Log Creek. From two overlooks, hikers can view Pine Log Mountain - one of the highest elevations in Bartow County's Appalachian foothills - and the site of the Pine Log Cherokee Indian Village. The trail system includes two loops east and west and is rated moderate to difficult with rugged terrain. The eastern loop takes hikers by an early CCC quarry pond for picturesque views. You can call "Keep Bartow Beautiful" for more info about this trail! 770-387-5167. This trail is not recommended for inexperienced hikers.

name: Blue Clay Road Trails
description:
Blue Clay Road Trails features 7 miles of hiking trails near Wilmington, NC.<br />
This area features an awesome network of trail loops for hikers to enjoy. These rocky trails are mostly flat and very well-marked. They are multi-use trails and are very popular with mountain bikers, so please be aware.

name: Tonto Natural Bridge State Park
description: Please carry drinking water while hiking these trails. All Trails are steep and strenuous. No pets or glass containers on any trails! Four trails offer visitors spectacular views.

name: Little Pee Dee State Park
description: The Beaver Pond Nature Trail can be accessed from the park road or from the campground. This 1.3-mile trail to a beaver pond loops back to the original point of entry.

name: Cattail Cove State Park
description: The primary trail follows the shoreline of Lake Havasu and provides an excellent view of the Parker Dam.

name: Dawson Forest
description:
There are several different trails here at Dawson Forest to hike. They range from doulbetrack to beautiful singletrack and lead to some cool views in areas. The hills are very steep, both up and down, but they aren't too long.

Be aware that this is a very popular horse destination.

name: Fruit Loop And Railbed
description: Fruit Loop and Railbed features 12 miles of hiking trails near Oxford, MS.

name: Towsley Canyon
description: Towsley Canyon features 5 miles of hiking trails near Valencia, CA.

name: Lyman Lake State Park
description: Three trails, one, the Rattlesnake Pointe Pueblo Trail leading through a former village with restored ruins and rock art, allow visitors the opportunity to hike throughout the park.

name: Viper
description: Viper features 6 miles of hiking trails near Santa Clarita, CA.

name: Rocky Mountain Recreation Area
description: Rocky Mountain Recreation Area features 10 miles of hiking trails near Rome , GA.

name: Pico Canyon Park
description: Pico Canyon Park is a 21-acre passive park that is home to a transplanted Oak tree popularly known as "Old Glory."  This park has a few walking pathways for visitors to enjoy on nice California days!

name: Hart State Outdoor Recreation Area
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Sulphur Mountain
description: Sulphur Mountain features 18 miles of hiking trails near Oak View, CA.

name: Sulphur Mountain
description: Sulphur Mountain features 18 miles of hiking trails near Oak View, CA.

name: Placerita Canyon Nature Center (Los Pinetos & Canyon Trail Only)
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Placerita Canyon Nature Center (Los Pinetos & Canyon Trail Only)
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Placerita Canyon Nature Center (Los Pinetos & Canyon Trail Only)
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Hartwell Lake
description: Great hiking trails in nearby Hart State Park, Lake Hartwell State Park, Sadlers Creek State Park, and Tugaloo State Park.

name: Lake Guntersville State Park
description: The hiking trails in Lake Guntersville State Park traverse moderate to difficult terrain and cover over 36 miles of park property. They are multi-use trails, serving as hiking, biking and horse trails. The trails are varied with some following alongside the banks of the Tennessee River, others lead to seasonal waterfalls and wildflowers, and some that peak your interest just by their name alone such as the Old Still Path and the Moonshine Trail.

name: Lumber River State Park
description:
Hikers enjoy the park's nature trail system. Princess Ann has 1.5 miles of trails. Chalk Banks Trail, a 1.5-mile loop, meanders along the river's edge, by a wetlands habitat, and a mixed pine and hardwoods forest.

Begin near the picnic shelter and enjoy a peaceful walk along the highest bank of the Lumber River. The trail features a 100-foot boardwalk across a wet area. A fishing pier and turn-of-the-century millpond are adjacent to the trail.

name: Lake Havasu State Park
description: One trail, the Mohave Sunset Trail, allows visitors a trip into the desert and back via shoreline. No bicycles; pets on leash.

name: Carpinteria State Beach
description:
This beach hike heads down-coast along the state beach to City Bluffs Park and the Chevron Oil Pier. A small pocket beach contains the Harbor Seal Preserve. From December through May this beach is seals-only. Humans may quietly watch the boisterous colony, sometimes numbering as many as 150 seals, from a blufftop observation area above the beach.

After seal-watching, you can then sojourn over the Carpinteria Bluffs or contiue down the beach to Rincon Point on the Santa Barbara-Ventura county line.

name: Carpinteria State Beach
description:
This beach hike heads down-coast along the state beach to City Bluffs Park and the Chevron Oil Pier. A small pocket beach contains the Harbor Seal Preserve. From December through May this beach is seals-only. Humans may quietly watch the boisterous colony, sometimes numbering as many as 150 seals, from a blufftop observation area above the beach.

After seal-watching, you can then sojourn over the Carpinteria Bluffs or contiue down the beach to Rincon Point on the Santa Barbara-Ventura county line.

name: Carpinteria State Beach
description:
This beach hike heads down-coast along the state beach to City Bluffs Park and the Chevron Oil Pier. A small pocket beach contains the Harbor Seal Preserve. From December through May this beach is seals-only. Humans may quietly watch the boisterous colony, sometimes numbering as many as 150 seals, from a blufftop observation area above the beach.

After seal-watching, you can then sojourn over the Carpinteria Bluffs or contiue down the beach to Rincon Point on the Santa Barbara-Ventura county line.

name: Cossatot River State Park-Natural Area
description: For hiking enthusiasts, the park features the 14-mile River Corridor Trail and the 3.5-mile Harris Creek Trail.

name: Lake Catherine State Park
description: Park interpreters offer guided hikes.

name: Sadler's Creek
description: Some easy hiking trails in the pine woods at Sadler's Creek State Park. Many of the trails run close to the water, providing great views of Lake Hartwell.

name: Clear Creek
description: Clear Creek features 8 miles of hiking trails near Oxford, MS.

name: Lake Wateree State Park
description: The Desportes Island Trail is a moderate .7-mile loop trail.

name: Val Verde Community Regional Park
description:
