Open from sunrise to sunset, Val Verde Community Regional Park is a great neighborhood park in the heart of Val Verde. Val Verde Park is a 58-acre community regional facility in a verdant rural setting, nestled among mature oak trees.

Some walking paths wind throughout this park taking you past a children's play area, a community recreation building, horseshoe pits, outdoor basketball courts, picnic tables and barbeque grills, a softball field, a swimming pool, and a tennis court.

name: Buncombe - Brickhouse Recreation Area
description: Buncombe - Brickhouse Recreation Area features 28 miles of hiking trails near Whitmire, SC.

name: Shelf Road Trail
description: Pets allowed on leash.

name: Romero Road
description: Romero Road features 6 miles of hiking trails near Santa Barbara, CA.

name: Crack in the Wall Trail
description: This is a very popular and scenic easy to moderate trail that follows a wash to the shoreline of Lake Havasu. The hike takes about three to four hours and is just over two miles each way. Hikers have the option of staying in the wash and going thru the "Crack," a narrow slot canyon, or go up a parallel route following the wash on the hillside and back into the wash trail.  Like most desert wash trails, flash floods pose a danger.  Flooding can be a hazard because several small washes funnel into the large wash creating the narrow slot canyon.  If recent significant rain has occurred, small pools form within the narrow passages.  While the pools are passable, the rocks are slippery and the pools can be 2 feet deep or more and hiking the trail is not advised. The crack has a steep slide rock portion that's fairly easy going down, but very hard to climb back up.  Most hikers choose to hike down the crack and take the upper trail to bypass the crack on the way back. The upper trail on the return crosses or rejoins the wash trail and main trail shortly before arriving back at the trailhead.

name: Jesusita
description: Jesusita is a 7 mile hiking trail in Santa Barbara, California.

name: Groom Creek Loop
description: Groom Creek Loop features 8 miles of hiking trails near Prescott, AZ.

name: Santa Ana River Trail and Parkway
description: The Santa Ana River Trail is currently 60% complete.  When finished it will run 110 miles - from the San Bernardino County National Forest to the Pacific Ocean at Huntington Beach where the trail ends.  There are currently two gaps in the trail:  From Green River in Orange County to Hidden Valley Wildlife area in Riverside County; and from Waterman Avenue in San Bernardino, CA to the National Forest boundary line near Mentone, CA.

name: El Capitan State Beach
description: The El Capitan Beach Trail offers visitors a great view of this area's ecosystems.

name: Paynes Creek
description: Paynes Creek is a gorgeous 7 mile trail that offers numerous gorgeous views of Lake Hartwell. The Paynes Creek Campground is nearby.

name: Buck's Pocket State Park
description: Buck's Pocket State Park has 20 miles of hiking trails varying from 1/4 mile to 6 miles in length. There are also six miles of horseback trails. These trails offer visitors a perfect opportunity to get better acquainted with the area's rich woodlands and vistas.

name: Pinhoti Trail @ Sloppy Floyd
description: Pinhoti Trail @ Sloppy Floyd features 4 miles of hiking trails near Rome, GA.

name: Smith Ravine
description: Smith Ravine features 6 miles of hiking trails near Prescott, AZ.

name: Vasquez Rocks Natural Area Park
description:
932 acres of beautiful rock formations exist within this county park. Park hours differ depending upon the sunrise and sunset. Between April 1- August 31, the park is open from 8:00 a.m.- 7:00 p.m., and between September 1-March 31, the park is open from 8:00 a.m.- 5:00 p.m.
Hiking trails run throughout this park where Tiburcio Vasquez, one of California's most notorious bandits, hid in 1874 to elude law enforcement. The park also has an amphitheater, animal exhibits, a historic Ranger's House, and picnic areas.

name: Tugaloo State Park
description: Hiking - 4 miles of trails

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: E
description:
Section E of the Pacific Crest Trail runs 109.3 miles from the town of Agua Dulce to Highway 58 near Mojave. This section of the PCT is radically different from the rest of the trail, and not in a good way: the majority of it runs through the Mojave Desert, and much of it isn't even a trail at all. Instead, the route follows many gravel roads and the Los Angeles Aqueduct. The trail was intended to follow the "crest" of the nearby Liebre Mountains, but private land managers of the Tejon Ranch have refused to allow passage across their land for the trail.<br />
<br />
The current rendition of section E passes Old Sierra Highway; Angeles National Forest; Big Tree Trail 14W02; CRHT; Lake Hughes, CA; Highway 138; Lancaster, CA; Los Angeles Aqueduct; Tylerhorse Canyon; Gamble Spring Canyon; Tehachapi, CA; and Mojave, CA.

name: Delta Heritage Trail State Park
description: Trailheads are located at Helena junction near Barton, Walnut Corner at the U.S. 49 overpass, Lick Creek (Ark. 85 just south of Barton), and in Lakeview. The trail stretches through a shaded canopy of native hardwoods, alongside agricultural fields, and across many streams. Wildlife viewing and birdwatching opportunities abound along the route. Once completed, the Delta Heritage Trail will also offer sweeping views from bridges that span the Arkansas River and the White River.

name: Lake Hartwell State Park
description: There is a 3/4-mile nature trail located on the park.

name: Lake Russell Loop
description: This is a great loop around Lake Russell with some great views of the lake. There's a nice campground here as well. The 2 dam crossings are very cool.

name: Sourwood
description: Sourwood is a beautiful hiking trail that leads to a gorgeous waterfalls.

name: Ladyslipper
description: Ladyslipper features 7 miles of hiking trails near Cornelia, GA.

name: DeSoto State Park
description: DeSoto State Park also offers miles of hiking trails, beautiful bluffs and rock formations, a number of small waterfalls.

name: Devil's Punchbowl Natural Area
description: The Devil's Punchbowl is a unique 1,310 acre geological wonder where visitors can walk, hike or take a horseback rise on a 7.5 mile round-trip trail through a deep canyon formed by the runoff of large quantities of water from the higher San Gabriel Mountains. See spectacular up tilted rock formations created by layers of sedimentary rocks, or visit the Nature Center to learn about the native wildlife and park history. You can also explore the landscape of Joshua trees, California Junipers, Pinyon Pine Woodland and Desert Chaparral shrubs while observing the variety of wildlife.

name: Mojave Narrows Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Water Tank Trail
description: Water Tank Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Calhoun, GA.

name: Chickasaw National Recreation Area
description:
Chickasaw National Recreation Area is a place where natural beauty meets history in harmony. Meander along any of the hiking trails. They will offer you a delightful experience. In the same hike, you can view the intricate and artistic rock work done by the Civilian Conservation Corps, catch a glimpse of a beaver building a dam or a bison grazing on the prairie.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Hot Springs National Park
description: There are 23  trails offering 24  miles of hiking available within the park.

name: Frady Branch
description: The Frady Branch Trails near Currahee Mountain are mostly wide doubletrack trails that receive a lot of horse traffic, but they do go past some really cool historic sites including old home sites and graveyards, as well as a couple of waterfalls. If you're in the area and have some time to kill, come check this place out! Be sure to walk around the top of Currahee Mountain, too.

name: Cabezon Peak Wilderness Study Area
description: Cabezon Peak's dramatic volcanic formation is one of the most well-known landmarks in northwest New Mexico. With an elevation of 7,785 feet, the Peak is part of the Mount Taylor volcanic field and is the largest of 50 volcanic necks rising from the Rio Puerco Valley.  Desert shrublands dominated by cholla cactus give way to pinon and juniper on the flanks of the peak.   The symmetrical peak forms cliffs on all sides, and the surrounding landscape gently falls away from the base of the cliffs.

name: Kilbourne Hole Volcanic Crater
description: Restrooms and drinking water are not available.

name: Glade Run Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Socorro Nature Area
description: Interpretive, self-guided nature trail.

name: San Lorenzo Canyon Recreation Area
description: This scenic east-west canyon offers ample outdoor opportunities for hiking and primitive camping. Some of the geological features you can find on a hike in San Lorenzo Canyon are arches, shelter caves, and interesting rock formations -- there is something interesting around every corner. The cottonwoods indicate there may have been a reliable water source at one time in the area. The area is a longtime favorite winter and driving destination of both the New Mexico Carriage Club and the Rio Grande Mule and Donkey Association. The area has remnants of old ranches and homesteads; springs and tiny creeks also are hidden in the canyon bottoms and washes.

name: White Mesa Bike Trails
description: Dragons Tail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Albuquerque, NM.

name: Guadalupe Backcountry Byway
description: For 30 miles, the Guadalupe Backcountry Byway travels the transition from cholla cactus in the Chihuahuan Desert west of Carlsbad up into the pines of the dramatic Guadalupe Escarpment. Travelers can see mule deer, pronghorn antelope, gray fox, scaled quail, mourning dove, a variety of songbirds, and small mammals. The Byway is located along the Capitan Reef of the Permian Basin and passes through an area of producing oil and gas wells. The plains give way to steep limestone outcrops cut by dry arroyos. Beneath the surface are numerous caves, including Carlsbad Caverns and Lechugilla Cave within nearby Carlsbad Caverns National Park.

name: NGCSU Athletic Complex
description: This is a 1-2 mile paved hiking trail system in a triple-8-style configuration that winds along the side of the ridge above the NGCSU athletic complex. While it is paved, there are several challenging climbs and descents, and it passes through some gorgeous sections of forest and provides amazing views of the athletic center below, some of the nearby dorms, all with the majestic North Georgia mountains in the background!

name: Yahoola Creek Park
description:
This park is right in Dahlonega and offers a couple of miles of scenic hiking trails up in the woods. These trails are a great natural getaway for the locals when they don't want to drive all the way up the mountain to the Appalachian Trail.<br />
The park also offers a road/track for running, soccer fields, baseball fields, tennis courts, a stream, a playground, and a community garden.

name: Cedar Glades Trail
description: Cedar Glades Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Hot Springs, AR.
#305  features 7 miles of hiking trails near Prescott, AZ.

name: Trail #62
description: Trail #62 features 10 miles of hiking trails near Prescott, AZ.

name: Whiskey 25 Race Route
description: Whiskey 25 Race Route features 28 miles of hiking trails near Prescott, AZ.

name: Yahoola Creek Reservoir
description: This is about a 4 mile trail that circles Yahoola Creek Reservoir but also swerves back into the woods a ways. This trail is surprisingly tough with many short, steep climbs in the back hills. While this is a wide doubletrack trail that isn't always very entertaining, this trail is right on the edge of town and is very easy-to-access. It's great for a short after work hike or trail run without having to drive all the way up to the Appalachian Trail.

name: Clayton Lake State Park
description: With a wide variety of trees lining the water's edge, the beautiful foliage offers outdoor enthusiasts the chance to reconnect with nature along the park's hiking trails.

name: Jake to Bull Mountain Connecter
description: This is a great singletrack trail that runs through the beautiful Chattahoochee National Forest, but do be aware that there are several forest service road crossings and significant horse and bike traffic.

name: Hike Inn
description: This trail starts off connected to the Approach trail, but soon splits off and takes its own path to the Hike Inn Lodge. You will need reservations if you wish to stay at the Hike Inn, but no reservations are needed to hike the trail! It's five miles of moderate climbs and hills that crosses a couple of streams and bridges. It's a beautiful hike, but doesn't offer views until you get to the lodge!

name: Jake Mountain Trails
description:
This is a beautiful trail through the forest! The low point of the trail is about halfway through at a deep creek crossing that is knee-deep almost all year long.

This is a gorgeous trail through a gorgeous forest, but there's serious horse traffic here and a lot of poop to go with it.

name: Amicalola Falls
description:
Amicalola Falls is a very popular destination for both day hikers and backpackers.

For day hikers, Amicalola offers an easy approach to the base of the falls, and it definitely doesn't take a day to get there! You can see the falls from the parking area, and it takes less than a mile to get to the base. However, if you want to hike to the top of the falls, it is a long, long staircase up to the top! Also, there are other scenic singletrack trails in the park.

For backpackers, Amicalola falls functions as about an 8 mile approach trail to the top of Springer Mountain and the official beginning of the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/2291/Hiking-Trails/Appalachian-Trail-001--Springer-Mountain-to-Hightower-Gap.html">Appalachian Trail</a>. Early every spring there is a festival held at Amicalola, and a large group of AT through-hikers begin their journey en masse. There is also a large hike-to lodge up the side of the mountain that's still in the park.

name: Castaic Lake State Recreation Area
description: The site includes 29 miles of shoreline. A major attraction is the 425-foot tall Castaic Dam.

name: Pinhoti Trail - Armuchee To Snake Creek Gap
description: Pinhoti Trail - Armuchee To Snake Creek Gap features 15 miles of hiking trails near Villanow, GA.

name: Dry Creek
description: Dry Creek features 26 miles of hiking trails near Sublinga, GA.

name: Pinhoti Trail - Snake Creek Gap To Dug Gap
description: Large parking area at Snake Creek Gap with restrooms. The hike from Snake Creek ascends initially toward Dug Gap and after a couple miles descends to a wooded valley with multiple stream crossings. The second half of the hike toward Dug Gap is mostly along the ridge line and you'll find a couple primative campsites along the trail here.

name: Bull / Jake Mountain
description:
This is a beautiful trail in the North Georgia mountains that passes historic items back in the forest such as an old, rusting pickup and old cabins. This trail goes through some cool rhododendron tunnels, crosses some gorgeous creeks, and generally provides awesome access to the beautiful Chattahoochee National Forest.<br />
<br />
There is significant horse and mountain bike traffic on this trail, though, so it isn't very ideal for hiking. The Appalachian Trail is just up on top of the ridge, though, and it is hiking-only!

name: Jones Creek Ridge Trail
description: This trail crosses the a dam near the reservoir below Bull Mountain and then climbs up through a couple of meadows to the top of Jones Creek Ridge, where you can take in some gorgeous views of North Georgia. This trail has some of the best views in the Bull/Jake Mountain Trail System, but be aware: there is significant horse and mountain bike traffic on this trail.

name: El Mirage Dry Lake Off-Highway Vehicle Recreation Area
description: There are several opportunities for hiking, rock scrambling, rock hounding, and wildlife watching. El Mirage has desert tortoises, a state and federally-listed threatened species.

name: Musgrove Mill State Historic Site
description: Musgrove Mill has nearly 2.5 miles of interpretive trails, including a one-mile loop along the southern bank of the Enoree River that includes most of what was the 1774 property of Edward Musgrove, which was briefly occupied by the British during the summer of 1780; and a 1.2-mile trail through the battlefield north of the Enoree River that marks where much of the fighting took place.

name: CDT NM18: Jnc. NM Hwy 36 & 117 to NM Hwy 117
description: Segment 18 of the Continental Divide Trail runs 27.1 miles from the junction of NM Hwy 36 and NM Hwy 117 to NM Hwy 117. This trail runs from 117 to 117 because the entire segment runs ON Hwy 117. Like the two segments before, this entire section is 100% road. Hopefully at some point a real trail will be built to hold this section of the Continental Divide route.

name: Singletary Lake State Park
description: CCC-Carolina Bay Loop Trail is an easy one-mile trek that begins near the pier at the lakeshore. Journey through a forest of bay shrubs, cedar, cypress, gum and poplars. The return segment of the trail takes you through a forest of longleaf pine and bay vegetation.

name: Tishomingo State Park
description: Tishomingo State Park is a historic area located in the foothills of the Appalachian Mountains. Historians believe Paleo Indians once roamed the area. Uncommon to Mississippi, Tishomingo has large rock formation throughout the park. Disc golfing, boating, swimming, picnicking, canoeing and field sporting are all popular here. A 13-mile trail system is also available for hikers. The trail takes you through rocky ridges and fern-filled canyons.

name: Carters Lake
description: Several interpretive trails.

name: Rose Hill Plantation State Historic Site
description: The Rose Hill Nature Trail runs through both park property and United States Forest Service property. The trail covers one-and-a-quarter miles and extends to the Tyger River..

name: Sumner Lake State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Pilchers Pond Figure 8
description: Pilchers Pond Figure 8 features 8 miles of hiking trails near Villanow, GA.

name: Lake Ouachita State Park
description: Hikers may enjoy a few wildlife trails.

name: Granite Basin Loops
description: Granite Basin Loops features 11 miles of hiking trails near Prescott, AZ.

name: Womble
description: Womble features 37 miles of hiking trails near Mt. Ida/hot Springs, AR.

name: Woodring Branch
description: This is a beautiful hiking trail along the shores of Carter's Lake. The loop is a very easy, scenic hike that is 3.5 miles long.

name: Mount Yonah
description: There's a trail that climbs up to the summit of Mount Yonah. It gains about 1,400 feet of elevation in a fast 2.5 miles. There's a gorgeous view off the top of the rock face, and if you are into climbing, opportunities abound for easy-to-hard sport climbing, top roping, bouldering, and trad climbing.

name: Appalachian Trail 001: Springer Mountain to Hightower Gap
description:
This is the southernmost section of the Appalachian Trail, and it technically starts at the summit of Springer Mountain. Many people begin their hike at Amicalola Falls and hike the AT approach trail on their way up to Springer. (Note: the Google Maps location given is for the Springer Mountain parking lot, which is already a mile or two north of the official start of the AT.) <br />
From the Southern Terminus, the trail travels north past the Springer Mountain parking lot, Stover Creek shelter, Three Forks area, and Hawk Mountain shelter to Hightower Gap on USFS 42. <br />
Near Three Forks and the final split with the BMT is the gorgeous Long Creek Falls. Hiking in the 1 mile from the Three Forks parking area is a popular day hike.<br />
(Note: when you continue on from Hightower onto section 2 of the AT, make sure that you take the singletrack that heads back up the ridge, and not the trail that drops down the side of the mountain. The trail that drops down the mountain is NOT the Appalachian Trail.)<br />
The Benton MacKaye Trail also has its Southern Terminus near the top of Springer Mountain, and before they part ways for good the BMT and AT intersect 4 times near the Springer Mountain parking lot, forming 3 small loops of singletrack. These loops are very popular with casual day hikers due to the easy access, great views, short mileage, and loop design.<br />
<br />
Best parking spot: see Google Map on the right.

name: Cheraw State Park
description: Cheraw State Park features 9 miles of hiking trails near Cheraw, SC.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 01: Springer Mountain to Three Forks
description:
The trail starts south of the Springer Mountain parking lot near Springer Mountain where it branches off of the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/2291/Hiking-Trails/Appalachian-Trail-001--Springer-Mountain-Hightower-Gap.html">Appalachian Trail</a>. Here at the beginning the Benton MacKaye intersects the A.T. at 4 different points, forming 3 loops of trail that are very popular with day hikers looking for an easy-to-access loop that doesn't require much effort. Difficulty of the trail is easy to moderate. This section of the trail runs roughly north from the Springer Mountain parking lot to Three Forks. This entire section of the trail lies in the deep forest of the Ed Jenkins National Recreation Area.

The Benton MacKaye is one of the wildest long-distance backpacking trails in the nation. Unlike the A.T., the B.M.T. eschews cities, shelters, parks, and campgrounds wherever possible and instead opts for as wild and pristine of a route and experience as possible. It runs a total of 288 miles.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail: Georgia
description:
The Benton MacKaye is one of the wildest long-distance backpacking trails in the nation. Unlike the A.T., the B.M.T. eschews cities, shelters, parks, and campgrounds wherever possible and instead opts for as wild and pristine of a route and experience as possible. It runs a total of 288 miles.<br />
The BMT runs for about 50 miles through the state of Georgia until it crosses the border into Tennessee.

To continue following the BMT North, click on over to the Tennessee section.

name: Red And White Loop
description: A pretty hiking trail in the forest, connected to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/949/Hiking-Trails/River-Loop.html">River Loop.</a>

name: River Loop
description: This is a beautiful trail that follows the Cartecay River for several miles. It can be steep in spots, but the views of the river and the deep forest are well worth it!

name: Ridgeway Loop
description: There are some short, steep hills here above Carter's Lake with some campsites nearby. The forest is beautiful, and there are some great views of the lake.

name: Pigeon Mountain
description: Pigeon Mountain features 12 miles of hiking trails near LaFayette, GA.

name: River Island State Park
description: Wedge Hill Trail is approximately å_ mile in length, medium difficulty, overlooking Colorado River. Scenic overlooks include Colorado River and Parker Dam.

name: Appalachian Trail 002: Hightower Gap to Woody Gap
description:
Section 2 of the Appalachian Trail begins at Hightower Gap and runs for 12 miles, mostly East, to the junction with GA Hwy 60 at Woody Gap. Along the way it runs past Horse Gap, Sassafras Mountain, Cooper Gap, the Gooch Mountain Shelter, Gooch Mountain, and Black Mountain. Much of this trail follows the ridgeline, but one big section drops down the ridge into a valley, and then climbs back up.

(Note: as you begin section 2 at Hightower Gap, make sure that you take the singletrack that heads back up the ridge, and not the trail that drops down the side of the mountain. The trail that drops down the mountain is NOT the Appalachian Trail.)

Best parking location: "Woody Gap" lat=34.6777486591, lon=-83.9996076382

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 02: Three Forks to GA Hwy 60
description:
The Benton MacKaye Trail follows the Appalachian Trail for the first mile north of Three Forks before it joins the Duncan Ridge National Recreation Trail, following that the rest of the way to GA Hwy 60. <br />
Near Three Forks and the final split with the AT is the gorgeous Long Creek Falls. Hiking in the 1 mile from the Three Forks parking area is a popular day hike.<br />
This is one of the most remote sections of the BMT in Georgia, and it is rated "most difficult" for frequent ascents and the long, uninterrupted length.

name: Long Creek Falls
description: The trail begins at Three Forks, a popular dispersed recreation area in the southeast corner of the district. The trail begins on the north side of the road and starts as a relatively gradual hike alongside Long creek. There are three short ascents before reaching the blue blazed side trail to the falls at 1.1 miles. The hike follows the white blazes of the Appalachian Trail north to the side of the trail. This was a wonderful family hike! We did it with a 4 month baby in tow! (Although that was a lil rough!)

name: Wall Doxey State Park
description: A two and half mile nature trail winds around Spring Lake, affording beautiful views of the water and of native Mississippi flora and fauna.

name: Sardis Lake
description: Sardis Lake is located five miles north of Clayton, Oklahoma, along Oklahoma Highway 2 in beautiful southeastern Oklahoma. The lake covers 14,360 acres, with 117 miles of shoreline, and offers many opportunities for every diversification of outdoor recreation. There are three campgrounds located around the lake offering various facilities including general hookups, restrooms, showering facilities, swim beach and fishing docks. The lake also has facilities for group camping and picnic shelters equipped with tables, electricity and large outdoor cooking grills. Although Sardis Lake is known for producing several of Oklahoma's largest bass, the lake also provides fishermen excellent opportunities to catch crappie, catfish, and walleye. Come join us at the western tip of the Ouachita Mountain Range.

name: Saddleback Butte State Park
description: The Saddleback  Butte Trails offers a 4 mile round trip over a 1,000-foot elevation gain.

name: Appalachian Trail 003: Woody Gap to Neels Gap
description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail starts at GA Highway 60 (Woody Gap) and ends at GA Highway 129 (Neels Gap). Shelters along this route include Woods Hole Shelter and Blood Mountain Shelter.<br />
This section climbs to the rocky top of the famous Blood Mountain (skirting the Blood Mountain Wilderness), offering gorgeous views of the mountains for miles around! This is the most popular section of the Appalachian Trail in Georgia, and for a very good reason!

Best parking locations:
"Woody Gap" lat=34.6777486591, lon=-83.9996076382
"Reese State Memorial" lat=34.7424174142, lon=-83.9212214749

name: Jones Lake State Park
description:
Bay Trail is a five-mile loop around Jones Lake, offering an excellent chance to experience the habitats of a Carolina bay. Wander through dense vegetation and over boggy soil to view lovely lakeside flora. Large pond cypress trees, draped with Spanish moss, line the shore and grow in the shallow water. Leatherwood plants with delicate white flowers, also called titi, overhang the water's edge. Several short side-trails lead to the lake, allowing hikers a chance to catch their breath while viewing the vista across the lake. Begin Bay Lake Trail at the picnic area or campground. For trail interpretation, contact park staff.

The park also has a one-mile nature trail. The Cedar Loop Trail journeys through both the bay forest and sand ridge communities.

name: Queen Wilhelmina State Park
description: The natural beauty of the mountain and a close up view of the flowers and wildlife beckon you to the four trails in this park. The Oachita Trail passes through this state park.

name: Smithgall Woods State Park
description: Hiking and Bicycling - 23 miles of roads and trails, 5 miles of nature trails, most closed during scheduled hunts

name: Fort Macon State Park
description: Fort Macon has over 1.5 miles of ocean beach for hiking. As you walk along the beach you may see one of the 302 different species of birds found in the park or experience the thrill of watching Dolphins playing in the ocean.

name: DeSoto Falls
description: There are two waterfalls along the DeSoto Falls Trail. The lower falls cascade about 20 feet and the upper and most scenic falls drop 80 feet! Both are accessed by a maintained trail leading from the day use parking area. It is about 1/4 mile to the lower falls and about 3/4 mile to the upper falls. This is not a loop trail.

name: Landsford Canal State Park
description:
There is much to see and do at Landsford Canal State Park. The most popular hike is the Canal Trail, which is 1.25 miles one way. This trail will take you along the well-preserved structures of the old navigation locks on the Catawba River.
The Nature Trail, just 0.5 miles one way, will take you to a viewing platform where one of the largest known stands of Rocky Shoals Spider Lilies can be viewed. These lilies come into full bloom around mid-May, and stay in bloom until about mid-June. The stands of lilies literally blanket the river in white blooms. A spectacular site.
The Eagle Point Trail, only 0.25 miles one way, ends at a bluff overlooking the Catawba River where both British and American soldiers crossed during the revolutionary war.
For paddlers, 7.4 miles of the Catawba River Trail can be enjoyed starting at the park. SC route 9 landing will be your take-out downriver.
All trails, including the canoe trail, start near the picnic area at Landsford Canal State Park.

name: MCAS New River Trail
description:
MCAS New River Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Jacksonville, NC. <br />
This trail has short, but steep climbs all along the path as it meanders under the cool forest canopy. Get out and stretch your legs on this short, but beautiful hike. Make sure to watch out for mountain bike traffic as well!

name: Chester State Park
description: The Caney Fork Creek Nature Trail loops around the park lake and is approximately 1.3 miles in length.

name: CDT NM19: NM Hwy 117 to Zuni-Acoma TH (NM Hwy 117)
description:
Finally, the CDT is back on a real trail. Section 19 of the Continental Divide Trail runs for 55.2 miles from NM Hwy 117 to the Zuni-Acoma TH (NM Hwy 117). While most of this section is trail, some of it does, admittedly, follow the road at some point.<br />
Along the way this segment passes Cerro Brilliante, Cerro Negro, Cerro Chato, the Chain-of-Craters Wilderness Study Area, Cerro Lobo, Lost Woman Crater, Cerro Rendija, Cerro Hueco, Cerro Leonides, Cerro Americano, Cerro Bandera, Bandera Crater, NM Hwy 53, Cerro Candelaria, and El Malpais National Monument.<br />
Note: this segment crosses the time zone line.

name: Arkabutla Lake
description: There's a 2,3, and 5 mile hike through a series of trails. The 5-mile is great with all the loboly pines in the middle of the hike.

name: Hickory Nut
description: Hickory Nut is a 19 mile hiking trail in Helen, Georgia.

name: Unicoi State Park and Lodge
description: Outdoor enthusiasts can enjoy hiking and mountain biking on scenic mountain trails, including an easy lake loop, challenging trek to Anna Ruby Falls, pretty three-mile trail to downtown Helen and rugged 7.5-mile singletrack for bikers.

name: Talimena State Park
description: Hiking and backpacking trails throughout Talimena State Park offer a wide range of scenic, wooded terrain.

name: Appalachian Trail 005: Tesnatee Gap Unicoi Gap
description:
This Appalachian trail hike goes from GA Hwy 348 (Tesnatee Gap) to GA Hwy 75 (Unicoi Gap). Shelters along the route include Low Gap Shelter and Blue Mountain Shelter. The trail also climbs or passes Horsetrough Mountain and Blue Mountain.<br />
Best parking location: see Google Map to the right.

name: Appalachian Trail 004: Neels Gap to Tesnatee Gap
description:
Section 4 of the AT runs 5.5 miles from the store at Neels Gap on US Hwy 129 to Testanee Gap on GA Hwy 348. This section of trail is very remote since the entire 5.5 mile length lies in the center of the Raven Cliffs Wilderness. It crosses Levelland Mountain and Cowrock Mountain on the way.

Best parking location: "Tesnatee Gap" lat=34.7260494054, lon=-83.8476196274

name: Slippery Rock Trail  (Georgia)
description: This is a trail inside Tallulah Falls State Park. Can only be hiked with a permit. Extremely dangerous vertical slopes.

name: Slaughter Creek / #141
description: The Slaughter Creek trail runs 2.7 miles one-way from Lake Winfield Scott up to a junction with the Appalachian Trail.

name: Issaqueena Lake
description: Issaqueena Lake features 7 miles of hiking trails near Clemson, SC.

name: Tallulah Gorge State Park
description: Tallulah Gorge State Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Tallulah Falls, GA.

name: Cooper Creek
description: The beautiful Cooper Creek Scenic Area contains a number of singletrack trails and has several trails that connect to it and lie right outside its boundaries. Tucked away in the heart of the national forest, Cooper Creek gets very little traffic, so you don't have to deal with the crowds like you do on the AT. Every time I've been here, I've had the place all to myself! It has several campgrounds nearby as well, so it's a great place to camp, go on day hikes, or do some easy backpacking.

name: Anna Ruby Falls
description: This is an easy hike, but the view is well worth it! The main trail up to Anna Ruby falls is only about a half a mile one-way and it is paved, with some steps. The falls are definitely worth the hike! If you're more adventurous, there's a singletrack trail that continues on for about 5  more miles beyond the end of the pavement. There's a $2 access fee.

name: Lake Winfield Scott / #143
description: A short 1-mile trail that circles Lake Winfield Scott. Trail connects to the campground as well as the Slaughter Creek Trail

name: Jasus Creek
description: Jasus Creek features 12 miles of hiking trails near Helen, GA.

name: Monte Sano State Park
description: Currently over 14 miles of hiking/biking trails service our state park and its patrons. The Park's trail systems are maintained by our employees and with the help of local hiking and biking groups.

name: Verde River Greenway State Natural Area
description: The trails in this area link up with the Dead Horse Ranch State Park trail system. There is also about a mile of trail along Verde River.

name: Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve State Natural Reserve
description: Visitors must stay on trails. No horses, dogs, or mountain bikes allowed.

name: Wichita NWR - Mt. Scott Loop
description: Wichita Nwr - Mt. Scott Loop features 10 miles of hiking trails near Meers, OK.

name: Arthur B. Ripley Desert Woodland State Park
description: The park has a self-guided nature trail.

name: Dead Horse Ranch State Park
description: The trails in this system are in Dead Horse Ranch State Park and in the Coconino Natinal Forest. Trail users, the Dead Horse Ranch Trails Coalition, Arizona State Parks Rangers & Volunteers, and the Forest Service have worked together to develop and manage this system for you enjoyment. Bring extra water and get an early start in the summer months. Trailheads are located north of the lagoon area or at the end of Flycatcher road.

name: Angel Falls Trailhead
description: This is a heavily wooded trail that leads you to two different waterfalls. One is 1/2 mile in and the other is 1 mile from the starting point. There is a creek that runs along side the trail for   a while. I would describe it as a moderate hike with some steep inclines.

name: Allsopp Park
description: Allsopp Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Little Rock, AR.

name: Duncan Ridge
description: The Duncan Ridge Trail (DRT) stretches 32.9 miles from GA Hwy 180 near Vogel State Park to the Benton MacKaye Trail and GA Hwy 60.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 03: GA Hwy 60 to Skeenah Gap
description:
This section of the Benton MacKaye trail is rated "most difficult" due to the many steep ascents and descents in its short length. There are 3 peaks over 3000' on this section: Wallalah Mountain, Licklog Mountain, and Rhodes Mountain. From GA Hwy 60, the BMT runs with the Duncan Ridge National Recreation Trail until it reaches Rhodes Mountain. At that point the trails split, and the BMT heads northwest.<br />
<br />
Most of the trail is in the Cooper Creek WMA.

name: Vogel State Park
description:
Vogel is located at the base of Blood Mountain in the Chattahoochee National Forest. Park Hours: 7AM-10PM Office Hours: 8AM-5PM GeorgiaStateParks.org/Vogel ACCOMMODATIONS & FACILITIES: 233 Acres <br />
35 Cottages ($95-$160) - #5, #6 and #30 are dog friendly ($40 per dog, max 2)<br />
103 Tent, Trailer, RV Campsites ($25-$28) -- some sections close during winter 18 Walk-in Campsites ($19)Pioneer Campground ($50)22-Acre Lake with Beach 4 Picnic Shelters ($50) <br />
<br />
Group Shelter (seats 75, $160) <br />
<br />
Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) Museum <br />
<br />
General Store <br />
<br />
THINGS TO DO & SEE: <br />
<br />
Hiking and Backpacking - 17 miles of trails, Appalachian Trail nearby <br />
<br />
Fishing <br />
<br />
Lake Swimming (seasonal) <br />
<br />
Pedal Boat and Kayak Rental (seasonal) <br />
<br />
Miniature Golf (fee) <br />
<br />
Bike Rental <br />
<br />
GeoCaching <br />
<br />
Playground <br />
Hikers can choose from a variety of trails, including the popular 4-mile Bear Hair Gap loop, an easy lake loop that leads to Trahlyta Falls, and the challenging 13-mile Coosa Backcountry Trail.

name: Trahlyta Lake Trail (Georgia)
description: Vogel State Park has 5 mixed use trails. for a total of 20 miles of trail throughout the park.

name: Coosa Backcountry Loop
description: The Coosa Backcountry Trail is a massive 39.4-mile singletrack loop that starts near Vogel State Park (and has a spur trail that runs to Vogel). The loop runs through the Sosebee Cove Scenic Area, heads up to Coosa Bald, runs with the Duncan Ridge Trail for a distance, and also runs through the Blood Mountain Wilderness. There's also a spur trail branching off that joins with the Appalachian Trail. Consequently, the Coosa Backcountry Trail can function as a connection from Vogel State Park to the AT, and from the AT to the Duncan Ridge Trail. With this variety of combinations available, you could backpack this area for weeks and not have exhausted all of the possibilities!

name: Great Plains State Park
description: Hiking trails give visitors a chance to explore the park on foot and take in the scenery at a slower pace.

name: Tuzigoot National Monument
description:
Witness the incredible legacy of a people who live in the Verde Valley 1,000 years ago.Set aside a few hours to explore the museum and roam the trails through the Tuzigoot pueblo and Tavasci Marsh. Spend time with a ranger and learn about the Sinagua and the lives they led in the Verde Valley. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Mississippi River State Park
description: Two self-guided trails available.

name: Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway
description: Excellent, vast selection of trails.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 06: Shallowford Bridge to Weaver Creek Rd.
description:
This section of the BMT begins with some road walking along the Toccoa River and Stanley Creek before turning back into singletrack. The BMT eventually joins up with the Stanley Gap Trail for a few miles, and then splits off again and continues on its way along the Tennessee Valley Divide.<br />
<br />
This section is rated "more difficult."

name: Tatum Lead-Pinhoti
description: The majority of these trail is rocky doubletrack that coincides with an ORV trail. Parts of this trail do pass through some gorgeous woodlands, though, and there are excellent views at the Cohutta Overlook nearby!

name: Big Park Loop
description: Big Park Loop features 3 miles of hiking trails near Oak Creek, AZ.

name: Bell Rock Trailway
description: Bell Rock Trailway features 3 miles of hiking trails near Oak Creek, AZ.

name: Petrified Forest National Park
description:
ne of the best ways to enjoy and experience Petrified Forest National Park is on foot. Maintained trails range in length from one-third mile to almost three miles.<br />
<br />
You can also hike in the trail-less Wilderness Area, as a day hike or on an overnight backpacking trip.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Mountaintown Creek Trail
description:
This is a rather steep, challenging hike that follows Mountaintown Creek up to the top of the ridge, crossing it multiple times along the way. Be prepared to get your feet wet!

The creek and trail go through a beautiful area of the forest that is extremely lush and green. The many waterfalls next to the trail are gorgeous and definitely picture-worthy!

name: Appalachian Trail 006: Unicoi Gap to Dicks Creek Gap
description:
Section 6 of the AT begins at Unicoi Gap on GA Hwy 75. It runs 16 miles to Dicks Creek Gap. Along the way, the trail runs past Rocky Mountain, Tray Mountain, Tray Mountain Shelter, Young Lick, Roundtop, Double Spring Mountain, and Deep Gap Shelter.<br />
Best parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Burns Park
description: Burns Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Little Rock, AR.

name: Llama
description: Llama features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Raisin Woods
description: Raisin Woods features 5 miles of hiking trails near Dalton, Ga, GA.

name: Long Branch
description: This is a short loop trail that's an easy hike for the uninitiated or newly initiated.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 04: Skeenah Gap to Wilscot Gap, GA Hwy 60
description:
From Skeenah Gap, the Benton MacKaye runs 5.3 miles along the crest of Wilscot Mountain to another junction with GA Hwy 60. This section is rated "more difficult."<br />
Cool Feature: there's a 270 foot swinging bridge above the Toccoa River along this stretch of trail!

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 05: Wilscot Gap to Shallowford Bridge
description:
The Benton MacKaye follows the Wilscot Mountain Range on this section, and it crosses two peaks: Tipton Mountain and Brawley Mountain. The half-mile of trail leading to (or from, depending on the direction you're hiking) Shallowford Bridge follows a gravel county road. <br />
<br />
This section is rated "more difficult."

name: Templeton/ Baldwin Loop
description: Templeton/ Baldwin Loop features 10 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Red Rock State Park
description: The family-oriented trail system is well marked for your safety and pleasure.

name: Wade Mountain Greenway
description: Wade Mountain Greenway is a 4 mile hiking trail in Huntsville, Alabama.

name: Flat Creek Loop
description: This is a beautiful trail that goes down along the creek, crosses it, and then climbs back up. It's not a tough trail, although some parts are rocky.

name: Green Mountain
description: This is a gorgeous trail winding through the deep forests of the North Georgia mountains. It's a stiff climb from the Deep Gap parking lot up to the top of Green Mountain, and the trail winds gradually down the back side to a beautiful vista on the shores of Lake Blue Ridge.

name: Stanley Gap
description: Stanley Gap is a beautiful trail through the North Georgia mountains. It doesn't lead to any real views, but the forest itself is gorgeous. It's a tough climb up to the high point of this trail.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 07: Weaver/Laurel Cr. Rd. to Bushy Head Gap (rd)
description: This section of trail is rated "easiest," and except for 0.4 miles of it, it is on private property. The BMT Association has this recommendation in regards to this private property: "PLEASE STAY ON THE TRAIL ACROSS PRIVATE PROPERTY. THERE IS AN OVERNIGHT SHELTER ON THE SISSON PROPERTY NEAR INDIAN ROCK LAKE (AT 4.2 MILES SOUTH TO NORTH). IF YOU DO NOT PLAN TO USE THIS SHELTER, PLEASE PLAN YOUR HIKE SO THAT IT CARRIES YOU ACROSS THIS SECTION IN ONE DAY AS THERE IS CURRENTLY NO CAMPING ALLOWED ON THE PRIVATE PROPERTY ALONG THE TRAIL."

name: Bear Creek
description: This is a gorgeous trail that traverses a pristine area of national forest in the Cohutta Mountains. The Bear Creek trail follows the tumbling Bear Creek and also passes the Gennett Poplar, one of the largest poplars alive.

name: Stonewall Falls Loop
description: This is a gorgeous loop through the North Georgia mountains that climbs to the top of several ridge lines and ends at the beautiful Stonewall Falls.

name: White Twister
description: This is a short 4 mile singletrack trail that runs through an old burn area with some great views of the nearby mountains. It also drops down the hillside and runs along the bank of a beautiful mountain stream.

name: Pinhoti Trail - Bear Creek
description: This is a gorgeous hiking trail through the deep forest of the Cohutta Mountains. Some of these trees are huge!

name: Baldwin Loop
description: Baldwin Loop features 2 miles of hiking trails near Oak Creek, AZ.

name: Wheeler Lake
description: Joe Wheeler Resort State Park's most popular hiking is a trail system located between the Day Use Area and the Resort Lodge. This trail network consists of approximately 2.5 miles of trails.

name: Ram's Head Trail
description: RamåÕs Head Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Cloudland Canyon State Park
description: 4 different trails in this State Park. 2 Waterfalls and over 1200 stairs to climb.

name: Andrew Jackson State Park
description: Andrew Jackson State Park offers two, one-mile loop trails.

name: Jackfork Mountain Bike Trail
description: Jackfork Mountain Bike Trail features 7 miles of hiking trails near Little Rock, AR.

name: Pinnacle Mountain State Park
description: The park offers a wide variety of hiking trails including the 1 1/2-mile West Summit Trail, 1 1/2-mile East Summit Trail, 2 1/2-mile Base Trail, 2-mile Rocky Valley Trail, and 1-mile East Quarry Trail. In addition, the park includes two barrier-free trails. These are the 1/2-mile paved Kingfisher Trail and 0.6-mile paved Arkansas Trail in the Arkansas Arboretum. The park serves as the eastern terminus of the 250-mile Ouachita National Recreation Trail which stretches from Pinnacle Mountain State Park to eastern Oklahoma.

name: Broken Arrow / Chicken Point
description: Broken Arrow features 2 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Moccasin Creek State Park
description: Park visitors can tour an adjacent trout rearing station, hike on several nearby trails in the Blue Ridge Mountains or simply relax in this peaceful setting. The park's central location makes it a perfect jumping off spot for exploring area waterfalls, mountain bike trails, shops and restaurants.

name: Herkenham/Ridge Trail Lollipop
description: Herkenham/Ridge Trail Lollipop features 7 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Hemlock Falls Trail
description: Easy hike along Moccasin creek to the falls. Good flow in the creek and seasonal waterfalls along the way. Fun bridge crossing on the way to the falls. Well marked trail.

name: Herkenham Tr
description: Herkenham Tr features 1 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 08: Bushy Head Gap to Dyer Gap
description:
This is one of the longest and most remote sections of the Benton MacKaye Trail in the state of Georgia. According to the BMT Association, it "follows or is closely parallel to the western rim of the Blue Ridge and the Tennessee Valley Divide for the duration of this section." The trail also crosses the top of Flat Top Mountain.<br />
<br />
This section is rated as "most difficult."

name: Girdner
description: Girdner features 5 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Five Points
description: Five Points is a 20 mile hiking trail in Trenton, Georgia.

name: Ridge Trail
description: Ridge Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Oconee Station State Historic Site
description: : The Oconee Connector Trail connects Oconee Station to Oconee State Park. This trail is approximately four miles long and gains or loses 800 feet in elevation.  A 1å_-mile Interpretive Trail circles the four-acre pond and provides access to the half-mile Station Cove Falls Trail in the Sumter National Forest.

name: Southside Park
description: Southside Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Spartanburg, SC.

name: Cebolla Wilderness
description: A popular hiking trail in the wilderness area is the Narrows Rim Trail (BLM). Start from a trailhead located at the southern end of the Narrows Picnic Area, and follow a rock carin trail or the edge of the cliff along the rim of sandstone. The views from the narrows rim are spectacular. Going to the far end a distance of 4 miles will result in excellent views of La Ventana Natural Arch.

name: Munds Wagon Trail
description: Munds Wagon Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Huckaby
description: Huckaby features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 09: Dyer Gap to Watson Gap
description:
At only 4.5 miles long, this is the shortest section of the Benton MacKaye trail in the state of Georgia. The BMT joins up with the South Fork Trail for 1.6 miles, and then leaves it again. <br />
<br />
This section is rated "easiest."

name: Oconee State Park
description: Oconee has six nature/hiking trails originating in the park. The Oconee Trail, Old Waterwheel Trail and Lake Trail are loop trails within park boundaries. The Hidden Falls Trail and Tamassee Knob Trail are out-and-back trails that begin in the park and travel to U.S. Forest Service property. The park is an access point to the Foothills Trail.

name: Chimney Rock Trail
description: Chimney Rock Trail  features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: West Malpais Wilderness
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Palo Duro Canyon State Park
description: Great hiking!

name: Jim Thompson
description: Jim Thompson features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Dawa Loop
description: Dawa Loop features 3 miles of hiking trails near Sedona, AZ.

name: Afton Canyon Natural Area
description:
Hiking and Sightseeing:
Bring your camera and binoculars! Afton Canyon has a diverse landscape of hills, canyons and washes. Multicolored rock walls and changing light conditions make for many photographic opportunities. Washes and stream channels are good hiking trails and excellent for experiencing natural conditions.

name: Croft Passage
description: Croft Passage features 20 miles of hiking trails near Spartanburg, SC.

name: CDT NM20: NM Hwy 117 to the Mt. Taylor Trailhead
description:
Segment 20 of the CDT runs 27.3 miles from NM Hwy 117 to the Mt. Taylor trailhead. Unfortunately, this entire section is routed along roads. <br />
Along the way this segment passes Las Ventanas Ridge, El Malpais lava flows, I-40, Hwy 547, Lobo Canyon Road, and the town of Grants.

name: Lake Wister State Park
description: Hiking trails include a self-guided nature trail and a 6.4-mile hiking trail that takes visitors into the surrounding wilderness to view wildlife such as deer, ducks and rabbits.

name: South Fork
description: The South Fork trail contains the northern terminus of the lengthy Pinhoti trail that stretches from North Georgia into Alabama. Parts of this section of trail are really wide, grassy forest road, and some parts are beautiful singletrack. One section of the trail is very muddy and passes through a few swamps, and it transitions into very rocky terrain with a good dash of roots and mud thrown in. This can be a challenging hike!

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 10: Watson Gap to Double Springs Gap
description:
This 8.5 mile section of the BMT lies almost completely inside the boundary of the Cohutta Wilderness. Combined with section 11 in Tennessee, this area offers 15.7 miles of pure singletrack hiking without crossing a single road. If you are looking for a true wilderness experience in the Southeast, this is it!<br />
<br />
The northernmost end of this section is on the GA/TN line. If hiking south to north, pick up the trail descriptions in Tennessee.<br />
<br />
This section is rated "more difficult."<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Map location given is for the BMT intersection with Jones Cemetery Road.

name: Black Rock Mountain State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Appalachian Trail 007: Dicks Creek Gap to Bly Gap
description:
The final section of the Appalachian Trail in Georgia runs 9 miles from Dicks Creek Gap to Bly Gap, which is roughly on the GA/NC state line. Along the way it passes Little Bald Knob, Buzzard Knob, Plumorchar Shelter, and Rocky Knob.

Best parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

If you are north bound, pick up the trail descriptions in North Carolina. (Or <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/611/Hiking-Trails/Appalachian-Trail-008--Bly-Gap-to-Deep-Gap.html">click here</a>.)

name: Slide Rock State Park
description: The park offers short trails, including a nature trail. It is also very close to Coconino National Forest hiking trails.

name: Colson Canyon Rd
description: Colson Canyon Rd features 50 miles of hiking trails near Santa Maria, CA.

name: Paris Mountain State Park
description: Paris Mountain State Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Greenville, SC.

name: Sumac Creek
description: Sumac Creek features 10 miles of hiking trails near Cisco, GA.

name: Keowee-Toxaway State Park
description: The Raven Rock Hiking Trail is located behind the park office and is a little over four miles in length.  For those who may prefer a shorter hike, the Natural Bridge Nature Trail is a 1å_-mile loop located behind the park office.

name: Piranha Pit
description:
Piranha Pit features 5 miles of hiking trails near Havelock, NC. These trails have plenty of tight singletrack with rocky trails, creek crossings, and fun bridges for hikers to enjoy. There aren't many views, but it's a beautiful walk in the woods.<br />
Be sure to keep an eye out for mountain bikers as this is a popular riding trail as well.

name: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
description:
Chickamauga Battlefield features a 7 mile self-guiding auto tour, monuments, historical tablets, hiking trails and horse trails. The Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center contains exhibits and the Fuller Gun Collection which contains over 300 examples of military long arms.<br />
For groups or individuals wishing to hike certain distances and learn along the way, 45 miles of designated hiking trails are available.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Providence Mountains State Recreation Area
description: A trio of park trails offer an excellent introduction to the Providence Mountains, one of the dominant ranges in the eastern Mojave desert: the NiÌ±a Mora, Crystal Spring, and Mary Beal Trails.

name: Palmetto Trail - Blackstock Battlefield Passage
description:
An idea conceived in 1994, The Palmetto Trail is an ambitious South Carolina project connecting the Atlantic coast with the Blue Ridge mountains. When completed, the trail will cover over 425 continuous miles and run through 14 counties.<br />
290 miles are completed and currently available for public use. <br />
<br />
PALMETTO TRAIL SECTION 14 - BLACKSTOCK BATTLEFIELD PASSAGE: <br />
<br />
4 mile loop path separated by two unfinished sections. Spectacular riverfront hiking and mountain biking along a remote section of the Tyger River. Interpretive historic site. Moderately difficult trail during good conditions.

name: Palo Duro Td
description: Palo Duro Td features 26 miles of hiking trails near Canyon, TX.

name: Devils Fork State Park
description: The Bear Cove Trail, a loop trail that begins and ends between the two picnic shelters, is located in the day-use area. This moderate hiking trail is 2 miles in length and winds through a predominately hardwood forest. The Oconee Bell Nature Trail is an easy 1-mile loop trail that received its name for the rare wildflower that can be found along the footpath.

name: Nimrod Lake
description: Nimrod Lake lies between the Ouachita and Ozark Mountains. This lake is very popular with fisherman and there are also opportunities for hiking, swimming, boating, canoeing, kayaking, fishing and camping.

name: Iron Mountain Loop
description: Iron Mountain Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Cisco, GA.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 11: Double Springs Gap to US Hwy 64
description:
The majority of this section of the Benton MacKaye trail lies in the Big Frog Wilderness. When combined with Section 10 in Georgia, you can hike 15.7 miles of pristine trail without crossing a single road. If you're looking for a true remote wilderness experience in the Southeast, this is it! <br />
<br />
The northern end of this section lies next to the Ocoee River. The southern end lies on the TN/GA line. If hiking north to south, pick up the trail descriptions in Georgia.<br />
<br />
This section is rated "most difficult."

name: Benton MacKaye Trail: Tennessee
description:
The Benton MacKaye Trail runs for 82 miles through the state of Tennessee, from the Georgia border to the North Carolina Border.<br />
If you are looking for detailed information about specific sections of the BMT in TN, please click on the individual trail listings below.

name: Red Clay State Park
description:
Red Clay State Historic Park is located in the extreme southwest corner of Bradley County in Tennessee, just above the Tennessee-Georgia state line.<br />
<br />
The park encompasses 263-acres of narrow valleys formerly used as cotton and pasture land. There are also forested ridges that average 200 feet or more above the valley floor. The site contains a natural landmark, the Blue Hole Spring, which arises from beneath a limestone ledge to form a deep pool that flows into Mill Creek, a tributary of the Conasauga and Coosa River system. The spring was used by the Cherokee for their water supply during council meetings.<br />
Red Clay has a 100-person capacity picnic pavilion and 18 individual picnic tables. The picnic shelter may be reserved up to one year in advance and is equipped with a grill, a water fountain and restrooms.<br />
<br />
Individual picnic tables each have a grill and are available on a first-come, first-served basis<br />
Behind the amphitheatre near the picnic area is an entrance to a 1.7 mile loop trail which goes to the Overlook Tower. The trail is a moderate grade and is well marked. A short nature trail begins at the spring and ends at the farmstead.

name: Appalachian Trail: North Carolina
description: The Appalachian Trail runs 259 miles through the mountains of North Carolina, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/2797/Georgia/Appalachian-Trail--Georgia.html">Georgia</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3325/Tennessee/Appalachian-Trail--Tennessee.html">Tennessee</a> border. If you are looking for detailed information on each section of trail, click on the individual section listings below.

name: Robbers Cave State Park
description: Robbers Cave State Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Wilburton, OK.

name: Mohave & Milltown Railroad Trail
description: The M&M Railroad Trails are intertwined as they follow the route of an historic railroad grade.  Hikers and mountain bikers travel along the actual railroad grade for most of the way, although detours are sometimes necessary where the grade has washed away from flooding.  OHV and equestrian users follow a route which does not lie on the grade, but parallels and frequently crosses the railroad bed.  Both routes are marked with signs and rock cairns to keep visitors on course.

name: Appalachian Trail 008: Bly Gap to Deep Gap
description:
Section 8 of the AT begins at the NC/GA state line and heads north from Bly Gap for 7 miles to Deep Gap. Along the way it passes the Muskrat Creek Shelter.<br />
<br />
Best parking location: <br />
"Deep Gap" lat=35.0395594721, lon=-83.5527102254<br />
<br />
Note: if you are southbound, pick up the rest of the trail descriptions for the AT in Georgia. (Or click here.)

name: Elise Chapin Wildlife Sanctuary
description: Several great trails here at the Wildlife Sanctuary. Area is run by the Chattanooga Audubon Society.

name: Jack Rabbit Trails
description:
This is a beautiful trail along the shores of the lake, and there are a couple of great views from the top of some of the ridges.

Note: This trail was built by and is maintained by mountain bikers. There is significant mountain bike traffic.

name: Arnette Park
description: Arnette Park features 2 miles of hiking trails near Fayetteville, NC within the 100 acre park. Plenty of the park's 100 acres are left in its natural state, making it a perfect place to get out in nature and possibly see some wildlife. The park also includes picnic areas, pavilions, playgrounds, sports areas, and more.

name: Anne Springs Close Greenway
description: Anne Springs Close Greenway features 10 miles of hiking trails near Ft. Mill, SC.

name: Rainbow Basin Natural Area
description: Rainbow Basin has a diverse landscape of hills, canyons and washes. Multicolored rock walls and mesas are accented by changing light conditions, making for many photographic opportunities. The washes are good hiking trails for experiencing the area's natural beauty.

name: Table Rock State Park
description: The extensive trail system carries hikers past streams and waterfalls to the top of Table Rock and Pinnacle mountains. Table Rock is an access point to the foothills trail.

name: Island Creek Trail
description: Island Creek Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Pollocksville, NC. There is a 1/2 mile interpretive trail as well as 2 easy loop trails, all of which are well-marked. These areas are great for an afternoon hike to stretch the legs or just get out in nature. Remember to share the trails with mountain bikers and trail runners.

name: Santa Rosa Lake
description: Great trails in Overlook area.

name: Lake Rim Park Trail
description:
Whether you want to take a stroll on the one-mile border trail through the wetlands to Bone Creek, play a game of soccer with friends, or have a family picnic, Lake Rim Park offers something for everyone. An assortment of outdoor amenities, including picnic areas, horseshoe pits, walking trails, tennis courts, sand volleyball courts, athletic fields, natural areas, a Native American themed garden, and children's playgrounds are here for you to enjoy.<br />
Lake Rim Park Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Fayetteville, NC.

name: Otero Canyon
description: Otero Canyon features 5 miles of hiking trails near Albuquerque, NM.

name: Brush Creek
description: Brush Creek features 7 miles of hiking trails near Ocoee, TN.

name: El Morro National Monument
description:
The Inscription Trail:A must-see! If you only have an hour or less, you will definitely want to take the trail to the pool and past hundreds of Spanish and Anglo inscriptions, as well as pre-historical petroglyphs. This loop trail is paved, 1/2 mile in length, and wheelchair accessible with assistance.<br />
The Headland Trail:This 2-mile loop includes the Inscription Trail, and continues to the top of the bluff. There, you will be rewarded with spectacular views of the Zuni Mountains, the volcanic craters of the El Malpais area, and the El Morro valley.<br />
Atsinna: Another reward for hiking the Headland Trail is the Ancestral Puebloan ruin, Atsinna, or "place of writings on rock". Between approximately 1275 to 1350 AD, up to 1500 people lived in this 875 room pueblo.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 009: Deep Gap to Wallace Gap
description:
This section of the Appalachian trail takes a turn south and makes almost a complete circle around the Standing Indian campground. Shelters along this route include Standing Indian, Carter Gap, Big Spring, and Rock Gap.<br />
Best parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Cape Fear River Trail
description:
The trail is a 10-foot wide paved path for walkers, joggers, bicyclists, and others utilizing non-motorized transportation. It winds for nearly four miles, one- way, through a beautiful blend of trees, plants and wildlife with spectacular views of the river. The terrain can be flat or slightly hilly. In addition to the wooden bridges, including one covered bridge, there is a 700-foot boardwalk through the marsh and wetlands near Clark Park.<br />
Along the trail are interpretive signs explaining the wildlife and plant life found in the area. There are more than 700 species of plants and trees, and 150 species of birds. The River Trail area is also home to an unusual combination and diversity of hardwood trees. Frogs, lizards and turtles are common sights, with an occasional deer.<br />
The trail is designated as part of the East Coast Greenway. The Greenway is a series of urban trails and greenways that will eventually connect from Maine to Key West, Florida, similar to the Appalachian Trail.

name: White Oak Mtn Biology Trails
description: White Oak Mtn Biology Trails features 15 miles of hiking trails near Collegedale, TN.

name: Eufaula Lake
description: Hiking trails at Dam Site South as well as at Arrowhead and Fountainhead State Parks.

name: All American Trail
description:
All American Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Raeford, NC.<br />
Explore North Carolina's Sandhills Region near the perimeter boundary of Fort Bragg, and explore the local terrain that ranges from flat to fairly hilly. Eventually there will be a 1,000 ft boardwalk that crosses Rockfish Creek and the surrounding wetlands.

name: Big Hill Pond State Park
description: Big Hill Pond State Park encompasses 5,000 acres of timberland and hardwood bottom land. Activities here include mountain biking, boating, fishing, hiking, horseback riding and camping.

name: Pickwick Landing State Park
description: Enjoy the Island Loop Trail, which meanders almost 3-miles through a beautiful hardwood forest along the river. More relaxing than strenuous, the trail offers the hiker a glimpse of wildlife and natural wonders of this resort park.

name: Raccoon Mountain Trail Network
description: Over 20 miles of trails ringing the top of Raccoon Mountain. There are some great views of the Tennessee River in the valley below, and some really cool rocks and cliffs to look at along the hike.

name: Colonel Francis Beatty Park
description: Colonel Francis Beatty Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Charlotte, NC. The park encompasses 265 acres with hiking trails as well as recreational fields and courts, horseshoe pits, indoor shelters, picnic shelters, picnic areas, playgrounds, mountain bike trails, and a lake for kayaking, fishing, and canoeing.

name: T.O. Fuller State Park
description: The Park has over 6 miles of hiking trails from moderate to rugged. The Discovery Trail is a 6-mile continuous loop with a number of scenic points of interest including the Chucalissa Indian Village and Wetlands.

name: Dry Falls
description: This is a beautiful waterfall trail right along the side of the road. It's a short path to hike down from the road to the falls. The path then takes you around and directly behind the waterfall.

name: Tanasi Trail System
description: Tanasi Trail System features 30 miles of hiking trails near Ocoee, TN.

name: Tehachapi Mountain Park
description: Hiking, nature awareness on the Nuooah Nature Trail

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 12: US 64 to FS 173 - trestle
description: Section 12 of the Benton MacKaye trail runs 17 miles through the wilds of Tennessee before it reaches civilization again. It does pass Highway 68, McFarland Road, and Lost Creek Road and campground, though.

name: Foothills
description: Foothills features 10 miles of hiking trails near Albuquerque, NM.

name: Gorges State Park
description: Offering rugged terrain that will challenge any outdoors enthusiast, visitors who traverse the steep, backwoods trails will be rewarded with views of dazzling waterfalls or perhaps an encounter with one of the numerous rare species of the park. However, some of the more secluded areas of the park are not recommended for casual hiking.

name: Pismo State Beach
description: With 6 miles of sandy beach noted for such activities as surf-fishing, hiking, and surfing, the park also offers an accessible nature center and one of the largest monarch butterfly over-wintering sights on the West Coast. (805) 489-2684.

name: Enterprise South
description: Enterprise South features 10 miles of hiking trails near Chattanooga, TN.

name: Mcdowell Nature Preserve
description: Mcdowell Nature Preserve provides camping, trails, a playground, fishing pier and amphitheater.

name: Hanging Dog
description: Some steep sections of trail, and a couple of spots with good overlooks, but other sections are not very well maintained. A good sense of direction is crucial, as this place can be hard to navigate.

name: Appalachian Trail 010: Wallace Gap to Wayah Gap
description:
Nearly straight shot north from Wallace Gap to Wayah Gap. The trail passes US Hwy 64 and Siler Bald Shelter along the way.<br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Blue Mountain Lake
description: There are several trails available, including Tower Heights Trail, a 1.5-mile trail at the entrance of the campground. This trail traverses the ridge and affords hikers majestic views of Blue Mountain Lake and Mt. Magazine.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: F
description:
Section F of the PCT runs 84.1 miles from Highway 58 near Tehachapi Pass to Highway 178 at Walker Pass. The Tehachapi Mountains are considered the southernmost section of the Sierras, often referred to as the "Sierran Tail" or the "Sierran Hook." After exiting the Tehachapis, the PCT runs up to the Sierra Crest and follows that for the majority of this section. <br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes Golden Oaks Spring; Hamp Williams Pass; Cottonwood Creek; and Pinyon Mountain.

name: Homolovi State Park
description: With over 300 archaeological sites discovered in the park, hiking its 5 trails is a must.

name: Copperhead Island
description:
Copperhead Island is a beautiful place to get outdoors with access to Lake Wylie, boat ramps, fishing piers, picnic shelters, volleyball courts, horseshoes, primitive camping, and, of course, some walking trails. <br />
These trails are a network of loops that explore the whole island. Paths are flat and often paved, they're perfect for families with small children or people who just want to get out and enjoy the views.

name: Cebolla Wilderness
description: Excellent trails.

name: Booker T. Washington State Park
description: This is a great little hiking trail through the woods that offers some cool views of the Tennessee River.

name: Chilhowee Recreation Area
description: Chilhowee trail system features 20 miles of hiking trails near Ocoee, TN.

name: Clemmer Trail
description: Clemmer Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Ocoee, TN.

name: Son Tay Trail
description: Son Tay Trail is a 3 mile trail conveniently located near downtown Fort Bragg. Hike or take a light jog through the peaceful woods, or just take a leisurely stroll to stretch your leggs.

name: Petit Jean State Park
description: Get information on the more than 20 miles of hiking trails in Arkansas that will guide you to Petit Jean's secrets. Walk to the spectacular 95 foot Cedar Falls, one of the most spectacular waterfalls in Arkansas, meander through amazing geology on the Seven Hollows, or enter Rock House Cave and view ancient pictographs.

name: Big Bend of the Colorado Recreation Area
description: Big Bend of the Colorado Recreation Area is one of Colorado's newest parks. It is located on the shores of the Colorado River, making fishing, boating and swimming very popular activities. Picnicking, hiking and camping are also common in this scenic area. The park offers several amenities including a boat launch, hiking trails, historic sites, RV sites and a nice camping area. The park offers four miles of trails and plenty of undeveloped area to hike and explore.

name: Jones Gap State Park
description: A network of easy to strenuous hiking trails in the Mountain Bridge Recreation Area links Caesars Head and Jones Gap state parks. Registering with the park before using these trails is mandatory. Detailed trail maps are available for sale at the park headquarters.

name: Volcano Trail
description: Volcano Trail features 7 miles of hiking trails near Albuquerque, NM.

name: Wolf River Trail
description: Wolf River Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Memphis, TN.

name: Rio Grande Nature Center State  Park
description: Nature and interpretive trails.

name: Herb Parsons
description: Herb Parsons features 7 miles of hiking trails near Memphis, TN.

name: Sandia Mountains Foothill Trail
description: Elena Gallegos features 12 miles of hiking trails near Albuquerque, NM.

name: Cowpens National Battlefield
description:
The partially paved 1.3 mile trail includes wayside exhibits, the 1856 Washington Light Infantry Monument and the historic Green River Road which was the centerline of the battle. (45 minutes)<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Petroglyph National Monument
description:
Petroglyph National Monument offers several hiking trails to allow for viewing of natural features and a variety of petroglyphs. These trails range in difficulty from easy to moderate.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Tour de Wolf
description: Tour de Wolf features 6 miles of hiking trails near Memphis, TN.

name: Weymouth Woods-Sandhills Nature Preserve
description:
A nature preserve, Weymouth Woods is different from traditional parks. This limited-use area serves to preserve and portray the natural features unique to its region. Weymouth Woods is a place where you can look at the longleaf pine forest and see how human actions have affected the environment, where you can learn about rare and endangered species the red-cockaded woodpecker, the pine barrens tree frog and the bog spicebush.<br />
Observe plant and animal life along more than four miles of well-marked, easy-to-hike trails.

name: Chain of Craters Backcountry Byway
description: The Chain of Craters Backcountry Byway is a 33-mile backcountry byway located in El Malpais National Conservation Area (NCA) and National Monument in northwestern New Mexico. The byway, which is County Road 42, passes almost exclusively through public lands. County Road 42 forms the western boundary of the West Malpais Wilderness and connects NM 53 and NM 117.

name: Kings Mountain State Park
description: The park has several hiking trails. The 16-mile Kings Mountain Hiking Trail, the 1.5-mile Farm Trail and the 1.8-mile Ridgeline Trail. The Ridgeline Trail provides a unique trail experience connecting three parks and two states. The trail connects Kings Mountain State Park, Kings Mountain National Military Park and Crowder's Mountain State Park in North Carolina. The .7-mile Nature Trail at the park provides a leisurely walk.

name: Lions Club
description: Lions Club  features 7 miles of hiking trails near Fayetteville, TN.

name: Tomo-Kahni State Historic Park
description: Docents take visitors on a two to three hour guided walk on the Kawaiisu Trail.

name: Appalachian Trail 011: Wayah Gap to Tellico Gap
description:
The AT runs 13.5 miles north from Wayah Gap, past the Wayah Shelter and the Cold Spring shelter, to Tellico Gap on Otter Creek Road.<br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Edwards Point
description: Edwards Point features 25 miles of hiking trails near Chattanooga, TN.

name: Arrowhead State Park
description: Hiking and biking trails are scattered throughout Arrowhead State Park. The extensive trails in the park are great ways to explore the Oklahoma scenery and take in the natural world, whether on horseback, on foot or on a mountain bike.

name: Village Creek State Park
description: Five park trails totaling seven miles allow hikers the opportunity to explore this forest on their own, or on a guided trail walk with a park interpreter.

name: Mount Magazine State Park
description: Mount Magazine State Park offers some of the best hiking in Arkansas along with a variety of Arkansas outdoor adventure activities. Explore the Arkansas mountain biking trails, hang gliding locations and more! Hikers can take a hike on the Signal Hill Trail, or the Greenfield, Benefield, Mossback Ridge, or Will Apple's Road Trails and explore the many natural and historical resources of the mountain as well as stunning views of Bear Hollow, the Arkansas River Valley and Blue Moutain Lake. Hiking trails vary in length from .5 to 2.8 miles.

name: Dupont State Forest
description: Waterfalls galore, mountains covered in slickrock offering amazing views, rhododendron tunnels and deep forests, what more could you ask for in a hiking destination?

name: Panthertown Valley
description:
Known as the Yosemite of the East, Panthertown Valley is a high-altitude valley (for the east) in the mountains of North Carolina that contains and is ringed by a multitude of massive granite cliffs and majestic mountains.<br />
This is a popular backpacking destination due to the beautiful mountains, amazing views, gorgeous rivers and streams, and the abundance of waterfalls. Panthertown doesn't just have one attraction: it has a true multitude!<br />
The network design of the trail system can make it easy to get lost at times, so bring a map. However, this design makes it a very easy beginners introduction to backpacking, since you are never more than a few miles from your car. Because of the design, you can do a multi-day backpacking expedition, see a significant amount of area, and still end up back at your car right where you started. As a result, the logistics of hiking in Panthertown are much easier (again, beginner friendly) than doing an epic point-to-point hike on something like the Appalachian Trail. <br />
Many of the trails are open to mountain bikes, and some are open to horses.

name: Harrison Bay State Park
description: There are three hiking trails at the park. There is a 4.5 mile trail, a .5 mile trail and 1 mile trail. Trails are open year-round. There is a biking trail available at the marina.

name: Renaissance Park
description:
Renaissance Park has 6.5 miles of trail over 145 acres. There are 2 separate loops, both starting at the parking lot, and connected by a service road. These trails wind throughout the woods, offering hikers a nice little getaway.<br />
Beware of the high amounts of mountain bike traffic in this area, these trails are officially designated mountain bike trails.

name: Foster Falls
description: The hiking trail leads to the gorgeous Foster Falls, as well as several large cliffs that are popular with sport climbers. There are several hike-in camping spots here, as well as several car-camping sites.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 14: Appalachia Powerhouse to Unicoi Gap
description:
Section 14 of the Benton MacKaye trail begins on the southern end near the Hiawassee River downstream from the Appalachia Powerhouse. It runs just under 13 miles on its way to Unicoi Gap, crossing TN Hwy 68 along the way.<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given for the start is the "Narrows" on the Hiawassee River.
