name: Benton MacKaye Trail 13: Trestle to Appalachia Powerhouse
description: From the trestle in Reliance (TN), section 13 of the BMT roughly parallels the Hiawassee River and heads east for 7.3 miles to the Appalachia Powerhouse.

name: CDT NM21: Mt. Taylor Trailhead to FR 239
description:
Segment 21 of the Continental Divide Trail runs 26.4 miles from the Mt. Taylor Trailhead to FR 239. As a nice change of pace, close to 100% of this section is actual trail and not roads.<br />
Along the way the trail passes Mount Taylor, La Mosca Lookout, FS Rd. 453, Rock Tank, George Tank, a couple other FS Roads, Antelope Tank, and Rd. 22.

name: Badger Trail
description: Ascending into the southern end of the Cerbat Mountains, Badger Trail meanders through scenic Mohave Desert vegetation and interesting granitic rock outcroppings. The route gains almost 1,100 feet in elevation over its 3.2 mile length and joins with Castle Rock Trail at the upper terminus. With a consistent 8 percent grade, you will find this route moderately strenuous to hike or bike. At several locations along the trail, you will be treated to spectacular view of the surrounding valleys and mountains. Weather conditions are most comfortable between the months of September and May, although early-morning use during the summer can be pleasant as well.

name: Twin Springs Trailhead
description: Twin Springs Trail is an easy 1.4-mile hike (one way) up a valley on the eastern side of the Black Mountains, following an old vehicle route that has been reclaimed to a single track. The trail ends at a spring which surfaces at a gap in a volcanic dike. Adventurous hikers can continue cross country up the canyon beyond this gap to reach the two namesake springs. You may observe various wildlife species in the area that rely on the water provided at these springs, as well as wild burros and cattle. Use of the trail is most comfortable between the months of September and May, although early-morning hiking during the summer can be pleasant as well.

name: Wabayuma Peak Trail
description: The first two miles of Wabayuma Peak Trail follow an old jeep road into the Wabayuma Peak Wilderness.  At about the two mile mark, you will find yourself in a saddle; a wire fence will be on your left.  Look for the narrow path heading up the slope.  Near the top of the ridge, the trail becomes faint, but blaze marks on large ponderosa pine will serve to guide you to the top.  The trail ends in a saddle 1/2 mile south of the Wabayuma Peak summit; proceed cross-country to reach the peak.  Hikers must return the way they came.  The top of Wabayuma peak offers spectacular views of the Black Mountains to the west, the Aquarius Mountains to the east and of the Hualapai Mountain range to the north and south.

name: Cherum Peak Trail
description: Moderate for hikers; difficult for mountain bikers due to elevation gain; foot access only at the peak.

name: Monolith Gardens
description: Monolith Gardens features 8 miles of hiking trails near Kingman, AZ.

name: Bosque From Alameda
description: Bosque From Alameda features 13 miles of hiking trails near Albuquerque, NM.

name: Campbell Mesa Loops
description: Campbell Mesa Loops features 15 miles of hiking trails near Flagstaff, AZ.

name: Hooker Falls (Waterfall North Carolina)
description: This is a 14 foot waterfall, and was the waterfall used in the movie Last of the Mohicans.  The hike is level and short with great view..

name: Thunderbird Lake Clear Bay
description: Thunderbird Lake Clear Bay features 15 miles of hiking trails near Norman, OK.

name: Arkansas River - Toad Suck Ferry Pool
description: Trails near Old Ferry Landing.

name: Foothills Rim Trail
description: Foothills Rim Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near Kingman, AZ.

name: Crowders Mountain State Park
description: The beauty and diversity of Crowders Mountain State Park are best appreciated on its miles of hiking trails. Hiking trails lined with wildflowers and mountain laurel lead along the ridges and to the summits of Crowders Mountain and Kings Pinnacle. Other trails are easy promenades through pastoral surroundings. Circle the lake on a gravel path or view aquatic plants and animals along a narrow creek. Bring a pair of binoculars and do some bird watching or tote a camera and capture the beauty of wildflowers in bloom.

name: Lower Oldham Loop
description: Lower Oldham Loop features 6 miles of hiking trails near Flagstaff, AZ.

name: Oldham Trail
description: Oldham Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Flagstaff, AZ.

name: Stanky Creek
description: Stanky Creek features 5 miles of hiking trails near Memphis, TN.

name: Tims Ford State Park
description: Tims Ford State Park offers over 27 total miles of trails. There are 6 miles of paved biking/hiking trails that connect all the major areas of the park. A multi-use mountain bike/hiking trail has an out and back total of over 16 miles and runs along the shoreline of Tims Ford Reservoir. The park also offers two foot traffic only dirt trails that total over 5 miles in length. One of these trails includes two suspension bridges and offers spectacular views of the Reservoir.

name: Mount Nebo State Park
description: Fourteen miles of trails encircle Mount Nebo. For mountain biking enthusiasts, the 4 1/2-mile Bench Trail is a fairly level route along a natural terrace that encircles Mount Nebo. As you ride through the mixed hardwood and pine forest, you'll pass historic springs and Fern Lake, and see rock work done by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the early 1930s.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 15: Unicoi Gap to Sandy Gap
description: Section 15 of the BMT runs about 8 miles from Unicoi Gap to Sandy Gap, passing Tate Gap along the way.

name: Lake Thunderbird State Park
description: An array of hiking, mountain biking and nature trails are also available in Lake Thunderbird State Park.

name: Sherman Branch Park Mtb Trail
description:
Sherman Branch Park has an 11 mile loop that runs through the beautiful forest. Although it doesn't offer many views, it's great for a workout or just a day in the woods.<br />
This trail is designated as a mountain bike trail, and it gets a significant amount of bike traffic. Please practice caution.

name: Cliffs of the Neuse State Park
description:
Follow the cliffs' edge for lovely views of the river below. A path bordered by a rail fence leads along the riverbank. Oaks, dogwoods and other trees line the path, often cloaking views of the river with a veil of Spanish moss. Though the cliffs formed over millions of years, irresponsible actions on the part of man could destroy them in no time. To preserve this beautiful formation, climbing on the cliffs is not permitted.

Follow park trails to creeks that were once used to make moonshine and cornmeal. Mill Creek was the home of a gristmill that processed grain while federally-operated whiskey stills were located along Still Creek. Today, the area where these creeks empty into the Neuse River serves as a place to fish and enjoy nature.

Four hiking trails are accessible from the parking lot at the museum. Each is less than a mile in length and offers a closer look into the heart of Cliffs of the Neuse State Park.

name: Hiwassee/Ocoee Scenic River State Park
description: The park has a 1 mile hiking trail loop that goes around the campground and along the Hiwassee River. There are also several hiking trails in the Cherokee National Forest which is adjacent to the State Park Gee Creek campground.

name: Schultz Creek
description: Schultz Creek features 25 miles of hiking trails near Flagstaff, AZ.

name: I.h. Managerial Park
description: I.h. Managerial Park features 4 miles of hiking trails near Memphis, TN.

name: Fort Valley Trail System
description: Fort Valley Trail System features 6 miles of hiking trails near Flagstaff, AZ.

name: Old Post
description: Old Post features 7 miles of hiking trails near Russellville, AR.

name: South Cumberland State Park
description: Hiking may be the most appealing aspect of South Cumberland State Park. The park includes some of the most noted hiking trails in the country including:

name: Villanueva State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Appalachian Trail 012: Tellico Gap to Nantahala River
description:
This section of the AT begins at Tellico Gap and runs 8 miles roughly north to the crossing of the Nantahala River at the Nantahala Outdoor Center (on US Hwy 74). This is a great place to refuel, grab a meal, and buy any gear you might need at the outdoors store.<br />
Along the way the trail passes Wesser Bal Shelter and A. Rufus M shelter.<br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: MontaÌ±a de Oro State Park
description: Montana De Oro features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Luis Obispo, CA.

name: MontaÌ±a de Oro State Park
description: Montana De Oro features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Luis Obispo, CA.

name: MontaÌ±a de Oro State Park
description: Montana De Oro features 15 miles of hiking trails near San Luis Obispo, CA.

name: USNWC
description:
Catawba Mtb Park-US National Whitewater Center features 9 miles of hiking trails near Charlotte, NC. Mountain bike trails have wound through this area since the 90s, and recently the US National Whitewater Center was built there. It's a man-made river where professionals can go practice or beginners can go have fun. <br />
About 9 miles of hiking trails explore this area, making it a great place to go outdoors. Get a good hike in, watch kayakers pull crazy tricks, and watch rafts flip.

name: Fiery Gizzard Trail
description: The Fiery Gizzard trail is said to be one of the best trails in Tennessee, and it is arguably in the top 25 in the country according to Backpacker Magazine. It's a point-to-point hiking trail that offers beautiful views and amazing waterfalls! Interesting legends exist about how this trail got its name--one being that Davy Crockett burned his tongue on a gizzard, another one is that an Indian chief threw a gizzard into a fire to get the attention of Europeans. The trail is part of the South Cumberland Recreation Area and goes through the Grundy Forest State Natural Area. The Fiery Gizzard is a very difficult and strenuous hike and is only meant for experienced hikers/backpackers.

name: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
description:
"It is necessary now and then for a man to go away by himself and experience loneliness; to sit on a rock in the forest and to ask of himself, 'Who am I, and where have I been, and where am I going?'...If one is not careful, one allows diversions to take up one's time-the stuff of life" -Carl Sandburg as quoted from a letter to his friend, Ralph McGill.<br />
Enjoy the solitude of Connemara. Hike its many trails and take from it the energy to avoid diversions.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Tight Rope
description: Tight Rope features 1 miles of hiking trails near Bernalillo, NM.

name: Madonna Mtn: Rock Garden
description: Madonna Mtn: Rock Garden features 5 miles of hiking trails near San Luis Obispo, CA.

name: Reedy Creek Regional Park
description:
Reedy Creek Nature Preserve protects 737 acres of natural, forested habitat within Reedy Creek Park. There are over ten miles of hiking trails in the nature preserve for the outdoor enthusiast, giving visitors the opportunity to explore a variety of terrains, while enjoying scenic views of small lakes, forests, fields, streams, and wildlife. Reedy Creek Nature Preserve is also home to Reedy Creek Nature Center and the Dr. James F. Matthews Center for Biodiversity Studies. One of the most popular routes in the preserve leads to the ruins of the Robinson Rockhouse, built circa 1790.<br />
Mountain bikes are permitted only on pit graveled trails and paved roads within the preserve. Dogs are welcome on preserve trails, but must remain on a 6-foot or shorter leash at all times. All trails are marked with color symbols.

name: Meat Grinder
description: Meat Grinder features 1 miles of hiking trails near Bernalillo, Nm, NM.

name: Bluewater Lake State Park
description: Quarter mile trail for hiking.

name: Sycamore Cove
description:
This trail-essentially a loop-is a nice family hike with a variety of vegetation types and scenery. The trail initially follows Starnes Branch amidst large hemlock trees. After crossing the branch, the trail becomes moderate in difficulty and makes a rather constant climb to a higher and drier sideslope. Take heart, because in a less than a mile the trail levels out, winding in and out of several drainages. <br />
In the fall and winter, there are some nice views, which are more easily enjoyed when hiking in this direction (rather than starting at the eastern trailhead): They include Pilot Mountain, the lush Davidson River valley, and glimpses of the French Broad River valley and Schenck Job Corps Center. The last å_ mile is a fairly steep descent back to US 276. Upon reaching the highway at the trail's eastern trailhead, walk alongside the highway for 200 yards to return to the suspension bridge.

name: Daniel Ridge
description:
Daniel Ridge features 5 miles of hiking trails near Brevard, NC. This beautiful loop trail climbs steeply up a ridge to overlook the Davidson River and the famous Looking Glass Rock.<br />
Don't forget a camera because this hike is a pretty one!

name: Farlow Gap
description:
From Daniel Ridge Trail, this trail starts with a moderate climb as it contours around Fork River Ridge and Daniel Ridge. From there to Farlow Gap, the trail becomes steep with several switchbacks. Though it may be tempting at times, please do not leave the main trail, because shortcutting switchbacks causes erosion. The trail is very strenuous at times, and its tread has tree roots and loose rocks along much of its length. <br />
However, it has great variety in scenery and vegetation. You will cross several streams and three ridges (the crossings of Shuck Ridge Creek and the Right Fork of the Davidson River are difficult). You will also move from a forest of cove hardwoods, such as yellow poplar and red oak, to an upland hardwood forest of oak, black gum and red maple. Small waterfalls, cascades, and an old mica mine near the trail below Farlow Gap are points of interest.

name: Black Mountain
description:
This is a beautiful trail in the mountains of North Carolina! It's pretty easy to access, since the parking lot is right off of the highway.<br />
<br />
It's an arduous hike up to the top of Black Mountain, so be prepared to work for it, and to be at it a while! There are sections of steep, eroded roots and rocks, steep staircases, mud... just about everything you can imagine! There are some great views to be had though, especially when the leaves are off the trees in the winter.

name: Cove Creek Trail
description: The trail starts out on a gravel road, then takes you on a path through the group campground, then next to a small waterfall and onto Cove Creek Falls. You will climb and wind through some thick vegetation to get to the waterfall.

name: Brevard-area Pisgah National Forest
description: Pisgah National Forest, "the land of waterfalls," is one of the wildest places in the Southeast, and it's a hiker's paradise! There are hundreds of miles of gorgeous singletrack trails in the dark depths of Pisgah that lead to gorgeous views, pristine streams, and breath-taking waterfalls. You have to visit Pisgah!

name: North Slope
description:
In early June, there is a beautiful display of Mountain Laurel along this section. Before reaching the crest, the trail again turns left, at its intersection with the North Slope Connector (#359A), which climbs steeply to the Art Loeb Trail. <br />
From this point, the North Slope Trail gradually descends the flank of North Slope Ridge on an old road, before ending at the campground amphitheatre parking lot. Turn right on the campground road and return to the Art Loeb Trailhead. This trail is open seasonally to mountain bikes from October 15 through April 15.

name: Poston Park
description: Poston Park has over 7 miles of hiking and nature trails and 10 miles of mountain bike singletrack. This beautiful park offers other amenities as well, such as shelters, dog parks, and sports fields. Explore their scenic trails that wind under cool tree cover.

name: Lake Dardanelle State Park
description: The main park also includes a trail.

name: Woolly Hollow State Park
description: One trail.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 17: Tellico River Rd. to Beech Gap, Nantahala NF
description: Section 17 of the Benton MacKaye trail runs 12.2 miles and has its northern/eastern end on the TN/NC state line on the Cherohala Skyway. If hiking south to north, pick up the trail descriptions in North Carolina.

name: Tower
description: Tower features 2 miles of hiking trails near San Luis Obispo, CA.

name: Shelby Farms Park Conservancy
description: Excellent hiking--combination of paved and unpaved; multi-use.

name: Fort Chaffee Tank/humvee Trails
description: Fort Chaffee Tank/humvee Trails features 12 miles of hiking trails near Fort Smith, AR.

name: Ojito Wilderness
description: Deep meandering arroyos offer miles of terrain in which to wander. Rock layers in the canyon walls and cliffs enhance sightseeing and photography. Hiking, backpacking, sightseeing and horseback riding, to name a few, can all be enjoyed without a permit in this remote, secluded area.

name: Ignacio Chavez Special Management Area
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Perea Nature Trail
description: Easy one-mile loop hiking trail.

name: Ben Geren Park Trail
description: Ben Geren Park Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near Fort Smith, AR.

name: Jump Off Rock
description:
Legend has it that more than 300 years ago a young Indian maiden leapt from this rock to her death when she learned that her lover, a Cherokee chief, had been killed in battle. Indian lore to this day maintains that on some moonlit nights the ghost of the heartbroken maiden can be seen on the rock. Views from the rock during daylight hours are breathtaking of the valleys below. The rock itself is surrounded by landscaped grounds. <br />
The easy (or blue) trail takes only about 8 minutes and is roughly about 500 feet long. The medium (or yellow) trail usually takes around 15 minutes and is around 1200 feet in distance. <br />
The hard (or red) trail is the hardest one, and despite it being about the same length as the medium trail, it takes a little longer to complete because of its added level of difficulty.

name: Jackson Park Nature Trail
description: Jackson Park is largest county-owned park in Western North Carolina, covering 212 acres. Jackson Park covers 212 acres in Henderson County. The parks' facilities include 4 picnic shelters, 9 baseball fields, multi-purpose fields for soccer and events, 8 tennis courts, playgrounds, and many walking trails, providing a central location for many community sports and activities. The park is home to many species of birds, wildlife, and plants, making the park a great place to observe nature.

name: Los Osos Oaks State Natural Reserve
description: Trails traverse through the variety of plant communities, and the trail is alternately in bright sunlight or dappled shade. A word of caution: one of the predominant undergrowth plants in the area is poison oak. A sign at the entrance helps visitors identify and stay away from this pesky plant. Staying on the trails helps to avoid contact.

name: AEDC
description: Aedc features 14 miles of hiking trails near Tullahoma, TN.

name: Appalachian Trail 013: Nantahala River to Stecoah Gap
description:
This section climbs from the Nantahala Outdoor Center (great place to re-supply and re-fuel yourself) and heads northwest to NC highway 143 (Stecoah Gap). Only one shelter along this section about halfway - Sassafras Gap Shelter.<br />
Recommend parking spot: "NC 143 (Stecoah Gap)" lat=35.3583760086, lon=-83.7178448659

name: Meeman-Shelby Forest State Park
description: Meeman-Shelby Forest offers more than 20 miles of hiking trails that meander throughout the park. The 5-mile paved Bicycle Trail is also accessible to persons with a disability and strollers. Hikers will enjoy the approximately 8-mile, wooded Chickasaw Bluff Trail while easy, shorter jaunts can be enjoyed on the Pioneer Springs Trail and Woodland Trail. The 8-mile Horse Trail is open for horses and hikers. The trail meanders along a bluff with the largest loop overlooking Poplar Tree Lake. Trail maps are available at the visitors center. Please abide by the rules and regulations particular to the trails. Trails are open year round, although some trails located in the Mississippi River bottoms are off limits during managed hunts.

name: Ute Lake State Park
description: Great desert hiking.

name: Dardanelle Lake
description: From Interstate 40, Take exit #81(State Highway #7), Trun left (south) on Highway 7, Travel 5 miles to Highway 7 spur turn right, Travel 3 miles on Highway 7 spur, Arrive at the Russellvile Project Office/Lake Dardanelle Field Office.

name: Golden Eagle Trail
description: Golden Eagle Trail features 7 miles of hiking trails near Barling, AR.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 18: Beech Gap to Farr Gap
description:
Section 13 of the BMT has its southern terminus on the NC/TN state line on the Cherohala Skyway. If you are hiking north to south, please pick up the trail descriptions in Tennessee.<br />
From its start on the state line, the trail runs almost due north for 13 miles to Farr Gap, passing Strawberry Knob, Cherry Log Gap, Chestnut Knob, Glenn Gap, Rockstack, Big Fodderstack, Big Stack Gap, and Little Fodderstack along the way.

name: Morro Bay State Park
description: To Black Hill summit is 3 miles round trip with 600-foot elevation gain.

name: Latta Plantation Nature Preserve
description:
Latta Plantation Nature Center serves as the gateway to the 1,351 acres of Latta Plantation Nature Preserve and has 16 miles of trails offering hikers, nature enthusiasts, and horseback riders the opportunity to explore a variety of terrain while enjoying scenic views of the lake, forests, and streams. It is the only Mecklenburg County property open to horseback riding. <br />
Thirteen (13) miles are designated as horseback and hiking trails and three (3) miles are designated as hiking only. Due to the delicate nature of sharing trails with horses, mountain bikes are permitted only on paved roads within the preserve.

name: Stecoah Gap
description:
There is a 4 mile long (one way) gated gravel that begins at Stecoah Gap and heads up the mountain from there. This gated road offers some incredible views of the Stecoah Valley!

Note: The Appalachian Trail also crosses the highway at Stecoah Gap.

name: Appalachian Trail 014: Secoah Gap to Yellow Creek Gap
description:
This section of trail heads almost directly north to Yellow Creek Gap on County Road 1242. The only shelter along this route is the Brown Fork Gap Shelter.<br />
This trail highlights some beautiful ridge top views and scenic, peaceful woods. Although this trail is moderate there are some short, steep climbs. <br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Joyce Kilmer Slickrock Wilderness
description: This Wilderness area contains one of the largest old growth forest tracts in the eastern US and features miles of hiking trails. Primative camping areas can be found throughout making this a good spot for overnight backpacking trips. Some trails can be steep and narrow with many peaks above 5,000 feet.

name: Chickasaw State Park
description:
Hikers enjoy over 4 miles of easy to moderate hiking trails at the park.
Fern Creek Trail - .8 miles
Forked Pine Trail - .65 miles
Friend's Trail - 1.15 miles
Lakeshore Trail - 1.5 miles

name: Sunset Crater Volcano National Monument
description:
This is a self-guided loop trail. Pick up a trail guide and explore an exciting volcanic landscape at the base of Sunset Crater Volcano.<br />
Note: This trail does not climb the volcano, which is closed to hiking.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Wupatki National Monument
description:
Wupatki Pueblo Trail, located at the Visitor Center, is a self-guided tour of the largest pueblo in the park. Don't miss the blowhole, a fascinating geologic feature. The trail is less than .5 mile (.8km) round trip.<br />
Lomaki Pueblo Trail is an easy .5 mile (.8km) walk to several pueblos.<br />
Wukoki, Citadel, and Nalakihu Pueblos are reached by short .2 mile (.4 km) trails.<br />
Doney Mountain Trail ascends .5 mile (.8 km) from the picnic area to the top of the cinder cone for spectacular views of the surrounding area.<br />
The backcountry of Wupatki is closed to hiking to protect fragile archeological sites. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Lava Flow Trail
description: Lava Flow Trail, in the 34,400-acre Table Top Wilderness, offers a hiking opportunity of light to moderate difficulty in a varied and dramatic Sonoran Desert landscape. Three trailheads are linked by a relatively level 7 1/4-mile trail. From south to north, the trail meanders through dense forests of saguaro, paloverde, ironwood, and cholla; skirts the jumbled basaltic slopes of Black Mountain; traverses an extensive creosote-bush flat; and crosses several large washes. Lava Flow Trail provides sweeping views of Vekol Valley and the Sand Tank Mountains to the west, while flat-topped Table Top Mountain - highest point in the Table Top Wilderness - looms to the east.

name: Morrow Mountain State Park
description:
Morrow Mountain State Park is a great location to view the Uwharrie Mountains. The park is home to the Lake Tillery and the Yadkin/ Pee Dee River. Fishing and boating are popular in this area. Hiking and horse back riding are also common. The park offers rental cabins and camping areas for your overnight enjoyment.

Over 15 miles of hiking trails are available. These trails take you through a nature trail of the woodlands, to the summit of Morrow Mountain and through lush green farmlands.

name: Caliente Mountains
description: The trail head for the Caliente Mountain Access Trail is located on the north side of State Highway 166 just west of the bridge that crosses the Cuyama River (N 35å¡ 6' 35.93", W 119å¡ 51' 9.19" (35.109982,-119.852553)) about 14 miles west of New Cuyama.

name: Chimney Peak Special Recreation Management Area
description: The area offers outstanding opportunities for primitive recreation and experiences of solitude and isolation. Please click on the following links for additional information.  The scenic Chimney Peak Back Country Byway meanders among several Congressionally designated Wilderness areas and, for the more adventurous, the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail bisects the SRMA.

name: Red Rock Canyon State Park
description:
Day Use
Miles of trails meander through the dramatic landscape of the park, and hiking is an intimate way to experience the desert. Use desert safety precautions- bring twice as much water as you think you need, and layered clothing for sudden fluctuations in temperature.

name: Draper
description: Draper features 13 miles of hiking trails near Oklahoma City, OK.

name: Morro Strand State Beach
description: From The Cloisters to Morro Rock is 3.2 miles round trip on Morro Strand Trail.

name: Laurel Mountain Descent
description:
Laurel Mountain Descent features 16 miles of trail near Pisgah Forest, NC. The ascent is a steep climb full of switchbacks and low-lying rhododendron, while still giving you some great views. Reach the top and take in the beautiful mountain top views, and then head back down and loop back to the start. <br />
Watch out for mountain bike traffic.

name: Lake Eufaula State Park
description: On land, Oklahoma's diverse foliage and wildlife can be observed on hiking trails such as the Bluebird Trail.

name: Indian Boundry
description: Indian Boundry features 3 miles of hiking trails near Tellico Plains, TN.

name: Governor's Creek
description:
Governor's Creek features 4 miles of hiking trails near Sanford, NC. <br />
This heavily wooded trail winds through the forest and crosses several streams and gullies. The terrain changes a couple times from a root-filled trail to dirt to sand, and it constantly keeps the hiker on their toes. This trail is multi-use and very popular with mountain bikers so be sure to practice caution.

name: Tsali Thompson Loop
description: This is a beautiful trail through the rhododendron and majestic trees with incredible views of Fontana Lake.

name: Tsali Mouse Branch Loop
description:
Great trail like all of the other Tsali trails, but a little more technical, with more frequent and steeper climbs. Some of the downhills are steeper as well. Also, this has some of the best views in the entire trail system!<br />
<br />
Many excellent views of Fontana Lake!

name: Tsali Left Loop
description: The best loop at Tsali! The trail is right above the water for most of its length, and there is basically zero navigating that needs to be done. Its just one long, beautiful singletrack trail!

name: Tsali Right Loop
description:
Great Tsali Singletrack! More climbing and descending than the left loop. Awesome views at the overlook, although some of the trail up there is pretty overgrown.<br />
<br />
This trail offers great views of Fontana Lake

name: Tsali Recreation Area
description:
The Tsali Trail System contains 4 different trail loops on the shores of the majestic Fontana Lake. All of the trails provide access to the gorgeous forest and viewpoints of the lake.

The trails are:
<a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/198/Hiking-Trails/Tsali-Left-Loop.html">Left Loop</a>
<a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/195/Hiking-Trails/Tsali-Right-Loop.html">Right Loop</a>
<a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/378/Hiking-Trails/Tsali-Mouse-Branch-Loop.html">Mouse Branch</a>
<a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/957/Hiking-Trails/Tsali-Thompson-Loop.html">Thompson Loop</a>

name: Mount Pisgah Trail
description: This is a very steep trail that takes you to the top of Mount Pisgah. It is fairly strenuous. There is a viewing platform at the top and the view is spectacular. On a clear day you can see the neighboring cities of Asheville, Canton, and Waynesville.

name: Red Rock Canyon State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Appalachian Trail 015: Yellow Creek Gap to Fontana Dam
description:
This section of trail runs 8 miles north from Yellow Creek Gap to Fontana Dam (The AT entrance to the Great Smoky Mountain National Park). Along the way it passes Cable Gap Shelter, Fontana Village, NC Hwy 28, and the Fontana Dam Shelter.<br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Chimney Rock State Park - Four Seasons
description: This is one of five different trails in Chimney Rock State Park. It is one of the more advanced out of all of them. It is a 1.2 mile round trip hike rated moderate to  strenuous. This trail starts in the Upper Meadows and leads to the Hickory Nut Falls Trail. It is an uphill climb all the way and goes up a total of 400 feet in elevation all the way to the base of Hickory Nut Falls and to the bottom of Chimney Rock.

name: Chimney Rock State Park - Skyline
description: This is one of five different trails located in Chimney Rock State Park. It is a .7 mile round trip hike rated moderate to strenuous. It starts above the Chimney Rock peak and gives you an overhead view of Lake Lure. You will wind through thick greenery alongside natural cliffs. This trail will take you to landmark points such as Devil's Head,  the Opera Box, and Exclamation Point, the highest peak of the park.

name: Chimney Rock State Park - Great Woodland Adventure
description: This is one of five different trails located in Chimney Rock State Park. It is an easy to moderate .6 mile round trip hike best suited for families with small children. It is interactive and led by Grady the Groundhog, the park mascot, as he teaches the children about the animals living in the park.  It's an easy walk with some uphill sections and some stairs. This will be a lot of fun for the kids.

name: Chimney Rock State Park - Hickory Nut Falls
description: This is one of five different trails located in Chimney Rock State Park. It is 1.5 mile round trip and is rated a moderate hike. There are some uphill sections and some stairs at the base of the falls. On this trail you will trek through the deciduous forest all the way to the bottom of the 404 ft tall  Hickory Nut Falls. You will be able to feel the mist from the waterfall. There are also great views of the ancient cliffs on the way to the Falls.

name: Badin Lake Trail
description: Badin Lake Recreation Area features 6 miles of hiking trails near Troy, NC. Visitors can picnic, swim, fish, or hike, and enjoy the beautiful lake and the surrounding area. Horseback riding and mountain biking are popular here as well, and there are an additional 17 miles of trail for off-roading vehicles.

name: Chimney Rock State Park
description: There are several different trails to hike here at Chimney Rock State Park. Click on the links below to reach the individual listings for the various trails.

name: Chimney Rock State Park - The Outcroppings
description: This trail is one of five to choose from located in Chimney Rock State Park. The Outcroppings trail is about .5 miles long and is rated moderate to strenuous. There is an elevator that goes up to the Chimney Rock level, but there is also a more scenic route of stairs and boardwalks. There are points of interest along the way called, The Rock Pile, Pulpit Rock, and The Moonshiner's Cave. Be sure to check them all out. This trail will take you all the way to the top of Chimney Rock. The elevation is over 2,200 feet and on a clear day, the view is amazing.

name: Cerrillos Hills State Park
description: There are 1,100 years of mining history in these hills which can be seen by hiking, biking, or horseback riding on the 5 miles of trail among rolling juniper savanna.

name: Kern River Parkway & Bakersfield's Bicycle Trails
description: The Kern River Parkway is a native riparian area which extends over 30 miles through Bakersfield along the Kern River.  It extends east to west from the mouth of the Kern Canyon to Enos Lane and is comprised of over 6,000 acres of trails, parks, and waterways.  One of the most used areas is the Kern River Parkway Trail, a paved road used for commuting and exercising by walkers, joggers, rollerbladers, and cyclists.  Also, no motorized vehicles are allowed within the Kern River Parkway - lakes, trails, and off-road.

name: Athens Regional Park Trail
description: Athens Regional Park Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Athens, TN.

name: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks
description:
he Sequoia and Kings Canyon Wilderness encompasses hundreds of thousands of acres of pristine High Sierra country and forms the backbone of these two parks. Select from the information below for more information on how to enjoy and protect the parks' wilderness.The parks also contain 5 day hikes that allow visitors to see truly amazing scenery.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 016: Fontana Dam to Newfound Gap
description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail traverses half of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and includes stops at Fontana Dam, Millies Ridge, Russell Field, Spence Field, Derrick Knob, Silers Bald, Double Spring Gap, and Mt. Collins shelters. Be sure to check on permits before planning a hike through Smoky Mountains NP - shelter reservations book early!<br />
<br />
This section runs between Fontana Dam (near NC 28) and Newfound Gap (US 441).<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spots:<br />
See Google Map to the right<br />
"US 441 (Newfound Gap)" lat=35.6110766333, lon=-83.4248355122

name: Raven Rock State Park
description:
Raven Rock is one of our most underrated state parks. The views from the overlook (above) on the Raven Rock Loop Trail are some of the finest in the Piedmont. The topography is diverse, highlighted by the 152 ft. high outcropping of crystalline rock that gives the park its name. <br />
The park is located on the ""fall line"", where the river literally falls and produces the best rapids in the eastern piedmont. At this geological transition zone, the hilly landscape and resistant rocks of the Piedmont give way to the flat terrain and softer rocks of the coastal plain. Walk to a section of the river known as ""Fish Traps "" to see the fall line for yourself.<br />
The park's bluffs and ravines sprout mountain laurel and rhododendron, species not usually found this far east. Raven Rock is also noted for its early spring display of wildflowers such as Dutchman's breeches, bloodroot, saxifrage, and bellworts.<br />
Don't be turned off by the burned areas near the park's entrance. This is a fire-adapted ecosystem, and the recent burn was designed to mimic the natural fire disturbances that were common in this area prior to European settlement.<br />
The park offers family, group, and canoe camping , as well as hiking, fishing, and horseback riding.<br />
For more information, visit the park's official website or call (910) 893-4888.<br />
Size: 3950 acres in 2002.

name: Waterrock Knob
description:
This trail starts by pulling off the Blue Ridge Parkway into a visitor center where you can park and begin hiking. It is a key place to hike and one of the highest altitudes in the Smoky Mountains.<br />
The steep climb gains 412ft in elevation, but it's totally worth it with stunning mountain top views of Maggie Valley below. There are places to rest and overlooks along the way.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 19: Stiffknee Tr, Farr Gap to Deals Gap
description: Section 19 of the Benton MacKaye Trail mostly follows the Stiffknee Trail. Section 19 ends at Deals Gap on Hwy 129.

name: John Paul Hammerschmidt Lake
description: John Paul Hammerschmidt Lake extends 26 miles along the Arkansas River, about half in Arkansas and half in Oklahoma. The shoreline offers a variety of terrain that includes bottomland hardwood timber banks, steep bluffs, open agricultural fields, and urban developments. Outdoor recreational opportunities exists at four parks. Modern park amenities include boat launching ramps, drinking water, camp sites, picnic sites, playgrounds, and trails.

name: Ozark Lake
description: Interpretive trails in Reed Mountain area.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 20: Deals Gap to Eagle Creek Trail
description: Section 20 begins with 3.6 miles of walking along a paved road (NC Hwy 28) on the way to the Great Smoky Mountain National Park. (If you're hiking south to north.) At Twenty Mile Ranger Station, the BMT turns into the park and follows a National Park Road for a ways before it finally turns back into a trail.

name: Spadra Creek Nature Trail
description: Spadra Creek Nature Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Clarksville, AR.

name: Goose Creek State Park
description: Eight miles of hiking trails meander through the estuarine areas of Goose Creek State Park. The diversity of wetlands ranges from freshwater and brackish-water marshes to black gum and cypress swamps. Large stands of pine and mixed forest provide cover for a variety of birds and land animals.

name: Galisteo Basin Preserve
description: Galisteo Basin Preserve features 5 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: San-lee Park
description:
San-Lee Park is a 177 acre park, that offers hiking trails, a mountain bike trail, a Nature Center, playground, picnic facilities, campgrounds and two stocked lakes for fishing. <br />
Approximately 4 miles of hiking trails offer a true nature experience at San-Lee Park. The trails wind along the two lakes and through the woods, offering great fishing spots, access to an array of wildflowers, and many great views. The Nature Trails are open year round during park operational hours at no cost.<br />
There are also extensive mountain bike trails here as well.

name: Lee Creek Reservoir Trail
description: Lee Creek Reservoir Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Van Buren, AR.

name: Fisher Farm Park
description:
Fisher Farm consists of a 200-acre park which is in the early stages of development.<br />
A fabulous place for walkers, this is a natural area populated with a variety of wildlife, insects, and plant life.<br />
Fisher Farm offers four miles of trails for all levels of hikers. The park is now accessible from the north by the West Branch Greenway.

name: Old Stone Fort State Archaeological Park
description: The trail around the perimeter of the ancient, 2,000 year old enclosure is 1-1/4 miles in length and is a great way to learn about this historic area. It covers the most dramatic scenery in the park including several waterfalls. The three largest falls - Step Falls, Blue Hole Falls, and Big Falls - run along the trail. There are 2 miles of foot trails beyond the main interpretive trail.

name: Bent Creek
description:
Bent Creek features 30 miles of hiking trails near Asheville, NC. The trails are located in the northern tip of the Pisgah Ranger District of the Pisgah National Forest and some connect with the Mountains to Sea/Shut In Trail. Trails are varied and are great for beginners and families as well as advanced hikers. <br />
There are plenty of easy loop trails around Lake Powhatan as well as more advanced trails that climb the surrounding mountains.

name: Pinson Mounds State Archaeological Park
description: The park offers six-miles of trails including a nature trail and a boardwalk with a stop overlooking the Forked Deer River which borders the park.

name: Trona Pinnacles
description:
Description
The Trona Pinnacles are some of the most unique geological features in the California Desert Conservation Area. The unusual landscape consists of more than 500 tufa spires, some as high as 140 feet, rising from the bed of the Searles Dry Lake basin. The pinnacles vary in size and shape from short and squat to tall and thin, and are composed primarily of calcium carbonate (tufa). The Trona Pinnacles have been featured in many commercials, films, and still-photo shoots.

name: Blue Ridge Parkway
description:
The Parkway offers 100 trails ranging from short "leg-stretcher" walks to the Appalachian Trail. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: High Desert Trail System
description: High Desert Trail System features 23 miles of hiking trails near Gallup, NM.

name: Greers Ferry Lake
description: Greers Ferry Dam stands at the foot of beautiful Round Mountain in the Ozark Mountains of north-central Arkansas. Numerous parks offer modern camping and recreational opportunities. Marinas provide rental services, food and other supplies and services. Lake fishing is good throughout the year. A trout hatchery furnishes trout for the Little Red River flowing out of the dam. Hiking trails give visitors a beautiful natural view of the lake and its surroundings. Activities on and around Greers Ferry Lake will keep anyone busy.

name: Meriwether Lewis Loop Trail
description: A wonderfully scenic trail just off historic Natchez Trace in Tennessee. It is an easy to moderate skill level course. It begins at Grinder's Stand, the burial site of Meriwether Lewis. Then you can follow it along down to the Little Swan Creek. It isn't too much of a challenge, but the scenery is definitely worth it!

name: Arkansas River - Webbers Falls Pool
description: The Webbers Falls area attracts many visitors during the early spring when the many flowering trees and shrubs such as redbud and dogwood are in bloom and again in the fall when the many hardwood trees are changing their colors. An observation platform and visitors facilities have been provided at Webbers Falls Lock and Dam so that visitors may watch the lockage of barges and pleasure craft. On a bluff above the powerhouse is a scenic overlook where visitors may view the lock and dam and a large area of the lake Sportspeople will find recreation opportunities at Webbers Falls Lake the year around. For the fisherman the predominate species of fish in the lake are catfish, white bass, black bass, crappie, bream, walleye, sauger, buffalo, carp and a rapidly growing population of striped bass. Many have predicted that the striped bass will reach weights in excess of forty pounds in Oklahoma waters. Opportunities are equally as good for the hunting enthusiast. Principal game species present at the project include whitetail deer, fox squirrel, gray squirrel, cottontail rabbit, swamp rabbit, raccoon, mink, opossum, bobwhite quail, mourning dove, and several species of waterfowl. There are three recreation areas on the lake that offer many opportunities for water oriented activities. The facilities at these areas include designated campsites, picnic areas, boat launching ramps, drinking water, swimming beaches, and sanitary facilities.

name: Stinchcomb East
description: Stinchcomb East features 2 miles of hiking trails near Bethany, OK.

name: CDT NM23: FR 239A to Cerro Colorado
description:
Finally, back on the trail! After a long segment of forest service road, segment 23 of the CDT is almost all trail! There are two very small road segments, but they are minute in the great scheme of things. <br />
Segment 23 runs 29.8 miles from FR 239A to Cerro Colorado. Along the way it passes Cerro Parido, Cerro Pelon, the Ignacio Chavez Wilderness Area, Guadalupe Rd., and the Empedrado Wilderness Study Area.

name: Fred Young
description: Fred Young features 7 miles of hiking trails near Jackson, TN.

name: Lake Poinsett State Park
description: For hiking enthusiasts, the 1.1-mile Great Blue Heron Trail can be enjoyed in a leisurely 45-minute hike.

name: Foss State Park
description: Foss State Park has an equestrian camp with a multi-purpose trail for horseback riding, hiking and mountain biking.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 23: Noland Divide Tr Jct. to Smokemont CG
description:
The 23rd section of the Benton MacKaye Trail runs 16.4 miles through the rugged wilderness of the Great Smoky Mountain National Park between the Noland Divide Trail Junction and the Smokemont Campground.<br />
<br />
Note: The Google Maps location given for this trail is actually the northern end of this section of the BMT, not the southern end.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 24: Smokemont CG to Straight Fork Rd.
description: The 24th section of the Benton MacKaye Trail runs 15 miles between the Smokemont Campground and Straight Fork Road through the rugged Great Smoky Mountain National Park.

name: Mountains to Sea Trail
description: The Mountain to Sea Trail is a long distance trail running east-west across the state of North Carolina. The trail is planned to be 1000 miles long, but currently only about half of that length (500 miles) has been completed. It is possible to connect the completed sections with forest roads, paved roads, and other trails, however.

name: South Mountains State Park
description: Choose from a variety of marked hiking trails. The most popular trail, High Shoals Falls Loop Trail, travels one mile along the Jacob Fork River to the base of High Shoals Falls, a beautiful crystal-clear waterfall. The trail then continues to the top of the falls before looping around and returning to the picnic area. The terrain can be rugged, so be observant of the trail and wear sturdy shoes.

name: Fort Loudoun State Park
description: There are connecting trails at the park. They may be hiked separately or together. Combined they cover approximately 5 miles. These trails are not difficult at a reasonable pace and they offer many opportunities for wildlife viewing. Hiking for the less adventuresome can be provided through the use of asphalt trails meandering through the picnic areas.

name: Bluff Creek Trail
description: Bluff Creek Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Oklahoma City, OK.

name: Clingman's Dome
description: Clingman's Dome is a .5 mile steep trek up a paved trail to an elevation of 6,643 ft. This is the highest point in the entire Great Smoky Mountains National Park. It is a very popular spot within the park. At the summit there is a 54 ft observation tower taking you above the coniferous rainforest. On a clear day there is a 360 degree view of the park and the seven surrounding states.

name: Hearst San Simeon State Park
description: The path tours the eastern fringe of the seasonal wetland and soon reaches a boardwalk that leads across it from one viewing area to another. Beyond the boardwalk the trail junctions. The right fork leads southwest 0.2 mile to the Moonstone Gardens restaurant and Highway 1. Along this side trail, Eagle-eyed hikers might get a glimpse of Hearst Castle located &#64257;ve miles north.

name: Henry Horton State Park
description: There are three easy-rated hiking trails at Henry Horton. The Hickory Ridge Loop is located near the campground and traverses habitats ranging from oak-hickory forest to unusual cedar glades. The Wilhoite Mill Trail follows the Duck River among second growth woods covering an early mill community. The Turkey Trail winds through rich woods and old fields.

name: Cades Cove
description: Cades Cove features 11 miles of hiking trails near Maryville, TN.

name: Smoky Mountains National Park
description: Miles and miles of trails from mild to wild. The Appalachian Trail runs through the park and can be linked up with park trails to create the perfect loop. Note: shelters along the AT may require advanced reservations - book ahead!

name: Appalachian Trail 017: Newfound Gap to Davenport Gap
description:
This is the second major section of Appalachian Trail inside Smoky Mountains National Park. Shelters along this route include Icewater Spring, Kephart, Pecks Corner, Tricorner Knob, Cosby Knob, and Davenport Gap shelters. Shelter spots along this route may need to be reserved in advance.<br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Okmulgee State Park
description: A 3 1/2 mile hiking trail, part of which is ADA accessible, attracts nature lovers to the park.

name: Kitsuma
description: Kitsuma features 10 miles of hiking trails near Black Mountain, NC. Hike up switchbacks through the scenic Pisgah National Forest and be ready for a workout. The ascent to the ridge is a tough one, but the views are worth it, and the descent down the Blue Ridge is a little easier. Be careful of steep dropoffs near the trail, and keep an eye out for mountain bikers as well.

name: Fossil Fails
description: Nice hikes in the area.

name: Oklahoma "ankle Express" Hiking Trail - Greenleaf State Park
description: Oklahoma "ankle Express" Hiking Trail - Greenleaf State Park features 18 miles of hiking trails near Braggs, OK.

name: Santa Fe Rail Trail
description: Santa Fe Rail Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: Tenkiller State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Jacksonport State Park
description: The Tunstall Riverwalk Trail allows visitors to stroll alongside the river.

name: Old Toll Road
description: Old Toll Road features 22 miles of hiking trails near Montreat, NC. This network of trails is made up of mostly doubletrack and singletrack. The climbs here are long and rocky, and there are no switchbacks.

name: Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument
description:
You can enjoy the scenery, take a tour of Alibates, go on a hike, or just sit and view wildlife. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Cochiti Lake
description: Excellent trails in Cochiti Recreation Area.

name: Arcadia Laketrails
description: Arcadia Laketrails features 7 miles of hiking trails near Edmond, OK.

name: Pacific Crest National Recreation Trail, Owens Peak Segment
description: The trail north of Walker Pass provides great views; first west to the Kern River Valley and then east into the desert.  During the spring and summer you will find a variety of wildflowers.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: G
description:
Section G of the PCT runs 113.5 miles from Walker Pass on Highway 178 to Mt. Whitney. This section of trail ends at Mt. Whitney, which stands 14,491 feet high and is the highest point in the lower 48. The area around Whitney is all wilderness: this section of the route is very, very wild! Other important features include the South kern River and the Monache Meadows (which is the largest meadow in the Sierras).<br />
<br />
After leaving the town of Onyx, the trail passes Morris/Jenkins saddle; Jenkins/Ownes saddle; Joshua Tree Spring; Spanish Needle Creek; Canebrake Road; Fox Mill Spring; Spur ridge camp; Manter Creek; South Fork Kern River; Inyokern, CA; Kennedy Meadows Campground; Beck Meadows Trail 35E01; Deer Mountain's northern ridge; Monache meadows; Olancha Pass Trail; Death Canyon Creek; Diaz Creek; Mulkey Pass; Trail Pass Trail; Lone Pine, CA; Cottonwood Pass; Sequoia National Park; Siberian Pass/Rock Creek Trail; Rock Creek; Guyot Creek; Crabtree Meadow; and the John Muir Trail.

name: Chickasaw Trace
description: Chickasaw Trace features 8 miles of hiking trails near Columbia, TN.

name: Lake Norman State Park
description:
At Lake Norman State Park, fun is just a matter of scale. On one hand, there's the largest manmade lake in the state, Lake Norman. When filled to capacity, its surface area is 32,510 acres with a shoreline of 520 miles and a main channel 34 miles in length, thus its nickname, the "Inland Sea." Thirteen miles of the shoreline are in the state park, which provides boating access.<br />
On another hand, the park boasts its own 33-acre lake where fishing and boating are enjoyed. And with hiking and biking trails, picnic areas, interpretive programs and campgrounds, there's more to Lake Norman State Park than merely water.<br />
Lake Norman State Park features 13 miles of hiking trails near Troutman / Charlotte, NC.

name: Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument
description: The most fascinating rock formations from ancient volcanic ash... "moonscape" or "smurf land" There is a $5 per car charge and well worth it. The road to the Tent Rocks in paved and has a bathroom facility and picnic areas with tables and some with shelter.

name: Atalaya Mountain (174)
description: Atalaya Mountain (174) features 7 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: Tenkiller Ferry Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout area.

name: Dale Ball
description: Dale Ball features 30 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: Mousetail State Park
description: Mousetail State Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Linden, Tn, TN.

name: Bicycle Post Trails
description:
Bicycle Post Trails features a 10 mile loop trail near Greenville, NC. This loop is mainly meant for mountain bikers, but it's a great trail for hikers as well. The path features some great climbs and descents, as well as log crossings and creek crossings. <br />
Enjoy your beautiful surroundings are stay awhile near some of the trail's trick sections to enjoy some mountain biking talent. Remember that this is a multi-use trail so please be courteous.

name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
description:
Hikers enjoy the Smoky Mountains during all months of the year with every season offering is own special rewards. During winter, the absence of deciduous leaves opens new vistas along trails and reveals stone walls, chimneys, foundations, and other reminders of past residents. Spring provides a weekly parade of wildflowers and flowering trees. In summer, walkers can seek out cool retreats among the spruce-fir forests and balds or follow splashy mountain streams to roaring falls and cascades. Autumn hikers have crisp, dry air to sharpen their senses and a varied palette of fall colors to enjoy.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Santa Cruz Lake Recreation Area
description: The Santa Cruz Lake trail system includes 6.4 miles of trail. The trails are moderate to difficult. Please bring water and wear sturdy shoes for hiking. Trails include La Caja, Laguna Vista, and the Debris Basin Trail.

name: Lake Fort Smith State Park
description: For backpackers, the park serves as the western terminus of the 165-mile Ozark Highlands National Recreation Trail.

name: Mountain to Sea Trail (Craggy Gardens)
description: Out and back trail offers a spectacular views of the Craggy Gardens area with a total elevation gain of only 200 feet. Trail head located at Craggy Gardens Visitor Center on the left.

name: Craggy Pinnacle Trail
description:
This short out-and-back trail takes hikers up some fairly steep climbs through beautiful high-elevation forest and blooming rhododendron. The climb is completely worth it once you reach the top where you can take in stunning 360 degree views of the surrounding area and the Blue Ridge Parkway. <br />
This is a popular trail, so you won't be alone, but it's popular for a reason!

name: Medio Dia Loop
description: Medio Dia Loop features 16 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, Nm, NM.

name: B. Everett Jordan Lake
description: B. E. Jordan Dam and Lake is located near the center of North Carolina with a large population base in a 75-mile radius of the project. It is a major attraction for recreation seekers with facilities such as campsites, picnic areas, beaches, nature trails, etc. available.

name: Yates Mill County Park
description: A day at Historic Yates Mill County Park offers visitors an "Escape from the Daily Grind," with experiences that interpret and preserve our agricultural heritage, environmental resources and history through educational programs, events and exhibits. The park is a 174-acre wildlife refuge and an environmental research center.

name: La Tierra
description: La Tierra features 15 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: Lower Douglas Falls Trail
description: This trail (lower part only) is an amazing trail for the family. The walk is easy with only a 240 elevation difference with a round trip distance of 1 mile. Douglas falls has a breathtaking cascade of 60 feet with all kinds of rocks to look for salamanders!

name: Lake James State Park
description:
Taking a hike on the extensive trail system at Lake James State Park is a great way to enjoy the outdoors at your own pace. A walk in the spring when the air is scented with sweet wild azalea and rhododendron blossoms or a stroll in the fall when the leaves are ablaze in colors is tonic for the soul.<br />
There are hiking trails at both Catawba River and Paddy's Creek areas to satisfy all ages and thirsts for adventure; from the .75-mile Holly Discovery Trail, to the historically significant, 1-mile section of the Overmountain Victory Trail, to the scenic vista at the end of the Lake Channel Overlook Trail, there's something for everyone here.

name: Hyde Memorial State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Crowder District Park
description: Great hiking trails.

name: Natchez Trace State Park
description: 13.5 miles of hiking trails, ranging from 1/2 mile up to 4 1/2 miles, meander through the forest and fields and along the lakeshores and streams of Natchez Park. Contact the park for more information. Overnight camping is allowed on backpacking trails only. The backpacking trail is 40 miles. A Backcountry camping permit is required.

name: Jordan Lake State Recreation Area
description: There are numerous hiking trails at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area. All are easy walking and suitable for trekkers of all ages, although the New Hope Trail is more strenuous than others. Pets must be leashed at all times and bicycles are not permitted on any trails at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area.

name: Horse Thief Camp
description:
Horse Thief Camp is located 23 miles north of I-15 on Excelsior Mine Road (use the Cima Road Exit), is nestled between the Kingston Range, North Mesquite Mountain and Pahrump Valley Wilderness Areas. This secluded primitive camp offers dramatic view of the surrounding landscape and is an ideal base camp for exploring the local area.
Bring your camera and binoculars! The Area has a diverse landscape of hills, canyons and washes. Multicolored rock walls and changing light conditions make for many photographic opportunities. Washes and stream channels are good hiking trails and excellent for experiencing natural conditions.

name: CDT NM24: Cerro Colorado to Los Pinos Trailhead
description:
Segment 24 of the CDT runs 35.5 miles from Cerro Colorado to the Los Pinos Trailhead. This segment is about 50% trail, 50% road.<br />
Along the way this segment passes La Ventana Mesa, Mesa Portales, Mesa De Cuba, NM Hwy 197, US Hwy 550, the town of Cuba, NM Hwy 126, and Los Pinos County Rd.

name: Old Mount Mitchell Trail
description:
Trail Blaze: Yellow Circles<br />
Difficulty: Difficult, Steep<br />
This short trail is a steep climb up but gives you a feel for the true beauty of Mt. Mitchell.

name: Commissary Trail
description:
Trail number:<br />
Trail Blaze: Orange Diamonds <br />
Difficulty: Easy to moderate <br />
Trail follows an old railroad grade and offers spectacular views of the Black Mountains.

name: Mountains to Sea Trail (Trail #440) Balsam Gap - NC 128
description: Trail follows the ridge with breathtaking views.

name: Setrock Creek Falls (Trail #197)
description:
Beautiful waterfall that is easy for the whole family, located in at the Black Mountain Campground. <br />
This very short trail leads to a stunning waterfall that often runs low, and when it does it splits into multiple cascades that come down in three main sections.

name: Green Knob Trail (Trail # 182)
description:
This trail follows a ridge line to the Green Knob Lookout Tower at 5,090 feet. The trail is very steep and gets rocky so some minor scrambling is required. The trail provides amazing views of this beautiful mountainous region. After 2.8 miles the trail reaches the Green Knob Lookout Tower on the right side. From the tower the trail descends for 0.5 mile with switchbacks to the Blue Ridge Parkway.<br />
The trail follows a white blaze.

name: Mt. Mitchell Trail (Trail 190)
description:
Strenuous Trail that Starts at Black Mountain Campground at the foot of Mt. Mitchell (Located off of Highway 80 S.) and ends at Mount Mitchell State Park. <br />
The trail climbs from 3200 with in the 5.6 miles and offers amazing views.

name: Pisgah National Forest: Burnsville
description: Pisgah National Forest, "the land of waterfalls," is one of the wildest places in the Southeast, and it's a hiker's paradise! There are hundreds of miles of gorgeous singletrack trails in the dark depths of Pisgah that lead to gorgeous views, pristine streams, and breath-taking waterfalls. You have to visit Pisgah!

name: River Loop Trail (Trail #  200)
description:
Blaze: Yellow<br />
This easy trail starts at the Black Mountain Campground and goes around the Briar Bottom Group Camp. It offers views of the South Toe River with little to no elevation change.

name: Devil's Den Nature Loop (Trail #192)
description:
Blaze: Yellow<br />
This easy hike is a great family hike or quick stroll. Summer Ranger programs usually occur around this area. The trail begins in the Black Mountain Campground near the amphitheater. You'll cross a wooden bridge and get a glimpse at some magnificent boulders.

name: Higgins Bald Ground (Trail #190A)
description:
Blaze: Yellow<br />
This is a spur of the Mt. Mitchell Trail. It branches off to the left and brings hikers past some old cabin foundations, and then it reconnects with Mt. Mitchell after about a mile.

name: Camp Alice Trail
description:
Trail Number:<br />
Trail Blaze: Blue Squares<br />
This trail is difficult and connects Commissary Trail and the Old Mount Mitchel Trail. The Mountains to Sea trail takes this route.

name: Walker Falls
description:
Easy hike, along road, great stop to Douglas Falls.<br />
Walker Falls is a multi-cascade waterfall that can be pretty impressive in high water.

name: Mount Mitchell State Park
description:
Mount Mitchell State Park is closed.

Choose between a short stroll or a more extensive hike into the woods. Either choice will be rewarding as the beauty of the park is best seen from one of its many trails. Hikers should wear appropriate clothing and carry proper gear as the high altitude makes the climate of Mount Mitchell chilly, even in summer. Severe storms above 6,000 feet are unpredictable and can be life-threatening. Fog and winds can impede search-and-rescue crew and helicopter access. Hike and camp in the back country at your own risk.

name: Cherokee Landing State Park
description: Located in the Cookson Hills, just south of Tahlequah on Lake Tenkiller, Cherokee Landing State Park  features RV hookups with 30/50 amp electric and water, a dump station, primitive campsites, covered picnic shelters and restrooms with hot showers. RV sites can accommodate rigs up to 40-feet in length.

name: Balsam Nature Trail
description:
Trail Blaze: White Triangles<br />
This easy trail provides viewers with a self guided nature trail that provides you with information on the local flora and fauna. Start by walking up the summit trail then make a left turn on to the Mountains to Sea trail which will take you through a Douglas fir forest. make another left (following signs)at the next intersection to continue back to the parking area. Near the end of the trail is a Spur that takes you to the highest spring east of the Mississippi.

name: Black Mountain Crest Trail (Trail #179)
description:
Blaze: Orange Triangles<br />
This trail is one of hardest trails in the Eastern US due to its 3300ft altitude gain. <br />
Starting from Mt. Mitchell (6684') the trail is well maintained and crosses several summits including, Mt. Craig, Big Tom (6526'), Balsam cone (6600'), Cattail Peak (6600') and Potato Hill (6440') then descends to Deep Gap (5760). Deep Gap is the first camping site allowed from Mt. Mitchell (Shelter no longer exists!!! It has been gone for at least 15 years now) and also intersects with the Colbert's Ridge Trail. From Deep gap the trail is not as well maintained due to fewer people traveling on this section and continues to Winter Star Mountain (6203') and Mount Gibbs (6220). From Mount Gibs the trail follows an old toll road to Bowlings Creek and follows the creek to the Bowlings Creek Road Trail head.

name: Roaring Fork Falls (Trail #195)
description: The Trail follows an old Forest Service Road (FR 5520). Along the trail there is a concrete storage building that is believed to have held dynamite during the creation of the road. Continue straight (keep left) at the intersection with another old road. When the trail/FR5520 makes a hairpin turn over a stream look for a wood boardwalk and trail straight ahead that will lead to the falls. Continue 100 yards to the trails end at the base of the large falls. 0.7 miles one way, 1.4 round trip. Great family hike with less than 200 elevation change

name: Devil's Den State Park
description: Take a wet-water hike up Lee Creek, or trek the 15-mile Butterfield Hiking Trail. This trail from the park through the Ozark National Forest leads backpackers deep into the hills and hollows of the rugged scenic Ozarks.

name: Oakview County Park
description:
Historic Oak View County Park is a 19th-century historic farmstead with a mission to interpret North Carolina's agricultural heritage and rural history via educational programs, special events and exhibits. <br />
There is a self-guided tour that takes visitors around the local heritage sites. Perfect for families, this walk is very easy and has a relatively flat terrain.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail: North Carolina
description: The Benton MacKaye Trail runs 124 miles through the state of North Carolina, from the Tennessee border to its northern terminus at Davenport Gap. (Google Maps location given is for Davenport Gap). To get additional information about the individual sections of the BMT in NC, please click on the links to the individual listings below.

name: Benton MacKaye Trail 25: Straight Fork Rd. to Davenport Gap
description:
The 25th and final section of the Benton MacKaye Trail runs the last 18 miles of its total 288 from Straight Fork Rd. to its northern terminus at Davenport Gap.<br />
<br />
The Benton MacKaye is one of the wildest long-distance backpacking trails in the nation. Unlike the A.T., the B.M.T. eschews cities, shelters, parks, and campgrounds wherever possible and instead opts for as wild and pristine of a route and experience as possible. It runs a total of 288 miles.<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given is Davenport Gap, the northern terminus of the BMT, not the southern beginning of this section.

name: Aspen Vista
description: Aspen Vista features 10 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: Appalachian Trail 018: Davenport Gap to Max Patch Road
description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail heads mostly east from the boundary of the Great Smoky Mountain National Park for 15 miles until it reaches Max Patch Road.<br />
Recommended parking spot: see Google Map to the right.

name: Fossil Flats
description: Fossil Flats features 5 miles of hiking trails near West Fork, AR.

name: Winsor (254)
description: Winsor (254) features 9 miles of hiking trails near Santa Fe, NM.

name: Bandelier National Monument
description:
Most visitors begin their exploration of Bandelier with a walk on the Main Loop Trail. This short 1.2 mile loop trail starts from the Visitor Center and leads through excavated archeological sites on the floor of Frijoles Canyon. A portion of this trail is handicapped accessible.<br />
<br />
Other trails in this area include the 3 mile round-trip Falls Trail to the beautiful Upper Falls and various trails of different lengths and difficulty leading up to the mesa tops.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 019: Max Patch Road to Hot Springs
description: This long section of trail runs 20 miles from Max Patch Road to the town of Hot Springs, NC. Along the way it passes the Roaring Fork Shelter, Lemon Gap, Walnut Mountain Shelter, Garenflo Gap, Deep Park Shelter, and a Jesuit Hostel.

name: Signal Hill
description:
Just 1 minute off of the interstate, Signal Hill provides 5 miles of beautiful trail for hikers to enjoy. The trail winds through the woods and provides a great place to get outdoors. <br />
This trail is designated as a mountain bike trail, so please use caution.

name: Crabtree Falls Loop
description:
This short loop trail takes hikers to Crabtree Falls. <br />
Skill:Moderate to Strenuous<br />
Time: 1.5-2 hrs<br />
Elevation Gain: 530<br />
A quick hike takes you to the stunning 70 foot waterfall cascades. A bridge crosses over the creek in front of the falls, offering beautiful views. You can either turn back here or continue on the loop.

name: Buncombe Horse Trail (Trail #191)
description:
This is the longest Trail in the Black Mountain Range. <br />
<br />
Where the trail intersects the Access road to Mt. Mitchell (SR 128). The trail then continues along an old railroad grade. <br />
<br />
After Maple Camp Bald the trail then descends through old growth fir and spruce forests.

name: Caraway Hills
description:
Caraway Hills has a beautiful 6.5 mile loop that winds through the scenic Caraway Mountain Creek Valley. Different parts of the trail vary in terrain from quick climbs, steep descents, creek crossings, and stunning views. <br />
This is a multi-use trail, and is popular with mountain bikers, so please practice caution while enjoying the outdoors!

name: Pettigrew State Park
description:
Beginning at the park office, a one-mile section winds past the campground and Somerset Place. After wandering through a sweetgum forest, the trail leads to Bee Tree Overlook, a wooden platform offering a view of the lake and a place to observe wintering waterfowl. Between the site of Bonarva and the canal is a short trail leading to Pettigrew Family Cemetery.<br />
Moccasin Trail leads northwest from the park office for approximately three miles to Moccasin Canal. After traveling through a cypress and hardwood forest, the trail stops at a 350-foot boardwalk, which cuts through a cypress swamp to Moccasin Overlook. This view of Big Point is one of the most impressive vistas in the area. Morotoc Trail continues from the overlook to Cypress Point. Bicycles are allowed on most of the park trails.<br />
The Pocosin Natural Area has a short trail to an observation tower and carnivorous plant management area. See the park map for distance and difficulty.

name: Finch Park
description:
Finch Park features 3 miles of fairly easy hiking trails near Lexington, NC. There are some beautiful creek crossing where the trail crosses over some bridges, but for the most part this trail is about deep woods and beautiful tree canopies. <br />
It's perfect to spend a little time in nature, but look at for mountain bikers, as this is a popular biking area.

name: Carolina Hemlock Trail (Trail #1003)
description:
Starting at the upper part of this trail, it wanders through classic Appalachian forest, with a few switchbacks it crosses South Highway 80 (NC 80) then continues along the toe river. The Lower half of the trail offers spectacular views of the Toe River and a great short easy hike. <br />
Blaze Color: yellow

name: Big Tom Gap (Trail #191A)
description:
Blaze: Blue<br />
Short, Steep, Narrow Trail that connects the Buncombe Horse Trail (191) and the Black Mountain Crest Trail (179)

name: Colbert Ridge Trail (Trail #178)
description:
Trail # 178<br />
Blaze: Yellow<br />
Strenuous trail from Colbert Creek Road to Deep Gap terminating at the Black Mountain Crest Trail. Few switchbacks and steep elevation gains from 2,750' to 5,700' in 3.7 miles.

name: Woody Ridge (Trail # 177)
description:
This short difficult trail takes you up to the Black Mountain Crest Trail ( Trail # 179) with wonderful views.<br />
Blaze: Yellow

name: Lake Crabtree County Park
description:
Lake Crabtree County Park offers visitors opportunities for outdoor recreation. Located on a 215-acre site adjacent to a 520-acre flood control lake, the park hosts more than 16 miles of trails for its main activity. Other activities include group and individual picnicking, catch-and-release fishing, boating, and nature study.<br />
The main loop for hikers is a 5.8 mile loop trail around Lake Crabtree which features woodlands, a dam, and pristine wetland areas as well as beautiful views.

name: Jean-pierre Chouteau Trail
description: Jean-pierre Chouteau Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Okay/ft. Gibson, OK.

name: Concord Park
description: Concord Park features 6 miles of hiking trails near Knoxville, TN.

name: Black Mountain
description: Black Mountain features 20 miles of hiking trails near Crossville, TN.

name: Fort Gibson Lake
description: Fort Gibson Lake is located on the Grand (Neosho) River about 5 miles northwest of historic Fort Gibson, Oklahoma, from which it draws its name. It is about 7.7 miles above the confluence of the Grand (Neosho) and Arkansas Rivers. The lake lies in Wagoner, Cherokee, and Mayes Counties and extends upriver to the Markham Ferry Dam (Lake Hudson). Northeast Oklahoma has long been noted for its outstanding fishing. At Fort Gibson Lake, sportsmen will find black bass, white bass, crappie, and several varieties of catfish and panfish. Three heated fishing docks offer winter fun for crappie fishing. When "game fever" is in the air, hunters will find such species as whitetail deer, bobwhite quail, mourning dove, duck, geese, cottontail rabbit and squirrel.

name: Fenton Lake State Park
description: The Jemez Mountains provide the backdrop for this lake. Set in a valley of ponderosa pines along the Rio Cebolla, there is an abundance of wildlife viewing.  Enjoy camping, hiking, fishing, and picnicking.

name: Stones River National Battlefield
description:
Stones River National Battlefield offers visitors nearly seven miles of trails for hiking and walking within the park. The park trail system also connects to the City of Murfreesboro's Greenways which boast 4.5 miles of paved trails along the Stones River and Lytle Creek.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Sequoyah Bay State Park
description: Sequoyah Bay State Park, on Fort Gibson Lake, offers 225 miles of shoreline for a variety of water sports and other recreational fun. The park's semi-modern campground is an excellent area for an overnight stay. The park also offers picnic tables, playgrounds, comfort stations, a basketball court, a volleyball area and a nature trail.

name: William B. Umstead State Park
description: Twenty miles of hiking trails provide access to most of William B. Umstead State Park. Visitors may choose between a short stroll along a nature trail or a more extensive hike into the woods. Either choice will be rewarding as the beauty and diversity of the park's natural resources are best seen from any one of its many trails. Some of the trails at the park interconnect; to avoid becoming lost, pay close attention to trail markers. No bikes or horses are allowed on hiking trails.

name: Appalachian Trail 020: Hot Springs to Allen Gap
description:
The AT runs 14.5 miles from the town of Hot Springs to Allen Gap, passing Spring Mountain and the Spring Mountain Shelter along the way.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "TN 70 (Allen Gap)" lat=35.9869270336, lon=-82.7872040563

name: Cumberland Mountain State Park
description: The park offers several miles of moderate trails around the lake, creek and in the woods.

name: Rich Park
description:
Rich Park features a 6 mile network of trails that will suite any level of hiker. The trails feature gravel surface in some places as well as some bridges. There aren't any views, but it's a great place to get out and stretch your legs.<br />
These trails are designated as mountain bike trails, so beware of the traffic.

name: North Wake Landfill District Park
description: A day at North Wake Landfill District Park provides a variety of recreational activities for all ages. The Park opened in 2010 to serve nearby communities.

name: Sequoyah State Park & Lodge
description: Sequoyah State Park & Lodge is on the shores of Fort Gibson Lake and offers 225 miles of shoreline for awesome boating, swimming, fishing, hiking, picnicking, horseback riding, disc-golfing, golfing and camping. The park's amenities include campsites, grills, picnic areas, playgrounds, a swim beach, a golf course and a restaurant.

name: Roman Nose State Park
description: Roman Nose State Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Watonga, OK.

name: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site
description:
The Thomas Hariot Nature Trail offers a 20-minute pocket wilderness experience of the island's natural setting. Wayside signs on the trail relate what English explorers observed of the natural resources and the commodities that could be made from them.<br />
The Freedom Trail leads 1å_ miles from the nearby Elizabethan Gardens through the park land to the island's western edge, offering a viewshed that the native Algonquians enjoyed from their island home.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Table Rock
description: A 2 mile, well-marked, trail with views of the Gorge as you're hiking up to the ridge. The views from the summit of the mountain are incredibly and well-worth the strenuous climb.

name: Chapel Hill High School
description:
Chapel Hill High School surprisingly features over 10 miles of beautiful hiking trails to explore. These trails are somewhat primitive and aren't marked that well, so make sure you know where you're going! This area is very easy to access and is great for hikers of all skill levels. <br />
