The trail is mostly tight, dirt singletrack, but it does have areas of boardwalk, and there are plenty of added extras for the local mountain bikers. This is a multi-use trail so beware of fast moving mountain bikers!

name: Heyburn Lake
description: Hiking trails at Sheppard Point.

name: Appalachian Trail 023: Sams Gap to Spivey Gap
description: This, the 23rd section of the Appalachian trail, runs 12 miles from Sams Gap on I-26 to Spivey Gap on US 19. The first section runs along the NC/TN state line, and then it turns further east into North Carolina. Along the way the trail passes Street Gap, Big Bald Mountain, and Bald Mountain Shelter.

name: Forks Of The River
description: Forks Of The River features 4 miles of hiking trails near Knoxville, TN.

name: Linville Falls Trail
description: Short family hike on a wide well maintained trail that offers several different spectacular views of Linville Falls and gorge.

name: Jockey's Ridge State Park
description: Both children and adults enjoy climbing and playing on the park's huge pile of sand. Some hike the dune for the spectacular views of coastal Carolina, others for the experience of the desert-like environment. When hiking the ridge, look for fulgurites, glass tubes formed when lightning hits the sand. (Please don't remove the fulgurites from the park.)

name: Blue Jay Point County Park
description: Nice hiking area.

name: Northwood
description: Northwood features 8 miles of hiking trails near High Point, NC. This network of trails is not necessarily scenic, but it does offer nice wooded hiking paths. However, recently part of the trail was clear cut. Beware of high mountain bike traffic.

name: Lake Frierson State Park
description: The Dogwood Lane Trail is a favorite in the spring.

name: Twin Fork Recreational Area
description: Twin Fork Recreational Area features 6 miles of hiking trails near Murfreesboro, TN.

name: Bootleg Canyon
description: Bootleg Canyon features 35 miles of hiking trails near Boulder City, NV.

name: Willams Hill Recreation Area
description: Hiking available; no developed trails.

name: Appalachian Trail 021: Allen Gap to Devil Fork Gap
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs 20 miles from Allen Gap(TN Hwy 70) to Devil Fork Gap (NC Hwy 212). Along the way it passes Little Laurel Shelter, Jerry Cabin Shelter, and Flint Mountain Shelter. This section follows the NC/TN state line, closing it numerous times.

name: Cedarock Park
description:
Cedarock Park features plenty of amenities for visitors including Cedarock Historical Farm, which provides an example of life on a farm in North Carolina During the 19th Century, shelters, disc golf, camping, the Old Mill Dam, and plenty of fishing. <br />
6 miles of trail wind their way throughout this park and provide a great afternoon walk or a beautiful day hike.

name: American Tobacco Trail
description:
American Tobacco Trail features 23 miles of hiking trails near Durham, NC.<br />
It is a rails-to-trails project running through the woods and crossing the city of Durham. It's a dirt path, occasionally paved, with some interspersed boardwalks.

name: Center Hill Lake
description: Great hiking at Floating Mill Recreation Area.

name: Dennis Moore's Trail
description: Dennis Moore's Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Farmington, AR.

name: Haw Ridge Park
description: Haw Ridge Park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Oak Ridge, TN.

name: Duke Forest
description: Mostly wide gravel paths suitable for walking, jogging, or biking.  Several foot paths diverge from the wide gravel roads and lead to some interesting scenery, particularly in the area off Whitfield Road.  Lots of people here on the weekends.

name: Beaman Park
description: Beaman Park lies on the Highland Rim, just outside of the Nashville Basin, in the northwest edge of Davidson County. Its terrain features steep, forested slopes, with drier ridge tops and elevations just under 1000 feet. The area was once known as Paradise Ridge, and while the beauty of the land might inspire one to envision paradise, the name actually comes from 2 early settlers, the Paradise brothers.

name: Syllamo Trails
description: Syllamo Trails features 22 miles of hiking trails near Mountain View, AR.

name: Blue Diamond
description: Blue Diamond features 30 miles of hiking trails near Las Vegas, NV.

name: Lake Mead National Recreation Area
description:
Some of the best places are only available on foot. With mountains and valleys making up 87% of Lake Mead NRA, there are places to hike and explore for everyone, including some guided hikes.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 022: Devil Fork Gap to Sams Gap
description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail follows the NC/TN state line for 8 miles from Devil Fork Gap (NC Hwy 212) to Sams Gap (I-26, US Hwy 2). The only shelter on this section is the Hog Back Ridge shelter.<br />
This little-used section of the AT runs through ridge top woods where hikers can experience both new growth and old growth forests. <br />
Recommended parking spot: "I-26, US 2 (Sam's Gap)" lat=35.9525269904, lon=-82.5609283192

name: Railroad Tunnel
description: Railroad Tunnel features 8 miles of hiking trails near Boulder City , NV.

name: Tanglewood Park
description:
The multi-use asphalt trail is the perfect place to go for a jog, ride your bike, or take a peaceful stroll through the woods. The asphalt trail is 10 feet wide and is accessible via parking lots on Northtrail Road or at Shelter 2.<br />
There is also around 6 miles of mountain bike trail, forming 3 different loops.

name: Limekiln State Park
description: Inspiring redwoods, a sandy beach, and a trail into Big Sur history are some of the attractions of Limekiln State Park. The park opened in September of 1995 after the state acquired a privately held campground and 716 acres of land in southernmost Big Sur.

name: Falls Lake State Recreation Area
description:
Falls Lake Trail will eventually travel the entire south shore of the lake. A portion of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail, the trail will connect two recreational areas and provide camping for backpackers. Portions of the trail travel through state parkland where all state park regulations apply. The remainder of the trail travels through N.C. Wildlife Resource Commission gamelands. For your safety, wear blaze orange while hiking this trail during hunting season.

A one-mile loop trail at B. W. Wells passes the naturalist's home and an interpretive area. Short trails at Rolling View and Sandling Beach allow a closer look at the aquatic environment. There are also short trails at Beaverdam and Holly Point.

name: Chaco Culture National Historical Park
description:
There are four backcountry hiking trails in Chaco Culture National Historical Park ranging from a relatively level 3 mile roundtrip hike to a trails over 7 miles long and climbing up to 450 feet. Whichever trail you choose to take it will provide you with a rare opportunity to experience the present-day solitude and sweeping vistas of the canyon and mesa landscape; allow you to see the impressive Chacoan great houses, roads, and features in an undeveloped setting; and help you understand the scope and extent of the Chaco world.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Hobby Park
description:
Hobby Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Winston-Salem, NC. This loop trail has some fairly steep terrain that will get your heart pumping and make you work for your workout. There are plenty of steep climbs through this wood covered trail, and the path stays mainly in the forest.<br />
Be aware that this is a multi-use trail and is very popular with mountain bike riders, so please practice caution!

name: Appalachian Trail 024: Spivey Gap to Nolichucky River
description:
This section of the AT runs 10 miles from Spivey Gap to the Nolichucky River. The trail crosses over from North Carolina to Tennessee and ends in TN at the bridge over the Nolichucky. Along the way it passes the shelter at No Business Knob.<br />
Find the description for section 025 of the AT under Tennessee, or click here.

name: Cedars of Lebanon State Park
description: Cedars of Lebanon State Park is a 900-acre state park which is used for intensive recreation. Activities here include hiking, horseback riding, swimming and camping.

name: Burgess Falls State Park
description: Burgess Falls State Park lies on the edge of Tennessee's Highland Rim adjacent to the Cumberland Plateau. Activities here include boating, fishing and hiking.

name: Crowley's Ridge State Park
description: A trail guide can be located at http://www.arkansasstateparks.com/!userfiles/pdfs/CRidge-trail guide-04.pdf

name: Beaver Dam
description:
Beaver Dam features 10 miles of hiking trails near Raleigh, NC. These trails are rated easy to moderate and consist of 4 loops: a 2.6-mile outer loop, a 1.6-mile inner loop, a 2.4-mile west loop and more advanced 6-mile loop called the South Loop.<br />
<br />
Enjoy the shaded trail system that runs under a beautiful tree canopy, but be sure to watch out for other trail users, like mountain bikers.

name: Harpeth River State Park
description: For your hiking and wildlife viewing pleasure, enjoy the solitude and tranquility of several miles of easy to difficult trails meandering through wildflower meadows, lush forests, and along majestic bluffs. At the Narrows of the Harpeth three trails originate at a common trailhead near the park entrance. A half-mile bluff overlook trail includes a steep ascent to a narrow bluff offering hikers a panoramic view of the Harpeth Valley. A half-mile trail along the backside of the limestone bluff leads to the site of Montgomery Bell's Pattison Forge where a small waterfall is all that remains of the iron forge operation. Another half-mile trail connects the canoe launch area to the canoe take-out parking area at the Harris Street Bridge Access Area. At the Gossett Tract there are two trails. A one mile trail circles a meadow and another one mile trail winds along the river providing a glimpse of Mound Bottom Archeological Site. At Hidden Lake a one mile trail meanders around and through a wildflower meadow. Another trail offers a half-mile hike through the forest and along majestic bluffs to a small lake with a one mile spur trail ascending to the top of a ridge where the remains of an old marble dance floor are all that remain of a 1940's resort.

name: Radnor Lake State Park
description:
Radnor Lake is day use only and is protected as a Class II Natural Area, so the trails are strictly used for hiking and wildlife observation.

Trails are off limits to pets, jogging, and bicycles.

name: Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area
description: Amazing pocket of nature near the nexis of I-85 and I-40.  You may have seen the mountain with the tower on top near the interstate but you really have to hike around to really appreciate the area.  Wide gravel road leads to the top with several hiking trails to take you beside the river and small fishing ponds.  Be sure to check out the overlook, a nearly shear cliff face that is probably 100-200 feet high.  Top elevation is 867 feet.

name: Warner Parks Hiking Trail System
description: The hiking trail system includes 9 color-coded trails ranging in length from 150 yards to 4.5 miles. All of the trails have been expanded, improved and maintained by the Nature Center staff with the aid of seasonal workers and volunteers. Trails are open from daybreak until 11PM. Hikers must remain on trails at all times; pets must be leashed. No horses, motorcycles or bicycles on trails.

name: Grand Canyon South Rim Trail
description: Short, easy hike along the South Rim of the Grand Canyon. Trail offers several viewing areas and spectacular views of the canyon.

name: Johnsonville State Historic Park
description: Johnsonville's hiking trails are open.

name: Turkey Mountain
description: Turkey Mountain features 10 miles of hiking trails near Tulsa, OK.

name: Lake Charles State Park
description: Hiking trails with interpretive walks.

name: Occoneechee Speedway
description: Historic racetrack that has been overgrown with a forest!  The second NASCAR racetrack to open and the only track remaining from the first NASCAR season in 1949.  Well marked trails take you around the race track where you can still see the grandstands and outbuildings.  Trails also lead to and along the Eno River.

name: Jones Mill
description: Jones Mill features 5 miles of hiking trails near Smyrna, TN.

name: Spring Mountain Ranch State Park
description: Spring Mountain Ranch State Park was once home to the Paiute Indians. The 520-acre area was also a luxurious ranch retreat to a few different owners. The park is a great area for picnicking, exploring and hiking. The picnicking area offers tables, grills and restrooms.

name: Nathan Bedford Forrest State Park
description: There are over 25 miles of hiking trails in the park. 5-mile has orange markings; 10-mile has red markings and 20-mile has blue markings.  Several shorter trails ranging from .25 miles to 2 miles are also available. Two backcoutry shelters are availabe for overnight hikes and can be reserved with a permit issued at the park office. Trail maps are available at the park office and museum.

name: Edgar Evins State Park
description: There are approximately 11 miles of trails at Edgar Evins from moderate to strenuous. Of the five trails the longest and most challenging is the 5.5 mile Merritt Ridge Trail which rises upon the ridges from an intersection along the 2.5 mile Jack Clayborn Millennium Trail Loop. By combining the two trails a hiker can enjoy approximately 8 miles of diverse terrain. Both the Millennium Trail and the Merritt Ridge Trail share the same trail head. Registration is required at this trail head. Other trails vary in length from to 1.5 miles and do not require registration. The Highland Rim Nature Trail, located at the Visitor Center, is especially noted for an abundance of spring wildflowers.

name: Montgomery Bell State Park
description: Montgomery Bell offers a variety of hiking experiences for all ages. From a .75 mile walk in the woods to the 11.7 mile-long overnight/backpacking trails, there are trails for hikers of all experience levels. The backcountry trail has three overnight shelters dispersed along its length, open year-round.

name: Long Hunter State Park
description: There are several hiking trails at Long Hunter designed to provide pleasant walking experiences for all. Among the more popular is the two-mile loop Lake Trail around Couchville Lake. It is also home to the Jason Allen Arboretum Trail at Couchville Lake that weaves its way through the first certified arboretum in a Tennessee State Park. Visitors along the Jason Allen Arboretum Trail will see 44 stenciled leaves on the barrier-free, hard surfaced path that signify where the different trees are marked. These stenciled leaves were created by Tina Turbeville, a Friend of Long Hunter, who worked with Jason and Fred Dickson, another Friend of Long Hunter, to carefully apply the leaf stencil to the Arboretum trail. Unlike most sites where trees are planted for the sole purpose of creating an arboretum, these trees were already occurring naturally around Couchville Lake. This provides a wild feel and makes the arboretum site even more special.

name: Salem Lake
description:
Salem Lake has been called the hidden diamond in the city of Winston-Salem. Located minutes away from downtown Winston-Salem, Salem Lake offers a 365-acre lake with a 7-mile trail that offers a scenic view of the lake at all times. <br />
The newly reconditioned 7-mile trail has made Salem Lake one of the most popular outings for exercise in the area. Runners, walkers, bikers, and equestrians have found the new surface on the trail to be refreshing & inviting.

name: Warrior Creek At Kerr Scott Reservoir
description:
Warrior Creek At Kerr Scott Reservoir features 9 miles of hiking trails near Wilkesboro, NC.<br />
This trail runs along the contours of the reservoir and continues along to where the Upper Yadkin River feeds into the lake. Warrior Creek is very scenic, but can be challenging at times so be ready for a work out. Also, be ready for a high amount of mountain bike traffic.

name: CDT NM25: Los Pinos Trailhead to NM Hwy 96
description:
Segment 25 of the CDT runs 19.7 miles from Los Pinos Trailhead to New Mexico Highway 96. This entire section is comprised of gorgeous singletrack in the majestic New Mexico Mountains... no roads to be found here!<br />
Along the way this trail passes the San Pedro Peaks High Point.

name: Appalachian Trail 025: Nolichucky River to Iron Mountain Gap
description:
This section of the AT runs from the Nolichucky River in TN to Iron Mountain Gap on the TN/NC state line. Along the way it passes the Curley Maple Gap Shelter, Indian Grave Gap, Unaka Mountain, and Cherry Gap Shelter.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: "TN 395 (Indian Grave Gap)" lat=36.1108010342, lon=-82.3609233624<br />
<br />
Note: if you are south bound, the description for section 024 can be found under North Carolina, or just click here.

name: Appalachian Trail: Tennessee
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs 116 miles through the state of Tennessee, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3308/North-Carolina/Appalachian-Trail--North-Carolina.html">North Carolina</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3332/Virginia/Appalachian-Trail--Virginia.html">Virginia</a> border.<br />
If you are looking for detailed information about individual trail sections, please click on the links to the individual trail listings below.

name: Appalachian Trail 028: Carvers Gap to US 19E
description: This section begins at Carvers Gap on TN Hwy 143 on the TN/NC state line, follows the state line for a ways, dips into North Carolina for several miles, and finally crosses the border and dives deeply into TN until it reaches US 19E. Along the way it passes Stan Murray Shelter, Over Mountain Shelter, and Apple House Shelter.

name: Hamilton Creek Mountain Bike Park
description: Hamilton Creek features 5 miles of hiking trails near Nashville, TN.

name: Obed Wild & Scenic River
description:
Regardless of the time of year, every season offers its own special rewards to those who take the time to explore the Obed Wild and Scenic River on foot. Visitors interested in a short, easy walk will enjoy the hike to Lilly Bluff Overlook, a mere five minutes down a wide, relatively flat path. The trail ends in a winding network of overlook platforms which provide lofty and commanding views of Clear Creek canyon's sheer sandstone walls and of the river far below. The self-guided Emory River Nature Trail, a .7 mile loop which begins at Rock Creek Campground and which follows the banks of the Emory River, will also provide the visitor with an introduction to the cultural and natural resources of the Obed Wild and Scenic River.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Country Park
description: Country Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Greensboro, NC. These trails are well-groomed, well-marked, and well-traveled. With a dog park, two fishing lakes, a veterans' memorial, playgrounds, picnic shelters, and boat rentals, this is a very popular park.

name: Canton Lake
description: Hiking trails available in Blaine Park area.

name: Daniel Boone Scout Trail
description: An awesome, challenging trail.  You have to hike about half a mile on the Tanawha trail to get to the Daniel Boone Scout trailhead and the real climbing begins here.  Toward the top of the climb you'll find ropes and ladders to help you reach the summit, well worth the effort for the views!  You need to purchase a permit to hike this trail as it is on Grandfather Mountain property (private).  We purchased our permits at Footsloggers in Boone (also a Footsloggers in Blowing Rock) and you can also purchase a permit at the Grandfather Mountain Country Store (though it was closed the day we went to the trail).  Permits cost between $5 (quoted on grandfather.com) and $7 (what we actually paid at Footsloggers).

name: Frozen Head State Park
description:
Hikers must inquire in the Visitors Center about open trails. Trails range from easy to very difficult. A color topo map may be purchased at the Visitors Center.

Trails are open daily from 8 a.m. until one hour before sunset. This is one of the finest trail systems in Tennessee. There are over 80 miles of very scenic and challenging foot trails throughout this wild and rugged 13,122-acre mountain park. The trails feature waterfalls, giant sandstone rock formations, bluffs, abundant wildlife and 14 mountain peaks over 3,000 feet in elevation.

Each of the 20 trails are color blazed and most of the trails inter-loop together giving a choice of 7 loop trails ranging from .6 mile to 15 miles round-trip. A portion of the Cumberland Trail passes through as well.

Frozen Head State Park has several trails: Bird Mtn Trail 4.0 Chimney Top Trail 6.6 Empry Gap Trail to Falls 0.5 Interpretive Trail Loop 0.5 Judge Branch Trail Loop 1.2 Lookout Tower Trail 6.9 North Old Mac Trail 3.3 Panther Branch Trail 2.1 South Old Mac Trail 2.4 Spicewood Trail 2.5

name: W. Kerr Scott Dam & Reservoir
description: W. Kerr Scott Reservoir is located in the beautiful Yadkin River Valley in Wilkesboro, North Carolina. There are several trails located at Kerr Scott Reservoir, most of which are very popular with mountain bikers.

name: Overmountain Victory Trail (Kerr Scott Reservoir)
description:
Overmountain Victory Trail within the Kerr Scott Reservoir features 14 miles of hiking trails near Wilkesboro, NC. This trail is part of the federally-designated Overmoutain Victory National Historic Trail, and it generally follows the route that American Patriots took to confront the British Army during the Battle of Kings Mountain in October 1780.<br />
There are bridge crossings, creek crossings and stunning lake views along this out-and-back trail, but be ready for a full day of hiking. Also be aware of mountain bike traffic.

name: J Percy Priest Lake
description: Hiking trails at Hamilton Creek, Long Hunter State Park, Stewart Creek and Volunteer Park (Smyrna), all of which are very closeby.

name: Guilford Courthouse National Military Park
description:
Those who enjoy hiking can take advantage of the 2.5 miles of battlefield walking trails.Twenty-eight monuments within the park honor Revolutionary soldiers, statesmen, heroes, and heroines. William Hooper and John Penn, two of North Carolina's three signers of the Declaration of Independence, are buried under the Signers' Monument. A large equestrian statue of General Nathanael Greene dominates the monument honoring the soldiers of the Southern Army and its leader.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Lake Fayetteville Trail
description: Lake Fayetteville Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Fayetteville, AR.

name: Dark Mountain Trail
description:
Dark Mountain Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Wilkesboro, NC. This trail has decent climbs and descents with some switchbacks, and stunning views of the lake.<br />
It's also popular with mountain bikers, so be sure to practice precaution on the trail.

name: Coalinga Mineral Springs National Recreation Trail
description: The trailhead is located across the creek from the Coalinga Mineral Springs County Park.  Once on the trail, the visitor has over 2.5 miles of continuous trail to hike on which leads to the top of Kreyenhagen Peak.  The trail width is between 18 and 24 inches, and 48 inches in hazardous areas to provide safety to the hiker and horseman.

name: Keystone State Park
description: Keystone State Park in northeast Oklahoma is located on the Keystone Lake. The lake provides excellent opportunities for boating, water skiing and fishing. The park provides boat rentals, boat launches, a floating restaurant and a marina. Hiking and cycling are also common activities at this park.

name: Appalachian Trail 026: Iron Mountain Gap to Hughes Gap
description: This section of the AT begins at Iron Mountain on the TN/NC state line and follows the line all the way to Hughes Gap. They Clyde Smith Shelter is near the end of this section of trail.

name: Keystone Mountain Bike Trail
description: Keystone Mountain Bike Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Tulsa, OK.

name: Appalachian Trail 027: Hughes Gap to Carvers Gap
description:
This section of trail runs 4.5 miles from Hughes Gap to Carvers Gap on TN 143. Along the way it passes Roan High Mountain and Roan High Knob Shelter.<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given for the southern end of this section is approximate.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: "Carvers Gap" lat=36.1063207118, lon=-82.1104066822

name: Wild Turkey
description:
This trail is the perfect backdrop for your next scenic hike whether you're experienced or a beginner! At just under five miles, this trail features a tight single track, bridges of varying sizes, some small climbs. This trail connects with two other watershed trails, Owl's Roost and Reedy Fork, for more continuous hikes. Put all three together, and you have a great long distance hike!<br />
This is a multi-use trail, so beware of bikers!

name: Canyon de Chelly National Monument
description:
About 6 miles from the Visitor Center, there is one public trail to hike at the White House Ruin Overlook.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Grandfather Mountain State Park
description:
Grandfather Mountain State Park offers more than 12 miles of trails lacing 2,456 acres along the mountain's ridgeline and its highest point at Calloway Peak. The trails offer magnificent scenery from rock outcrops and quiet forested coves near the mountain's crest. Permits are required.

Most of these trails are challenging; steep, rocky terrain can make progress slow at times. Hikers must use the trails' ladders and cables in some of the steeper sections. Be aware that hiking to the ridge area and back from the low-elevation trailheads may take a full day. Plan for enough time to get back to your vehicle before dark. And, wear proper clothing and carry adequate equipment.

name: Withrow Springs State Park
description: 3 Moderate trails and 1 strenuous trail. NOTE:  On April 16, 2010, the park's War Eagle Cave on the War Eagle Trail closed. This temporary emergency closure was necessary to protect this cave from the possibility of contamination from the White-nose Syndrome, a fungus that has killed millions of hibernating bats in the eastern half of the United States.

name: Lees-McRae College
description:
Lees-McRae College features 5 miles of hiking trails near Banner Elk, NC. This loop trail has plenty of singletrack, forest roads, gravel roads, and pavement. Switchbacks wind through this wooded area, and it's a perfect place to get out and stretch your legs.<br />
Beware of the high mountain bike traffic.

name: Old Davidsonville Historic State Park
description: Four hiking trails and a self-guided walking trail through the historic town site.

name: Owls Roost (Bur-Mil Park)
description:
Owls Roost is part of the Bur-Mil Park trail system and features 8 miles of beautiful track near Greensboro, NC.<br />
The trail descends down, passing some gullies along the way, until it reaches the shores of Lake Brandt where you can take in beautiful views of the pristine lake. Hike through scenic pine tree filled woods, but be aware that this is a multi-use trail, and it is very popular with mountain bikers.

name: Shelby Bottoms
description: Beautiful greenway trail alongside the Cumberland River.

name: Bur-Mil Park
description: There are several great trails available to hike in the park. For more information about the individual trails, click on the trail listings below. This 250-acre park adjacent to Lake Brandt provides a wide variety of recreational opportunities.

name: Northeast Park
description:
Whether hiking, biking, or riding horses; whether novice or veteran, Northeast Park has a trail fit for you. Over 10 miles of trails wind through the property. Walkers enjoy the 8/10 mile paved path that rings the center of the park. Many trails are exclusive to equestrians and are situated throughout the facility. <br />
Hikers and bikers can choose from an array of trails; flat or elevated, rugged or smooth, long or short. Be sure to cross the creek at the low water crossing and experience some of the nicest hike, bike, and horse trails in the park. Maps are available in front of the park offices and at the bulletin board in the horse trailer parking lot.

name: Bald Eagle
description:
Bald Eagle features 6 miles of hiking trails near Greensboro, NC.<br />
Bald Eagle Trail skirts the shores of Lake Higgins, providing beautiful scenery for hiking and mountain biking. This moderate hike offers opportunities to view unique waterfowl and possibly a bald eagle, the trail's namesake. It is considered a semi-technical mountain bike ride by the trail sponsor, Greensboro Fat Tire Society, with its rooty sections and hairpin turns. The 1.3-mile loop on the western side of Lewiston Road is an added bonus.

name: Big Loop
description: Big Loop is a perfect 2 mile afternoon hike or leisurely walk. This path winds through the woodlands in the western side of the park, and follows a stream toward Lake Brandt. It follows the lake contours and then turns away and follows another streambed back to the start.

name: Roan Mountain State Park
description: There are approximately 12 miles of hiking trails in Roan Mountain State Park and 2.25 miles of mountain bike trails. Difficulty levels range from easy to strenuous. Hikers can stroll along the Doe River or take a challenging trail up to a ridge with a great view. Trail users should wear appropriate footwear and clothing and carry drinking water.

name: Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park
description: From the Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park lot, take the signed trail toward Overlook Trail. Along McWay Creek you'll spot some eucalyptus, quite a botanical contrast to the redwoods growing up-creek. (During spring, ceanothus and dogwood splash color along the trail.) The path leads through a tunnel under Coast Highway One, veers right, and emerges to offer the walker grand panoramas of the Big Sur coast.

name: Natural Falls State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Appalachian Trail 029: US 19E to Dennis Cove Road
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs from US 19E to Dennis Cove Road. Along the way it passes the Mountaineer Shelter, Walnut Mountain Road, Bitter End Road, and Moreland Gap Shelter.

name: Blue Heron
description:
Blue Heron is the newest Watershed Trail in Greensboro and it offers an extension of the Reedy Fork trail via N. Church Street! The Greensboro Fat Tire Society has been working hard constructing Blue Heron since spring 2009. <br />
The trail skirts along the shore line of beautiful Lake Townsend. There is plenty of variety too as the trail leads you out of the woods for multiple power line crossings. A few sections have deep gullies and dips that are fun to blast through and out of on your bike. Blue Heron flows great and is relatively easy for any rider or hiker to tackle.

name: Mcmurtry Trail
description: Mcmurtry Trail features 27 miles of hiking trails near Stillwater, OK.

name: Coyote Creek State Park
description: Approximately 1 mile of trails.

name: Siloam Springs State Park
description:
This 3,323-acre park offers true natural beauty with its forested terrain, dotted with wildflowers and accented with a sparkling lake. The park offers activities including hunting, fishing, camping, picnicking, horseback riding, winter sports, hiking and nature appreciation.

The Siloam Springs trails brings you face to face with beautiful wildflowers, valleys and flatlands. The park offers many trails varying in experience level.
Four primitive campsites are also available for use.


Phone (217) 894-6205

name: Emerald Outback
description:
Emerald Outback is part of the Beech Mountain Adventure Trail park and features 8 miles of hiking trails near Beech Mountain, NC. These trails traverse the beautiful mountain country and nearly everywhere on the trail hikers are treated to stunning mountain top views. Small waterfalls and creeks are an added perk, and make this area a must see for every hiker!<br />
These trails are multi-use trails so be courteous to mountain bikers and trail runners

name: Big Cypress Tree State Park
description: Big Cypress Tree State Park is a 27-acre state park that lies in the floodplain of the Middle Fork of the Obion River. Hiking is a popular activity here given all of the natural scenery and the history.

name: Grand Canyon - North Rim
description: Incredible views (an understatement) and great facilities with only 10% of the people at the South Rim! The drive into the park on highway 67 is worth the trip alone - high alpine meadows dotted with aspen and spruce trees and tons of wildlife. Trails are well marked and many start at the visitors center. Pick up the free map and guide at the entrance to the park ($25 per vehicle). Hiking trails include the Widforss trail, North Kaibab trail, and the Ken Patrick trail, among others.

name: CDT NM26: NM Hwy 96 to Skull Bridge Trailhead
description: Segment 26 of the CDT runs 14.6 miles from NM Hwy 96 to the Skull Bridge Trailhead. This segment is almost entirely actual trail, with only two small bits of road to walk along.

name: Greenway Runarounds
description:
Greenway Runarounds features 3 miles of hiking trails near Boone, NC.<br />
This is a basic trail system that meanders through thick forests under beautiful tree canopies. There aren't any views, but it's great for a relaxing walk through the woods. It is a multi-use trail so watch out for mountain bikers.

name: Panther Creek State Park
description: Panther Creek State Park features 15 miles of hiking trails near Morristown, TN.

name: Keystone Lake
description: This 26,000 acre lake is truly an urban playground. There are 16 recreation areas (3 with alcohol free beaches); 11 boat ramps, miles of sandy beaches, 3 marinas, 2 off-road vehicle areas, 5 short distance trails, a waterfowl refuge, 3 seasonal green tree reservoirs, and thousands of acres of land open to public hunting. Camping facilities range from primitive to full hook up. Cabins are available at Keystone State Park. Boat rentals are available through Keyport Marina and Pier 51. Keystone Lake is noted for its striped bass, sand bass, black bass, lake strain small mouth bass, crappie, and catfish. Downstream fisheries are accessible from Whitewater and Brush Creek Parks. Swift Park (a day use Tulsa County park) provides boat access to the Arkansas River below the lake when water levels are adequate. Hunting and fishing are regulated by state and Federal laws. The same licenses are required as in the other parts of the State of Oklahoma. Services and supplies are available at commercial concessions on the lake. Overnight accommodations are available in nearby communities. Copies of rules and regulations governing public use of the lake may be obtained at the Keystone Project Office.

name: Rocky Knob Park
description:
Rocky Knob Park has about 5 miles for both hikers and mountain bikers to enjoy. It is advertised as a mountain bike park, but hikers are allowed on the trails as well, and have their own trails in some sections.<br />
Most of these trails wind under beautiful forest canopies, giving hikers a nice tranquil experience. Views are rare, but it's a great place to get outdoors. Remember to be aware of the mountain bikers.

name: Orilla Verde Recreation Area
description: There are wonderful hiking opportunities in the area. Trails are steep and hiking can be strenuous.  Good physical condition, sturdy shoes, and plenty of drinking water are necessary.  For more information on other trails in the Recreation Area, please stop by or call the Visitor Center.

name: Horizon Park
description:
Horizon Park features 4 miles of hiking trails near Winston-Salem, NC.<br />
492 acres of rolling wooded hills and natural beauty make up the tranquil setting of Horizons Park. This county-wide facility was purchased by Forsyth County in late 1977 from Horizons Residential Care Center. It is the Forsyth Park System's second largest facility and has been developed to retain its appeal to families and nature lovers.

name: Norris Watershed
description: Norris Watershed features 20 miles of hiking trails near Norris, TN.

name: Abiquiu Lake
description: Gorgeous hiking trails.

name: Norris Dam State Park
description: Many miles of woodland trails meander throughout the park and adjacent lands, providing spectacular views of Norris Lake and its surrounding hills and valleys. Hiking trails are open year round.

name: Big Ridge State Park
description: Big Ridge State Park is a 3,687-acre park with a wealth of activities and plenty of nature to observe. This park offers mountain biking, boating, fishing, hiking, swimming and camping. The trails here range from very easy to rugged in difficulty.

name: Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park
description: From the signed trailhead, follow the trail to Pfeiffer Falls. Very shortly, on your left, you'll spot a trail heading left to Valley View.  Cross the bridge at the creek and continue up the hill.  You will come to an intersection.  To the left takes you to the Valley Overlook.  To the right, the trail continues to Pfeiffer Falls.

name: Walnut Creek State Park
description: Hikers, mountain bikers and equestrian enthusiasts will enjoy the 15-mile Sand Plum Trail that features flat to rolling terrain with many vistas of the lake.

name: Old Hickory Lock and Dam
description: Besides its many parks and recreation areas, Old Hickory is home to several group camp facilities such as the Boy Scouts' Camp Boxwell, Lincoya Girl Scout Camp, Fraternal Order of Police Camp for underprivileged children, the Easter Seal Camp, and Ruillman Rehabilitation Center, all of which provide outdoor experiences for thousands of young people each year.

name: Medoc Mountain State Park
description:
Medoc Mountain State Park is a park close to urban areas that offers a perfect escape from work. The park has beautiful foot trails for hiking and plenty of nature to explore. Camping, canoeing, fishing and picnicking are other common activities here. The park also offer interpretive programs.<br />
The park offers seven trails that equal a little more than 10 miles when combined. Most of the trails are easy or moderate in difficulty, and trail scenery includes an artesian well, granite outcroppings and miniature rapids. Winding along Little Fishing Creek, around the high ridge of Medoc Mountain and through the forests, the trails are the best way to appreciate the beauty and diversity of Medoc Mountain.

name: Appalachian Trail 030: Dennis Cove Road to Watauga Dam Road
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs 14 miles from Dennis Cove Road to Watauga Dam Road. Along the way it passes the Laurel Fork Shelter, US 321, and the Watauga Lake Shelter.

name: Nadeau National Recreation Trail
description: The Nadeau Trail provides motorized access through western Panamint Valley and ties in with cherry-stems and spurs leading to OHV, wilderness hiking, and packing opportunities. The Nadeau Trail has a fascinating history, from a place of geologic unrest and prehistoric petroglyphs to acting as the main corridor for Remi Nadeau's freight wagons loaded with silver lead ingots headed down to Los Angeles in the 1800's. History seekers, cultural explorers, and desert recreationists have an unlimited number of possible stops along the trail.

name: Gloss Mountain State Park
description: Miles of prairie floor stretch out as far as the eye can see, broken up only by the native red dirt and sparse green shrubbery. Buzzards and eagles loom overhead, while lizards and insects will become familiar friends along the rocky terrain. Bring a camera to capture the unique land geography, geological formations, Selenite gypsum, scenery and wildlife.

name: Townsend Ridge Road Trail
description: Townsend Ridge Road Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Rogers, AR.

name: Andrew Molera State Park
description: Mountains, meadows and the mouth of Big Sur River are some of the highlights of a walk through Andrew Molera State Park, largest state park along the Big Sur coast. More than 20 miles of trail weave through the park, which has a diversity of ecosystems. You can hike along the bluffs overlooking three miles of beach, and climb through meadows and oak woodland. At the river mouth are a shallow lagoon and beautiful sandy beach.

name: Cordell Hull Dam And Reservoir
description: Cordell Hull Dam And Reservoir is a very popular destination for families and outdoor lovers alike. Cordell Hull Lake covers about 12,000 acres and this park has recreation opportunities for hiking, biking, horseback riding, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Bashore Ridge
description: Bashore Ridge features 4 miles of hiking trails near Rogers, AR.

name: Hobbs State Park-Conservation Area
description: Park interpreters offer a wide diversity of programs and workshops throughout the year.

name: Dutton Hollow Loop
description: Dutton Hollow Loop features 3 miles of hiking trails near Rogers, AR.

name: Pension Mountain
description: Pension Mountain features 2 miles of hiking trails near Berryville, AR.

name: Etsu Campus Trail System
description: Etsu Campus Trail System features 5 miles of hiking trails near Johnson City, TN.

name: Point Sur State Historic Park
description: The Point Sur Light Station Trail offers a half mile guided walk. The tour includes the lighthouse itself, the keepers' houses, the blacksmith shop and the barn, where livestock was kept. You'll learn the fascinating story of the isolated life lived by the four keepers and their families.

name: Justin P. Wilson Cumberland Trail State Park
description: On June 22, 1998, TN State Parks announced the creation of the Cumberland Trail State Park, Tennessee's 53rd State Park and the only state park of its kind. In September 2002, the park was renamed the Justin P. Wilson Cumberland Trail State Park in recognition of Wilson's dedication and leadership in catalyzing efforts to build the trail.

name: Appalachian Trail 031: Watauga Dam Road to Tenn 91
description: Section 31 of the Appalachian Trail runs 15.5 miles from Watauga Dam Road to TN Hwy 91. Along the way it passes Vandeventer shelter and Iron Mountain shelter.

name: CDT NM27: Skull Bridge Trailhead to US Hwy 84
description:
Segment 27 of the CDT runs 14.4 miles from the Skull Bridge Trailhead to US Hwy 84. A good portion of this segment is real trail, but a sizable portion is also routed along a road. <br />
Along the way the trail passes Mesa De Los Viejos.

name: Lock 4
description: Lock 4 features 9 miles of hiking trails near Gallatin, TN.

name: Elk Knob State Park
description:
The 1.9-mile (one way) Summit Trail to the top of Elk Knob has finally been completed with the help of over 6,000 hours provided by many volunteers over 5 and one half years. The beautiful and well maintained trail is a big part of the adventure but the breathtaking view from the top is the icing on the cake.

Along the trail, hikers will catch glimpses of the mountainous terrain of Watauga and Ashe Counties. Upon reaching the summit, hikers will have spectacular views of The Peak, Three Top and Bluff Mountains, Mount Jefferson, Grandfather Mountain, Mount Mitchell, Mt Rodgers (Va.), and the Iron Mountains in Virginia and Tennessee.

name: Beaver Lake
description: Excellent hiking trails throughout the area.

name: Sycamore Shoals State Historic Park
description: There is a two mile walking/fitness trail that follows the Watauga River. The trail also accesses Sycamore Shoals Hospital which is adjacent to the park

name: Pilot Mountain State Park
description: Journey on foot, on horseback or in a canoe. No matter what your mode of travel, Pilot Mountain has miles of trails to explore. Little Pinnacle Overlook offers hikers a close-up view of Big Pinnacle and distant views of the valley below. Equestrians and hikers alike will relish the trails through the six-mile woodland corridor that connects the two sections of the park. Cliffs and crevices, ravens, and rhododendron are only a small part of the scenery to be discovered. For more information about the trails, see the park map. All visitors with horses must be able to provide proof of a negative equine infectious anemia (Coggins) test while visiting North Carolina State Parks. Horse rentals not available.

name: Laguna Mountain Recreation Area
description: There are three trailheads, one each at Laguna Mountain, Sweetwater, and Short Fence.  From the Laguna trailhead, a somewhat rugged hike will bring you up and over a ridgeline and then drop you into Miller Creek canyon, which is pretty easy going. If you follow the creek, you eventually will find a series of waterfalls up in the gorge.

name: Norfork Lake
description: Trails in Dam-Quarry and Robinson Point areas.

name: Reelfoot Lake State Park
description: Reelfoot Lake State Park has three hiking trails that are very popular and an auto tour that circles the lake. The Airpark Trail is a 45 minute walk through old cypress forest and second growth vegetation. The Keystone Trail winds along the shoreline of Reelfoot Lake for 1.5 miles and is the only lakeshore trail. The Black Bayou Trail goes along the old bayou for approximately 2 miles and is an excellent bird watching and wildlife observation walk. The Auto Tour visits 12 points of interest and circles Reelfoot Lake.

name: South Boundary (164)
description: South Boundary (164) features 22 miles of hiking trails near Taos, NM.

name: Copan Lake
description: About 4,850 acres of water is impounded behind this dam on the Little Caney River. The Corps also holds fee to approx. 12,000 acres of land around the lake that is available for a variety of recreational uses including hunting,& hiking.

name: Devisadero Loop (108)
description: Devisadero Loop (108) features 5 miles of hiking trails near Taos, NM.

name: Bledsoe Creek State Park
description: Bledsoe Creek State Park is a 164-acre park located on the Bledsoe Creek embayment of the Old Hickory Resevoir. Activities here include boating, fishing, hiking and camping.

name: Skiatook Lake
description: Gentle rolling hills of Blackjack and Post Oak interspersed with Tall Grass Prairie surround beautiful Skiatook Lake. The meandering shoreline is accentuated be steep picturesque bluffs which offer spectacular views for the recreation user. Boating, hiking, swimming, camping, picnicking as well as hunting and fishing are all popular activities at the lake. Whitetail, quail, rabbit and squirrel are plentiful around the lake and some 6,000 acres are open to hunters wishing to pursue these species. Sport fishing also offers many hours of enjoyment for the visitor. Largemouth bass, black and white crappie, channel catfish, and several species of sunfish are plentiful in Skiatook Lake.

name: Stone Mountain State Park
description:
Stone Mountain is not immediately visible upon entering the park that bears its name, but this magnificent 600-foot granite dome is well worth the wait. Sunlight and shadows dance across a broad tapestry of stone. White-tailed deer emerge from the security of the forest to graze on meadow grasses at the mountain's base. The scenery is only one attraction of the park.<br />
There are 7 beautiful trails to explore here: Stone Mountain Loop Trail, Cedar Rock Trail, Wolf Rock Trail, Black Jack Ridge Trail, Middle Falls/Lower Falls Trail, Widow's Creek Trail, and Bridle Trail. These trails range from 4.5 miles to just .5 miles and cover summits, granite outcrops, scenic woods, waterfalls, and creeks.

name: Angel Fire Resort
description: Angel Fire Resort features 22 miles of hiking trails near Angel Fire, NM.

name: Kaibab Trail
description: Kaibab Plateau South features 19 miles of hiking trails near Fredonia, AZ.

name: Black River Recreation Area
description: The 1,200-acre Black River Recreation Area is managed to provide low-impact recreation and environmental education opportunities while maintaining a healthy river system and riparian habitat. This river corridor acts as a transition zone between the limestone foothills of the Guadalupe Escarpment and the southern gypsum soils to the east. Several spring-fed pools within the area comprise the headwaters of the Black River. The area includes a series of deep, elongated pools interconnected by a shallow, narrow stream.

name: Mount Jefferson State Natural Area
description: An investment of little more than an hour's time offers a high return as the beauty and diversity of the park are best seen while hiking along its trails. Spectacular views of the surrounding countryside and a closer look at the park's vegetation are just a small part of the rewards reaped from a walk in this mountain forest.

name: CDT NM28: US Hwy 84 to NM Hwy 110
description:
Segment 28 of the CDT runs 22.8 miles from US Hwy 84 to NM Hwy 110. The majority of this section is legitimate trail, although one small portion is routed along a road. <br />
Along the way this trail passes Mogote Ridge, the Canjilon Meadows Trail, and Mogote Peak.

name: Wild Rivers Recreation Area
description: Trails are steep and hiking can be strenuous.  Good physical condition, sturdy shoes, and plenty of drinking water are necessary.

name: Sabinoso Wilderness
description: The Sabinoso Wilderness is a remote area in the northeastern portion of New Mexico.  The Wilderness includes a series of high, narrow mesas surrounded by cliff-lined canyons.  The rugged country primarily supports piÌ±on pine and juniper woodlands with occasional clusters of ponderosa pine.  A perennial warm season grass savanna is found on the mesa tops.  Streams periodically flow in the canyon bottoms supporting riparian vegetation including willow and cottonwood.  The deep canyon area, surrounded by the wide-open New Mexico plains, is unique for this region.  The deep incisions cut by CaÌ±on Olguin, CaÌ±on Largo, and Lagartija Creek create a striking topographical and geological contrast in this otherwise flat terrain.

name: Red River Wild and Scenic River
description: The La Junta Trail is 1å_ miles one-way with an elevation drop of 800 feet.  It is a difficult trail that provides spectacular views of and access to the confluence of the Red River and RÌ_o Grande. El Aguaje Trail is a moderate å_ miles one-way trail with an elevation drop 560 feet to the Red River.

name: Kaweah Lake
description: Horse Creek Campground has interpretive trails.

name: Pigeon Creek National Recreational Trail
description: Pigeon Creek National Recreational Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Mountain Home, AR.

name: Slaughter Pen Trail
description: Slaughter Pen Trail  features 5 miles of hiking trails near Bentonville, AR.

name: Temple Trail
description: An historic wagon road of the 1870s linking the sawmills of the Mt. Trumbull area to St. George, Utah. Much of the rough-milled lumber cut from the Uinkaret Mountains was hauled to St. George for the building of the Mormon Temple. Much of the trail is still visible, some of it traversable with automobiles, most of it passable only with 4-wheel drive vehicles, horses, or hiking. Some sections are located on private land. The trail is sporadically marked on public lands from the Mt. Trumbull area to just southeast of St. George, Utah.

name: Valley of Fire State Park
description: Valley of Fire State Park is Nevada's oldest and largest state park. It opened in 1935 and has been a very popular site ever since.  The park's most popular activities include camping, hiking, picnicking and exploring. The park is named for the red sandstone formations that mark the park. It has a fairly pleasant climate year-round.

name: Merchants Millpond State Park
description:
Merchants Millpond State Park is the home of aged cypress trees, spanish moss and a coastal swamp area. This is one of North Carolina's rarest ecological communities. Canoeing, fishing, camping, picnicking and hiking through the enchanting area are all popular activities here.<br />
The park offers nine miles of trail with a variety of habitats. Merchants Millpond is heavily infested with ticks during warm weather months; be cautious while hiking. Insect repellent may help prevent a tick bite and the possibility of disease.

name: Fisher River Park
description:
Fisher River Park features 4 miles of hiking trails near Mount Airy, NC. <br />
The trail switches between exhilarating singletrack and wide open fire roads. There are quite a bit of ups and downs throughout the trail. For the most part this trail stays within the shelter of the woods, but at one point it does lead you up to a beautiful mountain top.<br />
This trail is a multi-use trail and has become very popular among mountain bikers, so please use caution on the trail.

name: Moore's Springs Trails
description:
Moore's Springs Trails features 6 miles of hiking trails near Danbury, NC.<br />
This trail system is made up of 3 loops: the 'Original Loop,' the 'Major Tom to Ground Control,' and the 'Land of the Lost.' Original Loop is the easiest our of all three, while Major Tom has the most climbing. There are beautiful creek crossings under the vast forest canopy, but watch out for mountain bike traffic.

name: Beacham Trail
description: Beacham Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Eureka Springs, AR.

name: Dam Overlook
description: Dam Overlook features 4 miles of hiking trails near Eureka Springs, AR.

name: Mayo River State Park
description:
Mayo River State Park is a 1, 967-acre area that is great for picnicking, hiking, fishing (with N.C. fishing license only) and relaxing. There are a few hiking loops, picnic shelters and ponds on the property for your convenience.

The park offers a .5-mile hiking loop and a 1.8-mile hiking loop.

name: Paris Landing State Park
description: The park's self-guided trail system is three miles long and consist of two trails ranging from easy to moderate. If that's not enough, over 100 miles of trail are nearby at Land Between the Lakes

name: Kerr Lake State Recreation Area
description:
Set a course for Kerr Lake State Recreation Area to enjoy sailing, fishing, water skiing and camping. This 50,000-acre, man-made lake is a haven for water sports enthusiasts and landlubbers alike. The lake is situated in the northeast corner of the Piedmont region and lies in both Virginia and North Carolina. The recreation area's headquarters are located north of Henderson at Satterwhite Point. More than 800 miles of wooded shoreline provide access to a variety of fun-filled activities on the lake.<br />
Bullocksville, Satterwhite Point and Hibernia areas have nature paths offering a closer look at the environment.

name: Pea Ridge National Military Park
description:
The park's hiking trail is seven miles long and goes through both natural and historic areas of the park. If you are not interested in hiking the entire trail there are several shorter loop trails, accessible from tour stop 7.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Boiling Springs State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Death Valley National Park
description:
There are few constructed trails here, but in a place this desolate you usually don't need them. Most hiking routes in the park are cross-country, up canyons, or along ridges. Although footing can be rough and rocky (wear boots), and dry falls may need to be scaled, thick brush is uncommon.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Garrapata State Park
description:
Rocky Ridge Trail quickly leaves Highway 1 behind and offers far-reaching views of the Santa Lucia Mountains and the sea. A grand loop of the state park can be made by returning to the trailhead via redwood-lined Soberanes Canyon.

Soberanes Canyon Trail stays close to the creek and enters the redwoods. Western sword fern, redwood sorrel, blackberry bushes and Douglas iris decorate the path.

name: Standing Stone State Park
description: Standing Stone State Park offers over 8 miles of day-use hiking trails, providing access to some of the park's loveliest areas. Trails range from easy to strenuous and pass into virgin woods, through vivid wildflowers and over-flowing streams, and around beautiful Standing Stone Lake. Remember, all plants, animals and natural features are protected. Please leave them for others to enjoy!

name: West Rim, Rio Grande Gorge
description: West Rim, Rio Grande Gorge features 18 miles of hiking trails near Taos, NM.

name: Appalachian Trail 032: Tenn 91 to US 421
description: Section 32 of the AT runs 7 miles from TN Hwy 91 to US 421. Along the way it passes Double Springs shelter.

name: Dismal Swamp State Park
description:
Feel your daily stresses melt away as you cross the historic Dismal Swamp Canal and walk along the 2000-foot boardwalk into this geological wonder. Experience first hand the lush swamp forest and get up-close and personal with the wide variety of wildlife.<br />
For the adventurer, there are 18 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails, some along former logging roads. Or, enjoy a leisurely paddle down the Dismal Swamp Canal in your canoe or kayak.

name: Big South Fork
description: Big South Fork features 10 miles of hiking trails near Oneida, TN.

name: Bull Shoals Lake
description: Hiking trails in the Lakeview Area.

name: Warriors Path State Park
description: The trails traverse through woods and field areas with the degree of difficulty ranging from easy to moderate. Please wear fluorescent orange when hiking during hunting seasons.

name: Warriors' Path State Park
description: Warriors' Path State Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Kingsport, TN.

name: Rotary Park
description: Rotary Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Clarksville, TN.

name: Eagle Nest Lake State Park
description: The park is surrounded by the stunning scenery of the high mountains of the Moreno Valley. The lake at 8,300' elevation is a cool retreat from summer heat or a winter wonderland.

name: The Channels Natural Area Preserve
description: The Channels Natural Area Preserve is 721 acres of interesting sites to see. It is an area of significant high elevation forest and has quite a few rather large sandstone boulders and eroded crevices. It is located with a larger state forest and has hiking and sightseeing available to visitors.

name: CDT NM29: NM Hwy 110 to Hopewell Lake (US Hwy 64)
description:
Segment 29 of the Continental Divide Trail runs 28.3 miles from NM Hwy 110 to Hopewell Lake (US Hwy 64). The majority of this segment is routed along roads, but one portion of it is actually legitimate trail.<br />
Along the way this segment passes Canjilon Mountain, Quartzite Peak, Tusas Mountain, and Burned Mountain.

name: Westwood Park
description: Westwood Park is a wooded site with nature trails, two lighted ballfields, playground equipment, fitness stations, disc golf (9 holes), mountain bike trails, community fishing pond, shelter, restroom facilities and paved parking.

name: Pickett State Park
description: More than 58 miles of hiking trails meander through the wilderness of Pickett State Park and the surrounding forest.  They vary in length and difficulty, from short day-use trails suitable for families, to longer multi-day backpacking trails.  A backcountry camping permit is required through the park office.  The trails afford views of sandstone bluffs, natural bridges, waterfalls and diverse plant life. Please leave them for others to enjoy!

name: Bernice Area at Grand Lake State Park
description: The park also features a one mile paved walking and jogging path that is handicapped accessible.

name: Cimarron Canyon State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Sgt. Alvin C. York Historic Park
description: The trail at Sgt. Alvin C. York Park is an easy hike that is .6 mile long crossing over a swinging bridge and up a set of steps leading to the grave-site of Sgt. Alvin C York.

name: Birch Lake Park
description: Birch Lake Park consists of about 1,137 acres of water. It is feed from Birch Creek in Osage County and the available activities here include swimming, boating, fishing, hiking, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Appalachian Trail 033: US 421 to Damascus
description:
Section 33 of the Appalachian Trail runs 14.5 miles from US 421 in Tennessee to the town of Damascus in Virginia. Along the way it passes Little Mountain and Abingdon Gap.<br />
If you are north bound, please pick up the trail descriptions in Virginia. (Or click here.)

name: Grand Gulf State Park
description: Two trails provide spectacular views of the gulf.

name: New River State Park
description:
Rugged hillsides, pastoral meadows and farmlands surround what is believed to be one of the oldest rivers in North America the New River. Its waters are slow and placid. Its banks are fertile and covered with wildflowers. Dedicated as a National Scenic River in 1976, this gentle river is the centerpiece of New River State Park.<br />
There are 6 miles of trails that reach throughout this State Park, all of them relatively short and easy, but the terrain ranges from hikes along ridges to paths that follow the river.

name: Dunbar Cave State Park
description: There are three trails on the natural area that range from a leisurely walk to a fairly strenuous hike. All trails begin and end at the visitors' center.

name: Morris State Park
description: Wind through Crowley's Ridge on Beech Tree Trail.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Southern California: H
description:
Section H of the PCT trail runs 175.8 miles from Mt. Whitney to Tuolumne Meadows and Highway 120. Mt. Whitney is the highest point on the entire Pacific Crest Trail with an elevation of 14,491 feet. In fact, it's the highest point in the lower 48 states! According to the official PCT guidebook, many backpackers agree that this section of the Pacific Crest Trail has some of the finest mountain scenery in the United States! Much of this section of the PCT follows the massively-popular <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/323/Hiking-Trails/John-Muir-Trail.html">John Muir Trail</a>.

Along the way the trail passes Sandy Meadow; Wallace Creek; Wright Creek; Forester Pass; Vidette Meadow; Bubbs Creek Canyon; Bullfrog Lake; the town of Independence, CA; Glen Pass; Rae Lakes Ranger Station; Arrowhead Lake; Dollar Lake; Woods Creek; Pinchot Pass; Lake Marjorie; South Fork Kings River; Mather Pass; Upper and Lower Palisade Lakes; Deer Meadow; Middle Fork Kings River; Helen Lake; Muir Pass; Evolution Creek; Evolution Lake; McClure Meadow; South Fork San Joaquin River; Lakeshore, CA; Senger Creek; Sally Keyes Lakes; Heart Lake; Selden Pass; Rosemarie Meadow; Mono Creek; Lakeshore, CA; North Fork Mono Creek; Silver Pass; Lake Virginia; Purple Lake; Deer Creek; Upper Crater Meadow; Mammoth Lakes, CA; Boundary Creek; Reds Meadow, Rainbow Falls-Fish Valley-Cascade Valley Trail; Minaret Creek; Middle Fork; Ansel Adams Wilderness; Thousand Island Lake; Island Pass; Donohue Pass; Lyell Fork; and Tuolumne Meadows, CA.

name: Port Royal State Park
description:
The Overlook Trail is a short stroll along the top of the bluff to overlook the Red River and the bottom below. This trail is of moderate difficulty and about 100 yards long.

The Trail of Tears is an original, preserved section of the Trail of Tears certified by the National Park Service. This trail is about 300 yards long and is rated easy.

The River Bottom Trail connects to the Trail of Tears and provides a leisurely walk through a forested river bottom. This trail is .6 miles long and rated easy.

name: Sheltowee Trace
description: The Sheltowee Trace trail is a 307 mile-long long distance backpacking trail. It runs through "Daniel Boone National Forest, Big South Fork NRRA, and Natural Bridge, Cumberland Falls, & Pickett State Parks in Kentucky and Tennessee," according to sheltoweetrace.com. But almost 100% of the trail is in Kentucky.

name: Honey Creek Resort and State Park
description: Several miles of multi-purpose trails.

name: Honey Creek Area at Grand Lake State Park
description: While enjoying your stay in Grove, be sure to check out the two-mile walking path through the park, which is especially beautiful in the spring when the Dogwood and Redbud trees are in full bloom.

name: Clayton Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Steele Creek
description: Steele Creek features 21 miles of hiking trails near Bristol, TN.

name: Knights Path
description: Knights Path features 6 miles of hiking trails near Clarksville, TN.

name: Rainbow Rim Trail
description: Rainbow Rim Trail features 19 miles of hiking trails near Fredonia, AZ.

name: White River Valley
description: White River Valley features 11 miles of hiking trails near Branson, MO.

name: Table Rock State Park
description: Table Rock State Park is a 356-acre area on the Table Rock Lake in Missouri. Camping is very popular, specifically for its convenient location next to the lake. Mountain biking, scuba diving, hiking, fishing and swimming are also very common here. A few trails on the property add up to about 15 miles of hiking. The views and terrain are diverse.

name: Indian Mountain State Park
description: The park has two walking trails (one paved and one unpaved). Contact the park for more information on the trails.

name: Dale Hollow Lake
description: Plenty of excellent trails.

name: Roaring River State Park
description:
Roaring River State Park is well-known for its trophy trout fishing in additional to other recreational activities including camping, lodge vacationing, swimming, dining, hiking, interpretive programming and picnicking. The 4,000-acre park is a scenic landscape made up of rolling hills and blue springs.

The hiking here is exceptional with seven different trail options for your enjoyment. Combined, the trails make up about 10-12 miles in length. Each trail is scenic and unique in its own way.

name: Fort Ord Public Lands
description: Fort Ord Public Lands features 18 miles of hiking trails near Monterey, CA.

name: Fort Ord Public Lands
description: Fort Ord Public Lands features 18 miles of hiking trails near Monterey, CA.

name: False Cape Natural Area Preserve
description: False Cape Natural Area Preserve is a one-by-six mile stretch of land between the Atlantic Ocean and Back Bay. This is a home to many state-rare plants and animals with two-dozen rare species having been found here. Activities here include hiking, biking and camping.

name: Cumberland Gap National Historic Park
description:
There are over 85 miles of hiking trails in the park ranging from short, easy 1/4 mile hikes to the 21 mile Ridge Trail. Backcountry trails lead to remote, wilderness areas. Backcountry camping is allowed in designated sites with a permit. Permits are free of charge and can be obtained at the park visitor center.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail: Virginia
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs for 550.3 miles through the state of Virginia, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3325/Tennessee/Appalachian-Trail--Tennessee.html">Tennessee</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3335/West-Virginia/Appalachian-Trail--West-Virginia.html">West Virginia</a> border. Virginia contains more of the Appalachian Trail than any other state.<br />
To get detailed information about each section of the AT in Virginia, click on the links to the individual trail listings below.

name: Asilomar State Beach
description: Three self-guided nature trails with audio available.

name: Grayson Highlands State Park
description: 9 trails lead to panoramic vistas, scenic waterfalls and a 200 year old pioneer cabin.

name: Fort Ord National Monument
description: The Fort Ord National Monument  offers world-class recreation for residents and visitors to the Central California Coast.  Lands of the former Fort Ord offer 86 miles of trail on approximately 7,200 acres - open every day from dawn to dusk for hikers, mountain bikers, horseback riders, wildlife/wildflower photographers and nature enthusiasts.  Visitors can choose to walk or ride the narrow single track trails atop the grassland hills or the generous winding trails through oak woodlands and maritime chaparral.

name: Oologah Lake
description: Excellent trails.

name: Occoneechee State Park
description: About 3.1 miles of walking trails wind through woodlands throughout the park. A one-mile self-guided interpretive trail takes visitors through a terraced garden and land where Occonneechee Plantation once was. The park also has a 15-mile round trip multi-purpose linear trail for hiking, biking and horseback riding.

name: Grayson Co. Rec Park Trail
description: Grayson Co. Rec Park Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Independence, VA.

name: Appalachian Trail 034: Damascus to US 58
description:
This section of the AT begins at the town of Damascus, VA, crosses US 58 rather quickly, passes the Saunders shelter, crosses Whitetop Laurel Creek passes the Lost Mountain shelter, and finally ends on US 58.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: "US 58" lat=36.6449726645, lon=-81.7362875001<br />
<br />
If you are south bound, pick up the AT trail descriptions in Tennessee. (Or click here.)

name: El Vado Lake State Park
description: Excellent multi-use trails.

name: Wilderness Road State Park
description: Wilderness Road Trail, an 8-mile hiking, biking and equestrian trail. Indian Ridge Trail, a self-guided, natural heritage trail.

name: Virginia Creeper Trail
description: Virginia Creeper Trail features 35 miles of hiking trails near Abingdon-Damascus, VA.

name: Big Sugar Creek State Park
description: A hiking trail winds through the Elk River Breaks Natural Area for those who want to enjoy the beauty and solitude of the area.

name: Appalachian Trail 035: US 58 to Elk Garden
description: Section 35 of the AT runs 7 miles from the junction with US 58 to Elk Garden.

name: Big Oak Tree State Park
description: Two trails, including a boardwalk, take you past some of the large trees in the park.

name: Panoche Hills
description: Hilltops over 2,500 feet high offer scenic vistas of the lush San Joaquin Valley and spectacular Sierra Nevada Mountains.  The Panoche Hills was once part of a vast inland sea.  Fossils found include vertebrates such as mosasaurs, plesiosaurs, and marine turtles. Visitor service improvements are now complete at the new day use facility, which features a parking area, a shade structure, picnic benches, a vault toilet, and a kiosk providing an interpretive panel, a map, and information about the area.

name: Appalachian Trail 036: Elk Garden to VA 603
description: Section 36 of the Appalachian Trail runs 17 miles from Elk Garden to VA Hwy 603. Along the way it passes the Thomas Knob shelter, Wise Shelter, and Old Orchard Shelter.

name: Iron Mountain
description: Iron Mountain features 8 miles of hiking trails near Damascus, VA.

name: Rio Grande Wild and Scenic River
description:
The RÌ_o Grande Wild and Scenic River, located within the RÌ_o Grande del Norte National Monument, includes 74 miles of the river as it passes through the 800-foot deep RÌ_o Grande Gorge. Flowing out of the snowcapped Rocky Mountains in Colorado, the river journeys 1,900 miles to the Gulf of Mexico. Here the river flows in a rugged and scenic part of northern New Mexico.
The RÌ_o Grande Wild and Scenic River provides a wide variety of recreational opportunities, luring anglers, hikers, artists, and whitewater boating enthusiasts. Two developed recreation areas are located along the river: Wild Rivers on the north and Orilla Verde in the south. In addition to these scenic recreation areas, a spectacular vista of the gorge is seen from the High Bridge Overlook where highway 64 crosses.

name: New River Trail State Park
description: New River Trail State Park features 51 miles of hiking trails near Galax, VA.

name: Heron Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Navajo National Monument
description:
Three Mesa Top Trails Behind Visitor Center Always Open<br />
<br />
Sandal Trail: paved trail leads top overlook of Betatakin/Talastima cliff dwelling (1-mile round trip).<br />
<br />
Aspen Trail: branches off Sandal Trail to descend 300 feet to view ancient aspen forest (0.8-mile round trip).<br />
<br />
Canyon View Trail: view of head of Betatakin Canyon; leads to campground (0.6-mile round trip)<br />
Free permit/reservation needed to hike to Keet Seel, call 928-672-2700.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Rinconada Loop
description: Rinconada Loop features 6 miles of hiking trails near Questa, NM.

name: New River Trail State Park
description: New River Trail is a 57-mile linear park that follows an abandoned railroad right-of-way. The park parallels the scenic and historic New River for 40 miles and passes through four counties. The trail's gentle slope makes it great for visitors of all ages to hike, bike and ride horseback. Several places in the park provide horse, canoe and bike rentals, boat launches and gift shops. Fishing is popular, and primitive camping sites dot the trail. The park hosts a horse arena, and guided horseback trips are available. There are access points to the trail at Allisonia, Cliffview, Draper, Foster Falls, Fries, Galax, Ivanhoe and Xaloy (near Pulaski). Horse trailer parking is available at Allisonia, Cliffview, Draper, Fries, Foster Falls and Xaloy.

name: Marina State Beach
description: Dune Nature Trail, a 0.3 mile interpretive pathway, explores the dune ecosystem. The trail is mostly a wooden boardwalk linked with "sand ladders." Signs identifying the &#64258;ora and a great view of the Monterey Peninsula add to the walk's enjoyment.

name: Natural Tunnel State Park - Lover's Leap
description: This is one of eight hiking trails at Natural Tunnel State Park. The Lover's Leap trail was named after two lovers, a Shawnee and a Cherokee, who supposedly jumped off a cliff into the gorge because they were not allowed to be married. This trail is .4 mile long and of moderate difficulty. It follows the rim of the gorge providing excellent views. There are many switchbacks and stairs to climb to get to the cliff.

name: Appalachian Trail 037: VA 603 to Dickey Gap
description: The Appalachian Trail runs 8.5 miles from VA Hwy 603 to Dickey Gap on this, the 37th section of the trail. Along the way it passes the Hurricane shelter.

name: Staunton River State Park
description: Six wooded trails provide miles of hiking along the Dan and Staunton rivers as well as Buggs Island Lake.

name: Rio Chama Wild and Scenic River
description: Excellent hiking and backpacking area.

name: Natural Tunnel State Park
description: Natural Tunnel State Park has seven walking trails.

name: Natural Tunnel State Park
description: There are 8 different hiking trails here at Natural Tunnel State Park, and plenty of things to see! Click on the individual trail listings below for more detailed information.

name: Natural Tunnel State Park - Boardwalk
description: This is a 500-foot boardwalk and observation deck that provides accessibility to guests with disabilities. You may ride the chairlift, when operable, to the mouth of the tunnel.

name: Natural Tunnel State Park - Carter Log Cabin
description: This is one of eight different hiking trails within Natural Tunnel State Park. It is a short, easy, .13 mile trail that takes you to an old cabin in the woods. The cabin was built as part of Carter's Fort in 1748. It is believed to be the oldest house in Scott County, Virginia. It follows a creek and is a very simple trail. The cabin is open and you can walk inside.

name: Wild Rivers Recreation Area
description: Trails are steep and hiking can be strenuous.  Good physical condition, sturdy shoes, and plenty of drinking water are necessary.  For more information on other trails in the recreation area, please stop by or call the visitor center.

name: Wild Rivers Backcountry Byway
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Soap Creek Trail
description:
Soap Creek Trail is located in northern Arizona in the Vermilion Cliffs National Monument. The trailhead is located off Highway 89A, about eight miles west of Marble Canyon.
This primitive trail follows Soap Creek Canyon to the Colorado River in Marble Canyon. It is a difficult but popular hike among day hikers and fisherman due to the natural scenery and access to the Colorado River. This trail is 2.2 miles long. The best season of use is during the spring and fall.
There are no fees or permits required. Ropes will be needed to ascend boulder jams created by flooding. All ropes must be removed after individual use. Please be careful as there is no first aid is available in the immediate area. The nearest reliable first aid is at Lee's Ferry (National Park Service). The nearest hospital is in Page, AZ, 45 miles away.

name: Natural Tunnel State Park - Spring Hollow
description: The Spring Hollow Trail is a .28 mile, moderate hike that winds downhill through some woods on a narrow path alongside Stock Creek. It brings you to the northern entrance of the natural tunnel. The trail ends just inside the tunnels mouth.

name: CDT NM30: Hopewell Lake (US Hwy 64) to Lagunitas Campground
description:
Segment 30 of the CDT runs 17.7 miles from Hopewell Lake (US Hwy 64) to Lagunitas Campground. This section is almost all legitimate trail. <br />
Along the way the trail passes Jawbone Mountain.

name: Appalachian Trail 038: Dickey Gap to Brushy Mountain
description:
The AT runs for 14.5 miles here between Dickey Gap (VA Hwy 650) and Brushy Mountain.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 670" lat=36.7631583985, lon=-81.4931564817

name: Angel Peak Scenic Area
description: While formal hiking trails in the area are limited, dispersed hiking opportunities abound along the rim.

name: Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness
description: Great trails.

name: Osage Hills State Park
description: Osage Hills State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Bartlesville, OK.

name: Great Salt Plains State Park
description: There are nature trails to enjoy while taking in the scenery.

name: Chub Sandhill Natural Area Preserve
description: Chub Sandhill Natural Area Preserve borders the Nottoway River for almost five miles and is a 1,066-acre natural preserve. IT is rich in rare plant life and offers a short hike for people to observe this rare habitat.

name: Pine Mountain State Resort Park
description: Pine Mountain is a hiker's paradise with 12 miles of self-guided trails. Hike to Chained Rock, the Hemlock Garden or various other trails with names like Honeymoon Falls, Rock Hotel, and Timber Ridge. The new Pine Mountain State Scenic Trail, will pass near the park when completed.

name: Difficult Creek Natural Area Preserve
description: Difficult Creek Natural Area Preserve is a 818-acre preserve that has remained much the same even since pre-settelment times. This area is extremely rich in all sorts of vegetation and has clay rich soils. Hiking is the only allowed activity here due to the fragility of the environment.

name: Kaw Lake
description: The lake covers 17,000 surface acres and has 168 miles of shoreline at the normal elevation of 1010.00 feet above sea level. Ground breaking ceremonies were held in May 1966 and impoundment of the reservoir occurred in 1976.
