Construction on the recreation facilities concluded in July of 1980 with the completion of the Osage Cove Public Use Area. There are nine public use areas and two lake access points located around the lake for visitors to enjoy. Campers can select from over 300 family campsites, many of which are equipped with water and electric hookups.

name: Merced River Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Indian Valley Reservoir Recreation Area
description: The Kowalski trail offers the hiker 2.5 miles following the reservoir's west edge. You must cross the dam to access the trail.

name: Columbus-Belmont State Park
description: There is a 2.5-mile self-guided hiking trail in the Park. Dramatic images of the Civil War come to mind when walking on the bluffs and massive earthen works that formed the Confederate trenches.

name: Condon Peak Recreation Area
description: A trail leading up the Condon Peak summit can be accessed from the parking area.

name: Dumont Dunes Off-Highway Vehicle Area
description: Plenty of hiking opportunities. Rock-hounding and rock scrambling also popular.

name: Cedar Roughs Wilderness Area
description: Great hiking.

name: King Range National Conservation Area Trails
description: King Range National Conservation Area offers a wide range of hiking opportunities.

name: Uvas Creek Park Preserve
description: This 95 acre greenbelt preserve is operated by the City of Gilroy. The Uvas Creek, which meanders through the center of the preserve, is its defining characteristic. A paved trail runs for 1.9 miles along the boundary of the preserve.

name: Capulin Volcano National Monument
description:
Capulin Volcano National Monument offers a variety of activities for the visitor. With nearly five miles of hiking trails, visitors can experience a varied landscape. See the Rocky Mountains from the volcano top, or explore Capulin's very own lava flow at its base.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Road Apple
description: Road Apple features 10 miles of hiking trails near Farmington, NM.

name: Fairy Stone State Park
description: Known for its legendary fairy stones, Fairy Stone State Park contains a 168-acre lake that is a hotbed for fishing. Activities here include camping, swimming, hiking, mountain biking horseback riding, fishing and boating (electric only).

name: Paiute Wilderness Trails
description: Difficult trails, but well worth it.

name: Barkley Lake
description: Excellent hiking trails located throughout the area.

name: Indian River Park
description: Indian River Park features 3 miles of hiking trails near Chesapeake, VA.

name: Appalachian Trail 039: Brushy Mountain to Great Valley
description:
This section of the AT runs 11.5 miles between Brushy Mountain and Great Valley.<br />
Note: Google Maps location given is for the Mt. Rogers Headquarters and the Partnership Shelter on VA hwy 16 (recommended parking spot).

name: I.C. Dehart Trail System
description: I.c. Dehart Trail System features 8 miles of hiking trails near Wool Wine, VA.

name: Philpott Lake
description: Nestled in the rugged foothills within sight of the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia are the lake and surrounding public lands of Philpott Lake. The clear water and natural shoreline make Philpott Lake a unique place to visit. Over 6,000 acres of surrounding land, 3,000 acres of water, and a power plant make up Philpott Project located in portions of Franklin, Henry and Patrick counties. Congress authorized construction in 1944 for flood control and hydroelectric power generation as the primary purposes, and water supply and recreation as subsequent purposes.

name: The Whoops
description: The Whoops is a 9 mile hiking trail in Farmington, New Mexico.

name: Choinumni Park
description: Choinumni Park is located on the Kings River near Trimmer Springs on Pine Flat Road 31 miles east of Fresno. The park is 170 acres with a campground, fishing access, playground and a hiking trail.

name: Navajo Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Pine Flat Lake State Park
description: Kings River Canyon houses Pine Flat Lake and this area is definitely a California gem. This park is 5,790 acres and has hiking, swimming, fishing, boating, canoeing, kayaking, and camping.

name: Aztec Ruins National Monument
description:
Aztec Ruins provides visitors an intimate opportunity to explore the Ancestral Puebloan "great house" known as West Ruin. A self-guided 700 yard walk winds through rooms built centuries ago. Along the way discover skillful stone masonry, remarkably well-preserved wood roofing and original mortar in some walls. The interpretive trail guide combines modern archeological findings with traditional Native American perspectives to enhance the visitor experience.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail
description: Although the Anza Trail began in CuliacÌÁn, the portion of route established between Nogales, Arizona and San Francisco, California was designated by Congress as a National Historic Trail in 1990. The National Park Service (NPS) administers the trail, but works in partnership with federal, state, and local government agencies, as well as private landowners who manage or own lands along the trail route.

name: Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail
description: Although the Anza Trail began in CuliacÌÁn, the portion of route established between Nogales, Arizona and San Francisco, California was designated by Congress as a National Historic Trail in 1990. The National Park Service (NPS) administers the trail, but works in partnership with federal, state, and local government agencies, as well as private landowners who manage or own lands along the trail route.

name: Busiek State Park
description: Busiek State Forest and Wildlife Area features 10 miles of hiking trails near Springfield, MO.

name: Hack Canyon Trail
description: The trial provides access to Kanab Creek Wilderness and a route down to the Colorado River within the Grand Canyon National Park.

name: CDT NM31: Lagunitas Campground to the New Mexico/Colorado State Line
description: Section 31, the final section of the CDT in New Mexico, runs 19 miles from Lagunitas Campground to the New Mexico/Colorado Border. Unfortunately, the majority of this segment is currently routed along roads with just a few short sections of trail interspersed throughout. Along the way it passes the Brazos Ridge High Point and Osier Mesa.

name: Alien Run Trail
description: Alien Run Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Aztec, NM.

name: Staunton River Battlefield State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Hungry Mother State Park
description: More than 12 miles of trails are open year-round.

name: Hoffler Creek Wildlife Preserve
description:
Open Tuesday through Sunday 10 am to 4 pm<br />
Free parking and admission<br />
<br />
www.hofflercreek.org<br />
4510 Twin Pines Road <br />
Portsmouth, VA, 23703<br />
<br />
- Lake Trail encircles Lake Ballard <br />
- Riparian Trail winds through the woods between the central lake and the creek, bordering a wetland habitat <br />
- Bluebird Trail bisects a meadow and ends at a raised viewing platform overlooking the marsh and Hoffler Creek proper <br />
- Homestead Trail leads through woodland habitat and connects with a Spur Trail which ends at a large bird blind overlooking wetland habitat and another part of Hoffler Creek <br />
- Kids Trail cuts through more woods connecting pavilion with a raised lake viewing deck <br />
<br />
The preserve is 142 acres in size and the main Lake Trail loop is approximately one mile in length<br />
<br />
Kayak rentals available in warmer months<br />
10am-2:30pm, weather permitting. <br />
$10/hr ($5 for members) during the week<br />
$20/hr ($10 for members) on weekends<br />
Personal kayaks may be launched for a $5 weekday and $10 weekend fee (waived for members)<br />
<br />
No running, biking, pets, camping, hunting or fishing

name: Appalachian Trail 040: Great Valley to Rich Valley
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs 12 miles between Great Valley and Rich Valley

name: Lake Cumberland State Park
description: Lake Cumberland State Park is located on the Cumberland River but the Wolf Creek Dam pools the water together creating the reservoir known as Lake Cumberland. Activities here include mountain biking, hiking, swimming, fishing, boating, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Black Mesa State Park & Nature Preserve
description: Hikers need to be prepared for high temperatures during the summer and are advised to bring plenty of water.  Allow at least four hours to hike to the top of the mesa from the parking area and back.

name: Guest River Trail
description: Guest River Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near St. Paul, VA.

name: Paria Canyon Permit Area
description: Before highways and railways, before pioneers, even before Columbus.....the land we know as the United States was truly a vast wilderness. To protect these last remaining areas, in 1984 Congress created the Paria Canyon - Vermilion Cliffs Wilderness. Paria Canyon's outstanding scenery, desert wildlife, colorful history, and opportunities for primitive recreation will remain free from the influence of man and are protected in this condition for future generations. Its 112,500 acres beckon adventurers who yearn for solitude, scenic splendor, and the chance to explore one of the longest and deepest slot canyons in the world.

name: Wire Pass Trail
description: Elevation above sea level: 5,040 feet (1,536 meters). 44 miles (70.8 kilometers) to Lee's Ferry Trailhead. Wire Pass is also the main trailhead for Coyote Buttes North.

name: First Landing State Park
description: First Landing State Park features 12 miles of hiking trails near Virginia Beach, VA.

name: Lake Cumberland State Resort Park
description: Two trails offer excellent hiking.

name: Lake Wappapello State Park
description: Four trails wind through the park offering great views of the lake.

name: Old Spanish National Historic Trail
description: The trail takes its name from the old Spanish colonies in northern New Mexico and southern California that were linked by this rugged route. The Spanish outpost of Santa Fe, New Mexico was founded in the early 1600's and the pueblo of Los Angeles, California was founded in 1781. But it was not until 1829 when Santa Fe merchant Antonio Armijo led 60 men and 100 mules northward on the known trails blazed by native peoples that a suitable land passage between these colonies became established and regularly used. On the return trip, Armijo backtracked along the route Spanish padres Dominguez and Escalante recorded as they returned to Santa Fe from southern Utah more than fifty years earlier. Portions of both the Northern Route and the Armijo Route pass through the Bureau of Land Management's (BLM) Arizona Strip District.

name: Natural Bridges State Beach
description: Signed Monarch Trail begins near the park's small interpretive center. Soon the trail splits; the leftward fork leads to a monarch observation platform. Sometimes on cold mornings, the butter&#64258;ies look like small, brown, &#64258;uttering leaves. As the sun warms the tropical insects, the "leaves" come to life bobbing and darting. As many as 200,000 monarchs cluster in the state park on a "good" butter&#64258;y year. The other branch of the trail is a self-guided nature trail. It ends in a grove of Monterey pine.

name: Wappapello Lake State Park
description: Wappapello Lake State Park is a 45,000-acre park that sits in the foothills of the Ozark Mountains on the St. Francis River. Activities here include hiking, fishing, boating, swmming, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Laurel River Lake
description: Hiking trails located at Laurel River Damsite.

name: Sugarite Canyon State Park
description: Excellent multi-use trails.

name: Carrollton Nike Park
description: Carrollton Nike Park features 2 miles of hiking trails near Smithfield, VA.

name: Wickliffe Mounds State Historic Site
description: Woods Walk Trail - enjoy a leisurely walk through the woods here on a 200-yard loop trail. Views of seasonal wildflowers and bird watching opportunities available.

name: Seacliff State Beach
description: Take Seacliff Trail from New Brighton State Beach to Seacliff State Beach; longer beach walks possible.

name: Lost Lake Recreation Area
description: Excellent trails.

name: Wilder Ranch State Park
description: Wilder Ranch State Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Santa Cruz, CA.

name: Appalachian Trail 041: Rich Valley to Garden Mountain
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs 17 miles between Rich Valley and Garden Mountain. Along the way it passes the Knot Maul Branch and Chestnut Knob shelters.

name: Mount Trumbull Trail
description: The Mt. Trumbull trail quickly ascends the south slope of this high basalt-capped mesa. From the southern rim of the basalt cap, the trail ends and the final mile to the summit on the north edge of the mesa is trailless. Once atop the mesa the route to the summit passes through a beautiful forest of ponderosa pine. At the northern edge of the mesa, broad sweeping views of the heart of the Arizona Strip, as well as much of southern Utah, await the persistent hiker.

name: Old Growth
description: Old Growth features 5 miles of hiking trails near Aptos, CA.

name: Canal Loop
description: Canal Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Grand Rivers, KY.

name: Kingdom Come State Park
description: The 14 hiking trails that crisscross nearly 5 miles of rugged mountain terrain provide the opportunity to explore the park's giant rock formations and scenic overlooks. All of the trails are fairly short in length (1/8-7/8 mile), but many trail routes may be combined for hikes of varying lengths and difficulty. A trail guide publication is available at the park. Trails are open year-round.

name: Continental Divide Trail: Colorado
description:
The Continental Divide Trail is 3,100 miles long, stretching from Mexico to Canada and roughly following the continental divide. It is a part of the Triple Crown of long distance hiking trails in the US, along with the Pacific Crest Trail and Appalachian Trail. It is still under construction, so sections of it are constantly changing. The information posted here on Tripleblaze is the most up-to-date available, but these trail descriptions and GPS locations may become obsolete at some point in the future. If you notice any obsolete information, always feel free to post a review with the new info!

Whenever possible, the Google Maps location given for each section of trail will be for the most southern point. All sections are numbered in a south-to-north fashion.

The Colorado section runs for approximately 650 miles from the New Mexico border to the Wyoming border, traveling the high-altitude mountains through the wilds of the Colorado Rocky Mountains.

To follow the trail to the south, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3196/New-Mexico/Continental-Divide-Trail--New-Mexico.html">New Mexico section</a>. To follow the trail to the North, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3203/Wyoming/Continental-Divide-Trail--Wyoming.html">Wyoming section</a>.

name: CDT CO01: New Mexico Border to Blue Lake AP
description:
Section one of the Continental Divide Trail in Colorado runs 30.3 miles from the New Mexico border, past Cumbres Pass (and the trailhead there), past Three Lakes, Past Dripping Lakes, and it ends at a trailhead near Blue Lake.<br />
The Google Maps location given is for the point where the CDT crosses the New Mexico/Colorado Border. A better parking spot would be further north at Cumbres Pass: lat=37.01797644, lon=-106.450062146<br />
Or you could park at the northern end of this section: lat=37.238152, lon=-106.628989

name: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area
description:
Whether you're just looking for a quick walk, a day hike, or a multi-day backpack trip, Glen Canyon has something to offer. <br />
<br />
The hikes listed here are only the beginning. If you are out camping on the shores of Lake Powell or anywhere in the backcountry you are welcome to explore the many side canyons, slickrock hills, and passageways through washes into slot canyons or hanging gardens. Just stay safe.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Ozark National Scenic Riverways
description:
The hills and forests of the Ozark National Scenic Riverways area invite the hiker. In addition, all dirt roads and old traces are open to hiking, and except for horseback riders, there won't be much traffic. Many trails leave the park and cross private or state lands. Please respect others' rights.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Sheltowee Trace - Laurel Lake Trail
description: Sheltowee Trace - Laurel Lake Trail features 11 miles of hiking trails near London, KY.

name: Cane Creek (sheltowee Trace Trail)
description: Cane Creek (sheltowee Trace Trail) features 10 miles of hiking trails near London, KY.

name: Christmas Hill Garlic Ride
description: Christmas Hill Garlic Ride features 9 miles of hiking trails near Gilroy, CA.

name: Navajo State Park
description:
Hikers may enjoy several designated trails throughout the park. There are also miles of outstanding areas to hike along the San Juan River.<br />
Nature Trail- this 1,008 ft. dirt trail winds along the lake and is not appropriate for biking.<br />
Rosa Trail- this 3,460 ft. dirt trail circles Rosa Campground, overlooking the lake and marina.<br />
Windsurf Beach Trail- this 6,024 ft gravel trail extends from the Visitor Center, along the old railroad grade which overlooks the lake, to Windsurf Beach primitive campground.<br />
Piedra Trail- this 5,063 ft. gravel trail continues from Windsurf Beach primitive campground along the Piedra arm of the lake, and then climbs to views above the river itself. It is the first segment of a trail that will eventually reach all the way to Arboles Point primitive campground at the confluence of the San Juan and Piedra Rivers. Some spots may be somewhat steep for biking.<br />
Sambrito Wetlands Trail- this 3,534 ft gravel trail circles part of the Sambrito Wetlands Area of the park. The far end of the loop overlooks the San Juan River Valley and part of the lake in the distance.

name: Seven Sisters
description: Seven Sisters features 5 miles of hiking trails near Wytheville, VA.

name: The Forest of Nisene Marks State Park
description: Forest Of Nisene Marks & Soquel Demonstration Forest features 30 miles of hiking trails near Santa Cruz, CA.

name: Millerton Lake State Recreation Area
description: Hikers heading for the hills surrounding the lake will &#64257;nd grassland, chaparral and oak woodland environments. The best hike is South Shore Trail, sometimes called Winchell Ridge Trail, which follows the contours of Winchell Bay on its way to the Marina at Winchell Bay. The trail extends some four miles from Blue Oak Camp Picnic Area to its end a bit past the marina. Because the &#64257;rst half of the trail closely parallels the road (on the inland side of the road no less), most hikers will &#64257;nd the second half of South Shore Trail more satisfying and begin the walk at South Bay Picnic Area.

name: Chitactac-Adams County Park
description: Interpretive trails.

name: Camp Horizon
description: Camp Horizon is a 10 mile hiking trail in Arkansas City, Kansas.

name: Sullivan Canyon Trail
description: The Sullivan Canyon non-motorized route is a 15-mile long, one-way route through the Paiute Wilderness Area. The route runs from the ridgeline near Mount Bangs down into the Virgin River Gorge Canyon.

name: Coyote Buttes Permit Area
description: Before highways and railways, before pioneers, even before Columbus.....the land we know as the United States was truly a vast wilderness. To protect these last remaining areas, in 1984 Congress created the Paria Canyon - Vermilion Cliffs Wilderness. Coyote Buttes' outstanding scenery, desert wildlife, colorful history, and opportunities for primitive recreation will remain free from the influence of man and are protected in this condition for future generations. Its 112,500 acres beckon adventurers who yearn for solitude, scenic splendor, and the chance to explore one of the most beautiful geologic formations in the world.

name: Pennyrile Forest State Resort Park
description: Bring your camera, because the photo opportunities are limitless on the nature trails. Seven trails loop around the lake and through the forest areas and are rated from easy to difficult in hiking ability.

name: Pacheco State Park
description: Spikes Peak, South Boundary, Canyon Loop, and Pig Pond Trails run to Spikes Peak  constituting a 5.5 miles round trip with 500-foot elevation gain.

name: South Boundry Loop
description: South Boundry Loop features 15 miles of hiking trails near Los Banos, CA.

name: South Boundry Loop
description: South Boundry Loop features 15 miles of hiking trails near Los Banos, CA.

name: South Boundry Loop
description: South Boundry Loop features 15 miles of hiking trails near Los Banos, CA.

name: Claytor Lake State Park
description: Claytor Lake State Park contains the 4,500-acre Claytor Lake is a perfect getaway for day use or overnight stays. The park itself is 472 acres and three miles of lake frontage. Activities here include hiking, boating, camping, swimming, canoeing, kayaking and fishing.

name: Lake Maury
description: Lake Maury features 10 miles of hiking trails near Newport News, VA.

name: Pachecho Falls
description: Pachecho Falls features 25 miles of hiking trails near Gilroy, CA.

name: Appalachian Trail 042: Garden Mountain to US 21
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs for 15 miles between Garden Mountain and US 21. Along the way it passes the Jenkins Shelter and VA hwy 615.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 615" lat=37.1027324444, lon=-81.2022060515

name: Lake Malone State Park
description: Discover the beautiful landscape of Lake Malone State Park on the mile and one-half Laurel Trail or the quarter mile Wildflower Trail. These easy-rated hiking trails provide picturesque views of many rock walls, once used as shelters by prehistoric Native Americans. Mountain laurel, holly, dogwood, and wildflowers provide a rich tapestry of native flora.

name: Coyote Lake-Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description: The Bear and Mendoza Ranch sections of the park have 35 miles of hiking, biking and equestrian trails that wind through oak studded canyons; and on top of grassy ridgelines, providing spectacular views of southern Santa Clara Valley. Trailheads can be found in all three sections of the park.

name: Rainbow Bridge National Monument
description:
You may backpack to Rainbow Bridge across Navajo Nation lands. A permit from the Navajo Nation is required. You may write to: Navajo Nation, Parks and Recreation Department, Box 9000, Window Rock, Arizona 86515.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: San Joaquin River Trail
description: This scenic area straddles the San Joaquin River just upstream from Millerton Lake State Park Recreation Area and includes lands in Fresno and Madera Counties. The management area is bounded by Kerckhoff Reservoir and the Sierra National Forest on the eastern boundary. Hikers, bicyclists and horseback riders who use the San Joaquin River Gorge trails have access to several thousand acres of public land.

name: The Toadstools
description: The trailhead is located on Hwy. 89, 45 miles east of Kanab, 12 miles west of Big Water, or 1.5 mile east of the Paria Contact Station. There are no signs marking the trailhead. A short access road on the north side of the highway leads to a hiker's gate in the fence line. A power pole near the fence is a good landmark. Visitors should park near the hiker's gate. This is a moderate 1.5 mile round trip hike. A trailhead register is located a short distance from the fence. Follow the wash and a well defined social trail to view the hoodoos. Exploration in the general area will reveal other hoodoos and balanced rocks. Cryptobiotic soil crusts are prevalent in the area and should be avoided when exploring off trail. Return to the trailhead the way you came.

name: Levi Jackson Wilderness Road State Park
description: Between 1774 and 1796, more than 200,000 pioneers traveled over the Wilderness Road and Boone's Trace during the settlement of Kentucky. Today, visitors to the park can retrace the footsteps of the early pioneers on eight-and-one-half miles of hiking trails that include original portions of these historic throughways.

name: Uvas Canyon County Park
description: The park has six miles of hiking trails including a one mile Waterfall Loop that travels along Swanson Creek past many of the park's waterfalls.

name: Bearclaw Poppy
description: Bearclaw Poppy features 11 miles of hiking trails near St. George, UT.

name: Crackers Neck
description: Crackers Neck features 8 miles of hiking trails near Radford , VA.

name: Smith Mountain Lake State Park
description: There are 13 hiking trails ranging from half a mile to three miles long. Trails meander through the park's various features, including hardwood forests, pine forests, secluded coves and picturesque vistas. They are open year-round during daylight hours.

name: Barrel Ride
description: Barrel Ride features 0 miles of hiking trails near St. George, UT.

name: Little Black Mountain Petroglyph Site
description: Little Black Mountain Rock Art Site has a trail which is a half-mile, easy hike designed to see most of the rock art on site. The surfaced trail winds its way over the rust-colored soils of the Moenkopi Formation through the Little Black Mountain Rock Art Site. The trail provides access to petroglyph viewing areas and platforms overlooking hundreds of rock art designs.

name: Mount Logan Trail
description: The short hike to the summit of Mt. Logan is worth the brief effort. To the south and west are majestic views of portions of the western Grand Canyon and Arizona Strip. The Pine Valley Mountains, Virgin Mountains, and scenic portions of southern Utah are also visible in the far distance.

name: Virgin River Gorge Nature Trail
description: Enter the Virgin River Canyon Recreation Area and park at the top of the hill where the campground loop roads split.  This surfaced trail climbs 40 feet to the crest of a desert shrub-covered hill that commands an impressive view of the heart of the Virgin River Gorge.  Interpretive plaques at the summit display historic, geologic, and other information of interest.

name: Harvey Bear Trail
description: Harvey Bear Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near San Martin, CA.

name: Frisco Highline Trail
description: Frisco Highline Trail features 35 miles of hiking trails near Springfield, MO.

name: Wilson's Creek National Battlefield
description:
A 7-mile trail system for horseback riding and hiking is accessible from the tour road. Parking is available in the Visitor Center parking area as well as at each of the eight interpretive stops.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Hensley Lake
description: Excellent hiking opportunities.

name: North Fork of Pound River Lake
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Clearwater Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout area.

name: Twin Lakes State Park
description: Six miles of trails for hiking take the visitor through hardwood forests and near the lakes.

name: Appalachian Trail 043: US 21 to VA 608
description:
The A.T. runs for 13 miles here between US 21 and VA Hwy 608. Along the way it passes the Helveys Mill shelter, VA hwy 611, and the Jenny Knob shelter.<br />
Recommended parking location: "VA 612" lat=37.1394932505, lon=-81.1199009857

name: AÌ±o Nuevo State Park
description: Seal-viewing is allowed only on guided walks, which can be pre-booked at http://anonuevo.reserveamerica.com/

name: Chippokes Plantation State Parks
description: Great hiking.

name: Fort Massac State Park
description: The park contains a 1- mile loop trail through grassy woods with the trailhead near the fort. This trail is designated as a Forest Watch Tree Identification Trail and brochures are available in the visitors' center. The 2.5-mile Hickory Nut Ridge Trail shouldn't be missed, as it takes hikers along the scenic Ohio River.

name: Trinidad Lake State Park
description: There's so much to see on Trinidad's trails! Ten miles of trails reward eager explorers wanting to learn, exercise or conduct nature study. Several trails are ADA-accessible. Sights range from open vistas, to grasslands, forests, cliffs and ponds. Cold-weather enthusiasts can enjoy hiking all winter.

name: Rancho Canada Del Oro
description: Rancho Canada Del Oro  features 10 miles of hiking trails near Morgan Hill, CA.

name: Appalachian Trail 044: VA 608 to Mouth of Dismal Creek
description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail runs 5 miles from VA Hwy 608 to Dismal Creek. It climbs Brushy Mountain along the way.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 606 (Dismal Creek)" lat=37.17009837, lon=-80.9021640942

name: Gooseberry Mesa
description: Gooseberry Mesa features 14 miles of hiking trails near St. George, UT.

name: John H. Kerr Dam and Reservoir
description: Trails located throughout area.

name: Kiptopeke State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Anderson Lake County Park
description: Hikers, runners, bicyclists, and skaters can enjoy the multiple use paved trail which follows Coyote Creek north for fifteen miles to Coyote Hellyer County Park. This asphalt path is relatively flat and meanders along the creek underneath Oak, Cottonwood and Sycamore trees.

name: Anderson Lake County Park
description: Hikers, runners, bicyclists, and skaters can enjoy the multiple use paved trail which follows Coyote Creek north for fifteen miles to Coyote Hellyer County Park. This asphalt path is relatively flat and meanders along the creek underneath Oak, Cottonwood and Sycamore trees.

name: Anderson Lake County Park
description: Hikers, runners, bicyclists, and skaters can enjoy the multiple use paved trail which follows Coyote Creek north for fifteen miles to Coyote Hellyer County Park. This asphalt path is relatively flat and meanders along the creek underneath Oak, Cottonwood and Sycamore trees.

name: Henry W. Coe State Park
description: Henry W. Coe State Park features 9 miles of hiking trails near Morgan Hill, CA.

name: Grand Bench Trail
description: The name of this rugged 36,300-acre wilderness in northwest Arizona refers to the two sets of steep cliffs separated by a bench. The lower cliffs rise 1,600' (488m) above the Mojave desert floor and are dissected by several deep, narrow canyons. When viewed from the west, the upper cliffs form a dramatic backdrop to the wilderness area by abruptly climbing another 1,800' (549m). As its name implies, the Grand Wash Bench Trail travels along the bench between the two sets of cliffs from the north boundary to the south end.

name: Appalachian Trail 045: Mouth of Dismal Creek to New River
description: Section 45 is a long one: 24.5 miles in length. It runs from the Mouth of Dismal Creek (VA hwy 606) to the New River Crossing. Along the way it passes the Wapiti shelter, Sugar Run Mountain, VA hwy 663 and Sugar Run Gap, and Doc's Knob shelter.

name: Big Basin Redwoods State Park
description: Trails range from easy to strenuous.

name: Quicksilver
description: Quicksilver features 5 miles of hiking trails near Los Gatos, CA.

name: Spruce Tree House Trail
description: Short hike down across a canyon to one of the cliff dwelling houses this park is famous for.  This is one of the easier to access houses that does not require climbing.

name: Almaden Quicksilver County Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Petroglyph Point Trail
description: A 2.4 mile loop starting at the Spruce Tree House, leading to petroglyphs and stunning canyon scenery.

name: Mammoth Cave National Park
description:
Mammoth Cave National Park preserves the cave system and a part of the Green River valley and hilly country of south central Kentucky. This is the world's longest known cave system, with more than 390 miles explored. The park is home to over 64 miles of trails ranging from nature trails to more advanced trails. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Calero County Park
description: The back country offers 18.6 miles of trails available to hikers.

name: Calero County Park
description: The back country offers 18.6 miles of trails available to hikers.

name: McCoy Hollow Trail
description: This is a narrow rocky trail through a dense forest. The path is mostly shaded by the trees which turn to gorgeous colors in Autumn. There are plenty of interesting rock outcroppings along the trail for you and the kids to climb on. It seems like there could be a cave under any one of them. Get ready to see some animals because this area is a wildlife hot spot.

name: Newport News Park
description: Newport News Park features 6 miles of hiking trails near Newport News, VA.

name: Lexington Reservoir County Park
description: Great trails.

name: J.E.M. Trail
description: Jem Trail features 21 miles of hiking trails near Hurricane, UT.

name: Snow Canyon State Park
description: Surrounded by Navajo sandstone, capped by an overlay of black lava rock, makes photography, hiking, biking and camping in Snow Canyon a double treat. Early spring and fall use of the park is especially appealing due to southern Utahs moderate winter climate. Two recent volcanic cones are found near the head of the canyon. This strikingly colorful canyon is 11 miles northwest of St. George.

name: John W. Flannagan Dam and Reservoir
description: Hiking trails  throughout area.

name: Butano State Park
description: On the map, Butano State Park seems rather close to the bustling Santa Clara Valley, and to the Bay area. But this 2,800-acre park, tucked between sharp Santa Cruz Mountains ridges, has a remote feeling.

name: Santa Teresa Park
description: Santa Teresa Park features 6 miles of hiking trails near San Jose, CA.

name: Eastman Lake
description: Excellent hiking throughout area.

name: Santa Teresa County Park
description: The park offers over 18 miles of unpaved trails for equestrian, hiking and bicycle use.

name: Santa Teresa County Park
description: The park offers over 18 miles of unpaved trails for equestrian, hiking and bicycle use.

name: Rocky Ridge Trail
description: Rocky Ridge Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near San Jose, CA.

name: Telegraph Trail System - South
description:
Telegraph Trail System (south) is basically right in downtown Durango, making it a perfect place for a quick getaway! This network of loop trails will take you on switchbacks in and out of scenic canyons and along paths with low-lying desert scrub lining the trail. You'll also hike into wide open fields that showcase the mountains that surround you!<br />
These trails are multi-use and very popular with mountain bikers, so please share the trail!

name: Sam A. Baker State Park
description: Take a leisure walk or a challenging hike on one of four scenic trails.

name: Carr Creek State Park
description:
Carr Creek Lake was once home to some of the area's earliest pioneer settlements as early as the 1770s. Carr Fork, a tributary of the North Fork of the Kentucky River, is located 8.8 miles below Carr Creek Dam, and is thought to have gotten its name from William Carr, a well-known "Long Hunter" who hunted in the area.

There are nice hiking trails and interpretive hiking trails that run through this park. These trails are maintained for hikers only. If you get too hot on your hike, head down to Irishman Creek and take a dip at the beach!

name: Vasona and Los Gatos Creek County Parks
description: Hikers, runners, bicyclists, and skaters enjoy the Los Gatos Creek multiple use trail which begins at Lexington Reservoir and follows the Los Gatos Creek for nearly 14 miles through the Town of Los Gatos, Vasona Lake County Park, Los Gatos Creek County Park, and the cities of Campbell and San Jose.

name: Vasona and Los Gatos Creek County Parks
description: Hikers, runners, bicyclists, and skaters enjoy the Los Gatos Creek multiple use trail which begins at Lexington Reservoir and follows the Los Gatos Creek for nearly 14 miles through the Town of Los Gatos, Vasona Lake County Park, Los Gatos Creek County Park, and the cities of Campbell and San Jose.

name: Vasona and Los Gatos Creek County Parks
description: Hikers, runners, bicyclists, and skaters enjoy the Los Gatos Creek multiple use trail which begins at Lexington Reservoir and follows the Los Gatos Creek for nearly 14 miles through the Town of Los Gatos, Vasona Lake County Park, Los Gatos Creek County Park, and the cities of Campbell and San Jose.

name: CDT CO02: Blue Lake AP to Elwood Pass TH
description: The CDT trail runs for 24.4 miles from Blue Lake to the Elwood Pass Trailhead. Along the way it passes several high mountain passes, 13,300 foot Summit Peak, The Unicorn, Montezuma Peak, and Long Trek Mountain.

name: Sanborn County Park
description: For experienced hikers, Sanborn Park has over 15 miles of trails that showcase the geographic features of the park. The Lake Ranch Trail offers a shaded, easy hike between Lake Ranch and Black Road.

name: Sanborn County Park
description: For experienced hikers, Sanborn Park has over 15 miles of trails that showcase the geographic features of the park. The Lake Ranch Trail offers a shaded, easy hike between Lake Ranch and Black Road.

name: Sanborn County Park
description: For experienced hikers, Sanborn Park has over 15 miles of trails that showcase the geographic features of the park. The Lake Ranch Trail offers a shaded, easy hike between Lake Ranch and Black Road.

name: Petersburg National Battlefield
description:
Hiking and bicycle trails can be found at both the Eastern Front (Main) Unit and the Five Forks Battlefield Unit. Outdoor exhibits are located near these trails which will help you understand the historic significance of Petersburg National Battlefield.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Pandapas Pond Trails
description: Pandapas Pond Trails features 7 miles of hiking trails near Blacksburg, VA.

name: Mill Mountain Trails
description: Mill Mountain Trails features 8 miles of hiking trails near Roanoke, VA.

name: Saratoga Gap
description: Saratoga Gap features 10 miles of hiking trails near Saratoga, CA.

name: Mesa Verde National Park
description:
Hiking in Mesa Verde National Park is restricted and allowed only on designated trails. Visitors may not enter cliff dwellings unless accompanied by a uniformed park ranger. However there are several trails that total 20 miles within the park.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Berwind Lake Wildlife Management Area
description: Three designated trails, an overlook, and miles of unimproved logging and gas well roads

name: Coyote Creek Parkway
description: This scenic parkway meanders along Coyote Creek for 15 miles. The north portion features a paved multi-use trail popular with bicyclists, rollerbladers, and hikers. South of Metcalf Road, an equestrian trail parallels the paved trail. Public transit is available to Coyote Creek Parkway.

name: Coyote Creek Parkway
description: This scenic parkway meanders along Coyote Creek for 15 miles. The north portion features a paved multi-use trail popular with bicyclists, rollerbladers, and hikers. South of Metcalf Road, an equestrian trail parallels the paved trail. Public transit is available to Coyote Creek Parkway.

name: Coyote Creek Parkway
description: This scenic parkway meanders along Coyote Creek for 15 miles. The north portion features a paved multi-use trail popular with bicyclists, rollerbladers, and hikers. South of Metcalf Road, an equestrian trail parallels the paved trail. Public transit is available to Coyote Creek Parkway.

name: Telegraph Trails System - Horse Gulch
description:
Horse Gulch is a 6 mile loop within the Telegraph Trail System. The trail will take you through wide open meadows that highlight the stunning mountains that surround you. The trail also leads up rocky paths and through scrub "forests."<br />
This trail is multi-use and is popular with mountain bikers, so please share the trail.

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail
description: The Los Gatos Creek Trail offers recreational opportunities for walkers, jogger, bicyclists, skaters, non-motorized scooters, bladers and nature lovers. The trails is operated by the County of Santa Clara Park Department, City of Campbell, Town of Los Gatos and the City of San Jose. The trail passes through a number of jurisdictions. Visitors are responsible for all rules and regulations applicable to each jurisdiction. Another great amenity to the trail is the Los Gatos Creek dog park. With artificial turf it's able to withstand the many dogs that love this park. There's shade, seating and water.

name: Portola Redwoods State Park
description: The park centers around two creeks-Peters and Pescadero-which meander through a basin. Douglas &#64257;r and oaks cloak the ridges while redwoods, accompanied by huckleberry and ferns, cluster in cooler bottomlands.

name: Portola Redwoods State Park
description: The park centers around two creeks-Peters and Pescadero-which meander through a basin. Douglas &#64257;r and oaks cloak the ridges while redwoods, accompanied by huckleberry and ferns, cluster in cooler bottomlands.

name: Mermet Lake State Fish & Wildlife Area
description: The area has two trails. The nature preserve has a small å_-mile, interpretive trail with tree identification markers and a small boardwalk extending into the cypress swamp. Another nature area has a 1-mile interpretive trail with tree identification markers along the way.

name: Big Hill
description:
Big Hill is one of the clearest lakes in Kansas, located in what is known as Kansas' "Little Ozarks."

A hiking trails emerges out of the Mound Valley Campground, and explores the hickory forests and large prairies in the area.

Warning: most of this area is open to hunting.

name: Green River
description: Green River features 20 miles of hiking trails near Cambellsville, KY.

name: Green River Lake State Park
description: The parks offers 28-miles of multi-use trails for hiking and mountain biking. These trails offer great outdoor fun, exercise, and an opportunity to explore the natural beauty of Green River Lake

name: Sam McDonald Park
description: Hiking, jogging.

name: Heritage Grove
description: Heritage Grove Trail is open to pedestrians only. No horses are allowed on this trail.

name: Memorial Park
description: Over eight miles of hiking trails lead the visitor through a changing panorama of habitats from Pescadero Creek, through the woods and to the summit of Mt Ellen (elevation 600 feet). The self-guided Mt. Ellen Nature Trail offers a short and easy interpretive loop through the park's northern area.

name: Pescadero Creek Park
description: Pescadero Creek Park's approximately 26 miles of trails provides adventure for park visitors of all abilities.

name: Great Valley Grasslands State Park
description: By linking a couple of levee roads (closed to vehicles), hikers can fashion a six mile tour of the great grassland, as well as the willow- and cottonwood-lined San Joaquin River that winds slowly, in a series of sloughs and oxbows, through it.

name: Stevens Creek County Park
description: Hikers, bikers and equestrians may enjoy a variety of over 6 miles of single track and multi-use trails. Solitude may be found along many of the trails which connect with the Mid-Peninsula Open Space Fremont Older Preserve.

name: Upper Stevens Creek County Park
description: This 1,095 acre Santa Cruz mountain redwood park offers a wilderness experience for visitors interested in the park's mature stands of douglas fir and redwoods. The park is also popular with mountain bicyclists and for its 11 miles of  long hiking trails and valley vistas. This park offers lush, densely wooded trails for a variety of users. The unique combination of recreational resources and natural beauty make Upper Stevens Creek County Park a magnet for hikers, bicyclists, equestrians, and nature lovers.

name: Breaks Interstate Park
description: More than 25 miles of hiking trails lace the park, varying from easy to difficult. Most are less than one mile long, but interconnected trails offer the more ambitious hiker a good choice of routes over varying terrain. Maps with descriptions of each trail are available at the Visitor Center. Trail names give clues to the outstanding physical features of each: Cold Spring, Geological, Grassy Creek, Grassy Overlook, Lake, Loop, Overlook, Prospectors' Ridge, River, Towers, and Tower Tunnel. Both the Ridge and Geological trails are self-guided, with booklets available at the Visitor Center that detail points and notes of interest. But if you would prefer, guided hikes are scheduled throughout the summer. Additionally, if you call ahead, our Visitor Center staff will be happy to plan a guided hike to meet your family's or group's schedule.

name: Hellyer County Park
description: Multi-use paved trail.

name: Overend Mountain Park
description: Overend Mountain Park is a 5 mile hiking trail in Durango, Colorado.

name: New Quarter Park
description: There are a series of small hiking trails and loops in the park.  The mountain bike trail offers approx. 6 miles of forested, blazed trails with expert areas for bikers.  The looped Hiking trails offer a couple view points and some historical information stands.

name: Brockover Mesa - Outer Loop
description:
Pass by ponds, forests, meadows, cattle fields, and creeks on the beautiful Brockover Mesa--Outer Loop Trail. The trail shifts between singletrack and logging roads, and provides stunning views in multiple spots. It's a great day hike to just enjoy the outdoors.<br />
This is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

name: Brockover Mesa - Canyon Rim Loop
description:
This scenic trail is a part of the Turkey Springs/Brockover Mesa Mountain. The trail follows the Martinez Canyon Rim and provides beautiful views all along the trail. There are some creek crossings and meadows along this fairly easy trail as well. This is a perfect day hike to see a lot of beautiful views without too much strenuous work.<br />
This is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

name: Brockover Mesa
description: Expansive network of trails up the mountains from Pagosa Springs in the San Juan National Forest.

name: Sac River Trail
description: Sac River Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Springfield, MO.

name: Fremont Older
description: Fremont Older features 0 miles of hiking trails near Cupertino, CA.

name: Breaks Interstate Park
description: Breaks Interstate Park is a 4,600-acre state Park shared by Kentucky and Virginia. This is one of the most versatile and adventurous state parks in Virginia or Kentucky offering some of the most amazing Appalachian views. Activities here include camping, hiking, fishing, boating, canoeing, kayaking, mountain biking and horseback riding.

name: Sailor's Creek Battlefield Historic State Park
description: There are two short hiking trails. One (.1 miles) leads to the battlefield monument. The Confederate Overlook Trail (.8 miles), which leads to Sailor's Creek, enables visitors to observe the Confederate position during the battle.

name: Nolin Lake State Park
description: A 1.6 mile hiking trail is open year-round that has a small waterfall when the conditions are right. This trail is a moderate exercise so please ensure that you have proper hiking shoes and water.

name: Praeter Ridge Trail
description:
This trail is a 7.8 mile loop that starts and ends in the Morefield Campground area.<br />
The trail takes you along a ridge until you reach the top of the mountain. From the top you get stunning views of the surrounding area.

name: Grapevine Lake  A&b
description: Grapevine Lake  A&b features 4 miles of hiking trails near Madisonville, KY.

name: Animas City Trail
description: Animas City Trail climbs 1,500 feet in just 3 miles, making it a difficult trail, but great for a serious workout. The trail is well-maintained and leads you up to beautiful views of downtown Durango. Check out views of the Animas Valley and Turtle Lake as well on this scenic loop trail.

name: Knife Edge Trail
description:
A 2 mile out and back trail with views of the Knife Edge (8290 feet). Starts and ends at the Morefield Campground area.<br />
This is a fairly easy hike that skirts around the cliff face and provides stunning views of the Sleeping Ute mountain and Cortez.

name: Buckhorn Lake
description: Buckhorn Lake is found in a very rugged area in eastern Kentucky. It lies in the Cumberland Plateau and has opportunities for camping, hiking, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and swimming.

name: Falling Creek Park
description: Falling Creek Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Bedford, VA.

name: Nolin River Lake
description: Nolin River Lake has an average annual visitation of over two million and maintains one of the lowest drowning rates in the State. Known for its unique blue/green water, Nolin is one of the top five lakes in Kentucky for catfish, bass, crappie, and walleye fishing. The majority of the path Nolin River follows is located within the boundary of Mammoth Cave National Park, making for very scenic canoe trips.

name: Highway 87 Trail
description: Highway 87 Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near San Jose, CA.

name: Bullet Canyon
description: To access the canyon drive 7 miles south of the Kane Gulch Ranger Station on State Highway 261 and turn right. This dirt road (County Road 251) takes you 1.5 miles to the trailhead. The trail is moderately difficult.

name: Grand Gulch
description: Grand Gulch is a popular area for hiking and backpacking to see Ancestral Puebloan cliff ruins and rock art in a natural setting.

name: Lookout Tower Trail
description: Great trail for families and kids.  Starts out with a paved entrance and quickly leads to a wooded trail and the lookout view point.  The rest of the trail follows the edge of the reservoir.

name: Pinnacle Rock State Park
description: Pinnacle Rock State Park is becoming a favorite area to hike and bike. There are several trails to choose from between Pinnacle Rock and Jimmy Lewis Lake. The park now has over seven miles of hiking and biking trails.

name: Freedom Park (aka:district Park)
description: Freedom Park (aka:district Park) features 5 miles of hiking trails near Yorktown, VA.

name: Monte Bello Open Space
description: Monte Bello Open Space features 6 miles of hiking trails near Palo Alto, CA.

name: Lick Wash
description: Best as a day hike. Can be combined with other routes for a longer backpacking trip. This route can be used by horses. 4 miles one-way to junction with Park Wash.

name: Dry Fork Trail
description:
This 9 mile trail winds through the beautiful forests of Durango. Aspens shade this trail, and create a great atmosphere for a relaxing hike. All along the trail there are beautiful views of the surrounding area, which make this hike incredibly scenic. It does tend to get crowded, even on the weekdays, but don't let that stop you from enjoying the trail!<br />
This is a multi-use trail, so please practice trail etiquette.

name: Rancho San Antonio County Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Colorado Trail / Junction Creek
description:
This route is the southwestern terminus of the famous Colorado Trail. It's a great out-and-back from the Junction Creek Trailhead, or keep going and you can backpack for days.<br />
This well-maintained, and at times popular, trail will keep you climbing for 9 miles up the mountain until you reach a high point. Enjoy the views from up there because you'll have earned them!

name: Cache River State Natural Area
description: More than 18 miles of designated foot trails exists within Cache River State Natural Area. Other than Little Black Slough Trail and Tupelo Trail which are considered moderate in difficulty, the trails are easy to walk. A 5-mile segment of the 45-mile-long Tunnel Hill State Trail passes through the region, providing expanded opportunities for hikers and cyclists. Paralleling the Karnak-Belknap Road on its northern side, the Tunnel Hill Trail links Little Black Slough, the Lower Cache unit and the Henry N. Barkhausen Cache River Wetlands Center. Trail length is based on round trip distances.

name: Appalachian Trail 046: New River to Stony Creek Valley
description:
This section of the AT runs 19.4 miles from the crossing of the New River in Pearisburg to Stony Creek Valley. Along the way it passes the Rice Field and Pine Swamp shelters.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 614" lat=37.3536920153, lon=-80.7655093318

name: Sand Canyon Trail
description: Sand Canyon contains many Ancestral Puebloan archaeological sites. The popular Sand Canyon Trail is 6.5 miles (one-way) from Sand Canyon Pueblo down to the lower trailhead in McElmo Canyon.

name: Klaus Park
description: Klaus Park features 3 miles of hiking trails near Cape Girardeau, MO.

name: Nathan Boone Homestead State Historic Site
description: Hike along the Interpretive Trail System.

name: Joseph D. Grant County Park
description: Joseph D. Grant County Park features 6 miles of hiking trails near San Jose, CA.

name: Roger Pryor Pioneer Backcountry
description: Roger Pryor Pioneer Backcountry is Missouri's largest undeveloped area at 60,000 acres. The area offers nearly 30 miles of hiking trails. This is the place to go for intense solitude and relaxation.

name: Phil's World
description:
Phil's World is a 10 mile loop trail located near Cortez, Colorado. Hike this well-maintained and well-marked singletrack through the desert. The trail passes low-lying desert shrubs as well as desert forests. <br />
This is a popular area for mountain bikers so please share the trail.

name: Appalachian Trail 049: Sinking Creek to Craig Creek Valley
description:
This section of the trail runs 11.3 miles from Sinking Creek Valley (VA hwy 42) to Craig Creek Valley (VA hwy 621). It climbs out of the first valley, follows the ridgeline for a long ways, and then descends into the second valley. Along the way it passes VA hwy 630, Sarver Hollow Shelter, and the Niday Shelter.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 630" lat=37.3514843774, lon=-80.3792072276

name: Candlers Mountain
description: Candlers Mountain features 25 miles of hiking trails near Lynchburg, VA.

name: Fish Slough Area of Critical Environmental Concern
description: Excellent hikes.

name: Montvale Trails
description: Montvale Trails features 7 miles of hiking trails near Roanoke, Va, VA.

name: Appalachian Trail 051: VA 624 to US 220
description:
Section 51 is a long one, as it runs 25.5 miles from VA Hwy 624 to US Hwy 220. It passes a number of places along the way, though: VA Hwy 785, VA Hwy 311 near the town of Catawba, Johns Spring Shelter, Catawba Mountain Shelter, McAfee Knob, Campbell Shelter, Tinker Mountain, and Lamberts Meadow Shelter.<br />
Recommended parking spot:"VA 311" lat=37.3801033629, lon=-80.0896480723

name: Appalachian Trail 050: Craig Creek Valley to VA 624
description:
This section runs 14.6 miles from Craig Creek Valley to VA Hwy 624. Along the way it passes Brush Mountain and Pickle Branch Shelter.<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given is a best-guess for the southern end of this section of trail.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 620" lat=37.3902832565, lon=-80.1960835423

name: Slickhorn Canyon
description:
Hiking in this canyon is rugged. The creek channel is frequently clogged with boulders, and there are many pour-offs and steep talus to be negotiated, challenging even the most experience hiker. Note that pets and stock animals are not allowed in Slickhorn Canyon or its tributaries.

At least four days should be allowed to hike the entire length of the canyon and explore the side canyons. The going is slow. Flash floods can occur at any time. Be aware of weather conditions, especially up-canyon from you.

name: Hovenweep National Monument
description:
The trail system at Hovenweep provides visitors excellent views of all the archeological sites. The Square Tower Group features a two mile loop that begins at the visitor center and is a perfect starting point for any visit. Between the visitor center and the first overlook (a distance of roughly 300 yards), the trail is paved and may be traversed by visitors in wheelchairs with assistance. Most visitors spend an hour exploring the area, with the full two-mile loop taking at least 1.5 hours.<br />
Visitors may also explore the outlying sites, which include Cajon, Cutthroat Castle, Goodman Point, Holly and Horseshoe/Hackberry. Most areas have very short (a half mile or less one-way) trails which are primitive and lightly maintained. Backpacking is not permitted at Hovenweep.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Pocahontas State Park
description: More than 52 miles of signed multi-use trails for bicycles and hikers, and the paved Spillway Trail for those with disabilities.

name: Carvin's Cove Trail system
description: Carvin's Cove Trail system features 30 miles of hiking trails near Roanoke, VA.

name: Arastradero Preserve
description: Arastradero Preserve features 8 miles of hiking trails near Palo Alto, CA.

name: Lake View Trail At Pocahontas
description: Lake View Trail At Pocahontas features 12 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Pocahantos State Park
description: Pocahantos State Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Appalachian Trail 048: Johns Creek Valley to Sinking Creek
description: This section of the Appalachian trail runs 7.4 miles up and over the ridge between Johns Creek Valley and Sinking Creek Valley. (Running between VA hwy 632/USFS 156 and VA hwy 42.) Along the way it passes Rocky Gap on VA hwy 601 and the Laurel Creek Shelter.

name: Alum Rock Park
description: Alum Rock Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near San Jose, CA.

name: Appalachian Trail 052: US 220 to Black Horse Gap
description:
Section 52 runs 13.5 miles from US 220 to Black Horse Gap on the Blue Ridge Parkway. Along the way it passes the parking lot at US Hwy 11, Fullhart Knob, Fullhart Knob Shelter, Wilson Creek Shelter, and Blue Knob.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "US 11" lat=37.4037335852, lon=-79.8898617428

name: Holliday Lake State Park
description: The park has five hiking trails and one aquatic trail. Lakeshore Trail is a 6.3-mile hiking trail that loops around the lake and the Holliday Lake 4-H Educational Center, passing through a hardwood forest, wetlands and managed pine plantation. Saunders Creek Trail provides access from the campground to the picnic area and is .1-mile in length. Dogwood Ridge Trail is a .7-mile loop that starts across from the Redbud campground. Northridge Trail is .4-miles and provides a ridge top walk from the picnic area to the northern end of Holliday Lake and hooks up with the Lakeshore Trail. The Sunfish Aquatic Trail is a self-guided water adventure that requires a boat and free trail brochure. A brochure map and numbered stop's provide information about the lake and environment as you paddle or peddle around its edges. The trailhead for Carter Taylor Connector Trail is next to the amphitheater.

name: York River State Park
description: More than 25 miles of hiking, mountain biking and equestrian trails allow visitors to explore the marsh, river shoreline and forests.

name: Mancos State Park
description: Most trails located in Mancos State Park are single-track and suitable for mountain bike use. Winter conditions can make trails unsuitable for biking. Mancos trails connect to numerous U.S. Forest trails and the Denver-to-Durango Colorado Trail. http://www.coloradotrail.org/.

name: CDT CO03: Elwood Pass to Wolf Creek Pass
description: Section 3 of the CDT in Colorado runs for 17.6 miles from Elwood Pass to Wolf Creek Pass. Along the way it passes Bonito Pass, Silver Mountain, Silver Pass, the Wolf Creek Ski Area, and Alberta Peak.

name: Lake Glendale
description: Lake Glendale features 13 miles of hiking trails near Golconda, IL.

name: Wunderlich Park
description: Wunderlich Park offers numerous trails, some for horseback riding and hiking, and some for just hiking. Trails run along gulches and creeks, others traverse unique hillside habitats and lead you to breathtaking views of the countryside. Learn more about specific Wunderlich trails below.

name: Dody Ridge
description: Dody Ridge is a 12 mile hiking trail in Roanoke, Virginia.

name: Panther Wildlife Management Area
description: Miles of connecting trails and unimproved roads are open for hikers and walkers.  All gated roads are open to foot traffic.  Map and trail guides are available at the office.

name: Tunnel Hill State Trail
description: Tunnel Hill State Trail stretches for 45 miles from Harrisburg to Karnak. The trail continues on a trails spur for 2.5 miles from Karnak to Cache River State Natural Area - Henry Barkhausen Wetlands Center on the old Chicago and Eastern Illinois railroad bed. The 9.3-mile section between Tunnel Hill and Vienna crosses trails already known to outdoor recreationists: the River-to-River Trails, which extends from the Mississippi to the Ohio River; the unmarked American Discovery Trails, which in southern Illinois follows back roads and some of the River-to-River Trail; the U.S. 76 Bicycle Route, a part of the TransAmerica Bike Route; and the Trail of Tears, the primary route the Cherokee Indian tribe took in the winter of 1838-39 during their forced move from the Great Smokies to Oklahoma.

name: Appalachian Trail 047: Stony Creek Valley to Johns Creek Valley
description: This section of the AT runs 13.2 miles from Stony Creek Valley (VA hwy 365) to Johns Creek Valley.

name: Peaks View Park
description: Peaks View Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Lynchburg, VA.

name: Dragon's Back
description: Dragon's Back features 12 miles of hiking trails near Salem, VA.

name: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space
description: El Corte de Madera Creek Open Space Pres features 20 miles of hiking trails near Woodside, CA.

name: Dameron Marsh Natural Area Preserve
description: Dameron Marsh Natural Area Preserve 316 acres of protected land that lines the shore of the Chesapeake Bay. This site is very rich in wildlife diversity and is even home to some endangered species. Activities here include hiking, canoeing and kayaking.

name: Appalachian Trail 053: Black Horse Gap to Bearwallow Gap
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail parallels the Blue Ridge parkway for 8 miles from Black Horse Gap to Bearwallow Gap. Along the way it passes Montvale Overlook, Harvey's Knob Overlook, Bobblet's Gap Shelter, Sharptop & Peaks of Otter Overlook, and Mills Gap.

name: Alviso Marina County Park
description: Great trails.

name: Fishtrap Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout area.

name: Huddart Park
description: Many miles of trails afford even the experienced hiker many hours of pleasure. Many of the trails are also open to equestrian use, making this park one of the favorite destinations of the local equestrian community.

name: Ed Levin County Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Ed Levin County Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Purisma Creek
description: Purisma Creek features 9 miles of hiking trails near Woodside, CA.

name: Rockwood Park
description: Rockwood Park is a 2 mile hiking trail in Richmond, Virginia.

name: Zion National Park
description:
Hiking in canyons, even short hikes, requires advance planning. Many hikes involve walking in water. Rivers and washes are subject to flash flooding. Know the weather and flash flood potential forecasts before starting your trip. The forecasts are posted daily in park visitor centers. Many canyons require ropes, hardware, and advanced technical skills for rappelling and ascending.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Trail of Tears State Park
description: The 3,415-acre Trail of Tears State Park helps visitors to better understand the history of the American Indians' relocation to Oklahoma. The visitor center has many exhibits and interpretive programs that walk you through this era of American history. Bird watching, camping, fishing, picnicking, horseback riding, hiking, boating, swimming and metal detecting are other popular activities here. The park's four hiking trails  equal about 15 miles in length. The trails take you through historic homesteads. Each trail is a different level of difficulty.

name: Penitencia Creek
description: Welcome to Penitencia Creek County Park. This 78-acre linear park and regional trail incorporates parklands and open space from a number of agencies including Santa Clara County, the City of San Jose and the Santa Clara Valley Water District. This four-mile trail follows Penitencia Creek from the 700-acre Alum Rock Regional Park (City of San Jose) to its confluence with Coyote Creek. The trail is incomplete at this time, however, a majority of the trail is developed and is open to public use and enjoyment.

name: Volcanic Tablelands
description: The Volcanic Tablelands is a vast volcanic landscape that was formed over 700,000 years ago by materials spewing from the Long Valley caldera, located to the northwest.

name: Burleigh H. Murray Ranch
description:
The current trail consists of the old ranch road winding its way alongside Mills Creek for about one mile up to a 1930's bungalow that serves as a park residence.

At this point the trail veers off the road and bends down to cross the creek allowing the visitor to look back in time while viewing the Mills Barn and surrounding outbuildings.

name: Indian (1300)
description:
The Indian Creek Trail #1300 trailhead is located on the north side of the Bear Lake Campground. This trailhead is a multi user trail system and accesses 23 miles of motorized trails available for ATV, motorcycle, bicycle, foot and horse use.<br />
Follow these scenic ATV trails through the thick mountain forests and overlook the beautiful Spanish Peaks across in the east and the high Sangre de Cristos in the southwest. Remember to share the trail!

name: Whiskey Trail
description: Whiskey Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near Mckee, KY.

name: Cave-In-Rock State Park
description: In addition to the natural splendor of the cave itself, the park contains two established hiking trails of moderate difficulty, plus numerous unmarked trails for exploration and appreciation of tranquil forests and inspiring views.

name: Willis Creek
description: Hikers must be cautious if hiking here during flash flood season, especially in the narrows. Hikers should carry adequate amounts of water. 2.2 miles one-way to junction with Sheep Creek.

name: Edgewood Park & Natural Preserve
description: Edgewood Park and Natural Preserve contains ten miles of trails that explore its varied habitats. Most are open for equestrian use. The Sylvan Loop and Trail, the only path in the park that isn't open for equestrian use, is a popular jogging and hiking trail.

name: Trail of Tears State Forest
description: The fire trails are open all year for hiking. There are hiking trails at the Forest, including one designed for cross country running. Other trails pass through hills and valleys where one can appreciate the lush vegetation and abundant wildlife.

name: CDT CO04: Wolf Creek Pass to South River Peak
description: The CDT trail runs for 19.5 miles between Wolf Creek Pass on US Hwy. 60 and South River Peak. Along the way the trail passes Mount Hope and traverses many high-alpine ridges and mountain sides.

name: Appalachian Trail 054: Bearwallow Gap to Jennings Creek Road
description: Section 54 of the Appalachian Trail runs from Bearwallow Gap (VA Hwy 43) to Jennings Creek Road. Along the way it passes Cove Mountain and the Cove Mountain Shelter.

name: Fish and Owl Canyons
description:
The Fish and Owl Canyons are located in the Cedar Mesa area of Southern Utah. There is a day hike available from this area, or several overnight trails.
There is a fee of $2/person/day or $5/person for seven consecutive days. Overnight permits can be obtained from the Kane Gulch Ranger Station up the road.
In inclement weather the road to the trailhead can become impassable even for 4WD vehicles.

name: Mirada Surf
description: A .36 mile multi-use trail from Magellan Ave. to Surfers Beach provides an important link in the California Coastal Trail, a popular trail for sea-side strolls, jogs, or rides. Another trail leads from Highway 1 to Quarry Park through Mirada Surf East. A spur from this trail also leads to the residential neighborhood on Santiago Ave. All paths are open to hikers, joggers, equestrians, bicyclists and dogs on leash. Bicyclists must stay on the California Coastal Trail and park service roads only.

name: Boggy Draw Loop
description:
Boggy Draw Loop offers 9 miles of beautiful singletrack through scenic forests and meadows. This day hike will take you under tree cover and then out into an open field where you can overlook the surrounding areas. The elevation doesn't change drastically, which makes it a nice, quiet day hike. <br />
This is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

name: Water Dog Lake Park
description: Water Dog Lake Park features 20 miles of hiking trails near Belmont, CA.

name: Camp Creek State Park
description: Several scenic trails are found on the park and the adjacent state forest. Trails are open to hikers, mountain bikers, and some are open for equestrian use.

name: Ohlone Regional Wilderness
description: The remote and beautiful wilderness areas of the Ohlone Wilderness are accessible only through the Ohlone Wilderness Trail. The Ohlone Trail traverses 28 miles of mountains and canyons in southern Alameda County and is open to hikers and equestrians. Trail bicycles and motor vehicles are not permitted.

name: Mission Peak Regional Preserve
description: Rising steeply to the east of the city of Fremont, Mission and Monument peaks form a dramatic backdrop to the South Bay. The determined and conditioned hiker who reaches the top of Mission Peak will be rewarded with views of Mount Hamilton to the south, the Santa Cruz Mountains to the west, Mt. Tamalpais to the north, and Mt. Diablo and the Sierra Nevada to the northeast. This is a very popular park, particularly on weekends, with hundreds of visitors attempting the 3-plus-mile hike to Mission Peak. About five hours are required to reach the summit and return. This parkland's 3,000 acres are accessible from parking lots at Ohlone College (slightly longer hike, but more gradual ascent; plenty of parking on weekends) or from a small staging area at the east end of Stanford Avenue in Fremont (steep climb to the summit; parking lot is extremely congested on weekends). There is no access to the park from Mill Creek Road.

name: Sunol Regional Wilderness
description: Please do not short cut trails in steep areas, or slide in the grass on hillsides or banks. Erosion is ugly and expensive to control.

name: Sunol Regional Wilderness
description: Please do not short cut trails in steep areas, or slide in the grass on hillsides or banks. Erosion is ugly and expensive to control.

name: Sunol Regional Wilderness
description: Please do not short cut trails in steep areas, or slide in the grass on hillsides or banks. Erosion is ugly and expensive to control.

name: Appalachian Trail 056: Parkers Gap Road to Petites Gap
description:
Section 56 of the AT runs 7 miles from the Parkers Gap Road parking area to Petites Gap. Along the way it passes Apple Orchard Mountain and Thunder Hill Shelter.<br />
Recommended parking location: "USFS 35 (Petites Gap)" lat=37.5594861311, lon=-79.4585577363

name: Road Canyon Trail
description: There is a day hike fee of $2.00/person/day or $5.00/person for seven consecutive days. An overnight permit may be obtained from the Kane Gulch Ranger Station. An annual day hike pass is also available for $20 from the Monticello Office or the Kane Gulch Ranger Station.

name: Collins Canyon to Grand Gulch Trail
description: Excellent segment of Grand Gulch network of trails.

name: Government Trail
description: The trailhead is 1.5 miles from the sign. It is 3.1 miles to the junction with Grand Gulch and the hike is easy to moderately difficult.

name: Kane Gulch
description: Several day hikes.

name: Powhite Park
description: Powhite Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Bluestone Wildlife Management Area
description: Bluestone Wildlife Management Area features 0 miles of hiking trails near Hinton, WV.

name: Kodachrome Basin State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Beaver Dam State Park
description:
The park's trails offer all levels of hiking experience. See incredible views of the canyon from the vantage point high on the Overlook Trail. From there is a 360-degree view of the park; to the north, the remnants of Hamblin Ranch, and also where Headwater and Pine creeks merge forming Beaver Dam Wash, and to the south, the Beaver Dam Wash canyon that directs the streams to Littlefield, Arizona and into the Virgin River. Access this loop trail at the southern end of Campground B. The ascent to the viewpoint is a moderate hike.

From the Oak Knoll Trail, go for an easy hike and bring a fishing pole because this trail descends to the stream bank where there are rainbow trout. This easy trail is southeast of the campgrounds. Follow the park road south about .5 miles, turn left at the Oak Knoll sign onto the spur road and park at the gate.

The Waterfall Trail offers streams, warm springs and waterfalls that drew the Civilian Conservation Corps to this part of the park during its stay in 1934-35. Visitors can explore the pond and natural Jacuzzi - remnants of days-gone-by. Hiking the trail offers visitors a glimpse into the past and incredible scenery. This easy-to-moderate trail is near the southern boundary of the park.

name: Forest Hill Park
description: Forest Hill Park features 2 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Pipestem Resort State Park
description: Twenty trails are maintained for your exploration. Hike year-round at Pipestem.

name: Prairie State Park
description: Prairie State Park is a 3,942-acre area of grasslands and woodlands. The park is a preservation of the prairie land that once covered Missouri. The park offers exhibits and interpretive programs. Hiking, picnicking and camping are all popular here. The park offers five trails that equal about 12 miles in length when combined. The three mile Drover's Trail is handicap accessible. Each trail provides a different variety of terrain and scenery.

name: Bear Creek Lake State Park
description: Bear Creek Lake State Park is located within the Cumberland State Forrest in Central Virginia. It contains a 40-acre lake with a boat launch, fishing, pier, boat rentals and a swimming beach. Other Activities here include biking, camping, hiking and horseback riding.

name: Appalachian Trail 055: Jennings Creek Road to Parkers Gap Road
description: Section 55 of the A.T. runs 11.5 miles from Jennings Creek Road (VA Hwy 614) to Parkers Gap Road (near the Blue Ridge Parkway). Along the way it passes Fork Mountain, Bryant Ridge Shelter, and Cornelius Creek Shelter.

name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historic Park
description:
Historic surroundings and magnificent views await hikers along the trails of the park giving an insight into early pioneer life in Central Kentucky. Overlook Trail or hike along the creek where young Abraham and friends used to work and play.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Ferne Clyffe State Park
description: Eighteen diverse trails offer visitors the chance to view the beauty of Ferne Clyffe at their own pace.  Motorized vehicles and bicycles are not permitted on the trails.

name: Cascade Falls
description: Cascade Falls features 18 miles of hiking trails near Cedar City, UT.

name: Belle Isle
description: Belle Isle features 2 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Northbank Trail
description: Northbank Trail features 2 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Buttermilk
description: This is one of the best trails in the James River Park system, with cool rocks, views of the river, and some great trails to hike or run on.

name: Johnson's Shut-Ins State Park
description: Choose from many trails to explore the many natural features of the park.

name: Crystal Springs Regional Trail
description: The Crystal Springs Regional Trail is a planned 17.5-mile trail that, when finished, will extend from San Bruno to Woodside. 15.3 miles of the trail are now complete. It provides an alternative recreational route to the 1,210-mile Juan Bautista DeAnza National Historic Trail. The trail serves over 325,000 visitors annually. People of all ages can be seen on a given day, from parents with children in strollers to distance runners. Uses for the trail include walking, running, skating/rollerblading, bicycling and horseback riding.

name: Crystal Springs Regional Trail
description: The Crystal Springs Regional Trail is a planned 17.5-mile trail that, when finished, will extend from San Bruno to Woodside. 15.3 miles of the trail are now complete. It provides an alternative recreational route to the 1,210-mile Juan Bautista DeAnza National Historic Trail. The trail serves over 325,000 visitors annually. People of all ages can be seen on a given day, from parents with children in strollers to distance runners. Uses for the trail include walking, running, skating/rollerblading, bicycling and horseback riding.

name: Crystal Springs Regional Trail
description: The Crystal Springs Regional Trail is a planned 17.5-mile trail that, when finished, will extend from San Bruno to Woodside. 15.3 miles of the trail are now complete. It provides an alternative recreational route to the 1,210-mile Juan Bautista DeAnza National Historic Trail. The trail serves over 325,000 visitors annually. People of all ages can be seen on a given day, from parents with children in strollers to distance runners. Uses for the trail include walking, running, skating/rollerblading, bicycling and horseback riding.

name: Coyote Hills Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Coyote Hills Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Coyote Hills Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Appalachian Trail 057: Petites Gap to James River
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs down from Petites Gap to the foot bridge crossing of the James River. It's 10 miles long, and passes Highcock Knob, Hickory Stand, and Matts Creek Shelter along the way.

name: CDT CO05: South River Peak to Squaw Pass
description: The CDT runs 23.5 miles between South River Peak and Squaw Pass. Along the way the trail passes Piedra Peak, Knife Edge, Cherokee Lake, and Chief Mountain.

name: Sheep Creek Trail
description: The route begins as a broad shallow canyon. After 0.5 mile the route enters the Navajo Sandstone and becomes a narrow, sculpted rock passage. The canyon becomes deeper and broader as it continues. Hiking is mostly level in the sandy/gravelly wash bottom. North-facing slopes feature Ponderosa pine and Douglas fir.

name: Goshen Pass Natural Area Preserve
description: Goshen Pass Natural Area Preserve is Virginia's oldest state-managed natural area. It offers some spectacular views of the 3.7-mile long gorge along the Maury River. Activities here include hiking, canoeing, fishing and kayaking.

name: Del Valle Regional Park
