description: Del Valle Regional Park is a beautiful little with a five mile long lake as the centerpiece. There are opportunities here for activities including camping, swimming, canoeing, kayaking, boating, hiking, and horseback riding.

name: Devils Garden
description:
The walk begins at the Devils Garden parking area off the Hole in the Rock road.
From the parking area, social trails wind between the oddly shaped hoodoos and lead to several arches, including Metate Arch. This is an easy walk and a great place for families to explore. Plan to spend a least 30 minutes walking in the area. There are picnic tables, BBQ grills, and a pit toilet.

name: Taum Sauk Mountain State Park
description:
Taum Sauk Mountain State Park is a 7,500-acre site full of recreational opportunities. The park is home to the highest point in the state in the St. Francois Mountains. Avid hikers, backpackers and picnickers love the park's diverse terrain and exceptional scenic views.

The park's 38 miles of trails wind through rocky glades and woodlands to the tallest waterfall and the highest point in Missouri. The trails range from moderate to difficult.

name: Quarry Lakes Regional Recreation Area
description: The Quarry Lakes Natural Unit provides visitors excellent opportunities to hike and ride bicycles. The park's trail network connects to the Alameda Creek Regional Trail, which extends from Niles Canyon westward all the way to Coyote Hills and the Don Edwards National Wildlife Refuge on San Francisco Bay.

name: San Pedro Valley Park
description: San Pedro Valley Park contains seven trails offering a variety of habitats, lengths and levels of difficulty. One of the most scenic, Montara Mountain Trail, offers views of Pacific Ocean, the Farallon Islands and the exterior of Pacifica. Brooks Creek Trail offers views of Brooks Falls as it drops 175 feet in three tiers during the rainy months of winter and spring. Learn more about specific San Pedro Valley Trails below.

name: Twin Falls Resort
description: Twelve hiking trails vary from remote wooded paths to scenic walks to the two falls for which the park is named.

name: Lake Del Valle State Recreation Area
description: Lake Del Valle features 20 miles of hiking trails near Livermore, CA.

name: Coyote Point Recreation Area
description: A number of paved pathways connect the various park areas and can be used for a brisk walk or a casual stroll. Please observe all trail signs and posted speed limits. Bicycles and motorized vehicles are not allowed off designated paved areas. Please respect your fellow trail users and follow the trail etiquette guidelines for safe and courteous trail use.

name: Kershaw-Ryan State Park
description: Kershaw-Ryan State Park is located in a scenic canyon of the north end of Rainbow Canyon in eastern Nevada. The canyon walls reach 700 feet. The park offers a picnic area with a wading pool, playground and hiking trails. The park also offers a 15 site campground with coin-operated restrooms, showers and an RV dump station. The park's main hiking trail is a 1.5-mile Overlook Trail.

name: Rough River Lake
description: Hiking trails connect with nearby state park.

name: Appalachian Trail 058: James River to Blue Ridge Parkway
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs from the foot bridge crossing of the James River to the Blue Ridge Parkway. Along the way it passes the John's Hollow shelter, Bluff Mountain, and Punchbowl Shelter.

name: CDT CO06: Squaw Pass to Weminuche Pass
description: The CDT runs for 12.9 miles between Squaw Pass and Weminuche Pass. Along the way the route runs past the Squaw Lake Trail and Snowslide Trail.

name: Giant City State Park
description: Exploration of the picturesque natural wonders of Giant City State Park can be enjoyed along the Post Oak, Devil's Standtable, Giant City, Stonefort, Indian Creek, Trillium and Arrowwood trails. The Post Oak Trail has been designed for disabled visitors. The 12-mile Red Cedar Hiking Trail provides an invigorating challenge to the truly dedicated backpacker.

name: Limekiln
description: Enjoy the San Luis Valley on this 6 mile out-and-back trail that takes you through a desert terrain and overlooks Colorado's beautiful front range. Make sure to bring extra water out here, and remember to share the trail with mountain bikers!

name: Lathrop State Park
description: Lathrop's two trails, the Hogback Trail and the Cuerno Verde Trail, offer visitors exceptional views of the Spanish Peaks, Greenhorn Mountain and Pikes Peak. Yucca, prickly pear, cholla and claret cup cacti can be viewed from the trails as well as a variety of wildflowers that bloom from early spring through late autumn. The Hogback Trail is for hikers only. The Cuerno Verde Trail goes around Martin Lake and is open to bicyclists and hikers.

name: Junipero Serra Park
description: The Quail Loop Trail (1.2 miles), leads the visitor through a changing panorama of habitats from the creek, through the woods and to the open grasslands. The self-guided Live Oak Nature Trail (.3 mile) offers short interpretive loop along the park's lower north-facing slope. A Live Oak Nature Tail Interpretive Guide is available.

name: Natural Bridges National Monument
description:
While many park features are visible from overlooks along the scenic drive, the true beauty of Natural Bridges lies just a short walk away from the pavement. Moderate hiking trails lead from overlooks to the base of each natural bridge. All are less than 1.5 miles round-trip, with the trail to Owachomo being the shortest and easiest (.5 mile round-trip). All of the trails have uneven stone steps.<br />
Sources: National Park Service

name: Rough River Dam State Resort Park
description: The Lake Ridge Trail, a one-mile nature trail along the shoreline, links the lodge, marina and cottage areas. This is a great trail for bird watching and offers beautiful lake views. For a quiet walk in the woods, the Army Corps of Engineers maintain a self-guided interpretive trail, the Folklore Trail which is a 0.7 mile loop and includes an old pioneer cabin.

name: Cedar Breaks National Monument
description:
Cedar Breaks offers three trails accommodating all skill levels. Whether its a shady stroll through the forest or a hike along the rim, our trails have something for everyone. There is also a fourth, more strenuous trail just north of the park for experienced hikers.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Turlock Lake State Recreation Area
description: Trails have been cut (and made by use) to the river's edge by blackberry fanciers, who enjoy picking the native fruit from July through October. The paths, which receive little or no maintenance and are overgrown, explore a woodsy environment around the campground, between the river and the lake. Not only are the paths poor, but access is dif&#64257;cult; there's no day use area on the river side of the park. Best bet is to ask rangers if you can leave your car near the park entrance station and walk into the campground where the trail begins.

name: Pleasanton Ridge Regional Park
description: Pleasanton Ridge Regional Park features 20 miles of hiking trails near Sunol/Pleasanton, CA.

name: Bluestone State Park
description: Bluestone State Park is laced with a number of intriguing hiking trails. Some of these afford panoramic views of Bluestone's picturesque lake and mountainous terrain.

name: Stockton State Park
description: Stockton State Park is home to the Stockton Lake, a great place for water skiing, scuba diving, sailing, swimming or fishing. Picnicking, photographing, hiking, camping and relaxing are all popular activities on the mainland here. The park has two hiking trails that equal about three miles in length when combined.

name: Crowley Lake Campground
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Elephant Rocks State Park
description: Walk amid the giant boulders on the accessible Braille Trail.

name: Fort Davidson State Historic Site
description: This trail is named for the shoes commonly worn by Civil War soldiers and is relatively flat. ADA accessibility is only mildly difficult due to the flatness. Wheelchairs may have problems on unpacked gravel or occasional mud. The trail makes use of an area of the historic site that has been touched by mining, yet has forest along the East Branch of Knob Creek. While the surface of the trail is mostly gravel, mud and dirt may be present.  Some of the trail is subject to flooding as it is in the flood plain of the creek. Low hanging vegetation may at times present an obstacle.

name: Moncove Lake State Park
description: There are five hiking trails on the park and surrounding Wildlife Management Area that guests can enjoy. The trails are relatively short with the longest being around 2 miles, although the terrain may cause them to seem longer. Anyone interested in longer or sustained hikes may want to investigate the nearby Allegheny Trail on Peter's Mountain which runs the length of the state, the southern terminus of which connects to the Appalachian Trail. While hiking in our area, you are almost certain to encounter some of the wildlife found here. Be on the lookout for white-tail deer, turkey, fox, bobcat, coyote, squirrels, chipmunks, and beaver.

name: James River State Park
description: James River State Park features 15 miles of hiking trails near Gladstone, VA.

name: Mule Canyon
description: Because of the orientation of this canyon one finds slickrock walls mixed with ponderosa pines. There is a day hike fee of $2.00/person/day or $5.00/person for seven consecutive days. An overnight permit may be obtained from the Kane Gulch Ranger Station. An annual day hike pass is also available for $20 from the Monticello Office or the Kane Gulch Ranger Station.

name: Arch Canyon
description: The mouth of Arch canyon is 2 1/2 miles up that road where you will see Arch Canyon Ruins. The canyon has beautiful redrock walls, and it is possible to see several arches. The creek that runs along the bottom of the canyon normally has water (all water should be treated prior to drinking). Look along the canyon walls for hanging gardens. As you look for hanging gardens, you are also likely to spot cliff dwellings. Please remember to treat these special places with respect. This trail has no fee.

name: Cedar Mesa
description: Cedar Mesa is a popular area for hiking and backpacking to see Ancestral Puebloan cliff ruins and rock art in a natural setting. Many miles of spectacular canyons lined with cliffs cut across the mesa. Some ruins are amazingly inaccessible, perched high on ledges and under overhangs. On its eastern edge the mesa's caprock dips sharply downward toward Comb Wash. Many canyons cut through this area. Other attractions include the scenery and wildlife, as well as the solitude of desert canyons.

name: Garin/Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Parks
description: The 20-mile system of trails within Garin and Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Parks give you the opportunity to explore the 4,763 acres that comprise these parklands. While the trails are not paved, many are suitable for bicycles. Please, no motorcycles.

name: Deep Run
description: Deep Run features 4 miles of hiking trails near Richmond, VA.

name: Hermosa Creek Trail
description:
Hike among high ridges and deep canyons along this remote trail. The trail is wide, well-maintained, and very easy to hike, and it winds through beautiful forests, open meadows with views of the La Platas, and fields of wildflowers. <br />
The main trail is about 16 miles, but there are plenty of side trails to explore. Either day hike or spend a couple days backpacking and exploring this area!

name: Trout Creek Trail
description:
Trout Creek Trail is an incredibly scenic trail with wild raspberry bushes lining the trail and wild mint filling the air. The trail leads you along beautiful singletrack up to a meadow that's a perfect place to enjoy a little picnic. <br />
This is a multi-use trail so please share the trail!

name: Crawford State Park
description: Four hiking trails.

name: Montauk State Park
description: Explore the park on one of three trails.

name: Bryce Canyon National Park
description:
Bryce Canyon offers several day-hiking trails. Because many of these are interconnected, our most popular hikes are combinations of two or more of these basic trails. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Mammoth Mountain Resort
description: Mammoth Mountain Resort features 80 miles of hiking trails near Mammoth Lakes, CA.

name: CDT CO08: Twin Lakes to Beartown Trailhead
description: The Continental Divide Trail measures 10 miles in length between Twin Lakes and the Beartown Trailhead. Along the way the trail passes Hunchback Mountain, Hunchback Pass, White Dome, Vallecito Lake, Ute Creek, and Nebo Creek.

name: Millers Meadows
description: Millers Meadows features 5 miles of hiking trails near Wichita, KS.

name: Hayward Regional Shoreline
description: Excellent trails for hiking and jogging.

name: Fall River Lake
description: Flowers, birds and game enhance this project in rolling prairie country. The 10,900-acre Fall River Game Management Area is located here.

name: Dry Creek Trail
description: Dry Creek Trail features 9 miles of hiking trails near Modesto, CA.

name: Fall River State Park
description: Six hiking trails.

name: Devils Postpile National Monument
description: There are about 8 miles of trails in Devils Postpile National Monument. The trails offer a variety of opportunities for all fitness levels. Expanding your hiking outside the boundaries of the Monument will take you into the High Sierra of the Ansel Adams Wilderness. If hiking with your pet, make sure it is on a leash at all times within the Monument. All of the following distances are from the Devils Postpile trail head.

name: Stockton Lake
description: Stockton Lake is a very popular and scenic lake in the beautiful Missouri Ozarks. This park covers a total of 39 square miles, with 298 miles of shoreline and activities here include hiking, horseback riding, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Picket Wire Canyon
description: Long and mostly flat hike leading towards a historic mission, 1/4 mile stretch of dinosaur tracks, and a historic ranch.

name: San Luis State Park
description: Four miles of wide, level gravel trails in the wildlife area provide a pleasant, safe hiking or mountain biking experience among the low dunes and wetlands. The wildlife area is closed from Feb. 15 until July 15 annually.

name: Cole Creek Trail
description: Cole Creek Trail features 11 miles of hiking trails near Lebanon, MO.

name: CDT CO07: Weminuche Pass to Twin Lakes
description: The CDT runs for 10.5 miles from Weminuche Pass north to Twin Lakes. Along the way the trail passes Lavaca Creek, Ute Lake, Rio Grand Pyramid, and Window Peak.

name: Appalachian Trail 059: Blue Ridge Parkway to Long Mountain Wayside
description: Section 59 of the AT runs 10 miles from the Blue Ridge Parkway (see Google Maps Location) to Long Mountain Wayside. Along the way it passes the Lynchburg Reservoir, USFS 38, and the Brown Mountain Shelter.

name: Perryville Battlefield State Historic Site
description: Enjoy the beautiful and historical grounds of the park on one of the self-guiding walking trails. Over 40 interpretive signs are part of the nearly 12-mile trail system. Pick-up a map at the museum. Thanks to the preservation successes of the battlefield, native plants and wildlife find a protected home here and also thrive. Recently Perryville Battlefield entered into a partnership with the Kentucky Dept. of Fish and Wildlife in an effort to return 100 park acres back to its original appearance and re-introduce native habitat. So as you stroll back in time along Doctor's Creek and past the cannons, you may also stumble upon some wild turkey, mink, deer, and numerous bird species, just as the soldiers did years ago.

name: Saline County State Fish and Wildlife Area
description:
Saline County State Fish and Wildlife Area is a 1,270-acre site that is primarily used for recreational activities. Long before the first settlers appeared, the American Indians made salt obtained from their "Great Salt Springs." Although this was once the site where the Native American and others obtained their salt, there are no longer visible springs on the property. An 8-foot-tall bronze statue of the Shawnee Chief Tecumseh, stands near the trailhead for Eagle Mountain Crest Trail to commemorate the importance of the land. The site includes a 105-acre lake which adds to the usefulness of the area. Today visitors use the park as a hunting ground, picnicking site, camping ground, fishing and boating area and a hiking destination.

The four designated hiking trails are Lake, Cave Hill, River and Wildlife Nature Trail. There are also horse trails on the property that you may hike if you desire.
Phone (618) 276-4405

name: San Bruno Mountain SP
description:
The San Bruno Mountain State Park is located at the northern reaches of the Santa Cruz range, which provides visitors with gorgeous views of the bay and city.

Hiking is the most popular activity, the main starting point being the park's entrance. From here you embark on a variety of outstanding views. During your hike, feel free to stop at one of the many picnicking sites for a refreshing break. There are four main trail hikes with a few different length options. Hike one, the Summit Loop is 3.54 miles. Hike two, the Bog Loop is .8 miles. Hike three, the Saddle Loop is 2.9 miles. Hike four, all access hike/loop is .3-.8 miles.

As with many parks in California, the weather is changeable so wear layered clothing.

name: Five Canyons Open Space
description: Hiking and biking are common activities in the park.

name: Don Castro Regional Recreation Area
description: There is access to the Bay Area Ridge Trail, the Chabot to Garin trail and over five miles of trails in the Five Canyons Open Space.

name: Caswell Memorial State Park
description: One of the most magnificent aspects the park has to offer is its seemingly endless nature trails. The trails allow a glimpse of what the riparian ecosystem of the valley would have looked like in pristine times. A majestic Oak Forest is surrounded by many other lush plant species, some of which are rarely found anywhere else in the area.

name: San Bruno Mountain State & County Park
description: Hiking is the most popular activity in the park. The main starting points are from the park's entrance, trailhead parking area and from the mountain's summit. Various neighborhood access points including Crocker Road and Carter Street also provide good starting points. Views afforded from many spots on the trails are unparalleled in the bay area.

name: Middle Fork Loop  (ozark Trail)
description: Middle Fork Loop  (ozark Trail) features 38 miles of hiking trails near Potosi, MO.

name: North Trace (ozark Trail)
description: North Trace (ozark Trail) is a 35 mile hiking trail in Potosi, Missouri.

name: Dublin Hills Regional Park
description: Great trails.

name: CDT CO09: Beartown Trailhead to Stony Pass Trailhead
description: Section 9 of the Continental Divide Trail runs 7.7 miles from the Beartown Trailhead to the Stony Pass Trailhead. 1.4 miles after leaving the Beartown Trailhead the CDT joins up with the Colorado Trail and runs concurrent with it. Along the way, the trail passes Bear Creek, Beartown Bald, and Stony Pass Peak.

name: Cull Canyon Regional Recreation Area
description: Cull Canyon also is on the Chabot-to-Garin Regional Trail, which is being developed between the two parks. The trail runs along the east side of Cull Canyon Reservoir, then heads north for six miles through East Bay Municipal Utility District property to EBMUD's Chabot Staging Area on Redwood Road (an EBMUD hiking permit is required for this section, phone 287-0459). From here the Willow View Trail leads into Anthony Chabot Regional Park.

name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve
description:
The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, conifer and aspen forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. <br />
Explore anything from dune trails, where you can climb the "high dune," to forested trails under the aspens and evergreens, to alpine trails, and back down to trails that wind through grasslands, shrublands, and wetlands! Great Sand Dunes really does have it all!

name: Candlestick Point State Recreation Area
description: The park offers hiking, jogging, bicycling, bird watching, informal games, and picnicking. There is a bike path and a fitness course. Candlestick Point is also a popular entry point for windsurfing on the bay.

name: Anthony Chabot Regional Park
description: Anthony Chabot Regional Park features 19 miles of hiking trails near Castro Valley, CA.

name: Anthony Chabot Regional Park
description: Anthony Chabot Regional Park features 19 miles of hiking trails near Castro Valley, CA.

name: Dewey Lake
description: Wooded hills rise some 700 feet above the lake. A full range of facilities are available at Jenny Wiley State Resort Park.

name: Youngers Creek
description: Youngers Creek features 12 miles of hiking trails near E-town, KY.

name: McLaren Park
description: McLaren Park, the second largest park in San Francisco, was named for John McLaren, the superintendent of Golden Gate Park from 1887 to 1943. It includes a natural area rich in native plants and animals, as well as picnic areas, playgrounds, lawns and planted gardens, a golf course, tennis courts, and an amphitheater. Miles of paved and unpaved trails wind through the park, many of them built during the Depression by the Works Progress Administration. You can hike through a variety of habitats, both native and introduced, including forests, grasslands, and marshy riparian areas, where springs feed Yosemite Creek.

name: Bayview Park
description: The primary trail is a paved road that loops through the park, beginning and ending at the eastern end of Key Avenue. Remnants of stairs and retaining walls built by the Works Progress Administration during the Depression can still be seen along the roadway.

name: Dillard Mill State Historic Site
description: Hike to a bluff overlooking the scenic mill.

name: Bennett Spring State Park
description: Take a long or short hike on one of six trails to scenic views featuring the Ozarks, streams, the spring, spring branch and hardwood forests.

name: Appalachian Trail 060: Long Mountain Wayside to Salt Log Gap
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs for 8.5 miles from the Long Mountain Wayside on US Hwy 60 to Salt Log Gap. Along the way it passes Bald Knob, Cow Camp Gap, and Cole Mountain.

name: Black Bear Loop Greenbrier State Forest
description: Black Bear Loop Greenbrier State Forest is a 5 mile hiking trail in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia.

name: Panorama Trail
description: Start at 7,214 feet and descend the Panorama trail toward Yosemite Valley. Beautiful views of the valley and waterfalls like Illilouette Fall. Continue via the John Muir Trail and Half Dome trail to the top of Half Dome for a 18 mile round trip.

name: Council Bluffs Trail
description: Council Bluffs Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Potosi, MO.

name: Four Mile Trail
description: Hike starts along Sentinel Creek and leads to Glacier Point at 7,214 feet. Stunning vistas of Yosemite Valley below as you climb. Union Point is 3.0 miles in; Glacier point is at 4.8 miles.

name: Cheney State Park
description: Plus 3 nature trails.

name: Ripon Riding Spot
description: Ripon Riding Spot features 12 miles of hiking trails near Ripon, CA.

name: Ripon Riding Spot
description: Ripon Riding Spot features 12 miles of hiking trails near Ripon, CA.

name: Ripon Riding Spot
description: Ripon Riding Spot features 12 miles of hiking trails near Ripon, CA.

name: Colorado Trail: Molas Pass To Bolam Pass Rd.
description:
This section of the Colorado Trail starts out at US 550, passes through the Little Molas Lake Campground, and begins the ascent. You'll climb through an old burn area, which leaves wide open space to see the surrounding views. <br />
The elevation remains well above 10,000 feet for a good long while, and once you finish this section, you'll find yourself at Celebration Lake. This area can be more crowded since it's accessible by 4WD.

name: Mt. Davidson Park
description: Myriad trails traverse the western slopes, where the densely overgrown vegetation and fog drip give a hiker the feeling of being in a rainforest.

name: Hughlett Point Natural Area Preserve
description: Hughlett Point Natural Area Preserve is home to several rare and even endangered species. This 204-acre preserve is also an important area for migratory waterfowl and songbirds. Activities here include canoeing, kayaking, boating and hiking.

name: Yosemite Valley
description: Yosemite Valley features 7 miles of hiking trails near Mariposa, CA.

name: Martin Luther King Jr. Regional Shoreline
description: Throughout the 741-acre Martin Luther King Jr. Regional Shoreline there are paved trails suitable for hiking, bicycling, running and jogging. Along the trail on the east side of the park there is an exercise course. Glimpses of the changing sunset are best caught at Arrowhead Marsh and Garretson Point.

name: John Muir Trail
description: The high Sierra classic named for the man who inspired many to visit. One of the most scenic trails in America.

name: Glen Canyon Park
description: Beyond Glen Canyon Park's recreation center, ball field, and tennis courts lies a large urban canyon that has incredible spring wildflower displays, dramatic rock (chert) formations, and Islais Creek, one of the few remaining free-flowing creeks in San Francisco. This 60 acres of wilderness, formerly referred to as the San Miguel Hills, not only provides critical habitat for a wide array of wildlife, but serves as a relaxing sanctuary from the city's urban bustle. An extensive network of hiking trails leads through a variety of habitats, from the lush creekside vegetation to the rocky grass- and scrublands of the canyon's steep eastern slope, where a profusion of wildflowers blooms each spring.

name: Billy Goat Hill
description: Billy Goat Hill has a small trail network consisting of 0.2 miles. The trail is made up of steep switchbacks up the hillside to a view point. The trail climbs a short distance further before flattening out near Beacon Street.  Walter Haas Park is adjacent to Billy Goat Hill across Beacon Street.

name: Bernal Heights Park
description: A paved limited-access road and a network of well-defined dirt trails wind around the hill's flanks and provide access to the summit.

name: Thunder Mountain
description: Thunder Mountain features 16 miles of hiking trails near Red Canyon- Bryce Canyon Np, UT.

name: Cross Timbers State Park
description: All park trails are open to hiking and backpacking. All but the Ancient Trees Trail are open to other non-motorized uses such as jogging and mountain biking. Back country camping is allowed by special permit on segments of the Chautauqua Hills Trail.

name: Sandstone
description: Sandstone features 3 miles of hiking trails near Fort Leonard Wood, MO.

name: Yosemite National Park
description:
One of the best ways to experience Yosemite is by taking a hike. Here are some of hikes available in different areas of Yosemite:Yosemite Valley, Glacier Point Road, Wawona and Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias, Hetch Hetchy, White Wolf andTuolumne Meadows.<br />
<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: C Trail
description: The trail covers and elevation change of 2,200 feet and winds 4.2 miles to a large white painted "C" on the mountainside. The overlook affords panoramic views of the region's majestic mountain ranges, sage-studded valleys and quaint, rustic communities below. The trail traverses the Markagunt Plateau, one of many plateaus that form the Colorado Plateau.  Expansive views to the West showcase Indian Peak rising to 9,784 feet. The hike offers several benches with view to rest and enjoy the scenery along the way.

name: Twin Peaks Park
description: At 922 feet in elevation, Twin Peaks is second only to Mt. Davidson in height, offers spectacular views of the Bay Area, and is a world-famous tourist attraction. Originally called "Los Pechos de la Choca" (Breasts of the Maiden) by early Spanish settlers, these two adjacent peaks provide postcard views and a treasure trove of animal and plant diversity. Most visitors to Twin Peaks drive (or take a tourist bus) to the north peak parking lot to enjoy 180-degree views of the Bay Area.

name: Wolverine Canyon
description: 5 miles one-way to Horse Canyon.  For a loop, hike 5 miles down Wolverine to Horse Canyon then 9 miles up Horse Canyon to the Wolverine Loop Road, and then 4 miles (right, south) via the road to the trail head for the total of approximately 18 miles.  Backpackers should avoid looping back through Little Death Hollow as they may have trouble getting their packs past obstacles and through the slot section. These are unmarked routes.  Hikers must be able to read and use a topographic map or take compass bearings, and pay attention to landmarks so they can find their way back out.  There are no obstacles in Wolverine Canyon.  If you choose to venture into Little Death Hollow, the slot section has 6-7 obstacles to negotiate, including a chock stone 10-15 feet high which requires stemming and climbing.  Other obstacles require crawling on your stomach.  A short length of rope is recommended to lower or drag packs.  After heavy rains, deep pools of water might present problem.

name: Bishop Ranch Open Space
description: Bishop Ranch Open Space features 10 miles of hiking trails near San Ramon, CA.

name: Rocky Peaks Trail
description:
There is a designated trail, Rocky Peak Trail, near the large group camping area that leads to the top of one of the peaks in the area. This is a relatively short hike, however it can be steep in areas. The uphill hike is greatly rewarded with a stunning view of the surrounding area.
There are other opportunities to hike around and explore the Three Peaks area, with varying terrain, large areas to explore, and a variety of wildlife to be seen, Three Peaks has something to offer every hiker.

name: Las Trampas Regional Wilderness
description: The park is bisected by Bollinger Creek. To the west is Rocky Ridge, accessible from the parking lot via a paved road that brings hikers near the 2,024-foot summit. At the 1,760-foot elevation you can hike westward along a trail managed by the East Bay Municipal Utility District to the Valle Vista Staging Area on Canyon Road in Moraga, or south to the Chabot staging area in Castro Valley. A permit is required for hiking on EBMUD lands. Call 510-287-0459 for more information.

name: Brushy Peak Regional Preserve
description: Excellent trails. Bring drinking water when you visit the 1,833-acre Preserve; no drinking water is available. Please note that dogs must be on-leash at all times while visiting or hiking in Brushy Peak Regional Preserve to protect the area's fragile natural resources.

name: Corona Heights Park
description: A one-mile trail network winds around the hill and leads up to the summit for a 360å¡ degree vies of San Francisco Bay Area. Trails that lead around the hilltop consist of fairly stable and sometimes steep, dirt paths with a series of box step staircases scattered around. The trail leading down to the 15th street tennis courts is the most challenging section with  steep terrain with loose gravel. This section is about 0.2 of a mile in length.

name: Cottonwood Narrows Trail
description: One-way mileage through the canyon from the upper trail head to the lower trail head is 1.5 miles. Those wishing to do a loop can return along the road for a total of 2.5 miles round trip.

name: Willow Gulch
description: Hikers must be willing to walk in water. The hike begins at the Willow Gulch trail head off of the Hole in the Rock road.  This is a moderate 3.0 mile round trip hike to Broken Bow Arch and back. From the trailhead, the route heads east past a pedestal rock with a large flat top, the "Mortar Board," and down a sandy hill into Willow Gulch. Pay attention to landmarks at canyon junctions for your return trip. Continue downstream 1.5 miles to the arch.

name: Fence Canyon
description: The hike begins at the Egypt trail head off of the Hole in the Rock road. This is a strenuous 6.0 mile round trip hike to the Escalante River and back. From the trail head, the route drops 800 feet down steep slickrock then heads in a northeasterly direction across sand and slickrock. Rock cairns may be encountered along the route. Drop into Fence Canyon along an old stock trail that descends off of the south side of the point of land between the two canyons that come together to form the main canyon. Continue down canyon to the river. The elevation change from the trail head to the river is approximately 1,000 feet.

name: Lower Harris Wash
description: Best done as a 2-3 day backpack.  Those who want to extend their trip can explore Silver Falls Creek on the east side of the Escalante River, 0.3 mile up river from the mouth of Harris Wash.  Allow 4 or more days if Silver Falls Creek is explored to it's upper reaches.  Day hikers can explore the upper portions of Harris

name: Escalante River (Town to Bridge)
description: The hike is best done as an overnight backpack, but can be completed as a long day hike by experienced canyon country hikers. The trip can be extended for several days if side trips are taken into lower Death Hollow or Sand Creek.

name: Phipps Wash Trail
description: This is an unmarked route. Hikers must be able to use topographic maps to find their way. Steep descents on slickrock and one pour-off to negotiate as you descend from Spencer Flat to Phipps Wash. A cairned route on the left side of the pour-off leads you safely around this obstacle. A steep cairned scramble up the slickrock leads to Phipps Arch.

name: Escalante Natural Bridge
description: Hikers must be willing to walk in water. The hike begins at the Escalante River trailhead.

name: Golden Gate Park Oak Woodlands
description: Three miles of asphalt and dirt paths wind through the Oak Woodlands and connect to the extensive trail and road network within Golden Gate Park.

name: Hickory Hollow Natural Area Preserve
description: Hickory Hollow Natural Area Preserve is 254 acres of mixed pine-hardwood forest, ravines and Cabin swamp. This is an important habitat for several species of animals and there is a system of hiking trails for one to observe all of this wildlife.

name: Lake Murphysboro State Park
description: A 3mile designated trail offers hikers the opportunity to enjoy the plant, animal and bird life of the park. For those who prefer to explore nature on their own, several paths criss-cross through the park's wooded hills.

name: Belle Isle State Park
description: Belle Isle State Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Lancaster, VA.

name: Natural Bridge State Resort Park
description: The ten hiking trails range from one-half mile to seven-and-one-half miles. Trail maps are available at the Hemlock Lodge.

name: Appalachian Trail 061: Salt Log Gap to Fish Hatchery Road
description: Section 61 of the AT runs 8 miles from Salt Log Gap (USFS 63) to Fish Hatchery Road. It passes the Seeley-Woodworth shelter along the way.

name: Poor Farms
description: This is definitely a locals trail system, and despite the complete and utter lack of trail markings, it appears to be legal (as far as I can tell). While I wouldn't recommend driving from out of town to check this trail out, for those living nearby I am sure it is a real gem. There are some great trails snaking through the forest here, but it is truly a massive spiderweb. If you are a first timer here, just start exploring. You will come out eventually. When you do, head back in and try a different fork in the trail. Wash, rinse, and repeat!

name: Point Lobos State Natural Reserve
description: The Cypress Grove Trail and North Shore Trail offer hikers a 0.75 mile to 3 miles or more round trip. Both Cypress Grove Trail and North Shore Trail depart from the northwest end of Cypress Grove parking area.

name: Ben Hawes
description: Ben Hawes features 10 miles of hiking trails near Owensboro, KY.

name: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
description: Two established trails wind through vast deposits of some of the most beautiful petrified wood found anywhere, with some pieces measuring nearly five feet wide! Please wear sturdy walking shoes and sunscreen, and carry plenty of drinking water.

name: CDT CO10: Stony Pass Trailhead to Carson Saddle Trailhead
description: The CDT runs for 16 miles from Stony Pass Trailhead north to Carson Saddle Trailhead. Along the way it passes Canby Mountain, Half Peak, Tundra Top, Cataract Peak, Carson Peak, and Bent Peak.

name: Redwood Regional Park
description: The East Bay Skyline National Trail and Bay Area Ridge Trail traverses Redwood for part of its 31-mile course.

name: Middle Harbor Shoreline Park
description: There are just under three miles of pathways that are available for pedestrians and bicyclists to explore the shoreline and inland areas of the park. These pathways are extensions of the regional San Francisco Bay Trail, and connect directly to the adjacent Port View Park and the West Oakland neighborhood.

name: Joaquin Miller
description: Joaquin Miller features 10 miles of hiking trails near Berkeley, CA.

name: Sycamore Valley Open Space Preserve
description: Great hiking.

name: Leona Canyon Regional Open Space Preserve
description: A pristine wooded canyon is protected in this 290-acre parkland near Merritt College in Oakland. The park is an ideal place for hiking, running, biking, dog walking, and similar activities.

name: North Mountain/longdale Loop
description: North Mountain/longdale Loop is a 12 mile hiking trail in Clifton Forge, Virginia.

name: Roberts Regional Recreation Area
description: Trail connections from the Roberts area to neighboring Redwood Regional Park make Roberts popular for bicyclists, joggers, runners and hikers. A map of Redwood Regional Park is available on request by phoning (510) 635-0138, ext. 2203.

name: Morgan Territory
description: Morgan Territory features 20 miles of hiking trails near Livermore, CA.

name: St. Joe State Park
description: St. Joe State Park is a 8,200-acre area with an approximately 2,000-acre OHV riding area. The park is in the Old Lead Belt with sand flats and hills that make the park an excellent location for off-roading. Swimming, fishing, boating, horseback riding, hiking, mountain biking, picnicking and camping are all very popular activities here. The park offers about 55 miles of multi-use trails for hiking, biking and horseback riding. Each has different levels of difficulty and terrain for your convenience.

name: Hap Magee Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Lower Calf Creek Falls
description: The hike begins in the Calf Creek campground located on Hwy 12, 15 miles east of Escalante. Hikers are charged a day use fee of $2.00 per vehicle. The 6.0 mile round trip hike to the 126 foot lower falls is on a developed trail adjacent to Calf Creek. The hike is moderately difficult due to sandy sections. An interpretive brochure is available at the trailhead. The hike can be hot, especially during summer months, and hikers must carry adequate water. This is a good introductory hike to the Escalante Canyons. Dogs must be leashed.

name: Whispering Pines North Loop
description: This trail is generally considered to be one of the best hiking and backpacking trails in the state. It consists of two loops: the north loop is approximately six miles long and the south loop is approximately 3.75 miles. The trail provides the opportunity for day hikes of varying lengths or a longer backpacking trip. It meanders through a beautiful mixed hardwood and pine forest that is home to a variety of animals such as bobcat and wild turkey. Extensive exposures of sandstone and granite can be explored along the banks of Pickle Creek and the River Aux Vases. Mosses and ferns create a luxurious effect on the moist overhangs that occur along the two streams. A hike on Whispering Pine Trail is especially enjoyable in the spring and winter, but a summer day hike ending with a cool dip in Pickle Creek or a backpacking trip on a crisp, fall weekend can be equally rewarding.

name: Appalachian Trail 062: Fish Hatchery Road to Tye River
description:
This section of the AT runs for 9.5 miles from Fish Hatchery Road to Tye River (VA Hwy 56). Along the way it passes Maintop Mountain, The Priest Shelter, and The Priest mountain.<br />
Note: the Google Maps location is approximate, but close.<br />
Recommended parking spot: "VA 56 (Tye River)" lat=37.8383696705, lon=-79.0232431318

name: Presidio at Golden Gate National Recreations Area
description:
The Presidio contains over 25 miles of hiking trails, including the Golden Gate Promenade, Presidio Promenade, Coastal Trail, Ecology Trail, and portions of the Bay Area Ridge Trail, the Bay Trail, and the Anza National Historic Trail. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Redwood Regional Park
description: Redwood Regional Park features 9 miles of hiking trails near Castro Valley, CA.

name: Cathedral Gorge State Park
description: Excellent hiking with unique views.

name: Hawn State Park
description: Explore one of Missouri's most scenic parks.

name: Red Hills
description: Red Hills features 17 miles of hiking trails near Jamestown, CA.

name: Red Hills
description: Red Hills features 17 miles of hiking trails near Jamestown, CA.

name: Red Hills
description: Red Hills features 17 miles of hiking trails near Jamestown, CA.

name: Appalachian Trail 063: Tye River to Reeds Gap
description: This section of the AT begins at Tye River and runs 10.5 miles to Reeds Gap. Along the way it passes Harpers Creek shelter, Three Ridges, and Maupin Field shelter.

name: Red Hills Area of Critical Environmental Concern
description: Interpretive nature trail system with various loops, total of about 17.3 miles.

name: Red Hills Area of Critical Environmental Concern
description: Interpretive nature trail system with various loops, total of about 17.3 miles.

name: Red Hills Area of Critical Environmental Concern
description: Interpretive nature trail system with various loops, total of about 17.3 miles.

name: Morgan Territory Regional Preserve
description: Excellent hiking

name: Huckleberry Botanic Regional Preserve
description: Huckleberry self-guided nature path, a 1.7-mile loop, traverses a wide variety of terrain and is maintained to minimum standards. The path descends into a mature bay forest, follows the contour for about half a mile, and then ascends to the botanically rich upper trail. For a less strenuous walk, stay on the upper trail-you will still encounter most of the stops on the self-guided tour.

name: Las Trampas Ridge
description: Las Trampas Ridge features 20 miles of hiking trails near Danville, CA.

name: Paintsville Lake State Park
description: Over 8 miles of hiking trails.

name: Penitente Canyon
description: Penitente Canyon offers gorgeous desert landscape with impressive sandstone cliffs. It is a true rock climbing destination, so don't expect to have the place all to yourself!

name: Bush Mill Stream Natural Area Preserve
description: Bush Mill Stream Natural Area Preserve is located where the freshwater Bush Mill Stream meets the saltwater Great Wicomico River. This area is extremely abundant in wildlife and is only accessible by foot or by canoe. Only open during the day, activities here are limited to hiking, kataking and canoeing.

name: Temescal Regional Recreation Area
description: A paved trail running the length of the park is wheelchair accessible. STAY ON TRAILS to help control erosion and to minimize contact with poison oak, which is abundant.

name: El Dorado Lake
description: Excellent trails.

name: Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve
description: Most trails are hiking and equestrian only. A few trails are multi-use. Dogs are permitted at Sibley, but are not allowed on adjacent Huckleberry trails. A visitor center at the park shelves self-guided tour brochures so guests can stroll the park and learn of its historic significance at their own leisure.

name: CDT CO11: Carson Saddle Trailhead to Spring Creek Pass Trailhead
description: The CDT runs with the Colorado Trail for 17.1 miles from the Carson Saddle Trailhead to the Spring Creek Pass Trailhead at Hwy 149. Along the way, the trail passes the highpoint of the Colorado Trail, Pt. 71 Mountain, and Jarosa Mesa.

name: Bluestone National Scenic River
description:
The Bluestone Turnpike Trail is a 9.5-mile moderate hiking trail that follows the path of an old riverbank road. Farmed and timbered until the 1940's, this forested area now has a great diversity of plants and river wildlife. Remnants of the area's human history remain, waiting to be discovered by observant hikers.<br />
<br />
The Bluestone Turnpike Trail connects on the north end with Bluestone State Park's campground road, just past the Old Mill Campground. On the south end at Pipestem Resort State Park, this trail connects with the Farley Loop Trail and River Trail. These trails can be accessed from the Mountain Creek Lodge, at the base of the tram at Pipestem Resort State Park.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Angel Island State Park
description: For an island barely a square mile in size, Angel Island has an extremely diverse history. Over the last two centuries, the island has seen use as a Mexican land grant, an Army artillery post, and an immigration station. Now it's a state park, attracting hikers, history buffs, and islophiles of all persuasions.

name: Pomme De Terre Lake
description: Cool, clear spring waters make this lake the "Gem of the Ozarks."

name: Eastshore State Park
description: Some areas of the park are now open to the public providing hiking, biking, bird watching and other day-use activities. While no one road extends the entire length of the park, the San Francisco Bay Trail will link the entire park when completed.

name: Angel Island
description: Angel Island features 18 miles of hiking trails near Tiburon, CA.

name: Angel Island
description: Angel Island features 18 miles of hiking trails near Tiburon, CA.

name: Kaintuck Trail
description: Kaintuck Trail features 15 miles of hiking trails near Newburg, MO.

name: Round Valley Regional Preserve
description: The preserve is open for hiking, horseback riding and bicycling (with some restrictions). The climate at the preserve is arid and temperatures commonly exceed 100 degrees Fahrenheit in the summer months. Be prepared for the summer heat: use sunscreen, wear a hat and loose-fitting clothing, wear good hiking shoes. Drinking water is available at the staging area. Be sure to carry plenty of water with you during your hike.

name: Claremont Canyon Regional Preserve
description: Claremont Canyon Regional Preserve is used primarily for its picturesque hiking trails. The Stonewall-Panoramic Trail is the primary access through the preserve. The .75-mile climb from Stonewall Road to the ridgetop is steep, but hikers are rewarded with a panoramic view of Oakland, Berkeley, San Francisco Bay, and the Golden Gate Bridge. The trail continues east along the ridge, straddling the boundary with University of California property, and connecting with the University's Ecological Study Area trail system. Gwin Canyon Trail is a scenic, single-track hiking trail located south of Claremont Avenue. It descends from the north end of Norfolk Road and ends 0.6 miles from from the trailhead, just above Claremont Creek. In Gwin Canyon an array of native vegetation provides excellent habitat for wildlife, especially after previous fires swept through the area.

name: Butler Wash Ruins Trail
description: The parking area is paved and pit toilet facilities are available. The hiking trail winds its way across some small washes and over slickrock before reaching an overlook of a cliff dwelling, 0.5 mile across the canyon. Interpretive signing is located at the overlook. Walk south of the overlook to view a natural bridge up the canyon. Round trip hiking distance is one mile, and travel time is approximately 1/2 hour. It is an easy to moderate hike. Please recycle interpretive brochures at the trailhead.

name: Mount Diablo State Park
description: "The Grand Loop" is 7 miles round trip with 1,700 foot elevation gain, but hikers can divide the walk into smaller segments. Additional trails available--the starting point for hikes is at Mitchell Canyon Staging Area.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Northern California: I
description:
Section I of the Pacific Crest Trail runs 76.4 miles from Highway 120 in Tuolumne Meadows to Highway 108 at Sonora Pass. This section is very steep with plenty of ups and downs, crossing mountain pass after mountain past. Most of the passes are below tree line, however, and the valleys can be very warm and enjoyable.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes Soda Springs, Delaney Creek, Tuolemne River, Conness Creek, Cold Canyon Creek, Miller Lake, Wilson Creek, Benson Pass, Smedberg Lake, Rogers Lake, Murdock Lake, Seavey Pass, Kerrick Canyon, Stubblefield Canyon Creek, Macomb Ridge Pass, Wilmer Lake, Tilden Lake, Grace Meadow, Dorothy Lake Pass, Lake Harriet, West Fork West Walker River, Kennedy Canyon Creek, and the Sierra Crest.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Northern California
description: The Pacific Crest Trail runs 2,663.5 miles from the Mexican border to British Columbia, Canada. This is the Northern California section of the PCT, and the section descriptions listed here on Tripleblaze will be lettered in a south-to-north fashion, as is done in the official PCT guidebooks. The Google Maps locations given here on the Tripleblaze will be for the southern tip of the section in question, whenever possible.

name: Pomme de Terre State Park
description: Pomme de Terre State Park is located on the Hermitage and Pittsburg sides of Pomme de Terre Lake. Boating, fishing for walleye, bass, crappie, muskie and catfish, swimming, hiking, camping and picnicking are all very popular here. Two popular trails that equal about four miles in length when combing are located here. The views the hikes offer are beautiful and the terrain is fairly gentle.

name: John James Audubon State Park
description: Whether you're out for a leisurely stroll or really want to work up a sweat, you're sure to find the 6.5 miles of trails at Audubon State Park to your liking. Trails wind through the nature preserve with variations in difficulty and length, including 2.7 miles of back-country hiking. The Eagle Glen Pet Trail is a one-mile trail where dogs on leashes are allowed with their owners.

name: Diablo Foothills Regional Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Muir Woods
description: Incredible Redwood forest with connecting trails to the coast. Trails are wide, well marked, and generally follow an easy grade.

name: Diablo Foothills
description: Diablo Foothills features 20 miles of hiking trails near Diablo, CA.

name: Shell Ridge Open Space Into Diablo Foothills And Mt Diablo S
description: Shell Ridge Open Space Into Diablo Foothills And Mt Diablo S features 12 miles of hiking trails near Walnut Creek, CA.

name: Shell Ridge Open Space Into Diablo Foothills And Mt Diablo S
description: Shell Ridge Open Space Into Diablo Foothills And Mt Diablo S features 12 miles of hiking trails near Walnut Creek, CA.

name: Shell Ridge Open Space Into Diablo Foothills And Mt Diablo S
description: Shell Ridge Open Space Into Diablo Foothills And Mt Diablo S features 12 miles of hiking trails near Walnut Creek, CA.

name: Tilden Regional Park
description: There are 39.41 miles of trails in Tilden Park, through many different kinds of terrain.  The larger multi-use trails allow hikers, bicyclers, and horses, some are for hikers and horses only, and the smaller single-track trails are for hikers only.

name: Chief Logan State Park
description: Traversing the park are 18 miles of trails that offer diverse hiking experiences from leisurely to challenging. The trails provide an excellent opportunity to enjoy the park's spring wildflowers and abundant wildlife. Some trails are recommended for mountain bike enthusiasts.

name: Fort Boonesborough State Park
description:
Just over a half mile of waking trails are just enough to get away from the hubbub. A .25-mile paved Fort Trail begins at the fort and comes out in the parking lot across from the pool.

The Halley Home Site Trail, a short connector trail between the other two, is named for the Halley's who built a large house on the property in the late 1790's. The house is gone but several hidden signs of the old rock foundation remain. The Halley's are buried on the park.

The Pioneer Forage Trail, connecting the campground to the fort, is a little over a quarter mile. It follows very briefly a section of rock wall from the Halley farm and some wagon road remnants. It also follows, for some distance, Spring Run Branch, a small stream that was named by the settlers and played a role in the siege of 1778. In the spring, wildflowers liven up the landscape.

name: Douthat State Park
description: Douthat State Park features 40 miles of hiking trails near Bath County, VA.

name: Appalachian Trail 064: Reeds Gap to Rockfish Gap
description: This, the final section of the AT before it enters Shenandoah National Park, runs 19.5 miles from Reeds Gap to Rockfish Gap. Along the way it crosses the Blue Ridge Parkway several times, roughly following its course.

name: Point Isabel Regional Shoreline
description: There are beautiful views of the Golden Gate and Marin County from this landscaped 23-acre park at the west end of Central Avenue in Richmond. This is one of the largest public off-leash dog parks in the nation with over 500,000 dog visits per year.

name: Ring Mountain Open Space
description: Ring Mountain Open Space features 10 miles of hiking trails near Tiburon, CA.

name: Mount Tamalpais State Park
description:
From Mountain Home Inn to East Peak summit is 6 miles round trip
with 1,300-foot elevation gain via Railroad Grade and Fern Creek Trails.

name: Walnut Creek Community Regional Park
description: Walnut Creek Community Regional Park is a lovely 2-acre park siting along the Walnut Creek trail. Activities here include horseback riding and hiking.

name: Echo Canyon State Park
description: The Ash Canyon trail leads into the park's backcountry. The 2.5-mile trail begins in the upper campground, climbs 300 feet in 1/3 mile to the valley rim, and then descends into the dramatic steep-sided walls of Ash Canyon. It joins the highway in Rose Valley near the eastern park entrance and returns to the campground through Echo Canyon.

name: Long Canyon Slot
description: This hike begins off the Burr trail road. From Boulder, drive 11 miles east on the Burr Trail Road to a small, unmarked paved pullout on the north (left) side of the road. From the pullout, the narrow slot is visible directly across the wash. Walk into this short canyon to experience the tall walls and narrow perspective of a slot canyon. This is a short, easy 15-minute round trip stroll.

name: Miller/Knox Regional Shoreline
description: A hike to the top of the nearby grassy hills is rewarded by spectacular views in all directions.

name: Berryman
description: Berryman features 24 miles of hiking trails near Steelville, MO.

name: Sherando Lakes Recreation Area
description: Sherando Lakes Recreation Area features 30 miles of hiking trails near Waynesboro, VA.

name: Lions Park Trail
description: Lions Park Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Rolla, MO.

name: Walnut Creek
description: Walnut Creek features 35 miles of hiking trails near Charlottesville, VA.

name: Briones Regional Park
description: Briones Regional Park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Walnut Creek, CA.

name: Prospect Trail
description:
Prospect Trail starts at the top of the free gondola from Mountain Village. This hike follows a well-maintained trail that winds through the thick forests. Ever now and then it will cross with some ski trails, where you'll be able to get stunning views of the surrounding mountains and the town down below.<br />
Please share the trails with mountain bikers.

name: Otter Creek
description: Otter Creek features 7 miles of hiking trails near Louisville, KY.

name: CDT CO12: Spring Creek Pass Trailhead to San Luis Pass
description: The CDT runs for 14.3 miles from Spring Creek Pass to San Luis Pass. Along the way it passes Gain Snow Mesa, Baldy no es Cinco, and Baldy.

name: Mt Tamalpais Fire Roads To West Point Inn
description: Mt Tamalpais Fire Roads To West Point Inn features 11 miles of hiking trails near Kentfield, CA.

name: Lime Ridge
description: Lime Ridge features 10 miles of hiking trails near Concord, CA.

name: Kennedy Grove Regional Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking.

name: MOOMOO hill
description: MOOMOO hill features 5 miles of hiking trails near Walnut Creek, CA.

name: Birm trail
description: Birm trail features 2 miles of hiking trails near Concord, CA.

name: Boone Station State Historic Site
description: Get in touch with the surroundings during a 1 mile self guided trail.

name: Wildcat Canyon Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Veterans Park
description: Veterans Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Lexington, KY.

name: Eldridge Grade To East Peak Loop
description: Eldridge Grade To East Peak Loop features 18 miles of hiking trails near Ross, Marin County, CA.

name: Eldridge Grade To East Peak Loop
description: Eldridge Grade To East Peak Loop features 18 miles of hiking trails near Ross, Marin County, CA.

name: Black Diamond Mines Regional Preserve
description: Excellent trails.

name: Usi Trails
description: Usi Trails features 9 miles of hiking trails near Evansville, IN.

name: Fable Valley
description: Fable Valley is a tributary to a canyon which drains into the Colorado River north of Dark Canyon. It is part of the BLM's Dark Canyon Primitive Area. The valley is approximately eight miles long and can be reached by one of two trailheads. The southern trailhead from Dark Canyon Plateau is more easily accessible; the northern trailhead from Beef Basin is very hard to reach. Fable Valley does not get extensive back country use. It has been historically used by cattle; currently livestock do not graze here on a regular basis. Fable Valley is higher and cooler than most other areas of the Monticello Field Office, but is still a desert environment.

name: Pine Mountain Loop
description: Pine Mountain Loop features 13 miles of hiking trails near Fairfax, Ca, CA.

name: Pine Mountain Loop
description: Pine Mountain Loop features 13 miles of hiking trails near Fairfax, Ca, CA.

name: Pine Mountain Loop
description: Pine Mountain Loop features 13 miles of hiking trails near Fairfax, Ca, CA.

name: Contra Loma Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Sobrante Ridge Regional Preserve
description: This 277-acre oak/bay parkland preserves the habitat of the extremely rare Alameda manzanita as well as other indigenous plant and animal species. A staging area at the end of Coach Drive serves as the trailhead for a two-and-one-half mile trail system that leads to ridgetop vistas of San Pablo and Richmond Bays, Mt. Diablo, and Mt. Tamalpais. For park information, telephone toll free: 888-EBPARKS (888-327-2757), option 3, ext. 4534.

name: CDT CO13: San Luis Pass to Eddiesville Trailhead
description: The CDT runs for 12.7 miles from San Luis Pass to the Eddiesville Trailhead. Along the way the trail passes Spring Creek, San Luis Peak, Organ Mountain, and Table Mountain.

name: St. Francois State Park
description: The St. Francois State Park consists of about 2,700-acres of wooded ridges, diverse hiking trails, access to the Big River and over 100 campsites. Fishing, boating, exploring, canoeing and picnicking are all very common activities here. The 15-17 miles of trails here provide the avid hiker with hours of fun. Each trail takes visitors to a whole different point of view of the beauty of nature.

name: Cabwaylingo State Forest
description: We offer several scenic trails for hikers. Along these paths, hikers can capture the scenic beauty of the forest and enjoy the many varieties of wildflowers and trees growing in the area. Overhanging rock cliffs can be found along several of these rustic trails. In the past, these cliffs provided shelter for early settlers in the area. Trails range from one mile to three miles in length.

name: Babcock State Park
description: Babcock has over 20 miles of trails.  The scenic overlooks are wonderful.

name: Randolph County State Recreation Area
description: Randolph County State Recreation Area is a 1,101-acre oasis for the avid outdoorsman. Amid rolling hills and abundant upland game cover, this area is a hunter's paradise offering quail, deer (archery only), squirrel, dove and rabbit hunting. Bass and channel catfish can be caught in its 65-acre lake. The site also provides equestrian trails, picnicking, hiking, winter sports and camping facilities.   Phone  (618) 826-2706

name: Camp Tamarancho
description: Camp Tamarancho features 10 miles of hiking trails near Marin, CA.

name: Ha Ha Tonka State Park
description: This park is known for its many hiking trails.

name: Fort Duffield
description: Fort Duffield features 10 miles of hiking trails near Louisville, KY.

name: Taylorsville Lake
description: The wonderful 24-mile trail system on this park is managed as multi-use trails for hikers, mountain bikers, and horseback riders. Wear your hiking shoes, bring your bike, or bring your horse and enjoy the fresh outdoor air!

name: Point Pinole Regional Shoreline
description: Excellent trails.

name: China Camp
description: China Camp features 12 miles of hiking trails near Marin, CA.

name: China Camp
description: China Camp features 12 miles of hiking trails near Marin, CA.

name: China Camp
description: China Camp features 12 miles of hiking trails near Marin, CA.

name: Sundance Trail
description: The Sundance Trail is best hiked in the spring or fall. Its trailhead can be reached from Utah State Highway 95 (U-95) by a series of dirt roads. Although it is generally passable by car, these roads may at times require a vehicle with up to six inches of clearance. Roads may be muddy/impassable during and after rain.

name: Dark Canyon SRMA
description: Dark Canyon is a very rugged area, and many of the trails are very strenuous. Visitors should be well prepared for extreme conditions.

name: China Camp State Park
description: A "Hike and Bike" site is available for those who travel to China Camp on foot or by bicycle.

name: JT Howell
description: JT Howell features 14 miles of hiking trails near San Rafael, CA.

name: JT Howell
description: JT Howell features 14 miles of hiking trails near San Rafael, CA.

name: JT Howell
description: JT Howell features 14 miles of hiking trails near San Rafael, CA.

name: St. James Hiking And Biking Trail
description: St. James Hiking And Biking Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near St James, MO.

name: Big Break Regional Shoreline
description: The Big Break Regional Trail, which runs along the southern edge of Big Break through the Ironhouse Sanitary District, provides access for hikers, bicyclists, and equestrians to the southeastern edge of the estuary. The trail connects to the northern end of the Marsh Creek Regional Trail, providing access to Brentwood and Oakley. The Marsh Creek Regional Trail connects to the Delta de Anza Regional Trail via West Cypress Road, providing access to Oakley, Brentwood, Antioch, Pittsburg, and Bay Point.

name: Carquinez Strait Regional Shoreline
description: Carquinez Strait Regional Shoreline comprises 1,415 acres of bluffs and shoreline along Carquinez Scenic Drive between the town of Crockett and the hillsides overlooking Martinez. This parkland provides a gateway to the river delta region along the northern edge of Contra Costa County. The coastal hills rise steeply up to 750 feet above Carquinez Strait. From the highest elevations the view includes the marshland of Benicia State Recreation Area to the north across Carquinez Strait. From atop Franklin Ridge along the Franklin Ridge Loop Trail and the California Riding and Hiking Trail, the horizon is pierced by the peaks of Mt. Tamalpais to the west and Mt. Diablo to the east. Looking south from this high point are the ridges of Briones and Las Trampas regional parks.

name: Waterbird Regional Preserve
description: The Preserve also provides hiking opportunities in the several miles of trails in the uplands area. Take the trail out of the parking area to reach the Meadowlark Ridge Loop for good views of the marsh. Walk to the northern end of the park towards the pepperwood trees to see signs of the old housing site dating from the early 1900s.

name: Martinez Regional Shoreline
description: Great trails for hiking.

name: Spring Valley State Park
description: Spring Valley State Park is a popular area for hiking, exploring, fishing, camping and sightseeing. The reservoir on the property is a home to many different types of waterfowl so birdwatching is popular here too. The park's facilities include a boat launch, trails for hiking, a campground, picnic area and a group area,

name: CDT CO14: Eddiesville Trailhead to Saguache Park Road
description: The CDT runs for 13.6 miles from the Eddiesville Trailhead to the Saguache Park Road. Along the way it passes La Gariita WB and Cochetopa Creek.

name: Crockett Hills Regional Park
description: Excellent hiking & running. Dogs allowed.

name: Blue Ridge Parkway
description:
The Parkway offers 100 trails ranging from short "leg-stretcher" walks to the Appalachian Trail. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 065: Rockfish Gap to Jarman Gap (Skyline Dr.)
description: This is the first section of the AT in Shenandoah National Park, and it begins at Rockfish Gap on I-64 and runs for 8 miles to Jarman Gap on Skyline Drive.

name: Glory Hole
description: Glory Hole features 15 miles of hiking trails near Angels Camp, CA.

name: Glory Hole
description: Glory Hole features 15 miles of hiking trails near Angels Camp, CA.

name: Glory Hole
description: Glory Hole features 15 miles of hiking trails near Angels Camp, CA.

name: Pyramid State Recreation Area
description:
Acquisition of about 16,000 acres of land from Southern Illinois University and the Campbell Pond makes this park Illinois' largest, with over 19,000 acres. Waterfowl hunting, wildlife viewing opportunities and more recreational activities are expected once the park expansion is complete. More than 500 acres of lakes make this park a hotbed for private fishing opportunities. Picnicking, horseback riding, hiking, small boating, hunting and camping are popular activities at this park.

The area offers 16.5 miles of trails that are open to horseback riding, hiking and mountain biking. In the future, an increase in trail length will be made.

name: Arrowhead Trails
description: Arrowhead Trails is a 14 mile hiking trail in Fayetteville, West Virginia.

name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
description:
Visitors can hike a mile and a half trail that winds its way through the cottonwood trees alongside the Arkansas River. The marsh is home to several species of birds. Interpretive exhibit signs tell the story of the river ecosystem, Santa Fe Trail and Bent's Fort. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Bolinas Ridge
description: Bolinas Ridge features 23 miles of hiking trails near Olema, CA.

name: Scales Lake Park Trails
description: Scales Lake Park Trails features 5 miles of hiking trails near Boonville, IN.

name: Appalachian Trail 066: Jarman Gap to Browns Gap
description: This section of the Appalachian Trail runs 15 miles through Shenandoah National Park from Jarman Gap on Skyline Drive to Browns Gap. Along the way it passes the Calf Mountain Shelter, Calf Mountain, and the Blackrock Hut.

name: Harmonie State Park
description: Trails range from moderate to easy.

name: Point Reyes National Seashore
description:
The National Seashore has about 150 miles (240 kilometers) of hiking trails to explore. Trail maps are available at the Bear Valley Visitor Center. There are many ways to customize your hike to accommodate your physical and time limitations. Stop by the Bear Valley Visitor Center for current trail information and suggested hikes.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Point Lookout State Park
description: This is not a challenging hike. The park offers a variety of route options to fit the hikers' abilities and interests. Smooth flat asphalt roads take you through the campground. The Civil War Museum/Marshland Nature Center are interesting stops. Just outside the Civil War Museum/Marshland Nature Center there is a short dock leading across a narrow salt marsh and out into Lake Conoy. Behind the Civil War Museum/Marshland Nature Center, is a short trail (Periwinkle Pt.) on the bed of a proposed 19th century Washington, D.C. to Point Lookout railroad. Continuing to meander through the campground, three route options return hikers to Route 5 and across the Causeway. To the east is the Chesapeake Bay, at its widest point. To the west is Lake Conoy. After you cross the Causeway, you can explore the site of the Civil War POW Camp for Confederates and Fort Lincoln. This is the widest spot of the peninsula and has lots of loblolly pine and smaller, dense vegetation. White tail deer and fox are often seen whe rounding bends in the trail. Continue to hike and you will pass the swimming beach and picnic area. Continue to the extreme end to the Point Lookout Lighthouse.

name: Onondaga Cave State Park
description: The Onondaga Cave State Park is known for its tall stalagmites, stalactites and flowstones. The Vilander Bluff at the park provides excellent views of the Meramec River. Visitors enjoy fishing, canoeing, caving, hiking, boating and exploring. Various hiking throughout park and through caves.

name: Honey Run
description: Honey Run features 14 miles of hiking trails near Camdenton, MO.

name: Estero Trail To Sunset Beach
description: Estero Trail To Sunset Beach features 8 miles of hiking trails near Inverness, CA.

name: Yatesville
description:
Yatesville is a beautiful park located in Eastern Kentucky. The park boasts a huge 2,242-acre lake which offers boating, fishing, and camping opportunities.

There are a few trails located in the area for visitor to enjoy. Ranging from normal hiking trails to interpretive trails, this area has something for everyone. Some of the trails do share the path with horses, though, so be on the lookout. Don't forget to enjoy some of the parks beautiful picnic sites after your hike as well!

name: Lake of the Ozarks State Park
description: Choose from 12 trails to explore Missouri's largest state park.

name: Jefferson Memorial Forest
description: The Forest has over 35 miles of hiking trails, ranging from the Siltstone trail (a rugged 6.7 miles, one way) to the Tulip Tree Trail (paved 0.3 miles, one way).

name: Washington State Park
description: Washington State Park is home to petroglyphs, hiking trails, Ozark overlooks, the Big River and a place of relaxation. Hiking, canoeing, camping, lodging, swimming, fishing, backpacking and other forms of boating are all popular here. Three hiking trails are provided and equal about nine or ten miles in length when combined.

name: Wayne Fitzgerrell State Recreation Area
description: For hikers and bikers, a newly constructed 4-mile hiking/biking trail is in place which runs from the day use areas through the campgrounds to Rend Lake Resort, and then connects to the Rend Lake College Bike Trail.

name: Mono Lake Tufa State Natural Reserve
description: Hiking, photography, bird watching, swimming, boating, and cross-country skiing are just a few of the many activities you can enjoy at this unusual lake.

name: McNeely Lake Park
description: Gravel and dirt trails along banks of McNeely lake, and into woods at the south end of the lake. Trails connect with horse trails and McNeely Lake Park South.

name: Yatesville Lake State Park
description:
Mary Ingle Trail System 2.5 mile
Located at the marina area, system of 6 separate trail loops: 3 rugged, wooded hiking trails; 2 exercise paths; 1 ADA self interpretive nature trail

Multi-Use Trail 20 mile
Operated by Lawrence County Saddle Club, 20 miles, open to hikers, backpackers, mountain bikers, and horseback riders, located near campground, limited number of stalls available

Pleasant Ridge Trail System 0 mile
5 separate trails, wooded nature trails extending through campground area towards lake

name: Trail Of The 4 Winds
description: Trail Of The 4 Winds features 12 miles of hiking trails near Kaiser, MO.

name: Rend Lake
description: Trails throughout area.

name: Greenbrier River Trail
description: Greenbrier River Trail features 76 miles of hiking trails near White Sulpher Springs, WV.

name: Watoga State Park
description: Great trails.

name: Droop Mountain Battlefield State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Pocomoke River State Park
description: A self-guided trail approximately one mile long leads you through old growth forest, which was once farmland, to the cool temperatures of the cypress swamp. Learn how this forest through time and man's activities has adapted and changed.

name: Hawks Nest State Park
description: Several excellent trails.

name: Tomales Bay State Park
description:
The Johnstone Trail offers hikers a trip from Heart's Desire Beach to Jepson Memorial Grove for a 3 mile round trip
with 300-foot elevation gain; to Shell Beach is an 8 mile round trip.

name: Cave Run
description:
Cave Run Lake is almost entirely surrounded by the northern section of the Daniel Boone National Forest. The lake is 8,270 acres in total and it is widely known for its beauty and outdoor recreation.

There are some great trails around the lake, especially in the Stoney Cove Rec Area, as well as picnic areas, a playground, a fishing station, and a boat ramp.

name: Cave-run Lake
description: Cave-run Lake features 0 miles of hiking trails near Owingsville, KY.

name: Laurel Creek Trail At Rimel Wv
description: Laurel Creek Trail At Rimel Wv features 9 miles of hiking trails near Marlinton, WV.

name: Sand Hills State Park
description: Eight multi-use trails for hiking.

name: CDT CO15: Saguache Park Road to CO Hwy 114 Trailhead
description: Section 15 of the CDT travels for 13.5 miles through the high mountains of Colorado from Saguache Park Road to the trailhead at CO Hwy 114.

name: Waverly Park
description: Waverly Park features 15 miles of hiking trails near Louisville, KY.

name: Lake Anna State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Marconi Conference Center
description:
The Marconi Conference Center is situated on wooded hills overlooking the eastern shore of Tomales Bay in Marin County. The center offers many walking trails through the property.

Some take you through the California Bay forest, another takes you along the meadow trail of grasslands which leads you to a beautiful ridge view, or guests also have the option to take shorter trails around the immediate forest to the conference center.

Wherever you choose to hike at Marconi offers a refreshing break from business and the opportunity to see a vast array of wildlife and various types of flowers and vegetation, including but not limited to, Mule Deer, many different bird species, butterflies, and wild flowers of unbelievable diversity.

This setting is ideal for any type of conference, business conjunction, or organization meeting place.

name: Montgomery Hall Park
description: Montgomery Hall Park features 2 miles of hiking trails near Staunton, VA.

name: Olompali State Historic Park
description:
Olompali and Mt. Burdell Trails offer hikers a
2.75 miles round trip with 600-foot elevation gain.

name: Stanislaus River Parks
description: Activities here include hiking, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Westmoreland State Park
description: Seven trails, including self-guided interpretive trails, cover six miles. Hikers can observe the flora and wildlife present on the coastal plain. The park's location beside the Potomac River allows visitors to see how the changing river level affects the land. The park has a beach trail that offers a stunning view of the Potomac River. There are no designated swimming areas along the park's shoreline.

name: Falls Hallow Trail
description: A Yellow blazed trail leads you along an access road that gives way to follow a stream with at least two waterfalls. The second part of the trail takes a sharp left cutting across the mountain face leading you to yet another access road.  The steap access road takes you to the summit for a total of 2,425 ft. gain in elevation.  Summit elevation- 4,463 ft.

name: New Hogan Lake
description: Trails throughout the area.

name: Canyonlands National Park
description:
Canyonlands has hundreds of miles of hiking trails which explore the park's natural and cultural features. Both the Island in the Sky and the Needles provide ample opportunities for short walks, day hikes and backpacking trips. Due to its remoteness, the Maze is primarily a backpacking destination.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Preddy Creek
description: Preddy Creek features 8 miles of hiking trails near Ruckersville, VA.

name: Capital View
description: Capital View features 7 miles of hiking trails near Frankfort, KY.

name: Cow Pasture Trail
description: Cow Pasture Trail features 7 miles of hiking trails near Cranberry Glades, WV.

name: Bittersweet
description: Bittersweet features 9 miles of hiking trails near Lake Ozark, MO.

name: O'Bannon Woods State Park
description: Nine trails offer a great variety of hikes.

name: Kennison Mountain Trail
description: Kennison Mountain Trail features 9 miles of hiking trails near Richwood, WV.

name: Arnold Rim Trail
description: Arnold Rim Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near Arnold, CA.

name: Top Of The World
description: Top Of The World features 6 miles of hiking trails near Arnold, CA.

name: Meramec State Park
description: Traverse through the natural features of the park on one of seven trails.

name: Grayson Lake State Park
description: The .8-mile Beech-Hemlock Forest Trail is an opportunity to discover and appreciate the distinctive plants, rock formations, and wildlife of the park. The trail begins near the theater area, and circles the campground near the shoreline of the lake. Of particular interest on the trail are the several species of ferns, mosses, and lichens, the flowering rhododendron, "lizard head rock," and the unusual combination of beech-hemlock trees. For the hearty hiker, there is also a 3 mile Lick Falls trail.

name: Joe Creason Park
description: Popular with bird watchers and cross-county runners, this park houses the Metro Parks administrative offices and the Louisville Tennis Center's nine clay courts; the Louisville Nature Center and Louisville Zoo are nearby. The 41-acre Beargrass Creek State Nature Preserve, with a 3.1-mile hiking trail managed by the Louisville Nature Center, is open to the public.

name: Helen Putnam Reginal Park
description: Helen Putnam Reginal Park features 13 miles of hiking trails near Petaluma, CA.
