Pick up the description of the rest of Northern California Section R or the end of Oregon Section A <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/2639/Hiking-Trails/Pacific-Crest-Trail--A--California-Border-to-I-5.html">here</a>.

name: Geneva State Park
description: 6 miles of multi-use trails traverse the park and are used by hikers, snowmobilers, cross-country skiers and hunters

name: Brezina Woods
description: Brezina Woods offers cycling, hiking, inline skating and picnicking.

name: Morrison-Rockwood State Park
description:
Boasting an abundant animal population, Morrison-Rockwood State Park offers woodland, water and other habitat to deer, foxes, coyotes, muskrats, groundhog, quail, geese, ducks, pheasants, rabbits and turkeys. The 1,164-acre site, which includes the beautiful 77-acre Lake Carlton, is a site that is abundant in recreational opportunities. Enjoy birdwatching, picnicking, fishing, hunting, boating, hiking and camping at this diverse state park. Winter sports are also popular at Morrison Rockwood State Park-- ice fishing and ice skating are permitted during the winter months. The park also offers 14 miles of cross country ski trails.

A three and a half mile nature trail offers many scenic views of the lake and forest. During the spring, wildflowers are abundant. The park also offers a 14-mile equestrian trail, which can be used by pedestrians.

name: Ogden Mills & Ruth Livingston Mills State Park
description: Several miles of trails.

name: Franklin Creek State Natural Area
description: Four and one-half miles of hiking trails are marked and maintained at the park. All trail markers are numbered and clearly shown on the park map. The Mill Springs Trail is a unique, concrete-surfaced trail suitable for people of all mobility levels. The trail leads to the beautiful Mill Spring and possesses an easy rating. Pioneer Pass is highly recommended to see the park's unique, natural beauty.

name: Dighton Rock State Park
description: Hiking and walking trails offer excellent opportunity for wildlife viewing and nature study.

name: Morrison Trail Loop
description: Part of the 10.8 mile (17 kilometer) Morrison trail, which also includes the Rimrock trail loop. The two loops offer a 2-day backpacking experience or a short day hike. This trail leads to Morrison Campground, a boat access located on Kinzua Bay of the Allegheny Reservoir. Facilities at the trailhead include a vault restroom and informational signing.

name: Mashamoquet Brook State Park
description: Rich with history, legend and lore, Mashamoquet Brook with its Wolf's Den, offers hiking, camping, fishing, and swimming for the whole family.

name: Paugnut State Forest
description: Paugnut State Forest's 1,702 acres spread out over four locations in north central Torrington and abut Burr Pond and Sunny Brook state parks. The main section of Paugnut totals more than 1,200 acres and is home to the 2.1 mile John Muir Trail which connects the two parks via the forest.

name: Stratton Brook State Park
description: A network of trails offers beautiful and scenic hikes through the surrounding wildnerness area.

name: Burr Pond State Park
description: Hike around the pond and connect with the John Muir Trail.

name: Beed's Lake State Park
description: A two-mile trail provides a unique hiking experience for visitors as it follows the shoreline around Beed's Lake. At the spillway, visitors can hike to the base of the dam and experience a cool refreshing mist as water rolls down the beautiful limestone face. This trail may be utilized by hikers, bicyclists, cross-country skiers and joggers.

name: Wilson Island State Recreation Area
description: Approximately five miles of trails are used for hiking, snowmobiling, cross-country skiing and mountain biking.

name: Massasoit State Park
description: Massasoit State Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Taunton, MA.

name: West Chicago Prairie Forest Preserve
description: Nine linking footpaths meander through West Chicago Prairie. Many connect with the Illinois Prairie Path, which leads outside of the forest preserve and connects with West Chicago's Reed-Keppler Park.

name: Massacoe State Forest
description: In the midst of suburban development, Great Pond's 297 acres of open space are a welcome relief.  Here nearly five miles of trails help you explore the relatively flat, quiet woodlands and provide access to Great Pond itself which, at 36 1/4 acres, is Simsbury's largest open water body.

name: Tk Lawless State Park
description: Tk Lawless State Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Vandalia, MI.

name: Warren Dunes State Park
description: Six miles of winding trails.

name: Timber Ridge
description: Timber Ridge has two miles of multipurpose trails and is a trailhead for the Great Western Trail and Illinois Prairie Path.

name: Lincoln Woods State Park
description: Lincoln Woods features 10 miles of hiking trails near Lincoln, RI.

name: Salt Springs State Park
description: The trails pass through old growth forest, overlook the gorge and meander through various habitats.

name: West DuPage Woods
description: Trails include a one-mile loop from the main parking lot and a two-mile loop from the Elsen's Hill parking lot. Both offer a variety of terrain and are very popular for hiking, cross-country skiing and horseback riding.

name: Palisades-Kepler State Park
description: Palisades-Kepler is a wonderful place to hike. On the six miles of trails, walkers can often see a variety of wildlife, including white-tailed deer and wild turkeys. Many species of trees, shrubs and flowers are also present along with innumerable species of songbirds.

name: Evans Field
description: Cycling, hiking, and picnicking are popular at Evans Field.

name: East Branch Forest Preserve
description: One 0.8-mile trail and several unmarked footpaths allow visitors to observe everything from white-tailed deer and coyotes to great blue herons and migrant waterfowl.

name: American Legion State Forest
description: Eight trails offer hikers great treks through the forest.

name: Cricket Creek Forest Preserve
description: Trails wind through the preserve and around the lakes and are ideal for hiking, biking, jogging and cross-country skiing.

name: Sterling State Park
description: A total of seven miles of trails provide opportunities for hiking, biking and exploring. The 2.9-mile paved Marsh Trail circles one of the marsh lagoons in the park. A 0.6-mile hiking trail follows the Lake Erie shoreline. These trails include interpretive stations, an observation deck and a covered pavilion with spotting scopes.

name: Fullerton Woods
description: Great cycling, hiking and picnicking.

name: Peoples State Forest
description: Six trails offer over ten miles of hiking.

name: West Branch Forest Preserve
description: Over 2 miles of trails ideal for hiking, bicycling, cross-country skiing and horseback riding winds through the preserve and connects to the Hawk Hollow Preserve trail system to the north.

name: Herritage Park
description: Herritage Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Adrian, MI.

name: Appalachian Trail 121: US 7 to CT 41
description: The Appalachian Trail runs 10.8 miles from US Hwy 7 to CT Hwy 41. Along the way it passes the Falls Village Handicap Accessible Trailhead, Great Falls Parking, Falls Village, Mount Prospect, the Limestone Spring Lean-to, and Canaan Road.

name: Beverly Park
description: Beverly Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Cedar Rapids, IA.

name: George Washington State Campground and Management Area
description: The 4,000-acre George Washington Management Area houses the 100-acre George Washington Memorial Campground. Activities offered here include biking, hiking, fishing, boating and swimming.

name: Round Top
description: Round Top features 10 miles of hiking trails near Athens, PA.

name: Songbird Slough Forest Preserve
description: Hikers and bicyclists can utilize the one-mile paved road in the preserve, but presently there are no nature trails or footpaths.

name: Dennis Hill State Park
description: A unique summit pavilion (formerly summer residence), located at an elevation of 1627 feet, is a popular attraction. Haystack Mountain, Mt. Greylock, the Green Mountains, and a portion of the State of New Hampshire can be seen from the summit in clear weather.

name: Quaddick State Park
description: Great trails for hikers.

name: Spring Creek Reservoir
description: With a half mile of shoreline and several benches scattered along the asphalt trail, Spring Creek Reservoir Forest Preserve is popular with exercise enthusiasts.

name: Pratt's Wayne Woods County Forest Preserve
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lowden-Miller State Forest
description: Lowden-Miller State Forest has approximately 22 miles of maintained trails available for hiking and cross-country skiing. Trails are open for use year-round except for a few days during the firearm hunting season. Check for closing dates at Castle Rock State Park.

name: West Thompson Lake
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Meacham Grove Forest Preserve
description: Hikers, bicyclists and cross-country skiers can explore 2.5 miles of limestone trails, which loop around the lake and through the adjacent wetlands. This stretch provides an excellent opportunity to observe great egrets, great blue herons, a variety of swallows, and other native wildlife, including beavers and dragonflies.

name: Robinson Woods-South
description: Robinson Woods-South offers picnicking facilities and trails for cycling and hiking.

name: Mallard Lake Forest Preserve
description: A 2.5-mile trail system, including a boardwalk ideal for bird-watching, winds around the lake and over two bridges and connects to Bartlett Park District trails.

name: Castle Rock State Park
description: The forest here is lush and mossy, crisscrossed by 32 miles of hiking and horseback riding trails. These trails are part of an even more extensive trail system that links the Santa Clara and San Lorenzo valleys with Castle Rock State Park, Big Basin Redwoods State Park, and the Pacific Coast.

name: Hawk Hollow Forest Preserve
description: A three-mile multipurpose trail meanders through the preserve, connecting to trails in Mallard Lake Preserve, West Branch Preserve, and the Bartlett Park District Trail System.

name: Catherine Chevalier Woods
description: Catherine Chevalier Woods offers picnicking facilities as well as trails for hiking and cycling.

name: Jockey Hill
description: Jockey Hill is a 15 mile hiking trail in Kingston, New York.

name: Castle Rock State Park
description: There are 6 miles of marked hiking trails where hikers can view woodland animals and birds inhabiting the park and photographers can sharpen their skills. More trails are planned with the park's development. Cross-country skiing and tobogganing also are available when weather permits.

name: Air Line State Park Trail
description: Though the rails are long gone, this rail bed once offered fashionable, rapid transit from New York to Boston.  Those who travel the corridor today witness the same inspiring panoramas and absorb the same solitude that has greeted travelers since the line was constructed. Stretching across eastern Connecticut from Thompson to East Hampton, this linear trail dates from the 1870s, and today draws walkers, hikers, horseback riders and bikers from across the state for the views, the relaxation and the solitude.

name: Shenipsit State Forest
description: Great hiking trails. The two primary attractions are the wonderful hiking along the Blue-Blazed Shenipsit Trail which passes over Soapstone Mountain and the amazing views from the Soapstone Mountain observation tower. While the original fire tower is long gone, today's tower stands specifically for the public's recreational viewing. As one of only two observation towers in Eastern Connecticut (the other being the monument at Fort Griswold State Park in Groton), the vistas afforded from this vantage point are spectacular as visitors can take in scenes from the Connecticut River Valley to the Springfield skyline.

name: Windsor Locks Canal State Park Trail
description: The 4.5 mile Windsor Locks State Park Canal Trail follows the historic towpath of this 170 plus year old historic waterway. The canal's many vantage points offer the trail user scenic vistas of both the Connecticut River and the old canal. Today's paved surface lies atop the towpath, the actual walkway which animals, often mules, hauled the freight barges by rope north and south along the water way. Author Charles Dickens was a notable visitor who passed through the canal on February 7, 1842.

name: Cowanesque Lake
description: Trails available at Cowanesque Lake, South Shore, and Tompkins Campground areas.

name: White Pines Forest State Park
description: Whether you choose an easy walking trail or a more difficult path, three of the seven marked trails are less than a mile long and provide ample opportunity to see the beautiful vine-covered limestone bluffs, blossoming spring flowers and whispering pines. The trails have color-coded markers to aid the hiker in orienteering. A nature trail with a limestone-screened path is accessible for the physically challenged.

name: Bigelow Hollow State Park
description: Marked trails lead from Bigelow Hollow to the Breakneck area, but no trail in this area is a loop trail. Hikers should be prepared to walk at least 6 miles to complete a loop around Breakneck. There are no marked trails to Briggs pond. For hikers desiring trails that start and end in the same place, the trails west of the park road both form loops and cover less of a distance than the trails leading to Breakneck.  This extensive trail system is maintained in cooperation with the Connecticut Forest and Park Association, which provides volunteer assistance.

name: Nipmunk State Forest
description: Natchaug & Nipmuck Trails- This trail is a part of a much longer trail that goes to Massachusetts. There is a campsite for backpacking, well marked trails, and a scenic small waterfall area (Pixie Falls). This is a great hike for families.

name: Kinzua Dam And Allegheny Reservoir
description:
Totally surrounded by forest, Kinzua Dam and Allegheny Reservoir are the heart of one of the largest and most popular outdoor recreation complexes in the northeastern United States. The Allegheny Reservoir spans the border between Pennsylvania and New York. In Pennsylvania , the reservoir is completely surrounded by the Allegheny National Forest.

Near Big Bend Outflow and Big Bend Overlook there are a couple interpretive hiking trails to explore. There are also some nice picnic areas with playgrounds and picnic shelters.

name: Ledges State Park
description: Ledges, one of Iowa's most popular state parks, has attracted millions of visitors. Thirteen miles of hiking trails lead up and down steep slopes to scenic overlooks and provide access to spectacular views of Pea's Creek "canyon". While most of the trails include steep portions, a fully accessible interpretive trail around Lost Lake is located at the southern part of the park.

name: Appalachian Trail 122: CT 41 to Sages Ravine
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs 7.4 miles from CT Hwy 41 to Sages Ravine. Along the way it passes the Riga Lean-to, the Brassie Brook Lean-to, and Bear Mountain.<br />
Note: if you are north bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in Massachusetts (or just <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/2450/Hiking-Trails/Appalachian-Trail-123--Sages-Ravine-to-Jug-End-Road.html">click here</a>).

name: Algonquin State Forest
description: Good trails for wildlife viewing.

name: Haystack Mountain State Park
description: A roadway provides access halfway up the mountain. Prominent along the road is a spectacle of foliage in the fall and an outstanding show of mountain laurel in June. From the end of the road there is a rugged half-mile trail to the top. Allow about half an hour for this walk if you are not a seasoned hiker.

name: Caldwell Woods
description: Over 200 miles of multi-use trails exist within this forest preserve. Some are as short as a 2 mile loop, while others extend up to 20 miles. Enjoy a relaxing walk, or a sweat-inducing hike on these trails.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Oregon
description: The Pacific Crest Trail runs North/South through the state, running about 460 miles from the California border to the Washington border. For more detailed information about each section of the trail, please click on the individual trail listings below.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: A: California Border to I-5
description:
Section A is the first section of the Pacific Crest Trail in Oregon, running north 27.8 miles from the California Border to I-5. There are many logging roads in the area, so the trail is usually paralleling a road.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes Observation Gap; Jackson Gap; Wrangle Gap; Siskiyou Gap; Grouse Gap, Road 40S30; Road 2080; and Ashland, OR.<br />
<br />
For the rest of Section A in California/Northern California Section R, please click here.

name: Grand Mere State Park
description: The first 1/4 mile of the trail is paved.

name: Waverly Glen
description: Waverly Glen features 20 miles of hiking trails near Waverly, NY.

name: Bunker Hill
description: Bunker Hill is an Ecological Management Site with picnicking, bird watching, and trails for cycling, hiking and inline skating.

name: CDT WY07: Co Rd 63 to Co Rd 22
description: Section 7 of the CDT in Wyoming runs 21.9 miles from County Road 63 to County Road 22. Along the way, the trail passes Separation Point and Bull Springs Rim.

name: Colebrook River Lake
description: Trails throughout area.

name: Camp Ground Road Woods
description: Camp Ground Road Woods provides picnicking facilities as well as trails for cycling and hiking.

name: Busse Forest Elk Pasture
description: Busse Forest Elk Pasture provides trails for inline skating, hiking, and cycling.

name: Lowden State Park
description: Almost 4 miles of good foot trails lead visitors through the natural wonders and beauty of the park.

name: Busse Forest - North
description: This park is an Ecological Management Site popular for bird-watching, cycling, hiking, inline skating and picnicking.

name: Douglas State Forest
description: Bordering both Connecticut and Rhode Island, this popular 5,907-acre state forest offers a variety of recreational opportunities. I didn't put the trail length because there are many trails from 1/2 mile to many miles. Trail maps are online.

name: Silver Creek State Forest Campground
description: Silver Creek (on site): 4 miles of rolling terrain extending from Lincoln Bridge State Forest Campground to Silver Creek State Forest Campground.

name: Busse North Pool
description: This park is an Ecological Management Site offering visitors birdwatching, cycling, hiking, inline skating and picnicking opportunities.

name: Miami Woods
description: Miami Woods is an Ecological Management Site offering cycling, hiking, inline skating and picnicking.

name: Duxbury
description: Duxbury features 8 miles of hiking trails near Duxbury, MA.

name: Bode Lake
description: Bode Lake has great trails for cycling, hiking and inline skating; fishing is also available.

name: Wrentham State Forest
description: Wrentham State Forest features 17 miles of hiking trails near Wrentham, MA.

name: Campbell Falls State Park Reserve
description: Hike through a beautiful natural setting that includes dense forest and waterfalls.

name: Poplar Creek Trail
description: Poplar Creek Trail provides opportunities for hiking, biking and horseback riding.

name: Lewis and Clark State Park
description: Lewis and Clark State Park is a fine place for a leisurely hike. On the trails, park visitors can see a variety of trees, shrubs, and, often, wildlife including deer, rabbits and squirrels, as well as a wide variety of bird species.

name: Ned Brown Meadow
description: Ned Brown Meadow offers trails for cycling, hiking, inline skating, picnicking, snowmobiling and model airplane flying fields.

name: Appalachian Trail: Massachusetts
description: The Appalachian Trail, which runs from Georgia to Maine, runs for 91 miles through the state of Massachusetts, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3254/Connecticut/Appalachian-Trail--Connecticut.html">Connecticut</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3328/Vermont/Appalachian-Trail--Vermont.html">Vermont</a> border. To get more detailed information about the individual sections of the AT in Massachusetts, please click on the individual section listings below.

name: Barrington Road Pond
description: Barrington Road Pond offers excellent cycling, hiking, inline skating and picnicking opportunities.

name: Appalachian Trail 123: Sages Ravine to Jug End Road
description:
The AT runs 9.5 miles from Sages Ravine near the CT/MA border to Jug End Road. Along the way it passes Mount Race, Mt Everett Rd., Guilder Pond Picnic Area, Guilder Pond, The Hemlocks Lean-to, and the Glen Brook Lean-to.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spots:<br />
"Guilder Pond Picnic Area" lat=42.1069448324, lon=-73.4356997841<br />
"Jug End Road" lat=42.144540467, lon=-73.4311608269<br />
<br />
Note: if you are south bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in Connecticut (or just click here).

name: Big Bend Lake
description: Enjoy the park's opportunities for boating, fishing, cycling, horseback riding, hiking and picnicking.

name: Glen Grove Equestrian Center
description: Glen Grove Equestrian Center provides trails for hiking, cycling and horseback riding.

name: Calvin R. Sutker Grove
description: Visit this Ecological Management Site for great cycling, horseback riding, and hiking.

name: Borderland State Park
description:
Borderland State Park is an extremely historically significant landmark in Massachusetts. The park originated in the early 1900s as a home to the artist Blanche Ames and her husband Oakes, a botanist. The couple's large stone mansion and many of its furnishings remain on the property. After their deaths, the property was transformed into a beautiful state park.

The large estate is a relaxing area to horseback ride, fish, canoe, walk or in the winter months, ice-skate and sled. The park also offers tours of the home.

name: Granville State Forest
description:
This 2,426-acre state forest borders Connecticut's 9,152-acre Tunxis State Forest. Woodlands are endless here providing for tranquil walks, relaxing hikes, invigorating horseback riding and simple, yet exciting fishing experiences. The Hubbard River on the property has cascades that flow through natural rock formations and form pools and waterfalls. The waters drop a rapid 450 feet in 2.5 miles.

Other popular activities at this lovely park include bird watching, camping, wildlife viewing, snowshoeing, and mountain biking.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: B: I-5 to Highway 140
description:
Section B of the Pacific Crest Trail in Oregon runs 54 miles from I-5 near Siskiyou Pass to Highway 140 near Fish Lake. Unfortunately, this section is one of the lowest and driest in both Oregon and Washington and its proximity to roads and logged areas eliminates any wilderness feeling that it might otherwise have had.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes Ashland, OR; Little Pilot Peak; Highway 66 at Green Springs Summit; Road 100-90; Hyatt lake Recreation Road 100-90; Hyatt Lake Campground; Hyatt Lake Resort, Ashland, OR; Road 39-3E-15; Wildcat Glades Road 39-3E-11; Grizzly Creek; Rogue River National Forest; Road 3720-740; and South Fork Little Butte Creek.

name: Harms Woods - Central Park
description: Harms Woods-Central Park is a relatively small county park in northeastern Illinois. Activities here include mountain biking, hiking and ice skating.

name: F. Gilbert Hills State Forest
description: The forest has 23 miles (37 km) trails, including a section of the 30-mile (48 km) Warner Trail, for walking, hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, cross-country skiing and off-road vehicle use.

name: Harris Beach State Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Paul Douglas & Crabtree Trail (Paved)
description: Excellent trail for cycling, hiking, and inline skating.

name: Glenview Woods
description: Glenview Woods offers excellent cycling, hiking and inline skating.

name: Beck Lake
description: Boating, cycling, fishing and hiking draw visitors to this wonderful urban park getaway.

name: Carl R. Hansen Woods
description: At this Ecological Management Site, visitors enjoy cycling, hiking, inline skating and picnicking.

name: Conant Brook Dam
description: Great trails.

name: Westville Lake
description: Hiking trails throughout the area.

name: Blue Star Memorial Woods
description: Blue Star offers excellent cycling, hiking, inline skating trails, as well as picnicking facilities.

name: Pilot Rock
description: Excellent hiking & climbing.

name: Southern New England Trunkline Trail
description: The Southern New England Trunkline Trail is a rail trail in Massachusetts. It occupies an abandoned railroad corridor running for approximately 22 miles (35 km) with an eastern terminus at Union Street in downtown Franklin, Massachusetts and a western terminus at the Connecticut state line in the Douglas State Forest, Douglas, Massachusetts. This railroad was built as the New York and New England Railroad, which was absorbed by the New Haven Railroad.

name: Beverly Lake
description: Beverly Lake   features 6 miles of hiking trails near Hoffman Estates, IL.

name: Camp Pine Woods
description: Visitors enjoy cycling, hiking and picnicking.

name: Lake Avenue Woods
description: Bird-watching, cycling, hiking and picnicking draw visitors to this lovely park.

name: City of Rocks National Reserve
description:
To venture into City of Rocks is to enter a world of slowly changing granite surrounded by high desert flora and<br />
fauna. Access to many or most parts of the reserve is found through 22.4 miles of trail. Many sections of trail<br />
pass through fragile soils. Help preserve City of Rocks by using designated trails and leaving natural features as<br />
you find them. Many of the trails are rocky and traverse steep terrain. Snow may cover some trails until mid-May.<br />
Check with a ranger or visitor center personnel prior to entering the backcountry for latest conditions.

name: Sandisfield State Forest (York Lake)
description:
The 300-foot beach of the York Lake is a popular attraction at the Sandisfield State Forest for swimming, picnicking and relaxing. Hunting (seasonally), walking, hiking, horseback riding and cross-country skiing are other popular activities at this hardwood state forest. The Campbell Falls State Park is also a nearby attraction that offers additional recreational activities and multi-use trails.

The 2.2 mile Pond Loop Trail is the most popular moderate level trail at Sandisfield-- it offers fantastic views of the lake.

name: Lake Taghkanic State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: River Trail Nature Center
description: This is a designated ecological management site; bird-watching, cycling, hiking, and a nature center attract visitors.

name: Oregon Caves National Monument
description:
Within the park there are four hiking trails with wonderful views of Oregon Caves National Monument and the Siskiyou Mountains that surround it. Most of the trails weave in and out of the boundary of the monument.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Brimfield State Forest
description: Brimfield State Forest  is home to 20 miles of roads and trails that can be used for hiking, walking and horseback riding. You'll also find Dean Pond Recreation Area on the park's property. This area is popular because of its 100-ft beach. Visitors love to sunbathe and fish here. There are multi-use trails, restrooms and several picnic areas for your fun and convenience.

name: Pinnacle State Park and Golf Course
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Erickson Woods
description: Visitors can enjoy bird-watching, cycling, hiking, inline skating, fishing, and picnicking.

name: Allegany State Park - Red House Area
description: Paved hiking trails.

name: Skokie lagoons
description: Skokie lagoons features 7 miles of hiking trails near Glencoe, IL.

name: Robinson state park
description: Robinson state park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Agawam, MA.

name: Allison Woods
description: Allison Woods offers paddling, picnicking facilities, as well as trails for cycling and hiking.

name: West Hill Dam
description: Great trails.

name: Mt. Everett State Reservation
description: This 1,356 acre state reservation is home to Mount Everett, a 2,000 ft plus mountain in the southwest corner of Massachusetts. The scenic Guilder Pond on the property provides a great setting for picnicking and fishing. Hiking trails take you through the park and up Mt. Everett. Cross country skiing is also common during the winter.

name: Bristol Blake State Reservation
description: Bristol Blake State Reservation is a 140-acre oasis in the town of Norfolk. The Stony Brook Pond and Teal Marsh are beautiful additions to the park, also adding more recreational fun for visitors. Wildlife observation and birdwatching thrive at this well protected park. An enchanting boardwalk leads over Kingfisher Pond to a stand of beech trees for a relaxing stroll. Hiking and snowshoeing are popular activities here.

name: East Brimfield Lake Park
description: East Brimfield Lake Park is a very destination for outdoor recreation. This dam cover a total of 2,070 acres and offers year-round opportunities. Activities here include hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing and kayaking.

name: Bash Bish Falls State Park
description: This 150-ft high set of waterfalls make for a fantastic picnic and wading location. The beautiful cascades and deep plunge of the falls will take your breath away. This is Massachusetts' highest single-drop waterfall. Bash Bish Falls is located next to the 4,169 acre Mount Washington State Forest which offers 30 miles of trails.

name: Buffumville Lake
description: Recognized as the Project of the Year 2000, this 200-acre lake offers state-of-the-art facilities for the latest recreational pursuits including BMX-style bike jumps, mountain bike trails and an 18-hole disk golf course. More traditional forms of recreation include fishing, hunting, 7 miles of multi-use trails, group picnic shelters and ice skating. For up-to-date information, call (508) 248-5697.

name: Crabtree Nature Center
description: This Ecological Management Site offers excellent walking trails.

name: Alfred A. Loeb State Park
description: The northern-most redwood grove in the U.S. can be found at the end of the Riverview Trail by crossing the North Bank Road and hiking the 1-mile U.S. Forest Service Redwood loop.

name: Ames Nowell State Park
description: Ames Nowell features 10 miles of hiking trails near Abington, MA.

name: Maquoketa Caves State Park
description: Hikers can enjoy the scenery along the 6 miles of trails. The trails in the eastern part of the park connect the park facilities and provide access to the caves. Trail highlights include the dramatic "Natural Bridge" which stand nearly 50 feet above Raccoon Creek, 17-ton "Balanced Rock", and "Dancehall Cave." A trail in the western area of the park takes hikers past a restored prairie, an experimental oak savanna restoration and a wildlife food plot.

name: Hodges Village Dam
description: Great hiking.

name: Raceway Woods
description: Raceway Woods is a 8 mile hiking trail in Carpentersville, Illinois.

name: Taconic State Park - Rudd Pond Area
description: A portion of the AT runs through Taconic State Park

name: Taconic State Park - Copake Falls Area
description: Great trails.

name: Pleasant Creek State Recreation Area
description:
At Pleasant Creek State Recreation Area more than 1,500 acres of land are available for visitors use, including a 410-acre lake for swimming, fishing and boating opportunities. This park is a relaxing location for a hike, a bike ride or a picnic. It is also one of the most popular boating areas in eastern Iowa.

There are ten miles of hiking trails on the property. These trails can also be used for biking, snowmobiling and cross country skiing. Many of the trails have scenic overlooks and access to park facilities.

name: Purgatory Chasm State Reservation
description: Purgatory Chasm State Reservation includes a .25-mile granite chasm, that reaches 70 feet high in places. There are a variety of rock formations throughout the reservation that can be seen by following the park's many trails.  Picnicking and rock climbing are common at the reservation, as well as hiking and exploring. The rock's can be slippery so wear rubber soles and appropriate equipment. It is not advised to visit this park during or directly after inclement weather.

name: Mt. Washington State Forest
description:
The 4,169 acre Mount Washington State Forest is located in the southern Taconic Mountains of the southwestern Berkshire region of Massachusetts. This state forest is situated high on a mountain plateau which offers spectacular views of the rolling woodlands surrounding it. 30 miles of multi-use trails are on the property, making it a great location for hiking, trail running, mountain biking and horseback riding. Wilderness camping is very common here.

Bash Bish Falls, a common tourist attraction, is adjacent to the forest.

name: Tower Road(skokie)
description: Visitors enjoy birding, cycling, fishing, hiking and inline skating.

name: Dam No 1 Woods-East
description: Walking/jogging.

name: Deer Grove Forest Preserve
description: Deer Grove features 10 miles of hiking trails near Palatine, IL.

name: Camp Alphonse
description: Camp Alphonse offers youth group camping, cycling and hiking.

name: Spring Lake (unpaved) Nature Preserve
description: Enjoy the park's horseback riding and hiking trails. There are also cycling opportunities.

name: Potawatomi Woods
description: Potawatomi Woods offers cycling, fishing, hiking anad picnicking.

name: Somme Woods
description: This Ecological Management Site offers hiking and picnicking.

name: Baker's Lake Younghusband Prairie
description: Bird-watching and hiking are popular here.

name: Castle Rocks State Park
description: Abundant opportunities for hiking in this unique terrain.

name: Mississippi Palisades State Park
description: The gateway to seeing the park's impressive assortment of plant and animal life is its rugged 15-mile trail system. The five trails in the northern part of the park are generally wider and less strenuous than the five in the south, which are narrow and extremely close to the bluff. The southern trails are hazardous when wet. Hiking trails are closed during the park's three-day firearm deer season, and specific information in available at the park office.

name: Jug End State Reservation & Wildlife Management Area
description: For hikers, the 2 mile Jug End Loop Trail journeys through a mixture of open fields, northern hardwood and Eastern Hemlock woodlands. Access and parking is also available to the Appalachian Trail, on Jug End Rd. (unpaved section), linking it to Mount Everett State Reservation.

name: Appalachian Trail 124: Jug End Road to US 7
description: The AT runs 4.5 miles from Jug End Road to US Highway 7. Along the way it passes MA Hwy 41 and Sheffield Egremont Road.

name: Baker's Lake Overlook
description: This Ecological Management Site is known for excellent birding and hiking.

name: Tolland State Forest
description: The 1,065-acre Otis Reservoir in the Tolland State Forest provides a wide variety of recreational activities to visitors. Fishing and swimming are popular at the park, as well as camping, hiking, picnicking, walking, hunting, mountain biking  and cross country skiing. The wooded peninsula also provides a sandy beach for visitors to relax and sunbathe on. Accessible restrooms and a boat ramp are also available for public convenience.

name: Tully Lake
description: The 22-mile (35 km) Tully Trail, a recreational trail cooperatively managed by the USACE, TTOR, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the National Park Service, and the Mount Grace Land Conservation Trust, runs along the northern shore of Tully Lake.

name: Appalachian Trail 125: US 7 to MA 23 (Great Barrington)
description:
The AT runs 8.4 miles from US Hwy 7 to MA Hwy 23 (Great Barrington). Along the way it passes Kellogg Road, Homes Road, the Tom Leonard Lean-to, and Lake Buel Road.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"Kellogg Road" lat=42.1443918907, lon=-73.3599557179

name: Wells State Park
description: Wells State Park features 10 miles of hiking trails in Sturbridge, MA.

name: Samuel H. Boardman State Scenic Corridor
description: Excellent hiking

name: Cuba Marsh Preserve
description: Three miles of trails for hiking, bicycling and cross-country skiing take visitors through open areas of gently rolling hills that feature views of the marsh and scattered groves.

name: Edward L. Ryerson Conservation Area
description: Over 6.5 miles of scenic trails wind through woods to the Des Plaines River. Trails here are open to hikers and, when snow is at least four inches deep, cross-country skiers.

name: Vietnam Trails
description: Vietnam Trails features 0 miles of hiking trails near Milford, MA.

name: Grafton Land Trust
description: Grafton Land Trust is a 20 mile hiking trail in Grafton, Massachusetts.

name: Presque Isle State Park
description: Presque Isle State PArk is a 3,200-acre park located on a sandy peninsula apart of Lake Erie. It's recreational activities include hiking, biking, swimming, boating, fishing and cross-country skiing. There are 15 trails here that amount to a grand total of 11 miles in length. They are, for the most part, very easy hikes with lovely scenery.

name: Willow Creek State Recreation Area
description: An 8-mile hiking and horseback trail winds through the area, with a limestone trail meandering from the swimming beach and proceeding to the west edge of Pierce.

name: Oquaga Creek State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Heron Creek Forest Preserve
description: Visitors can explore 2.3 miles of gravel trails for hiking, biking and cross-country skiing. Heron Creek offers parking, two picnic shelters, toilets, drinking fountains and interpretive signage.

name: Buffalo Creek Preserve
description: Four miles of crushed-gravel trails are open to hikers, bicyclists and cross-country skiers. Pedestrian and bicycle access is available at the corner of Checker Road and Arlington Heights Road; on Checker Road, west of Schaeffer Road, and at the corner of Lake Cook and Arlington Heights Roads. The trails run through open areas within the preserve, crossing several creeks, skirting the reservoir and traversing restored prairie.

name: Chicopee Memorial State Park
description: Chicopee State Park, formerly the Cooley Brook Reservoir and Watershed has been developed as a high use active recreation area. The total acreage is 575 acres including a 25 acre pond. Activities include swimming, fishing and picnicking.

name: Prairie Wolf Forest Preserve
description: This preserve features a 20-acre wetland, wet prairie and adjacent oak woodlands, a 1.75-mile trail for hiking, bicycling and cross-country skiing, a 1-mile self-guided nature trail, and a special Dog Exercise Area where your pet can run leash-free.

name: Eagle Trail
description: Eagle Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Twin Falls, ID.

name: Appalachian Trail 126: MA 23 to Tyringham Main Road
description: The AT runs 12.1 miles from MA Hwy 23 to Tyringham Main Road. Along the way it passes Blue Hill Road, Benedict Pond, the Mount Wilcox South Lean-to, and the Mount Wilcox North Lean-to.

name: Bear Lake State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Adams Farm
description: Adams Farm features 10 miles of hiking trails near Walpole, MA.

name: Lake Abert and Abert Rim
description: Excellent trails.

name: Warner Wetlands
description: Numerous recreational opportunities exist for bird watching, hunting, fishing, camping, and boating however, most of these activities are dependent on the water levels of the lakes which can fluctuate dramatically. Contact the Bureau of Land Management Lakeview District office to receive updated information about current lake levels before planning a trip to the Warner Wetlands.

name: Hyatt Lake Recreation Complex
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Grizzly Peak Trail
description: At an elevation of 5922 feet, Grizzly Peak affords an outstanding view of the Rogue Valley and the city of Ashland. This short trail to the summit passes through a mixed forest of fir and pine. The trail also offers outstanding views of the Cascades including Diamond Peak, Mt Mcloughlin, and Mt. Shasta. In early summer wildflowers put on a spectacular show along the trail. Keep an eye out for elk and deer, as well as many other animals including Golden Eagles and other birds of prey. Trail Length: 3 miles, one way Difficulty: Moderate Use level: Moderate to High

name: Rayburn Trails
description: Rayburn Trails features 10 miles of hiking trails near Millbury, MA.

name: Wompatuck State Park
description: Excellent hiking area; abundant trails.

name: Beartown State Forest
description: The 12,000  acre Beartown State Forest is home to the pristine 35-acre Benedict Pond.  This park is one of the best locations for wildlife observation and hiking. The network of trails that winds through the park open opportunities to see a variety of wildlife including deer, bobcats, beavers and black bears. The pond on the property offers great fishing, swimming and boating. During the winter, snowmobiling, snowshoeing and cross-country skiing are very popular activities at this location.

name: Rocky Woods
description: Rocky Woods features 7 miles of hiking trails near Medfield, MA.

name: Houghton's Pond Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Upton State Forest
description: This 2,660-acre state forest was formerly a  Civil Conservation Corps site. Several CCC buildings are still there for viewing. Hiking, Walking, mountain biking, hunting, horse back riding, cross country skiing and snowmobiling are popular activities at this year round park.

name: Espenscheid Forest Perserve
description: Espenscheid Forest Perserve  features 3 miles of hiking trails near Rockford, Il, IL.

name: Al Sabo
description: Al Sabo features 6 miles of hiking trails near Kalamazoo, MI.

name: Grassy Lake Forest Preserve
description: Winding through colorful sedge meadows and mature oak woodlands, 3.5 miles of trails offer scenic views of Grassy Lake and the Fox River valley. Trails here are open only for hiking and cross-country skiing. Bicycling is not allowed.

name: Spencer State Forest
description: The large 965-acre Spencer State Forest is a great swimming, fishing, hiking, canoeing, snowmobiling and picnicking area. The Midstate Trail that runs through Massachusetts also runs very close to the park. The park also offers scenic viewing areas and restrooms.

name: Ella Sharp Park
description: Ella Sharp Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Jackson, MI.

name: Moore Park Trail Network
description: Moore Park Trail Network features 20 miles of hiking trails near Klamath Falls, OR.

name: Gerber Recreation Area
description: While Gerber North and South Campgrounds are open yeararound, full amenities such as restroom maintenance, garbage collection, and host services are only available from mid-May to mid-September. Gerber Campgrounds have level parking, an RV dump station, drinking water, toilets, picnic tables, fire grates, concrete boat ramp and floating dock, gravel boat ramp, fish cleaning stations, garbage service, and day-use areas. Fees are charged for camping and day use at the Gerber North and South Campgrounds. Primitive campsites have toilets, fire grates, and picnic tables. There is no garbage service for these sites, so please pack it out. No fees are charged for these sites. If you find an archeological or historic site during your visit, please leave it undisturbed and contact the Bureau of Land Management Klamath Falls Resource Area office. It is against Federal law to disturb these sites or remove artifacts.

name: Wood River Wetland
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Whitehall State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: CDT WY08: Co Rd 22 to Bison Basin Rd
description: Section 8 of the CDT in Wyoming runs 35.3 miles from Co Rd 22 to Bison Basin Rd. Along the way, the trail passes Stratton Rim South, Green Mountain, Sheep Mountain, Crooks Peak, Crooks Mountain East, and the summit (7,641 feet) of Crooks Mountain West.

name: Captain Daniel Wright Woods
description: This peaceful oasis among the bustling suburbs offers 4 miles of scenic trails: a short loop for hikers, bicyclists and skiers that circles a pond, and a 3-mile loop for hikers, bicyclists, skiers and horses. A wheelchair accessible fishing pier provides easy access to a 3-acre man-made pond.

name: Old School Forest Preserve
description:
A 3-mile gravel loop trail explores Old School's woods and prairies and is open to hikers, bicyclists, horseback riders and cross-country skiers. A portion of this loop is part of the Des Plaines River Trail (DPRT).

A 1.5-mile gravel trail encircles the lake and is open to hikers, bicyclists and cross-county skiers.

The 1.5-mile asphalt road winding through the preserve offers a special one-way lane popular with bicyclists and in-line skaters, and is also open to hikers.

An interior 1.5-mile physical fitness loop, open only to foot traffic, offers workout stations that build strength and endurance.

name: Whitney And Thayer Woods/weir River Farm
description: Whitney And Thayer Woods/weir River Farm features 10 miles of hiking trails near Cohasset, MA.

name: Appalachian Trail 127: Tyringham Main Road to US 20 (Lee, MA)
description: The AT runs 8.6 miles from Tyringham Main Road to US Hwy 20 (Lee, MA). Along the way it passes Webster Road, Goose Pond Road (MA), Goose Pond, Upper Goose Pond Cabin, and I-90.

name: Great Esker Park
description: Great Esker Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Weymouth, MA.

name: Chester-Blandford State Forest
description: Chester-Blandford State Forest is home to the beautiful 60-ft cascade Sanderson Brook Falls. The forest is a spectacular hiking and exploring area with a  variety of trails that offer different views of the rustic park. Fishing, horseback riding and picnicking are also popular activities here.

name: Quincy Quarries Reservation
description: Quincy Quarries Reservation is the site of one of the first railroads in the United States. The area produced granite for over a century beginning in 1825. Now the reservation is a very popular rock climbing location. Picnicking and hiking are also common here. Scenic viewing opportunities are available.

name: Hopkinton State Park
description: Trail system is multi-use.  Hikers, mountain bikers, equestrians, cross country skiers are welcome.

name: Beals Cove Park
description: Beals Cove Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Hingham, MA.

name: Caryl Park
description: Caryl Park features 17 miles of hiking trails near Dover, MA.

name: Stodder's Neck/Abigail Adams Park
description:
Stodder's Neck is a peninsula located on the Hingham/Weymouth line at the mouth of the Back River. This 7-acre area is an excellent location for walking, picnicking and scenic viewing. The Weymouth Back River views and the green grass and large trees are a great sight after a long day.

Also known as the Weymouth Reservation.

name: Bellevue State Park
description: In the Nelson Unit, four trails provide a variety of hiking opportunities. One trail leads out to scenic overlook of the Mississippi, one winds past Indian burial mounds, one wanders through a restored prairie and a "Garden Sanctuary for Butterflies", and one takes you past an old limestone rock quarry. The Dyas Unit encompasses almost 4 miles of foot trails, scenic overlooks, a stream with beaver dams, and aquatic and other wildlife. In winter, bald eagles concentrate to feed near the open waters below Lock and Dam 12. Pileated woodpeckers are occasionally seen in isolated areas.

name: Blue Hills Reservation
description: Blue Hills features 5 miles of hiking trails near Milton, MA.

name: Grass Lake State Forest Campground
description: Platte Springs (9 miles NW): 2.5 miles of hilly terrain with interpretive trail at Platte River State Forest Campground. Hike and mountain bike.

name: Prairie Trail
description: Prairie Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Crystal Lake, IL.

name: Ellicottville Epic
description: Ellicottville Epic features 31 miles of hiking trails near Ellicottville, NY.

name: Stony Brook Reservation
description: The 475-acre Stony Brook Reservation  is a very scenic area that has a little bit of wooded hills, green valleys, rocky places and wetlands. The park's 12 miles of trails offer great hiking, walking, trail running and biking through beautiful views. Fishing in the Turtle Pond and picnicking are also commonly found at this park. There are also athletic fields, tennis courts, a swimming pool and an ice skating rink on the property.

name: Middlefork Savanna Forest Preserve
description: A 4-mile gravel trail is open for hiking, bicycling and cross-country skiing. Two boardwalks on the trail help protect sensitive wetland areas. A short 0.5-mile mowed path is open for hiking.

name: Millennium Trail and Greenway
description: The first section of the planned 35-mile Millennium Trail to connect central, western and northern Lake County communities and forest preserves opened in fall 2002 at Lakewood Forest Preserve in Wauconda. Today, more than 25 miles are complete and open to hikers, bicyclists and cross-country skiers. Horses are permitted only along a 9.25-mile section of gravel trail from Lakewood north to the horse trailer parking area at Singing Hills Forest Preserve in Volo. The trail surface changes from gravel to paved starting north of the Singing Hills horse trailer parking area. Horses are not permitted on the paved section.

name: Quinsigamond State Park
description:
Quinsigamond State Park is made up of two locations: Lake Park and Regatta Point. Altogether, the state park offers facilities for swimming, sailing, picnicking, fishing, rowing and tennis.
One of the best rowing courses in the world is located on Lake Quinsigamond, it is 2,000 meters long.

name: Ray Lake Preserve
description: Hikers, bicyclists, equestrians and cross-country skiers will enjoy a 2.7-mile gravel trail that winds around wetlands and wide open prairies, and includes three boardwalks and a scenic overlook. The preserve also has parking, toilets, and drinking water.

name: Mt. Tom State Reservation
description: Mount Tom State Reservation is a  2,161 acre area that is home to Mt. Tom, Lake Bray and  22 miles of hiking and walking trails. The park's lake is a common area for fishing and canoeing, as well as picnicking. Ice-skating and cross country skiing are also common in the winter.

name: Pistol River State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Nantasket Beach Reservation
description: Lifeguard protected swimming, coastal biking, and casual walking are all popular activities at the Nantasket Beach Reservation. The 26-acre park is a very popular summer destination for many city dwellers. Band concerts and dance lessons are also popular summertime events along the park's three mile shoreline.

name: Elm Bank Reservation
description: Elm Bank Reservation is a newer park that offers 182 acres of beauty surrounded by the Charles River. Fishing in the Charles River, hiking through the rolling fields and birdwatching in the woodlands are all popular activities at this reservation. The Massachusetts Horticultural Society is also located here.

name: Needham Town Forest
description: Needham Town Forest features 3 miles of hiking trails near Needham, MA.

name: Neponset River Reservation
description: Birding, fishing, hiking, kayaking and boating are all common activities at the marshy Neponset River Reservation. This reservation provides an unusually rich homeland for several plants and animals including a number of threatened species.

name: Quabbin Reservoir Watershed
description: The DCR managed Quabbin Reservoir Watershed contains over over 82,000 acres of land and water. Although the area's main priority is water preservation and preparation, the area is also commonly used for recreational purposes including walking and picnicking.  Moderate fishing, controlled hunting and birdwatching are also permitted on the property.

name: Rouge River
description: Morton-Taylor Trail is a 6 mile hiking trail in Canton, Michigan.

name: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
description:
The Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area is home 34 islands and peninsulas. The opportunities for exploring, hiking, camping, fishing or swimming are endless-- and all the fun is just a short trip from downtown Boston. The park is also home to one of the oldest lighthouses in the United States.

Within the National Park lies the Boston Harbor Islands State Park which comprises 13 islands located in Boston Harbor.

Wildlife observation and civil war education are also common activities at the park.

name: William P. Holiday Forest & Wildlife Preserve
description: There are over 10 miles of hiking trails for your enjoyment. For information on our Nature Walk Programs look at our Interpretive Centers and Calendar of Events pages.

name: Quincy Shores Reservation
description: Quincy Shore Reservation offers a variety of recreational opportunities including biking, picnicking, running, walking, fishing and swimming. The reservation has a 2.3 mile beach that is popular for all the activities listed above. The Caddy Park is located on the southern end of the beach and has over 15 acres of fields and a play area. There is also the Moswetuset Hummock, a National Historic Site, on the beach's northern end. The park has an observation tower, public restrooms and a historic area.

name: Cutler Park
description: The park contains trails suitable for a variety of activities including walking, hiking, bird watching, mountain biking, and cross-country skiing.

name: Batchlor Outer Loop
description: Batchlor Outer Loop is a 9 mile hiking trail in Amherst, Massachusetts.

name: Cutler Park Reservation
description: The seven hundred acres known as Cutler Park comprise the largest remaining fresh water marsh on the middle Charles. Located in Needham and Dedham, the marsh and small lake attract over 100 species of birds which make Cutler Park a prime spot for nature study. Other activities suitable to this wetland preserve are hiking, canoeing and fishing. Open year-round, dawn to dusk.

name: Independence Grove Canoe Launch
description: Bring your own canoe and launch it on the Des Plaines River. The launch, located near the preserve's North Bay Pavilion, offers shoreline fishing, a trail connection to the Des Plaines River Trail, and parking.

name: Boynton Park
description: Cascade Park features 3 miles of hiking trails near Worcester, MA.

name: Knightville Dam
description: Great trails.

name: Brook Farm Historic Site
description: Brook Farm Historic Site is a 179-acre National Historic Landmark. The park is renowned for being the location of the experimental society of Transcendentalists who lived on the farm in the 1840's. Hiking, picnicking and touring are popular activities here.

name: Appalachian Trail 128: US 20 to Pittsfield Road
description: The AT runs 9.4 miles from US Hwy 20 to Pittsfield Road. Along the way the trail passes Tyne Road, the October Mountain Lean-to, and West Branch Road.

name: Catharine Valley Trail
description: Catharine Valley Trail is  year round recreation trail that provides visitors with the opportunity to experience a scenic area with opportunities for cycling, walking, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing. The trail is still under construction in areas. Pets allowed.

name: JA Skinner State Park
description: The 400-acre J.A. Skinner State Park is a large, forested park on Mt. Holyoke,  the western-most peak of the Mount Holyoke Range. Take any of the park's multiple trails to see amazing views of the mountains surrounding the park and the Connecticut River Valley. 20 picnic sites with charcoal grill and public restrooms are available for your convenience certain times of the year.

name: Black Hawk State Park
description: The "Stubb" Severson Nature Trail offers visitors a chance to learn about many of the shrubs and trees found in the park. Along the trail, walkers often see a variety of wildlife, including deer, waterfowl and many species of songbirds.

name: Pope John Paul II Park Reservation
description: The park includes a number of trails for walking, hiking and running, including the Lower Neponset River Trail.

name: Mt. Holyoke Range State Park
description: The 3,000  acre Mt. Holyoke Range State Park covers a seven mile ridge that runs from Hadley to Belchertown. The beautiful rolling, wooded land is accented by several streams and ponds, making the area an attraction to all nature lovers, The park's 30 miles of trails make for excellent hiking, walking, trail running, cross-country skiing, snowmobiling, horseback riding and hunting.

name: Moore State Park
description: The 400-acre Moore State Park is a fantastic retreat area in the center of Massachusetts. The wooded park is full of a variety of beautiful flora and cascading waters. Canoeing, fishing, hiking, walking, picnicking, scenic viewing and hunting are common activities here.

name: Sterling Mine Ditch Trail
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Hemlock Gorge Reservation
description: Great hiking area.

name: Waterloo Recreation Area
description: A variety of trails are available for hiking, skiing, mountain biking, horseback riding and nature study can be found in the recreation area. The Trails of Waterloo's Discovery Center can help guide your exploration of all the natural features to be found.

name: Moraine Hills State Park
description: More than 10 miles of trails make Moraine Hills popular for hikers, skiers and cyclists, and provide one of the park's main recreation features. Three trails, surfaced with crushed limestone, wind their way through the park and offer you exceptional scenic and wildlife viewing opportunities. Enjoy the 2-mile Fox River Trail, the 3.2-mile Leatherleaf Bog Trail, and the 3.7-mile Lake Defiance Trail. To keep you on track, trails are color coded and one way. Our fourth trail, the River Road trail is paved, and is 1.7 miles long.

name: Hammond Pond Reservation
description: This protected woodland park features Hammond Pond for great fishing, numerous hiking trails and formations of sandstone conglomerate and Roxbury puddingstone for excellent rock climbing.

name: Greenbelt Forest Preserve
description: The preserve offers 5 miles of trails for hiking, 4 miles of trails for bicycling and cross-country skiing, and a 1-mile self-guided nature trail.

name: Callahan State Park
description: Callahan State Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Framingham, MA.

name: Singing Hills Preserve
description: More than 21.5 miles of the planned 35-mile Millennium Trail are complete and open to hikers, bicyclists and cross-country skiers. A 9.25-mile section from Lakewood north to Singing Hills Forest Preserve is open to equestrians. The trail surface is mainly gravel from Lakewood north to Singing Hills. North of Singing Hills, the trail surface is mainly asphalt with a few gravel sections.

name: Southwest Corridor Park
description: Southwest Corridor Park is a 52-acre urban park near Boston. The 4.7 mile linear park stretches from Back Bay to Forest Hills. Seven basketball courts, five tennis courts, two street hockey rinks, two amphitheatres, spray pools, playgrounds and six miles of biking, jogging and walking paths make this park a fantastic recreational location.

name: Enchanted Forest Trail
description: The Enchanted Forest Trail is a short scenic trail leading to the Felton Memorial Trail. Trail Length: .7 Mile Difficulty: Easy Use Level: Low

name: Fort Custer Recreation Area
description: Fort Custer Recreation Area features 25 miles of hiking trails near Augusta, MI.

name: Guernsey State Park
description: Guernsey State Park is home to a lake, seven campgrounds and a network of trails so there is no shortage of things to do here. Activities include swimming, camping, fishing, hiking mountain biking, canoeing, kayaking and boating.

name: Whitney Point
description: Trails available at Dorchester Park.

name: Van Buren State Park
description: 5 hiking trails that also allow mountain bikes

name: Van Buren State Park
description: 13 miles of trails.

name: Norwottuck Rail Trail
description: The Norwottock Rail Trail is an 11 mile path that links Northampton, Hadley and Amherst on the former Boston and Main Railroad. The level trail is great for beginners of cycling and cross country skiing or just a relaxing walk. It is also often used by those in wheelchairs and walkers.

name: Cape Sebastian State Scenic Corridor
description: A deep forest of Sitka spruce covers most of the park and a 1.5 mile walking trail takes you out to the lower levels of the cape.  If you're lucky, the trail will give you a chance to enjoy awe-inspiring views of the gray whales on their bi-annual migrations.

name: Rock Cut State Park
description:
The Rock Cut State Park's 3,100 acres are host to a full range of summer and winter activities. The park property includes two lakes-- Pierce Lake- 162 acres and Olson Lake-50 acres. Both lakes serve as excellent locations for fishing, ice fishing, ice skating and swimming. The park's recreational variety also includes camping, cross country skiing, hiking and horseback riding. Don't forget the incredible birdwatching and wildlife observation that could take place.

One of the more prominent activities, hiking, is excellent at Rock Cut State Park. The park offers 40 miles of scenic trails for the avid hiker. The trails are marked by color for level of experience and hiking, mountain biking or horseback riding use. Phone (815) 885-3311

name: Shindagin Hollow
description: Shindagin Hollow features 0 miles of hiking trails near Ithaca, NY.

name: Rollins Savanna Forest Preserve
description: A 5.5-mile trail with bridges and boardwalks encircles the site. This multi-use trail is open for hiking, bicycling, cross-country skiing and nature and wildlife observation. This preserve also offers a native seed nursery, parking, toilets, drinking fountain and a bridge crossing over Mill Creek. Snowmobiles can parallel a small section of the trail as they pass through the preserve.

name: Nobscot Mtn.
description: Nobscot Mtn. features 15 miles of hiking trails near Sudbury, MA.

name: Rock Cut State Park
description: Rock Cut State Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Rockford, IL.

name: Volo Bog State Natural Area
description:
Volo Bog Interpretive Trail: Designed for hikers only, this half-mile interpretive loop leads visitors through each stage of bog succession. It is constructed of wooden dock sections, boardwalks and a woodchip path. Trail brochures, adapted for each season, are available at the visitor center.

Tamarack View Trail: This 2.75-mile trail is designed for hiking and cross-country skiing (with a six-inch minimum snowbase). As park visitors traverse through woods, wetlands, field and prairie, they are given the opportunity to experience and enjoy the diverse communities within the park. From higher elevations along the trail, one can look down into the Volo Bog basin and view the state threatened tamarack trees. The trail begins just south of the visitor center and moves in a counter clockwise direction. All visitors are encouraged to move in the appropriate direction, but it is especially important that skiers do so to avoid accidents. A trail brochure for Tamarack View Trail is also available.

Deerpath Trail and Prairie View Trail: offer an additional 2 miles of hiking through old fields, woods & prairie restoration areas

name: Charles River Reservation and Loop
description: Charles River Reservation stretches from Boston Harbor up the river for 20 miles. Recreational activities abound at this park. There are athletic fields for all your sporting needs, there are trails for runners and cyclists, there is a par course, a skating rink, a playground, tennis courts and a swimming pool. The reservation is a fantastic multi-use park.

name: Nippersink Preserve
description: Hike, bicycle or cross-country ski along 3 miles of trails circling the lakes and adjoining woodlands. The preserve trail joins the public sidewalk to the north across Nippersink Road offering access to surrounding communities. Also features a bridge, boardwalk and scenic overlooks. A short woodchip trail winds through open oak groves.

name: Marl Flat Preserve
description: More than 25 miles of the Millennium Trail are currently open. The 1-mile paved section of Millennium Trail that runs through Marl Flat is open for bicycling, hiking and cross-country skiing. Horses are not permitted.

name: Mt. Pisgah
description: Mt. Pisgah features 8 miles of hiking trails near Northborough, MA.

name: Rutland State Forest
description:
Rutland State Park is a 300 acre recreational forest. Swimming, canoeing, picnicking, hiking, fishing, mountain biking, hunting and cross-country skiing are all permitted and encouraged at this diverse park. The park also offers public restrooms and a scenic viewing area of the rolling woodlands.

Great hiking trails.

name: Des Plaines River Trail and Greenway
description: The trail spans nearly the entire length of Lake County for 31 miles as it winds through 12 forest preserves. It is a key link in a regional network of trails that includes the North Shore Bike Path, the McClory Trail and the Millennium Trail.

name: Watkins Glen State Park
description: Gorge Trail offers views of over 19 waterfalls.

name: Amherst Trail
description: Amherst Trail features 7 miles of hiking trails near Amherst, MA.

name: Appalachian Trail 129: Pittsfield Road to MA 8/9
description: The AT runs 9.6 miles from Pittsfield Road to MA Hwy 8/9. Along the way it passes Blotz Road, the Kay Wood Lean-to, and Grange Hall Road.

name: Kal-Haven Trail State Park
description: Kal-Haven Trail State Park was once known as Kal-Haven Trail Sesquicentennial State Park, it is a rail trail that originally ran 33.5 miles from South Haven, Michigan, to just west of the city of Kalamazoo, Michigan. It is made up of woodlands and farmland. It is prominently used by cyclers and hikers, but at times snowmobilers travel on it.

name: October Mountain State Forest
description: The 16,500-acre October Mountain is the largest state forest in Massachusetts. The park's 47 campsites offer a great overnight stay in the large forest. Hiking, exploring, fishing, hunting, mountain biking and cross country skiing are all very common activities throughout the park's hilly woodlands. The Schermerhorn Gorge on the property offers a beautiful facet to the wooded area and the park's autumn leaves attract several visitors yearly. Camping season is from mid-May through mid-October-- there are three yurts available for renting in addition to the other campsites. ATV are also allowed on the trails from May 1 through last Sunday in November.

name: Brushy Creek State Recreation Area
description: With approximately 45 miles of multi-use trails, there are trail activities for everyone including horseback riding, hiking, snowmobiling, cross country skiing, and mountain biking.

name: Dolliver Memorial State Park
description: A trail will take you out past the Copperas Beds which are unique sandstone formations towering 100 feet above Prairie Creek. The trail then continues on up into oak covered hillsides and back down past Bone Yard Hollow. Trails also take you out to the Indian Mounds and up more wooded hillsides.

name: Robert H. Treman State Park
description: Beautiful  hiking.

name: CDT WY10: Sweetwater River to South Pass City
description: Section 10 of the CDT in Wyoming runs for 14.5 miles from the Sweetwater River to the historic South Pass City. Along the way, the trail passes Atlantic City.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: C: Hwy 140 to Hwy 138.
description:
Section C of the PCT in Oregon runs 76 miles from Highway 140 near Fish Lake to Highway 138 near the Cascade Crest. Section C offers up a true wilderness experience with gorgeous views thanks to the Sky Lakes Wilderness and Crater Lake National Park. <br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes the Devils Peak/Lee Peak Saddle; Honeymoon Creek; Highway 62, close to Mazama Campground; Crater Lake National Park, OR; Crater Lake, OR; and Discovery Point.

name: Prospect Hill
description: Prospect Hill features 10 miles of hiking trails near Waltham, MA.

name: Tioga Bridge
description: Tioga Bridge was constructed in 2012 on the piers of the Youngs Bay Bridge that washed out in the 1964 floods. The bridge was constructed by Oregonians using locally-sourced timber and materials. To access Tioga Bridge, park at the Susan Creek Day Use Area and use the fully accessible Emerald Trail. There are also a few parking spots close to the bridge along Highway 138 near milepost 27. Tioga Bridge provides access to the two nearly 8 mile long Swiftwater and Tioga sections of the North Umpqua Trail.

name: Mystic River Reservation
description: The Mystic River Reservation is a large, publicly owned area that is home to Mary O'Malley Park, Torbert Macdonald Park, Draw Seven Park and Mystic Lakes-- making it a hotbed of recreational activity. The opportunities available include: Swimming, rowing, sailing, soccer, picnicking, biking, running, hiking, tennis and boating.

name: CDT WY09: Bison Basin Rd to Sweetwater River
description: Section 9 of the CDT in Wyoming runs for 25.7 miles from Bison Basin Road to the Sweetwater River.

name: Two Rivers State Park Recreation Area
description: Two Rivers State Park features recreation trails for hiking, biking, skiing or snowshoeing through steep forested slopes and open hilltop meadows.

name: Valley of the Rogue State Park
description: Nature trail.

name: Rumney Marsh Reservation
description: This 600  acre reservation is a salt marsh that provides habitat for a vast array of wildlife. Boating, kayaking, canoeing,  fishing, walking, wildlife observing and bird watching are all popular activities at this peaceful park on the Saugus and Pines River estuary. Free interpretive programs that cover the importance of the reservation are offered throughout the year.

city: Boylston, Clinton, Holden, Hubbardston, Leominster, Princeton, Rutland, Sterling, and West Boylston.
name: Wachusett Reservoir Watershed
description: The primary reason for the 4,135-acre reservoir is to protect drinking water supply, so public use is limited. This reservoir was built between by damming the South Branch of the Nashua river. Activities at this area include shoreline fishing, hiking, walking, snowshoeing, birdwatching, picnicking and relaxing.

name: Pinckney Recreation Area
description: An extensive trail system is available to the hiker and mountain biker. The trails all begin at Silver Lake Beach. Trailside camping is available within designated campgrounds. Please contact the park office for registration information before you camp.

name: Sugar Loaf Loop
description: Sugar Loaf Loop is a 15 mile hiking trail in Kimberly, Idaho.

name: Potawatomi trail
description: Potawatomi trail features 24 miles of hiking trails near Pinckney, MI.

city: Barre, Hubbardston, Oakham, Phillipston, Princeton, Rutland, Templeton, and Westminster
name: Ware River Watershed
description:
Ware River Watershed is a 23,000-acre area. Since the watershed's primary purpose is water supply conservation, public water access is limited to shoreline fishing. Hiking, cycling, walking, non motorized boating, <br />
birdwatching, snowshoeing, cross country skiing and snowmobiling are all popular here.

name: Sun Lake Preserve
description: A footbridge and 3.25 miles of trails provide access for hiking, bicycling, cross-country skiing, and nature and wildlife observation. Three spurs connect the main trail to a residential community, the Lake Villa Baseball Park and Longwood Centre Park, home to the historic Lehmann Mansion.

name: Grant Woods Preserve
description: Six miles of trails here are open to hiking, biking, and cross-county skiing. In winter, snowmobilers have access to 4.5 miles of trails that tie into adjacent snowmobile trails on private land. A 1-mile grass trail in the far northeastern section of the preserve can be accessed from Cedar Lake Road. The trail extends to Fairfield Road, across from Lake Villa Township's Caboose Park.

name: Buttermilk Falls State Park
description: Beautiful forest trails.

name: Lake Erie State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Lake Le-Aqua-Na State Recreation Area
description: Whether you enjoy hiking, horseback riding or cross-country skiing, 8.5 miles of marked trails include something for everyone. Pets are welcome to enjoy the trails with you, but must be kept on their leashes.

name: Agate Fossil Beds National Monument
description:
Two trails lead to the north and south rim of the valley and to the sites where fossils have been found. The Daemonelix Trail has exhibits encasing actual fossils, while the Fossil Hills Trail currently does not.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Van Patten Woods
description: Five miles of trails are open to hikers, bicyclists, horseback riders, and cross-country skiers. The Des Plaines River Trail (DPRT) bisects the preserve and is also open to snowmobilers. It's accessible from the preserve trails or from the trailhead at the Russell Road entrance.

name: Revere Beach Reservation
description: Revere Beach Reservation is the home of the oldest public beach in America, it opened in 1896.  Lifeguards are on duty from late June to early September for safe swimming. Fishing and picnicking are common at the relaxing shoreline. The park's other amenities include a bandstand, a bathhouse, shaded picnic shelters and restrooms.

name: Middlesex Fells Reservation
description:
2,575 acres of rocky terrain and beautiful landscapes make up the Middlesex Fells Reservation. Hikers, mountain bikers, horseback riders, rock climbers, cross-country skiers and picnickers love visiting this naturally fun park with a lovely park on the property. Picnicking and dog walking are also common activities at Middlesex Fells Reservation.
Great hiking trails.

name: Maybury State Park
description:
Maybury State Park is a 944-acre area of an excellent variety of recreational choices. Cross country skiing, fishing, biking, horseback riding, picnicking and relaxing.

Great hiking trails.

name: Mine Kill State Park
description: Great trails.

name: Adeline Jay Geo-Karis Illinois Beach State Park
description: Illinois Beach provides excellent hiking opportunities. The southern part of the park features 5 miles of trails, including a 2.2-mile loop trail with a graveled surface. In the north, Camp Logan Trail is a 1.8-mile multi-use loop that cross-country skiers also can use. Cross-country skiing is not allowed in the nature preserve.

name: Rough and Ready Botanical Wayside
description: The Rough and Ready area is located in a region which is recognized as one of 200 biologically outstanding ecoregions in the world. It harbors a multitude of rare or special status plants endemic to the serpentine soils of the Siskiyou Mountains. Staying on the main trail avoids erosion and disturbing sensitive vegetation. A gate key is available for check out at Illinois Valley Visitor Center in Cave Junction for those who may have difficulty in accessing the area by foot.

name: Cathedral Hills Trails
description: The Cathedral Hills Trail System is located just outside the City of Grants Pass and is a haven for hiking, mountain biking, and horseback riding enthusiasts. The park includes many loop trails and natural areas among its 400 acres of Douglas fir and Ponderosa pine forest. Other common woody plants are Madrone, Oak, Manzanita and poison oak. Although spring is a popular time to visit because of the weather and abundant wildflowers, the unique and treasured recreation area of Cathedral Hills can be enjoyed year round. Please respect other trail users as well as private property boundaries surrounding the area.

name: Walden Pond State Reservation
description: Walden Pond State Reservation is known for the writings 'Walden' by Henry David Thoreau. Because of Thoreau's writing, Walden Pond has been designated a National Historic Landmark. 2,680 acres of woodlands and a deep kettle pond provide beautiful views to those who wish to hike, fish, picnic or relax.

name: TouVelle State Recreation Site
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Apple River Canyon State Park
description: Five trails - Pine Ridge, Tower Rock, River Route, Sunset and Primrose Trail (accessible) - wind through the woods for several miles within the park. Trails can be hazardous, please stay on the trail.

name: Minute Man National Historical Park
description:
Battle Road Trail. This five mile trail connects historic sites from Meriam's Corner in Concord to the eastern boundary of the park in Lexington. The main theme of the trail is the Battle of April 19, 1775, that launched the American Revolution.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Devil's Gate Interpretive Site
description:
Devil's Gate Interpretive Site is a beautiful area south of Casper and north of Rawlins, that offers hard-surfaced interpretive trails through stunning canyons. Look for interpretive signs along the path as well!
This area has restrooms, trash collection, and it is ADA Accessible. There is no fee to use the area.

name: Otter Point State Recreation Site
description: Excellent walking and hiking trails overlooking pristine beaches and unusual sandstone rock formations sculpted by wind and waves.

name: Mines of Spain State Recreation Area and E. B. Lyons Interpretive Center
description: Hiking and cross-country ski trails are available at the Mines of Spain. Four miles of ski trails are maintained, and 18 miles of hiking trails. There are 11 individual nature walks within the park, including those at the E.B. Lyons Interpretive Center and another at the Horseshoe Bluff Site. Other trails provide a wide range of opportunities for visitors to view Mines of Spain on old winding logging roads, to view limestone bluffs, scenic vistas, and to enjoy a hike through forests and prairie. Some of the trails are steep and challenging.

name: OC&E Woods Line State Trail
description: Great hiking.

name: Breakheart Hill Forest
description: Trails are available for hiking, mountain biking, and cross-country skiing.

name: Lakelands Trail State Park
description: Lakelands Trail State Park is a linear trail approximately 13 miles long with a gravel surface. Lakelands is designed for hiking, bicycling, and wheelchair use on the north side and horseback riding on the south side of the trail. Motorized vehicles and hunting are prohibited.

name: Chain O' Lakes State Park
description: Chain O'Lakes has four trail systems. The Nature's Way hiking trail starts at Oak Grove Picnic Area and is 2 å_ miles in length.
