The Pike Marsh North Picnic Area has an accessible trail that is å_ mile long. The park also contains an equestrian trail with three loops and a total length of 8 miles. Visitors can bring in their own horses for enjoyment on the trail. A parking lot for horse trailers with access to the equestrian trails is located near the park entrance. A biking/hiking trail, 6 miles in length, can be accessed at any picnic area between the concession stand and the park office. All trails can be used by cross-country skiers.

name: Lynn Woods Reservation
description: Lynn Woods Reservation features 5 miles of hiking trails near Lynn, MA.

name: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
description:
Follow the nature trail along the east side of the Saugus River. Watch for the birds and other wild life, identify trees and other plants.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: CDT WY11: South Pass City to Sweetwater River Trailhead
description: Section 11 of the CDT in Wyoming runs for 23 miles from historic South Pass City to a trailhead at the confluence of the Sweetwater River, Pool Creek, and Station Creek. Along the way, the trail passes Hwy 28, Pabst Peak, and Granite Peak.

name: South Pass City Historic Site
description: The Continental Divide National Scenic Trail also passes through town. Popular among serious hikers and mountain bikers, the Continental Divide National Scenic Trail runs the length of the Rocky Mountains from Canada to Mexico. Each year, numerous bikers and hikers utilizing this trail visit the site. Many use the general delivery at the General Store's post office for re-supply, and enjoy a tour through town before continuing on their journey.

name: FDR Park
description: FDR Park features 12 miles of hiking trails near Dubuque, IA.

name: Glendo State Park
description: Glendo State Park is most known for fishing as several record fish have been caught here. The massive Glendo Reservoir makes possible boating, canoeing, kayaking, fishing and swimming, but hiking, mountain biking, and camping are also available here.

name: Appalachian Trail 130: MA 8/9 to MA 8 (Cheshire, MA)
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs 9.5 miles from MA Hwys 8/9 in downtown Dalton to MA Hwy 8 (Cheshire, MA). Along the way the it passes Gulf Road and Cheshire.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"Gulf Road" lat=42.4817548148, lon=-73.1781200146

name: Gander Mountain Preserve
description: A challenging hike to the top is paid off with a scenic view of the Fox River in the valley below.

name: Land Locked Forest
description: Land Locked Forest features 7 miles of hiking trails near Boston, MA.

name: Belmont Conservation
description: Belmont Conservation features 10 miles of hiking trails near Belmont, MA.

name: Mt. Sugarloaf State Reservation
description: The Mt. Sugarloaf State Reservation is home to Mt. Sugarloaf, a summit with fantastic views of the Connecticut River and the Pioneer Valley. The park's common activities include picnicking, scenic viewing and hiking. Amenities include restrooms and a picnic pavilion.

name: Pittsfield State Forest
description: Pittsfield State Forest is a scenic park full of azalea fields, waterfalls and woodlands. The beautiful area is the perfect location for a hike through 30 miles of quiet trails, a picnic in a secluded spot or an overnight stay in any of the park's camping areas. The  Balance Rock State Park is also located in the northeast corner of Pittsfield  State Forest. ATV trails are open at certain times during the season, call ahead.

name: Wahconah Falls State Park
description:
The Wahconah Falls flows through smaller falls then cascades 40 feet into a deep pool. The Wahconah Falls State Park is home to a hardwood-conifer forest that is perfect for hiking, relaxing, picnicking or even fishing in the river.

A specific hike is a 0.5 mile loop trail of moderate difficulty through upper portions of the falls.

name: Split Rock Interpretive Site
description: Restrooms, trash collection, hard-surfaced interpretive trail, picnic tables, and interpretive signs.

name: Green Mountain
description: Named for the green timber which covers it, Green Mountain and its neighbors, Crooks Mountain to the west and Whiskey Peak to the east, comprise a small mountain range by Rocky Mountain standards. Green Mountain has no hard rock core but was formed from sediments eroded from the much older Granite Mountains just to the north. Crooks Mountain and its adjacent Crooks Gap and Crooks Peak were named after Civil War veteran and Indian fighter General George H. Crook.

name: Independence Rock Historic Site
description: Independence Rock State Historic Site a 136-foot boulder that stands up to 6,028 feet above sea level. It is one mile around and takes up 24.81 acres of its own space. Activitied here include Hiking and mountain biking.

name: Miner's Delight Trail
description: Rugged walking path through the site, interpretive kiosk at the entrance, and interpretive panels within the site.

name: Federated Women's Club State Forest
description:
This 984-acre state park stretches to the south and west in the watershed of the Quabbin Reservoir. Many different tree type invite visitors to relax and observe the nature surrounding them. A 140-acre wildlife sanctuary is on the property and is a haven for birdwatchers. A gorge lies in the southwest section of the forest and is the chief geological feature.

Camping, fishing, hiking and hunting are all common activities here.

name: Brighton Rec Area
description: Brighton Rec Area features 15 miles of hiking trails near Brighton, MI.

name: Wachusett Mountain State Reservation
description: The 3,000-acre Wachusett Mountain State Reservation is home to the 2,006 ft Mount Wachusett  that offers views of the surrounding New England landscape and and the Boston skyline. Hiking, walking, birdwatching, picnicking, and cross country skiing are common activities along the 17 miles of trail and views of this park.

name: Warren Grove Recreation Area
description: Warren Grove Recreation Area is open for passive recreation including horseback riding, bicycle riding, hiking, birding, hunting and nature/ecology study. A small parking area is being planned along Beaver Dam Road across from the Federal Aviation Administration's tower site. Access into the recreation area is via several sand roads and old woods roads through the area but no marked trails currently exist.

name: Myrtle Tree
description: This is a 1/4 mile trail in the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest. It ascends up to the world's largest known Myrtle Tree, which is also the largest myrtle tree in Oregon. There are some tables and bench seating at the end of the trail. There are no toilets, trash cans, or running water available.

name: Island Lake
description: Island Lake features 13 miles of hiking trails near Brighton, MI.

name: Lake Wyola State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Novi Tree Farm (Lakeshore Park)
description: Novi Tree Farm (Lakeshore Park) features 11 miles of hiking trails near Novi, MI.

name: Edness K. Wilkins State Park
description: Edness K. Wilkins State Park is a wonderful day-use park for the whole family. The North Platte River runs through the park and keep visitors cool. Activities here include fishing, canoeing, kayaking, hiking and swimming.

name: Bowman Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Brighton Recreation Area
description: Two trails are designed to make the remote areas of the park more accessible for visitors.

name: Mill Pond Conservation Area
description: Mill Pond Conservation Area features 8 miles of hiking trails near Burlington, MA.

name: Red Oaks County Park
description: Red Oaks Dog Park is now open! It features 5.2-acres of fenced enclosures for dogs to romp off-leash.  The dog park is located around the corner from the waterpark, with access from Dequindre Road.

name: George Wyth State Park
description: George Wyth has 5.5 miles of paved multi-purpose trails, which are great for biking, in-line skating and walking. These trails are linked to a 80 mile trail network within the cities of Waterloo and Cedar Falls. George Wyth also has 6 miles of grass hiking trails. In winter, sports such as cross-country skiing, and snowmobiling are also popular.

name: Lyon Oaks
description: Great hiking trails. Pets welcome.

name: Doyle Reservation
description: There are 3.5 miles of walking trails throughout the reservation.

name: Stony Brook State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Leominster State Forest
description: Leominster State Forest features 10 miles of hiking trails near Princeton, MA.

name: Robert V. Riddell State Park
description: The Robert V. Riddell State Park, a gift from Patricia Riddell Kent and Steven Kent in memory of Patricia's father, Robert V. Riddell of Colliersville and her grandfather, Alton B. Riddell, offers more than 1,000 acres of fields and forested woodlands located in the Susquehanna River Valley.

name: Windsor State Forest
description: Trails and old dirt roads that wind through the "The Bush" are favored by hikers.

name: Cedar Falls Area Trail System
description: Cedar Falls is covered in a network of hiking trails that connect together the various neighborhoods, the parks, and some of the industrial areas. Click on the individual trails for more detailed information about each one.

name: Adams Homestead and Nature Preserve
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Taughannock Falls State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Max V. Shaul State Park
description: Max V. Shaul State Park is a small wooded area with 20 tent and trailer camping sites. Picnic areas, playing fields and a playground are available for visitor enjoyment. Fishing in the Panther Creek, hiking on the nature trails and cross-country skiing in the winter are other common activities. Pets okay on leash. Rabies vacc. proof required.

name: Stone Park
description: Stone Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Sioux City, IA.

name: Ulrich Park
description: Ulrich Park features 3 miles of hiking trails near Cedar Falls, IA.

name: Kenneth Dubuque Memorial State Forest
description:
This 7,882 acre northern hardwood and spruce-fir state forest is renowned for its extensive multi-use trail system. 35 miles of multi-use trails, six miles of hiking trails and a one mile interpretive trail take you through historic sites and scenic views.

The park was closed for repair work after Hurricane Irene, so call ahead before you visit.

name: Guernsey Lake State Forest Campground
description: Sand Lakes Quiet Area (access on site): 10  miles of flat to very hilly terrain.

name: Pete's Draw
description: A day use and parking area, vault toilet, six overnight campsites with picnic tables, fire rings, shelters, tent pads, and RV parking, trash receptacle, and hardened pedestrian trail.

name: The Redds Day Use Area
description: Access road, parking area and a one-mile pedestrain trail with interpretive signs provides access to the river bank. There is a seasonal closure on wade fishing and wading on in the spawning beds during the month of April.

name: Great Brook State Park
description: Great Brook State Park features 15 miles of hiking trails near Carlise, MA.

name: CDT WY12: Sweetwater River Trailhead to Big Sandy Trailhead
description: Section 12 of the CDT runs about 23 miles from the a trailhead near the confluence of the Sweetwater River, Pool Creek, and Station Creek to a junction with the Big Sandy trail at the Big Sandy Trailhead. Along the way, the CDT passes Mount Nystrom, Independent Mountain, Sedgewick Meadows, Temple Peak, and Elephant Rock.

name: Proud Lake Recreation Area
description: Two of the hiking/ski trails run parallel to the Huron River, while another loops around a marsh. The longer trail, north of the Huron River, meanders alongside forests, fields and wetlands.

name: Appalachian Trail 131: MA 8 to MA 2
description: The AT runs 14 miles from MA Hwy 8 to MA Hwy 2. Along the way it passes the Mark Noepel Lean-to, Greylock Day Use Parking, Gould Trail Day Use Parking, Greylock Summit, the Wilbur Clearing Lean-to, and Pattison Road.

name: Rogue Wild and Scenic River
description: Great hiking.

name: Big Foot Beach State Park
description: The park has 6.5 miles of hiking trails through forest and open meadow. Most of the trails are relatively short and none are very strenuous.

name: Gilbert Lake State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Agassiz Rock Park
description: A short loop trail leads up Beaverdam Hill where Little Agassiz Rock appears as a giant granite monolith silhouetted against the sky. It rests precariously on a small jagged stone, leaving an opening below.

name: Wendell State Forest
description: Excellent trails.

name: Fenley State Recreation Area
description: Fenley State Recreation Area is a 287-acre property located in Grant County. The property consists of upland hardwoods, steep bluffs, and overlooks the Mississippi River. It is two miles west of Kieler and about four miles north of the Highway 151 bridge to Dubuque, Iowa.

name: Cadiz Springs State Recreation Area
description: Cadiz Springs State Recreation Area has eight miles of hiking trails. Cadiz Springs is one of the best places to view wildlife with its variety of forest, aquatic and meadow habitats.

name: Sprague Brook Park
description: Excellent area for hiking.

name: Milford Trail
description: Milford Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Milford, MI.

name: Letchworth State Park
description: Extensive trail system in this beautiful area.

name: Keuka Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: East Lake And West Lake Trails
description: East Lake And West Lake Trails features 8 miles of hiking trails near Manchester, IA.

name: Burchfield
description: Burchfield features 9 miles of hiking trails near Mason, MI.

name: Evangola State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: Harold Parker State Forest
description: Harold Parker State Forest features 35 miles of hiking trails near Andover, MA.

name: Flounce Rock
description: For a birdseye view of the Upper Rogue area, drive the winding gravel road up to the top of Flounce Rock. Just short of the top, take a 5 minute walk out to a rare population of Baker Cypress. Those with higher clearance vehicles can drive the final one-third mile to the top, and park at the microwave towers. A short, unmaintained trail to the south provides an unobstructed view of Lost Creek Lake, the Rogue River valley, and the Cascades.

name: Yankee Springs
description: Yankee Springs features 14 miles of hiking trails near Grand Rapids, MI.

name: Dodge #4 State Park
description: Fishing, swimming, hiking, cross-country skiing, canoeing and picnicking are all common activities at the Dodge #4 State Park. The park's amenities include a fishing pier, a boat launch, an observation platform, a picnic shelter, restrooms, a playground and a concession area. This one mile sandy shoreline is an excellent location for all your summer and winter activities. The 139-acre state park is located on Cass Lake.

name: Yankee Springs Recreation Area
description: The Gun Lake Trail is the only trail that meets federal accessability standards. The North Country Trail includes six miles within the recreation area. This national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes more than 1,500 miles in Michigan.

name: Cherry Plain State Park
description: The 175-acre Cherry Plain State Park is a scenic park on a sandy beach on the Black River Pond. The park offers a picnic area, a boat launch, horseback riding, biking and hiking trails. Camping is also popular here. Pets allowed on leash with rabies vaccine proof.

name: Backbone State Park
description: Backbone has 21 miles of hiking and multi-use trails. Visitors can hike along trails winding through old twisted and windblown cedars and up rough, rocky staircases to one of the highest points in northeast Iowa, the "Devil's Backbone."

name: Mt. Greylock State Reservation
description: At 3,491 feet, Mount Greylock is the highest elevation point in Massachusetts. This state reservation offers 60-90 mile views of the surrounding area. The park contains over 70 miles of trails for hiking, mountain biking, back-country skiing, snowshoeing and snowmobiling.  An 11.5 mile section of the Appalachian Trail is located through this park.

name: Otter River State Forest
description: Otter River State Forest is a common camping and hiking area for Massachusetts residents. Beaman Pond is located on the property and offers swimming, fishing and picnicking along the beach. The park has 85 campsites and a few rentable yurts for overnighters. Mountain biking is also a common activity at this park, as well as snowmobiling and cross country skiing in the winter.

name: Erving State Forest
description: Boating, swimming and fishing in Laurel Lake at Erving State Forest are all fun activities.  Camping, picnicking, hunting, horseback riding and winter sports in the beautiful woodlands of the park are also commonly enjoyed activities here. The park offers accessible beaches and restrooms for your convenience, as well as several picnic areas and scenic viewing areas.

name: Bradley Palmer State Park
description: Bradley Palmer  features 11 miles of hiking trails near Topsfield, MA.

name: Richard Bong State Recreation Area
description: Hikers have more than 16 miles of trails to explore. Dogs must be on a leash eight feet or shorter at all times.

name: Highland Recreation
description: Highland Recreation features 16 miles of hiking trails near White Lake, MI.

name: Mohawk Trail State Forest
description: Mohawk Trail State Forest is one of the most scenic woodland areas in Massachusetts. Over 6,000 acres make up this diverse park. From beautiful streams and rivers to heavily forested trails, this park is beautiful to explore. The park offers 56 campsites and 6 rentable cabins for overnight stays. Swimming, fishing, picnicking, camping and hiking are all popular here.

name: Savoy Mountain State Forest
description:
Savoy Mountain State Forest is a scenic wooded area in the hills of Massachusetts. Picnicking, fishing and swimming in the peaceful environment are the more common activities at this park. Camping in the park's 45 apple orchard campsites or four rental cabins is another popular pastime. 50 miles of multi-use trails open the door for even more recreational activities including: hiking, mountain biking or cross-country skiing.

The park is located atop the Hoosac Mountain Range in northwestern Massachusetts, providing for a surplus of scenic views.

name: Collier Memorial State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Lowell Heritage State Park
description: Great area for short hikes and walks.

name: White River State Trail
description: The fairly level grade and smooth limestone surface make this 12-mile trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. Each bicyclist age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Lake Dennison Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Petrifying Springs
description: Petrifying Springs features 15 miles of hiking trails near Kenosha, WI.

name: Thacher State Park (John Boyd Thacher)
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Thompson's Lake State Park
description: Great trails.

name: Betty and Wilbur Davis State Park
description: Extensive trails.

name: Pearl Hill State Park
description:
Pearl Hill State Park is a 1,000 acre area open on a seasonal basis from Memorial Day through Labor Day. The park's campground offers some of the most spacious and most private campsites in Massachusetts. The 51 campsites are all located under large, shady pines. Swimming, fishing and hiking are the most popular activities at this park. The park's many multi-use trails wind through miles of pond areas and woodlands. Snowmobiling and cross-country skiing are also common in the winter.

One of the most noted hiking trails is the Damon Pond of Willard Brook State Forest to Pearl Hill State Par trail at four miles long.

name: Halibut Point State Park
description: Halibut Point State Park is a uniquely beautiful coastal seascape. Looking seaward on a clear day, the view stretches from Crane Beach in Ipswich to Mount Agamenticus in Maine and the Isles of Shoals off the coast of New Hampshire.

name: Algonac State Park
description: Great trails for hiking.

name: McGregor Park and Visitor Center
description:
McGregor Park and visitor center is a partnership between the US Army Corps. of Engineers and the BLM. It is located 30 miles northeast of Medford, Oregon on the banks of the beautiful Rogue River along the Rogue-Umpqua Scenic Byway (Highway 62) just below Lost Creek Lake. Barrier-free facilities at McGregor Park provide access to restrooms, trails, picnic areas, a playground, fishing ramps, interpretive displays, environmental education programs and wildlife and salmon viewing.
The visitor center is staffed through the summer months and welcomes anyone interested in learning more about the natural and cultural history of the region. Summer hours are Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day weekend, Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and holidays, 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

name: Waterford Oaks
description: Excellent hiking and jogging paths/trails.

name: Lowell-Dracut-Tyngsboro State Forest
description: Great hiking area.

name: Pontiac Lake
description: Pontiac Lake features 11 miles of hiking trails near Pontiac, MI.

name: Bonavista State Park Golf Course
description: Excellent area to hike.

name: Willard Brook State Forest
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Pontiac Lake Recreation Area
description: A 1.9-mile hiking trail runs from the campground to the beach area.

name: Lake Walcott State Park
description: Excellent paved paths for hiking.

name: Willowdale State Forest
description: The forest's 40 miles (64 km) of trails, which include a section of the Bay Circuit Trail, are used for walking, hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, and cross-country skiing.

name: Bloomer Park
description: Bloomer Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Rochester Hills, MI.

name: Massacre Rocks State Park
description: Hike a nice stretch of the historic Oregon Trail.

name: Joseph H. Stewart State Recreation Area
description: Excellent trail system.

name: Lost Creek Lake
description: Miles of excellent trails throughout area.

name: Humbug Mountain State Park
description: Hiking to the top of Humbug Mountain is a major activity.

name: Klamath Wild and Scenic River
description: Great hiking.

name: CDT WY13: Big Sandy Trailhead to North Fork Lake
description: Section 13 of the CDT in Wyoming runs for 26 miles from the Big Sandy Trailhead to North Fork Lake. Along the way, the trail passes Lizard Head Peak, Mount Washakie, Raid Peak, Mount Bonneville, Musembeah Peak, Mount Lander, and Medina Mountain.

name: Anderson Park
description: Anderson Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Lansing, MI.

name: Mt. Grace State Forest
description: Mount Grace, the third highest elevation in Massachusetts, is a 1,621 foot summit. This 1,458-acre  park offers a variety of recreational activities: hiking, walking, horseback riding, cross-country skiing, snowmobiling, and hunting are a few common ones.

name: Harriet Hollister Spencer State Recreation Area
description: Harriet Hollister Spencer State Recreation Area provides picnic tables, cross-country skiing, hiking and biking trails and a pavilion for group activities. Deer hunting is permitted during the season. Small game hunting is not permitted. Pets okay on leash with rabies vacc. proof.

name: Fillmore Glen State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Georgetown-Rowley State Forest
description: The 1,112 acre Georgetown-Rowley State Forest is an excellent location for horseback riding, hiking, walking, hunting, cross-country skiing, mountain biking and snowmobiling. It is truly a year round park.

name: Weir Hill
description: Rising gently above Lake Cochichewick, Weir Hill offers hiking trails that pass over the crest of the 305-foot (93 m) double drumlin and track the shore of the lake.

name: Appalachian Trail 132: MA 2 to VT/MA Line
description:
The AT runs 4.1 miles from MA Hwy 2 to the VT/MA state line.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"Pattison Road" lat=42.6876480681, lon=-73.1596731799<br />
<br />
Note: if you are north bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in Vermont (or just click here).

name: Saugatuck Dunes State Park
description: Winding throughout the park, Saugatuck Dunes has 13 miles of sandy hiking trails. The southern portion of the park is mostly made up of the coastal dune natural area.

name: Sandy Point State Reservation
description: Located at the southern point of Plum Island, Sandy Point State Reservation is the ideal destination for wildlife observation and scenic viewing. The reservation is a very important protection location for the threatened piping plover the least tern during nesting season. Fishing and beach combing are also popular here.

name: Lawrence Heritage State Park
description: Good hiking.

name: Kiger Gorge Overlook
description: Kiger Gorge Overlook provides a prime veiwing opportunity for one of the most remarkable geologic landscapes in the Northwest. During the Ice Age, glaciers formed in the major stream channels on Steens Mountain. These glaciers dug trenches about one-half mile deep, through layers of hard basalt. The result was four immense U-shaped gorges - Kiger, Little Blitzen, Big Indian, and Wildhorse. The famous notch in the east ridge of Kiger Gorge formed during a later glaciation when a small glacier in Mann Creek Canyon eroded through the ridge top.

name: Natural Bridge State Park
description:
Natural Bridge State Park is home to the only naturally formed white marble arch/bridge in North America. This 48-acre park also has two other very unique features: the only man-made white marble dam in North America and an abandoned marble quarry. The ancient marble bridge is said to have been formed by a glacier melt thousands of years ago most likely. Fishing, picnicking and walking along the unique marble forms are popular activities here. The park also offers informative interpretive programs about the historic site.

There are two walking trails on the property-- one is .25 mile and the other is .5. One takes you through the chasm and another is a wooded trail.

name: Emery Park
description: Self-guided nature trail.

name: Sugar River State Trail
description: The fairly level grade and smooth limestone and asphalt surfaces make this 24-mile trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The one-mile section in New Glarus has been paved with asphalt suitable for in-line skating. Each bicyclist or skater age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Sampson State Park
description: Good hiking.

name: Clarksburg State Park
description: Multi-use trails, excellent hiking area.

name: Monroe State Forest
description: Monroe State Forest is made up of yawning valleys, high mountains and aged trees. This beautiful park offers plenty of hiking and horseback riding, full of incredible views. Fishing is also popular in the park's Deerfield River. Snowmobiling and cross country skiing are popular in the winter.

name: Chestnut Ridge
description: Excellent trails.

name: Stony Creek Metro Park
description: Stony Creek Metro Park features 14 miles of hiking trails near Rochester, MI.

name: Middle Fork Popo Agie River
description: Middle Fork Popo Agie River features 18 miles of hiking trails near Lander, WY.

name: Mt Morris Dam and Recreation Area
description:
Mount Morris Dam and Recreation Area is a day use park that offers a beautiful setting overlooking Letchworth Canyon, known as the "Grand Canyon of the East".

There are 384 acres associated with the Mount Morris dam that allow for plenty of recreational opportunities. Trails extend all throughout this park and are great for all levels of experience.

These are multi-use trails so act accordingly.

name: Finger Lakes Trail - Mt. Morris/letchworth State Park
description: Finger Lakes Trail - Mt. Morris/Letchworth State Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Mt. Morris, NY.

name: Nelson Dewey State Park
description: Nelson Dewey State Park sits on a 500-foot bluff and overlooks the Mississippi River. The views are almost as good as the variety of activities here with camping, hiking, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing available for visitors.

name: Jackson F. Kimball State Recreation Site
description: A walking trail connects the campground to the site where the clear spring bubbles from a rocky hillside. The park is a secluded place where you can contemplate the moment while relaxing in the whispering lodgepole pines.

name: Port Orford Heads State Park
description: The park has excellent hiking trails on the headlands affording spectacular views up and down the Pacific Coast.

name: Pecatonica State Trail
description: Pecatonica State Trail is 10 miles long and straight through the Bonner Branch Valley. This trial connects Belmont to the 47-mile Cheese Country Trail and the activities here include off-roading, horseback riding, hiking, mountain biking, snowmobiling, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

name: Bald Mtn Rec Area
description: Bald Mtn Rec Area features 12 miles of hiking trails near Lake Orion, MI.

name: Bald Mountain Recreation Area
description: Contains some of the steepest hills and most rugged terrains in southeast Michigan. Fifteen miles of marked hiking trails.

name: Appalachian Trail: Vermont
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs for 151 miles through the state of Vermont, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3303/Massachusetts/Appalachian-Trail--Massachusetts.html">Massachusetts</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3305/New-Hampshire/Appalachian-Trail--New-Hampshire.html">New Hampshire</a> border.<br />
Click on the individual trail segments below for more detailed information.

name: Appalachian Trail 133: VT/MA Line to City Stream (VT 9)
description:
The Appalachian Trail runs 14.3 miles from the VT/MA state line to City Stream (VT Hwy 9). Along the way it passes the Seth Warner shelter and the Congdon shelter.<br />
Note: the Google Map location given for the southern end of this trail is approximate. <br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"VT 9" lat=42.8851536982, lon=-73.114814862<br />
Note: if you are south bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in Massachusetts (or just click here).

name: Cape Blanco Lighthouse
description: The oldest lighthouse in the state, Cape Blanco Lighthouse sits atop wind-swept bluffs overlooking the Pacific Ocean. These bluffs, the western-most point of land in Oregon, provide an unparalelled opportunity to watch California gray whales and other marine mammals. The site's proximity to the Cape Blanco State Park provides visitors with camping, hiking, and beach combing opportunities in addition to a lighthouse visit.

name: Rose Oaks Park
description: Excellent hiking/jogging trail.

name: Sweet Pond State Park
description: The park is undeveloped, except for the Sweet family home (privately rented), a public parking area and a foot trail. There are traces visible of historic farmsteads and roads on the property. The 1.3 miles Sweet Pond Trail circumnavigates the pond. It is a popular place for the easy hike and for paddling and swimming (though not currently as the pond has been drained).

name: Sinks Canyon State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Hunter's Creek Park Trails
description: Hunter's Creek Park Trails features 0 miles of hiking trails near Buffalo, NY.

name: Bessemer Bend
description:
Located just 8 miles south of Casper, Bessemer Bend is a great place to get outdoors. The area offers a great picnic area, perfect for families, and beautiful interpretive trail.
There is no fee to use this area and it is ADA Accessible.

name: Stid Hill
description: Stid Hill features 5 miles of hiking trails near South Bloomfield, NY.

name: Yellowstone Lake State Park
description: Yellowstone Lake has more than 13 miles of hiking trails. Trails may vary in difficulty. Steep climbs or descents and stairways may be encountered. Use caution when on steep bluffs or near a cliff. Stay well away from cliffs which are not protected by a barricade or barrier. Stay behind barricades and barriers where provided and watch small children closely. The main trail head is located at the bottom of Campground Hill Road.

name: Bear Swamp
description: Bear Swamp features 15 miles of hiking trails near Cortland, NY.

name: Orion Oaks
description: Great trails.

name: Grafton Lakes State Park
description: Grafton Lakes State Park is located not he forested mountain ridge between Taconic and Hudson Valleys. The 2,357-acre park has five ponds, sandy beaches and a variety of walking trails. Fishing, canoeing, kayaking, sailboating, picnicking, walking, hiking and horseback riding are all popular activities here. During the winter, snowmobiling, snowshoeing, cross-country skiing and ice skating are also common.

name: Belmont Mound State Park
description: The park has 2.5 miles of hiking trails. The trails go around the base of the mound, through the center of the park and to a loop in the northeast corner of the park. The trails are mostly for hiking, but off-road bikes may also use the trails.

name: Knox Farm State Park
description: Beautiful nature trails.

name: Independence Oaks
description: Excellent trails.

name: Peebles Island State Park
description: Peebles Island State Park is at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk Rivers. It offers spectacular river and rapids views for walkers and joggers who take advantage of the miles of paths through the gently rolling and wooded landscape. Picnickers and fishermen come to relax and winter visitors use the facilities to cross-country ski, hike and snowshoe.

name: Annett Wayside Park
description: Annett Wayside Park is part of the large Annett State Forest. It is located near the Cathedral of the Pines National Shrine. Picnicking, hiking, pet walking and exploring are popular here. A .25 miles hiking trail offers nice views of the Black Reservoir.

name: Highland Oaks
description: Great hiking.

name: Rhododendron State Park
description: The 2, 723-acre Rhododendron State Park is named after the 16-acre Rhododendron Maximum grove on the property. An accessible trail is available for walking or hiking and takes you through the flower clusters. The grove on the property is the largest in New England and was established as a National Natural Landmark in 1982. Pets are permitted in some areas of the park.

name: Gibson Jack/west Fork
description: Gibson Jack/west Fork features 18 miles of hiking trails near Pocatello, ID.

name: New Glarus Woods State Park
description: New Glarus Woods State Park is a 435-acre park just outside of New Glarus. There are many activities here including camping, hiking, cross-country skiing and snow shoeing.

name: Holland Lake State Forest Campground
description: North Country Trail (1/2 mile S): This North Dakota to New York hiking route includes over 1500 miles of Michigan pathway.

name: Woodlawn Beach State Park
description: Woodlawn Beach State Park is located on the eastern-most terminus of Lake Erie. Within the Buffalo metropolitan area, the park offers a beautiful, one-mile long natural sand beach with lovely panoramic views and spectacular sunsets on the lake. Woodlawn Beach supports a diversity of wildlife habitats including one of the finest freshwater sand dune areas remaining on Lake Erie. Recreational opportunities are plentiful and include picnicking, beach volleyball, nature trails and a playground on the beach.

name: Glimmerglass State Park
description: Nature Trails.

name: Addison Oaks
description: Addison Oaks features 7 miles of hiking trails near Leonard, MI.

name: Rose Lake
description: Rose Lake features 4 miles of hiking trails near Bath, MI.

name: Maudslay State Park
description:
The Maudslay State Park is home to the former Moseley family estate. The park is located on the Merrimack River, featuring beautiful 19th century gardens.

Walking, biking and horseback riding are popular on the trails that wind through the scenic park. Picnicking is also a very common pastime.

name: John Muir Trails
description: John Muir Trails features 10 miles of hiking trails near La Grange, WI.

name: Seven Lakes State Park
description: An endless variety of topography and ecosystems form the area called Seven Lakes. Trail systems criss-cross the entire area. Many of these paths are worn down over the years by the local nature lovers, over 6.5 miles of trails are clearly marked as a designated trail system taking visitors beside two lakes, a stream and numerous swamps and low swales. Songbirds, muskrats, beaver, turtles, squirrels, deer, waterfowl, heron and many other species of wildlife call these wet areas home. This trail system is used by hikers, cross country skiers, snowmobilers (when there is four or more inches of snow) and mountain bikers.

name: Kettle Moraine John Muir + Emma Carlin
description: Kettle Moraine John Muir + Emma Carlin is a 28 mile hiking trail in Palmyra, Wisconsin.

name: Holly Recreation Area
description:
Disc Golf, fishing, hiking, hunting, mountain biking, picnicking and swimming during warm months, cross country skiing and snowmobiling in cold months, this park has an activity for everyone. Holly State Recreation Area is a park of rolling woodlands and open fields with scenic views no matter what activity you choose. The 8,000 acres of open land provide for hours of fun with amenities such as a dump station, boat rentals, a boat launch, cabins, electrical service, modern restrooms and campsites with hookups.

Five trails that equal about 35miles when combined offer excellent hiking and skiing opportunities.

name: Fort Dummer State Park
description:
Fort Dummer State Park, located in the Connecticut River Valley, has 217 acres of forest land just outside of Brattleboro. The park overlooks the site of Fort Dummer which was flooded when the Vernon Dam was built on the Connecticut River in 1908. This site can be seen from the northernmost scenic vista on the Sunrise Trail. Also located within the park are a small picnic area, hiking trails and a large open field.<br />
There are 3 trails available for hiking: the Sunrise Trail, the Sunset Trail, and the Broad Brook Trail.<br />
Sunrise Trail- This nearly one-mile loop trail traverses level and gently sloping ground on the eastern side of the park in the town of Vernon. The Fort vista is about midway on the trail. The trail is wooded the entire way.<br />
Sunset Trail- The Sunset trail is a 0.5 mile loop trail on the western side of the park, starting near the entrance and looping through the play field. The trail has a western vista of the village of Algiers in the town of Guilford. The trail passes through gently sloping ground and travels for a portion of its length on an old town road that was cut off when the interstate was constructed. The remains of the Boyden Farm, dating form the 1880s, can be seen along this trail. These include stone walls, a small shed and farmhouse.<br />
Broad Brook Trail- This 0.5 mile trail descends from the campground to a popular swimming hole on Broad Brook. The trail is steep in sections, and therefore is a much more strenuous hike than the other trails. Travel time is 10 minutes to the brook, 20 minutes back.

name: Big Indian Gorge Trail
description: The Big Indian Gorge Trail begins at the back of South Steens Campground. The hike is 8 miles to the headwall of the gorge and passes through numerous meadows and cottonwood and aspen groves. Along the way, you will make 3 stream crossings which can be difficult or impassable at times in the spring and early summer. Use caution! The trail is easy to follow for the first 7 miles and then it fades away and becomes a cross-country hike. During your journey, you'll be amazed at the size of this classic U-shaped, glacially carved gorge, the wildflowers in spring and summer, and the waterfalls tumbling out of the headwall. Many beautiful, existing primitive campsites beckon the overnighter.

name: Tucker Brook Town Forest
description: Tucker Brook Town Forest features 6 miles of hiking trails near Milford, NH.

name: Holdridge Recreation Area
description: Holdridge Recreation Area features 15 miles of hiking trails near Holly, MI.

name: Highland Forest
description: Highland Forest features 15 miles of hiking trails near Fabius/syracuse, NY.

name: Cape Blanco State Park
description: Work off your picnic lunch by hiking over eight miles of trails with many spectacular ocean vistas, woodland and wetland settings.

name: The Bus
description: The Bus features 10 miles of hiking trails near Lander, WY.

name: Owyhee Wild and Scenic River
description: Floating along the Owyhee River in Oregon, you pass through astonishing high desert canyonlands with thousand foot rhyolite cliffs and sand castle rock formations. Visitors will marvel at the variety of birds and mammals, including river otters, bighorn sheep and golden eagles. The Owyhee River's fragile ecological balance requires the utmost respect from its visitors. The Owyhee River's floatable sections are very remote and contain numerous technical and challenging rapids. This river is not for the inexperienced floatboater! Once you enter these deeply carved canyons, you will be a long way from help. Emergency access is extremely difficult, and cell phone coverage is nonexistent within the confines of the canyon. You must be prepared to handle all problems and emergencies on your own. To properly prepare, floaters should contact the Vale BLM Office to obtain information well in advance of a planned float trip. A waterproof river guide that includes a river map identifying rapids may be purchased from the Vale BLM office (541-473-3144).

name: Monadnock State Park
description: Monadnock State Park is located in the midst of the 3,165 ft Mount Monadnock. Camping, hiking, picnicking, cross country skiing and other winter sports are popular at this scenic park.

name: Horse Hill Nature Preserve
description: Horse Hill Nature Preserve is a 10 mile hiking trail in Merrimack, New Hampshire.

name: Fort Fetterman Historic Site
description: Fort Fetterman Historic Site is preserved today to remind people of the era of "winning the west." Several restored buildings are  open for visitors and contain artifacts and exhibits dating back to the 1800's. Activities here include camping and hiking.

name: Pisgah State Park
description: Pisgah State Park is includes 13,300 acres of forest terrain, a watershed north of the Ashuelot River, seven ponds, highland ridges and wetlands. The variety of terrain gives way to several recreational activities including biking, fishing, hiking, horseback riding, dog walking, ATV riding and snowmobiling. The park offers several different trailheads to keep from congestion. Pets are permitted at the park.

name: Molly Stark State Park
description:
Molly Stark State Park contains about two miles of foot trails. In wintertime, cross-country skis and snowshoes can be used on the foot trails and park roadways. Bicycles are limited to the paved and gravel roadways. Park entry fees apply during the operating season of Memorial Day weekend through Columbus Day.<br />
Mt. Olga Trail-1.7 mile loop, 1.5 hours. Blue blazes.<br />
This moderate trail starts across from the park office and rangers' quarters and ascends moderately with several switchbacks through northern hardwoods, and spruce and fir woodlands. Evidence of the land's agricultural past is visible near the beginning, including old farm machinery and several stone walls. Near the 0.9 mile mark, a short spur trail leads to the Summit of Mt. Olga, elevation 2,450 feet, and to the Mt. Olga lookout tower. This former fire watchmen's lookout is kept open for recreational viewing of the expansive 360 degree views of the southern Vermont Green Mountains, the Berkshires to the south in Massachusetts, and Mount Monadnock to the east in New Hampshire. The Searsburg wind farm is visible to the west, and Mount Snow can be seen to the northwest. The trail descends through similar woods, crossing the route of an old turnpike road several hundred feet below the summit spur. The trail ends at the top of the campground.<br />
Nature Center Spur- 0.1 mile. Blue blazes.<br />
This easy trail connects to the campground end of the Mt. Olga Trail. The nature center is a CCC constructed former toilet building that now houses a few park history and nature exhibits. This is an out and back trail.

name: Miller State Park
description:
Miller State Park is located on the 2,290ft summit of Pack Monadnock. It is the oldest state park in New Hampshire. Hiking is the most common activity here, but picnicking, dog walking and winter recreation are all also popular. The park's open hours vary, and should be looked up beforehand. Pets are permitted.

The park offers three main hiking trails that ascend Pack Monadnock. The Wapack trail is the most well-known and is a 21 mile trail that extends from Mt. Watatic to North Pack Monadpack.

name: Chief White Crane Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Springfield Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Scab Creek  Recreation Area
description: The Scab Creek  Recreation Area Is located in a beautiful and secluded lodge pole pine setting at 8,200 feet tucked in the foothills of the Wind River Mountains. This campground has 9 camp sites that include a fire pit and picnic table. The Scab Creek trail head is a major point of access to the Bridger-Teton Wilderness. Scab Creek Trail is steep, but well maintained for two miles. The trail grade becomes gentle as it joins the Bridger Wilderness trail system in The Bridger Teton National Forest. Several non-maintained trails lead to local areas of interest.

name: Green River/Warren Bridge River Access Area
description: Great hiking.

name: Steamboat Lake Interpretive Site
description: Interpretive trail.

name: Lewis and Clark Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Pierson Ranch Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Volga River State Recreation Area
description:
Volga River State Recreation Area in Fayette, Iowa is located in one of the most scenic parts of the state. Many people call this area "Little Switzerland" because of its geologic features and rugged terrain-- this is unique to most of the state's rolling hills and farmland. Wildlife observation is an excellent pastime at this park because of its natural perfect habit for a variety of animals including red fox, raccoons, skunks, possums, mink and beavers among many others. It is also a fantastic birdwatching location. Hunting is permitted during regular season.

The park is also a great location for hiking, swimming, boating, camping and mountain biking.

The park's many multi-use trails include the Frog Hollow Trail, Lake View Trails, Ridge Trail, Albany Trail and Lima Trail. The full trail system equals 25 miles. Trails can be used for cross country skiing, mountain biking, hiking and horseback riding.

name: City Creek Trail
description: City Creek Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Pocatello, ID.

name: Thousand Springs State Park
description: Excellent trails scattered throughout the area offer hikers varied choices.

name: Seneca Lake State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: Robert Frost Farm State Historic Site
description: Robert Frost Farm State Historic Site was the home of the famous poet, Robert Frost, and his family from 1900-1911. Many of his poems reference his memory of this home. Tours, walking trails, poetry readings and picnicking are all popular activities at this lovely location.

name: Musquash Conservation Area
description: Musquash Conservation Area features 7 miles of hiking trails near Londonderry, NH.

name: Spirit Mound Historic Prairie
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Chesterfield Gorge Natural Area
description: Chesterfield Gorge Natural Area spans 13 acres. It offers great opportunities for hiking as you explore the footpaths along the gorge and enjoy the scenic views.  The off-season poses unique risks inherent when participating in outdoor recreational activities. Please be aware that many State Park areas and trails are not staffed during the off-season, and day-use fees are not collected. Recreationists should possess the necessary knowledge, skill, and equipment to ensure their own safety. Users assume all risk while recreating in State Park lands.

name: Ortonville Recreation Area
description: A 3.5-mile hiking and mountain bike trail are located at the Bloomer #3 State Park.

name: Appalachian Trail 134: VT 9 to Stratton-Arlington Road
description: The AT runs 22.6 miles from VT Hwy 9 to Stratton-Arlington Road. Along the way it passes the Melville Nauheim shelter, Little Pond Mountain, the Goddard shelter, Glastenbury Mountain (a 3,748-foot summit), the Kid Gore shelter, and the Story Spring shelter.

name: Como Lake Park
description: Self-guided trails.

name: Woodford State Park
description:
Woodford State Park is located deep within the Green Mt. National Forrest. This 398-acre park is located on a mountain plateau and contains Adams Reservoir but there are also several other lakes and ponds in the area. <br />
The trails in Woodford State Park are popular for hiking during the warmer months, and for snowshoeing and cross-country skiing during winter. Snowmobiling is also popular in the area. There are 2 hiking trails, the Woodford Trail, a 2.7 mile trail around the lake, and the Atwood Trail, a .5 mile loop hike that runs along the shoreline.

name: Mather Regional Park Vernal Pools
description: Great hiking area.

name: Crater Lake National Park
description:
While there's no "best" way to experience the park -that depends on your interests, time and ambitions- there are different activities, trails and opportunities to enhance your enjoyment and appreciation of this special place.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: CCC Ponds/Pinedale Pathway
description: The original CCC Ponds were developed by the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) during The Great Depression in an effort by Franklin D. Roosevelt to create jobs in the 1930s. The work consisted of reforestation, road and park construction, flood control and beautification projects. The CCC Ponds are an important historical feature to the Pinedale Area. These Ponds were re-constructed during the 1990's and given specific themes to provide for various wildlife species: the Fish Pond, Duck Pond, Beaver Pond, and Frog Pond. A walking path was added to enable public access, as well as the installation of benches, interpretive signs and a parking lot. Over the years the area has seen increasing recreational use from Wyoming natives and visitors alike in the form of fishing and non-motorized activities such as walking and bird watching. Attached to the CCC Ponds parking area is a paved bike path called the Pinedale Pathway that loops from the parking lot back down into town for a round trip of about 6 miles. In the winter 3.5 miles of the CCC Pond area and part of the Pinedale Pathway are groomed for cross- country skiing opportunities.

name: Cayuga Lake State Park
description: Cayuga Lake State Park is a flat location on a lakeshore with gently sloping hills and scenic views. Fishing, camping, boating and picnicking are very popular here. There is also a boat launch, playground and playing field for visitors' convenience. The park also offers vacation rentals with fantastic amenities.

name: Bruneau Dunes State Park
description:
Unlock the mysteries of the desert on
Bruneau Dunes 6 mile hiking trail with
breathtaking views you won't forget.

name: Edward MacDowell Lake
description: Excellent trails.

name: Darien Lakes State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Black Rock Canal
description: Nice trails throughout park.

name: Sleepy Hollow State Park
description: There are more than 11 miles of hiking trails that take you through prairie grasses, hardwood forest and stands of pine trees.

name: Metamora- Hadley Recreation Area
description: Metamora-Hadley Recreation Area is a 723-acre park with a variety of recreational options including cross country skiing and snowmobiling in the winter and fishing, hunting, hiking, canoeing and swimming during the warm months. The park's amenities include a boat launch, a concession store, a picnic area, a playground, electrical service for campers, modern restrooms and a sanitation station. The Metamora-Hadley Nature Trail is a six mile trail open for cross country skiers and hikers.

name: Ionia State Recreation Area
description:
Ionia State Recreation Area is a 4,500-acre park full of hills, creeks, woodlands and a lovely lake. Fishing, hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, canoeing, swimming, camping and picnicking are popular in the warm months while cross country skiing and snowmobiling are popular is cooler months. The park has modern restrooms, a picnic area, a sanitation station, a dog trial area, a boat launch and electrical service.

Four trails on the property offer different levels of difficulty for hikers, skiers, horseback riders and mountain bikers. Together the trails make up about 35 miles.

name: CDT WY14: North Fork Lake to Summit Lake
description:
Section 14 of the CDT runs for 26.7 miles from North Fork Lake to Summit Lake. Along the way, the trail passes Mount Victor, Europe Peak, Round Top Mountain, Mount Baldy, Angel Peak, Mount Lester, Harrower Peak, Guiterrez Peak, Knife Point Mountain, Jackson Peak, Fremont Peak, Mount Sacagawea, Threlkeld Peak, Elbow Peak, Mount Helen, Henderson Peak, American Legion Peak, Winifred Peak, Mount Arrowhead, East Twin Peak, Split Mountain, Bow Mountain, Stroud Peak, Mount Oeneisis, and Sky Pilot Peak. The trail also passes August Lake, Rambaud Lake, Cook Lakes, Tommy Lake, Lake Nelson, Lower Jean Lake, Upper Jean Lake, Uppermost Jean Lake, Upper Elbow Lake, Elbow Lake, and Twin Lakes.<br />
<br />
Recommended Parking Spot: Big Sandy Trailhead: lat=42.6881873362 lon=-109.271360376

name: Drummer Park
description: Drummer Park features 10 miles of hiking trails near Keene, NH.

name: Mendon Ponds Park
description: Before heading out to Mendon Ponds Park print the map. The color coded hiking trails and additional details will keep you on the right track.

name: Beaver Island State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: Dryer Road Park
description: Dryer Road Park features 16 miles of hiking trails near Victor, NY.

name: Birch Creek Historic Ranch
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Chittenango Falls State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lake Kegonsa State Park
description: The park has more than five miles of hiking trails along the lake and through varied habitat.

name: Wyalusing State Park
description: Wyalusing has more than 14 miles of hiking trails. Trails may vary in difficulty. Steep climbs or descents and stairways may be encountered. Use caution when on steep bluffs or near a cliff. Stay well away from cliffs which are not protected by a barricade or barrier. Stay behind barricades and barriers where provided and watch small children closely. Trail surfaces can become slippery when wet, leaf covered, or where loose gravel is present.

name: Jamesville/skytop
description: Jamesville/skytop features 14 miles of hiking trails near Syracuse, NY.

name: Military Ridge State Trail
description: The fairly level grade and smooth limestone and asphalt surfaces make this 40-mile trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The 2.5-mile section between Fitchburg and Verona has been paved with asphalt suitable for in-line skating. Each bicyclist or skater age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Fort Rock
description: Fort Rock features 0 miles of hiking trails near Exeter, NH.

name: Clark Reservation State Park
description: Five trails.

name: Glacial Drumlin State Trail
description: The fairly level grade and smooth limestone and asphalt surfaces make this 52-mile trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The 13-mile section from Waukesha through the town of Dousman has been paved with asphalt suitable for in-line skating.

name: Oatka Creek Park
description: This mostly undeveloped parkland is home to wildlife and fishing enthusiasts.  Approximately one mile of this creek (both banks) runs through the 461-acre Oatka Creek Park. This park also offers one lodge for rent.

name: Ellicott Creek Park
description: Paved walking/jogging trails.

name: Pikes Peak State Park
description: Pikes Peak State Park is a hiker's delight. On its trails, hikers can explore beautiful wooded bluffs and valleys. Along the trails, hikers will see sheer walls of Decorah limestone, and fossil remains including brachiopods, gastropods and cephalopods. The trail goes past Bridal Veil Falls, a refreshing spring. The other trail leading to the Point Ann overlooks and the town of McGregor offers an invigorating hike with breathtaking views.

name: Akron Falls Park
description: Very nice for day trip

name: Governor Dodge State Park
description: Governor Dodge maintains nearly 40 miles of trails. All are open to hiking, except on ski trails when they are snow-covered.

name: Lake Shaftsbury State Park
description:
Lake Shaftsbury State Park is on an 84-acre parcel surrounding the small but picturesque Lake Shaftsbury. Shaftsbury State Park offers day and overnight recreation. A full service day use area and a rustic group camping area are available.<br />
Healing Springs Nature Trail is a walking path around Lake Shaftsbury which provides a glimpse of the area's history as well as its beautiful woods and waters.

name: Capital Springs State Recreation Area
description: There are over six miles of hiking trails and boardwalks at Capital Springs. Birding is excellent throughout the year due to the variety of natural habitat.

name: Hank Aaron State Trail
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers, joggers and in-line skaters. Some sections of the trail are on-street, so remember to use caution.

name: Blue Mound State Park
description: Blue Mound State Park features 6 miles of hiking trails near Blue Mounds, WI.

name: Lakeshore State Park
description: The park's trails are open to walking and running and offer great views of the Milwaukee skyline, Lake Michigan and Lakeshore's short grass prairies. Pets are welcome, but must be on a leash 8 feet or shorter and under control at all times.

name: Tower Hill Pond
description: Tower Hill Pond features 5 miles of hiking trails near Auburn, NH.

name: Old Erie Canal State Historic Park
description: The terrain is woodland and wetland that present opportunities for hiking, picnicking, horseback riding, bicycling, canoeing, fishing, and snowmobiling.

name: Townshend State Park
description:
A visit to Townshend Hill State Park, located at the foot of Bald Mountain on a bend of the West River, feels like a step back in time. Stonewalls, cellar holes, and old roads are evidence of such a past. <br />
Visitors can take a hike up the Bald Mountain Trail, passing various chutes, waterfalls and pools on the way to spectacular vistas to the north, south and east.

name: Powder Mills Park
description: At 380 acres, Powder Mills Park offers a unique natural setting with steep hillsides, creekside meadows and wetlands that provide a variety of recreational activities. There is downhill skiing, hiking, a sand volleyball court, and trout fishing. The park also offers six lodges and four shelters all available to rent.

name: Odiorne Point State Park
description: Odiorne Point State Park offers expansive views of the ocean. Picnickers, mountain bikers, hikers and explorers love this scenic park with its rocky shores. Boating and fishing are also common activities. Pets are not permitted in this park.

name: Ambrose A. Call State Park
description: The rugged and heavily wooded park offers two miles of trails that wind through the forest, down a ravine, and along a picturesque winding creek. Many species of shrubs, flowers and trees can be found at A.A. Call. A cross-country ski trail is available in the winter.

name: Green Lakes State Park
description: Two glacial lakes and an upland forest are attractive features of Green Lakes State Park. The park is also home to the 18-hole Green Lakes State Park Golf Course. Hiking, snowshoeing and cross-country skiing on the park's 10 miles of trails and fishing in the lakes are other popular activities. Pets okay on leash. Camping is also available. The great hiking trails here can also be used for mountain biking.

name: Grand Haven State Park
description: Although the park is closed in the winter, foot traffic to view the shoreline ice, lighthouse pier and sunsets is encouraged.

name: Canonsburg
description: Canonsburg features 16 miles of hiking trails near Grand Rapids, MI.

name: Saratoga Spa State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Buckhorn Island State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Appalachian Trail 135: Stratton-Arlington Road to VT 11/30
description: The AT runs 17.5 miles from Stratton-Arlington Road to VT Hwy 11/30. Along the way the trail passes Stratton Mountain, the Stratton Pond Shelter, Stratton Pond, the William B. Douglas Shelter, Spruce Peak, and the Spruce Peak Shelter.

name: Wentworth-Coolidge Mansion State Historic Site
description: The new walking path is finished! Be sure to go for a stroll on this 1.5 mile waterside path that connects the Wentworth-Coolidge Mansion Historic Site, Creek Farm and Portsmouth Conservation Land. Free parking and trail access are available at the Wentworth-Coolidge Mansion Historic Site.

name: All Crescent Trails
description: All Crescent Trails features 50 miles of hiking trails near Fairport, NY.

name: East Bank Trail
description: Milwaukee is well-known for its many parks.  But, the Milwaukee River hasn't always been a prime attraction.  But, thanks to several grants and the hard work of volunteers, you can now hike or mountain bike along the Milwaukee River in what is best described as Milwaukee's Central Park.  What I found was a hidden urban gem.  The trail winds its way through the deep river valley.  You will be amazed at how quickly you forget that you are in the heart of the city.  The East Bank Trail itself is short, but it connects to many more trails in Riverside Park and Estabrook Park.

name: Spring Lake State Forest Campground
description: North Country Trail (6 miles South): This national route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan.

name: Devil's Hole State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: North Point Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Pawtuckaway State Park
description: Pawtuckaway State Park is a great location for a variety of recreational activities including cycling, hiking, swimming, fishing, canoeing, kayaking, snowmobiling, cross-country skiing, rock-climbing, picnicking and camping. This is a great family outing location and a wonderful place to camp.

name: Ice Age National Scenic Trail
description: The Ice Age Trail goes through several state and federal lands in Wisconsin, including traveling many miles through county and private lands. In addition to the state parks and forests listed below (from west to east along the trail), the Ice Age Trail travels through many state wildlife and fishery areas, and some state natural areas.

name: Fundy Trail
description: Fundy Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Nottingham, NH.

name: Effigy Mounds National Monument
description:
Touring the Monument involves short walks along Accessible trails or extended walks along steep hiking trails.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Pacific Crest Trail: D: Hwy 138 to Hwy 58.
description:
Section D of the Pacific Crest Trail in Oregon runs 61.3 miles from Highway 138 near the Cascade Crest to Highway 58 near Willamette Pass. Highlights of this section include Mt. Thielsen, Sawtooth Ridge, Cowhorn Mountain, Diamond Peak, Mt. Yoran, and a possible detour along the Oregon Skyline Trail.<br />
<br />
Along the way the PCT passes the south end of North Crater Trail 1410; Mt. Thielsen Trail & New Mt. Thielsen Trail 1456; Thielsen Creek; the highest point in the Oregon-Washington section of the Pacific Crest Trail; Tipsoo Peak; Maidu Lake; Tolo Camp; Windigo Pass; Summit Lake; Road 700; Road 6010 near Summit Lake Campground; Pengra Pass; Crescent Lake, OR; and the Old Oregon Skyline Trail.

name: Clough State Park
description: Beautiful hiking.

name: Bandon State Natural Area
description: Great hiking area.

name: Milwaukee River Trail
description: Milwaukee River Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Milwaukee, WI.

name: Ball Mountain Lake
description:
The natural setting surrounding Ball Mountain Lake is enjoyed by a variety of visitors. Panoramic views from the overlook area at the dam offer sightseers, photographers, picnickers, and hikers pleasing views of Stratton and Bromley Mountains.<br />
There is a 15 mile loop trail that skirts the lake as well as a short interpretive trail in the campground.

name: Face Rock State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Great place to hike.

name: Jamaica State Park
description: 772 acre Jamaica State Park is home to several great hiking trails. Click the listings below for more detailed information about each trail.

name: Bear Brook State Park
description: Bear Brook State Park is a very popular location for a variety of recreational activities including hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, swimming, fishing, canoeing, kayaking, archery, picnicking and winter sports. This 10,000  acre park is the largest park in New Hampshire.

name: New River ACEC
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Whirlpool State Park
description: Whirlpool State Park has two levels--the upper, or street level has many overlooks with spectacular views of the swirling waters of the rapids, the whirlpool and the Niagara River Escarpment. Visitors picnic and children use the playground at this level. The lower, or river level is accessible by walking the 300 feet of trails and steps that descend into the gorge. This level has several nature trails and access for fishing.

name: Black Creek Park
description: Great trails.

name: De Veaux Woods State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: McIntosh Woods State Park
description: A one-mile nature trail takes visitors into the heart of McIntosh Woods and signs describe different features of the park.

name: Duncan Reservior Campground
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Havenwoods State Forest
description: More than six miles of trails invite hikers, runners and joggers to explore the property's woods, wetlands and grasslands. With several different trail segments visitors can choose a hike of varying length.

name: Pease Creek Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Hoffmaster State Park
description: With more than 10 miles of trails, the casual hiker or the serious student of nature will find a variety of interesting natural features. Upland, shoreline and aquatic birds are abundant. Hawks soar on the air currents of the dunes when winds are from the east. A main attraction is the Dune Climb Stairway leading to the top of a high sand dune. There, an observation deck offers a panoramic view of the dunes and Lake Michigan.

name: Governor Nelson State Park
description: In spring, summer, and fall, hike 8.4 miles of trails through many diverse ecological communities including oak woodland and savannah and mesic and wet prairies. Wildflowers are abundant along the trails. Various animals can often be seen while hiking the trails. Also found on the hiking trails are two accessible viewing platforms with information panels.

name: Tower Hill State Park
description: Two miles of trails meander through the park. Tower Hill is an excellent area for amateur bird watchers, offering a variety of habitat with riverbanks, deep woods and clearings.

name: Seven Bridges Trail (Grant Park)
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Bullards Beach State Park
description: 4.5 miles of open beach to explore

name: Yellow River State Forest
description: Yellow River State Forest features 50 miles of hiking trails near Harper's Ferry, IA.

name: Abraham Lincoln Park
description: In recognition of the 200th anniversary of President Abraham Lincoln's birth, Monroe County Executive Maggie Brooks announced on February 12, 2009 that the County has renamed Irondequoit Bay Park East in his honor. The beautiful 182 acre County Park, located on the east shore of Irondequoit Bay in the Town of Penfield, is now officially known as Abraham Lincoln Park.

name: CDT WY15: Summit Lake to Union Pass
description:
Section 15 of the CDT in Wyoming runs 34.1 miles from Summit Lake to Union Pass. Along the way, the trail passes Mount Whitecap, Ladd Peak, Glover Peak, Greeley Point, Squaretop Mountain, Gannett Peak, Klondike Peak, Lost Eagle Peak, Big Sheep Mountain, and Osborn Mountain. The trail also passes Granite Lake, Bench Lake, Lower Green Lake, Green River Lake, and Roaring Fork Trail.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=43.469079 lon=-109.886620

name: Seneca Park
description: Hiking/running trails.

name: Durand Eastman Park
description: The Durand Lake Trail is a 1.2 mile walk that has a very strong wilderness feel to it. There are sections of corduroy (log paths) along the southern part of the trail. The Trott Lake Trail is a .5 mile walk over small rolling hills. Along the path you will see the area that used to be Dr. Henry S. Durand's old campground where there are also unusual trees which are labeled. The Eastman Lake Trail is a 1.5 mile walk that is spectacular for any season. This trail follows along the lake where you can see waterfowl and warblers, especially during migration seasons.

name: Bear Brook
description: Bear Brook features 40 miles of hiking trails near Allenstown, NH.

name: Artpark State Park (Earl W. Brydges)
description: Great nature trails.

name: Tryon
description: Tryon features 6 miles of hiking trails near Rochester, NY.

name: Blind Sucker No.1 State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail runs through this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Platte River State Forest Campground
description: Platte Springs (on site): 2.5 miles of hilly terrain with interpretive trail marking points of interest.

name: Big Knob State Forest Campground
description:
Big Knob/Crow Lake (on site): 1/4 mile Big Knob loop, 2.5 mile Crow Lake.
Marsh Lake (on site): 1.5 miles of level terrain along Lake Michigan beach and wetland pathway.

name: Blind Sucker No. 2 State Forest Campground
description: Two trails in the area, excellent for hiking. The North Country Trail runs through this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Scheck's Place State Forest Campground
description:
Shore-to-Shore Riding/Hiking Trail (on site): Western spur of the 355-mile trail enters Scheck's Place Trail Camp adjacent to campground.
Muncie Lake (1 mile North): 11.5 miles. Hike, mountain bike, cross-country ski.

name: Arbutus No. 4 State Forest Campground
description:
Vasa (4 miles NE): 16.7 miles. Hike, mountain bike, cross-country ski.
Muncie Lake (9 miles East): 11.5 miles. Hike, mountain bike, cross-country ski.
Sand Lakes Quiet Area (10 miles NE): 10 miles of flat to very hilly terrain. Hike, mountain bike.

name: Big Oaks State Forest Campground
description:
Buttles Road (10 miles West): 7 miles of rolling terrain. Hike and mountain bike.
High Country (16 miles West): Over 80 miles of varied terrain connecting 9 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic back country.

name: Northampton Park
description: Northampton Park (973 acres) has hiking, bridle and cross-country ski trails, a downhill ski slope, a model airplane field, playground equipment, soccer fields, and a youth camping area. The park also offers two lodges that are available for rent. Horseback riding is permitted from May through October only, see more information below.

name: Wilson Mountain Reservation
description: Hiking is popular here; guided nature walks available.  617-333-7404

name: Verona Beach State Park
description: Verona Beach State Park, located on the eastern shore of Oneida Lake, is a picnicker's and camper's delight. Shaded picnic areas and the campground are adjacent to the beach with an excellent view of the water. The lake, Black Creek, cattail marshes, and bottomland hardwood swamps give Verona Beach one of the most diverse aquatic habitats in the Central Region, and well worth a hike on the "Woods and Wetland" nature trail. The winter season hosts snowmobilers, cross-country skiers and ice fishermen. The eastern portion of the park is open for hunting deer, small game, and waterfowl, in season.

name: Edwards Creek
description: Edwards Creek features 7 miles of hiking trails near Greenville, MI.

name: Burke Lake Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Lava Trail System
description: The Snake River used to flow across the northern portion of the Snake River Plain, but now flows along the southern margin of the Plain. The river was pushed there by successive lava flows. Sixty six thousand acres are within a Wilderness Study Area (WSA). The northwest end of the lava flow has been designated as a National Natural Landmark by the US Park Service. Today, three trails go across this desolate landscape, one primitive and the other two developed with interpretive signs. Even though this area looks uninhabited, it is growing and alive with wildlife and vegetation.

name: Northwood Meadows State Park
description: Northwood Meadows State Park is a large, 674.5-acre park in a scenic wilderness setting. The park is an excellent location for walking and picnicking. There is also a pond on the property that makes a great location for fishing and non-motorized boating. Cycling, hiking, snowmobiling and cross-country skiing are also common activities.

name: Hopkinton-Everett Lake
description: Hiking trails in Elm Brook Park.

name: Natural Bridge State Park
description: Natural Bridge State Park has a natural sandstone arch with an opening 25 high and 35 feet wide and accompanies beautiful Wisconsin scenery. Activities here include hiking and hunting.

name: Appalachian Trail 136: VT 11/30 to Danby-Landgrove Road
description: The AT runs 17.8 miles from VT Hwy 11/30 to Danby-Landgrove Road. Along the way it passes the Bromley shelter, Bromley Mountain, Mad Tom Notch Road, Peru Peak, the Peru Peak shelter, Mt. Tabor, the Lost Pond shelter, and the Big Branch shelter.

name: Tryon Park
description: Tryon Park contains 82 undeveloped acres on the western shore of Irondequoit Bay and offers hiking and natural scenic areas.

name: Lucien Morin Park
description: Lucien Morin Park (formerly Ellison Wetlands) is located on the north side of Ellison Park and continues to Irondequoit Bay. This marsh area is great for canoe and kayak access to the bay. In 2001, an additional 12 acres were acquired in the wetlands area.

name: Devil's Cove Park
description: At 18 acres, Devil's Cove Park is the newest Monroe County Park. It was acquired in 2000 and is located on Irondequoit Bay; it establishes the 21st Monroe County Park. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has listed the Irondequoit Bay ecosystem among the highest priorities for preservation. The park will remain natural and undeveloped.

name: Vaughan Woods State Park
description: Hiking is available on several trails that connect to make up one large loop, a system of 3  miles. Visitors can walk shorter looping sections if they choose.

name: Table Rocks
description: Scenic panoramas of the Rogue Valley and surrounding mountains await you at the Table Rocks Area of Critical Environmental Concern. This 3,172-acre area is cooperatively managed by the Bureau of Land Management and The Nature Conservancy to provide educational opportunities and protect special biologic, geologic, and scenic values. Steep hiking trails lead to the top of Upper and Lower Table Rocks, while a half-mile accessible trail at Lower Table Rock provides visitors with a less strenuous option. To protect this special place, dogs, bikes, and horses are prohibited. To avoid large school groups on weekdays in April and May, plan your hike before 9am or after 1pm.

name: Webster Park
description: At Webster Park, you'll discover 550 acres beautiful evergreen-planted slopes, rolling lakeshore breakers and cool green valleys. Located along the shore of Lake Ontario, this Monroe County Park even has a fishing pier. There is a multi-use athletic field, tennis/pickleball courts, a youth camping area, and a family campground in the park. Camping Reservations can be made by calling 585 872-5326 during the summer months, and 585-872-0083 during other months.

name: Irondequoit Bay Park West
description: This beautiful Monroe County Park is located on the west shore of Irondequoit Bay and offers hiking and access to the bay for fishing.
