Completely undeveloped, Irondequoit Bay Park West's 147 acres are located along approximately 2,000 feet of Irondequoit Bay water frontage. Irondequoit Bay Park West features a small undeveloped car-top boat launch.

name: North Umpqua Wild and Scenic River
description: Excellent trails.

name: Millpond Recreation Site
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Emerald Trail
description: The newly constructed Emerald Meadow Trail is a great way to explore the entire Susan Creek Recreation Area. This 1.25 mile trail links the Susan Creek Campground, Susan Creek Day Use Area, Susan Creek Falls Trail, Tioga Bridge, and the North Umpqua Trail while paralleling the Wild and Scenic North Umpqua River. The Emerald Trail is fully accessible however one small section may be difficult for people who use wheelchairs due to a small hill. Follow the wheelchair-friendly alternate route signs posted at the top and bottom of the hill.

name: Susan Creek Falls Trail
description: This lovely waterfall drops 50 feet over moss-lined rock cliffs. The 0.8 mile trail is moderately accessible to people with disabilities. The trailhead is located on the north side of Highway 138 directly across from the Susan Creek day use area and raft launch.

name: North Umpqua Trail - Swiftwater Trailhead
description: The Swiftwater Trailhead is the western terminus of the 79 mile long North Umpqua Trail. The trailhead parking area south of the Swiftwater Bridge has interpretive panels, garbage cans, a small picnic area, and a vault restroom. The Tioga segment of the North Umpqua Trail is 7.8 miles long from Swiftwater trailhead east to the Tioga Bridge. The Swiftwater segment of the North Umpqua Trail is 8 miles long and stretches from the Tioga Bridge to the Wright Creek Bridge. The trail is open to anglers, hikers, mountain bikers, and is closed to all motor vehicle use including ATVs and motorcycles. The trail is steep in sections and is therefore considered moderate. There are no facilities for equestrian users, however, some do enjoy the rugged and challenging forested ride. Swifwater Trailhead and the North Umpqua Trail between the trailhead and Deadline Falls are fully accesible to people with disabilities. Past that, the steep trail and numerous rocks and roots make the rest of the trail not accessible to people who use wheelchairs.

name: Lowell Lake State Park
description:
Open year round for day use (winter road conditions permitting). Park is undeveloped with no camping or restroom facilities. Free entry.<br />
Lowell Lake Trail is a loop approximately 3.5 miles in length, which completely encircles Lowell Lake. Trail highlights include a Revolutionary War-era cemetery, stands of large white pine trees, and scenic views of the lake and wetlands. The trail is located on relatively flat terrain and the hike is of moderate difficulty. The trail is marked with blue paint blazes. The northern portion of the trail follows park service roads on both sides of the lake as well as approximately 1000 feet of Little Pond Road, a town road. Parking for the trail is available at the parking area located near the boat landing off Lowell Lake Road.

name: Newton Hills State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Mt Agamenticus
description: Mt Agamenticus features 7 miles of hiking trails near York, ME.

name: Pillsbury State Park
description: Pillsbury State Park is a lesser known park of New Hampshire but is nonetheless fun. The park has great cycling, boating, camping, fishing, hiking and winter sport opportunities. It is a heavily wooded area with several ponds and great opportunities to view wildlife. The Monadnock-Sunapee Greenway, a 51-mile hiking trail, runs through this park. The park is also home to abandoned cellar holes from the late 1700s and early 1800s.

name: Moreau Lake State Park
description: Many excellent trails.

name: Wolf Creek Falls Trail
description:
During the rainy season of winter and early spring, Wolf Creek Falls puts on a massive display of the strength and power of water. Spring brings lush vegetation and vibrant colors for photographers. Spring and early fall days, especially with a light overcast, are considered the best weather conditions for taking memorable photos.
The reduced water flows in the summer months reveal the delicate and complex channels and pathways that water has carved into the bedrock cliffs underneath Wolf Creek Falls. The trail is not accessible to people who use wheelchairs due to the 13% grade on the first footbridge.

name: Lost Forest
description: An unusual stand of ancient ponderosa pine forest growing out of the sand is the outstanding feature of the Lost Forest Research Natural Area, which is located in the northeast portion of the area. A remnant of a forest that existed in a cooler and wetter age, these pines survive on half the typical annual precipitation for this tree species due to unique soil and hydrologic properties of the area. The nearest forest is 40 miles to the northwest, yet the pines continue to reproduce and thrive in this environment. Motorized vehicles are allowed in the Lost Forest on routes posted "open." No cross country use is allowed. Camping is permissible in designated sites only. Camping areas are primitive. There are no facilities, water, or restrooms in the area.

name: D.A.R. State Forest
description: Several miles of beautiful trails.

name: Muskegon State Park
description:
Muskegon State Park is a 1,233-acre area with plenty of recreational opportunities. Fishing, metal detecting, swimming, cross country skiing, hiking, boating, picnicking and playing are just a few of them. Muskegon State Park is on the shore of Lake Michigan. The park has four campground available for overnight use, a fish cleaning station, a playground for children, a picnic area and modern restrooms.

The park has several multi-use trails that equal about 11 miles in length when combined.

name: Pilot Knob State Park
description: The park has excellent trails for hikers and horseback riders. In winter, a warming house with electricity and heat provides comfort for ice skaters, snowmobilers, cross-country skiers and ice fishermen.

name: Vanderkamp
description: Vandekamp features 20 miles of hiking trails near Syracuse, NY.

name: Great Bear
description: Great Bear features 10 miles of hiking trails near Syracuse, NY.

name: Crack-In-The-Ground
description: Crack in the Ground is a volcanic fissure over two miles long and up to 70 feet deep in Lake County Oregon. The length of the fissure can be hiked, as there is an established trail along the fissure's bottom. Normally, fissures like this one are filled in with soil and rock by the processes of erosion and sedimentation, but because Crack in the Ground is located in such an arid region, very little filling has occurred. As a result, Crack in the Ground exists today nearly as it did shortly after its formation. When you get there it is easy to cool off, as the bottom of the crack can be as much as twenty degrees below the surface temperature.

name: Four Mile Creek State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: Blitzen River Trail
description: The Blitzen River Trail takes off from the southern tip of Page Springs Campground at the base of Steens Mountain. The trail follows the Donner und Blitzen Wild & Scenic River upstream to its junction with Fish Creek. The trail itself receives limited maintenance, so expect a variety of conditions ranging from rocky slopes to thick brush to dusty foot paths...and the occasional river crossing when conditions allow (beginning mid-summer). The Blitzen River Trail affords many wonderful fishing spots and stops along the way. If you do fish, please 'catch and release' the beautiful Redband Trout so as to preserve this unique species. Many birds and wildlife are in the canyon - be on the lookout for deer, antelope, cougar and especially the western rattlesnake. If overnight backpacking is in your plan, there are many established primitive camp sites within the canyon.

name: Chimney Bluffs State Park
description: Nature trails to scenic overlooks.

name: Ithaca Jailhouse Trail
description: Ithaca Jailhouse Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Ithaca, MI.

name: Emerald Lake State Park
description:
Located conveniently between Manchester and Rutland, the park is popular for its wooded hillside campground, beach and swimming area, and nearby attractions and tourist destinations. The park surrounds 20-acre Emerald Lake, named for the emerald green color of its waters when viewed from above.<br />
The park is a favorite destination of hikers, with the Long Trail and Appalachian Trail nearby, and trails on Dorset Mountain.

name: Delta Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Cape Arago State Park
description: Great beach hiking.

name: Wilson-Tuscarora State Park
description: Wilson-Tuscarora State Park is a well-preserved natural area for many varieties of plants and wildlife, encompassing 476.5 acres of mature woods, open meadows and marshland. Tuscarora Bay, divided from Lake Ontario by a strip of land called "The Island," has a boat launch and emergency storm shelter docks. The park's four-mile nature trail is also used for hiking, snowshoeing and cross-country skiing. Fishing for many varieties of pan fish and game fish, from boats or from shore, is extremely popular. Picnickers can enjoy scenic views of the lake while children play in the playground.

name: Decorah Mtb Trail System
description: Decorah Mtb Trail System features 14 miles of hiking trails near Decorah, IA.

name: Blackwater Dam
description: One of the oldest dams in New England, this small facility near Webster provides some of the best kayak waters in the country during spring releases. It is the site of sanctioned events each year and has hosted Olympic pre-trials. Hydropower production was never incorporated after local citizens objected to creation of a permanent pool of water. For up-to-date information, call (603) 934-2116.

name: Pike Lake State Park
description: 5 hiking trails

name: Big Elk Creek
description:
Big Elk Creek is a tame hike taken in itself. It accesses some much bigger terrain in the Snake River Range.<br />
<br />
Neeley Cove off of the Siddoway Fork is well worth the trip and you can loop to Upper Palisades Lake this way. <br />
<br />
Enjoy other forks of Elk Creek too for more loops.

name: Sunset Bay State Park
description: A network of hiking trails connects Sunset Bay with nearby Shore Acres and Cape Arago State Parks. Hiking these trails will give you a chance to experience pristine coastal forests, seasonal wildflowers and spectacular ocean vistas from atop the rugged cliffs and headlands. From points along the trail, you'll be treated to views of Gregory Point and the Cape Arago lighthouse.

name: Fair Haven Beach State Park
description: Nice trails.

name: Rollins State Park
description: Rollins State Park is located on the south slope of Mt. Kearsarge. Picnicking, hiking and dog walking are common activities at this scenic park. A one-half mile trail takes you to the summit of Mt. Kearsarge. The views of Mt. Monadnock to the hills of New Hampshire's coastal plain are beautiful. Pets are permitted at the park.

name: Duck Lake State Park
description:
Duck Lake State Park is a 728-acre, day-use area that offers a variety of recreational activities including: hiking, cross-country skiing, hunting, fishing, canoeing, swimming, snowmobiling and picnicking.
The Duck Lake-Paved Trail is the most popular path at the park at 0.50 miles in length. The park's natural features range from open brush land to mature hardwood forest.

name: North Springfield Lake
description: There is a short interpretive trail that leads hikers along the shores of the North Springfield Lake. Take in the scenic lake views while learning a little bit more about the area!

name: Hamlin Beach State Park
description: Hamlin Beach State Park is an scenic location for a camping trip with its clear waters, sandy beaches and numerous camping sites. A nature trail and 10 miles of multi-use trails are also available for a variety of recreational opportunities. Hiking, cycling, snowmobiling and cross-country skiing are common activities here. Fishing and picnicking are also popular. Pets okay on leash.

name: Lakeside Beach State Park
description: Great area to hike.

name: Wadleigh State Park
description: The Sunapee-Ragged-Kearsarge Greenway is a 75 mile loop trail that links four New Hampshire State Parks: Sunapee, Winslow, Rollins, Wadleigh. The trail also links three New Hampshire State Forests: Gile, Kearsarge and Shadow Hill as well as one Wildlife Management Area: Bog Mountain.

name: Golden Hill State Park
description: Golden Hill State Park is home to the Thirty Mile Lighthouse that was decommissioned in 1958. The park offers fishing, camping, boating, hiking, picnicking and nature walks. It also offers tours of the lighthouse. During the winter, visitors enjoy snowshoeing and snowmobiling. The Lighthouse Cottage is available for renting year-round. Picnic tables and grills are available for visitor use. Pets okay outdoors only.

name: Fort Rock State Natural Area
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Gull Point State Park
description: The western portion of Gull Point State Park is a hiker's delight, with a fine self-guided interpretative trail. On the 1.3 mile trail, visitors can identify a variety of natural features by using the trail brochure. This area of the park is an excellent place to observe a wide variety of wildlife from songbirds to white-tailed deer. In the winter, the area is open for cross-country skiing.

name: Appalachian Trail 137: Danby-Landgrove Road to VT 103
description: The Appalachian Trail runs 14.6 miles from Danby-Landgrove Road to VT Hwy 103. Along the way it passes the Lula Tye shelter, Homer Stone Mountain, Green Mountain, Little Rock Pond, the Little Rock Pond shelter, White Rocks, the Greenwall shelter, VT Hwy 140, Bear Mountain, and the Minerva Hinchey shelter.

name: Doerner Fir Trail
description: The Doerner Fir is one of the largest coast Douglas fir trees in the world. Winding roads take travelers through some of the most valuable forests in the nation to this site 50 miles from Coos Bay in Oregon's Coast Range mountains. Once at the trailhead, take a half-mile hike through a pristine old-growth stand to the Doerner Fir.

name: Pinnacle
description: Pinnacle features 10 miles of hiking trails near Newport, NH.

name: Fort Defiance State Park
description:
Fort Defiance State Park has 191 acres of woodlands that provide a beautiful contrast to the usual landscape of Iowa.

The park is home to a 16 site campground. Electrical hookups are located at half of the sites, but the rest are primitive. Picnicking and hiking are popular activities at this park.

The hiking trails on the property take you through the scenic landscapes. Three of the trails are open for equestrian use too.

name: Wilgus State Park
description:
Wilgus State Park was originally constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps but was developed and expanded again from 1960 til present. Since it is located on the Connecticut River it is a very popular destination for canoeing and hiking and there are rentals available for those activities. <br />
There are no hiking trails in the state park, but this park provides access to the Pinnacle Trail hike, which provides a scenic vista of the Connecticut River Valley.

name: Winslow State Park
description: A one-mile foot trail leads from the picnic area to the summit of Mt. Kearsarge. A 1- 3/4 mile trail offers a loop possibility.

name: Palisade Canyon To Upper Palisade Lake
description: Palisade Canyon To Upper Palisade Lake features 6 miles of hiking trails near Palisades, ID.

name: The North Spit
description: This site is the southernmost end of a series of sand dunes extending along the Oregon coastline from Florence to Coos Bay. The ever-changing habitat is home to a wide variety of mammals and birds, including some threatened and endangered species. Strolling along the beach, visitors may glimpse an osprey diving for fish or whales spouting offshore. A full-sized boat ramp is open for public use at no charge.

name: Elinor Bedell State Park
description: Several miles of trail will take you through wetlands, woodlands, and along the lakeshore.

name: Derrick Cave
description: A lava tube 30 feet high, 50 feet wide and 1/4 mile long. Derrick Cave was named for H.E. Derrick, a pioneer rancher in the Devils Garden area. Derrick Cave developed just south of the main vent for the Devils Garden Flows and was the route of most of the lava which spread south from the vent. In the 1960s, Derrick Cave was a designated nuclear fallout shelter with supplies of food and water. There are no facilities at this site and the road is rough and should be taken with caution.

name: Devils Lake State Park
description: Devils Lake State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Baraboo, WI.

name: Mosquito Creek (the Racecourse)
description: Mosquito Creek (the Racecourse) features 8 miles of hiking trails near Wilson, WY.

name: Devil's Lake State Park
description: There are 29 miles of trails in the park, ranging from easy strolls along a paved pathway along the lakeshore, to a rocky hiking ascent up the south face of the East Bluff. With several different trail segments, visitors can choose a hike of varying length that includes vistas, woods, meadows, glacial moraines, talus slopes and ridgetop backwoods.

name: Lake Alvin Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Owasippe
description: Owassippi features 30 miles of hiking trails near Muskegon, MI.

name: Cottonwood Springs Lake
description: Wonderful trails throughout the area.

name: Mt. Ascutney State Park
description: Ascutney State Park is home to several great hiking trails. For detailed information about each one, click on the individual trail listing links below.

name: Craters of the Moon National Monument
description:
A Violent Past, Calm Present, and Uncertain Future. Craters of the Moon National Monument is a vast ocean of lava flows with scattered islands of cinder cones and sagebrush. Within the park there are over 20 miles of trails. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Cache Creek To Game Creek
description: Cache Creek To Game Creek is a 10 mile hiking trail in Jackson, Wyoming.

name: Franklin Falls Dam
description: Franklin Falls Dam features 8 miles of hiking trails near Franklin, NH.

name: Marble Beach State Recreation Area
description: Marble Beach has a paved trail that runs the length of the park and is connected with miles of area recreational trails.

name: Snow King Resort
description: There are miles and miles of trails on Snow King Resort right in the town of Jackson to hike. Some of the trails are very steep, and some aren't. The views off of the top are definitely worth the effort, though!

name: CDT WY16: Union Pass to Sheridan Trail
description: The CDT runs for 20.6 miles from Union Pass to Sheridan Trail. Along the way, the trail passes Lake of the Woods, Fish Lake Mountain, and Buckskin Ridge.

name: Camp Plymouth State Park
description:
Camp Plymouth is rich in history from the birth of our nation right up to present day. <br />
There is a .5 mile out-and-back trail that leads to Vista Rd. The trail follows blue blazes and <br />
climbs steeply to a vista of Echo Lake and Camp Plymouth State Park. The trail passes through a young forest with birch, beech and aspen trees.

name: Ferry Beach State Park
description: Nature trails and guided nature programs available.

name: Lake St. Catherine State Park
description:
Lake St. Catherine State Park, which consists of 117 acres, is a beautiful State Park situated around the scenic Lake St. Catherine. <br />
Within the park there is a short interpretive trail that takes hikers through grassy plains and wooded forests. The Delaware and Hudson Rail Trail is close by as well!

name: Golden and Silver Falls State Natural Area
description: Hike 1.4 miles to the top of Golden Falls to get an eagle's-eye view of the cascading waterfall and giant old-growth firs and cedars.

name: Bulldog
description: Bulldog features 3 miles of hiking trails near Hailey, ID.

name: Creek Creek Nature Trail
description: If you hike quietly you may see deer, rabbits, small lizards, or possibly an eagle or a moose.  When skies are clear, prepare for an expansive view of the Snake River, volcanoes and surrounding farmland.

name: North Menan Butte Trail
description: Great hiking, unique physical features.

name: Halverson Lake Trail
description: Halverson Lake is a pond nestled along the canyon with opportunities for camping, hiking, backpacking, biking, horseback riding, hunting, picnicking and scenic/wildlife viewing. The BLM non-motorized portion of the canyon between the USGS gauging station, downstream to the Canyon County line, encompasses the Halverson Bar area.  Throughout the area, you can follow trails that lead through scattered Bonneville Flood boulders and see remnants of mining homesteads and old placer claims. Halverson Lake, near the base of the canyon cliffs, provides a small oasis in the desert. If you hike the Halverson Bar area, plan at least several hours to allow more than ten miles of trails to lead you to interesting locations!

name: Harrington Beach State Park
description: Harrington Beach State Park has seven miles of hiking trails and one mile of Lake Michigan shoreline to explore. Walking the beach along Lake Michigan, hikers can see the remains of a 700-foot pier that was used in the early 1900s for shipping limestone quarried and processed at the park. The old pier is on the point which is the dividing point between the north and south beaches.

name: Black Canyon
description: Black Canyon features 6 miles of hiking trails near Wilson Wy, WY.

name: Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site
description:
Over 100 acres of the park is forested. Several nature trails wind through this woodland area. Interpretive wayside panels about the area's natural history, are located along the trails.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Lambs Gulch
description: Lambs Gulch features 4 miles of hiking trails near Hailey, ID.

name: Croy Creek Trail System
description: This trail system and skills development area are for motorcycle riders, mountain bikers, hikers and equestrians.  The area is managed by the BLM and Blaine County.

name: Appalachian Trail 138: VT 103 to US 4
description: The AT runs 17.4 miles from VT Hwy 103 to US Hwy 4. Along the way the trail passes the Clarendon shelter, Lower Cold River Road, the Governor Clement shelter, Killington Peak and Killington Ski Resort, the Cooper Lodge shelter, the Pico Camp shelter, Pico Peak, and the Churchhill Scott shelter.

name: Lake Louise State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Lucky Peak Lake State Park
description: Lucky Peak Lake State Park is located on the side of the Boise River in the foothills of southwestern Idaho. this park offers swimming, fishing, boating, mountain biking and hiking.

name: Lucky Peak State Park
description: Paved trails offer nice walks.

name: Phillips Canyon
description: Phillips Canyon features 15 miles of hiking trails near Wilson, WY.

name: New Fane
description: New Fane features 6 miles of hiking trails near Kewaskum, WI.

name: Coolidge State Park
description:
Known for its rustic feel, hillside campsites that give way to dramatic mountain views, and authentic character, Coolidge State Park is the developed recreation centerpiece of the 21,500 acre Calvin Coolidge State Forest, the largest state-owned land holding in central Vermont.<br />
Within the park, there are miles of hiking trails to explore, several streams home to elusive brook trout, and abundant wildlife. Some visitors are lucky enough to catch a glimpse of a barred owl, a moose, or rarely even a black bear!<br />
There are more than 30 miles of maintained hiking trails on public land in the Coolidge Range area. Trails are identified with colored rectangular blazes. There are also many miles of woods roads for walking and exploring. Also sections of the Appalachian Trail and Long Trail run right through here!

name: Wilson Creek Trail System
description: The Wilson Creek Travel Management Area is a 28,000 acre area of mostly public lands located in the Owyhee Front, about 10 miles south of Marsing. Idaho. The northernmost portion of the subregion lies along Highway 78, near the Snake River. The project area runs approximately from Highway 78 south The Wilson Creek subregion is portion of the larger (261,487-acre) Owyhee Front Special Recreation Management Area (SRMA) that was designated as "Limited to Designated Roads and Trails" in the 1999 Owyhee Resource Management Plan.

name: Hole-in-the-Wall
description: The Hole-in-the-Wall is a colorful and scenic red sandstone escarpment that is rich in legend of outlaw activity in the late 1800s, most notably Butch Cassidy and the Wild Bunch Gang. The "hole" is a gap in the Red Wall that, legend has it, was used secretly by outlaws to move horses and cattle from the area. The area is primitive in nature, with no services. Visitors should be skilled in cross-country travel and take adequate water, food, and fuel. Please pack trash from the area, and respect private property owners who are working with the BLM to make this an enjoyable recreation opportunity.

name: Eisenbahn State Trail
description: The fairly level grade and smooth limestone and asphalt surfaces make this 25-mile trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The five-mile section in West Bend has been paved with asphalt suitable for in-line skating.

name: Selkirk Shores State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Wind Cave National Park
description:
Imagine walking across a prairie and viewing scenery similar to that seen by Black Hills pioneers in the 1890s. Such landscapes can be seen from the 30 miles of hiking trails in Wind Cave National Park. From these trails you can view one of the best examples of mixed-grass prairie in the United States. Seventy percent of the park is mixed-grass prairie and the balance is ponderosa pine forest and riparian habitat.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Two Lights State Park
description: Strollers and hikers can enjoy the refreshing sea breezes along shoreline trails and watch ships sailing into and out of Portland Harbor. Remember, ocean breezes can cool off a summer afternoon, so bring warm clothing to ensure an enjoyable visit. When walking along the rocks by the ocean, stand at least 20 feet back from the surf and keep a close eye on chidlren who are in your care.

name: Crescent Beach State Park
description: Several short trails, as well as beachcombing.

name: Ahern State Park
description: The 128-acre Ahern State Park is great fishing, biking and hiking area. The park is located on the shore of Lake Winnisquam. Pets are not allowed in the park.

name: Trout Creek and Oregon Canyon Mountains
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Mirror Lake State Park
description: There are over 19 miles of hiking trails at Mirror Lake State Park.

name: Big Sioux Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Jackman Park Campground
description: Great hiking.

name: Pueblo Mountains
description: The Pueblo Mountains straddle the border between Nevada and Oregon at the northern end of the Black Rock Desert. The eastern crest of the Pueblo Mountains is particularly steep and rugged, while the western range front dips gently to the west. Elevations range from 4,200 at the town of Denio to 8,632 at the summit. The area contains small meadows, aspen groves, riparian habitat, and talus slopes, providing a mosaic of wildlife habitat types rich in wildlife species diversity. One hundred seventy species of birds, 47 species of mammals, 18 species of amphibians and reptiles and 3 species of fish may be found here. Prehistoric and historic properties of varying significance are known to exist in this relatively unstudied region. Prehistoric rock art is considered one of the area's special features. Hunting, backpacking, camping, and sightseeing are popular activities in the Pueblos. Ranching is another dominant land use in this area - half a dozen ranches have grazing permits for allotments in the Pueblos.

name: South Steens Family & Equestrian Campgrounds
description: South Steens Campground is located on Steens Mountain, approximately 18 miles from Highway 205 via the Steens Mountain Loop Road. Visitors will find picnic tables and grills at 36 campsites amid juniper and sage. The Campground is close to the Historic Riddle Brothers Ranch, several hiking trails, and Little Blitzen and Big Indian Gorges. An equestrain campground designed specifically for horse users is directly adjacent. Recreational stock (horses, mules, llamas, goats, etc.) are not allowed in the family portion of South Steens Campground, but are welcome and comfortable at 15 equestrian sites complete with tie posts and small corrals.

name: Page Springs Campground
description: Page Springs Campground is located at the base of Steens Mountain, just 3 miles from the town of Frenchglen at 4,200-foot elevation. Thirty-six campsites are available under the cottonwood and juniper trees near the Donner und Blitzen Wild and Scenic River. A trailhead for the Blitzen River Trail is located within the campground. A volunteer camp hosts is generally on site May-October to share information about the area. In 2008/2009, Page Springs Campground was upgraded with concrete picnic tables and new fire rings, landscaping, ADA approved water lines and faucets, new culverts, leveling and new gravel on site access road and camp sites, new portal signs and fee collection station, new entrance fence and an ADA restroom facility.

name: Kiger Wild Horse Viewing Area
description: Southeastern Oregon is home to the Kiger Mustangs, considered one of the most pure herds of Spanish Mustangs in the west today. Visitors may catch a glimpse of these wild horses at several viewing sites in a habitat area covering 37,000 acres. NOTE: Trees and other vegetation have grown significantly within the viewing area since it was established. Viewing oppotunities from this location may prove unsuccessful.

name: Steens Summit Trail
description: The Steens Summit Trail is a short hike that allows easy acceess to the summit of the 8th highest mountain in Oregon - Steens Mountain - at 9,733'. Park at the end of the Wildhorse Lake Overlook Road, hike past the gate and follow the closed run up to a sutnning, 360 degree view of Steens Mountain and the surrounding countryside. If you're lucky enough to be up there on a clear day, you can spy 3 other states and Mount Shasta - almost 200 miles away! Don't let the short distance of the hike fool you...air is a little thin at this altitude!

name: Mann Lake Recreation Site
description: Great trails.

name: Wildhorse Lake Trail
description: Wildhorse Lake Trail is a challenging hike for the dedicated adventurer. Park at the end of the Wildhorse Lake Overlook Road and follow the trail 1/4 mile to the Wildhorse Lake Overlook. From there, the 1-mile long segment to the lake receives limited maintenance and is very steep and unstable, so use extreme caution, especially if you are carrying a fishing pole! For overnighters, camping is limited to two, established but primitive sites at the lake. Make sure you have a camp stove as fires are not allowed within the Wildhorse Lake basin. Check the sign up sheet inside the registration box to verify if either site is available. There are other sites approximately 3 miles down the canyon if the lake sites are taken, but be aware there isn't a trail leading into the canyon - the brush is thick and the elvation gain on the way out is almost 3000' feet.

name: Pike Creek Trail
description: If snow and rain prevent you from getting up to the north, south, and west sides of Steens Mountain, head to the east side where access is year-round. The trail begins near a juniper tree growing out of a rock - see 'directions' for the specific location. The Pike Creek Trail follows a very old jeep road for one mile and becomes a walking trail for another mile before petering out. Experienced trekkers can pick up the trail again further ahead where it eventually leads to a neat, established campsite. There are two creek crossings which can be difficult to pass in early spring and after summer thunderstorms. Destinations along this trail include an old cabin, an old mine and the upper Pike Creek drainages. Look for deer, cougar and the ever elusive bighorn sheep along this trail. NOTE: Portions of the land in the Pike Creek drainage are private property, includng the parking area near the trailhead. The public use of private land is a privilege. Please respect private property and landowners throughout your travels.

name: Little Blitzen Gorge Trail
description: The Little Blitzen Gorge Trail is 8.5 miles to the headwall of Little Blitzen Gorge with the last mile becoming a cross-country adventure. You will encounter one stream crossing which can be difficult or impassable at times in the spring and early summer. Use caution! Along the way, you will pass through wildflower meadows, massive cottonwood and aspen groves and waterfalls for your viewing pleasure. Many existing campsites are available for the overnight, backpacking crowd.

name: Mendon/shrewsbury Cc Fire Roads
description: Mendon/shrewsbury Cc Fire Roads features 20 miles of hiking trails near Mendon, VT.

name: Lake Vermillion State Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: E: Hwy 58 to Hwy 242
description:
Section E of the PCT in Oregon runs 76 miles from Highway 58 near Willamette Pass to Highway 242 at McKenzie Pass. This section of trail improves as it goes along, with progressively better views and more lakes to enjoy. The last third of the trail spends most of its time in the gorgeous (and very popular) Three Sisters Wilderness.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes Middle Rosary Lake; North Rosary Lake; Maiden Peak Trail; Taylor Lake; Road 600 at Irish Lake; Riffle Lake; Brahma Lake; Jezebel Lake; Stormy Lake; Blaze Lake; Cougar Flat; Tadpole Lake; Moody Lake; Island lake; Dumbbell Lake; Bend, OR; Camelot Lake; Sisters Mirror Lake; North Fork of Mesa Creek; Hinton Creek; Separation Creek; White Branch Creek; Minnie Scott Spring; and South Matthieu Lake.

name: Loon Lake Recreation Site
description: Some good hiking trails.

name: Middle Fork Trail
description: West Fork Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Oakridge, OR.

name: North Hartland Lake
description:
At the upper end of the reservoir, the Ottauquechee River flows through the sheer-faced 165-ft deep Quechee Gorge, one of the outstanding natural spectacles in the state. An overlook area and a state-managed campground as well as a new Visitor Center are nearby.<br />
With more than 1,700 acres of land ranging from forests and fields to wetlands and a reservoir, North Hartland Lake has recreation opportunities for everyone! There is a beautiful nature path that skirts along the reservoir, and provides beautiful views.

name: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Lapham Peak Unit
description: There are several miles of hiking trails within the forest. One of the highlights of the forest is the observation tower which offers panoramic views of the surrounding area. Hiking is not allowed on the cross-country ski trails when they are snow-covered. Pets must be on a leash 8 feet or shorter at all times.

name: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Pike Lake Unit
description: Nine different hiking trails provide you with a variety of topography and scenery. Summer is a great time to view wildflowers while walking the forest trails. Pets must be on a leash 8 feet or shorter at all times.

name: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Mukwonago River  Unit
description: The Mukwonago River Unit of the Kettle Moraine State Forest is under development in Waukesha and Walworth counties. The property was acquired by the state for public recreation and conservation goals including habitat protection and restoration.

name: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Loew Lake Unit
description: Over four miles of the Ice Age National Scenic Trail go through the forest.

name: Kettle Moraine State Forest
description: There are several miles of hiking trails within the forest. The Ice Age National Scenic Trail travels for 31 miles through the length of the forest. Hiking is also available at the Greenbush recreation area (13.5 miles), New Fane loop system trails (7.7 miles), Zillmer loop area (11.4 miles), Butler Lake loop (3 miles), Parnell Tower loop (3.5 miles), Tamarack loop (2 miles), and the Lake to Lake Bike Trail (6.5 miles).

name: William M. Tugman State Park
description: A trail around the south end of the lake allows hikers to get away from the developed area of the park and explore the lakes many inlets. Maybe you'll catch glimpses of osprey, crane, eagle, deer and other forest creatures as you walk through forests of spruce, cedar, fir, and alder.

name: Green Belt Trails( Sawyer Road)
description: Green Belt Trails( Sawyer Road) features 20 miles of hiking trails near Cape Elizabeth, ME.

name: 400 State Trail
description: Wetlands, wildlife, sandstone bluffs, rolling croplands and pastures are just a few of the sights you can enjoy on the 400 State Trail as it repeatedly crisscrosses the Baraboo River. The entire length of the 22-mile trail follows along the river valley from Elroy to Reedsburg.

name: Pine Hill Park
description:
Pine Hill Park offers a unique 300 acre, 16 miles of single track trail system, offering some of the very best: trail running, mountain biking, hiking, walking, GPS-ing/Geocaching, and snowshoeing in central Vermont.<br />
Most of these trails are mainly used by mountain bikers, so please use caution.

name: Leslie Gulch
description: Excellent trails.

name: Hulls Gulch National Recreation Trail
description: The ascent from the Lower Trailhead around the hillside and then along the creek upstream for three miles to the Upper Trailhead is gentle but there is little shade, so it's a good idea to bring water and be prepared for desert conditions.

name: Bruneau-Jarbidge River Wilderness
description: The Bruneau - Jarbidge Rivers Wilderness is located on the high basalt plateaus of Owyhee County in southwestern Idaho in the western United States. The wilderness area is named after and protects much of the Bruneau and Jarbidge Rivers and their canyons. Whitewater rafting is a popular recreational activity in this wilderness area, which has rivers up to Class V. About 40 miles (64 km) of the Bruneau River and about 28.8 miles (46.3 km) of the Jarbidge River are classified as a wild river.

name: Killington Mtn
description:
Killington Mtn features 15 miles of hiking trails near Killington, VT during the off-season summer months. Once the snow melts Killington becomes a destination for hikers and mountain bikers instead of skiers and snowboarders. Enjoy the many converted trails that cover this entire resort, and take in the beautiful mountain top views from the Killington Peak. Don't forget that the Long Trail passes right by here!<br />
Beware of mountain bike traffic.

name: Warm Springs Reservoir
description: Excellent hiking.

name: CDT WY17: Sheridan Trail to Brooks Lake
description:
Section 17 of the CDT in Wyoming runs for 19.4 miles from the junction with the Sheridan Trail to Brooks Lake. Along the way, the trail passes Lava Mountain, Pelham Lake, Pilot Knob, US Hwy 26, and Brooks Lake Lodge. <br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=43.751471 lon=-110.005954

name: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller National Historical Park
description:
wenty miles of scenic carriage roads and trails crisscross the gentle forested slopes of Mount Tom, one of the oldest professionally managed woodlands in America. Walk under the cool canopy of centuries-old hemlocks, beech and open-growth sugar maples to visit the Pogue, a 14-acre pond perched near the mountain summit. Don't miss Mount Tom's South Peak, where you can enjoy a bird's-eye view of Woodstock.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Myre - Big Island State Park
description: Trails take you along a combination of wooded and open rolling hills. Albert Lea Lake can be seen from some areas along parts of the trail.

name: Quechee State Park
description:
Quechee State Park's location along US Route 4, and its proximity to many Upper-Valley attractions make the park a popular tourist destination. The focal point of the park is Vermont's deepest gorge, formed by glacial activity approximately 13,000 years ago. <br />
There are a few hiking trails that wind throughout this park and allow you to take in its natural beauty.

name: Wellington State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Rocky Arbor State Park
description: The park has a 1-mile, self-guided nature trail.

name: Gold Lake To Bobby Lake
description: Gold Lake To Bobby Lake features 13 miles of hiking trails near Oakridge, OR.

name: Sanilac Petroglyphs Historic State Park
description: The park contains a one mile hiking trail that crosses the Little Cass River in two places. The trail is open from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. year-round.

name: Beaver Creek Valley State Park
description: Excellent hiking park.

name: Mystery Cave State Park
description: A variety of experiences available.

name: Wild Goose State Trail
description: The level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. Walkers and bikers must stay on the main trail corridor and keep off the adjacent horse trail in Dodge County.

name: Legend Rock State Petroglyph Site
description: Great trails, ADA accessible.

name: Grand Teton National Park
description:
There are many outdoor recreation activities to choose from at Grand Teton National Park. During the summer you can hike, walk, view wildlife, take photographs, backpack, camp, climb, fish, swim, boat, float, canoe and bike. In winter skiing and snowshoeing are popular activities.<br />
Source: national Park Service

name: Hot Springs State Park
description: Hot Springs State Park sits along the Big Horn River and recieves 8,000 gallons of 135 degrees Fahrenheit water every 24 hours. This hot water is used for therapudic bathing in the free bath house here and other activities include fishing, hiking, horseback riding, canoeing, kayaking, swimming and mountain biking.

name: Appalachian Trail 140: VT 12 to VT 14 (White River)
description: The AT runs 12.6 miles from VT Hwy 12 to VT Hwy 14 (White River). Along the way it passes Dana Hill, Thistle Hill, the Thistle Hill shelter, and Joe Ranger Road.

name: Bomoseen State Park
description:
Welcome to Bomoseen State Park. The 3,576-acre park is located in the Taconic Mountains on the shores of Lake Bomoseen, the largest lake entirely within Vermont's borders. The Taconics are the slate-producing region of Vermont, and the area's history parallels the rise and fall of Vermont's slate industry. The park contains several quarry holes and their adjacent colorful slate rubble piles as reminders of this period.<br />
Several hiking trails, including one to Half Moon, provide great hiking and wildlife-viewing opportunities. Boating, fishing and swimming are popular in Lake Bomoseen and nearby Glen Lake.

name: Iron Bog Lake Trail
description: Iron Bog Lake Trail is a short 1.5 mile trail that winds up through a canyon covered in pine. The trail follows the side of the canyon until about 1/2 mile before the lake, where it levels out on a shelf.  There is ample wildlife along the trail, with possible sightings of elk and moose.

name: Umpqua Lighthouse State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Appalachian Trail 139: US 4 to VT 12
description: The AT runs 23.7 miles from US Hwy 4 to VT Hwy 12. Along the way it passes VT Hwy 100, Kent Pond, River Road, Quimby Mountain, the Stony Brook shelter, Stony Brook Road, Pinnacle, and the Winturri Shelter.

name: Hillsboro State Trail
description: The fairly level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. Each bicyclist age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Bay City Recreation Area
description: More than seven miles of trails help visitors explore the wetlands! Includes over three miles of paved accessible pathways, three observation towers, boardwalks, viewing platforms and shoreline spotting scopes. Bicycles and rollerblades are welcome.

name: Gifford Woods State Park
description:
With its location at the base of Killington and Pico peaks and close proximity to the Appalachian and Long trails, this park is a favorite of hikers. Many through-hikers pass the park on their Appalachian Trail journey from Georgia to Maine. The park is also a popular destination during the fall foliage season for its dramatic autumn colors.<br />
Day hikes are available and there is an easy hook up with the Appalachian Trail. There are more than 30 miles of maintained hiking trails on public land in the Coolidge Range area. Trails are identified with colored rectangular blazes.

name: Kohler-Andrae State Park
description: There are several opportunities for hiking on nature trails, dune cordwalks, or along the Lake Michigan shoreline at Kohler-Andrae.

name: Silver Lake State Park
description: Silver Lake State Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Mears, MI.

name: Sun Peak Trail
description: These trailheads provide access to the Big Wood River and Big Wood River Trail System, which links communities in the Wood River Valley. Also connects to the North Ketchum trail system and to backcountry trails on National Forest lands.

name: Midland City Forest
description: Midland City Forest features 9 miles of hiking trails near Midland, MI.

name: Evergreen Cemetary
description: Evergreen Cemetary features 2 miles of hiking trails near Portland, ME.

name: Eagle Island State Park
description: Great trails.

name: Alden Hill
description: Alden Hill features 3 miles of hiking trails near Gorham, ME.

name: Mackworth Island
description: The 100-acre Mackworth Island is a well preserved area that is connected to Falmouth by a causeway. The area offers hiking and fishing opportunities, as well as a chance for wildlife observation. The hiking trail is a 1.25-mile trail that encircles the island. It takes about an hour to complete.

name: Palisades State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Abanachee Loop
description: Abanachee Loop features 4 miles of hiking trails near Old Forge, NY.

name: Hart-Montague Trail State Park
description: The Hart-Montague Trail State Park is a paved, 22-mile trail passing through rural, forested lands. Scenic overlooks and picnic areas are located along the route. This is designated a wildlife viewing area.

name: Half Moon Pond State Park
description:
Nestled away in the forests of 3,500-acre Bomoseen State Park sits the quiet camping area comprising Half Moon Pond State Park. Set in the dense woods of a small, sheltered basin, the park surrounds Half Moon Pond. <br />
A perfect place for campers seeking a respite from the hustle and bustle of daily life, the park offers a vast trail system including a short walk or, for the more ambitious, a full-day's hike. Hikers are likely to see a variety of wildlife including white-tailed deer or an occasional moose.

name: Pine Haven
description: Pine Haven features 12 miles of hiking trails near Sanford, MI.

name: Wildcat Mountain State Park
description: The park has more than 20 miles of trails that can be hiked, a nature building and many scenic vistas.

name: Vincent Creek Recreation Site
description: This site offers five camp sites along the Smith River, at the mouth of Vincent Creek. Camp or picnic - good swimming holes under old growth trees. The old fire watch Guard Station still exists on this site.

name: Appalachian Trail 142: Connecticut River to Dartmouth Skiway
description:
The AT runs 18.1 miles from the Connecticut River (VT/NH state line) to the Dartmouth Skiway. Along the way it passes the city of Hanover, the Velvet Rocks shelter, Trescot Road, Etna Hanover Center Road, Three Mile Road, the Moose Mountain shelter, Goose Pond Road, Holt's Ledge, and the Trapper John shelter.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spots: <br />
"Trescot Road" lat=43.7053373485, lon=-72.2294787187<br />
"Etna Hanover Center Road" lat=43.7039300384, lon=-72.2120276176<br />
"Dartmouth Skiway" lat=43.7908000189, lon=-72.1012436665<br />
<br />
Note: if you are south bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in Vermont (or just click here).

name: Appalachian Trail: New Hampshire
description: The Appalachian Trail, which runs over 2,000 miles from Georgia to Maine, runs for 162 miles through New Hampshire from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3328/Vermont/Appalachian-Trail--Vermont.html">Vermont</a> Border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3283/Maine/Appalachian-Trail--Maine.html">Maine</a> Border. Along the way it passes through New Hampshire's majestic White Mountains. To find more detailed information about each section of the AT in NH, please click on the individual section listings below.

name: Adams Gulch Loop
description: Adams Gulch Loop features 7 miles of hiking trails near Ketchum, ID.

name: Blue Mounds State Park
description: Easy to moderate hiking trails. Main trail leads you over the top of the mounds through rich and varied prairie-dominated terrain. Trails give hikers a rare opportunity to experience Minnesota's ever-changing tallgrass prairie.

name: Rivertrail
description: Rivertrail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Portland, ME.

name: Whetstone Gulf State Park
description: Whetstone Gulf State Park features 0 miles of hiking trails near Lowville, NY.

name: Miller Trail
description: The Miller Trail, located within the Ed O. Taylor Wildlife Management Area, provides access to the Middle Fork Powder River. This challenging trail includes a steep descent which rewards hikers with the opportunity to fish in a beautiful primitive backcountry setting.

name: Outlaw Cave Trail
description: The Outlaw Cave Trail provides access to the Middle Fork Powder River from the Outlaw Cave Campground. The trail descends steeply into Middle Fork Canyon, dropping nearly 1,000 feet in elevation before intersecting the river just opposite the infamous Outlaw Cave.

name: Bolon Island Tideways State Scenic Corridor
description: This park is a quiet place with a hiking trail that extends half way around the island. The shoreline along the Umpqua River side of the park has been home to hundreds of Double Crested Cormorants since 1988.  The birds nest close together, each pair building a platform of sticks in the trees.  Such rookeries are usually too remote for easy viewing, which makes Bolon Island Day Use area so unique! The trail also provides a nice view of the Umpqua River.

name: Appalachian Trail 141: VT 14 to Connecticut River (NH/VT Line)
description:
The AT runs 9.3 miles from VT Hwy 14 to the Connecticut River (NH/VT state line). Along the way it passes I-89, Podunk Road, Griggs Mountain, the Happy Hill shelter, Elm Street, and I-91.<br />
Recommended parking spot: <br />
"Podunk Road" lat=43.7207676216, lon=-72.4132487788<br />
Note: if you are north bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in New Hampshire (or just click here).

name: Rivertrance
description: Rivertrance features 6 miles of hiking trails near Portland, ME.

name: Kilen Woods State Park
description: Moderate trails that take you along a hilly terrain. Trails are best in the spring when prairie and woodland flowers are in bloom. Trails go through prairie, oak savanna and floodplain forest.

name: Jewel Cave National Monument
description:
There are two self-guided trails at Jewel Cave National Monument, and one U. S. Forest Service trail which begins approximately 1 mile from the Jewel Cave visitor center. Printed information on all three trails is available at the visitor center year-round, and at the historic ranger cabin in the summer. The trails are diverse: from a å_ mile (.4 km) to over 5.5 miles (8.9 km), from level to steep and rugged, and everything in between. There is bound to be at least one trail just right for you.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Eagle Island State Historic Site
description: Hiking trails available.

name: Salmon Creek Trail
description: Salmon Creek Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Oakridge, OR.

name: Custer State Park
description: Custer State Park is a 71,000-acre park with specacular terrain and an abundance of wildlife. There is a herd of 1,300 bison roaming freely throughout the park and there is also hiking, mountain biking, fishing and camping for visitors to enjoy!

name: Greenbush
description: Greenbush features 9 miles of hiking trails near Plymouth, WI.

name: Jenny Lake Trail
description: The Jenny Lake trail follows the outline of Jenny lake for the entire circumference. The first two miles are shared with Cascade Canyon Trail, and it breaks off as Cascade Canyon Trail turns up the canyon to Hidden Falls.  Jenny Lake trail continues around the remainder of the lake, including crossing the River between Jenny Lake and String Lake with a branch trail proceeding to String Lake.

name: CDT WY18: Brooks Lake to North Buffalo Fork River
description: Section 18 of the CDT in GA runs for 23.3 miles from Brooks Lake to North Buffalo Fork River. Along the way, the trail passes Upper Brooks Lake, and Smokehouse Mountain.

name: Cascade Canyon Trail
description: This is popular trail within Grand Teton National Park.  The trail follows the south side of the lake for several miles, then turns up canyon to the 200 ft Hidden Falls. Proceeding past Hidden falls can leads to inspiration point, which offers views of the lake.  There is an optional boat shuttle service that bypasses the trail along the lake and drops passengers about 0.5 miles from the base of Hidden Falls.

name: Hard Guy
description: Hard Guy features 12 miles of hiking trails near Boise, ID.

name: North Fork (lower Sect.)
description: North Fork (lower Sect.) features 6 miles of hiking trails near Westfir, OR.

name: Alpine Trail
description: Alpine Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Oakridge, OR.

name: Flat Creek
description: Flat Creek features 2 miles of hiking trails near Oakridge, OR.

name: East Side Trail
description: East Side Trail features 16 miles of hiking trails near Boise, ID.

name: Waldo Lake
description: Waldo Lake features 22 miles of hiking trails near Oakridge, OR.

name: Southwick Beach State Park
description: Great trail system.

name: Notch Trail
description: Moderate to strenuous. After meandering through a canyon, this trail climbs a log ladder and follows a ledge to "the Notch" for a dramatic view of the White River Valley. Trail begins at the south end of the Door and Window parking area. Watch for drop-offs. Not recommended for anyone with a fear of heights. Treacherous during or after heavy rains.

name: Door Trail
description: Easy. An accessible å_ mile boardwalk leads through a break in the Badlands Wall known as "the Door" and to a view of the Badlands. From there, the maintained trail ends. Travel beyond this point is at your own risk. Watch for drop-offs.

name: Window Trail
description: Easy. This short trail leads to a natural window in the Badlands Wall with a view of an intricately eroded canyon.

name: Dorena Lake
description: Interpretive trails.

name: Reid State Park
description: Beachcombing and hiking trails provide excellent hikes.

name: Mears State Park
description: Mears State Park is a 50-acre village park. Fishing, swimming, hiking and snowmobiling are fun activities at this sandy park. The Mears modern campground is on the park and it has 175 campsites with electrical hookups and modern restrooms.

name: Rick's Basin/quakie Ridge
description: Rick's Basin/quakie Ridge features 6 miles of hiking trails near Alta, Wy, WY.

name: Appalachian Trail 143: Dartmouth Skiway to NH 25A
description: The AT runs 16 miles from the Dartmouth Skiway to NH Hwy 25A. Along the way the trail passes Dorchester Road (Smarts Mtn Trailhead), Mousley Mountain, Fire Warden's Cabin, Smarts Mountain, the Hexacuba shelter, and Mount Cube.

name: Sturgeon Bay & Lake Michigan Ship Canal
description: Hiking trails throughout the area.

name: Menominee River State Recreation Area
description: Hiking opportunities are available on the Pemene Falls hiking trail found in the southern portion of the property. It is the only maintained hiking trail.

name: Lowell Preserve Multi-use Trail System
description: Libby Hill Loop/ Lowell Preserve features 4 miles of hiking trails near Windham , ME.

name: Packsaddle Lake
description: Packsaddle Lake features 5 miles of hiking trails near Tetonia, ID.

name: Sharps Creek
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Thetford Hill State Park
description: Thetford Hill State Park is located in the southern part of the Thetford State Forrest. Trail running is the most popular activity due to the world-class Woods Hill Trail which is 5km in length. Hiking and cross-country skiing are also available for visitors.

name: Oregon Badlands Wilderness
description: At 29,000 acres, the Oregon Badlands Wilderness is a vast expanse of lava outcrops and weathered western junipers. Five trailheads offer access to fifty miles of trails crossing the wilderness and are open to hiking and horse back riding. The Oregon Badlands Wilderness is open year-round, but is mostly accessed in the Fall, Winter and Spring.

name: Pigeon Bridge State Forest Campground
description: State Forest Pathways: Shingle Mill (on site): 14 miles consisting of 5 loops ranging from 3/4 - 11 miles in length. Glat to hilly terrain. High Country (on site): Over 80 miles of flat to very hilly terrain connecting 8 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic Pigeon River Country.

name: Greely Woods
description: Greely Woods features 8 miles of hiking trails near Cumberland, ME.

name: Bluff Trails
description:
There is a spider-web network of trails stretching across the bluffs of La Crosse, and it would be hard to write an accurate description of all of them. I can say that there are some gorgeous cliffs and incredible views to be had from these trails that you might not expect to find! <br />
<br />
It's probably easiest to access this trail network from the TNT trail.

name: La Crosse Ridge Loop
description: La Crosse Ridge Loop features 3 miles of hiking trails near La Crosse, WI.

name: Ob-1 / Pud-n / Dark Side
description: Ob-1 / Pud-n / Dark Side features 2 miles of hiking trails near La Crosse, WI.

name: Skeeter / Abyss / French Connection / Bob Trail
description: Skeeter / Abyss / French Connection / Bob Trail features 2 miles of hiking trails near La Crosse, WI.

name: Lost Loop / Still Hill / Imberm
description: Lost Loop / Still Hill / Imberm features 2 miles of hiking trails near La Crosse, WI.

name: Human Powered Trails (hpt)
description: Human Powered Trails (hpt) features 9 miles of hiking trails near La Crosse, WI.

name: Elroy-Sparta State Trail
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers.

name: Tnt Trail
description: This a steep climb from the valley straight up the ridge until it crests the top. This trail can be used to access other trails on the bluffs as well.

name: Wolfes Neck Woods State Park
description: The popular Casco Bay Trail carries visitors along Maine's legendary coast to a point where the surrounding islands of Eagle, Counsin and others are described on an interpretive panel.

name: Gardner Mountain Foot and Horse Trail
description: This seven mile long trail is open to hikers and horseback riders. The route ambles through a mountain meadow and then follows a ridgeline overlooking the Gardner Mountain Wilderness Study Area. Please respect private property boundary signs.

name: Bass Lake State Forest Campground (Marquette)
description: Anderson Lake (8 miles SE): 6  miles of rolling terrain with access from Anderson Lake State Forest Campground. Hiking, mountain biking, cross-country skiing.

name: Bass Lake State Forest Campground
description: Canada Lake (19 miles SE): 14 miles of gently rolling terrain at Natalie State Forest Campground. Hike, mountain bike, groomed for cross-country skiing.

name: White Lake State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Sylvan Lakeshore Trail
description: This short trail is an easy trail that encircles beautiful Sylvan lake. On the north side of the trail are rocky stairs and  tunnel through the rock formations that form that forms the lake.

name: Little Devils Trail (Trail #4)
description:
This trail climbs up from the Sylvan Lake Trailhead and intersects the Norbeck Trail which can be used as a loop trail with the Harney Peak trail. Halfway to the Norbeck Trial is a spur trail that takes you up to the top of Little Devils Tower offering fantastic views. <br />
Trail offers great wildlife viewing and offers an up close look at the Cathedral Spires.

name: Hystery
description: Hystery features 4 miles of hiking trails near Eugene/lowell, OR.

name: Mallo Trail
description: The Mallo Trail trailhead is located at a small parking area approximately one mile east of Mallo Camp on Beaver Creek Road. Parking at the trailhead is limited. Organized groups advertising events on the trail must contact the Newcastle Field Office to obtain a special recreation permit for activities occurring on BLM administered lands.

name: Great River State Trail
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. A state trail pass is required for bikers 16 years of age and older.

name: Lookout Point Lake
description: 22 miles southeast of Eugene, Lookout Point Lake is a popular recreation area offering year-round fishing, seasonal water skiing, sailing, swimming, picnicking and hunting. The area is also managed for wildlife habitat such as waterfowl, blacktail deer, upland game birds, wintering elk, bald eagles, osprey and many other species. Lookout Point Dam an earth-and-gravel-fill dam with a concrete gated spillway. The dam was completed in 1954 and provides flood control and has three generators, which produce 40,000 kilowatts.

name: Mount Rushmore National Monument
description:
Mount Rushmore National Memorial is visited by nearly three million people each year that come to marvel at the majestic beauty of the Black Hills of South Dakota and learn about the birth, growth, development and preservation of the country. From the history of the first inhabitants to the diversity of America today, Mount Rushmore brings visitors face to face with the rich heritage we all share. <br />
The park offers short trails with many steps allowing a variety of views of Mount Rushmore.<br />
<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Presidential
description: This is a .5 mile trail around Mount Rushmore. There are a lot of stairs and it's pretty strenuous. You'll find several informational plaques along the way with history and quotes from the presidents.

name: Split Rock Creek State Park
description: Trail begins at the campgrounds.

name: Westcott Beach State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Appalachian Trail 144: NH 25A to NH 25 (Glencliff, NH)
description: The AT runs 9.7 miles from NH Hwy 25A to NH Hwy 25 (Glencliff, NH). Along the way the trail passes the Ore Hill shelter, Ore Hill, NH Hwy 25C, Mount Mist, Webster Slide Mountain, and Wachipauka Pond.

name: Bradbury Mountain State Park
description: Bradbury Mt State Park features 18 miles of hiking trails near Pownal, ME.

name: Branbury State Park
description:
Branbury is located on the eastern shore of Lake Dunmore at the base of Mt. Moosalamoo. The Green Mountain National Forest is its neighbor to the east. Historically, the 69-acre park operated as a farm at the turn of the century, then a guest house, summer boy's camp and private beach and picnic area. In 1945, it became Branbury (Brandon-Salisbury) State Park.<br />
Hiking trails to scenic vistas, waterfalls, caves, mountain lakes and streams, as well as an interpretive nature trail, provide outstanding hiking opportunities.

name: Mud Lake State Forest Campground
description: Mud Lake State Forest Campground has eight tent and small trailer sites with vault toilets and potable water from a well pump. The campground is on Mud Lake, which provides scenic views, excellent fishing and relaxing boating. The park also has beautiful hiking trails that line Big Mud Lake to Pike Lake. ATV use and wildlife observation are also common activities here.

name: Leverentz Lake State Forest Campground
description:
Sheep Ranch (on site): 4.5 miles of rolling terrain.
Pine Forest (1/2 miles West): .8 miles of flat terrain

name: Weber Lake State Forest Campground
description: Lost Tamarack (on site): 4.75 miles, 2 loops. Hike and camp.

name: Dexter Lake
description: 22 miles southeast of Eugene, Dexter Lake is a popular recreation area offering year-round fishing, seasonal water skiing, sailing, swimming, picnicking and hunting. The area is also managed for wildlife habitat such as waterfowl, blacktail deer, upland game birds, wintering elk, bald eagles, osprey and many other species. Dexter Dam was completed in 1954 and provides flood control and has one generator, which produces 15,000 kilowatts

name: CDT WY19: North Buffalo Fork River to Yellowstone National Park Boundary
description:
Section 19 of the CDT in Wyoming runs for 23.3 miles from North Buffalo Fork River to the Yellowstone National Park Boundary. Along the way, the trail passes through the Teton Wilderness and the Grand Teton Mountains. It also passes the Two Ocean Plateau South and the Upper Snake River.<br />
<br />
Recommended Parking Spot: lat=43.754825 lon=-110.010253

name: La Crosse River State Trail
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers.

name: Mascoutin Valley State Trail
description: The entire trail is open to walking and bicycling. The trail base of limestone, grass and gravel makes the tread more suitable for off-road bikes. Wildlife viewing opportunities are available in the Eldorado Marsh Wildlife Area in Fond du Lac County and the Rush Lake Marsh area in Winnebago County.

name: North Shore Trail
description: North Shore Trail features 14 miles of hiking trails near Lowell, OR.

name: Dexter State Recreation Site
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Elijiah Bristow State Park
description: Elijiah Bristow State Park features 13 miles of hiking trails near Eugene, OR.

name: Big Lost River Trail
description: This loop trail system includes a 3/4-mile trail designed for maximum accessibility (grade and slope) from the trailhead down to the Big Lost River.  For those wanting a more arduous hike and a spectacular view of Mt. Caleb, a side trail, also 3/4-mile hike, provides the second half of the loop.

name: Elijah Bristow State Park
description: Elijah Bristow has more than 10 miles of trail for hikers, mountain bikers and equestrians. Part of the trail system includes a portion of the Eugene to Pacific Crest trail.

name: Buckhorn State Park
description: Four miles of trail start from the south picnic area. The trails course through wetlands, oak woods, jack pine thickets, shoreline and a small prairie.

name: Fall Creek Lake
description: Fall Creek Lake is a 1,852 acre lake and is encompassed by 22 miles of forested shoeline. This area is protected by the Army Corps of Engineers and recreational opportunities here include hiking, boating, canoeing, kayaking and fishing.

name: Great River Bluffs State Park
description: Easy trails with scenic overlooks of Mississippi River Valley. Particularly nice in fall.

name: Mill Bluff State Park
description: There are more than two miles of hiking trails at Mill Bluff offering views of the park's mesas, buttes and pinnacles. Stairs lead to the top of Mill Bluff. Pets are permitted on the hiking trails and in campsites when on an 8-foot leash. Pets are not permitted on the nature trail or in the picnic and swimming areas.

name: Whittaker Creek
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Sleeper State Park
description: More than four miles of maintained trails are available to those who wish to hike. These trails pass through a variety of habitats and are directly accessible from the campground. Vault toilets are available along the routes.

name: Jordan Craters
description: Coffee Pot Crater, the only feature to which there is vehicle access, covers about two-thirds of a square mile and is a well-preserved, steep-sided crater. One of the most interesting features in the vicinity of Coffee Pot is a sequence of roughly aligned spatter cones. They consist of blocks of lava, probably ejected in a semi-molten state, that have welded together, forming cones. The interiors of the cones have a glassy "furnace lining" look because they were vents for hot gasses.

name: Darlingtonia State Natural Site
description: Walking trail with interpretive signs.

name: Sebago Lake State Park
description: Whether hiking on marked trails or bicycling on park roads, visitors find many way to enjoy the park.

name: Appalachian Trail 145: NH 25 to NH 112 (Kinsman Notch)
description: The AT runs 9.5 miles from NH Hwy 25 to NH Hwy 112 (Kinsman Notch). Along the way it passes the Jeffers Brook shelter, Jeffers Brook Road, Sanitarium Road, Mount Moosilauke, Mount Blue, and the Beaver Brook shelter.

name: Jasper State Recreation Site
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Lake Herman State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Dodge Point Public Reserved Land
description: This well-managed forest bears the destinction of being named the State Of Maine's 1978 Tree Farm of the Year. Take the interpretive trail that starts at the Old Farm Road and make sure you explore the Shore Trail for the best views!

name: Ridgeline Trail
description: Ridgeline Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Eugene, OR.

name: Port Crescent State Park
description: Several trails totalling seven miles meander through various areas of the park.

name: Roche-A-Cri State Park
description: The park has more than five miles of trails that can be hiked. The stairway to the top of the 300-foot Roche-A-Cri mound is one of the highlights of the park and offers spectacular views. The stairway is open from 6 a.m. to sunset.

name: Perrot State Park
description: The park has 12.5 miles of hiking trails. Many of the trails take you up to the top of the bluffs and give you a unique opportunity to enjoy scenic views of the Mississippi River valley.

name: Gooseberry Badlands Scenic Overlook Trail
description: At a turnoff on Wyoming State Highway 431, the visitor is greeted by a panoramic view of colorful desert and endless blue sky at the Gooseberry Badlands Scenic Overlook. The colors of the soil, which mysteriously change with the seasons, accentuate the grotesque and intricately carved rock formations, inviting further exploration along a 1.5 mile interpretive trail. Hikers should bring drinking water. There is no overnight camping. The area is 25 miles west of Worland.

name: Lone Tree Trail
description: This challenging 3/4-mile trail leads to the magnificent Paint Rock Canyon and is a steep and rocky journey to Paint Rock Creek where it meets the Paint Rock Canyon Trail. The route to the Lone Tree Trail is marked by a sign on the Cold Springs Road, about 6 miles beyond the Paint Rock Canyon trailhead. Horses or mountain bikes are not recommended on the Lone Tree Trail.

name: Duck Swamp Environmental Education Area
description: This 81-acre oxbow lake and marsh is a cut-off meander of the Bighorn River. Visitors can hike a 1 mile interpretive and educational loop overlooking the wetland to view and learn about its many residents: song birds, great blue herons, hawks, owls, dabbling ducks, kingfishers, muskrats, mink, beaver and others. The area is about 3 miles north of Worland on Wyoming State Highway 433. Drinking water, restrooms, car and bus parking, barbecue, and covered picnic tables are available for day-use.

name: Deschutes River
description: Deschutes River features 14 miles of hiking trails near Bend, OR.

name: Elkhorn Loop
description: Elkhorn Loop features 12 miles of hiking trails near Idaho City, ID.

name: Tamarack Resort
description: Tamarack Resort features 60 miles of hiking trails near Cascade, ID.

name: Echo Lake State Park
description: Excellent trail around the lake, plus many others to explore.

name: Sunrise Lake State Forest Campground
description: Sunrise Lake State Forest Campground features 9 miles of hiking trails near Cadillac, MI.

name: Whaleback Shell Midden
description: The site includes a scenic walking trail maintained by the Damariscotta River Association. It includes an old orchard, bird watching, and the remains of the shell middens.

name: Swans Falls Campground
description: The area is popular with hikers.

name: Ludington State Park
description: Ludington State Park is a 5,300-acre area with an excellent variety of recreational activity choices. The park has four trails for hiking and mountain biking; lakes, ponds and marshland for fishing, canoeing and swimming; and a picnic area.  There is also a playground on the property for children. The park's four camping areas are available for an overnight stay.

name: Range Ponds State Park
description: Leisurely walks are a must on the two-miles of easy trails comprised of old logging roads and railroad beds.

name: Appalachian Trail 146: NH 112 to US 3 (Franconia Notch)
description: The AT runs 16.3 miles from NH Hwy 112 to US Hwy 3 (Franconia Notch) (I-93). Along the way the trail passes Mount Wolf, the Eliza Brook shelter, Kinsman Mountain South Peak, the Kinsman Pond shelter, Lonesome Lake, and the Lonesome Lake hut.

name: Holzinger Lodge
description: Holzinger Lodge features 9 miles of hiking trails near Winona, MN.

name: Phil's Trail Loop
description: Phil's Trail Loop features 9 miles of hiking trails near Bend, OR.

name: Fourth Of July Lake / Ants Basin / Robinson Bar
description: Fourth Of July Lake / Ants Basin / Robinson Bar features 26 miles of hiking trails near Stanley, ID.

name: Allis State Park
description:
Allis State Park is located on the summit of Bear Hill which provides sweeping views of central Vermont from a lookout tower once used to spot forest fires. On a clear day, Killington, Pico, and Mt Ascutney peaks are visible to the south; Camel's Hump and Mt. Mansfield to the north; Abraham, Lincoln, and Ellen to the west; the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the east.<br />
A nature trail with a guide is available at the park.

name: West Eugene Wetlands
description:
On the western edge of Eugene, visitors can view wildlife and restored wetlands while they walk trails or ride the Fern Ridge Bicycle path through the West Eugene Wetlands.
The West Eugene Wetland Project Office is located on a small hill overlooking 12 acres of restored wetlands. This house was converted into an office for BLM's wetland project staff and partners.
Tsanchiifin Walk - The 0.5 mile Tsanchiifin Walk trail is named after the local band of Kalapuya Indians that lived in this area. From the west side of Danebo Avenue the trail branches off to the north from the Fern Ridge Bike Path.
Stewart Pond/Bertelsen Nature Park Stewart Pond - a seasonal emergent wetland, is home to many species of water birds. Geese and ducks are numerous during the wet season.
Meadowlark Prairie -The Meadowlark Prairie overlook is located on Greenhill Road, between West 11th Avenue and Royal Avenue. This site has several picnic tables that are covered by a shelter, as well as bathrooms and interpretive signs.

name: Clay Creek
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Tyrrell Forest Succession Trail
description: The Forest Succession Trail at the Travis Tyrrell Seed Orchard is a .75 mile long self-guided interpretive trail that provides visitors with an opportunity to pass through the various stages of forest development, ranging from a recently planted reforestation stand to an old growth grove. The seed orchard is usually open Monday - Friday (8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.). We recommend that visitors call ahead.

name: Row River Trail
description: Bicyclists, hikers, and equestrians may enjoy the numerous lakeside vistas and historic covered bridges along the Row River Trail. This 17-mile long rails-to-trails route begins in downtown Cottage Grove and ends in Culp Creek, a few miles to the north of the Sharps Creek Recreation Site. The trail is also part of the recently designated Covered Bridges State Scenic Bikeway.

name: Whitewater State Park
description: Whitewater State Park is a 2,700-acre area of fishing, swimming, hiking, camping and skiing fun. Scenic bluffs, excellent trout fishing, interpretive programs and beautiful spring flowers are a few of this park's attractions. The park has three hiking trails that make up 15 miles in length-- one is a wheelchair accessible trail, another is a self-guided trail and finally a 10 mile hiking trail that is a combination of easy, moderate and challenging.

name: Pilot Butte State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Three trails.

name: Horse Ridge Recreation Area
description: Excellent trails.

name: Dry River Canyon Trail
description: The primitive and un-maintained Dry River Canyon trail follows the canyon bottom. At approximately 2.3 miles, the trail disappears into a large rockfall. For most people, this is a good turn-around point. Only experienced hikers who are comfortable rock-hopping should continue beyond this point. The trail resumes after about 50 yards and continues for another 0.75 miles to the head of the canyon where it emerges at State highway 20 opposite Evans Well Road. Please respect adjacent private property by staying on the trail. The total length of the trail is 3.2 miles.

name: Mt. Apetite
description: Mt. Apetite features 10 miles of hiking trails near Auburn, ME.

name: LaPine State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Rice Lake State Park
description: Easy walking trail.
