name: Cape Mountain Trail System
description: Cape Mountain Trail System features 10 miles of hiking trails near Florence, OR.

name: Franconia Notch State Park
description: The Appalachian Trail offers hikers excellent opportunities.

name: Lake Shetek State Park
description:
Lake Shetek State Park is home to the largest lake in southwestern Minnesota, because of this reason fishing is a very popular activity at this park. Visitors also enjoy swimming, picnicking, boating, camping and cycling.

Hiking and cycling are popular on the park's six mile loop trail.

name: Shotgun Creek
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Yellowstone National Park
description:
Yellowstone National Park, encompassing 2.2 million acres, is one of America's premier wilderness areas. Most of the park is backcountry and managed as wilderness. Over 1,100 miles (1770 km) of trails are available for hiking. However, there are dangers inherent in wilderness: unpredictable wildlife, changing weather conditions, remote thermal areas, cold water lakes, turbulent streams, and rugged mountains with loose, "rotten" rock. Visiting wilderness means experiencing the land on its terms. If you choose to explore and enjoy the natural wonders of Yellowstone, there is no guarantee of your safety. Be prepared for any situation.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 147: US 3 to US 302 (Crawford Notch)
description:
The AT runs 27.7 miles from US Hwy 3 (I-93) to US Hwy 302 (Crawford Notch). Along the way the trail passes Mount Liberty, Mount Lincoln, Mount Lafayette, the Greenleaf Hut, Mount Garfield, the Garfield Ridge shelter, the Galehead Hut, South Twin Mountain, Mount Guyot, the Guyot shelter, Mount Bond, Mount Zealand, the Zealand Falls Hut, Whitewall Mountain, Ethan Pond, and the Ethan Pond shelter.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spots:<br />
"US 302" lat=44.1708076981, lon=-71.3880872166<br />
"Ethan Pond Trailhead" lat=44.1670946065, lon=-71.3859957887

name: Carley State Park
description: The trail criss-crosses the north branch of the Whitewater River numerous times. Excellent spring wildflower viewing along trails.

name: Tumalo State Park
description: Take a hike and explore one of the river trails as they gently wind through canyons created by the untamed river.

name: Prineville Reservoir State Park
description: Great hiking trail.

name: Cougar
description:
With the beauty of the McKenzie River and a good reputation for trout fishing and several boat launches, this scenic 1,280 acre lake offers many recreational opportunities. There are visitor viewpoints at both sides of the Cougar Dam that offer spectacular views of the valley downstream and the vistas upstream around the lake.

There are a few trails that exist within this recreation area. Check out the Downstream Area for a trail-head to a cool path that will lead to beautiful forests and amazing views. There's also a picnic area at the Echo Day Use Area for a post-hike snack.

name: Lincoln Bridge State Forest Campground
description: Lincoln Bridge State Forest Campground is a camping area with opportunities to fish, hike, mountain bike, canoe, observe wildlife and ride your ATV. The campground has nine tent sites on the Pine River. There are vault toilets and potable water. The Silver Creek Pathway is a four mile trail for biking and hiking.

name: Heceta Head Lighthouse State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Heceta Head trail is part of a 7-mile network. Trails of varying difficulty feature beach and wildlife viewing areas. Wildlife refuge islands feature a view of puffins, cormorants, gulls, and other bird nesting areas. Sea lions and whales can be seen from the beach and cliff-top lighthouse.

name: Miss River - Pool 1
description:
Located within the Upper Mississippi River Valley between Minneapolis and St. Paul. This pool is within the Mississippi National River and Recreation Area corridor. There is an observation platform for visitors to watch lock operations and see towboats and barges up close.

Trails extend out around this area into different recreation areas. These trails are perfect for viewing the Mississippi River as well as plenty of wildlife. Hike along the wooded bluffs and see if you can catch a bald eagle soaring overhead.

name: House Lake State Forest Campground
description: The House Lake State Forest Campground has 41 campsites, 35 of them accommodate a 40-foot vehicle/trailer. The campground is located on House Lake, so fishing and boating opportunities are very convenient. Hiking and mountain biking are popular on the 2.7 mile Trout Lake Pathway. Vault Toilets and drinkable water from a hand pump are located at the campground.

name: Minneopa State Park
description: The word Minneopa comes from the Dakota language and is interpreted to mean "water falling twice," referring to the beautiful waterfalls of the Minneopa Creek. Walk the trail which encircles the falls, leading down a limestone stairway to the valley below. Ascend the opposite side and enjoy a panoramic view of the valley which reveals the underlying geology of this area. Visit Seppmann Mill, a wind driven grist mill fashioned in German style from native stone and lumber, or hike through oak savanna and native prairie grasslands overlooking the scenic Minnesota River Valley.

name: Plum Line
description: Plum Line features 4 miles of trail near Warren, VT. This trail skirts near Mad River, and takes you up a quick ascent up the mountain. Get ready to do some serious climbing, but the views will be worth it!

name: Carl G. Washburne Memorial State Park
description: There are several trails of varying difficulty leading from the campsites to the beach, wildlife viewing areas, and second-growth forests.

name: Merrick State Park
description: There are two miles of hiking trails at the park. The trails meander along the length of the park and offer hikers a variety of river views and access to the park's secluded areas.

name: Fischer Creek State Recreation Area
description: Fischer Creek State Recreation Area has about one mile of Lake Michigan shoreline, scenic wooded bluffs, grasslands and wetlands. It's a place for hiking, picnicking, wildlife viewing and relaxing on the beach (there are no life guards). Much of the Lake Michigan shoreline consists of scenic bluffs that rise up to 40 feet above the water level. The area also includes more than 600 feet of river frontage on Fischer Creek.

name: Alderwood State Wayside
description: Excellent hiking.

name: CDT WY20: Yellowstone National Park Boundary to Lewis Lake and South Entrance Road
description:
The CDT runs for 27.1 miles from the Yellowstone National Park Boundary to Lewis Lake and South Entrance Road. Along the way, the trail passes Big Game Ridge South, Barlow Peak, Mount Hancock, Big Game Ridge North, Overlook Mountain, Channel Mountain, Mount Sheridan, Heart Lake, and Factory Hill.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=44.317325 lon=-110.598279

name: High Cliff State Park
description: High Cliff hiking trails offer different levels of challenge to hikers. All trails are looped and vary in length. Hikers should stay on marked trails and behind barricades and barriers where they are provided. From the vantage point of the cliff, and especially from the 40-foot observation tower, you can see the cities of Appleton, Oshkosh, Neenah, Menasha and Kaukauna.

name: Busternut
description:
This 2 mile loop trail is a scenic walk through the woods that leads over stone bridges. Located near Waitsfield, it has easy access and is perfect for an afternoon walk or a short hike. <br />
The trail twists and turns a lot, keeping you on your feet, but beware of the mountain bike traffic.

name: Appalachian Trail 148: US 302 to NH 16 (Pinkham Notch)
description: The AT runs 26 miles from US Hwy 302 (Crawford Notch) to NH Hwy 16 (Pinkham Notch) through the beautiful White Mountains of New Hampshire. Along the way, the trail passes Mount Webster, Mount Jackson, the Mizpah Spring Hut, Mount Pierce, Mount Eisenhower, Mount Franklin, Mount Monroe, the Lake of the Clouds Hut, Mount Washington, Mount Clay, Mount Jefferson, Mount Adams, the Madison Spring Hut, and Mount Madison.

name: John A. Latsch State Park
description: John A. Latsch State Park is an excellent fishing and hiking location among buffs with scenic views. Snowshoeing is available in the winter. A .5 mile hike takes you to the top of Charity Bluff.

name: Crawford Notch State Park
description:
Two short, easy walks begin across the road and bridge from the Willey House site. The Pond Loop Trail, å_ mile round trip, bears to the left just beyond the bridge, leads through the woods to a
viewpoint of the pond, and loops back to the bridge. The Sam Willey Trail, one mile round-trip, bears to the right 30 yards beyond the bridge, follows the Saco River through the woods past several beaver
dams, and loops back to the bridge.

name: Button Bay State Park
description:
Button Bay, a 253-acre park, is located on a bluff in Ferrisburgh along the 130-mile long Lake Champlain.<br />
You can explore Button Point Natural Area, a small mature hardwood forest, hike the trail, and visit the Nature Center.

name: Wiouwash State Trail
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. Bikers do not need a trail pass while using the trail. Due to the possibility of hoof marks in the trail surface, wider-tire bicycles are recommended.

name: Big M
description: Big M features 20 miles of hiking trails near Manistee, MI.

name: Irish Hill
description:
Irish Hill features 6 miles of hiking trails near Berlin, VT. <br />
The Irish Hill ridgeline is a series of peaks which rise behind Berlin Pond and provide a watershed for pure water for our communities. It is still an undeveloped area which offers recreational opportunities, wildlife habitat, forest woodlands and watershed integrity. The views from the ridgeline are absolutely stunning and make the whole hike worth it.

name: Roughlock Falls Nature Area
description: The Roughlock Falls Nature Area is located in Spearfish Canyon and is one of the most beautiful locations in the Black Hills. Here there is fishing, hiking and snowmobiling available for visitors.

name: Point Beach State Forest
description: There are 17 miles of hiking trails in the forest ranging from a half mile, to more than seven miles long. There are also six miles of Lake Michigan shoreline to explore.

name: Friendship State Trail
description: The level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers.

name: Sakatah Lake State Park
description: Hiking trails are moderate to challenging. The State Trail provides a level walking surface.

name: Seyon Lodge State Park
description:
One of Vermont's best kept secrets, Seyon Lodge State Park provides rustic and welcoming facilities in the midst of the inspiring beauty of Groton State Forest. Situated on the pristine shores of Noyes Pond, the secluded setting allows guests to enjoy some of the most beautiful and undisturbed natural scenery in Vermont. <br />
Wildlife abounds and hiking and cross-country ski trails provide easy access to the solitude of the surrounding forests.

name: Waterbury Center State Park
description:
Waterbury Center State Park sits on the eastern side of the Waterbury Reservoir. This reservoir is the ninth largest body of water in VT and is a hotbed for fishing year round.<br />
The park is located on a 90-acre peninsula with 22 picnic sites, tables, hibachis, a swimming beach, a nature trail, a trailer boat ramp, boat rentals, a concession area, and restrooms.<br />
The nature trail is about .5 miles long and takes 30 minutes at a leisurely pace. This trail highlights the natural history, geology, and cultural history of the area.

name: William Mitchell State Park
description: William Mitchell State Park is a 334-acre area in Cadillac, MI. It is a very popular camping area for its great location between Lake Mitchell and Lake Cadillac. Fishing, swimming, boating, hiking and canoeing are all popular here, as well as cross country skiing and snowmobiling in the winter. The park's amenities include modern restrooms, a boat launch, a playground, a visitor center, electric service and a picnic shelter.

name: Long Lake (Missaukee) State Forest Campground
description: Long Lake (Missaukee) State Forest Campground in Mitchell State Park is a fishing, mountain biking, hiking, ATV and canoeing destination. The campground is on scenic Long Lake with 12 tent and small trailer sites. The campground offers vault toilets and potable water.

name: Kingsland Bay State Park
description:
Kingsland Bay State Park sits on the picturesque shores of Lake Champlain. Visitors can enjoy the picnic areas and historic buildings of the park, or rent a canoe/kayak for an easy paddle around this protected bay. Much of the 264 acres, along the shores of Lake Champlain, remains as a natural area. <br />
There are about 5 scenic trails along the shoreline of Lake Champlain, which give hikers stunning views of the lake. These trails are fairly short, less than a mile for each of them.

name: Ricker Pond State Park
description: icker Pond State Park, established in the 1930's, is located on the western shores of Ricker Pond and adjacent to the Montpelier-Wells Rail Trail (Cross Vermont Trail). The park is part of the Groton State Forest, and has access to over 17 miles of hiking trails and over 20 miles of gravel roads and multi-use trails suitable for mountain biking and horseback riding.

name: Medicine Lodge Archaeological Site
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Fred Meijer White Pine Trail State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Old US-131 State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail is (1 mile west) of this campground. There is a spur trail connecting the Campground to the NCT: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Goose Lake State Forest Campground
description: Cadillac (9 miles South): 11.3 miles of flat terrain. Hike, mountain bike, and cross-country ski.

name: Camden Hills State Park
description: 20 trails offer miles of hiking options.

name: Appalachian Trail 149: NH 16 to US 2
description: The Appalachian Trail runs 21.1 miles from NH Hwy 16 (Pinkham Notch) to US Hwy 2. Along the way, the trail passes Wildcat "D," Wildcat Mountain, the Carter Notch Hut, Carter Dome, Mount Hight, South Carter Mountain, Middle Carter Mountain, North Carter Mountain, the Imp Campsite shelter, Mount Moriah, Middle Moriah Mountain, and the Rattle River shelter.

name: Tawas Point State Park
description: Located on the end of the point is the Sandy Hook Hiking Trail. The trail offers two-miles of guided hiking with interpretive stops along the way. The trail is designated for hiking only, bicycles and pets are prohibited.

name: Tippy Dam Recreation Area
description: The North Country Trail is located 1.5 miles north of the campground. This national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes more than 1,500 miles in Michigan.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: F: Hwy 242 to Hwy 35
description:
Section F of the PCT in Oregon runs 112.5 miles from Highway 242 at McKenzie Pass to Highway 35 near Barlow Pass. Highlights of this section include old lava flows, Mt. Washington, Three Fingered Jack, Mt. Jefferson, and the Breitenbush Lake-Olallie Lake Area. Many people consider Jefferson Park to be one of the most beautiful spots on the entire Pacific Crest Trail, but as a result of that beauty, this section is very popular.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes the town of Sisters; Little Belknap; lava flows; Washington Ponds; Coldwater Spring; Santiam Highway (US Hwy 20); Cascade Divide; Rockpile Lake; Pamelia Lake alternate route; Shale Lake; Cross Milk Creek; Russell Creek; Whitewater Creek; Scout Lake; Bays lake; South Fork Breitenbush River; Skyline Road 42 (4220) near Breitenbush Lake; Cigar Lake; Head Lake; Ollallie Lake Resort, Estacada, OR; Skyline Road 42 (4220) near Olallie Lake Resort; Jude Lake; Lemiti Creek; Trooper Springs; Warm Springs River; Summit Butte; Oak Grove Fork Clackamas River; Skyline Road 42; Crater Creek; US Highway 26 at Wapinitia Pass; and an old section of Highway 35 at Barlow Pass.

name: Devil's River State Trail
description: The level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The trail is great for avid bird watchers and nature advocates. Many different bird and wildlife species can be seen along the trail.

name: Neptune State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Benches set on a cliff above the beach give you an excellent view of Cumming Creek, wildlife and the rock-pounding waves. From this location, you can watch for whales, see a variety of birds, sea lions and the occasional deer in the creek. The creek is also a great place to look for agates. At low tide you can walk to the south to see a natural cave and tidepools.

name: Warren Island State Park
description: The island is a lovely place for a short hike.

name: Mount Washington State Park
description: Mount Washington State Park is a 60.3-acre area on the summit of the highest peak in the Northeast. The White Mountain National Forest surrounds the park. Hiking and dog walking are the most common activities here.

name: Orchard Beach State Park
description: A half-mile self-guiding nature trail and two miles of hiking trails are adjacent to the campground.

name: Mt. Philo State Park
description: A short, easy hike: it will provide you with some spectacular views. There are picnic benches, a bathroom, a vending machine, campsites, and a lean-to at the top. Dogs are allowed. It is possible to push a wheelchair up the access road.

name: Boulder Beach State Park
description:
The park is located on the 423-acre Lake Groton where there are plenty of trails to explore. <br />
The day use area has 75 shaded picnic sites with tables and hibachis. All rest rooms have lavatories and flush toilets. There is 200 feet of beach and swimming area, cartop boat launch, play area, three large parking lots, and a concession stand. Canoes, kayaks and pedal boats are available to rent.

name: Stillwater State Park
description: At Stillwater State Park there is a swimming beach, boat launch/dock facility, play area, shelter, and access to miles of hiking trails. Since it is part of the Groton State Forest it has access to over 17 miles of hiking trails and over 20 miles of gravel roads and multi-use trails suitable for mountain biking and horseback riding. There is also a beautiful rail trail nearby for awesome nature strolls.

name: Washburne State Wayside
description: Several interpretive signs relate the story of the Applegate Trail, a historic route that stretched through Oregon from the south. A nature trail takes you through grove.

name: Big Deer State Park
description: Big Deer State Park is a part of the Groton National Forest, and it has plenty of beautiful and secluded hiking trails as well as access to many more trails in the Groton National Forest.

name: Burnt Hollow
description: The Burnt Hollow Management Area is located approximately 20 miles north of Gillette along Highway 59. Burnt Hollow consists of more than 18,000 acres of public land in sagebrush country with dramatic geologic formations and a diversity of wildlife species. This primitive non-motorized recreation area offers hunting, backpacking, hiking, and horseback riding. Trails are not marked, but several miles of old roads (especially near the south parking lot) provide a network for riding or hiking. Several stock water ponds and small reservoirs are located within the unit, but potable water is not provided. Visitors should come prepared with a map and compass or GPS unit. There are no visitor facilities within the unit.

name: Kettle Pond State Park
description:
Kettle Pond State Park is part of Groton State Forest, which has over 26,000 acres, and is the second largest landholding operated by the Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation. The park provides access to the enormous variety of trails within the State Forest. <br />
Day use parking for hiking and boating is separate from the campground and is located adjacent to VT Route 232. The hiking trail and boat portage trail is located in the northwest corner of the parking near the kiosk.

name: Flandrau State Park
description: The gentle flowing Big Cottonwood River meanders through this southern park. The sand-bottom swimming pond, picnic area, campgrounds and group center attract many visitors every summer to this very popular state park. The terrain is diverse, offering views of wooded river bottoms, oxbow marshes and open grasslands. Hikers and cross-country skiers enjoy the flat trails on the bottom of the valley or more challenging routes on the oak-shaded bluffs. Visit historic stone buildings crafted by Works Progress Administration(WPA)crews. Vegetative features include goat prairies, small white lady's slippers, and the floodplain forest.

name: Burrow's Trail
description: This hike starts from a spur trail at the trailhead of the Burrows Trail. The climb is gradual following a stream until it reaches the Long Trail. Heading North to the summit there are many great views and overlooks. The trail gets steep at times with some climbing on rocks. Once to the peak, continue north over the summit. The descent is steep at first then comes to a clearing. On the right, is the Burrows Trail a long winding climb down through softwood then hardwood to the parking area. This trail leads to the summit, which is at 4,065 ft above sea level.

name: Scarface Mountain
description: Scarface Mountain features 6 miles of hiking trails near Lake Placid, NY.

name: Medicine Lodge Canyon
description: This beautiful deep canyon calls for rugged hiking. With many side canyons and cliffs that tower more than 300 feet there is no designated trail system, but travel is possible along wild game trails. Traveling the canyon will require numerous stream crossings and, as canyon walls get higher to the west, hiking becomes more difficult. Primitive camping is allowed but seasonal fire restrictions may apply.

name: Lower Crooked  Wild and Scenic River
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lower Deschutes Wild and Scenic River
description: The Lower Deschutes River is Central Oregon's playground. From white water rafting and swimming to hiking and biking, you'll find an ideal location for outdoor sports. Follow the Lower Deschutes River Back Country Byway along the river to campgrounds at Beavertail and Macks Canyon, or the accessible fishing ramp at Blue Hole. Then visit Sherars Falls, where Native Americans still fish the traditional way, leaning from tall platforms over the river to dipnet steelhead salmon. The river is very popular and crowded during summer weekends, so arrive early to get a campsite.

name: Hallowell Reservoir
description: Hallowell Reservoir features 6 miles of hiking trails near Hallowell, ME.

name: Monroe Trail
description: The Monroe trail is the direct way from the east to travel on Camel's Hump. It's classified as moderate to advanced hiking, and the average time takes about 4 hours, So plan for a day hike if you want to tackle this one. Great views from the very beginning as well!

name: Walsh Road Equestrian State Forest Campground & Trail Camp
description: Northern spur of the 355-mile Shore-to-Shore Riding/Hiking Trail enters campground.

name: Reed & Green Bridge State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail is 0.5 miles north of this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Historic Mill Creek State Park
description: This park offers an example of life in the 1700s as the industrial age began to alter saw mills across northern Michigan.

name: Wetzel State Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Ross Lake State Forest Campground
description: Gemini Lake (3 miles NW): 1.5 miles of flat terrain. Hike and mountain bike.

name: Veterans Memorial State Forest Campground
description: Platte Springs (2 miles SW): 2.5 miles of hilly terrain with interpretive trail marking points of interest. Hike and mountain bike.

name: Carrieville State Forest Campground
description:
Pine Valley (5 miles NW): 8.2 miles of slightly rolling terrain. Hike, mountain bike, and cross-country ski.
Silver Creek (8 miles NE): 4 miles of rolling terrain extending from Lincoln Bridge State Forest Campground to Silver Creek State Forest Campground. Hike, mountain bike.

name: Black Lake Trail Camp
description: Black Mountain (2 miles East): 30-mile complex of pathways including 1.3 barrier-free, paved pathway with beautiful forest scenery and shelter houses.

name: Pine Grove State Forest Campground
description: High Country (on site): Over 80 miles of flat to very hilly terrain connecting 8 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic Pigeon River Country.

name: Stoney Creek Trail Camp
description: High Country Pathway (10 miles South): Over 80 miles of trail. Hike, bike, and camp at 10 State Forest campgrounds along its route.

name: Black River State Forest
description: There are 29 miles of biking trails, five of which are located at the Pigeon Creek Campground. This segment links to the remaining 24 miles of hiking, biking and ski trails. Riders should note that bike trail surfaces vary, and include sand, gravel and grass.

name: Wellesley Island State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: CDT WY21: Lewis Lake and South Entrance Road to Old Faithful and US Hwy 20
description: The CDT runs for 24 miles from Lewis Lake and South Entrance Road to Old Faithful and US Hwy 20. Along the way, the trail passes Shoshone Lake and Geyser Basin.

name: Hinesburg Town Forest
description:
Several miles of multi-use trails on 837 acres of mixed woodlands.<br />
Please use a compass and trail map when hiking in the Town Forest. If you notice missing or damaged signs or blazes or other trail conditions of concern, please contact a member of the Hinesburg Trails Committee.

name: New Discovery State Park
description: New Discovery State Park is part of the Groton Forest, which is the second largest state forest in Vermont with over 26,000 acres to explore. The State Park provides great access to plenty of trail within the forest. There is also the Osmore Pond Trail, located within the park, that takes hikers along the scenic pond, and the Big Deer Mountain Trail, also located within the park, which brings hikers up the mountain for beautiful views of the area.

name: Acadia Carriage Roads
description: Acadia Carriage Roads features 45 miles of hiking trails near Bar Harbor, ME.

name: Lake Thompson Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Silver Mine - Harriman State Park
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Sebago Cabin Camp - Harriman State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Lake Tiorati Beach - Harriman State Park
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Lake Welch Beach - Harriman State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Perry Hill
description:
There are 3 looped trails here that, if combined, give you about 3,000ft of climbing. These trails are well-maintained and well-marked, and although there aren't many views along here it's a great trail to get outdoors on.<br />
These trails are mainly used by mountain bikers so please use caution.

name: Fox River State Trail
description: The level grade and smooth asphalt and limestone surfaces make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The 11 miles of asphalt trail in Brown County from the northern trailhead to Lasee Road are suitable for in-line skaters. Each bicyclist and skater age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Hartman Creek State Park
description: Hikers have about 10 miles of varied trails to choose from at Hartman Creek State Park.

name: Alsea Falls Recreation Site
description: Alsea Falls recreation site is nestled along the South Fork Alsea River and the South Fork Alsea River National Back Country Byway between the small communities of Alsea and Alpine. The byway is often used as an alternative route to Waldport along the Central Oregon Coast. The town of Alsea offers a post office, gas, food, church, a library and some overnight facilities. On your way to the town of Alsea, stop by Mary's Peak recreation area. Managed by the Siuslaw National Forest, it offers tent camping and numerous trail opportunities. The North Fork Alsea River fish hatchery offers views of large fish.

name: Trap Creek - Swamp Creek Loop
description: Trap Creek - Swamp Creek Loop is a 14 mile hiking trail in Stanley, Idaho.

name: Mckenzie River Trail
description: Mckenzie River Trail features 26 singletrack along the Mckenzie river near Eugene, Oregon. Along the way, the trail passes through lava flows and deep forests, and passes by gorgeous crystal-clear lakes, thundering waterfalls, river rapids, and absolutely massive evergreen trees!

name: Clear Creek
description: Clear Creek features 6 miles of hiking trails near Buffalo, WY.

name: Camel's Hump State Park
description:
Trails close when snow begins melting and open the weekend before Memorial Day. Even then, if the trails are very wet and muddy it's best to stay off them - use your best judgment. <br />
On the Duxbury side, the Monroe Trail is somewhat challenging, but there's also an accessible loop with its own parking area. This loop is 8/10 of a mile long, is wide and flat, and has three viewing spots to the summit of Camel's Hump - it's perfect for small kids and elders. <br />
On the Huntington side, the Burrows Trail is a bit shorter and attracts lots of hikers. Always a good idea to get there early (8AM) on a good weather weekend day to get parked and on the trail. <br />
All trails get more rugged as they get closer to the summit.

name: Moore Dam
description: Moore Dam  features 3 miles of hiking trails near Littleton, NH.

name: Nerstrand Big Woods State Park
description: Eleven miles of hiking trails.

name: Farm Island Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Poison Creek Trail
description: The two mile long Poison Creek Trail ambles through mountain meadows before descending steeply to Poison Creek.

name: Dry Creek Petrified Tree
description: A picnic shelter is available to accommodate small groups; an outhouse is also provided. Collection of petrified wood, open fires and target shooting are prohibited. Please help keep the area clean and plan to pack out trash.

name: LaFramboise Island Nature Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Holbrook Island Sanctuary
description: Holbrook Island Sanctuary is a scenic, well-preserved area of forests, rocky shores and the Penobscot Bay. The park's purpose is to protect a variety of ecosystems. The plant and animal diversity is impressive and wildlife observation and birdwatching abound. Cross-country skiing, fishing, hiking, kayaking, swimming, picnicking and snowshoeing are also popular. The Fresh Pond Nature Trail is open for hiking use.

name: Sleepy Hollow Ski And Bike Center
description:
Sleepy Hollow Ski And Bike Center features 10 miles of hiking trails near Burlington, VT. Trails here range from easy to difficult, with mountain top views looking over the surrounding area.<br />
Be aware that these trails were built for mountain biking, and they get a lot of bike traffic.

name: Keyhole State Park
description: Keyhole State Park is a great place for wildlife observation as it is a destination for many migratory birds. Complete with a lake, this park offers camping swimming, boating, canoeing, kayaking, fishing, trail running and hiking.

name: Mary Island State Park
description: 12 wooded acres make up Mary Island State Park. The park offers fantastic views of the surrounding Canadian shore and shipping channel. A few trails, picnic areas and campsites are available for visitor use. Access by boat only. Pets okay with rabies vaccination verification.

name: Snowbank Trail
description: Snowbank Trail features 25 miles of hiking trails near Howe, ID.

name: Camden State Park
description: Camden State Park is a great fishing, hiking, walking, picnicking and relaxing park. The beautiful woodlands, the Dakota Valley and Brawner Lake provide scenic views of the large park. Cross-country skiing is also popular during the snow season. 13  miles of trails are available for hiking and walking when it's warm and cross-county skiing and snowmobiling when it's cold. The trails are beginner level.

name: Smith Rock State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: AuSable River State Canoe Camp
description: Mason Tract (13 miles SE): 11.5 miles of slightly hilly terrain. Hike, cross-country ski. Closed to bicycling due to erosion and safety concerns.

name: George S. Mickelson Trail
description: The George S. Mickelson Trail features 110 miles of hiking trails near Deadwood, SD.

name: Bear Butte State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Missouri Bend Recreation Site
description: Day-use picnic area nestled between Hwy 34 and the Alsea River approximately 10 miles west of the town of Alsea. Missouri Bend contains picnic sites, vault toilet, small trail, kiosk, river access and a winter pole slide boat launch. No camping is allowed.

name: Little River State Park
description:
Little River State Park is one of the most popular parks in central Vermont. Waterbury Reservoir is particularly favored for boating with a portion of the reservoir devoted to quieter uses. Angling for bass and trout is as popular here as water-skiing.<br />
Enjoy swimming beaches, play areas, boat rentals and a launch, and miles of hiking and mountain bike trails in the adjacent Mt. Mansfield State Forest. Self-guided history and nature trails are located close to the camping area.<br />
The Little River History Hike, which is especially popular, is a journey through time. The miles of stone walls, cemeteries, cellar holes and orchards give evidence of life one hundred years ago.

name: Hunger Mountain: Waterbury Trail
description: Hunger Mountain is nice to hike because of the lack of development. Hunger has views of the Green Mountains to the west and Groton State Forest and the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the east. A possible side trail leads south to White Rock Mountain, while the Skyline Trail heads north to Worcester Mountain.

name: Cascadia State Park
description: A pair of hiking trails give you a chance to explore the area. A three-quarter mile trail leads to the spectacular Soda Creek Falls. A newer trail ushers you through historic Douglas-fir trees along the South Santiam River (a good place to fish and swim).

name: Rifle River Recreation Area
description: Rifle River Recreation Area features 14 miles of hiking trails near Rose City, MI.

name: Appalachian Trail 150: US 2 to ME/NH Line
description:
The 150th section of the Appalachian Trail, the last section in the state of New Hampshire, runs 16.5 miles from US Hwy 2 to the Maine/New Hampshire state line. Along the way it passes Shelburne Dam, Mount Hayes, Cascade Mountain, Bald Cap, the Gentian Pond shelter, and Mount Success.<br />
<br />
Note: if you are north bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in Maine (or just click here).

name: Lake St. George State Park
description:
Lake St. George State Park is home to the 1,017-acre Lake George. Numerous birds find their home here making it a great birdwatching area. Fishing for salmon and brook trout are very popular here and the park offers rentable canoes and boats. There is a lovely campground with scenic views of the crystal water and a few picnic areas and grills. The park also offers a playground area for children and a volleyball court and basketball court for the sports enthusiast.

Three to five miles of scenic hiking trails are within walking distance from the campground.

name: Black Butte
description: This trail is a strenuous 1,600 ft. ascent up a volcano in the Deschutes National Forest. It's shaded at first, but then the trees thin out at the top. Plan to hike upward the entire time. There's pretty much no level spots until you get to the top. From the top, you'll have views of all the surrounding volcanoes and the town of Sisters.

name: Ambrose Lake State Forest Campground
description: Great trails.

name: Continental Divide Trail: Idaho
description:
The Continental Divide Trail is 3,100 miles long, stretching from Mexico to Canada and roughly following the continental divide. It is a part of the Triple Crown of long distance hiking trails in the US, along with the Pacific Crest Trail and Appalachian Trail. It is still under construction, so sections of it are constantly changing. The information posted here on Tripleblaze is the most up-to-date available, but these trail descriptions and GPS locations may become obsolete at some point in the future. If you notice any obsolete information, always feel free to post a review with the new info!

Whenever possible, the Google Maps location given for each section of trail will be for the most southern point. All sections are numbered in a south-to-north fashion.

This section of the cdt runs for approximately 327 miles along the Idaho/Montana border from its departure from Wyoming. The trail switches from state to state regularly over these 300 miles before eventually committing to traveling North through Montana.

To follow the trail to the south, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3203/Wyoming/Continental-Divide-Trail--Wyoming.html">Wyoming section</a>. To follow the trail to the North, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3204/Montana/Continental-Divide-Trail--Montana.html">Montana section</a>.

name: CDT ID01: Wyoming Border to Targhee Pass and US Hwy 20
description:
The first section of the CDT in Idaho runs for 22.4 miles from the Idaho/Wyoming border to Targhee Pass and US Hwy 20 on the Idaho/Montana border. Along the way, the CDT passes out of Yellowstone National Park, crosses the Montana/Idaho border several times, and passes Mount Two Top.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=44.6749860683, lon=-111.274850328

name: Acadia National Park
description:
Acadia is a hiker's paradise. Within the park, 125 miles of trails offer choices for all abilities and interests. From flat rambles across meadows to challenging climbs up iron rungs, you can find it here. Terrain varies from rugged shoreline and deep woods to open mountain summits with views of the ocean and outer islands. For those who prefer more level footing, 45 miles of carriage roads are excellent for walking.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Foster Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout area.

name: Mud Pond Loop
description:
Mud Pond Loop features 4 miles of beautiful trails winding through a thick forest canopy. Enjoy the peaceful atmosphere and get out and stretch your legs on this beautiful trails.<br />
This is mainly used as a mountain bike trails, so beware of mountain bike traffic.

name: Centennial Trail
description: Centennial Trail is a 111 mile hiking trail in Sturgis, South Dakota.

name: South Higgins Lake State Park
description: There is a self-guided nature trail in South Higgins, as well as five miles of hiking trails surrounding Marl Lake that offer naturalists a good opportunity to explore the local area and observe wildlife. Please keep in mind that portions of the Marl Lake trail system pass through areas open to hunting. It is recommended that hikers wear highly visible clothing during the hunting seasons.

name: Standing Rocks
description: Standing Rocks is a 13 mile hiking trail in Stevens Point, Wisconsin.

name: Healy Lake State Forest Campground
description: Betsie River (5 miles NE): 10 miles of rolling to hilly terrain. Hike and mountain bike.

name: Oahe Downstream Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Stowe Pinnacle
description: The Stowe Pinnacle Trail is relatively short but steep, with a bald open summit from which you can see the Green Mountains to the west, and the Worcester Range. You'll see Hogback Mt. to the southeast, which you can get to via the Hogback Trail.

name: Moose Point State Park
description: Picnicking after a long day of work is a common activity at the Moose Point State Park. The park is located on a scenic coastal route that offers beautiful views of the Penobscot Bay. Hiking and hunting are also common here. The park has three common hiking trails: the Big Spruce Trail, the Moose Trail and the Meadow Trail that equal about 1.2 miles when combined as a loop.

name: Red Rocks
description: This 100-acre community park and natural area is the perfect place to get outdoors. There are 2.5 miles of beautiful forested hiking trails with views across the scenic Lake Champlain.

name: Weeks State Park
description: In summer, excellent hiking.

name: Lost Dauphin State Park
description: Lost Dauphin State Park is a small 19-acre gem along the Fox River in Brown County. The park is managed locally and offers rolling hiking trails and picnicking opportunities.

name: Oakwood Lakes State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Newton Blackmour State Trail
description: The trail is open between Black Creek and Seymour for nine miles. The level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. The 14 miles from New London to Black Creek is closed to all use until the trail is developed on this segment.

name: Fort Ridgely State Park
description: The trails will take you through a wide variety of terrain from easy to challenging. Trails wind through mostly wooded areas and open prairie areas. These varied landscapes produce a wide variety of plant communities that offer hikers many different things to see throughout the year.

name: CDT WY22: Old Faithful and US Hwy 20 to Idaho Border
description: The CDT runs for 17 miles from Old Faithful and US Hwy 20 to the Idaho border. Along the way, the trail passes the Old Faithful visitor center, Biscuit Basin, US Hwy 20, and Mystic Falls.

name: Tomorrow River State Trail
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. Some sections may have hoof marks where the limestone trail is shared with horses. Each bicyclist age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail. Passes are available along the trail at self registration stations or at the Portage County and Waupaca County Parks offices.

name: Luce Trail
description: Luce Trail is mainly used as a mountain biking trail, and it's located on the Trapp Family Lodge premises. The trail gives you glimpses of the mountains and plenty of scenic pastures. It is well groomed and well-marked, but do be aware of the high mountain bike traffic.

name: Stowe Town Forest
description:
Stowe Town Forest features 7 miles of hiking trails near Stowe, VT. There are a couple of different loops to choose from which pass nice little creeks and a couple of small waterfalls. These trails are great for a leisurely hike in the woods.<br />
These trails are somewhat popular with mountain bikers so please be aware.

name: Jericho Mountain State Park
description: Jericho Mountain State Park is a fantastic location for a variety of recreational activities. It is only a few miles away from downtown Berlin. The park offers ATV riding, hiking, horseback riding, mountain biking, fishing, swimming, canoeing, kayaking, picnicking and snowmobiling, cross-country skiing, dog sledding, and skate skiing during the winter.  The park is currently still under development but will soon have more miles of trails and amenities.

name: Buffalo Bill State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Levis Mounds
description: Levis Mounds has well over 20 miles of singletrack to hike, and there's about another 20 miles of cross country ski trails that are also open to hiking. Some of the trails head up to the top of the mounds and provide gorgeous views of the surrounding Clark County forest from the tops of the sandstone cliffs.

name: CDT ID06: NF-192 to Morrison Lake
description: Section 6 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 34.1 miles from NF-192 to Morrison Lake. Along the way, the trail crosses the Montana/Idaho state line several times and passes the Beaverhead Mountains, Harkness Lake, and Cottonwood Peak.

name: Hopkins Creek Equestrian State Forest Campground and Trail Camp
description:
Hopkins Creek Campground offers 16 tent and small trailer campsites and a group camping area that can accommodate 108 people. It is adjacent to the Shore to Shore Riding Trail-- a 400 miles trail and near the North Missaukee ATV trail-- a 57 mile trail. The campsites include vault toilets and drinking water from a hand pump well.

Hiking and fishing are other popular activities here.

name: Appalachian Trail 151: ME/NH Line to Grafton Notch (ME 26)
description:
The AT runs 14.6 miles from the Maine/New Hampshire state line to Grafton Notch on ME Hwy 26. Along the way the trail passes the Carlo Col shelter, Mount Carlo, Goose Eye Mountain, the Full Goose shelter, Fulling Mill, Mahoosuc Mountain, Speck Pond, and the Speck Pond shelter.<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given is the approximately the southern end of this trail.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"ME 26 (Grafton Notch)" lat=44.5898296757, lon=-70.9474838145<br />
<br />
Note: if you are south bound, pick up the Appalachian Trail section descriptions in New Hampshire (or just click here).

name: Appalachian Trail: Maine
description: The Appalachian Trail runs for 2,184 miles from Georgia to Maine (or vice versa). In Maine, the trail runs for 282 miles from <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3305/New-Hampshire/Appalachian-Trail--New-Hampshire.html">New Hampshire</a> to the summit of Mount Katahdin. Click on the individual section listings for more detailed information about each section.

name: Moss Glen Falls Trail
description: This is a very short, but scenic, hike to a spectacular waterfall. Although the trail is not well marked, the route is obvious. Follow the brook upstream to the falls. Be careful at the falls. Loose debris at the edge of the trail can be slippery and dangerous. Inexperienced hikers should stay to the left, above the falls. The trail connects to a VAST snowmobile trail so be careful not to follow the wrong trail back.

name: Green Peter Lake
description: Hiking trails in nearby Whitcomb Creek Park.

name: Baxter Bridge State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail is (1 mile North) of this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Higley Flow State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Seal Rock State Recreation Site
description: Nice hiking trail.

name: Saxon Hill
description:
Climb up Saxon Hill and take in some stunning mountain top views, or simply take a wooded hike through the many trails that skirt the mountain's base. Either way Saxon Hill has great hiking trails.<br />
Beware of the heavy bike traffic in this area.

name: Baird Creek
description: Baird Creek features 15 miles of hiking trails near Green Bay, WI.

name: Jimmy Smith Lake Trail
description: This popular year-round fishing hole features a trailhead along Jimmy Smith Lake in the spectacular White Cloud Peaks of the Sawtooth National Recreation Area. The area offers wonderful rainbow trout fishing opportunities. As of 2008, there is no motorized access around or beyond the lake.

name: Herd Lake Campsite & Overlook
description: Trailhead to Herd Lake.

name: Land of Yankee Fork State Park
description: Nicely maintained hiking trails.

name: CDT ID04: Ching Moose Road Trailhead to Interstate 15
description: Section 4 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 31.8 miles from the Ching Moose Road Trailhead to Interstate 15. Along the way, the trail passes Ching Creek, Aldous Lake, Baldy Mountain, Big Table Mountain, Price Peet Road, and the summit of Little Table Mountain (8,620 feet).

name: Sunny Hollow
description: Great place to hike or ride with your dog off leash. The area is maintained by Fellowship of the Wheel (http://www.fotwheel.org) and the Town of Colchester. Trails are well marked, maintained and split between Easy, Intermediate and Hard. Trails range in length with a reported max of 8 miles of trail. When hiking, be on the watch for riders, when riding be on the watch for hikers. All in all, a great place for a quick hike or ride.

name: North Higgins Lake State Park
description: Eleven miles of marked hiking, biking and cross-country ski trails are adjacent to the park on state-forest managed land. Trails are groomed.

name: Beaver Creek State Natural Area
description: Several miles of trails take off from the small bridge that crosses Beaver Creek.

name: Ahnapee State Trail
description: LocationFrom downtown Sturgeon Bay, this 46-mile, county-operated trail winds south along the beautiful Ahnapee and Kewaunee rivers to Algoma, Casco, Luxemburg and Kewaunee, passing by a mixture of evergreen glades, farmland, prairies and wooded areas teeming with wildlife and native wildflowers.

name: CDT ID05: Interstate 15 to NF-192
description: Section 5 of the CDT in Idaho runs for 44.2 miles from Interstate 15 to NF-192. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Monida Pass, Pinetop Mountain, Diamond Butte, Red Conglomerate Peaks South, Lima Peaks East, Lima Peaks West, and Garfield Mountain.

name: Smugglers Notch State Park
description:
Welcome to Smugglers' Notch State Park. The famous Smugglers' Notch is a narrow pass through the Green Mountains. Lined with 1,000-foot cliffs, the winding road is closed in winter. In the earlier days, only a footpath and trail for horses existed here.<br />
There are a total of 7 hikes here ranging from 1 mile in length to 3.4 miles in length. All of the trails here are either rated moderate or difficult, but they take by scenic ponds and up high peaks with beautiful views.<br />
Trails May Be Closed April 15th - Late May

name: Lake Cascade State Park
description: Beautiful hiking.

name: Frontenac State Park
description: Park has full-range of trails from easy to moderate to challenging. Trails will take you through forested areas, along the bluff edge, through wooded ravines, across old fields and restored prairies, and through wetland riverine forests...a variety of landscapes. Wildflowers in spring as well as prairie flowers can be seen along the trails.

name: Wildcat Mound
description: There are a couple of different trails winding up and down the sides of the mound. Once you reach the bluffs area, there's a trail that goes below the bluffs and one that goes up and circles the top. The views are incredible, especially when the leaves are turning in the fall!

name: Bobcat-Houlihan Trailhead
description:
Interpretive kiosks, horse trailer parking, horse hitching rails,
food storage boxes, and toilet facilities.

name: Bald Ridge Trailhead
description: Interpretive kiosks, picnic tables, fire rings, toilet facilities, horse trailer parking, horse stanchions and hitching rails. The Bald Ridge area is closed to all use from December 15 through April 30 of each year to protect essential wintering habitat for elk and mule deer.

name: Arcadia Dunes
description: Arcadia Dunes features 12 miles of hiking trails near Arcadia, MI.

name: Long Trail South to Mt. Mansfield peak
description: Mount Mansfield (elevation 4,393 feet) is the highest mountain in Vermont. From the east its ridge resembles the profile of a human face, and the names of its prominent features reflect this: Adams Apple (4,060'), Chin (4,393', highest point), Nose (4,062') and Forehead (3,940'). For about 2.3 miles (from the Forehead to Adams Apple) the Long Trail is almost constantly above treeline, the only such long stretch of alpine zone in Vermont. The trail ascends steeply at first, but soon eases through the forest with steps built in. The trail continues to ascend quite steeply, with a very steep ascent just before reaching the Taft Lodge at the 1.7 mile mark. Continue up the trail to the 2.0 mile mark and the junction at Eagle Pass. Continue South 0.3 mile and ascend the steep face of the Chin to the panoramic summit of Mount Mansfield, 4393' above sea level. Your return hike follows the same trails back to the parking area. Duration is about 6.5 hours round trip.

name: Underhill State Park
description:
Underhill is within Vermont's 39,837-acre Mt. Mansfield State Forest. On the headwaters of the Brown's River, at about 2,000 feet elevation, the park lies on the west slope of 4,300 feet Mt. Mansfield, the state's highest peak. Just over the summit ridge is the Stowe ski area, one of North America's original ski resorts. <br />
There are four trails to the summit ridge of Mt. Mansfield from Underhill State Park. Walking up the gated road from the park headquarters, the trails begin branching off shortly above the group camp area. The Sunset Ridge Trail, 3 miles to the summit, is the most popular. Vermont's Long Trail traverses the summit ridge and, with several trails from the other side of the mountain, many loops are possible. Hiking information and trail maps are available at the park headquarters.

name: Haselton
description: The trail takes you through the picturesque forest of the Haselton Trail, the Nose Dive Ski Trail and the Toll Road under Mt. Mansfield's Nose and features a 2.0 mi. alpine ridge walk along the Long Trail north to the Chin, Vermont's highest point (el. 4,393'). The trail then goes down the Long Trail past Taft Lodge and returns to Vt. 108 less than a mile north of the gondola parking lot (parking for the Haselton Trail).

name: Fort Phil Kearny Historic Site
description: Fort Phil Kearny State Historic Site is complete with an interpretive center, bookstore and self-duided tours of the fort and outlying sites. This site also offers hiking and picnic areas for day use.

name: Mahoosuc Public Reserved Land
description:
Mahoosuc Public Reserved Land goes hand in hand with the Grafton Notch State Park. These areas offers beautiful views of the backcountry and deep gorges. Twelve of the Appalachian Trail's most challenging miles are located here, but the effort is well worth the views that you will behold.

During the winter snowmobiling, cross country skiing and snowshoeing are popular activities on the rolling terrain. Birdwatching and wildlife observation are also exciting activities at this unique park.

name: Mary's Peak
description: Mary\'s Peak features 5 miles of hiking trails near Philomath, OR.

name: Twin Creek Trailhead
description: Closures/Restrictions: trail is closed January 1 through April 30. Trailhead is a day use site only.

name: Pine Ridge
description: Pine Ridge features 8 miles of hiking trails near Waterville, ME.

name: Elmore State Park
description:
Lake Elmore is 219 acres, and lies northwest of the village and empties into the Lamoille River through Pond Brook. Elmore Mountain is in the "Hogback Range" and its timber is mostly hardwood. The mountain has an elevation of 2,608 feet.<br />
There is convenient access to several hiking trails to Elmore Mountain and its fire tower, as well as a self-guided nature trail.

name: The Cove Palisades State Park
description: Great trails.

name: Bench Trail
description: Bench Trail features 10 miles of hiking trails near Greybull, WY.

name: Rocky Creek Loop
description: Rocky Creek Loop features 19 miles of hiking trails near Leadore, ID.

name: Hell Brook Trail
description: The Hell Brook trail is a fun and challenging route to 'The Chin' of Mt. Mansfield (The Summit). This is the shortest and steepest but also most technically difficult route to the summit. The trail is mostly large rocks and is usually wet. This route is considerably less busy than the popular Long Trail, which also makes it nice. Elevation gain is about 2600ft.

name: Jacques Cartier State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: Memorial Park
description: This trail is rests on top of one of Red Wing's gorgeous bluffs and begins in Memorial Park. This trail is popular with local mountain bikers, and some of the trails here are cross-country ski trails during the winter. However, there are some very cool places to hike too, with a varied array of terrain from deep, lush forested singletrack to rocky, dry trail. There some awesome views of Red Wing and the surrounding area!

name: Barn Bluff
description:
Barn Bluff is a gorgeous limestone bluff that juts up about 400 feet above the Mississippi river below, and about 200 feet above the nearby city of Red Wing. The back side of the bluff is densely forested, but much of the front side and top consist of a large grassy meadow, which naturally offers incredible views of Red Wing and the surrounding area! <br />
This hike is short, but it can be steep in places, but the tough climb is well-worth the views! <br />
This is also a very popular spot with rock climbers who enjoy the cliffs on the eastern end and northern side of the bluff.

name: Milan Hill State Park
description: Milan Hill State Park is a great location for camping, hiking, picnicking and cross country skiing. From the campground here, you can find excellent views of the surrounding mountain ranges. The park provides unique purple yurts that offer a comfortable stay in most weather conditions.

name: Buffalo River State Trail
description: The trail is open all year to walking. Users enjoy observing wildlife, birding, photography and berry picking. The trail surface may not be suitable for some bicycle types, especially bikes with thinner tires. Mountain bike riders may enjoy the rougher terrain. Each bicyclist age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail. Trail passes must be purchased before riding on the trail and should be carried with you while using the trail.

name: Donnell Pond Public Reserved Land
description:
Schoodic Mountain
Schoodic Mt. can be climbed as a loop (2.8 miles) or an up and back (2.5 miles). Allow 2 hours. The mountain's summit is bare and flat with 360 degree views, including dramatic views over Frenchman Bay and Mount Desert Island. The most direct route up Schoodic Mountain leaves from the rear of the Schoodic Beach parking area. However, a popular route on a hot summer day combines an ascent from the parking area with a descent to Schoodic Beach for a refreshing swim before the half-mile walk back to the parking area. The western half of Schoodic Mountain's summit, including the communications tower, is private property. Please respect our neighbors and stay on marked trails.

Black Mountain
The Black Mountain Cliffs Loop (2.9 miles - allow 2 hours) starts at the Schoodic Beach parking area, a popular trailhead leading to Schoodic Mountain, Schoodic Beach on Donnell Pond, and Black Mountain. The loop includes a roughly half-mile walk to Schoodic Beach from the parking area as well as 2.4 miles of hiking trail leading up to and back from the cliffs on the southwest flank of Black Mt. The loop also offers a trail link to Black Mt.'s western summit and the Caribou Loop Trail.

The Big Chief Trail (2.6 miles - allow 2 hours) on Black Mountain starts 2.2 miles down the Black Mountain Road, at a small trailhead parking area. It climbs steadily for approximately 0.6 miles through mixed woods and transitions into spruce and fir shortly before crossing onto open ledges with extensive views over the southern half of Tunk Lake and on towards the coast. A 1.4 mile loop around tiny Wizard Pond using a portion of the interconnected Caribou Loop Trail includes a stop atop Black Mt.'s attractive East Peak before returning to the 0.6 mile trail segment leading back to the trailhead.

Caribou Loop Trail
The Caribou Loop Trail (minimum 7 miles - allow 6-8 hours) ties together rugged Black and Caribou Mountains to create over 6 miles of backcountry hiking in Downeast Maine. The core loop is 6.1 miles, though hikers will need to add at least 0.9 miles of trail (one-way) to reach the core loop. Multiple access points mean that hikers can combine different sections of the loop into unique experiences. Access points include the Schoodic Beach/Mt. and Big Chief trailheads as well as the Caribou Mt. Trail, a 0.9 mile trail located approximately 1 mile down the Dynamite Brook Rd (accessed off Rt. 182 between Franklin and Cherryfield).

Tunk Mountain
The new Tunk Mt. and Hidden Ponds Trails provide the opportunity to explore scenic ponds and climb a low but brawny mountain with inspiring views.

The Tunk Mt. Trail (3.2 miles roundtrip - allow 3 hours) is an up and back hike involving some steep climbing once above Mud Pond (reached at approximately 0.7 miles). Several vista points with wide-ranging views southward are encountered on the climb. The upper summit area, including a vista northward, is on property owned by the Nature Conservancy.

The Hidden Ponds Trail (2 miles roundtrip - allow 1-2 hours) uses the first half-mile of the Tunk Mt. Trail and then loops for one mile around Salmon Pond. This trail, while still involving travel over rocks, roots, and bog-bridging does not include significant climbing. It passes by Salmon and Little Long Pond while being only a short walk from Mud Pond (via the main Tunk Mt. Trail). An interpretive brochure further describing the trail's ecology and geology can be downloaded. The Tunk Mt./Hidden Ponds Trailhead is accessed off Rt. 182 between Franklin and Cherryfield. Hikers can link in to the Caribou Loop Trail by walking south on the Dynamite Brook Rd. for roughly one mile.

Downeast Sunrise Trail
The Downeast Sunrise Trail is an 85-mile scenic rail trail running along the entire Downeast coastal area connecting multiple scenic conservation areas, intersecting salmon rivers, and providing year round recreation opportunities. It is open to snowmobiles, ATVs, horse-back riders, skiers, hikers, bikers, walkers, and joggers. Between Franklin and Cherryfield (where there are parking areas/trailheads), it passes through several sections of the Donnell Pond Public Lands. Shared-use roads open to vehicular and recreational trail use link the Sunrise Trail with other destinations within Donnell Pond Public Lands.

name: Niquette Bay State Park
description:
Today's 553-acre park began with an initial land purchase by the State of Vermont in 1975. It is named for Niquette Bay, the local name for an indentation along the northeastern shore of Lake Champlain's larger Malletts Bay. 4700 feet of scenic rocky and sandy shoreline along the bay comprise the park's southern boundary. <br />
The park's trail system accesses high points along ridges, from which impressive vistas overlook Malletts Bay to the south, the Green Mountain ridge line to the east, and the Lake Champlain Islands to the west. The park trail system is comprised of three interlocking "loops" along which a variety of hiking combinations can occur. The complete loop around the Ledges, Muhley, and Island View trails is 3.5 miles. The shortest distance to the lakeshore is 0.6 miles, via the Allen trail.

name: Devils Tower National Monument
description:
Hiking trails meander for approximately 8 miles (12.1 km) through Devils Tower National Monument. The popular 1.3 mile (2 km) paved Tower Trail circles Devils Tower itself. Other longer trails traverse tranquil forests and meadows in the monument.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Appalachian Trail 152: Grafton Notch to East B Hill Road (Baldpate Mountain Section)
description:
The Appalachian Trail ascends Baldpate's East and West peaks going north from ME Hwy 26. The hiking is rugged, remote, and moderately difficult to strenuous.<br />
<br />
The AT runs 10.3 miles to East B. Hill Road. Shelters along this section include the Baldpate Lean-to and the Frye Notch Lean-to.

name: Bates State Park
description: You can explore Bates on the more than three miles of hiking trails.

name: Grafton Notch State Park
description:
Grafton Notch State Park and the Mahoosuc Public Lands are located in some of Maine's most beautiful mountains, the Mahoosuc Range. This park is a great place for a backcountry hike or a long day of sightseeing. Part of the Appalachian Trail winds through this area.

Rushing waterfalls and deep gorges are some of the geography that makes this park special. Even if you just want to take a simple hike, you can see fantastic views of the gorges and waterfalls. Birdwatching, cross-country skiing, fishing, hiking, hunting, picnicking, snowmobiling and wildlife observation are a few of the popular activities at this diverse park.

name: CDT ID03: Red Rock Pass Road to Ching Moose Road Trailhead
description: Section 3 of the CDT that runs along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 30.6 miles from Red Rock Pass Road to the Ching Moose Road Trailhead. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Nemesis Mountain, Hell Roaring Creek, Lilian Lake, Blair Lake, the Centennial Mountains, and Taylor Mountain.

name: CDT ID07: Morrison Lake to Bannock Pass
description: Section 7 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 24.9 miles from Morrison Lake to Bannock Pass. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Island Butte, Sourdough Peak, Graphite Mountain, Ellis Peak, Medicine Lodge Peak, the summit of Elk Mountain (10,194 feet), and Maiden Peak.

name: South Beach State Park
description: Nice trails for hiking.

name: Dans Trail
description: Dans Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Corvallis, OR.

name: Roque Bluffs State Park
description: The trailhead parking lot is a quarter-mile east of the beach parking lots (up the hill toward Roque Bluffs village). Five hiking trails (with the longest loop approximately 4 miles) allow visitors to meander through fields and woodlands bordering Pond Cove and Great Cove.

name: Macomb Reservation State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: South Jetty (South Beach)
description: Adjacent to South Beach State Park, South Jetty offers horse access to the beach, fishing, clamming, surfing, scuba diving and (for the advanced) windsurfing when conditions permit.

name: Henry's Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lake Louise Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Interlochen State Park
description: The 187-acre Interlochen State Park is located on Green Lake and Duck Lake. The park's recreational opportunities include cross-country skiing, swimming, fishing, hiking, picnicking, boating and rustic camping. Amenities include a concession store, a picnic area, a playground, a dump station, a boat launch and electrical service.

name: St. Lawrence State Park Golf Course
description: Hiking trails offer views of the river

name: Yaquina Head
description: Yaquina Head Outstanding Natural Area is located on a narrow point of land jutting due west into the Pacific Ocean at the north end of Newport, Oregon. This headland provides visitors with one of the most accessible wildlife and ocean viewing locations on the Pacific Coast.

name: Luckiamute Landing  State Natural Area
description: Luckiamute Landing  State Natural Area is a great location for hiking, canoeing/kayaking, fishing, and sight seeing. The large 915 acre state park is located on a confluence of the Luckiamute, Williamette, and Santiam rivers so water sports abound here and it's a great scenic area. The hiking trail here winds through a expansive meadow and a beautiful hardwood forest.

name: Big Bear Point State Forest Campground
description: Phone number indicated above is for the Gaylord Management Unit. 14 sites. Hiking, fishing and ramp boat launch.

name: Hanson Hills
description: Hanson Hills features 6 miles of hiking trails near Grayling, MI.

name: Harrisville State Park
description: The Cedar Run Nature Trail is a two-mile trek through a wooded area.

name: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
description:
As you hike through the rugged badlands of the John Day Fossil<br />
Beds, beneath your boots the past is present. Where now you see an arid sagebrush steppe was once a lush,tropical jungle. The landscape where coyotes and elk now roam were once inhabited by rhinos, elephants and sabertooth predators. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Maidstone State Park
description:
Maidstone is the most remote of Vermont's state parks and still retains much of the wilderness character associated with the Northeast Kingdom. Maidstone Lake was created when glacial ice carved out a deep basin in a preexisting valley. The 475 acre state park and forest is a combination of northern hardwood and boreal forest with sugar maple, beech, yellow birch, red spruce and balsam fir as the most common trees.<br />
Surrounding the park are acres of forest lands that offer miles of logging roads for mountain biking or just walking.

name: Brown County Reforestation Camp Trails
description: Brown County Reforestation Camp Trails features 20 miles of hiking trails near Green Bay, WI.

name: Whistle Stop Trail
description: Enjoy the trail and please remember it is multi-use; motorized users must yield to non-motorized and please demonstrate courtesy and ethics to all trail users as well as abutting landowners.

name: Cutler Coast Public Reserved Land
description:
The coastal portion of the property has hiking trips from 3-10 miles. Wear sturdy footwear and take care near cliffs and on boardwalks, particularly in damp and slippery conditions. The estimated trail times listed below assume a leisurely pace in good conditions with brief stops.

Coastal Trail to Ocean (2.8-mile roundtrip, allow 2 hours) A forested path that runs through a cedar swamp and maritime spruce-fir forest before reaching a promontory overlooking the ocean. This is the easiest trail segment: the remainder is moderately difficult.

Black Point Brook Loop (5.5-mile roundtrip, allow 4-5 hours) Wooded trails and rocky cliffside hiking lead to a small cobble beach at Black Point Cove (accessible via a log ladder). The return route, via the Inland Trail, is somewhat rocky but over fairly gentle terrain.

Fairy Head Loop Trail (9.1-mile roundtrip, allow 6-7 hours)

This trail provides the most extensive shorefront hiking with 3.8 miles that skirt the shore. At Fairy Head, the trail turns inland through open meadows and forest, passing by a freshwater grass marsh and a large beaver pond.

name: Yellowstone National Park
description:
Yellowstone National Park, encompassing 2.2 million acres, is one of America's premier wilderness areas. Most of the park is backcountry and managed as wilderness. Over 1,100 miles (1770 km) of trails are available for hiking. <br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Burton's Landing State Forest Campground
description: Mason Tract (11 miles SE): 11.5 miles of slightly hilly terrain. Hike, cross-country ski. Closed to bicycling due to erosion and safety concerns.

name: Canoe Harbor State Forest Campground
description: Mason Tract (on site): 11.5 miles, rolling to slightly hilly terrain. Closed to bicycling due to erosion and safety concerns.

name: Minnesota Valley State Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Keystone Landing State Forest Campground
description: Keystone Landing State Forest Campground offers 18 tent and small trailer sites in a rustic campground with vault toilets and a potable water source. Observing wildlife, hiking the area, fishing in the nearby water, and relaxing are all common activities at this laid back site. ATVs are also permitted.

name: Mio Pond State Forest Campground and Group Camp
description: Mio Pond State Forest Campground and Group Camp has 24 tent and small trailer sites on the Mio Dam and a group camp area. There are vault toilets and drinkable water. Fishing, canoeing, ATV riding, wildlife observing and walking are popular activities here.

name: Appalachian Trail 153: East B Hill Road to South Arm Road
description: The AT runs 10.1 miles from East B Hill Road to South Arm Road. Along the way it passes Surplus Pond, Wyman Mountain,  the Hall Mountain lean-to, and Sawyer Mountain.

name: Rainbow Bend State Forest Campground and Canoe Camp
description: Mason Tract (9 miles SW): 11.5 miles, rolling to slightly hilly terrain, hiking, cross-country skiing. Closed to bicycling due to erosion and safety concerns.

name: CDT ID02: Targhee Pass and US Hwy 20 to Red Rock Pass Road
description: Section 2 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 33.7 miles from Targhee Pass/US Hwy 20 on the Idaho/Montana border to Red Rock Pass Road. Along the way, the trail crosses over the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Bald Peak, Targhee Peak, Hwy 87, and Saddle Mountain.

name: Lake Dubonnet State Forest Campground
description:
Lost Lake (on site): 6.3 miles of slightly rolling terrain .
Lake Ann (6 miles NW): 5.8 miles of rolling terrain.
Shore-to-Shore Riding/Hiking Trail (on site): Western spur of the 355-mile trail enters Lake Dubonnet State Forest Trail Camp.

name: Grand Isle State Park
description:
The Island, also known as Grand Isle, is 14 miles long and over 3 miles wide, making it the largest in Lake Champlain. Grand Isle State Park is the most-visited campground in the state park system. With 4,150 feet of Lake Champlain shoreline, Grand Isle is popular with many destination campers who spend their entire vacation here.<br />
There is a short nature trail here that walks hikers along the shoreline.

name: Eau Galle Lake
description: Excellent trails.

name: Down East Sunrise Trail
description: Currently 85 miles of multi-use trail is open for permanent year-round use from mile marker 2 at Washington Junction in Hancock, east to mile post 87, Ayers Junction in Pembroke (except for mud season).

name: Appalachian Trail 154: South Arm Road to Bemis Stream
description:
The AT runs 12.5 miles from South Arm Road to Bemis Stream. Along the way the trail passes Old Blue Mountain, and Elephant Mountain.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: <br />
"East B Hill Road" lat=44.6674786341, lon=-70.8920348931

name: Lake Ann State Forest Campground
description: Lake Ann (on site): 5.8 miles of rolling terrain for hiking. Lost Lake (6 mi SE): 6.3 miles of flat to slightly rolling terrain for hiking.

name: Beverly Beach State Park
description: Walking trails; beachcombing

name: Upper Sioux Agency State Park
description:
Upper Sioux Agency State Park is a 1,280-acre area of prairie land, bluffs and wooded hills. Hiking, horseback riding, snowmobiling and cross-country skiing are all popular here. Camping is also a common occurrence.

The park offers 18 miles of easy to moderate hiking that takes you along the Yellow Medicine River Valley. The views are great.

name: Goose Creek State Forest Campground
description: Great hiking area.

name: Devils Punch Bowl State Natural Area
description: Nice hiking trail.

name: Traverse City State Park
description: Keith J. Charters Traverse City State Park is a 47-acre area located on a quarter mile of beach on the Grand Traverse Bay. There is a year round campground on the park that has heated restrooms. Biking, hiking, fishing, swimming and picnicking are popular here, only two miles from downtown Traverse City.

name: Chippewa River State Trail
description: The trail is paved with asphalt from downtown Eau Claire to near Caryville (about 11 miles) to provide for in-line skating as well as biking. From there to its junction with the Red Cedar State Trail, the trail is surfaced with asphalt emulsion suitable for bicycling. The section of the Chippewa River trail in Pepin County (about 6.5 miles) between Durand and the Red Cedar junction is also paved with asphalt. Bridges are wood decked and railed.

name: Vasa Single Track
description: Vasa Single Track features 13 miles of hiking trails near Traverse City , MI.

name: Lowes Creek
description: Lowes Creek features 10 miles of hiking trails near Eau Claire, WI.

name: Manistee River Bridge State Forest Campground
description: Manistee River Bridge State Forest Campground is in Hartwick Pines State Park. The area is an excellent place for hiking, ATV riding, fishing, wildlife observing and canoeing.  The campground has 23 tent and small trailer sites along the scenic Manistee River. Vault toilets, potable water and picnic tables are available for your convenience.

name: Mt. Blue State Park
description:
Hiking, trail riding, biking, swimming and picnicking at Mt. Blue State Park are excellent. The park's location in the Western Mountains off abundant recreational opportunities just a few hours from several major cities. As Maine's largest state park, the 8,000-acre area is divided into two sections. Camping is a very common activity at the Webb Beach section with 136 wooded campsites.

ATV riding, fishing, hiking, horseback riding, hunting, off-road biking, snowmobiling, snowshoeing, swimming, wildlife observing, boating, camping, canoeing, and cross-country skiing are very popular here.

The multi-use trails on the property equal 24 miles when combined. They are two loops. In addition to these trails, there are five other trails that equal an additional seven miles approximately.

name: Forks State Forest Campground
description:
Muncie Lake (1/2 mile West): 11.5 miles. Hike, mountain bike, cross-country ski.
Vasa (3 miles NE): 16.7 miles. Hike, mountain bike, cross-country ski.
Sand Lakes Quiet Area (3 miles NE): 10 miles of flat to very hilly terrain. Hike and mountain bike.

name: Red Cedar State Trail
description: Red Cedar Trail is 14.5-trail that runs along the Red Cedar Valley. There is plenty of wildlife and scenery to go around here and activities include hiking, mountain biking, canoeing, kayaking, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

name: schaar's Bluff
