description: Short riverside walk in the oak woods wiyh veuws of lake / river from the bluffs.

name: Swedes Landing
description: Excellent trails in area.

name: Knight Point State Park
description: A trail loops around the point to offer scenic lake and shore vistas, plus intimate opportunities for close-up nature and forest viewing.  A connecting path cuts through the meadow for those wishing to shorten the walk.  Both trails are wide and easy to follow.

name: Terrace Oaks East Park
description: Terrace Oaks East Park features 2 miles of hiking trails near Burnsville, MN.

name: Burton Island State Park
description:
Burton Island is a 253-acre park off the southwestern tip of St. Albans Point in Lake Champlain's 'Inland Sea'. The park is accessible only by boat, with the state's passenger ferry making the 10-minute trip from Kamp Kill Kare State Park.<br />
There is a scenic self-guided nature trail that circles the whole island, and educates hikers along the way!

name: North Santiam State Recreation Area
description: North Santiam State Park plays host to some of the most beautiful riverfront in the area. It is one of the finest steelhead fishing spots on the North Santiam River. North Santiam State Park is a primitive campground and day-use area with drinking fountain and restroom facilities. Picnic tables dot the grass, making North Santiam State Park a great place to stop to stretch and eat a picnic lunch. Hiking trails show the beauty of the large old-growth trees and the river.

name: Garey Lake Trail Camp
description: Lake Ann (6 miles NW): 5.8 miles of rolling terrain. Access at Lake Ann State Forest Campground. Hike, mountain bike.

name: Lebanon Hills
description: Lebanon Hills features 8 miles of hiking trails near Eagan, MN.

name: Point Au Roche State Park
description: Nature trails.

name: Brighton State Park
description:
The outstanding attraction of this area is its remoteness: mountains with tree-covered slopes, fast running streams, and clear lakes. The wild lands to the northeast and southeast of the town of Island Pond are suited to the angler, the hunter, or the outdoor lover who likes to roam away from developed roads or towns. Logging roads into the deeper reaches of this area offer adventurous side trips.<br />
Brighton State Park is located on the shores of Spectacle Pond. There are hiking trails, a camper's beach with boat rentals, nature museum, an amphitheater, a garage theater, and play area.

name: Welch Ranch Recreation Area
description: The Welch Ranch Recreation Area includes more than 1,700 acres of open space along the Tongue River approximately 10 miles north of Sheridan, Wyoming. This area offers excellent hiking, wildlife viewing, hunting and fishing just a short drive from Sheridan. The Wyoming Game and Fish Department releases pheasants in the fall for hunting purposes. Welch Ranch has limited visitor services; there is no bathroom facility, garbage collection or potable water. Please plan accordingly if planning to stay overnight and practice Leave No Trace principles. Dispersed camping is also allowed, however, the area is closed to motorized use and target shooting is strictly prohibited.

name: Empire Bluff
description: This is a moderate 1.5 mile hike through a beech-maple forest. There is plenty of beautiful plant-life along the way and a stunning overlook of Lake Michigan at the end of the trail.

name: Bloomington Ferry Trail
description: Bloomington Ferry Trail features 13 miles of hiking trails near Bloomington, MN.

name: CDT ID08: Bannock Pass to Lemhi Pass
description: Section 8 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 27.1 miles from Bannock Pass to Lemhi Pass. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Grizzly Hill and Goat Mountain.

name: Quoddy Head State Park
description: Quoddy Head State Park is a beautiful area with recreational activities galore. The park features five miles of hiking trails through a truly scenic area, large woodlands, two bogs and the red-and-white striped lighthouse tower. The park offers a diversity of plant and wildlife, excellent for wildlife observation.

name: Appalachian Trail 155: Bemis Stream to ME 4
description:
The AT runs 13.9 miles from Bemis Stream to ME Hwy 4.<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given is the approximate southern end of this section of trail.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"ME 4" lat=44.8868502891, lon=-70.540788751

name: Mountain-Bay State Trail
description: The level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. Each bicyclist age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Shupac Lake State Forest Campground
description: Big Bear Lake (15 miles NE): 2.2 miles of rolling terrain. Hike, bike.

name: Mammoth Trail
description: Mammoth Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Chaska, MN.

name: Knight Island State Park
description:
Knight Island, acquired by the State in 1990, is one of three neighboring island parks in Lake Champlain's "inland sea". This 185-acre island is a mile long and nearly a half mile wide. The park includes all but 10 acres of private land on the island's southern tip. When on Knight Island, please respect the rights of the park neighbor and keep off the southern end. <br />
The island is mainly a remote campground, but there are some beautiful walking paths that provide gorgeous views of the lake. <br />
If you do not have a boat of your own, you will need to arrange water taxi service ($).

name: Salmon Falls Trail
description: Short Hike along river to Salmon Falls Area. There is ample parking and picnic area and toilets at the trailhead.

name: Richardson Public Reserved Land
description: Beautiful area to hike.

name: Kinnickinnic State Park
description: Kinnickinnic State Park offers about 6.5 miles of hiking trails winding through hills, woods and prairies.

name: Fogarty Creek State Recreation Area
description: Nice hiking trail.

name: Cobscook Bay State Park
description:
Cobscook Bay State Park has two short trails appropriate for walkers of all ages. The Nature Trail, which begins near the Park entrance, offers a forested, one-mile path that leads through forests, passes along a brook and then rises to two scenic outlooks with views out over Whiting Bay and Burnt Cove. The trail up to the outlook has a short, steep and rocky section: take extra care here in wet weather. The Nature Trail ends by two campsites, allowing walkers to return on a gravel road (for a 2-mile round trip).

The Shore Trail (also known as the Anthony's Beach Trail) is a 0.75-mile loop path that begins beside campsite 17, following near the shore to the boat launch, and then winding back through woods to come out between campsites 18 and 20. Many visitors enjoy shoreline explorations as well, but please don't wander into waterfront campsites and be mindful of fast-moving tides.

name: Four Seasons Adventure Trail
description:
Four Seasons Adventure Trail rings true to its name because it is a fantastic trail for any time of year. The 29-mile multi-use trail connects the communities of Newport, Corinna, Dexter, Sangerville and Dover-Foxcroft and has a variety of scenic views along the way.

Since it is a multi-use trail, take care to watch out for motorized vehicle if you are on foot. ATV riding, cross-country skiing, hiking, horseback riding, off-road biking, snowmobiling and snowshoeing are all popular here.

name: Afton State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails. The park maintains 6 miles of winter hiking trails in the park.

name: Four Ponds Public Reserved Land
description: The Appalachian Trail traverses the length of this 6,000-acre unit with a lean-to at Sabbath Day Pond and a campsite at Little Swift River Pond.

name: Negwegon State Park
description: Negwegon State Park is a large 3,638-acre park full of hiking, metal detecting, hunting and wildlife observing opportunities. The park is located on an undeveloped beach on Lake Huron. Fourwheel drive may be needed. Vault toilets are available for your convenience. The Negwegon-Bakcountry Campground is located on the property and offers four sites at $14 dollars a site. There are also three hiking trails on the property that equal about 10 miles when combined.

name: Potawatomi State Park
description: There are several hiking trails at the park. Potawatomi is home to the eastern trail head of the Ice Age National Scenic Trail, which begins near the observation tower. The 75-foot observation tower rises above the forest canopy giving a panoramic view. On a clear day, the view from the park's observation tower reaches 16 miles across Green Bay.

name: Bangor City Forest
description: Bangor City Forest features 10 miles of hiking trails near Bangor, ME.

name: Little Wolf Lake State Forest Campground
description: Little Wolf Lake State Forest Campground is a campground with 24 tent and trailer sites that are large enough for a 40 foot trailer. There are vault toilets and a potable water pump. The site on Little Wolf Lake provides excellent fishing, hiking and mountain biking.

name: Roosevelt Campobello International Park
description:
There are 8.4 miles of driving roads located in the park's 2,800 acres (1,158 hectares), and eight miles of walking trails. You can wander the trails individually for a short hike or combine them for longer hikes. Visit bogs, forests, shoreline, beaches, and more.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Dixville Notch State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Alburg Dunes State Park
description:
This 625-acre property became a state park in 1996. It is named for the sand dunes near the center and western end of the south-facing natural sand beach. This beach is amongst the longest beaches on Lake Champlain.<br />
There is a short, beautiful trail from dune to dune.

name: Cottonwood
description: This is mostly a dune trail. It's pretty hilly with no shade available. You'll travel through native grasses, shrubs, and wildflowers.

name: Fort Snelling State Park
description: Easy to moderate trails. Trails lead through wooded area and along lakes and rivers. Trails also connect the park with nearby historic sites. Excellent birdwatching!

name: Silver Falls State Park
description: For the equestrian users, dog owners, mountain bikers and outdoor enthusiasts, more than 25 miles of multi-use backcountry trails spread over the 9,000 acres offer a great escape.

name: Nine Mile
description: Nine Mile features 27 miles of hiking trails near Wausau, WI.

name: Dune Climb
description: This is a vertical climb up the sand dunes. It is strenuous and there is no shade. It's less than a mile to the top.

name: Oconto River State Trail
description: The level grade and smooth surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers.

name: Fisher Grove State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Appalachian Trail 156: ME 4 to ME 27
description: The Appalachian Trail runs 32.2 miles from ME Hwy 4 to ME Hwy 27. Along the way it passes the Piazza Rock Lean-to, Saddleback Mountain, The Horn, Saddleback Junior, the Poplar Ridge Lean-to, the Spaulding Mountain Lean-to, Spaulding Mountain, Sugarloaf Mountain, the Caribou Valley Road, South Crocker Mountain, Crocker Mountain, and Stony Brook Mountain.

name: Whitetail Ridge
description: Whitetail Ridge features 5 miles of hiking trails near River Falls, WI.

name: Butte Creek Falls
description: Short trail that wanders through pine forests along Butte Creek.  There are two waterfalls along the trail.  Upper Butte falls is a 35 ft drop from an overhang.  Lower Butte falls is a 85 ft cascading waterfall.

name: Ossineke State Forest Campground
description: Ossineke (On site): 1 mile of trail.

name: Minnehaha Park
description: Walking/jogging paths.

name: Pearl Park
description: Great walking/jogging path.

name: Keewaydin Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Shackford Head State Park
description: Several miles of trails cross the headland. A hiking trail from the parking area leads through woods to a rocky headland 173 feet above sea level, passing several pocket beaches and protected coves. From this outlook, visitors can see Campobello Island in New Brunswick, Canada, the town of Lubec, and the Eastport cargo pier on Estes Head, as well as aquaculture pens where Atlantic salmon are raised. Park trails afford great opportunities for wildlife watching as well - with warblers and hermit thrushes in the woodland areas, and bald eagles, common terns and spotted sandpipers along the shore. Ornithologists have documented 28 different bird species nesting on the headland.

name: Sleeping Bear Point
description: This is a strenuous 2.8 mile sandy trail. It's mostly unshaded and hilly. You'll trek through the dunes, through a ghost forest, and then come to an overlook of Lake Michigan.

name: Sleeping Bear Point Trail
description: Strenuous, hilly, sand, very little shade trail leading onto the dunes, through a ghost forest, with views of Lake Michigan.

name: Lynnhurst Park
description: Great walking/jogging path.

name: Lake Nokomis Park
description: Great walking/jogging path.

name: Pershing Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Fuller Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Rib Mountain State Park
description: There are more than 13 miles of hiking trails at Rib Mountain, with over eight miles accessible to people with disabilities. Pets are permitted in the park on the trails when on an 8-foot leash.

name: Lake Hiawatha Park
description: Excellent hiking/jogging path

name: Ponderosa State Park
description: Excellent long hikes.

name: Rangeley Lake State Park
description: Many hiking trails.

name: Whitefish Dunes State Park
description: Whitefish Dunes State Park has 14.5 miles of hiking trails. Please do not climb on the sand dunes and stay on the park's designated trails and stairs to protect the rare plant and animal species that call Whitefish Dunes home.

name: Capital City State Trail
description: The Capital City State Trail's asphalt surface is good for bicycling, walking, jogging and in-line skating. A state trail pass is required for anyone 16 and older who bikes, skates or roller-skis on the nine miles of the trail that go through the Capital Springs E-way south of Madison between Verona Road and Nob Hill near Industrial Drive. Passes are available at the trail heads at Verona Road and Nob Hill, the kiosk at the Syene Road parking lot or at the Lussier Family Heritage Center.

name: Avery Lake State Forest Campground
description:
Buttles Road (10 miles West): 7 miles of rolling terrain. Hike, mountain bike.
High Country (16 miles West): Over 80 miles of varied terrain connecting 9 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic back country.

name: Sibley Park
description: Paths excellent for walking/jogging.

name: Otsego Lake State Park
description: Except for the foot trail to the picnic shelter in the day-use area, there are no established trails in the park. Some paths throughout the wooded areas, however, yield fruitful blueberry bushes and an opportunity to find the rare and protected wild orchid, more commonly called the lady's slipper. Remember to take only photographs of this rare and delicate protected flower.

name: Lyndale Farmstead Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Bald Mountain Public Reserved Land
description: Bald Mountain Trail: This network of two trails offer short but moderate hikes up Bald Mountain where there are spectacular views of the lakes and mountains around the Rangeley region.

name: William Berry Park
description: Walking / jogging path.

name: Mississippi River Gorge
description: Great trail.

name: Coleman State Park
description: Beautiful trails.

name: Big Bear Lake State Forest Campground
description: Big Bear Lake (trail head at campground): 2.2 miles long in two loops, flat to rolling terrain, Buttles Road (6 miles SE, access from Buttles Road): 7 miles long in three loops, flat to rolling terrain, hike and bike.

name: Longfellow Park
description: Excellent hiking/jogging path.

name: Powderhorn Park
description: Great walking/jogging path.

name: Quartzville Wild and Scenic River
description: Great hiking area.

name: Bear Basin
description: Bear Basin features 25 miles of hiking trails near Mccall, ID.

name: Hoffman Hills State Recreation Area
description: There are more than nine miles of hiking trails at Hoffman Hills. A 60-foot-high observation tower offers spectacular views of the surrounding countryside.

name: Mississippi National River & Recreation Area
description: Several miles of hiking and walking trails are available within the park. Walks are generally on hard-surfaced trails, relatively level and generally shorter than hikes. They also usually have amenities, such as restrooms and drinking water and easy access/parking. Hikes will be more strenuous than a walk. Suggested hikes often include unpaved paths, uneven footing, steeper grades, generally longer distances, and lack of amenities such as restrooms.

name: Lake Calhoun
description: Great loop around the lake.

name: Lake Oahe
description: Hiking trails in Beaver Creek and East Sibley Park areas.

name: Pelican Lake Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Dean Parkway
description: Excellent walking/jogging path.

name: Brackett Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Thunder Bay River State Forest Campground
description:
Wah-Wah-Tas-See (on site): 1.5 miles of flat terrain with Native American interpretive information.
Norway Ridge (3 miles NE): 7 miles, slightly rolling terrain. Hike, bike, and cross-country skiing.

name: Matthews Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Lake of the Isles
description: Walking path.

name: Cedar Lake Park
description: Good walking/jogging path.

name: Peavey Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Kenwood Park
description: Running/jogging trails.

name: Pyramid Point
description: This is a moderate 2.7 mile hike to a bluff overlooking Lake Michigan and the Manitou Islands, then takes the hiker through a Beech-Maple forest and on into a meadow.

name: Riverside Park
description: Excellent hiking/walking/jogging path.

name: Luxton Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Tower Hill Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Loring Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Bryn Mawr Park
description: Excellent walking/jogging path.

name: Currie Park
description: Walking/jogging path

name: CDT ID09: Lemhi Pass to Goldstone Lake Road
description: Section 9 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 19.5 miles from Lemhi Pass to Goldstone Lake Road. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Goldstone Mountain.

name: Theodore Wirth Park
description: Theodore Wirth Park features 4 miles of hiking trails near Minneapolis, MN.

name: Yellowstone National Park
description:
With miles and miles of trails Yellowstone National Park offers many adventures. When planning your backcountry trip, remember that many of Yellowstone's trails are more than 7,000 feet above sea level. Most areas have some snow until late May or early June, and some areas (especially mountain passes) are snow-covered until mid- to late July. Permits maybe required.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: East River Flats Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Bassett's Creek Valley Park
description: Great hiking/jogging path.

name: Mill Ruins Park
description: Great walking/jogging path

name: Lake Wissota State Park
description: There are more than 18 miles of hiking trails at Lake Wissota State Park. Some trails are shared with off-road bicyclists. There are two, self-guided, scenic, nature trails. More than 200 species of birds often stop on the lake during the spring and autumn migrations. Birdwatchers may pick up species checklists at the park office.

name: Harrison Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Father Hennepin Bluffs Park
description: Great walking/jogging path.

name: Nicollet Island Park
description: Great walking/jogging path.

name: Lovell Square Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Goose Creek Falls Tr
description: Goose Creek Falls Tr features 5 miles of hiking trails near New Meadows, ID.

name: Hall Park
description: Great hiking/walking/jogging trail.

name: Kennebec Valley Trail
description: Kennebec Valley Trail consists of eight miles of scenic views and exciting terrain. The trail is open to ATV riding, cross-country skiing, dog sledding, hiking, horseback riding, mountain biking and snowmobiling. The route includes the "Arnold Trail," a historic area on the Kennebec River.

name: Chain of Lakes Park
description: Great hiking/walking/jogging paths.

name: Logan Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Line Creek Plateau
description: Line Creek Plateau is a 16 mile hiking trail in Red Lodge, Montana.

name: Farview Park
description: Excellent walking/jogging path.

name: Gluek Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore
description:
You can hike about 100 miles of designated trails in the Lakeshore. There are thirteen trails on the mainland for hiking, and most of them are maintained during the winter for cross country skiing, and snowshoeing too. Each trail has a trailhead with a parking area. Hiking trails on the dunes are marked by blue-tipped posts.<br />
(Source: National Park Service)

name: Aspen Park
description: Aspen Park features 7 miles of hiking trails near Gaylord, MI.

name: Edgewater Park
description: Plenty of walking/jogging paths.

name: Willow River State Park
description: The park has 13 miles of hiking trails that vary in difficulty. The most popular hiking trail destination is the Willow Falls and the scenic overlooks of the river valley.

name: Pinney Bridge State Forest Campground
description: Jordan Valley (on site): 18 miles of hilly terrain. Part of the North Country Trail. Hike and camp. Closed to bicycling due to erosion and safety concerns.

name: Lac qui Parle State Park
description: Visitors can access trails from behind the picnic shelter in the lower campground. Flat trails are easy to hike and take the visitor along some of the backwaters in the park. Lots of good bird watching and wildlife observation along trails. Trails are located in the upper and lower unit and are susceptible to seasonal flooding.

name: Johnson's Crossing Trail Camp
description: Located along the Shore to Shore Riding Trail (400 mile trail), this camp area has a large group use site that can accommodate 100 people and tents and trailers. The campground includes vault toilets and potable water. Hiking is also popular in this area, as well as fishing, wildlife observing and boating.

name: Waite Park
description: Walking/jogging path.

name: Columbia Park
description: Nice walking/jogging path.

name: Graves Crossing State Forest Campground
description:
Jordan Valley (6 miles East): 18 miles of hilly terrain. Part of the North Country Trail. Hike and camp.
Warner Creek (9 miles NE): 3.8 miles of flat to rolling terrain. Hike and bike.
The North Country Trail is (2 miles southeast) of this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Webber Park
description: Walking path.

name: West Whitlock Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Creekview Park
description: Great hiking/walking/jogging path.

name: North Mississippi Park
description: Excellent walking/jogging path.

name: CDT - Flume Creek Section
description: CDT - Flume Creek Section is a 12 mile hiking trail in Salmon, Idaho.

name: Fort Yamhill State Heritage Area
description: Walking trails.

name: Willamette Mission State Park
description: From rugged but sandy equestrian multi-use trails, to soft-landing jogging, history and nature trails, to sure-footed paved trails.  Sixteen miles in all - sure to find your suit!

name: Riverside National Recreation Trail #723
description: Riverside National Recreation Trail #723 features 5 miles of hiking trails near Estacada, OR.

name: Jackson Lake State Forest Campground
description:
Jackson Lake State Forest Campground is a popular area for fishing, hiking, wildlife observing, ATV riding, boating and camping. The camp area has 18 tent and small trailer sites, 15 of which accommodate a 40 foot trailer. The campgrounds include vault toilets and potable water.

The forest has two trails for hiking and hiking. When combined they equal 87 miles in length.

name: Narrow Gauge Pathway
description: Narrow Gauge Pathway features 7 miles of hiking trails near Kingfield, ME.

name: Williams Summit Trails
description: Williams Summit Trails features 50 miles of hiking trails near Salmon, ID.

name: Appalachian Trail 157: ME 27 to Long Falls Dam Road
description: The AT runs 19.1 miles from ME Hwy 27 to Long Falls Dam Road. Along the way, the trail passes the Horns Pond Lean-to (west and east), The Horns, West Peak on Bigelow Mountain, Little Bigelow Mountain, the Little Bigelow Lean-to, Flagstaff Lake, and Bog Brook Road.

name: Town Corner Lake State Forest Campground
description: High Country (on site): Over 80 miles of flat to very hilly terrain connecting 8 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic Pigeon River Country.

name: Lagrange to Medford Trail
description: Lagrange to Medford Trail is a 16-mile multi use trail that runs from South Lagrange to Medford Center to Lake View Plantation. The trail offers a gravel surface and fantastic views. ATV riding, cross-country skiing, dog sledding, hiking, horseback riding, hunting, snowmobiling and snowshoeing are all permitted and popular here.

name: Duck Lake Public Reserved Land
description: Beautiful remote area for hikes.

name: Clear Lake State Park
description: From the park there is access to more than 70 miles of hiking trails.

name: Peninsula State Park
description: Eagle Trail offers close-up views of the Niagra Escarpment. The White Cedar Nature Trail is a half-mile loop near the Nature Center. Peninsula has a total of 20 miles of hiking trails.

name: Round Lake State Forest Campground
description: High Country (on site): Over 80 miles of flat to very hilly terrain connecting 8 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic Pigeon River Country.

name: CDT ID10: Goldstone Lake Road to Miner Lake Road
description: Section 10 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 25.3 miles from Goldstone Lake Road to Miner Lake Road. Along the way, the trail passes Cowbone Lake, Darkhorse Lake, Skinner Lake, Skinner Meadows, Upper Big Hole River, and Berry Meadow.

name: Erratic Rock State Natural Site
description: Great hiking here.

name: Molalla River Recreation Corridor
description: The trail system is an extensive network of forested non-motorized trails that offers varying levels of difficulty and scenic glimpses of the Molalla River. Development and management of the 25-mile trails system is part of a cooperative effort with Molalla RiverWatch, a local non-profit and several hiking, biking and equestrian groups.

name: Nicolet Nat'l Forest
description: Nicolet Nat'l Forest features 19 miles of hiking trails near White Lake, WI.

name: Catherine Creek State Park
description: Nice hiking area.

name: Appalachian Trail 158: Long Falls Dam Road to Kennebec River
description:
The AT runs 17.2 miles from Long Falls Dam Road to the Kennebec River (US Hwy 201). Along the way, the trail passes Roundtop Mountain, West Carry Pond, the West Carry Pond Lean-to, Middly Carry Pond, East Carry Pond, Bates Ridge, Pierce Pond, and the Pierce Pond Lean-to.<br />
<br />
Note: the Google Maps location given is the approximate southern end of this section of trail. <br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot:<br />
"Caratunk (US Hwy 201)" lat=45.2384842293, lon=-69.9956003476

name: Shingle Mill Pathway
description: Shingle Mill Pathway is a 11 mile hiking trail in Vanderbilt, Michigan.

name: Old Abe State Trail
description: The level grade and paved surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers, joggers and in-line skaters. Each bicyclist and skater age 16 or older needs a Wisconsin state trail pass while using the trail.

name: Boyne Mountain
description: Boyne Mountain features 10 miles of hiking trails near Boyne Falls, MI.

name: Bigelow Preserve Public Reserved Land
description: Excellent hiking, with access to the Appalachian Trail.

name: Bannack State Park
description: Bannack State Park is home to Montana's first major gold discovery site. This discovery took place in 1862. The park is very reminiscent of the "Old West." The park is a National Historic Landmark and offers historic displays, interpretive programs, tours and other fun activities for visitors. Cycling, camping, birding, fishing, ice skating, picnicking and exploring are all popular here.

name: Pigeon River State Forest Campground
description: State Forest Pathways: Shingle Mill (on site): 14 miles consisting of 5 loops ranging from 3/4 - 11 miles in length. Flat to hilly terrain. Hike.

name: Brunet Island State Park
description: There are more than 8 miles of hiking trails at Brunet Island, including nearly two miles of the Ice Age national Scenic Trail. Geocaching has become a popular activity at Brunet Island and there are a variety of caches located within the park.

name: Council Grounds State Park
description: The park has several miles of trails for hikers. The park's 2.5-mile main road is also popular with walkers and runners.

name: Leelanau State Park
description: Approximately 8.5 miles of trails are available for hiking. A small section of the trail is ADA accessible.

name: Deer Mountain Campground
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Discovery Hill Trails
description: Discovery Hill Trails features 40 miles of hiking trails near Salmon, ID.

name: Black River State Forest Campground
description:
Big Knob/Crow Lake (20 miles SW): 1/4 mile Big Knob loop, 2.5 mile Crow Lake. Hike, mountain bike.
Marsh Lake (20 miles SW): 1.5 miles of level terrain along Lake Michigan beach and wetland pathway. Hike, mountain bike.

name: Tomahawk Creek Flooding State Forest Campground
description: High Country (on site): Over 80 miles of varied terrain connecting 9 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic back country.

name: Chippewa Moraine State Recreation Area
description: Lady slipperThere are more than 23 miles of hiking trails within the Chippewa Moraine. The Ice Age National Scenic Trail travels through the Chippewa Moraine, connecting to the interpretive center and loop trails, and the three primitive, outpost campsites. All pets must be on leash 8 feet or shorter and under control at all times near the visitor center.

name: Cape Kiwanda State Natural Area
description: Hiking trail along the beach.

name: William O'Brien State Park
description: William O'Brien State Park is a beautiful park along the banks of the St. Croix River known for its camping, fishing, cross-country skiing, bird watching, canoeing and interpretive programs. The park has great hiking and winter trails, nice picnicking sites and camper cabins. The park offer several hiking trails that equal about 15 miles in length when combined. 1.5 of it is wheelchair accessible, one of the trails is self-guided, and 1.5 miles of the trail is a paved bike path. The rest of the trail is 12 miles of easy to difficult hiking through wooded areas, wetlands and savanna areas.

name: Black Creek State Forest Campground
description:
Pine Haven (2 miles South): 10 miles of flat to rolling terrain. Hike, mountain bike.
Pere Marquette Trail of Mid Michigan (2 miles South): 20 miles of asphalt surfaced trail converted from abandoned railroad corridor. Hiking, biking.

name: Newport State Park
description: Newport State Park is a 2,373-acre park with 11 miles of Lake Michigan shoreline. There are over 30 miles of trails here and activities include hiking, mountain biking, camping, canoeing, kayaking, fishing, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

name: Clark's Lookout State Park
description: Clark's Lookout State Park is a 8.2-acre area one mile north of Dillon. The park is close to Beaverhead River and was high enough to provide Lewis and Clark with a view of the route that was ahead of them. Hiking, picnicking, wildlife viewing, sight seeing and interpretive learning are all popular here.

name: Young State Park
description: There are nearly five miles of nature trails that are perfect for hiking, jogging, and nature study in the park.

name: Appalachian Trail 159: Kennebec River to Monson, ME
description: The AT runs 33.7 miles from the Kennebec River (Caratunk) (US Hwy 201) to Monson, ME (ME Hwy 15). Along the way, the trail passes Pleasant Pond, the Pleasant Pond shelter, Pleasant Pond Mountain, Moxie Pond, the Bald Mountain Brook Lean-to, Bald Mountain, Bald Mountain Pond, the Moxie Bald Lean-to, the Horseshoe Canyon Lean-to, Lake Hebron, and Buck Hill.

name: White River Falls State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Stower Seven Lakes State Trail
description: Stower Seven Lakes State Trail is 14 miles long and passes through maple and oak forests, wetlands, prairies, lakes and farmlands. Activities here include hiking, biking, trail running, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

name: Champoeg State Heritage Area
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Peaks-Kenny State Park
description: Peaks-Kenny State Park is home to the famous "Castle" landmark-- a large, European style building built in 1890. With this and many other unique features, this park is a peaceful setting for a day of relaxation or fun. The park lies on the shore of Sebec Lake making it a common boating, fishing, swimming and picnicking destination. Hikers will also enjoy walking one of the five trails on the property. The 10-mile network of trails offers scenic views of beautiful woods and beach.

name: Clay Myers State Natural Area at Whalen Island
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: G: Hwy 35 to I-84 (Oregon/Washington Border)
description:
Section G of the Pacific Crest Trail in Oregon runs 51.7 miles from Highway 35 near Barlow Pass to Interstate 84 at Bridge of the Gods, which is the Oregon/Washington Border. Other parts also offer views of Mt. St. Helens, Mt. Ranier, and Mt. Adams. This section passes the majestically beautiful Mt. Hood, and later on there is an opportunity to take the beautiful Eagle Creek Trail as an alternate route.<br />
<br />
Along the way this section of the trail passes Government Camp, OR; Timberline Ski Area, Timberline Lodge, OR; Little Zigzag River; a split in the trail where the PCT turns into two routes; Lost Creek; Scout Camp after Sandy River; Ramona Falls; Preachers/Devils saddle; Larch Mountain Road 2030; Indian Springs Campground; Whaturn Lake Campground; Teakettle Spring; and Cascade Locks, OR.

name: Wallowa Lake State Park
description: Great hiking area.

name: Molalla River State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: CDT ID11: Miner Lake Road (Montana) to Gibbonsville Road
description: Section 11 of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 35.9 miles from Miner Lake Road (technically, this section begins in Montana) to Gibbonsville Road. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Rock Island Lakes, Homer Youngs Peak, Little Lake, Copperhead Peak, Ajax Peak, Jumbo Mountain, Pyramid Peak, Sheep Mountain, N Mountain, Eagle Mountain, and Morgan Mountain.

name: Milo McIver State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Peshtigo River State Forest
description: The state forest provides two systems of trails that are designated for cross-country skiing in winter and hiking the rest of the year. Numerous rustic roads and volunteer-maintained hunter walking trails on the forest are also open to hikers. Ski touring is allowed on unmarked trails throughout the forest.

name: Mirror Lake Trail
description: Mirror Lake trail wanders through a forest of pine and spruce in the Mt Hood area.  The trial travels up the mountain to Mirror Lake.  The lake itself offers great views of both Mt Hood, as well as Tom, Dick, and Harry, a local mountain grouping.

name: Fisherman's Island State Park
description: Several miles of trails makes hiking and nature observation pleasant pursuits.

name: Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area
description:
Hiking is a great way to experience Bighorn Canyon. These trails offer varying sights and tranquil settings to better explore the natural diversity the park has to offer. Some trails go through historic ranches while others take visitors to scenic vistas. The trail system is a wonderful way to extend your visit and make it truly unique.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Wolf River State Trail
description: The trail in Forest County is open to walking and bicycling. The trail may be rough or soft in many sections. If you plan to bike the trail, the tread is more suitable for off-road bikes. The trail is not developed in Langlade County but walkers and bicyclists may use the trail tread.

name: Sibley State Park
description: Easy to moderate trails offer beautiful vistas and wind through woods and hilltop prairies and savannas.

name: Lake Maria State Park
description: Lake Maria State Park is home to one of Minnesota's last remaining "Big Woods" that once covered the whole south of the state. Hikers, horseback riders, cross-country skiers and picnickers enjoy this park. The park's marshlands and rolling hills provide excellent views.

name: Cattail State Trail
description: The entire trail is open to walking and bicycling, though bicycling is not recommended. The trail may be rough or soft in many sections. If you plan to bike the trail, the tread is more suitable for off-road bikes.

name: Monson Lake State Park
description: There are 1.2 miles of trail, providing views of Monson Lake, and West Sunburg Lake. The majority of the trail passes through woodland, which provide opportunity for bird and wildlife observation.

name: The Underdown
description: The Underdown features 12 miles of hiking trails near Merrill, WI.

name: Pioneer Bridle
description: Pioneer Bridle features 10 miles of hiking trails near Sandy, OR.

name: Appalachian Trail 160: Monson, ME to West Branch of Pleasant River
description: The AT runs 33.7 miles from Monson, ME (ME Hwy 15) to the west branch of the Pleasant River. Along the way, the trail passes the Leeman Brook Lean-to, the Wilson Valley Lean-to, the Long Pond Stream Lean-to, Barren Mountain, Cloud Pond, the Cloud Pond Lean-to, Fourth Mountain, Third Mountain, Columbus Mountain, and the Chairback Gap Lean-to.

name: Governor Thompson State Park
description: Governor Thompson State Park has more than 16 miles of hiking trails. A variety of trails of different lengths take hikers past some fantastic rock formations.

name: Cape Lookout State Park
description: More than eight miles of hiking and walking trails wind through a lush old-growth forest.

name: Bonnie Lure State Recreation Area
description: If you want to get off the beaten path, Bonnie Lure State Park along Eagle Creek provides a refreshing getaway. You may catch a rare glimpse of a pileated woodpecker or hook an elusive steelhead trout (otherwise known as a silver-sided freight train) on its way back to the hatchery. It could easily become your favorite day-trip destination.

name: Wildwood Recreation Site
description: Wide range of trails from wide, handicapped accessible paths to more strenuous trails like the Boulder Ridge Trail. The Cascade Streamwatch allows you to see what's happening below the water and a large footbridge across the Salmon River leads to boardwalk trails on the other side.

name: Thompson's Harbor State Park
description: Six miles of trails.

name: Munson Creek Falls
description: Just outside of Tillamook, OR this short trail leads to views of Munson Creek Falls.  The falls are 319ft, which is the largest waterfall along the Oregon coast.  The trails wander through spruce and cedar forest.  The lower trail follows the creek and offers views from the base of the falls, while upper trail is more difficult, but offers even grander views from the mid-level of the falls.  A picnic area is located in the trailhead parking lot.

name: Munson Creek Falls State Natural Site
description: The park is home to ancient western red cedar and Sitka spruce. An important salmon spawning ground, Munson Creek Falls tumbles 319', making it the tallest waterfall in the Coast Range. A short trail winds along Munson creek to the waterfall. During the late fall through the winter watch the waters for spawning salmon.

name: Big Stone Lake State Park
description: One trail starts near park office with opportunities to view wildflowers. The other trail is in the Bonanza area and takes you along the lake through sheltered woods.

name: Tualatin River Nature Preserve
description: The Tualatin River Preserve is a nature preserve set along the banks of the Tualatin River.  The river and wetlands create a wonderful habitat for a variety of wildlife. There is a trail which wanders through the preserve, giving areas for viewing and relaxing.

name: Mary S. Young State Recreation Area
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Interstate State Park
description: The Minnesota side of the Interstate State Park is an excellent location for scenic river views, an overnight stay, rock climbing, canoeing or fishing. The park's location on the beautiful St. Croix River provides plenty of recreational choices. The park is beautiful in every scenic in its own unique way. Exploration of the various geological features of the park is a very common activity here. The park offers about 7.5 miles of trails. Two of trails make up three miles in length and are self guided through sandstone bluffs and river views. A half mile trail is handicap accessible and offers access to several picnic areas. The last trail is a four mile trail through rugged terrain with many steps.

name: Interstate State Park
description: There are more than nine miles of hiking trails in the park that offer the walker many opportunities for viewing the spectacular scenery and natural attributes of the park. Guided hikes are offered during the summer months. Pets must be on a leash 8 feet or shorter at all times. Hiking trails vary in difficulty. Not all trails are surfaced; use caution on steep bluffs and near cliffs. Trail surfaces can become slippery when wet, leaf-covered or where there is loose gravel.

name: Pickerel Lake (Otsego) State Forest Campground
description: Pickerel Lake (on site): 1.9 miles of wooded terrain with access from campground.

name: Wagonhammer Trail System
description: Wagonhammer Trail System features 50 miles of hiking trails near Salmon, ID.

name: Burt Lake State Park
description: A one-mile hiking trail is marked within the park. No bicycles, horses or motorized vehicles are allowed on this trail.

name: Hartford Beach State Park
description: Five hiking trails take visitors past historic sites and scenic overlooks, including burial mounds and a prehistoric village site.

name: Wells State Park
description: Six miles of hiking trails also offer three rustic trailside shelters for places to rest on the hike.

name: Cedar River North State Forest Campground
description: Cedar River Pathway (on site): 8 miles of gently rolling terrain.

name: Petoskey State Park
description: Two trails run through Petoskey State Park. Old Baldy Trail includes a stairway that leads up Old Baldy, a stable dune that is one of the attractions in the park. After climbing the dune, the view of the bay is breathtaking. The Portage Trail winds through very diverse terrain where a nature lover may find different species of plants and wildlife.

name: Rock Island State Park
description: There are about ten miles of trails with six miles of shoreline for hiking.

name: Haakwood State Forest Campground
description: Wildwood Hills (8 miles NW): 9.3 miles of rolling to hilly terrain. Hike, bike, groomed for cross-country skiing.

name: Iron Mountain Trail
description: Iron Mountain Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Lake Oswego, OR.

name: Black Lake State Forest Campground
description: Black Mountain (2 miles East): 30-mile complex of pathways including 1.3 miles barrier-free, paved pathway with beautiful forest scenery and shelter houses.

name: Ocqueoc Falls State Forest Campground
description: State Forest Pathways: Ocqueoc Falls Bicentennial Pathway(on site): 6 miles, 3 loops. Beautiful view of Ocqueoc Falls. Hike, bike.

name: Chief Plenty Coups State Park
description: Chief Plenty Coups State Park is the original home and farmstead of Chief Plenty Coups of the Crow tribe, renowned for his bravery and leadership. The National Historic Landmark park is located on the Crow Indian Reservation. The park offers interpretive programs and trails.

name: Onaway State Park
description: The park's three-mile nature trail allows hikers to view all the natural features of the park and surrounding areas.

name: Elk Rock Island
description: Elk Rock Island is a small, 13.24-acre park in Portland, Oregon. This park is the remains of an ancient volcano that erupted about 40 million years ago. This park sits on the Williamette River and activities here include hiking and wildlife viewing.

name: Tryon Creek State Natural Area
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Maricara Natural Area
description: In fall 2010, 1,500 feet of new natural-surface trails and 2,600 feet of improved trails were opened. Located in a residential neighborhood, the site includes a wetland, protected stream, important native plant species, and an older second-growth forest.  Includes natural area, and trails - hiking.

name: Marshall Park
description: Marshall Park is primarily a natural area developed with hiking trails located in the middle of a 400-foot-wide canyon. The canyon is a natural drainage basin formed by the west slope of the Palatine Hills, the hills northwest of Mt Sylvania, and by Tryon Creek that runs through it. Within the park is a waterfall framed by rock boulders. One of the notable features of the trail system is a small stone bridge which spans Tryon Creek.

name: Sheep Creek to Carmen Creek
description:
This hike starts along the road, left at the first intersection onto an ATV road that soon ends at the actual CDT. About 2 miles. <br />
<br />
From here the trail climbs in the basin at the base of Pyramid Peak and then up on to an exposed ridge. It is a beautiful hike with some amazing trail building underfoot.<br />
<br />
Trail leaves the ridge and crosses the head of Fourth of July drainage where you come to a series of alpine meadows. <br />
<br />
The next saddle, the trail crosses into Montana and the head of Big Lake Creek. Here you contour across this basin and trail cairns mark the way. Just beyond a nameless lake the trail climbs to a saddle then descends steeply to a trail junction (Big Lake Creek Trail to Twin Lakes)<br />
<br />
Trail climbs from this junction back onto the divide and another junction. To the west is Carmen Creek Trail and CDT continues from here across the base of Squaw Mtn and on to Slag-a-Melt Lakes.

name: Continental Divide Trail; Upper Sheep Creek To Carmen Creek
description: Continental Divide Trail; Upper Sheep Creek To Carmen Creek is a 21 mile hiking trail in Salmon, Idaho.

name: Woods Memorial Natural Area
description: About 98% of the landscape is native including oaks, Douglas fir, cedar, willow, red and blue elderberry, Oregon grape, trillium, thimbleberry, and others. This steeply sloped site is part of the Fanno Watershed, containing the headwaters of the two forks of Woods Creek. Although most of the park was logged about one hundred years ago, there are still some historic trees. It offers a natural setting that attracts wildlife in the quiet woods, along the creek, and in the meadow.  Includes natural area, paths - unpaved, and trails - hiking.

name: Mina Lake Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Tideman Johnson Natural Area
description: Tideman Johnson Natural Area is named after an early pioneer family who once owned this wilderness area. It is nestled right alongside a natural gorge along the banks of Johnson Creek and activities here are limited to hiking.

name: Hoeft State Park
description: The park features 4.5 miles of trails running through gently rolling, mixed hardwood/conifer forest as well as along the Lake Huron shoreline. There are many wildflowers to view, especially in the spring.

name: Hagg Lake
description: Hagg Lake features 14 miles of hiking trails near Forest Grove, OR.

name: Springwater Corridor
description: Excellent hiking, walking and jogging.

name: Oaks Bottom Wildlife Refuge
description: Oaks Bottom is a floodplain wetland located along the east bank of the Willamette River. Part of the park is built on a sanitation landfill consisting of 400,000 cubic feet of construction waste material layered with soil. The City of Portland acquired the landfill property from the Donald M. Drake Company at the beginning of 1969 to block its development as an industrial park. The area was believed, at the time, to be one of the few remaining marshland areas in Portland, and local residents were strongly opposed to its development as industrial property.

name: George Himes Park
description: George Himes Park is named after George Himes who was a pioneer Portlander, printer and historian. This park is 32 acres and has opportunities for picnicking and hiking.

name: Appalachian Trail 161: West Branch of Pleasant River to Nahmakanta Lake
description:
Section 161 of the Appalachian Trail runs 43.4 miles from the west branch of the Pleasant River to Nahmakanta Lake. As such, it is the longest section of the Appalachian Trail as it is divided by the official Appalachian Trail guidebooks. <br />
<br />
Along the way, the trail passes the Carl A. Newhall Lean-to, West Peak, White Cap Mountain, the Logan Brook Lean-to, the East Branch Lean-to, Big Boardman Mountain, Little Boardman Mountain, Kokadjo B Pond Road, Crawford Pond, the Cooper Brook Falls Lean-to, Church Pond, Jo Mary Road, Cooper Pond, Mud Pond, Lower Jo-Mary Lake, Potaywadjo Spring Lean-to, and Pemadumcook Lake.

name: Emerald Lake
description: Emerald Lake features 10 miles of hiking trails near Bozeman, MT.

name: Cape Meares State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Cape Meares has over 3 miles of hiking trails and a mile-long walking trail that winds through old-growth spruce trees, including the uniquely-shaped Octopus Tree. A Short quarter mile hike from a turn off at the park entrance will bring you the the largest Stika spruce tree in the state of Oregon.

name: Powell Butte Nature Park
description: Powell Butte Nature Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Portland, OR.

name: Terwilliger Parkway
description: Terwilliger Parkway is a 99-acre, city-owned park in Portland, Oregon. This park is a great get-away from city life as there is more space than other city-parks, and activities here include hiking, mountain biking and trail running.

name: Maple Bay State Forest Campground
description: Maple Bay State Forest Campground is a fantastic location for camping, fishing, hiking, mountain biking, ATV riding and wildlife observing. The campground has 38 tent and small trailer sites and great boat access and fishing. There are vault toilets and hand pump water that is potable.

name: Wilson River Trail
description: Wilson River Trail features 30 miles of hiking trails near Tillamook Forest, OR.

name: Marquam Nature Park
description: Marquam Nature Park includes a portion of the Marquam Trail, a linear trail and connection in the 40-mile Loop system, that starts at Willamette Park, passes over Council Crest, and connects with the Wildwood Trail in Washington Park. This natural area park supports an abundance of native plant species, and contains many trails that wind around Marquam Hill, through trees such as Douglas fir, western hemlock, red cedar, and bigleaf maples. There is a shelter with interpretive displays and maps near the entrance.

name: Kelly Butte Natural Area
description: This site is named after pioneer Clinton Kelly, who settled this donation land claim east of the Willamette river in 1848.  Includes natural area, and trails - hiking.

name: Pickerel Lake Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Hoyt Arboretum
description: Includes arboretum, disabled access picnic area, disabled access restroom, gift shop, natural area, paths - unpaved, picnic shelter, picnic site - reservable, trails - hiking, visitor attraction, and wedding site - reservable.

name: Washington Park
description: Includes disabled access play area, disabled access restroom, fountain, historical site, paths - paved, paths - unpaved, Pay to Park, picnic shelter, picnic site - reservable, picnic tables, playground, soccer field, stage, statue or public art, tennis court, tennis court - lighted, trails - hiking, visitor attraction, vista point, and wedding site - reservable.

name: Revheim Bay Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Aloha State Park
description: Mackinaw to Hawks Rails to Trails runs through Aloha State Park. The primary surface of the trail is gravel. During the summer this trail is non-motorized and used for hiking, equestrian, and biking. During the winter months the trail is groomed for snowmobiling.

name: Eastbank Esplanade
description: Great trails.

name: Pittock Mansion Acres
description: Once the private home of the Portland pioneer Pittock family, this 22-room house was designed by architect Edward Foulkes and completed in 1914. The mansion sits 1,000 feet above sea level on 46 acres and commands a view of five mountains in the Cascade Range. It is an outstanding architectural achievement with its eclectic design of circular rooms, combining fine plasterwork, cut and polished marbles, cast bronze, and superbly crafted hardwoods and paneling. Its progressive features included a central vacuum system, intercoms, and indirect lighting hidden in alcoves above the walls. The house is completely furnished with antique furniture and objets d'art, including family artifacts, appropriate to its 17th, 18th, and 19th century French and English designs.  Includes gift shop, historical site, museum, paths - paved, picnic tables, statue or public art, tours - guided, trails - hiking, visitor attraction, and vista point.

name: Macleay Park
description:
Part of the trail system that runs through Macleay Park used to be a portion of a flume that was used for mining--it was replaced by the trails that exist there today.

The park is located just a few minutes from the hubbub of the city, but you would never know. There are plenty of trails that extend through this park, one of which follows a creek that winds through the dense forest.

name: Indian Creek Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Teepee Mt. Saddle / Natural Bridge
description: Tepee Mt. Saddle / Natural Bridge features 6 miles of hiking trails near Big Timber, MT.

name: Guy  W. Talbot State Park
description: The tiny town of Latourell (pop. 12) borders the north side of the park. Homeowners ask that visitors please respect their privacy. A trail underneath the Historic Columbia River Highway bridge leads directly to Latourelle Falls (250' tall), only a few minutes away by foot.

name: Glacial Lakes State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Twin Lakes State Forest Campground
description: Black Mountain (6 miles SE): 30-mile complex of pathways through rolling to hilly terrain, hiking, biking, cross-country skiing, and horseback riding. Includes 1.3 miles barrier-free, paved pathway with beautiful forest scenery and shelter houses.

name: Lewis and Clark State Recreation Site
description: Good hiking trail.

name: Shepperd's Dell State Natural Area
description: Hiking trail to the falls.

name: Rocky Butte Natural Area
description: Includes historical site, natural area, paths - unpaved, statue or public art, trails - hiking, and vista point.

name: Richmond Lake Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Lake Hiddenwood Recreation Area
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Emigrant Springs State Heritage Area
description: Excellent trails.

name: Rooster Rock State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: CDT ID12: Gibbonsville Road to Chief Joseph Trailhead and MT Hwy 43
description: The 12th and final section of the CDT along the Idaho/Montana border runs for 16.6 miles from Gibbonsville Road to the Chief Joseph trailhead on Montana Highway 43. Along the way, the trail crosses the Idaho/Montana border several times and passes Anderson Mountain.

name: Bridal Veil Falls State Scenic Viewpoint
description: Bridal Veil Falls Tail is a short but steep hike on a well maintained trail. The trail begins at the top and works its way to the base of the falls. Several view points are available. The trail then retraces back up the hill.

name: Holeb Public Reserved Land
description:
Holeb Public Reserved Land hosts a very popular three-day canoe trip that carries visitors through the center of this 20,000-acre area. Wildlife observation is a popular activity at this park, it boasts the opportunity to see Moose and/or loons.

Other visitors enjoy camping, hiking, fishing, hunting, swimming and birdwatching.

The trails at Holeb Public Reserved Land begin here, but pass through private property. The private area are not maintained by the Bureau of Parks and Lands.

name: Wild River State Park
description: The Wild River State Park's highlights include camping, cross-country skiing, a dam overlook, canoeing and beautiful wild flowers.  Group camping, equestrian camping and modern camping are all offered and very popular here. A 35-mile trail system is available for the avid hiker or cross-country skier.

name: Lily Bay State Park
description: Lily Bay State Park is located directly beside Maine's largest lake. Because of this, water sports such as swimming, fishing, boating, canoeing and more are very popular at this park. The park is also home to the Mt. Kineo, an impressive landmark with five miles of hiking trails and views; the Big Moose Mountain, a 3,196 ft tall summit with 3.75 miles of hiking; and Big Spencer Mountain, at 3,205 feet this summit offers a 2-mile trail  with a 1,000 ft climb in elevation. In addition to these brilliant landmarks, there are many more. This is a fantastic destination for an hiker, picnicker or camper.

name: Whitaker Ponds Nature Park
description: Natural area with å_ mile walking trail, ecoroof-covered gazebo, observation dock, canoe launch into Whitaker Slough, wildflower meadow, and Lewis & Clark Garden.

name: Multnomah Falls Trail
description: Multnomah Falls are one of the most photographed falls around. At the trailhead is a gift shop and facilities.  The Falls can be seen from the start of the trail, but those adventurous enough can take the trail to the top of the falls for the overlook, or connect to further trails that travel up the gorge.

name: Leverich Trail
description: Leverich Trail features 6 miles of hiking trails near Bozeman, MT.

name: Government Island State Recreation Area
description: Great hiking.

name: Forest Park - Leif Erikson Drive
description: Miles and miles of hiking trails in the largest forested city park in the US. Choose from multiple trails and trailheads through the densely forested and rugged slopes. Trails are well signed and maintained.

name: Peninsula Crossing Trail
description: Trails offers hiking and cycling.

name: Deschutes River State Recreation Area
description: The Atiyeh Deschutes River Trail at river level is a favorite jaunt for hikers on hot summer days. You just can't beat the cool river and the shade of white alder trees (and while you're resting, look for the hanging basket-type nests built by the orioles).

name: Mystic Lake
description: Mystic Lake features 18 miles of hiking trails near Bozeman, MT.

name: Straight Lake State Park
description: The park is open to the public for foot traffic only. No motorized vehicles, bikes or horses are allowed. The Ice Age National Scenic Trail winds through the middle of the park along the Straight River and Straight Lake.

name: Ainsworth State Park
description: Hiking is definitely something you'll want to do while camping at Ainsworth State Park.

name: University Falls Trail
description: Short hike through fir and spruce forest.  The trail winds for about .5 miles out to a 65 foot waterfall.  Located in the Tillamook State Forest.

name: Round Lake
description: Round Lake  features 2 miles of hiking trails near Camas, WA.

name: Lost Cabin Lake
description: Lost Cabin Lake features 9 miles of hiking trails near Whitehall, MT.

name: John B. Yeon State Scenic Corridor
description: Here is a hiker's paradise with a gentle rising trail that permits access to two of the most beautiful and secluded waterfalls in the Columbia River Gorge: (lower) Elowah Falls and (upper) McCord Creek falls. Elowah Falls is a 289 foot drop over basalt that must be seen to appreciate. The view of the falls and way the tall cliffs jut out at odd angles is nearly disorienting at the bottom of the trail. Most days, the trails are never crowded. The crisp air, easy access and accompanying scenery of this area offer some of the best hiking and viewing opportunities available in the Gorge.

name: Wallowa and Grande Ronde Wild and Scenic Rivers
description: For a scenic float trip with family and friends, try exploring the remote Wallowa and Grande Ronde rivers. Boaters will enjoy the slow transition of scenery as they float from the steep-walled canyons and evergreen forests of the Oregon section into the arid, rocky grasslands and unique geology of the lower river in Washington. Make sure to take time to enjoy the primitive camping, wildlife viewing, fishing, and bird watching along this 91-mile long river corridor. Class III rapids offer whitewater excitement along the way, and multiple river access points allow you to customize your trip itinerary. These rivers will provide you a journey that you will never forget. Self-issue river permits, portable toilets, and firepans are required. State boating laws also apply. Scouting of all rapids is always advised. For current river conditions and more information, please call the River Station at Minam: 541-437-5580.

name: Storey Burn
description: Storey Burn features 4 miles of hiking trails near Forest Grove, OR.

name: Beacon Rock State Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Bonneville Lock and Dam
description: Great trails in the Hamilton Island Recreation Area.

name: Cheboygan State Park
description: Several well-marked trails allow hikers to see expansive vistas of the Lake Huron shoreline and inland natural areas.

name: Kelley Point Park
description: Paved and unpaved trails.

name: The Dalles Lock and Dam - Lake Celilo
description: The Dalles Dam is 192 miles upstream from the mouth of the Columbia River, two miles east of the city of The Dalles, Oregon. The dam extends 1.5 miles from the Oregon shore to the navigation lock on the Washington shore. The project consists of a navigation lock, spillway, powerhouse and fish passage facilities. Various recreational facilities are provided along Lake Celilo, the 24-mile long lake behind the dam. There is a visitor center available focusing on the project and the region with interpretive displays and Park Rangers on site to answer questions.

name: Banks-Vernonia State Trail
description: The trail is open to all non-motorized users ... horse, bicycle, and walkers/hikers.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: H: Hwy 14 (Oregon/Washington state line) to Hwy 12
description:
Section H of the Pacific Crest Trail is the first section in Washington State. It runs 147.5 miles from Highway 14 at Bridge of the Gods (the Oregon/Washington state line) to Highway 12 near White Pass. Since this section is so long, it passes through a number of different environments and passes many exception mountain peaks, including the occasionally active volcano Mt. Adams. This section begins at 180 feet above sea level and ends at 7,080 feet, so be prepared for some climbing.<br />
<br />
Along the way this section of trail passes Gillette Lake, Greenleaf Creek, Table Mtn., Road 2090, Road 2000, Rock Creek, Snag Creek, Road 2070, Trout Creek, Road 417, Wind River Ranger Station, Little Soda Springs Road 54, Wind River, Road 6517, Panther Creek Road 65, Panther Creek, Road 68, Cedar Creek, Big Huckleberry Mountain summit trail, Road 60 at the back of the Crest Campground, Green Lake, Blue Lake, Deer Lake, Sawtooth Mountain, Road 24, Road 8851, Road 88, Trout Lake Creek, Road 8810, Road 23, Road 521, Swampy Creek, White Salmon River, Sheep Lake, Riley Creek, Mutton Creek, Lewis River, Killen Creek, Muddy Fork, trailside Lava Spring, Road 5603, Road 115, Midway Creek, Walupt Creek, Sheep Lake, Cispus Pass, Cispus River, Lutz Lake, Tieton Pass, Chairlift Trail, and Ginnette Lake.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: Washington
description:
The Pacific Crest Trail runs for 510 miles through the state of Washington, from the Oregon border in the south to its terminus in BC. <br />
Click on the links to the individual trail listings for detailed information about each section.

name: Columbia Hills State Park
description: Columbia Hills State Park features 12 miles of hiking trails near Dallesport, WA.

name: Maryhill State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Tuscobia State Trail
description: The entire trail is open to walking and bicycling, though bicycling is not recommended. The trail is not groomed or surfaced and may be rough or soft in many sections. If you plan to bike the trail, the tread is more suitable for off-road bikes.

name: Continental Divide To 3 Mile Ridge
description: Continental Divide To 3 Mile Ridge is a 17 mile hiking trail in Gibbonsville, Idaho.

name: Three Mile Ridge
description: Three Mile Ridge features 18 miles of hiking trails near North Fork, ID.

name: Continental Divide Trail: Montana
description:
The Continental Divide Trail is 3,100 miles long, stretching from Mexico to Canada and roughly following the continental divide. It is a part of the Triple Crown of long distance hiking trails in the US, along with the Pacific Crest Trail and Appalachian Trail. It is still under construction, so sections of it are constantly changing. The information posted here on Tripleblaze is the most up-to-date available, but these trail descriptions and GPS locations may become obsolete at some point in the future. If you notice any obsolete information, always feel free to post a review with the new info!

Whenever possible, the Google Maps location given for each section of trail will be for the most southern point. All sections are numbered in a south-to-north fashion.

The Montana section of the CDT runs roughly 650 miles through the wild mountains of Montana from where it leaves the Idaho border until it reaches Canada. About 110 miles of this section of the CDT is located along <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/hiking-trails/Montana/Glacier-National-Park_2997">Glacier National Park</a>. Also, the CDT runs for about 327 miles along the Idaho/Montana border, where it switches back and forth between the two states on a regular basis. Many of those sections are listed under the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3202/Idaho/Continental-Divide-Trail--Idaho.html">Idaho Section of the CDT</a>.

To follow the trail to the south, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3202/Idaho/Continental-Divide-Trail--Idaho.html">Idaho section</a> and/or the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/hiking-trails/Wyoming/Continental-Divide-Trail--Wyoming_3203">Wyoming section</a>.

name: CDT MT01: Chief Joseph Trailhead and Hwy 43 to Schultz Saddle and NF-1203
description:
At the Chief Joseph Trailhead, the CDT leaves the Idaho/Montana border and heads north through the Montana mountains. Note: the trailhead is technically just over the border in Idaho.<br />
<br />
Section 1 of the CDT in Montana runs for 18.2 miles from the Chief Joseph Trailhead and Hwy 43 to Schultz Saddle and NF-1203. Along the way, the trail passes the Lost Trail Ski Area.

name: Starvation Creek State Park
description: Trails spreading out from this day-use park lead onto adjacent National Forest Service land and connect to the Mt. Defiance and Starvation Ridge trails. Heading east, trek along a remnant of the Historic Columbia River Highway to Viento State Park and campground.

name: Historic Columbia River Highway State Trail
description:
Between Hood River and Mosier, the five mile Twin Tunnels segment passes through two climate zones. Starting at the east Mark O. Hatfield Trailhead near Mosier, the trail leads through semiarid terrain dotted with Ponderosa pine for about a mile until you reach the Twin Tunnels. Spectacular geologic formations tell the story of the gorge's creation.

After passing through the tunnels, you'll emerge into a forest of fir trees and other common western Oregon plants. Viewpoints along the 3.5 mile segment from the tunnels to the west Mark O. Hatfield Trailhead overlook the river.

name: Lost Trail-twin Creeks Ridge
description: Lost Trail-twin Creeks Ridge features 13 miles of hiking trails near Salmon, ID.

name: Scapoose
description: Scapoose features 8 miles of hiking trails near Scapoose, OR.

name: Viento State Park
description: A one-mile, fully handicapped accessible trail from Viento to the Starvation Creek waterfall takes you along a section of the Historic Columbia River Highway. Now a hiking trail, there hasn't been auto traffic here in more than 50 years. If you get a chance to visit, imagine an old Ford Model T twisting around the corners!

name: Capri Lake
description: Capri Lake features 16 miles of hiking trails near Darby, MT.

name: Wygant State Natural Area
description: This park adjoins Seneca Fouts Memorial and Vinzenz Lausmann near Mitchell Point 5 miles west of Hood River on Interstate 84. A trail strikes through the park in a dense, hilly wilderness area that was once the old Oregon Trail and later the Historic Columbia River Highway. The first mile of this trail is on pavement that hasn't had an automobile on it for 50 years (it still has the yellow divider stripe). As it moves into the wilderness, Wygant trail penetrates a dense forest hillside along a gurgling creek. It is an ideal spot for backpackers who are looking for a little solitude.

name: Vinzenz Lausmann Memorial State Natural Area
description: Great hiking.

name: Mount Kineo State Park
description:
Mount Kineo State Park is home of the 1,789-foot Mount Kineo. The dramatic cliff face and fantastic views make it a common destination for visitors at the Moosehead Lake.

A boat shuttle brings visitors from Rockwood. Hiking, fishing, boating and birdwatching are popular here.

name: Seneca Fouts Memorial State Natural Area
description: Nice hiking trail.

name: Roy Lake State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Echo Hills Vinyard Mtb Trail System
description: Echo Hills Vinyard Mtb Trail System features 21 miles of hiking trails near Echo Oregon, OR.

name: Hospital Hill
description: Hospital Hill features 12 miles of hiking trails near White Salmon, WA.

name: Fayette Historic State Park
description: Five miles of hiking trails wind through beech and maple hardwood forests and throughout the historic townsite. Visitors will enjoy scenic views from the overlook trail.

name: Nahmakanta Public Reserved Land
description:
Nahmakanta Public Reserved Land is a beautifully well-preserved land open to the public for a variety of recreational opportunities. Hiking, camping, wildlife observing, hunting, fishing, snowmobiling, canoeing and kayaking are all enjoyed in abundance here. The land encompasses 43,000 acres of forests, mountains, streams and rolling hills. ATV riders and horseback riders are also welcome here at several of the many trails provided by the park.


28 miles of hiking trails, in addition to 9 miles along a highly scenic stretch of the Appalachian Trail are offered for hiking.

name: Pictograph Cave State Park
description: The park has a pleasant 1/4 loop trail to the caves, with interpretative displays along the route identifying and explaining the natural features, the prehistoric paintings and vegetation found in the area.

name: Appalachian Trail 162: Nahmakanta Lake to Abol Bridge
description: The AT runs 25.7 miles from Nahmakanta Lake to Abol Bridge. Along the way, the trail passes the Wadleigh Stream Lean-to, Nesuntabunt Mountain, Pollywog Stream, the Rainbow Stream Lean-to, Rainbow Lake, Rainbow Mountain, the Hurd Brook Lean-to, and Golden Road.

name: Portage Bay State Forest Campground
description: Ninga Aki (on site): 2.25 miles of flat terrain with interpretive information on local natural resources and Ojibwa Native American life.

name: L.L. Stub Stewart State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Moosehead Lake Public Reserved Land
description:
Moosehead Lake Public Reserved Land is made up of an eastern and western shore, both of which have different recreational opportunities. The Moosehead Lake is New England's largest freshwater body and it offers camping, fishing, hunting, paddling, hiking, paddling, snowmobiling and cross-country skiing opportunities. It is a park for every season with fishing and birdwatching in the spring; hiking, boating and camping in the summer; photography and sight-seeing in the fall; and ice-fishing, snowshoeing and cross-country skiing in the winter.

The Mt. Kineo and Little Kineo hiking trails are popular attractions.

name: Beaver Island State Forest Campground
description: Many hiking & biking opportunities on island roads.

name: Wilderness State Park
description: More than 16 miles stretch across the East Boundary, South Boundary, Nebo, Sturgeon Bay, Swamp Line and Big Stone trails. These trails are shared with all bicycles, including mountain bikes. The North Country Trail includes 10 miles within the state park, including the Red Pine Trail. This national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes more than 1,500 miles in Michigan.

name: Fort Sisseton Historic State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: Bearskin State Trail
description: The level grade and surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers.

name: Bangtail Divide
description: Bangtail Divide features 24 miles of hiking trails near Bozeman, MT.

name: Oswald West State Park
description: Excellent trails. Oswald West State Park offers miles of hiking trails in this 2,484 acre park.  A 13-mile stretch of the Oregon Coast Trail weaves its way through the entire park, starting at the community of Arch Cape and extending south towards the town of Manzanita.

name: Governor Knowles State Forest
description: The Governor Knowles State Forest Hiking Trail consists of two trails totalling 38 miles along the St. Croix River, a 22 mile trail on the north end of the property and a 16 mile trail on the south end. The trails meander along the top of the bluffs overlooking the St. Croix River and occasionally swing down onto the banks of the river. Both trails pass through scenic wilderness areas along the bluffs of the St. Croix River. Trails vary in difficulty. Parking lots are at major road intersections.

name: CDT MT02: Schultz Saddle and NF-1203 to Johnson Lake
description: Section 2 of the CDT in Montana runs for 31.4 miles from Schultz Saddle and NF-1203 to Johnson Lake. Along the way, the trail passes Bender Point, Hope Lake, West Pintler Peak, and East Pintler Peak.

name: Menominee River State Recreation Area
description: The large 9,767-acre park is a beautiful area on an undeveloped river. Fishing and canoeing are excellent here. Hiking and wildlife observing are also popular.

name: Grassy Mountain Loop
description: Grassy Mountain Loop features 16 miles of hiking trails near Bozeman, MT.

name: Zimmerman Trail
description: Zimmerman Trail is a 15 mile hiking trail in Billings, Montana.

name: Battle Ground Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Phipps Park
description: Phipps Park features 3 miles of hiking trails near Billings, MT.

name: Lewis & Clark Caverns State Park
description: Popular hiking area.

name: Appalachian Trail 163: Abol Bridge to Katahdin
description:
The 163rd section of the Appalachian Trail runs 15.1 miles from Abol Bridge to its northern terminus on the 5,267 foot summit of Mount Katahdin. If you are a north-bound thru-hiker, reaching Mount Katahdin means that you are finally finished with your trek! <br />
<br />
Of course, if you are south bound, this will be the first section of the Appalachian Trail that you will hike. To read all of the AT section descriptions, just cycle backwards through the numbers.<br />
Along the way to the summit of Katahdin, the trail passes Daicy Pond Campground Day Use Parking, Grassy Pond, Katahdin Stream Campground Day Use Parking Lot, and The Birches Lean-tos.
