name: Lake Elmo State Park
description: Nature trail.

name: Mackinac Island and Fort Mackinac Historic Park
description: Mackinac Island State Park is a historic area marked by the Fort Mackinac that was built in 1780. The 1,800-acre area is a popular destination for walkers, cyclers, hikers and horseback riders. This fort is Michigan's only war-era fort. Since the site is located on Lake Michigan, swimming is also popular.

name: Lime Island State Recreation Area
description: The 900-acre Lime Island State Recreation Area  c/o Straits State Park is an excellent location for fishing, hunting, hiking, canoeing, camping and walking.  Tent camping is also available: It is very primitive. Two to three bedroom cottages are also available for renting-- they have access to water and electricity.

name: Straits State Park
description: A hiking trail runs through the park. One end, has a viewing platform with an overlook of the Straits of Mackinac and Mackinac Bridge. The other end has a different view of the Mackinac Bridge.

name: Father Marquette National Memorial
description: Great scenic views.

name: Toll Canyon
description: Toll Canyon features 9 miles of hiking trails near Butte, MT.

name: Gandy Dancer State Trail - Northern Segment
description: The northern segment of the Gandy Dancer State Trail begins on the Minnesota side of the St. Croix River. The trail runs for 31 miles in Minnesota and then crosses back into Douglas County for 15 miles.

name: Gandy Dancer State Trail - Southern Segment
description: The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. A state trail pass is required for bicycling on some sections of the trail. You can buy annual and daily passes from designated vendors along the trail or at the Polk and Burnett County tourism centers.

name: Paradise Point State Park
description: Paradise Point State Park was acquired in six parcels between 1958 and 1986. Two stories claim credit for the park's name. In one story, local tribes used the area for encampment along the east of the Lewis River and called it "Paradise Point." In another, a motorboat club from Portland, Oregon used to travel to Kaner Rock on the Lewis River for river trips and camping. They called the quiet, peaceful area "Paradise Point."

name: Sica Hollow State Park
description: The scenic George S. Mickelson Trail stretches over one hundred miles through the Black Hills. The gentle slopes and easy access of the converted railroad track allow people of all ages and abilities to enjoy the beauty of the Black HIlls.

name: CDT MT05: I-15 to I-90
description: Section 5 of the CDT in Montana runs for 35.7 miles from I-15 to I-90. Along the way, the trail passes MT Hwy 91, Highland Rd, Burton Park Trail, Limekiln Hill, MT Hwy 2, Beaver Ponds Trail, and Upper Rader Creek Rd.

name: Raven Trails
description: Raven Trails features 0 miles of hiking trails near Minocqua, WI.

name: Hat Rock State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: CDT MT06: I-90 to I-15
description: Section 6 of the CDT in Montana travels for 29.1 miles from I-90 to another crossing with I-15 that is much farther north than the previous crossing. Along the way, the trail passes Goldflint Mountain, Delmo Lake, Whitetail Peak, and Nez Perce Road.

name: Madison Buffalo Jump State Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Missouri Headwaters State Park
description: Numerous foot trails to explore.

name: Rapid River Trail Camp
description: Direct access along the North Country Trail.

name: Ecola State Park
description: Ecola's trails offer cliff side viewpoints of secluded coves, forested promontories and even a long abandoned lighthouse.  The park's network of trails include an 8 mile segment of the Oregon Coast Trail, and a 2 1/2 mile historical interpretive route called the Clatsop Loop Trail.  Part of the Clatsop Loop Trail and the trail over Tillamook Head follow in the footsteps of the Corps of Discovery.  Captain William Clark and 12 members of the Corps of Discovery traveled through what is now the park in 1806 in search of a beached whale near present-day Cannon Beach.

name: Lake Wallula State Park
description: Lake Wallula State Park is located in northeastern Oregon and southeastern Washington. It is located at the site of the McNary Dam and offers hiking, mountain biking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Brooks Memorial State Park
description: Hikers should bring a day-pack with first-aid supplies, map and compass and/or GPS. Please contact a ranger for hiking information.

name: Forest Lake State Forest Campground
description: Au Train Songbird Trail (7 miles North): Interpretive Trail with songbird tour cassettes available in the city of Au Train (10 miles North).

name: Canoe Lake State Forest Campground
description: Gemini Lake (3 miles NW): 1.5 miles of flat terrain.

name: Fox River State Forest Campground
description: Fox River (on site): 27.5 miles of flat to hilly terrain from campground following the Little Fox and Fox Rivers to Kingston Lake State Forest Campground. Hike, mountain bike, fishing, nature observation.

name: Bible Point
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: CDT MT03: Johnson Lake to Seymour Campground Trailhead
description:
Section 3 of the CDT in Montana runs for 34.3 miles from Johnson Lake to the Seymour Campground Trailhead. Along the way, the trail passes McGlaughlin Peak, Warren Peak, Martin Lake, Johnson Lake, Rainbow Lake, West Goat Peak, Long Peak, Warren Lake, Beaverhead Mountain, Marche Peak, Fish Peak, Queener Mountain, Kurt Peak, Page Lake, Rainbow Mountain, Goat Flat, Mount Tiny, Upper Seymour Lake, Mount Howe, and Mount Evans.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=45.9911924101, lon=-113.183149621

name: Charles A. Lindbergh State Park
description: Scenic trails, some adjacent to creek.

name: Saddle Mountain State Natural Area
description: The main trail is steep and difficult in spots, with a 1603 feet rise in elevation over 2.5 miles.  It is recommended for experienced hikers wearing proper footwear and clothing.  Weather conditions can change rapidly, bringing wind and rain year round and snow in winter.  Portions of the trail can be slick in wet conditions.  The challenge this popular trail provides is well worth the reward.

name: St. Croix State Park
description: Easy trails that extend through the park and along the river.

name: Sherman to Patten Trail
description: The Sherman to Patten multi-use trail is 6 miles long and meanders through open fields, forested areas and along the perimeter of Thousand Acre Bog. Riders will find a gravel surface trail that is open to multiple use, year round. Most of this trail is very remote and riders should be prepared for a backcountry experience.

name: CDT MT04: Seymour Campground Trailhead to I-15
description: Section 4 of the CDT in Montana runs for 43.9 miles from the Seymour Campground Trailhead to I-15. Along the way, the trail passes Big Hole Road, Deep Creek, Burnt Mountain, and Divide Creek Road.

name: Lake Carlos State Park
description: Rolling hills. Takes you through forested areas, mature hardwoods. Great for fall hiking.

name: Lewis River
description: Lewis River features 14 miles of hiking trails near Cougar, WA.

name: Bennington Lake
description: Bennington Lake is located in southeastern Washington minutes from historic downtown Walla Walla, Washington's oldest city. Enjoy beautiful views of the northern Blue Mountains and the open space surrounding the lake. Bennington Lake, while small, offers plenty of fun, safe, and relaxing times. Tour local wineries and taste the world famous Walla Walla sweet onions (summers only). Take a short trip to the Whitman Mission National Historic Site and Interpretive Center just west of Walla Walla along Highway 12.

name: Wild Rivers State Trail
description: The entire trail is open to walking and bicycling, though bicycling is not recommended. The trail may be rough or soft in many sections. If you plan to bike the trail, the tread is more suitable for off-road bikes.

name: Glidden Lake State Forest Campground
description: Lake Mary Plains (on site): 10 miles of rolling terrain.

name: Gene's Pond State Forest Campground
description: Gene's Pond Pathway (on site): 2.3 miles of rolling terrain.

name: Hog Island Point State Forest Campground
description: Big Knob/Crow Lake (20 miles SW): 1/4 mile Big Knob loop, 2.5 mile Crow Lake. Hike and mountain bike.

name: Nicolet State Trail
description: The entire trail is open to walking and bicycling, though bicycling is not recommended. The trail may be rough or soft in many sections and walkers and bikers must share the trail with motorized vehicles. If you plan to bike the trail, the tread is more suitable for off-road bikes.

name: Fields Spring State Park
description: The variety of wildflowers make for an enchanting hike.

name: Northern Highland-American Legion State Forest
description: Hiking is a good way to get close to nature and understand your natural environment a little better. In addition to our four nature trails, the NHAL has seven other trails designated for hiking. There are also hundreds of miles of old logging roads, less traveled town roads, forest access roads and snowmobile trails that offer good hiking.

name: Milakokia Lake State Forest Campground
description: Milakokia Lake State Forest Campground is home to 35 tent and trailer sites, some of which can accommodate a 40-ft trailer. Boating and fishing on the Milakokia Lake are very popular activities. Hiking and mountain biking are also common here. The sites are rustic so there are only vault toilets and potable pump water available.

name: Bewabic State Park
description: A trail begins in the campground and leads to the day use area. Benches along the route allow hikers time to stop and appreciate the natural areas. The trail takes about one hour to hike.

name: Carney Lake State Forest Campground
description: Merriman East (4 miles North): 9.5 miles of rolling terrain. Hike, mountain bike, the first 3.3 miles maintained for cross-country skiing.

name: CDT MT07: I-15 to Unnamed Forest Road
description: Section 7 of the CDT in Montana runs for 10.5 miles from I-15 to an unnamed forest road. Along the way, the trail runs along Lowland Road, Hail Columbia Road some other back roads, before becoming a trail again.

name: Ape Cave
description: You can hike this as a loop with one portion above ground, the other below ground inside the lava tube cave. Bring a light or rent a lantern at the ranger facility at the trailhead (be sure to check seasonal hours before you head out). The hike inside the cave can be a little tricky so for the less adventurous there's a half mile out and back option underground. The above ground portion of the hike crosses exposed lava flows and offers glimpses of Mt. St. Helens above.

name: Mille Lacs Kathio State Park
description: These wooded trails take you to river, lake and beaver pond overlooks and through Kathio's rolling glacial moraines. Many trails are minimum maintenance during summer months.

name: Southern Bangor & Aroostook Trail
description: The Houlton to Phair Junction trail is 37 miles long and extends from Houlton through the Towns of Monticello, Bridgewater, Mars Hill, and loops through the southern edge of Presque Isle. Riders will find a hard gravel surface that is occasionally shared with logging trucks; riders should be aware of other vehicles on the trail and should yield right of way.

name: Shoepac Lake State Forest Campground
description: Sinkhole (on site): 2.5 miles of flat to rolling terrain through the interesting carst topography of the area's natural limestone sink holes. High Country (on site): Over 80 miles of varied terrain connecting 9 State Forest campgrounds winding through scenic back country.

name: Father Hennepin State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Banning State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: CDT MT08: Unnamed Forest Road to US Hwy 12
description:
Section 8 of the CDT in Montana runs for 66.1 miles from an unnamed forest road to US Highway 12. Along the way, the trail passes Kit Carson Road, Boulder R Road, Boulder Road, Road 5046, Thunderbolt Mountain, Bison Mountain, Okeefe Mountain, Treasure Mountain, and Jericho Mountain.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=46.2039800095, lon=-112.553097252

name: Trout Lake State Forest Campground
description: Trout Lake (on site): 2.7 miles of flat to slightly rolling terrain.

name: Rock Lake
description: Rock Lake features 12 miles of hiking trails near Cable, WI.

name: Sacajawea State Park
description: Sacajawea State Park is a 284-acre inland waters, day-use park at the confluence of the Snake and Columbia rivers. It features 9,100 feet of freshwater shoreline. The area is spread out with a big sky and excellent views of the two rivers as they flow together.

name: Sacagawea Heritage Trail
description: Sacagawea Heritage Trail features 22 miles of hiking trails near Tri-cities, WA.

name: Lost Creek State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Munuscong River State Forest Campground
description: Munuscong River State Forest Campground is located in Brimley State Park. The campground has 50 tent and small trailer sites, a few of which can accommodate a 40 ft trailer. The campground includes vault toilets and potable water from a well pump. Fishing, canoeing, mountain biking, hiking, ATV riding and wildlife observing are popular here.

name: Anderson Lake West State Forest Campground
description: Six miles of rolling terrain with access from campground.

name: Badger Mountain
description: Badger Mountain features 6 miles of hiking trails near Richland, WA.

name: Scraggly Lake Public Reserved Land
description: Hiking is one of the most popular activities here.

name: Winchester Lake State Park
description: Hiking the various looped trails is a popular pastime here.

name: Camp Wooten ELC
description: Beautiful forest for hiking.

name: Pike Lake State Forest Campground-Marquette
description: Anderson Lake (8 miles SE): 6  miles of rolling terrain with access from Anderson Lake State Forest Campground. Hiking, mountain biking, cross-country skiing.

name: Chamberlain Lake Public Reserved Land
description: Trails to the crests of two nearby peaks.

name: Crow Wing State Park
description: Trails wind through Old Crow Wing townsite, along Mississippi River, through wooded areas. Great scenic trails.

name: Elkhorn State Park
description: Elkhorn State Park marks the remnants of a 19th century mining town. This day-use park is an excellent place for photography, history, cycling, wildlife viewing and hiking.

name: North Horseshoe Lake State Forest Campground
description: West Branch (10 miles South): 1.4 miles of rolling terrain with trail head at West Branch State Forest Campground.

name: Cape Disappointment State Park
description: Significant nearby natural areas include Willapa Bay, Leadbetter Point and Beard's Hollow.

name: Lewis & Clark State Park
description: Excellent hiking at this historic site.

name: Lewis & Clark Trail State Park
description: The park is located on the historic Nimipooiskit trail that extends from the Rocky Mountains to the Pacific Ocean. Remnants of the trail can be observed near the park.

name: Seaquest State Park
description: 1 mile of ADA hiking.

name: Squaw Lake State Forest Campground
description: West Branch Pathway (13 miles South): 1.4 miles of rolling terrain with trail head at West Branch State Forest Campground. Hiking and mountain biking.

name: Glendalough State Park
description: Trail access from picnic area and trail center.

name: Natalie State Forest Campground
description: Natalie State Forest Campground has 12 tent and small trailer sites with vault toilets and potable water. The campground is also a great place to fish, mountain bike, canoe, hike, ATV and rest. The campground has a boat launch for public use and a 14 mile multi-use trail for hours of fun.

name: Copper Falls State Park
description: Copper Falls State Park has 17 miles of trails with several overlooks of the waterfalls.

name: Saunders State Trail
description: Saunders State Trail is 8 miles long and links with the Grandy Dancer State Trail. It begins near Saunders and continues on into Minnesota. Activities here include off-roading, hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, snowmobiling, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

name: Hells Gate State Park
description: Several excellent trails.

name: Perch Lake State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail is 5 miles north of this campground, and can be accessed at Muskollonge State Park: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Wagner Falls Scenic Site
description: The North Country Trail follows M-94 at Wagner Falls and enters the Hiawatha National Forest two miles west of the scenic site. This national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes more than 1,500 miles in Michigan.

name: Laughing Whitefish Falls Scenic Site
description: The North Country Trail runs through the north end of this scenic site with a side trail to the falls. This national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes more than 1,500 miles in Michigan.

name: Beaver Lake State Park
description: Beaver Lake State Park's non-motorized trail system covers 5.34 miles in a series of loops and several connecting segment trails that are open for hiking and biking. The Beaver Lake Nature Trail is a self-guided nature trail open to hiking only. Most of the trail system surface is either grass, dirt or hard-packed single-track, with manageable grades with only a few steeper sections.

name: North Country National Scenic Trail
description: North Country National Scenic TrailThe North Country National Scenic Trail is a premier hiking and backpacking trail that travels for more than 4,000 miles through seven northern states from Lake Sakakawea State Park in North Dakota to Crown Point, New York. The North Country trail is one of only eight National Scenic Trails in the United States and is also one of 42 designated Wisconsin state trails. In Wisconsin, the North Country Trail clips the northwest corner of the state for 200 miles, passing through Douglas, Bayfield, Ashland and Iron counties. The North Country Trail route crosses Wisconsin's western border at Minnesota's Jay Cooke State Park, and the trail crosses into Michigan's Upper Peninsula from Hurley to Ironwood via the U.S. Highway 2 bridge across the Montreal River.

name: Bond Falls Scenic Site
description: Great hiking area; 6 viewing areas on accessible boardwalk.

name: Brimley State Park
description: There are no established trails within the park, but a nearby abandoned railroad cooridor adjacent to the park provides opportunities for hiking and skiing in the winter.

name: Lake Superior State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail runs through this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Pirogue Island State Park
description: There are 2.8 miles of designated hiking trails, but the site is level and visitors can easily walk throughout the entire 269 acres.

name: Moose Lake State Park
description: Easy to moderate trails that wind through forest areas, meadows, along marshes and lakes. Trails loop around two wildlife ponds.

name: Nez Perce National Historical Park
description:
At a number of park sites there are short trails that allow visitors to interact with the park's resources.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Grand Island
description: Grand Island features 23 miles of hiking trails near Munising, MI.

name: Mississippi River - Gull Lake
description: Interpretive trails in Gull Lake Recreation Area.

name: Lake Gogebic State Park
description: Two mile scenic nature trail that loops back to the campgrounds.

name: East Branch of Fox River State Forest Campground
description: This campground has 19 sites for tent and small trailer rental. Vault toilets and potable water from well hand pump are located at the campground. Fishing, hiking, canoeing, off-roading and wildlife observing are popular activities here. Hiking on 27.5 miles of flat to hilly trails is a very common attraction to this park.

name: Agate Falls Scenic Site
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Badger State Trail
description: The Badger State Trail travels 40 miles between Madison and the Wisconsin-Illinois border while traversing farmlands, woods, rolling hills, scenic meadows, remnant prairies, ravines, glacial topography and several small communities. Highlighting the trail is the 1,200-foot long Stewart Tunnel. The tunnel is unique because it is built on a curve, and visitors cannot see the other end when first entering the tunnel. Flashlights and jackets are recommended as the tunnel is dark and cool, and water from springs above can trickle onto the trail. Bikers should walk bikes through the tunnel.

name: Cuyuna Lakes
description: Cuyuna Lakes features 25 miles of hiking trails near Ironton, MN.

name: Miners Castle Overlook
description: This is a short boardwalk trail that starts behind the information center. The platform at the end looks out over Lake Superior and what they call Miners Castle.

name: South Gemini Lake State Forest Campground
description: Gemini Lake (on site): 1.5 miles of flat terrain.

name: North Gemini Lake State Forest Campground
description:
Gemini Lake (on site): 1.5 miles of flat terrain.
Fox Lake (10 miles NE): 27.5 miles of flat to hilly terrain from Kingston Lake State Forest Campground following the Little Fox and Fox Rivers to Fox River State Forest Campground.

name: South Marquette Trails
description: South Marquette Trails features 20 miles of hiking trails near Marquette, MI.

name: Dworshak Reservoir
description: Excellent trails.

name: Van Riper State Park
description: Van Riper State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Champion, MI.

name: Little Lake State Forest Campground
description: Little Lake State Forest Campground is located in Van Riper State Park on Little Lake. The campground has 25 tent and small trailer sites. Six of them can accommodate a 40 foot trailer. The campsites include a vault toilet and potable water. Fishing, hiking, mountain biking, ATV riding and canoeing are popular here.

name: Pattison State Park
description: The park has over nine miles of hiking trails, offering stunning views of the waterfalls. The watchable wildlife in the park include almost 200 species of birds, 54 species of mammals and many reptiles and amphibians.

name: Maplewood State Park
description: Excellent hiking area with extensive trails.

name: Fort Ransom State Park
description: Fort Ransom State Park's non-motorized trail system covers over 14.64-miles in a series of loops, trails and connecting segment trails most which are multi-use and are open for hiking, horseback riding, biking, cross country skiing and snowshoeing. The majority of the trail system surface is either grass, dirt or hard-packed single-track, with manageable grades with only a few steeper sections.

name: Ike Kinswa State Park
description: The area around Ike Kinswa State Park was originally inhabited by the Cowlitz Indians. Their burial ground is located in the region. Many graves were relocated when the Mayfield Dam backed water up into the canyon. The area was originally named Mayfield Lake State Park, but the name was changed in 1971 to honor Ike Kinswa, a Cowlitz Indian who represented his people.

name: CDT MT09: US Hwy 12 to NF-136
description: Section 9 of the CDT in Montana runs for 23.8 miles from US Hwy 12 to NF-136. Along the way, the trail passes Greenhorn Mountain and Roundtop Mountain.

name: Dworshak State Park
description: Dworshak State Park is located among trees and meadows on the western shore of Dworshak Reservoir.  Camping, boating, fishing, swimming, hiking and waterskiing are just some of the many activities that await park visitors. A boat ramp and handling dock provide easy launching most of the year.  A fish-cleaning station is nearby to help with the day's catch.

name: Lake West
description: Lake West is located in southeastern Washington on the Lower Snake River. It is surrounded by a large, secluded fertile agricultural land base that provides very scenic views and there are recreational opportunities here for hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

name: Kingston Lake State Forest Campground
description: Fox River (on site): 27.5 miles of flat to hilly terrain from Kingston Lake following the Little Fox and Fox Rivers to Fox River State Forest Campground. Hike, fish, nature observation.

name: Scopan Public Reserved Land
description: Beautiful semi-remote area for hiking.

name: Leadbetter Point State Park
description: Half mile of ADA trails.

name: Craig Lake State Park
description: This park offers some of the most rugged trails in Michigan. An eight-mile trail loops around Craig Lake and offers some great opportunities to view wild life, fauna and the lakeshore. A 7.5 mile section of the North Country Trail runs through the park. The trail covers some rough terrain, but is well worth the effort. This national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes more than 1,500 miles in Michigan.

name: Pretty Lake State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail is 5 miles north of this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Aroostook State Park
description: Trails for hiking best during summer.

name: Amnicon Falls State Park
description: The park has 1.8 miles of trails. There are a number of short trails along both sides of the Amnicon River, offering varied views of the falls and surrounding scenery. A 0.8-mile self-guided nature trail provides scenic views of the river as well as access to the river bed down stream from the falls area.

name: Tahquamenon Falls State Park
description: The park has over 35 miles of hiking trails, enabling people to see beautiful portions of the park that are rarely seen by the public. The North Country Trail traverses 16 miles within the park, including the trail between the Upper and Lower Falls.

name: Spring Meadow Lake State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Cowiche Canyon
description: Cowiche Canyon features 12 miles of hiking trails near Yakima, WA.

name: Rainbow Falls State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Lake Bryan
description: Miscellaneous trails throughout area.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: I: Hwy 12 to I-90
description:
Section I of the PCT, the second section in Washington state, runs 99 miles from Highway 12 near White Pass to I-90 at Snoqualmie Pass. The first half of this section is protected by two wilderness areas and Mt. Ranier National Forest so it is gorgeous with great views, but the second half is at a lower elevation and is one of the most clear-cut areas in the West, according to the official PCT guide book.<br />
<br />
Along the way this section of the PCT passes Naches, WA; Deer Lake; Sand Lake; Buesch Lake; Cowlitz Pass; Snow Lake; Bumping River and Fish Lake; Anderson Lake; Dewey Lake; Highway 410 at Chinook Pass; Sheep Lake; Sourdough Gap; Blue Bell Pass; Scout Pass; Barnard Saddle; Hayden Pass; Martinson Gap; Louisiana Saddle; Rods Gap; Windy Gap; road 784; Tacoma Pass; Sheets Pass; Stampede Pass Road 54, junction to Lizard Lake; Dandy Pass; Stirrup Creek; Twilight Lake; Mirror Lake; Olallie Creek; Lodge Lake; Beaver Lake; and Highway 906.

name: Log Slide Overlook
description: This is a .4 mile trail which is fully accessible. It meanders through mature hardwoods to an overlook platform. From here you can see the old Log Slide site where they would slide logs down the dunes. It also provides a spectacular view of Lake Superior.

name: Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore
description:
Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore offers some 90 miles of trails within its 73,000 acres along 42 miles of Lake Superior's south shore. Whether you have only a few minutes, hours, or days to see a portion of the lakeshore, one of these hikes may be for you.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Jay Cooke State Park
description: Jay Cooke State Park is an excellent hiking park with trails that link up to the Willard Munger State Trail. Horseback riders, cross country skiers and bikers will also enjoy this park. The park's highlights are camping, a swinging bridge, the pioneer cemetery and Oldenburg Point. 50 miles of hiking trails through wooded areas and beside the river offer great scenic views.

name: Lower Granite Lake Lock & Dam
description: Lower Granite Lake is located along the lower Snake and Clearwater Rivers. this park provides many opportunities for outdoors recreational activities such as mountain biking, hiking, swimming, boating, canoeing, kayaking, fishing and camping.

name: Muskallonge Lake State Park
description:
Muskallonge Lake State Park is a 217-acre area that is known for its prime location between the shores of Lake Superior and Muskallonge Lake. Fishing, boating, swimming and other water sports are very popular here. The beautiful woodlands and streams throughout the park make a great environment for hiking, geocaching, snowmobiling and picnicking. The park has a playground, a beach, a picnic area, a sanitation station and modern restrooms for your convenience.

The Muskallonge Hiking Trail is a 1.50 mile path for scenic hiking at the park.

name: Palouse Falls State Park
description: The quarter-mile ADA-accessible hiking trail overlooks the falls.

name: High Bridge State Forest Campground
description: The North Country Trail is (5 miles North) of this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: Culhane Lake State Forest Campground
description:
Bodi Lake (1.5 miles East): 1.25 miles of rolling pine/oak uplands. Hike, mountain bike.
The North Country Trail runs through this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan.

name: Mouth of Two Hearted River State Forest Campground
description: Mouth of Two Hearted River State Forest Campground is located in the Tahquamenon Falls State Park. The campground has 39 tent and small trailer campsites with vault toilets and potable water from a pump. The campground is on Lake Superior so fishing and boating are popular activities here. Mountain biking and hiking  are also common, as well as ATV use.

name: Bodi Lake State Forest Campground
description:
Bodi Lake (on site): 1.25 miles of rolling pine/oak uplands.
The North Country Trail is (1.5 miles West) of this campground: This National Scenic Trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York includes over 1500 miles in Michigan. See www.northcountrytrail.org.

name: CDT MT10: NF-136 to Stemple Pass
description: Section 10 of the CDT in Montana runs for 18.1 miles from NF-136 to Stemple Pass. Along the way, the trail passes Black Mountain and Granite Butte.

name: Beavertail Hill State Park
description: The 65-acre Beavertail Hill State Park is located on the beautiful Clark Fork River. The park is an excellent fishing location, as well a common destination for canoeists. Camping, birding, hiking, picnicking and wildlife viewing are other popular activities here. The park provides a walking trail that will take approximately a half of an hour to hike. It takes you through a canopy of cottonwoods.

name: Greenleaf Lake State Recreation Area
description: Hiking trails under development.

name: Black Sandy State Park
description: A very popular campground is located at Black Sandy State Park. The campground is an awesome place to stay because it provides easy access to boating, water-skiing, salmon and trout fishing, swimming and cycling. The 43-acre park provides hours of fun and limitless activities.

name: Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park
description: Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park's non-motorized trail system covers approximately 6.75 miles in a series of loops and several connecting segment trails that are open for hiking, biking and horseback riding. Most of the trail system surface is either grass, dirt or hard-packed single-track, with manageable grades with only a few steeper sections.

name: Baraga State Park
description: Many nearby hiking trails provide opportunities to watch the wildlife, including whitetail deer, bald eagles, and waterfowl.

name: Beartrap Gulch
description: Beartrap Gulch features 12 miles of hiking trails near York, MT.

name: Aroostook Valley Trail
description: Open year-round; hiking best during peak season.

name: Mount Rainier National Park
description:
Permits are not required for day hiking. However, camping overnight in the wilderness at Mount Rainier requires a permit. In the summer, permits can be obtained at any ranger station in the park during their hours of operation. Obtain permits at: the Longmire Wilderness Information Center at Longmire, the Jackson Visitor Center at Paradise, the Ohanapecosh Visitor Center at Ohanapecosh, the White River Wilderness Information Center at the White River Entrance, the Sunrise Visitor Center at Sunrise and the Carbon River Ranger Station at the Carbon River Entrance.<br />
In the winter, permits are available at the Longmire Museum every day and the Jackson Visitor Center on weekends. Self-registration during the winter is available at the Carbon River Ranger Station, Ohanapecosh Ranger Station, and the Highway 410 entrance arch at the park's north boundary.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Big Bay State Park
description: There are seven miles of hiking trails at Big Bay State Park that wind through varied habitat, some of which is detailed through interpretive signage.

name: Grayland Beach State Park
description: The park has five marked, short trails leading from the campground to the beach. There also is one recreational trail that begins at campsite 44 and travels around Borrow Lake for 0.6 miles. The trail can be wet year round.

name: Big Pines
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Round Pond Public Reserved Land
description: Great area for hiking.

name: Mountain View Singletrack
description: Mountain View Singletrack is a 3 mile hiking trail in Detroit Lakes, Minnesota.

name: Apostle Islands National Lakeshore
description:
Hikers can enjoy more than fifty miles of maintained trails on the islands of the National Lakeshore. These trails provide access to lighthouses, abandoned quarries, old farm sites, historic logging camps, beaches, campsites, and scenic overlooks.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Sleepy Hollow
description: Sleepy Hollow is a 4 mile hiking trail in Bismarck, North Dakota.

name: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park
description: Along with the park's extensive trail system, the North Country Trail includes 23 miles within the state park. The national scenic trail hiking route from North Dakota to New York uses the following park trails: West River, Lake Superior, Little Carp River and Lily Pond trails.

name: Hartley
description: Hartley features 9 miles of hiking trails near Duluth, MN.

name: Savanna Portage State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Buffalo River State Park
description:
The Buffalo River State Park is full of beautiful prairie land and hardwood forests. Picnicking, camping, swimming and hiking are all popular activities here. Birding is also common here.

The park offers six miles of intermediate, groomed trails for hiking and cross country skiing.

name: Bangor & Aroostook Trail
description: Enjoy the trail and please remember it is multi-use; motorized users must yield to non-motorized and please demonstrate courtesy and ethics to all trail users as well as abutting landowners.

name: Sully Creek State Park
description: Horseback riders, mountain bikers, and hikers have access to the 120-mile long Maah Daah Hey Trail, which traverses the Little Missouri National Grassland and to the 50 plus mile long Maah Daah Hey II Trail. Those using the trail should carry adequate potable water for drinking. In the early spring or during high flows, canoeing the Little Missouri River also offers a unique perspective of the Badlands.

name: Bottle Beach State Park
description: The park features 0.7 miles of ADA-accessible walking trails. The trails are for pedestrian use only. No motorized vehicles, horses or bicycles allowed.

name: Twin Lakes State Park
description: A 1.5-mile nature trail with two scenic overlooks provides a spectacular view of Lake Superior on clear days.

name: Pipestem Trail
description: Pipestem Trail features 3 miles of hiking trails near Jamestown, ND.

name: CDT MT11: Stemple Pass to Rogers Pass and MT Hwy 200
description: Section 11 of the CDT in Montana runs for 24.9 miles from Stemple Pass to Rogers Pass and Montana Highway 200. Along the way, the trail passes Crater Mountain, Denton Mountain, and Sunset Mountain.

name: Westhaven State Park
description: At Westhaven State Park you will find 79.06-acres of beautiful views, plus 1,215 feet of shoreline on the Pacific coast and Half Moon Bay. The park is a popular location for surfing, fishing, and hiking. Swimming is not advised due to rough currents and rip tides, but clamming, crabbing and fishing are allowed.  This is a day use park only. One hiking trail that is available is a concrete walkway to the Westport Light State Park which is nearby and allows horseback riding.

name: Millersylvania State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Council Grove State Park
description: Council Grove State Park is a day-use park on the Clark Fork River. This area is where the treaty between the U.S. Government and the Salish, Kootenai and Pend d'Oriella was signed. The 187-acre area is a great location for bird watching, fishing, picnicking, hiking and wildlife viewing.

name: Theodore Roosevelt National Park
description:
The park contains 100 miles of trails. Some are self-guided nature walks (under 1 mile) and others are longer, more strenuous hikes. Take a hike and experience the same wild beauty and solitude of the badlands that captivated Theodore Roosevelt more than a century ago.<br />
Source: National Park Service<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Ginkgo Petrified Forest State Park/ Wanapum Recreational Area
description: This SP offers 7,470-acres of SP within which is  27,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Wanapum Reservoir on the Columbia River. It is a registered national natural landmark and is one of the most unusual fossil forests on Earth. The park was named after a petrified wood discovery by Professor George Beck in the early 1930's. Spectacular views of the Columbia River, Sentinel Gap and Ice Age flood-carved basalt landscapes are offered at various locations in the park. There trails that lead you through impressive views of rare fossil beds with two-dozen petrified logs. There are also many remains of Ice Age floodwater damage thousands of years ago.

name: Ginkgo Petrified Forest State Park
description: The Gorge area offers excellent hiking.

name: Buffalo Gap Trail
description: Buffalo Gap Trail is a 12 mile hiking trail in Medora, North Dakota.

name: Capitol Forest
description: Capitol Forest features 75 miles of hiking trails near Olympia, WA.

name: Ackley Lake State Park
description: Ackley Lake State Park is a beautiful park located in the heart of Montana's Big Sky Country. This 160-acre park is full of recreational activities that include fishing, boating, picnicking, camping, birding, ice fishing, water skiing, swimming and relaxing.

name: Potholes State Park
description: Potholes State Park is a 640-acre camping park with 6,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on Potholes Reservoir (also known as O'Sullivan Reservoir). Potholes Reservoir is often confused with the Pothole Lakes themselves, which are a 30- to 45-minute drive from the park. The terrain is desert with freshwater marshes.

name: Olmstead Place State Park
description: This working pioneer farm offers tours and elaborate school field trips. "Old-time" special events are sponsored by the park throughout the year. Viewing antique farm implements in action and enjoying the historic gardens are popular activities.

name: Deboullie Public Reserved Land
description: A 12-mile trail network with several loop options leads to many remote ponds and to Deboullie Mountain (1,981 feet) where a former fire tower offers expansive views of the surrounding region. Hikers can enjoy mountaintop blueberries in August and still find "ice caves" in denser woods - narrow, shaded crevices where snow and ice can remain year-round (supporting unusual plants such as the arctic sandwort). Several small waterfalls offer attractive places to cool off during warm-weather hikes.

name: Fish Creek State Park
description: Fish Creek State Park offers great recreational opportunities including hiking, mountain biking, fishing, wildlife viewing and picnicking. The 7,200-acre park is full of beautiful scenic and  clear pools of Fish Creek. Pets are OK.

name: Lake Sylvia State Park
description: Half mile ADA accessible trails.

name: Umtanum
description: This canyon has been designated as a state scenic route and offers excellent wildlife viewing, fishing in a Blue Ribbon trout stream, family river rafting and camping.

name: Silvia Ridge Loop
description: Silvia Ridge Loop features 5 miles of hiking trails near Montesano, WA.

name: Lookout Mountain National Recreation Trail (Marble Creek Trail System)
description: This trail is part of a 45-mile network collectively referred to as the Marble Creek Trail System providing access to and through the Grandmother Mountain Wilderness Study Area. The area has an intermingled ownership and is jointly administered by the BLM and the Forest Service. Lookout Mountain Trail follows a high mountain ridge alternating between forested saddles and open, rocky mountain tops. Scenic vistas are first rate.

name: Delaney Creek National Recreation Trail Hike
description: This trail is part of a 45-mile trail network collectively referred to as the Marble Creek Trail System providing access to and through the Grandmother Mountain Wilderness Study Area. The area has an intermingled ownership and is jointly administered by the BLM and the Forest Service. Delaney Creek Trail descends steeply from a high open ridge through dense forest to Marble Creek, intersecting with Marble Creek Trail. Historic features include remnants of logging camps and cabins.

name: Ranger Creek
description: Ranger Creek features 23 miles of hiking trails near Greenwater, WA.

name: Skookum Flats
description: Skookum Flats features 11 miles of hiking trails near Enumclaw, WA.

name: Chehalis Western Trail
description: Chehalis Western Trail features 20 miles of hiking trails near Lacey, WA.

name: Eagle Lake Public Reserved Land
description: Hiking trails available.

name: CDT MT12: Rogers Pass and MT Hwy 200 to Benchmark Trailhead
description: Section 12 of the CDT in Montana runs for 58.6 miles from Rogers Pass and Montana Highway 200 to the Benchmark Trailhead. Along the way, the trail passes the summit of Green Mountain (7,453 feet), Caribou Peak, Big Horn Lake, Grassy Hills HP, Steamboat Mountain, Red Slide Mountain, Halfmoon Peak, Crown Mountain, and Patrol Mountain.

name: Engineer Bluff
description: Engineer Bluff features 10 miles of hiking trails near Ft Lewis, WA.

name: Soldier's Field House
description: Soldier's Field House features 15 miles of hiking trails near Ft. Lewis, WA.

name: McCroskey State Park
description: Excellent, remote hiking area.

name: Makoshika State Park
description: Nature trail.

name: Schafer State Park
description: Schafer State Park is a 119-acre camping park on the Satsop River, midway between Olympia and Ocean Park. A big attraction to park users is the abundant fishing for steelhead, cutthroat trout and salmon on the Satsop River. Wading and swimming in the shallow water make it an equally attractive site for family gatherings. Buildings are constructed from native stone. Rich in local history, the park is a state and national historic site as designated by the Washington Heritage Register and National Register of Historic Places.

name: Bresemann Forest
description: This naturally wooded site is approximately 70 acres with a system of pedestrian nature trails. The beautiful and secluded walking trail may have users thinking they are miles from the city as they stroll along Morey Creek. Enter the forest through a wrought iron gate on the west side of the Sprinker Recreation Center parking lot near Spire Rock.

name: Michigan Tech Trails
description: Michigan Tech Trails features 14 miles of hiking trails near Houghton, MI.

name: Ashtabula Lake
description: Excellent trails throughout area.

name: Tolmie State Park
description: Tolmie State Park is a 105-acre marine day-use park with 1,800 feet of saltwater shoreline on Puget Sound. This forested park is on Nisqually Beach, a few miles from Olympia, the state's capital city. The park offers a variety of beachside activities and an underwater park that contains an artificial reef built in cooperation with scuba divers.

name: Nathan Chapman Memorial Trail
description: This paved trail system is about 1.6 miles long and surrounded by large trees and beautiful scenery, creating an easy and enjoyable walk to either site.

name: Foothills Trail
description: The Foothills Trail is a 12-foot wide non-motorized asphalt trail / linear park suitable for bicycles, walking, in-line skates and wheel chairs. It also has a soft shoulder path for equestrians.

name: Gooseberry Falls State Park
description: Trails will take visitor along the Gooseberry River and through evergreen and birch forests. Scenic views of waterfalls along trails.

name: Mud Mountain Dam (White River)
description: Great trails.

name: Federation Forest State Park
description: Excellent hiking in this area.

name: South Hill Loop Trail
description: This connection allows you to leisurely walk with your family or pets, circling South Hill Community Park and the relaxing wetlands until you have returned back to the children's playground.

name: Itasca State Park
description: Itasca State Park is Minnesota's oldest state park. It originated in 1891. The 32,000-acre area includes more than 100 lakes and offers great fishing, hiking and camping, as well as excellent cross-country skiing and snowmobiling in the winter. The park offers 49 miles of scenic hiking trails that wind throughout the park. There is also a 1.5 mile wheelchair accessible trail and a 16-mile paved bike trail.

name: Seeley Lake Park
description: This 48-acre natural area includes a 1.3 mile walking trail that provides green seclusion with young red alder saplings and in the growing season white snow berries and red and black blackberries. Small marshes appear suddenly amidst the brush and in the winter more of the pond is visible.

name: Frontier Park Trails
description: The Frontier Park Trails are natural and graveled surface trails in Graham.

name: Sluice Boxes State Park
description: Excellent area for hiking.

name: Victor Falls
description: Victor Falls features 8 miles of hiking trails near Bonney Lake, WA.

name: Clarks Creek Park
description: Clarks Creek Park is a 6 mile hiking trail in Puyallup, Washington.

name: Tower Rock State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Hope Island State Park (Mason)
description: One-and-a-half miles of beach and two miles of hiking trail attract boaters to this small, quiet island.

name: Split Rock Lighthouse State Park
description:
Some of the Split Rock Lighthouse State Park's highlights include
historic lighthouse tours, fantastic cross-country skiing, scenic viewing of Lake Superior, admiring beautiful waterfalls and picnicking along Lake Superior's shore. Camping along the pristine shores of the lake and hiking along the Superior Hiking Trail are also common activities. Fishing for trout, salmon and brown trout is also very popular at this diverse park.

At least eight miles of groomed trail along Lake Superior is available for hiking and cross-country skiing purposes. The trail is label intermediate to experienced.

name: Cross Ranch State Park
description: Over 16 miles of trail wind through Cross Ranch State Park and Nature Preserve. Trail posts identify the trail names.

name: Schoolcraft State Park
description: Trail takes you through wooded areas along the river.

name: Chambers Creek Regional Park
description: You have many different trail options and experiences at the Chambers Creek Properties.

name: McLain State Park
description:
McLain State Park is a 443-acre area of sandy beaches and beautiful views. Fishing, hunting, swimming, cross country skiing, hiking and relaxing are all popular activities at this scenic park on Lake Superior. The park also offers modern camping with electrical service, restrooms and firewood.

The McLain-Hiking/Ski Trail is a 4 mile trail of enjoyable views.

name: Lake Easton State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Mississippi River Headwaters - Leech Lake
description: Interpretive trail.

name: McMicken Island State Park
description: McMicken Island State Park is an 11.5 acre marine park with 1,661 feet of saltwater shoreline. It is situated in the beautiful South Puget Sound and features a pristine cove to set anchor. Visitors can enjoy the many hiking trails, viewing an active bald eagle nest and shellfish harvesting. The shellfish population is abundant and open to shellfish harvesters year round.

name: St. John Valley Heritage Trail
description: The St. John Valley Trail takes riders 16.5 miles from Fort Kent through St. John to St. Francis. Riders tour the countryside to experience rolling hills, farmland and several miles along the edge of the St. John River. While the trail is located near highways, users get a sense of remoteness. The trail is open year round for multiple use.

name: Fish Lake Trail
description: 2 miles one way.

name: Lost Lake Trail
description: This trail ascends to Lost Lake in the Grandmother Mountain Wilderness Study Area. The scenic alpine lake contains cutthroat trout. Undeveloped camping is allowed. The trail starts as a two-track road, is open to motorized use (ATVs and motorcycles), and is suitable for four-wheelers for 2 miles.

name: Little Lost Lake Trail
description: This trail ascends to Little Lost Lake in the Grandmother Mountain Wilderness Study Area. The small and shallow alpine lake contains no fish. Undeveloped camping is allowed. The trail starts as a two-track road, is open to motorized use (ATVs and motorcycles), and is suitable for four-wheelers for three miles.

name: Penrose Point State Park
description: A self-guided interpretive trail called "A Touch of Nature" was built by Eagle Souts in 1982 and renovated by a second group of Eagle Scouts in 1991. The trail is located in the day-use area, and extends for 1/5 mile.

name: Nolte State Park
description: Beautiful hiking in this state park.

name: Flaming Geyser State Park
description: Oct. through Dec. the Salmon Interpretive Trail and the walkway on the Flaming Geyser Bridge offer excellent opportunity to view wild salmon spawning areas.

name: Kachess Ridge Loop
description: Kachess Ridge Loop features 19 miles of hiking trails near Easton, WA.

name: Puget Park
description: Puget Park is part of the largest greenbelt in the city, the West Duwamish Greenbelt, which is home to many wild species that need protection and housing. This place is perfect for getting off the city streets and taking a hike!

name: Jarrell Cove State Park
description: Jarrell Cove State Park is a 43-acre marine camping park with 3,500 feet of saltwater shoreline on the northwest end of Harstine Island in south Puget Sound. The forested island park is accessible by road and bridge and is off the beaten path. Most visitors arrive by boat. The park has campsites near the docks, as well as on rolling, grassy areas. Jarrell Cove State Park administers five other satellite parks including: Harstine Island, McMicken Island, Stretch Point, Eagle Island and Hope Island State Parks. Harstine Island State Park is a day use park with beach access via a half-mile trail. It is a two mile drive from Jarrell Cove. The other satellite parks are all accessible by boat only and offer buoys for moorage.

name: Cushman Trail
description: The Cushman Powerline Trail is approximately 2.5 miles of non-motorized public trail that is a 16-foot wide paved asphalt pedestrian route and bike trail. A trail head with parking and restrooms is located at the end of Grandview Street in Gig Harbor. The trail has been managed and operated by PenMet Parks since 2011.

name: Maah Daah Hey
description: Maah Daah Hey features 100 miles of hiking trails near Medora, ND.

name: Squilchuck State Park
description: Park trails are open to day visitors who walk or bicycle into the park. However, when the campground or lodge is reserved, day visitors are not permitted in the campground or lodge area. Please respect the privacy of groups that have reserved the park.

name: Kopachuck State Park
description: Kopachuck State Park is a 109-acre marine park with 5,600 feet of saltwater shoreline on Henderson Bay. One portion of the park, Cutts Island (or "Deadman's Island") is a half mile from shore and reachable only by boat. The park provides scenic views of sunsets, the Olympic Mountains and Puget Sound. Campground closure: Kopachuck State Park is open for day use only. Due to hazardous trees in the forest, the campground area is closed indefinitely.

name: Dash Point State Park
description: Dash Point State Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Tacoma, WA.

name: Kanaskat-Palmer State Park
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Clark Fork River Trail #223
description: Clark Fork River Trail #223 features 9 miles of hiking trails near St Regis, MT.

name: Douglas Creek
description: Great hiking.

name: Lake Sawyer
description: Lake Sawyer features 15 miles of hiking trails near Black Diamond, WA.

name: Pacific Lake/Lakeview Ranch
description: Great trails.

name: Heyburn State Park
description: Excellent hiking trails.

name: Hansen Ridge
description: Hansen Ridge features 4 miles of hiking trails near North Bend, WA.

name: Potlatch State Park
description: Beautiful hiking.

name: Tettegouche State Park
description: Tettegouche State Park offers excellent overlooking from Shovel Point, hiking through fantastic views of the Sawtooth Mountains, great fishing opportunities and birdwatching. Rock climbing on the rocky, steep cliffs and inland bluffs is very common here. Cross-country skiing and snowmobiling are also popular in the winter. 23 miles of hiking trails are available and provide the opportunity to explore the park to its fullest intent. Scenic waterfalls, rivers and mountain views make up the beautiful trails.

name: Mississippi River - Lake Winnibigoshish, MN
description: the Mississippi River - Lake Winnibigoshish, MN is a great multi-use facility located on the shores of Lake Winnibishosh. This park offers hiking, swimming, boating, canoeing, kayaking, fishing and camping.

name: Twanoh State Park
description: Twanoh State Park, situated on the shoreline of Hood Canal, features one of the warmest saltwater beaches in Washington state. This is because Hood Canal is one of the warmest saltwater bodies in Puget Sound. The 182-acre marine, camping park has 3,167 feet of saltwater shoreline. The name of the park derives from the Native American Twana tribes, better known as the Skokomish, who made their home in the area.

name: Soos Creek Trail
description: Paved with soft shoulder. A separate soft surface trail for equestrians exists along some portions of the trail.

name: Devil's Gulch
description: Devil's Gulch features 24 miles of hiking trails near Cashmere, WA.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: J: I-90 (Snoqualmie Pass) to Hwy 2 (Stevens Pass)
description:
Section J of the Pacific Crest Trail runs 74.7 miles from I-90 at Snoqualmie Pass to Highway 2 at Stevens Pass. This section runs through gorgeous Cascade Mountains backcountry. Most of the beauty of this section is protected by the Alpine Lakes Wilderness.<br />
<br />
Along the way this section of trail passes Huckleberry Saddle, Needle Sight Gap, Chikamin Pass, Delate Creek, Lemah Creek, Waptus River, Deep Lake, Cathedral Pass, Deception Pass, Pieper Pass, Trap Pass, Trap Lake, Hope Lake, Mig Lake, Lake Susan Jane, and Stevens Pass ski area.

name: Iron Horse State Park
description: The 100-mile-long John Wayne Pioneer Trail meanders through a variety of ecosystems and geological zones. No motorized vehicles are allowed on the trail with the exception of snowmobiles in winter, which are allowed from Stampede Pass Rd. to Cabin Creek. Horse-drawn wagon users must obtain a key to the gates of Lake Easton State Park.

name: Olallie State Park
description: Beautiful hiking in the Cascadia Mountain Range.

name: Tiger Mountain
description: Tiger Mountain features 10 miles of hiking trails near Issiquah, WA.

name: Fort Wilkins Historic State Park
description: Running around the park, roughly parallel to the park boundary is a two-mile trail that provides great views of Lake Fanny Hooe and Lake Superior.

name: Copper Harbor Trails
description: Copper Harbor Trails features 20 miles of hiking trails near Copper Harbor, MI.

name: Windy Mountain Loop
description: Windy Mountain Loop features 11 miles of hiking trails near Great Falls, MT.

name: George H. Crosby Manitou State Park
description: Some of the best back-country trails in the state parks. These are rugged trails that offer great wildlife observation, old-growth forests, and scenic waterfalls. About 5 miles of the Superior Hiking Trail runs through the park.

name: Green River Trail
description: The Green River Trail winds more than 19 miles from Cecil Moses Park near Seattle's south boundary to North Green River Park in south Kent near Auburn. The GRT follows the Green River through industrial lands near the Duwamish Waterway in Tukwila to the broad Green River Valley. The trail provides excellent views and access to the Green River and surrounding river valley. The trail is paved over its entire length with some low-volume roadway segments. To the north the GRT follows the river along a riverside landscape and past industrial areas and manicured office parks. Near Fort Dent Park the GRT intersects the northern end of the Interurban Trail then meanders south down the river valley. Office buildings and suburban warehouse landscapes give way to open fields and hedgerows as the trail winds its way along the river. Entering Kent near Brisco Park, the GRT continues past the Green River Valley Natural Resources Area and through the Riverbend Golf Complex. At its south end the trail again intersects the Interurban Trail at Foster Park. The GRT links industrial lands to pastoral landscapes, parks, communities, and river views. Ideal for recreational journeys and nonmotorized commuting, the trail is highly popular with a variety of user groups. In the future the trail is slated to continue south through the City of Auburn and eventually to Flaming Geyser State Park at the Green River Gorge.

name: First Peoples Buffalo Jump
description: First Peoples Buffalo Jump State Park is a historic and archaeological site with one of the largest buffalo jump sites in the country. The park offers an interpretive trail that explains the historical significance of the park. Bird hunting, bow hunting, hiking, horseback riding, picnicking, bird watching, sightseeing and wildlife viewing are other common activities here.

name: Cedar River Trail
description: Excellent trail.

name: Columbia Plateau Trail
description: ADA hiking.

name: Banner Forest
description: Banner Forest features 20 miles of hiking trails near Port Orchard, WA.

name: Squak Mountain State Park
description: Squak Mountain State Park is a 1,545-acre, day-use park just outside of Issaquah and a short 15-minute drive from Seattle. The forested park features miles of trails in wilderness solitude for both equestrians and hikers alike.

name: CDT MT13: Benchmark Trailhead to Badger Pass
description: Section 13 of the CDT in Montana runs for 84.3 miles from the Benchmark Trailhead to Badger Pass. Along the way, the trail passes through the Bob Marshall Wilderness and passes by Deadman Hill, Red Butte, the Chinese Wall, Prairie Reef, Slategoat Mountain, Lone Butte, Redhead Peak, Three Sisters South, Three Sisters North, Lookout Mountain, Hahn Peak, Lake Levale, Table Mountain, Kevan Mountain, Pentagon Mountain, Bowl Creek, Bowl Mountain, Mount Field, and Pondera County HP.

name: Coffeepot Lake
description: Impressive basalt cliffs frame this eastern Washington lake. More than 900 acres bordering the lake are managed for wildlife habitat, as well as for recreational opportunities including boating, fishing*, hiking, horseback riding, camping, and picnicking (* Check Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife for Season and Special Fishing Gear Rules). Waterfowl are protected by a game reserve on public lands around Coffeepot Lake. Hunting and use of hunting dogs are prohibited within the game reserve.

name: Lakeridge Park
description: Lakeridge Park was named in 1947 by The Seattle Planning Commission. The parks was once known as "Dead Horse Canyon", named in 1909 by homesteaders Chas J. Walker upon the death and dehydration of a horse which had long roamed the area and been a pet of pioneer children. Walker helped log this area for the Taylor Sawmill on the beach just to the east. George Kinnear was the original owner of the property.

name: River's Edge
description: River's Edge features 3 miles of hiking trails near Great Falls, MT.

name: Lake Sakakawea State Park
description: Several multi-use trails in the park are perfect for hiking, biking, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing. Hikers are encouraged to take in the scenic beauty of the completed segments of the North Country National Scenic Trail found in this park.

name: Fauntleroy Park
description:
Open from 6 a.m. - 10 p.m., Fauntleroy Park is a densely wooded patch of forest located near Fauntleroy Cove in West Seattle.

There is a network of paths that run throughout the park, which are perfect for hiking, dog-walking, or just strolling on a lunch break. The trails total about 1.5 miles in length.

name: Westcrest Park
description: Westcrest Park is a very large park. It has a view platform with a great panoramic view of the city skyline, flat open meadow, with a short walking path, and a dog off-leash area. Amenities include picnic sites, restrooms, paths, woods, hiking trails and an ADA compliant play area.

name: Blake Island State Park
description: With 8 miles of hiking trails and 5 miles of beachfront, plenty of great walks await visitors.

name: Cougar Mountain Regional Wildland Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Lincoln Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Giant Springs State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lake Bemidji State Park
description: Easy to moderate trails that take you through areas of maturing pine, aspen and hardwoods. No winter hiking trails.

name: Camp Long
description: Great hiking.

name: Lincoln Rock State Park
description: Park staff offer interpretive programs on most Saturdays from Memorial Day through Labor Day.

name: Peshastin Pinnacles State Park
description: The park offers a mile and a half of steep hiking trail. For rock climbers, slabs and spires vary from easy to difficult and require rock-climbing equipment.

name: Little Missouri State Park
description: Little Missouri State Park has over 47 miles of trails for horseback riding and hiking. Horse corrals are available for individuals and groups bringing in their own horses, and several artesian wells are located within the park for horse watering purposes. Trails are marked at major interections.

name: Grand Ridge Park
description: A seven-mile, multi-use trail that was built with considerable help from volunteers with the Washington Trails Association traverses the long and linear park, wandering through a variety of forest settings that provide habitat for bears, cougars, owls and other wildlife. The trail will eventually end at Duthie Hill Park, the home of the region's most-popular mountain bike skills park.

name: Taylor Mountain Forest
description: About 33 trails. Great hiking!

name: Seward Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Dearborn Park
description: Short trails.

name: Hitt's Hill Park
description: Great trails.

name: Middle Fork Snoqualmie
description: Middle Fork Snoqualmie features 11 miles of hiking trails near North Bend, WA.

name: Lake Sammamish State Park
description: The park offers easy hiking trails, plus bicycling and mountain biking through natural areas along paved and compacted dirt roads.

name: Genesee Park and Playfield
description: Genesee Park and Playfield is a broad, rough meadow that stretches for about 5 blocks north from Genesee Street to Stan Sayres Memorial Park on Lake Washington Boulevard. Set in a quiet neighborhood, the atmosphere is quite soothing. It contains a huge and open grassy area for a playfield. Genesee also has a fully fenced 2 1/2 acres off-leash area with double gates, a doggie drinking fountain and a kiosk for community notices.

name: Schmitz Preserve Park
description: Schmitz Preserve Park in West Seattle is a great place to head out for a walk in the park. Once a place for a logger's heyday, this park is now a quiet and untouched place that give peace of mind to visitors. This is a truly great place to get away from things for a bit and take a hike!

name: Pigeon Point Park
description: Great trails.

name: Temperance River State Park
description: Temperance River State Park is home to a deep gorge, a diverse forest and rushing waterfalls. The park is a common location for hiking, camping, picnicking, rock climbing, cross-country skiing and snowmobiling. Birding is also common. 22 miles of hiking trails are available along the Superior Hiking Trail and the North Shore Corridor Trail. During the winter, 17 of the miles are open for cross-country skiing use.

name: North Shore
description: North Shore features 5 miles of hiking trails near Great Falls, MT.

name: Lake People Park (Xacua'bs)
description:
This half-acre park is located in a quiet neighborhood in the heart of Rainier Valley. The park was named after the Duwamish tribe who lived in this area, the Xacua'bs, which means "Lake People."

The park provides beautiful views across Rainier Valley, all the way to downtown Seattle, and out to the Cascade Mountains. There is a short hiking trail that runs around the park and then cuts through it.

name: Manchester State Park
description: Manchester State Park is a 111-acre camping park with 3,400 feet of saltwater shoreline on Rich Passage in Puget Sound. The park is covered in woods of fir and maple.

name: Snoqualmie Valley Trail
description: Crushed rock and original ballast surfacing. Former railroad trestles have been decked and hand railed from Duvall to Rattle Snake Lake with one on-road detour in the City of Snoqualmie.

name: Mt. Baker Park
description: Great hiking trails.

name: Duthie Hill Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Sun Lakes-Dry Falls State Park
description: Sun Lakes-Dry Falls State Park is a 4,027-acre camping park with 73,640 feet of freshwater shoreline at the foot of Dry Falls. Dry Falls is one of the great geological wonders of North America. Carved by Ice Age floods that long ago disappeared, the former waterfall is now a stark cliff, 400 feet high and 3.5 miles wide. In its heyday, the waterfall was four times the size of Niagara Falls. Today it overlooks a desert oasis filled with lakes and abundant wildlife.

name: Dr. Jose Rizal Park
description: Great hiking.

name: Illahee State Park
description: A veterans' war memorial is located in the park. Several interpretive displays are available that explain park features such as stilted trees, a Works Progress Administration-built kitchen shelter, totem garden, yew tree and the pier.

name: Frink Park
description: Frink Park is a 17.2-acre, city-owned park in Seattle, Washington. This park is a densly vegetated ravine and lies very close to Lake Washington. Activities here include fishing, hiking and trail running.

name: Fort Stevenson State Park
description: The park offers 8.13 miles of non-motorized, multi use trail which provides a pleasant place to bike, walk, jog and cross country ski. This includes a .22 mile interpretive trail and a .48 mile arboretum trail.

name: Green Mountain Trail
description: Green Mountain Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Bremerton, WA.

name: Leschi-Lake Dell Natural Area
description: Leschi-Lake Dell Natural Area provides plenty of green space as well as hiking trails for visitors.

name: East Lake Sammamish Trail
description: The East Lake Sammamish Trail follows a historic railroad route along the eastern shore of Lake Sammamish within the cities of Redmond, Sammamish and Issaquah. Part of the "Locks to Lakes Corridor," the trail is approximately 11 miles long and follows an off-road corridor along the lake and through lakeside communities. The existing "interim" soft-surface trail provides excellent views of the lake and Cascade foothills, and is popular with off-road bicyclists, joggers, walkers and other users. The ELST will be upgraded in phases to become a fully paved facility with soft-surface shoulders.

name: Pinnacle Peak
description: Pinnacle Peak Park is a 256-acre volcanic cone that rises straight out of the Enumclaw farmlands and straight down to the White River. Also known locally as Mt. Peak, and even Mt. Pete, Pinnacle Peak is one of the most popular hikes for Enumclaw and South county families. A one-mile long forested trail climbs 1000-vertical feet to the top of the 1800-foot geological knob. Once you get to the top, you will see extruded outcroppings of columnar basalt, concrete footings of an old fire lookout and best of all, spectacular views from the south side of Mt Rainier and the White River valley. The trail is named for Cal Magnusson, a long time Cascade mountaineer who worked at REI for 25 years with famed mountain climber Jim Whittaker. A recent acquisition of 83 acres on the south side of the park provides another access to the peak along gravel roads and even more spectacular views along the way. The new acquisitions also present an opportunity to develop an equestrian trail and other recreation amenities.

name: Madrona Park
description:
Open from 4:00 a.m.- 11:30 p.m., Madrona Park offers beautiful views overlooking the waterfront on Lake Washington. It has a wooded hillside that leads into a grassy beach and swimming area; lifeguards are on duty during the summertime. The park features a jogging path that winds along Lake Washington, as well as picnic areas for visitors to enjoy.

A network of hiking trails, totaling 1 mile, runs through the wooded section of the park.

name: Soaring Eagle Regional Park
description: Excellent trails.

name: Section 36 (Beaver Lake)
description: Section 36 (Beaver Lake) features 12 miles of hiking trails near Sammamish, WA.

name: Beauty Bay Trail
description: This small, seven unit picnic area, affords a pleasant highway rest stop in the forest. A short half-mile trail offers commanding scenic views of Coeur d'Alene Lake. Facilities are accessible including the 800 ft. paved path to a viewing deck overlooking Beauty Bay. An additional unpaved scenic trail (half-mile loop) in a forested setting affords beautiful views. A short half-mile trail leading from Beauty Bay recreation site offers commanding scenic views of Coeur d'Alene Lake. An 800 ft. paved trail leads to a viewing deck overlooking Beauty Bay. An additional unpaved scenic trail (half-mile loop) in a forested setting affords commanding scenic vistas.

name: Kinnear Park
description: A roughly pie-shaped, two-tiered park, Kinnear is bigger, grassier, and woodsier than the parks on the upper part of the hill, and offers closer views of the city and the sound. It is dominated here by the grain elevators of Pier 86, where ships dock to be fed their cargoes through snaking tubes. You can also spot joggers moving antlike along the narrow green of Myrtle Edwards and Elliott Bay parks on the shoreline.

name: Northeast Queen Anne Greenbelt
description: Excellent trails.

name: Washington Park Arboretum
description: Excellent walking trails.

name: Interlaken Park
description: Interlaken Park is a densely wooded area on the north end of Capitol Hill. The paths and trails throughout the park are frequented by bikers, hikers and joggers.

name: Duffy Creek
description: Excellent trails.

name: Tolt-MacDonald Park
description: Great trails.

name: Lawton Park
description: Visitors to Lawton Park can enjoy leisurely strolls down a wide pathway that carries the visitor through hills, woods and grassy lawns. There is also a dirt path that winds its way around maple trees and leads to three old picnic tables, as well as more primitive paths blazed by neighborhood children.

name: Juniper Dunes
description: Juniper Dunes consists of three adjoining areas comprising a total of approximately 19,600 acres.  Outside of the wilderness area, the primary recreational activity at Juniper Dunes is OHV use in the "Open" area. Other associated uses include picnicking and camping, and some hiking, horseback riding, and hunting are done as well. Helmets, safety flags on whip masts, and current state registration and tabs/stickers are required on all OHVs. Although Juniper Dunes is open to the public, portions of Peterson Road (the only access road into the area) are privately owned. Public access is contingent on the willingness of adjacent landowners to permit the public to cross their property to reach the BLM public lands. The BLM, Franklin County, and various other partners are working to establish formal public access into Juniper Dunes.

name: Yakima River Canyon
description: This canyon has been designated as a state scenic route and offers excellent wildlife viewing, fishing in a Blue Ribbon trout stream, family river rafting and camping. BLM manages over 9000 acres in the Yakima River Canyon area, including four developed river access sites. Follow the meandering river, as it slices between basalt cliffs formed by centuries-old upheavals. It's thought that Yakima River predates those stony ramparts, once flowing across a relatively flat landscape. As rock ridges rose, river erosion equaled the walls which once formed part of one of the largest lava fields in the world, said to have covered 200,000 square miles in Washington, Oregon and Idaho.

name: Fishtrap Recreation Area
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Hog Canyon Lake
description: The site is located within the BLM Fishtrap area and is open year-round. Recreation opportunities include boating, winter-only trout fishing, hiking, and horseback riding. Horseback riding typically starts from the Farmer's Landing parking lot along the access road south of the BLM ranch house (see site map). The entire water surface area of the lake is open for public use, but portions of the shoreline are privately owned. Refer to the map for shoreline private land boundaries and BLM public lands boundaries. The boat launch and all on-water recreation activities are administered by Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW). A WDFW permit is required to park in the parking lot. Please refer to Washington fishing and hunting regulations. No additional fees are charged by BLM. There are several non-motorized use trails at the site including the 1.3-mile Hog Lake Loop Trail which starts at the small BLM parking lot mid-way down the Hog Canyon Lake access road. Although slightly set back from the lake, the trail parallels the lake's west side, with easy off-trail access to overlooks of the lake.

name: Lake Washington Ship Canal
description: Various interpretive trails.

name: Discovery Park
description:
Open from 6 a.m. - 11 p.m., Discovery Park is a 534 acre natural area, and is the largest city park in Seattle.

Discovery Park, situated on Magnolia Bluff and overlooking the Puget Sound, is a perfect place to get out in nature. There is a total of 11.8 miles of trail running through this park. Trails take visitors through meadows, forests, and wetlands, and offer beautiful views of the surrounding Seattle area.

Remember to share the trail.

name: Ravenna Park
description: Great walking/jogging trails.

name: Cowen Park
description: Cowen Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Seattle, WA.

name: McCarthy Beach State Park
description: Wooded trails access the interior of the park. The rolling terrain is covered with mixed stands of pine, aspen and birch. The Pickerel Lake trail is a visitor favorite.

name: Island Center Forest
description: Excellent trails.

name: Martha Washington Park
description: Martha Washington Park is a beautiful expanse of green lawn, trees, and waterfront - a great place to bring your picnic blanket and frisbee. On a clear day, you can catch a glimpse of Mount Rainier as you lounge under a tree and look out over Lake Washington.

name: Mirror Lake Trailhead
description: The short trail traverses through dense forest terminating at scenic Mirror Lake. Undeveloped camping is allowed at the lake. The small lake is void of fish.

name: Crystal Lake Trails
description: Two excellent trails.

name: Mineral Ridge National Recreation Trail
description: The 3.3-mile trail was part of the first BLM recreation site developed in Idaho.  Construction began in 1963.  In 1982, the trail was designed as a National Recreation Trail and offers an invigorating hike and beautiful views of Lake Coeur d'Alene.  A Trail Guide describes the plants, animals and interrelationships of the forest at 22 marked stations along the trail.

name: Warren G. Magnuson Park
description: Open from 4 a.m. - 11:30 p.m., the Warren G. Magnuson Park offers 350 acres of park land and is Seattle's second largest park. A network of paved trails winds all throughout this urban park, taking you past an off-leash dog park, great picnic areas, a few beaches, and a beautiful stretch of Lake Washington's shoreline.

name: Dosewallips State Park
description: There is a wildlife viewing platform, and vast areas are open for field sports. Freshwater activities are nearby on the banks of the Dosewallips River, and saltwater activities can be found on nearby Hood Canal.

name: Beacon Hill
description: Beacon Hill features 25 miles of hiking trails near Spokane, WA.

name: Golden Gardens Park
description: Great trails.

name: Telford
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Burke-Gilman Trail
description: The trail follows a historic railroad route near the Lake Washington Ship Canal and north along Lake Washington to the Sammamish River. Along the way it passes the Hiram Chittenden Locks, Fremont Canal Park, Gas Works Park, University of Washington, Magnuson Park, Log Boom Park in Kenmore, Wayne Golf Course in Bothell and Blyth Park in Bothell. King County's best-known regional trail, the BGT is highly popular with cyclists, joggers, skaters and strollers.
