It is also an important nonmotorized route for weekday bicycle commuters between Seattle and the Eastside. The trail provides great access and views of the Ship Canal, Lake Union, Seattle neighborhoods, suburban cities, Lake Washington, and points east via other regional trails.

name: Matthews Beach Park
description:
Matthews Beach is Seattle's largest freshwater bathing beach. It's open from 6 a.m.-10 p.m. everyday, and spans 22 beautiful acres along the Pontiac Bay.

The park includes a boat launch, a guarded beach, picnic sites, children's play areas, volleyball and basketball courts, restrooms, and plenty of hiking trails for the whole family to enjoy!

name: Licton Springs Park
description: Licton Springs Park is a 7.6-acre park right beside North Seattle Community College. This park is a great place to come and tune out the city for a little bit with hiking paths, woods, creeks and small ponds to enjoy!

name: Sandy Lake - Mississippi River
description: The Headwaters Lakes Project is located in Minnesota's lake country. Campfires and sunsets and the peacefulness of the water make each day a special event. The dams were originally constructed of native materials (earthen embankments filled with puddled clay, and timber control structures) in the early 1880s, except Gull Lake, which was constructed in 1912, using concrete. Sandy Lake Dam had the northernmost navigational lock on the Mississippi River and was the site of an early trading post.

name: Cascade River State Park
description: Trails take the hiker through a variety of terrain. Many scenic areas along trails. The Superior Hiking Trail also runs through the park.

name: Scenic State Park
description: These are easy to moderate trails that take you through wooded areas including a virgin pine forest. The Chase Point Trail is on an esker between Coon and Sandwick lakes.

name: Sammamish River Trail
description: Super hiking/jogging.

name: Carkeek Park
description: This popular park offers extraordinary views of Puget Sound and the Olympic Mountains. Explore the secrets of this northwest Seattle watershed, nine miles from downtown. Here, 220 acres of lush forest, meadows, wetlands, creeks, and beach are formed by the magic of water and time. Come take part in an education program, have a picnic, or get involved as a volunteer teacher or as part of an outdoor work party. Walk the Pipers Canyon Story Trail, play on the uniquely salmon themed play area, or touch time at the historic Piper Orchard.

name: Big Finn Hill
description: Big Finn Hill features 5 miles of hiking trails near Kirkland, WA.

name: St. Edwards State Park
description: St. Edwards State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Kirkland, WA.

name: Cherry Valley
description: Cherry Valley features 15 miles of hiking trails near Duval, WA.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: K: Hwy 2 to Hwy 20
description:
Section K of the PCT runs 117.5 miles from Highway 2 at Stevens Pass to Highway 20 at Rainy Pass. This is one of the most challenging sections of the entire pacific crest trail, second only to the section that runs with the John Muir Trail in California. Highlights of this section include the gorgeous Glacier Peak and the Glacier Peak Wilderness.<br />
<br />
Along the way the trail passes Skykomish, WA; a 3-yard wide tributary of Nason Creek; Lake Janus; Glasses Lake; Grizzly Peak; Grizzly Lake; Wenatchee Pass; Saddle Gap; Cady Pass; Lake Sally Ann; Wards Pass; Indian Pass; Indian Pass to Miners Creek Detour; Murky Kid Pond; Lower White Pass; Red Pass; White Chuck River; Baekos Creek; Chetwok Creek; Sitkum Creek; Kennedy Creek; Glacier Creek; Pumice Creek; Fire Creek; Fire Creek Pass; Mica Lake; Mica Creek; Milk Creek; Vista Ridge; Vista Creek; Gamma Creek; Suiattle River; Buck Creek Pass; Miners Creek; Suiattle Pass; South Fork Agnes Creek; Agnes Creek; High Bridge Ranger Station; Stehekin, WA; Coon Lake; McGregor Creek; Buzzard Creek; Canim Creek; Bridge Creek Ranger Station; Berry Creek; Bridge Creek; Maple Creek; North Cascades National Park; Highway 20; and Rainy lake.

name: Pleasant Harbor State Park
description: Beautiful hiking with wildlife viewing platform.

name: Riverside State Park
description: 1 mile of ADA trail; excellent hiking.

name: Garrison Dam Lake Sakakawea
description: Garrison Dam, ND is located 75 miles northwest of Bismarck on the Missouri River. Lake Sakakawea is 178 miles long with 1,340 miles of shoreline and extends from Riverdale to Trenton. There are 35 recreation areas around Lake Sakakawea offering outdoor recreation opportunities such as camping, boating, fishing, sailing and hunting. The lake is an important resting stop for whooping cranes and a nesting area for the least tern and piping plover.

name: Finley Point State Park
description: Finley Point State Park contains a secluded campground on the south end of the Flathead Lake. Fishing, swimming and boating are excellent here. Hiking, golfing, water skiing, windsurfing and picnicking are other common activities here.

name: Centennial Trail State Park
description: The park, which is a 37-mile-long trail, is open to hikers, mountain bikers, joggers, roller bladers and (in some spots) equestrians. The trailheads are marked with the Centennial Trail logo.

name: Paradise Valley
description: Paradise Valley features 15 miles of hiking trails near Woodinville, WA.

name: Paradise Valley Conservation Area (PVCA)
description: 793 acres located south of SR-522 on Paradise Lake Road and adjacent to the Snohomish/King County line.  A majority of the site is heavily-timbered and contains a vast wetland area.

name: Bear Head Lake State Park
description: Connects with the Taconite State Trail.

name: Southwest County Olympic View Park
description: The site has two nature trails -- the larger trail system is on the north side of Olympic View Drive and a smaller one on the south side (inside of the bend in the road).  Use of off-road vehicles is not allowed on the trails.

name: Big Arm State Park
description: Big Arm State Park is a common hiking, camping, fishing and swimming destination due to its location on the pristine Flathead Lake. The park's landscape is made up of mature ponderosa pines, junipers, Big Arm Bay and surrounding mountain ranges. Visitors enjoy hiking through the great views of the nearby mountain ranges.

name: Soudan Underground Mine State Park
description: The Hiking Club trail starts at the Visitor Center, travels past the Soudan Iron Formation, through wooded areas of the park and along the rim of the old open mine pits. A map of the hiking trails is available at Park Office.

name: Lake Wenatchee State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Tambark Creek Park
description: Tambark Park is a 40-acre blend of open fields, woodlands, and wetlands, with features that include restrooms, sports field, picnic shelters, and off-leash area.

name: Steamboat Rock State Park
description: The Northrup Canyon day-use area offers hiking, biking and equestrian opportunities.

name: Meadowdale Beach Park
description: View various bird species in their natural habitat on a hike through the forest.  Or comb the beaches and enjoy the breathtaking views of the distant Olympic Mountains.

name: Bob Heirman Wildlife Preserve at Thomas' Eddy
description: The hike is an easy, mostly flat, 3-mile hike that protects undeveloped riverfront and important floodplain along the Snohomish River at Thomas' Eddy. Here the powerful river ripples and churns through a pair of tight hairpin turns, occasionally jumping its banks to create new channels and oxbow ponds. As you are hiking, watch for waterfowl, such as ducks and swans. Take in views of the marshy meadows and Lord Hill rising above the river. Pack a picnic lunch, water, and a camera, but leave the dogs at home as they are prohibited in the preserve.

name: Olympic National Park
description:
When you visit the Olympic Wilderness, whether to clamber along the roaring beaches of the wilderness coast, to immerse yourself in the freshness and healing of the old-growth forests, or to push yourself up onto the peaks and ridges of the high country, keep in mind that this remnant of wild America is fragile.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Lord Hill Regional Park
description: Lord Hill Regional Park features 15 miles of hiking trails near Monroe, WA.

name: Judge C.R. Magney State Park
description: Judge C.R. Magney State Park is known for its scenic waterfalls, camping, wildlife observation, trout fishing, hiking and picnicking. This is a year round day-use park, but the campground will be closed in the winter. Nine miles of hiking trails of moderate to challenging difficulty level are available. The trails lead you to the a series of waterfalls, forested areas and a nature trail.

name: Wallace Falls
description: Wallace Falls features 20 miles of hiking trails near Goldbar, WA.

name: Wild Horse Island State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Interurban Trail
description: The Interurban Trail links Tukwila, Kent, Auburn, Algona, and Pacific along a near-straight 14 mile-long alignment following the historic Interurban Rail Line. To the north, the Interurban starts at an intersection with the Green River Trail at Fort Dent Way near Fort Dent Park. The trail crosses over the Green River and under Interstate 405, then turns straight south within the Puget Sound Energy powerline corridor. The alignment crosses a wide variety of landscapes and provides views of many regional activities. Following the BNSF railroad south, the landscape passes through historic industrial areas and suburban lands before crossing the broad Green River Valley. The trail provides access to the Southcenter area, Renton Junction, downtown Kent, Emerald Downs in Auburn, and the communities of Algona and Pacific. The trail currently ends at 3rd Avenue SW in Pacific. A second southern intersection with the Green River Trail occurs at Kent's Foster Park, providing the possibility of an Interurban-Green River Trail recreational loop through the Green River Valley. The Interurban is an excellent north-south off-road, nonmotorized route that is popular with commuters between south King County and employment centers in Auburn, Kent, Tukwila, Renton, and Seattle. Access and parking are provided at numerous locations along the trail.

name: Bogachiel State Park
description: "It isn't the end of the world, but you can see it from there." So goes a popular Northwest saying about this vicinity. The remote park, located on the tip of the Hoh Rainforest, abounds in lush vegetation.

name: Beardance
description: This is a gorgeous trail that is super easy to access since it is right off of Hwy 35. The beginning of the trail is rocky and rough, but it smooths out higher up. As you continue to climb up along the side of the ridge, you are afforded several incredible views of the Flathead Lake, which is right below you. This trail is the perfect nearby day-hike destination!

name: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area
description:
Four self-guided walking trails in the park will take you back in time so you can explore the history and geology of Lake Roosevelt or simply enjoy the beauty of it's diverse scenery and terrain.<br />
Mission Point Trail: Only one-mile from the Kettle Falls Campground, at St. Paul's Mission, a 1/4 mile trail combines history and nature. There are signs along the trail explaining the history of the falls, the mission, and the Hudson's Bay Company's influence on the area.The view of the river is rivaled only by the abundance of plants you will find along the trail.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Flowing Lake Park at Leckie's Beach
description: Nature trail.

name: Mount Spokane State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Lake Mary Ronan State Park
description: Numerous hiking trails.

name: Red River State Recreation Area
description: Trails pass through the campground.

name: Narbeck Wetland Sanctuary Park
description: This 42.76 acre park  is accessible for passive recreational use with trails, interpretive signs, viewpoints, picnic tables, and restrooms. Narbeck offers two (2) walking trails, a small loop trail and a 1/2 mile interpretative trail around the perimeter, with educational signs and self guided tours.

name: Turtle River State Park
description: Turtle River State Park has a system of mountain biking, hiking, and interpretive trails. Winter users will find more than 7.5 miles of groomed cross country ski trails, and plenty of opportunities for snowshoeing.

name: Japanese Gulch
description: Japanese Gulch features 10 miles of hiking trails near Mukilteo, WA.

name: Farragut State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Lake Roesiger Park
description: Forested Trails

name: Spencer Island
description: Spencer Island is one of the best places in the Snohomish River Estuary to view waterfowl and shorebirds. Deer, coyote, river otter, and a host of small mammals and amphibians also inhabit the large island. The island has a dike top trail system, which provides scenic views of the wetlands, sloughs and mountains.

name: Fort Peck Project
description: Excellent hiking trails, as well as interpretive walks.

name: Grand Portage State Park
description: Nice trails for hiking. Boardwalk is wheelchair accessible and leads to the scenic overlook for High Falls, Minnesota's highest waterfall.

name: Bridgeport State Park
description: Bridgeport State Park is a 748-acre camping park with 7,500 feet of freshwater shoreline on Rufus Woods Lake. Set directly behind Chief Joseph Dam, this lake is actually a segment of the Columbia River. The park provides 18 acres of lawn and some shade in the midst of a desert terrain. "Haystacks," unusual volcanic formations resembling their name, are the park's most striking feature.

name: Anderson Lake State Park
description: Anderson Lake State Park features 4 miles of hiking trails near Port Townsend, WA.

name: Alta Lake State Park
description: Beautiful hiking in the park and vicinity.

name: Sequim Bay State Park
description: The Olympic Discovery Trail is a paved county maintained trail that travels from Port Angeles through the park.

name: Grahams Island State Park
description: Grahams Island State Park has two trails for hiking or walking. One is a 1.6 mile loop that can be accessed by the Sivert Thompson activity center. The other is a .5 mile loop located on the north end of the west campground.

name: Chief Joseph Dam and Rufus Woods Lake
description: With a total of 27 generating units, Chief Joseph Dam is the second-largest hydropower producer in the United States -- second only to Grand Coulee Dam. The power plant produces enough power to supply the electrical needs of over 1.5 million people.

name: Isle Royale National Park
description:
If you only have a few hours to spend on Isle Royale, day hiking is an excellent way to get into the backcountry for solitude and exploration. There are a number of short hikes available, from a 1-mile jaunt near Windigo to a 4-mile loop out to Scoville Point near Rock Harbor.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: South Whidbey State Park
description: Beautiful area for hiking.

name: Mount Pilchuck State Park
description: The park's most notable feature is a fire lookout building that sits atop the mountain. The fire lookout is on the National Historic Building register and has five interpretive plaques which identify the mountains seen from the building. There also are displays about the history of the lookout.

name: Wayfarers State Park
description: Nature walks over the rocky shoreline to the cliffs are popular with photographers for an excellent view of Flathead Lake.

name: Big Four Ice Caves / #723
description:
Debris piles of ice and snow from winter avalanches remain all summer long due to the shade from the 6,135 foot mountain. During the summer, rivers and streams of runoff below the ice form ice caves.<br />
<br />
According to Wikipedia, "The Big Four Ice Caves trail #723 is one of the most popular hikes in the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest attracting over 50,000 visitors per year." The parking lots are often filled past capacity, forcing hikers to park on the road. According to Wikipedia, while the trail is open to the public, the snowfields themselves are off limits due to the danger of cave ins that have caused fatalities in the past.

name: Fort Townsend State Park
description: Bicycles are permitted on some of the hiking trails.

name: Lime Kiln Trailhead
description: A series of trail signs, mile markers and trail names are installed along the way. The major landmark is the Lime Kiln structure. Behind it is where the lime was mined. Along the trail, there is a series of squatters and rail activity remnants. The scenery and the landscape are spectacular.

name: Robe Canyon Historic Trail
description: Hike the mile-long trail from the road to the river for a breathtaking view of Robe Canyon.  Only minutes from the town of Granite Falls, Robe Canyon has the look and feel of somewhere much more remote.  The return hike can be a challenge.  Portions of the trail are inaccessible during the rainy season.

name: Spruce R.R. Trail
description: Spruce R.R. Trail features 11 miles of hiking trails near Port Angeles, WA.

name: Fort Flagler State Park
description: In addition to the trails, there are 12.5 miles of roads and 3.6 miles of beach front to explore.

name: Black Butte Trails
description: These hiking/biking trails are on the private property of the Effertz family, who run Black Butte Adventures.  Do not enter the property if the gate is closed.  A box for donations is at the second gate.  If you follow the road past that gate (on foot or on a bicycle), a meandering singletrack path winds through the property.

name: Lake Pend Oreille
description: Excellent hiking throughout the area.

name: Adventure Route Segment Of The Odt
description: Adventure Route Segment Of The Odt features 26 miles of hiking trails near Port Angeles, WA.

name: Lewis and Clark State Park
description: Lewis and Clark State Park is situated on one of the upper bays of Lake Sakakawea. The rugged buttes of the North Dakota Badlands display a towering backdrop to one of the state's best recreation areas.

name: Camano Island State Park
description: Nice hiking trails.

name: Fort Worden State Park
description: 5 miles are ADA accessible.

name: CDT MT14: Badger Pass to Marias Pass and US Hwy 2
description:
Section 14 of the CDT in Montana runs 35.8 miles from Badger Pass to Marias Pass and US Highway 2. Along the way, the trail passes through the Bob Marshall Wilderness and passes by Beaver Lake, Family Peak, Scarface Mountain, Mount Poia, Morningstar Mountain, Spotted Eagle Mountain, Curly Bear Mountain, Elbow Mountain, Bruin Peaks East, Goat Mountain, Running Owl Mountain, Big Lodge Mountain, Crescent Cliff, Bullshoe Mountain, Running Crane Mountain, Elkcalf Mountain, Mount Baldy, Mount Pablo, Two Medicine Ridge East, and Two Medicine Ridge West.<br />
<br />
Recommended parking spot: lat=48.3189890134, lon=-113.352488327

name: Kayak Point Regional County Park
description: Nature trail.

name: Wolf Creek Trail/trail #544
description: This is a gorgeous trail that winds up the side of the mountains that passes through some deep stands of pine trees with loamy dirt, and through some high, rocky sections of trail and several scree fields. There are plenty of incredible views of the Flathead Valley and Flathead Lake.

name: Cama Beach State Park
description: While at Cama Beach, you can explore the expansive shoreline, gaze at beautiful sunsets, view an array of wildlife, hike or bike the area's 15 miles of trail and take in a boating workshop with the Center for Wooden Boats. Or just relax in a cozy historic cabin that offers the best of both worlds - the feel of earlier times and the ease of modern conveniences.

name: Herron Park/foys To Blacktail Trail
description: Located in Herron Park, located outside of Kalispell. Singletrack is spread around, with some old fire roads. There are a few great views to be had off of the top of the ridge too! The Foys to Blacktail singletrack trail takes off from Herron Park and, when completed, will climb all the way to the Blacktail ski resort.

name: Mount Aeneas, Trail #717
description: From the parking lot at Camp Misery, it's 3 miles and 1,778 feet of elevation gain up the trail to the summit of Mt. Aeneas. At its summit, Aeneas measures 7,528 feet above sea level. The first 1/2 to 3/4 of the ascent is below tree line, but there are still a few opportunities for views. The last section, though, is above the tree line as you traverse a ridge on your way to the ultimate summit, and the views of the Flathead Valley on one side and the endless mountains on the other sides are totally worth all of the effort! An above-tree-line view is pretty rare in this area of Montana, too.

name: Fort Casey State Park
description: Fort Casey State Park is a 467-acre marine camping park with a lighthouse and sweeping views of Admiralty Inlet and the Strait of Juan de Fuca. A coast artillery post features two 10-inch and two 3-inch historic guns on display. The park features 10,810 feet of saltwater shoreline on Puget Sound (Admiralty Inlet), and includes Keystone Spit, a two-mile-plus stretch of land separating Admiralty Inlet and Crocket Lake.

name: Switchback, Trail #725
description: Switchback/Trail #725 runs for 3 miles between the Jewel Basin Road and the Mount Aeneas Trail #717, right on the edge of the Jewel Basin Hiking Area. It's called "Switchback" because of the 42 switchbacks in its short 3 mile length. This is a beautiful trail deep in the majestic pines... enjoy!

name: Round Lake State Park
description: Discover the area's beauty on some gorgeous trails.

name: Krause Basin-Area Trails (D)
description: This small network of trails is mostly doubletrack, but there are some beautiful singletrack sections as well! It's best to just bring a compass and do some exploring, as there isn't really any signage out here.

name: Lone Pine State Park
description: Lone Pine State Park is right on the edge of Kalispell, and is accessible from either the bottom or the top (it is basically located on the side of a mountain). There are several of miles of singletrack and doubletrack trails in the park that are very scenic and great for hiking. If you want to get out in the woods for an after work hike or trail run, this is the place!

name: River Meadows Park
description: With 150 acres of large open meadows and forests along the banks of the Stillaguamish River, River Meadows offers recreationists a variety of outdoor activities.

name: Bison Plant
description: Bison Plant features 3 miles of hiking trails near Minot, ND.

name: Portage Creek Wildlife Area
description: Wetland / Meadow Trails

name: Big Bog State Recreation Area
description: Trails begin in the picnic areas in both units of the park.

name: Fort Ebby St Park
description: Fort Ebby St Park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Coupville/whidbey Is, WA.

name: Fort Ebey State Park
description: Panoramic views of the Puget Sound shoreline, the Olympic Mountains and sunsets. The park features paragliding, surfing and gun batteries to explore. Eagles may be viewed at Lake Pondilla.

name: Victoria Tract - Pilchuck Tree Farm
description: Victoria Tract - Pilchuck Tree Farm features 35 miles of hiking trails near Arlington, WA.

name: Twin Lakes
description: This area is a unique part of the Channeled Scablands with more than 14,000 acres of BLM public land located in Lincoln County. It is managed for its recreational opportunities, wildlife habitat, and seasonal livestock grazing. Camp or picnic between upper and lower Twin Lakes where shade trees offer a tranquil setting. Non-motorized trails wind through shrub-steppe uplands, past numerous wetlands, and through the upper Lake Creek Canyon. Fish for Rainbow trout, largemouth bass, yellow perch, yellow bullhead, black crappie and sunfish in the lake. For fishing or hunting regulations in the Twin Lakes area, contact the Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife. A dirt boat launch ramp is available for small boats.

name: Squire Creek Park
description: Enjoy nature at its finest!  Squire Creek offers RV and tent camping among the beautiful moss-laden trees of an old growth forest. The park is a perfect staging area for adventures into the Mt Baker - Snoqualmie National Forest,  hiking to the base of Whitehorse Mountain, or participating in the Bluegrass Festival in Darrington.  Two large picnic shelters are located near the crystal clear waters of Squire Creek.

name: Gamlin Lake Trail
description: This gentle and easy trail loops through a forest overstory and provides foot access to Gamlin Lake.  The trail is closed to motorized and equestrian uses. The trail can be used for cross-country skiing during the winter but it is not groomed.

name: Tatman Rail Trail
description: This ten mile trail travels along the old Great Northern Railroad's Tatman Branch Line (named for its location in Tatman Township), which once ran up to the Minot Air Force Base.  This flat gravel multi-use trail is used by hikers, runners, bicycles and snowmobiles.

name: Joseph Whidbey State Park
description: ADA accessible trail.

name: CDT MT15: Marias Pass and US Hwy 2 to East Glacier Park
description: Section 15 of the CDT in Montana runs for 15.7 miles from Marias Pass and US Highway 2 to East Glacier Park. Along the way, the trail passes Little Dog Mountain, Summit Mountain, Calf Robe Mountain, Red Crow Mountain, and Bearhead Mountain.

name: Pig Farm
description: Pig Farm features 30 miles of hiking trails near Whitefish, MT.

name: Old Mill State Park
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Libby Dam and Lake Koocanusa
description: Nestled in the mountains of Northwestern Montana lies one of the state's best-kept secrets. Libby Dam was built to provide flood protection for the Kootenai and lower Columbia Rivers, as well as providing an additional source of hydroelectric power for the region. Recreation is abundant with ample boating, camping and hiking opportunities. The Kootenai River is a blue ribbon trout stream. The state record rainbow trout (33 lbs) was caught right below the dam. Trout and kokanee salmon are also found in abundance in Lake Koocanusa. One of the many unique features of Libby Dam is a 75-ton granite sculpture found on the face of the Treaty Tower, the largest tower on the dam. This sculpture was part of an international competition held during construction commemorating the Columbia River Treaty, which allowed for the construction of Libby Dam. Public dam tours are available during the summer months at 10, 12, 2, and 4 o'clock daily. Group tours are available year-round with advanced notice. Due to budget cuts, the Visitor Center will be closed on Wednesdays in 2004.

name: Spencer Mountain
description: Spencer Mountain features 0 miles of hiking trails near Whitefish, MT.

name: Deception Pass State Park
description: 1.2 miles of ADA accessible trails; excellent hiking.

name: Little Mountain
description: Little Mountain  features 8 miles of hiking trails near Mount Vernon, WA.

name: Tally Lake Overlook
description: This is a steep, rocky, rooty climb to the top of the cliff above Tally Lake and some incredible views of the lake and the mountains.

name: Whitefish Trail
description: Whitefish Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Whitefish , MT.

name: CDT MT16: East Glacier Park to Pray Lake
description: Section 16 of the CDT in Montana runs for 10.7 miles from East Glacier Park to Pray Lake. Along the way, the trail enters <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/hiking-trails/Montana/Glacier-National-Park_2997">Glacier National Park</a> and passes Mount Henry, Appistoki Peak, and Two Medicine Lake.

name: Johnson Peak/Trixie Pass
description: This is a very steep trail climbing up to the lookout on top of Johnson Peak, and then going down the other side to a junction with a gravel road. Then, turn around and hike back up and over. There are a couple of good views to be had along the way.

name: Cattle Point
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: Sun Mountain Resort
description: Sun Mountain Resort features 80 miles of hiking trails near Winthrop, WA.

name: Heart Lake - Acfl
description: Heart Lake - Acfl features 10 miles of hiking trails near Anacortes, WA.

name: Big Mtn
description: Big Mtn features 8 miles of hiking trails near Whitefish, MT.

name: Rockport State Park
description:
The Evergreen Trail at Rockport State Park is a 2.7 mile hiking trail through old-growth forest. The trail reopened in 2012 after the completion of a maintenance and trail relocation project.
Sauk Mountain Trail is accessed by U.S. Forest Service Rd. 1030, located on the west boundary of the park. From Hwy. 20 to the Sauk Mountain trailhead is approximately eight miles of gravel logging road. From the trailhead to the summit is approximately three miles. The trail has numerous switchbacks and is moderately steep. The summit offers good views of the Skagit Valley and the North Cascades. For more information on trails and trail conditions in the North Cascades National Park and the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, call 360-856-5700.

name: Iceberg Point
description: Excellent hiking area.

name: CDT MT17: Pray Lake to Going-to-the-Sun Hwy
description: Section 17 of the CDT in Montana runs for 40.6 miles from Pray Lake to the Going-to-the-Sun Highway. Along the way, the trail passes through Glacier National Park and passes by Dry Fork, Rising Wolf Mountain, Red Mountain, Mount Morgan, Old Man Lake, Pitamaken Lake, Seven Winds of the Lake, Katoya Lake, McClintock Mountain, Morningstar Lake, Medicine Grizzly Peak, Eagle Plume Mountain, Bad Marriage Mountain, Atlantic Falls, Mount James, Medicine Grizzly Lake, Triple Divide Pass, Triple Divide Peak, Razoredge Mountain, Norris Mountain, Split Mountain, Apikuni Mountain, Medicine Owl Peak, Kakitos Mountain, Red Eagle Lake, Curly Bear Mountain, Red Eagle Mountain, Mahtotopa Mountain, St. Mary Lake, Virginia Creek, Virginia Falls, St Mary Falls, Gunsight Trail, Deadwood Falls, and Reynolds Creek.

name: Pearrygin Lake State Park
description: The park features the 3.1-mile Rex Derr trail, a multi-seasonal trail that begins at the east boat launch, traverses a hillside up through the shrub-steppe environment, skirts the old Graves Homestead and winds its way back through the east campground.

name: Anacortes Community Forest Lands
description: Anacortes Community Forest Lands features 20 miles of hiking trails near Anacortes, WA.

name: James Island State Park
description: James Island offers great short hikes with dramatic views from high bluffs. Hikers with children should be aware of fall hazards due to rocky high banks and cliffs and surrounding waters that are deep and swift.

name: Pacific Crest Trail: L: Hwy 20 to Hwy 3 (Manning Park, BC)
description:
Section L of the Pacific Crest Trail is the final section of the trail in Washington, and consequently the final section for the entire trail. This section runs 70.3 miles from Highway 20 at Rainy Pass, across the American/Canadian Border, and ends at Highway 3 in Manning Park in British Columbia. Much of this section lies far to the east of the Cascades. As a result, this section receives much less snow than Mt. Baker (one of the snowiest places on the planet), but it can still be snow covered into the late summer. <br />
<br />
Along the way this section of trail passes Porcupine Creek; Cutthroat Pass; Granite Pass; Methow Pass; Golden Creek; West Fork Methow River; Glacier Pass; Alpine-garden pass above South Fork Trout Creek; Harts Pass; Buffalo Pass; Windy Pass; Foggy Pass; Jim Pass; Devils Backbone; Holman Pass; alternate PCT route; Hopkins Pass; Castle Pass; Monument 78, United States-Canada Border; Castle Creek; Windy Joe Mountain; old PCT route; and Manning Park Lodge.

name: Lime Kiln Point State Park
description: ADA hiking.

name: Rasar State Park
description: 1 miles ADA hiking trails.

name: Watmough Bay
description: Nice short trail.

name: Glacier National Park
description:
Over half of the visitors to Glacier National Park report taking a hike. That's a lot of hikers, but over 700 miles of trail provide many outstanding opportunities for both short hikes and extended backpacking trips. <br />
Source National Park Service

name: Spencer Spit State Park
description: Excellent short hikes.

name: Priest Lake State Park
description: Excellent network of trails.

name: Buck Mountain
description: Buck Mountain features 10 miles of hiking trails near Winthrop, WA.

name: Voyageurs National Park
description:
Hike along one of the nine trails within Voyageurs National Park and explore the wonderful diversity the park has to offer. Trails are accessible by water and by land.Note that pets are not permitted on park hiking trails.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Brush Lake State Park
description: Brush Lake State Park is home to the 280-acre Brush Lake. The park is an excellent place for swimming, wildlife viewing, boating and waterskiing. The high alkali content does not support fish life. Canoeing, hiking, picnicking, camping and birdwatching are other common activities here.

name: Obstruction Pass State Park
description: There is a self-guided interpretive trail along the 0.6-mile trail to Obstruction Pass beach. The trail includes information about the geology, ecology and the cultural significance of Obstruction Pass and Orcas Island.

name: Granite Peak
description: Granite Peak features 20 miles of hiking trails near Colville, WA.

name: Franz Jevne State Park
description: The park offers excellent scenic hiking.

name: Hayes Lake State Park
description: Wooded trail runs along lakeshore and river.

name: Larrabee State Park
description: Excellent hiking.

name: Moran State Park
description: Moran State Park is a 5,252-acre camping park with five freshwater lakes and over 30 miles of hiking trails. Atop the 2,409-foot-high Mt. Constitution, the highest point on the San Juan Islands, there stands a stone observation tower built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1936. The tower offers panoramic views of the surrounding islands, the Cascade Mountains and a variety of Canadian and American cities.

name: North Cascades National Park
description:
The North Cascades National Park Service Complex preserves some of the finest mountain country in North America-a hiker's smorgasbord. From accessible trails and short, scenic strolls to steep, grueling hikes that will make your legs burn but your heart sing, there is a trail here that will suit your mood. The extreme gradients of climate and topography contribute to an impressive diversity of habitat and species. To navigate the incredibly steep elevational relief, the nearly 400 miles of trails often follow the long, forested, valley bottoms, then switchback up to the steep passes or ridges. Over 300 glaciers cling to the spires, peaks, horns and ridges of the surrounding mountains, and more than 127 alpine lakes lie in glacial cirque basins below. The valleys are narrow, deep, and U-shaped, covered on the lower reaches with dense stands of old trees and layers of green undergrowth.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Stuart Island State Park
description: Stuart Island State Park is an 85-acre marine camping park with 33,030 feet of shoreline. The park is part of the Cascadia Marine Trail and offers camping and moorage at Reed and Prevost harbors. Some campsites are for the exclusive use of those arriving by human- or wind-powered watercraft.

name: CDT MT18: Going-to-the-Sun Hwy to Swiftcurrent Lake and Many Glacier Road
description: Section 18 of the CDT in Montana runs from the Going-to-the-Sun Highway to Swiftcurrent Lake and Many Glacier Road. Along the way, the trail passes through Glacier National Park and passes by Going-to-the-Sun Mountain, Matahpi Peak, Piegan Mountain, Mount Siyeh, Cataract Mountain, Piegan Pass, Pollock Mountain, Bishops Cap, Mount Gould, Haystack Butte, Allen Mountain, Grinnell Lake, Lake Josephine, and Lake Sherborne.

name: Clement's Mountain
description: This hike is about 2 miles each way, and it climbs steeply up through a scree field to a peak overlooking this region of GNP. The view is absolutely stunning! Be forewarned, though: despite the short length, this is a strenuous hike, especially if you're not used to the elevation. And bring your camera!

name: Highline
description: The Highline trail is one of the most popular trails in Glacier National Park, and for good reason: the views off of this high-altitude trail just can't be put into words. For almost its entire 11 mile length, you are treated to views of tall, rocky mountain peaks, glaciers, and the valley far, far below you. If you come to Glacier, you need to hike this trail!

name: Galbraith Mtn
description: Galbraith Mtn features 20 miles of hiking trails near Bellingham, WA.

name: Curlew Lake State Park
description: The fossil-dig site at Stone Rose is worth the trip for the rock hound and the archeologically curious. A trip to Grand Forks in Canada is a nice day trip for the family.

name: Lake Bronson State Park
description: These are easy trails that take you through prairie and aspen parklands. Some of the trails wind along the lake. Hard-packed gravel on the lakeside trail makes it suitable for strollers.

name: Sucia Island State Park
description: Sucia Island State Park is a 564-acre marine park with 77,700 feet of shoreline. Sucia Island is considered the crown jewel of the state's marine park system. It is consistently ranked as one of the top boating destinations in the world. Sucia Island and several smaller island comprise the "Sucia group."

name: Patos Islands
description: Nice trail. Moderate.

name: Icelandic State Park
description: A 3/4 mile self-guided interpretive trail begins at the Gunlogson Homestead site and loops along the south side of the Tongue River. Other trails continue throughout the 200 acre Gunlogson Nature Preserve and natural wooded area along the river. Foot bridges provide easy crossing of the Tongue River and the area's many natural springs. The majority of this 3 mile trail system is groomed and open in the winter for cross-country skiing. A 6 mile paved bike and hiking trail connects the park to Cavalier and to the golf course just west of the park.

name: CDT MT19: Swiftcurrent Lake and Many Glacier Road to Canada Border
description: Section 19 of the CDT in Montana runs for 35.9 miles from Swiftcurrent Lake and Many Glacier Road in Glacier National Park to the Canadian border. Along the way, the trail passes Altyn Peak, Apikuni Mountain, Mount Henkel, Crowfeet Mountain, Fisher Cap Lake, Redrock Lake, Bullhead Lake, Mount Grinnell, Mount Wilbur, Swiftcurrent Pass, Swiftcurrent Mountain, Iceberg Peak, Ahern Peak, Ipasha Peak, Mount Kipp, Cathedral Peak, Kootenai Peak, Stoney Indian Peaks South, Stoney Indian Peaks North, Kootenai Lakes, Porcupine Ridge East, Citadel Peaks East, Waterton Lake, Goat Haunt Mountain, Olson Mountain, and Campbell Mountain.

name: Zippel Bay State Park
description: Beautiful hiking area.

name: Palmer Mountain
description: Palmer Mountain Recreation Area is a great place for hiking, backpacking, horseback riding, hunting, mounting biking, and fishing at Washburn Lake. Dispersed camping is also allowed. The autumn is especially picturesque when the many stands of aspen create a brilliant background. For those who want to "get away from it all," there are plenty of hiking options on a number of roads and trails that branch off the main Palmer Mountain Road. You are sure to find a favorite spot to enjoy the quiet, scenic views of the Okanogan hillsides, aspen groves and grasslands, and the peaceful waters of Washburn Lake.

name: Birch Bay State Park
description: Birch Bay State Park has an active summer interpretive program, a 1/2 mile Terrell Marsh Interpretive Trail and four interpretive signs throughout the park.

name: Chopaka Lake
description: Enjoy the solitude of Chopaka Lake and the nearby Chopaka Mountain Wilderness Study Area. Aspen groves and sagebrush line the shores, providing a scenic backdrop to lakeside activities. You might even see a mountain goat or two, high on the surrounding mountain sides. Eight campsites with fire rings and a vault outhouse provide camping facilities at the lake. Try your luck at fly fishing for trout, or take a peaceful hike in the 5,518 acre wilderness study area. Hike or boat-in camping is also allowed in the WSA, but there are no developed campsites.

name: Lake Metigoshe State Park
description: Lake Metigoshe State Park features 15 miles of hiking trails near Bottineau, ND.

name: CDT MT19 Alt: Swiftcurrent Lake and Many Glacier Road to Chief Mountain Trailhead and MT Hwy 17
description:
The Continental Divide Trail has two different endings, and this is the alternate section 19 leading to an alternate ending at the Chief Mountain Trailhead on MT Hwy 17, which is just south of the Canadian border. Note: GPS location given is for the Chief Mountain Trailhead. For the Swiftcurrent Lake GPS location, click over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/hiking-trails/Montana/CDT-MT19--Swiftcurrent-Lake-and-Many-Glacier-Road-to-Canada-Border_5233">regular Section 19</a>.

Alt Section 19 of the CDT in Montana runs for 27.4 miles from Swiftcurrent Lake and Many Glacier Road to the Chief Mountain Trailhead. Along the way, the trail passes through <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/hiking-trails/Montana/Glacier-National-Park_2997">Glacier National Park</a> and passes by Altyn Peak, Apikuni Mountain, Lake Sherborne, Swiftcurrent Ridge, Poia Lake, Crowfeet Mountain, Ptarmigan Wall, Seward Mountain, Red Gap Pass, Lake Elizabeth, Natoas Peak, Cosley Ridge, Gable Mountain, Yellow Mountain West, Yellow Mountain East, Belly River Valley, Bear Mountain, Belly River Trail, Sentinel Mountain, and Belly River.

name: CDT MT20: US/Canada Border to Bertha Lake Trailhead
description:
The Final, northernmost section of the CDT, and the 20th section of the CDT in Montana (although it is technically located in Alberta, Canada), runs for 4.3 miles along the shores of Waterton Lake from the US/Canada border to the Northern Terminus of the Continental Divide Trail at the Bertha Lake Trailhead in Waterton, Alberta.

Recommended parking spot: Bertha Lake Trailhead (Northern Terminus): lat=49.0466190876, lon=-113.917041108

There is also an alternative ending and northern terminus to the Continental Divide Trail: click on over to <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/hiking-trails/Montana/CDT-MT19-Alt--Swiftcurrent-Lake-and-Many-Glacier-Road-to-Chief-Mountain-Trailhead-and-MT-Hwy-17_5234">the Alt Section 19</a> to check it out.

name: Sitka Area State Parks
description: Hiking is one of the most enjoyable aspects of these seven sites, offering both beaches and forests for hikers' enjoyment.

name: Eagle Beach State Reacreation Area
description: This is an approximately 600 acre unit located at the saltwater confluence of the Eagle and Herbert Rivers. This unit encompasses a campground, 2 day use areas and an extensive trail system.

name: Katmai National Park
description:
There are few designated hiking trails within Katmai National Park and Preserve, but the park offers more than 4 million acres of wilderness for exploration. The Brooks Camp area offers opportunities for day hiking.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Point Bridget State Park
description: Cedar Lake Trail, Trappers Route, Historic McMurchie Cat Road, North Bridget Cove Trail, and Point Bridget Trail provide hours of hiking. Extensive information on sites along the trails may be found at http://dnr.alaska.gov/parks/units/ptbridg2.htm.

name: Haines Area State Parks
description: Mosquito Lake State Rec Site, the Portage Cove State Rec Site and many of the other sites have several campsites; some accessible via bicycle or hiking only.

name: Chilkat Bald Eagle Preserve
description: Viewing wildlife is possible only from certain, marked areas. Walking on the flats is prohibited.

name: Kachemak Bay State Park and State Wilderness Park
description: The park's abundance of trails offer hikers the ability to reach Alaska's deep back country. Vehicle use, including bikes, are not permitted.

name: Chilkoot Trail
description:
The Chilkoot Trail is one of two main routes to the Klondike that originate in this area. Long before the gold rush, the trail was established by Tlingit people as a trade route into the interior of Canada. Fish, seal oil and seaweed were traded with the First Nations peoples for moose and caribou hides, plant materials and other goods unavailable on the coast.<br />
<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Peace Arch State Park
description: Peace Arch State Park is a 20-acre day-use park commemorating treaties and agreements that arose from the war of 1812. The park celebrates the unguarded United States/Canadian border that stretches from the Strait of Juan de Fuca to the Bay of Fundy in Nova Scotia. The park features horticultural exhibitions and the giant, commemorative, concrete arch that straddles the border of the two nations. The countries co-maintain the monument.

name: Wood-Tikchik State Park
description: The park lies in a biological transition zone between coniferous forest and tundra. In general, white spruce and mixed spruce-birch forest, as well as muskeg and willow-alder thickets exist up to approximately the 900-foot elevation. Above this are bare rock, heath tundra, and alpine meadow. At the lowest elevations, wet tundra and marshlands are common. Summer months are the wettest; and the area averages up to 160 inches of snow. Filing a trip plan is strongly advised. Leave it with a friend, your air taxi, the Wood-Tikchik State Park office, or someone else reliable. Be sure to close it when your trip is complete.

name: Ninilchik State Recreation Area
description: Hiking near the Ninilchik River offers opportunities to observe a variety of birds and small animals. Eagles are common sights as well.

name: Lost Lake Tr
description: Lost Lake Tr features 7 miles of hiking trails near Seward, AK.

name: Kenai Fjords
description:
Exit Glacier is the only part of the park accessible by road. Here you can stroll the trails, walk very close to an active glacier, or take a ranger-led walk. It is a place where you can witness up close how glaciers re-shape a landscape and learn how plant life reclaims the barren rocky land exposed by a glacier's retreat.<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Lake Clark National Park
description:
Enjoy a climb up to alpine lakes and tundra meadows, a stroll across river gravel bars, or a challenging bushwhack up to a seldom-visited waterfall.<br />
<br />
Source: National Park Service

name: Clam Gulch State Recreation Area
description: Hikers enjoy the views of the Aleutian Mountain Range and the wide variety of wild-life, both flora and fauna.

name: Kasilof Area State Parks
description:
Moose, black and brown bear, lynx, squirrels, hares and other creatures are plentiful in all of these areas. Enjoy and respect them for this is their home.
Hikers visit these popular recreation areas for glimpses of these species.

name: Kepler-bradley Lakes State Park
description: Kepler-bradley Lakes State Park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Wasilla, AK.

name: Johnson Pass
description: Johnson Pass features 24 miles of hiking trails near Turnagain Pass, AK.

name: Captain Cook State Recreation Area
description: While in the area, many visitors enjoy wildlife viewing, bird-watching, berry-picking and rock-hunting.

name: Chugach State Park
description: Featuring 26 trails, maps and a safety video are available on the park's website.

name: Far North Bicentennial Park- Hillside
description: Far North Bicentennial Park- Hillside features 80 miles of hiking trails near Anchorage, AK.

name: Campbell Tract
description: Blm Campbell Tract features 12 miles of hiking trails near Anchorage, AK.

name: Lakeside Trail, Eklutna Lake
description: Lakeside Trail, Eklutna Lake features 13 miles of hiking trails near Eklutna, AK.

name: Eklutna Trail
description: Eklutna Trail features 13 miles of hiking trails near Eklutna , AK.

name: Mooseberry Mesa
description: Mooseberry Mesa features 2 miles of hiking trails near Wasilla, AK.

name: Independence Mine State Historical Park
description: Learn what it was like to live and work in one of Alaska's largest gold mining camps. Begin your tour of the Independence Mine State Historical Park at the Mine Mangers's House, which houses the Visitor Center and museum. Inside you'll see displays about mining, natural history and the Independence Mine story.

name: Gold Mint Glacier
description: Gold Mint Glacier features 14 miles of hiking trails near Palmer, AK.

name: Denali State Park
description: Several trails, ranging in difficulty, offer hikers the opportunity to view Alaska's pristine wilderness areas.

name: Tok Area Parks
description: Eagle Trail offers two short trails as well as an 8 mile hike to the Tok Trophy Sheep Management Area; Moon Lake and Tok River are more popular for a variety of activities.

name: Denali National Park
description:
A majority of the Trails in Denali National Park are located around the park entrance and vary in difficulty from ADA accessible to very strenuous trails. <br />
<br />
The Salvage River Trail (Mile 13-15 on Park Road) offers a few on and off trail hikes that range from moderate to strenuous. <br />
<br />
Eielson Visitor Center (Mile 66 on Park Road) contains two trails above the treeline. <br />
<br />
Hiking off-trail is allowed but should research the proper documentation and permits as required.

name: Parks Highway Bike Trail
description: This paved ADA accessible trail is a multi-use trail that connects the travels between the Park entrance,  Nenana River and terminates in the developed district of the park.

name: Jonesville Trail
description: This foot traffic only trail is a shortcut between the Parks Highway Bike Trail and the gravel bike path.

name: McKinley Station Trail
description: The 1.6 mile scenic hike offers beautiful views as it passes through Riley Creek Campground, under the Alaska Railroad Trestle and works its way up to the Triple Lakes Trail.

name: Horseshoe Lake
description: Trail is relatively short and flat with a elevation difference of 250 feet. The trail provides access to views of Horseshoe Lake

name: Chena River Lakes
description: Miscellaneous trails throughout area.

name: Harding Lake State  Recreation Area
description: Hiking along nature trails is another activity available at Harding Lake SRA.

name: Chena River State Recreation Site
description: This 29-acre park sits on the banks of the Chena River, and features river-side walking trails.
